fields.headline: Figo firing lethal Real
fields.trailText: As if defecting to the arch enemy were not enough to make Luis Figo the most despised footballer to cross swords with Barcelona, the positive effect he is having at Real Madrid has now truly twisted the knife.
fields.body:
As if defecting to the arch enemy were not, in itself, enough to make Luis Figo the most despised footballer to cross swords with Barcelona. But however appalled the Catalans were in the summer, his unpalatable act of treachery now makes them even more sickened considering the positive, and profound, impact he is having at Real Madrid. When Sports Director Jorge Valdano noted his side were 'learning how to roll their sleeves up and play in the ugly games,' he might have added a small gracias to Figo, a maestro motivated to perform whatever the weather, whoever the opposition. This has been a Real trademark conspicuous by its absence in recent seasons. Now it is back, Madrid look untouchable.

Figo's capacity for bestowing as much consistency as class on his team has had a knock-on effect and the team are galvanised. Figo, who dispatched the last-minute penalty to beat Lazio last week, embodies the philosophy of relishing both grim and glamorous. His £39 million transfer may have been controversial but, now the dust has settled, he is in his element. 'It was a difficult decision for Luis to leave Barcelona and come here, but his past is not what counts. What matters is that he is football crazy. He is a model professional and understands what defending Real Madrid's colours means,' enthused coach Vicente del Bosque.

What a difference to this time last year when their megabucks and mega-publicity new signing, a certain Nicolas Anelka, scored even less frequently than he smiled, felt persecuted, alienated his team-mates and went on strike. Real's normally diplomatic coach appears not too sorry to see the back of him, calling him an egomaniac and growling about the fact he never 'identified' with Real Madrid. That is a sin more cardinal than not trying or throwing wobblies. A Real Madrid player does not behave as if he is at any old club and last long.

Del Bosque, all strong principles with a human touch, has had a big influence on Madrid's improvement. Under his calm stewardship internal strife is no longer an issue. There can be no greater tribute to the esteem in which he is held by his squad that quality players who do not make the starting 11, and naturally there are several every game, no longer go moaning to the Spanish press.

With Anelka gone and Figo established, Real are top of La Liga, and the best performers so far in the Champions League second phase (they are the only team with a 100 per cent record, and are top scorers by a considerable margin). With such irresistible form Real are expected to win their domestic title at a breeze and, although they are too cautious to crow about a possible ninth (yes, ninth!) European Cup triumph before the knock-out lottery has even begun, the general thinking is that the current incarnation is superior to the Madrileños recently crowned the continent's finest in 1998 and 2000.

Who can stop them? Very hard to look beyond Manchester United, and possibly Bayern Munich - though group winners cannot meet in the quarter-finals - and even they face a job and a half suppressing a team who appear to race each other in the goalscoring charts for fun. Admittedly Madrid are by no means perfect. They remain vulnerable defensively and it's no secret they are in the market for a centre-half - with Lazio's silky Alessandro Nesta top of their wish list - but hey, chances are they always have another goal or few in the bag. Take a look at the list of Champions League marksmen.

Five different Real players have three goals or more so far. They possess matchwinners all over the park, so if Figo can't score, Raul can. And if Raul can't score, Guti can. And if Guti can't score, Roberto Carlos can (we could go on). Most importantly, Real possess the desire as well as the devastating finishing to outscore the opposition.

This refreshing ethos that permeates life at the Santiago Bernebeu has been something of an obsession since the club's change of ownership last summer.

While the new President, Florentino Perez, concerns himself with reducing their £170m debts, Valdano and his recently appointed assistant, Real icon Emilio Butragueno, are on a mission to hammer home to each and every player their responsibility to the legendary white shirt. It is something they take very seriously. Neither primadonnas who couldn't be bothered when it rained away from home, nor egos who bickered in the dressing room would be tolerated.

Valdano, who introduced Raul into the first team at 17 during his spell as Madrid's coach and the man who once said, 'I am interested in football as entertainment.You have to play attractively, otherwise it is like making love to a tree,' cuts an imposing figure as the club's statesman and public face. Butragueno's role is to be closer to the players. He is around to give them advice and to brainwash them about how blessed they are to play for Real Madrid.

Figo, having once been the flagbearer of what it means to play for Barcelona, seems to have swapped allegiances with astonishing poise even though no one would dare to imagine it has been easy. His old club visit his new home in a couple of weeks and doubtless the whole hyperbole machine will splurge into overdrive again. Figo doesn't want to get involved until this season's honours are handed out.

This May, if he owns something that eluded him at Barcelona - a European Cup medal for example - that ought to convince him he made the right choice.

webTitle: Anti-cancer pill to lull tumours into deep sleep

fields.headline: Anti-cancer pill to lull tumours into deep sleep
fields.standfirst: Days of wonder
fields.trailText: Scientists believe they are close to developing a pill to cure cancer after unravelling the mysteries of why tumours grow out of control. The findings could radically simplify treatment of Britain's biggest killer, with one in three people at risk of contracting it and one in four dying from it.
fields.body:
Scientists believe they are close to developing a pill to cure cancer after unravelling the mysteries of why tumours grow out of control. The findings could radically simplify treatment of Britain's biggest killer, with one in three people at risk of contracting it and one in four dying from it.

The Cancer Research Campaign hopes the breakthrough will help it to develop a 'chemical lullaby' to stop cancer cells dividing and lure them into an 'everlasting sleep'.

The findings on why cancers don't stop growing will be published in the science magazine Nature this week. Healthy cells normally fall into a permanent sleep or 'senescence' after dividing a certain number of times. In contrast, cancer cells continue to grow and spread. Researchers have pinpointed molecules that act as 'tumour suppressors', telling the cells to stop dividing.

Dr Naoko Ohtani, who is heading the research at the Paterson Institute in Manchester, has now unravelled how these molecules send cells to sleep. She said: 'We know there is a group of molecules that induce senescence, and we believe that in the future we may be able to mimic this to produce a completely new cancer treatment.'

Current cancer treatments involve very harsh techniques with severe side-effects. However, the new research opens up the prospect of a far more effective treatment that simply sends the cancers to sleep.

Dr Leslie Walker, head of science information at the Cancer Research Campaign, said: 'We hope this work will lead to a nice, clean, targeted anti-cancer pill that you can simply pop in your mouth at home.'

Doctors would only need to identifythe cancer and then prescribe the appropriate pill. Researcher Eiji Hara said: 'It will be five or six more years before we develop a drug.'

Scientists discovered about 40 years ago that healthy cells have a limit to how many times they divide before succumbing to senescence. However, it is now known that there are at least around 20 different 'tumour suppressor' genes which, if faulty, can lead to cells dividing forever, forming a tumour.

The researchers at Manchester have unlocked the biological mechanisms of how this happens, opening the way to designing a drug to stop it.

Professor Gordon McVie, director-general of the Cancer Research Campaign, said: 'Cancer cells' continual activity - their refusal to go to sleep - is one of the key problems facing cancer doctors today. This research could lead to a brand-new way of treating cancer.'

anthony.browne@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Butler serves, Blues prevail
fields.standfirst: Birmingham City Adebola 36, O'Connor 57   West Brom Butler 38 att: 25,025 :   2  :   1
fields.trailText: A satisfying victory and a deserved one for Birmingham, who successfully put the club's first major final for 38 years to the back of their minds.
fields.body:
A satisfying victory and a deserved one for Birmingham, who successfully put the club's first major final for 38 years to the back of their minds.

Trevor Francis' team certainly needed to, for Albion's commitment was total. The prolific Lee Hughes had a lean afternoon, but almost claimed an injury time equaliser with a shot across the face of goal

In the event Martin O'Connor, a midfield beaver in tandem with Bryan Hughes, rounded off a captain's performance with a deserved winner that took his side above their neighbours.

In recent seasons Birmingham have been head and shoulders above their rivals, in terms of league positions and the outcome of this fixture. This time, however, Albion share a top-six position and are looking an equally decent bet for the play-offs. Consider Birmingham's Worthington Cup final against Liverpool next Sunday, and it was no surprise that there was a buzz about this game. Birmingham weathered an early rush from Hughes and could have been two goals up by 30 minutes. Dele Adebola turned his marker splendidly to seek out the far corner with his shot, but was denied by Brian Jensen. The Brazilian Marcelo connected with a Nicky Eaden corner to force the keeper to turn the ball over the crossbar. Eaden's second corner, from the opposite side, came loose to Bryan Hughes who scooped the chance over from three yards.

Then Hughes was too high with a shot from the edge of the penalty box after Adebola set him up, and it was no shock when the hosts took the lead, Eaden heading back from the far post to Adebola who nodded wide of Jensen. Within two minutes Albion were level, with Tony Butler heading home a free-kick from Ruel Fox for his first goal for the club.

Marcelo had a good chance to regain the lead with a free header, which he steered at Jensen. A more difficult offering fell to Albion substitute Bob Taylor, introduced for the second half to replace Jason Roberts.

Birmingham went 2-1 up through O'Connor, whose drive from 18-yards went in off the post after Hughes and Adebola had set up the opening. Minutes later O'Connor was shown the yellow card for a late, lunging challenge on Richard Sneekes.

fields.headline: The perfect fashion show
fields.standfirst: Maria Grachvogel
fields.trailText: Maria Grachvogel.
fields.body:
The point is to show off your clothes, and to create a sexy impression. People sense a feeling the moment they arrive, so every element of your show needs to say the right thing about your collection.

The best model for a catwalk show has got to be a bit of an actress. Girls like Jodie Kidd really project. She doesn't just walk up and down, she has an understanding of what you're trying to communicate. A celebrity model works best when she normally wears your clothes. When Victoria Beckham modelled for me, it was amazing publicity, but it seemed like the most natural thing in the world.

All these clothes and models need a venue, and it's hard to find a perfect one. You've got all sorts of dull logistics, such as capacity, to consider. I'd love to show at the Criterion, but we could only seat 160, and people would scream at me for using such a small venue. The trouble is trying to seat all the important people. The front row is prime position. My dream front row contains Suzie Menkes, Anna Wintour and all the top UK and international press. Sitting beside them are the celebrities - Victoria, Madonna, Uma Thurman. And obviously all the key buyers from top stores in the world.

A lot of the show's success depends on the timing. If you show before lunch, you meet the newspaper deadlines, but it's very anticlimactic. I like the idea of staging it at cocktail time. The tradition is to serve champagne, but that's so boring. You've got to create an occasion worthy of a vodka martini and a glamorous party for all those front-row people.

 Maria Grachvogel will be showing at London Fashion Week on 23 February.

fields.headline: Frock tactics
fields.standfirst: Bandaged limbs, stuffed exotic birds, fluttering moths and two-way mirrors... an Alexander McQueen show can sometimes seem more like a horror film than fashion. Louise Davis has an exclusive preview of the auteur's spring collection
fields.trailText: Bandaged limbs, stuffed exotic birds, fluttering moths and two-way mirrors... an Alexander McQueen show can sometimes seem more like a horror film than fashion. Louise Davis has an exclusive preview of the auteur's spring collection.
fields.body:
Monday, 1.20pm: It's less than 36 hours to Alexander McQueen's spring/summer 2001 show on a bleak September afternoon. I'm standing in the middle of a draught-ridden warehouse down a grubby side street in London SW1. A small army of men are laying cable and erecting plastic seats. This is possibly the most unglamorous location in London. In the centre, there's a huge, illuminated glass chamber with white padded walls blasting 100,000 megawatts of lights. It's like the set for an eerie Hollywood sci-fi movie or a scene from One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest. Tomorrow, this will be Alexander McQueen's catwalk - a stark auditorium where fashion's VIPs will sit alongside the likes of Grace Jones, Gywneth Paltrow, Sharleen Spiteri and co - all of them whirled into a surreal fantasy world with gobsmacking clothes and wild- looking models. The McQueen dream will come alive for just 15 minutes.

Preparing a show is a monumental task. McQueen's secret is a vital group of behind-the-scenes experts: producers Sam Gainsbury and Anna Whiting, art director Joseph Bennett, lighting director Dan Landing and DJ John Gosling. They get together with McQueen and Katy England (his muse/stylist/design assistant) four months before the show to clarify the concept. 'Most of us don't usually do fashion ,' explains Landing who usually works on film, video and TV commercials, and is here clutching a large, round 60s film bulb. But McQueen's show is special. 'He looks beyond fashion - he makes it an event.'

The catwalk is a glass chamber with surveillance glass for walls. When the lights are on in the capsule, the models inside will see only reflections of themselves. The audience will be voyeurs.

The team has a seven-day turnaround at the venue. They arrive at 5am each morning. By the time the show begins, nearly 200 people (carpenters, metal workers, painters, model makers, electricians, wardrobe assistants, dressers, hair and make-up artists) will have been involved. It's an expensive process. This show has cost more than £70,000 and has been funded by American Express, which has supported the designer for the past seven seasons. It's an unlikely partnership - the bad-boy designer and the big corporate credit-card company - but it works.

4pm: Right now, fashion's most innovative showman is looking edgy, sitting in his EC1 studio with England, making final checks to each outfit. The office is mayhem. Amie Witton, McQueen's press officer, is looking pale and strained, finalising backstage passes and seating plans, and fending off endless press enquiries. Scores of skinny 18-year-old girls in bleached-denim drainpipes, scuffed-up stilettos and customised 80s T-shirts run around answering phones, while techno blasts from the stereo. 'Ha ha, can you believe this bloke from Girl About Town wants a ticket?' shouts a tall, blonde cockney girl, temporarily breaking her panic-stricken expression for a good laugh. As if. McQueen's tickets are like gold dust.

Tuesday, 2pm: Backstage the mood is tense. It's less than five hours until the show begins. The fashion pack are running around London attending other shows in anticipation of the biggie. This is the show of the week. The one everyone will be talking about. It's the reason foreign press and buyers come to London. Gosling is pumping house music front of stage. Models stalk in one by one to get their hair and make-up done. Whiting's mobile phone is ringing every two minutes. Bennett is making final checks. Today, there are 32 girls in the show. Jade Parfitt, Alec Wek and Jacquetta Wheeler enter. Security is strict. Even the models have to prove who they are before they are let into the warehouse. There's a chart of Polaroids at the entrance and, as they enter, they are ticked off like school pupils. Erin O'Connor and Karen Elson are next in. They sit drinking coffee, smoking, laughing, waiting to be dressed.

3.15pm: Katy England, clad in the skinniest denim hipsters and a cropped T-shirt, is busy unpacking insane creations. There's a dress made entirely from mussels and an ostrich-feather bodice made from polythene bags. McQueen, sporting his usual uniform of jeans, trainers, T-shirt and tattoos, is silent, laying out accessories and checking garments like a six-year-old boy tending a new railway set. He is pensive as he wanders around checking that everything is perfect. Hairdresser Guido and his team are binding models' heads in bandages. Make-up artist Val Garland is painting faces a pallid, creamy shade. 'Is anyone looking at what I am doing?' she scowls at her team, who are busy gossiping with Erin and Alec.

There are rows and rows of clothes (feathery concoctions, brocade suits, wooden bodices, sea-shell dresses), trays of accessories, and there's an old man in a dark room with a box of exotic moths, bred specially for the show's finale. He is making sure they don't come alive too soon. There are girls at sewing machines, working quickly, putting finishing touches to garments. Shaun Leane, the avant-garde jewellery designer, is unpacking an elaborate mother-of-pearl corset trimmed with a lethal-looking metal neckpiece that looks like a piece of samurai armour.

6.15pm: Kate Moss waltzes in with a pregnant Sadie Frost and plants a big kiss on Guido's cheek. All the models were meant to be here by 4pm, but this is Kate, and Kate can do anything. 'Right, who's doing Kate?' screams Garland, looking eagerly for a free assistant. Everyone knows everyone else, except the new girls, who sit there daunted, a little scared and clearly bemused by the whole pantomime. Jade has just been fitted into her elaborate eagle dress and had two stuffed birds placed either side of her head.

8pm: The show is an hour late. The audience are sitting staring at reflections of themselves in the glass chamber. Whooosssh - the baseline kicks in. The show begins. First on is Kate Moss, who whirls herself into the capsule shaking her head in a mad frenzy and staring only at her reflection on the walls. Then Jade, with her eagle-head dress, followed by Erin in a heavy shell number. Karen Elson comes off, trips up and nearly impales herself on the spiky Shaun Leane neckpiece. For a split second, everyone stops breathing, before Elson erupts into hysterical laughter. The last model goes on, then the capsule within the chamber shatters and a voluptuous nude lies there as moths flap around the chamber like a scene from Silence of the Lambs.

8.20pm: McQueen is sweating, his heart racing, looking deadly serious and slightly confused. The A-list tumble backstage. 'Kaaaaaaate,' shouts Gywneth Paltrow across the room. 'Daaaaarrrhling, how are you?' The two embrace. Champagne corks pop, TV crews and paparazzi photographers join the scene while McQueen dashes behind a black curtain to do a private interview. The guests will head off to the glittering after party at the Mayfair Club for champagne. Meanwhile, the clothes will be packed and sent back to the studio. Tomorrow, the set will be pulled down and emptied. And the moths will all soon be dead.

It's an unlikely partnership - the bad-boy designer and the big corporate credit-card company - but it works. 4pm: Right now, fashion's most innovative showman is looking edgy, sitting in his EC1 studio with England, making final checks to each outfit. The office is mayhem. Amie Witton, McQueen's press officer, is looking pale and strained, finalising backstage passes and seating plans, and fending off endless press enquiries. Scores of skinny 18-year-old girls in bleached-denim drainpipes, scuffed-up stilettos and customised 80s T-shirts run around answering phones, while techno blasts from the stereo. 'Ha ha, can you believe this bloke from Girl About Town wants a ticket?' shouts a tall, blonde cockney girl, temporarily breaking her panic-stricken expression for a good laugh. As if. McQueen's tickets are like gold dust. Tuesday, 2pm: Backstage the mood is tense. It's less than five hours until the show begins. The fashion pack are running around London attending other shows in anticipation of the biggie. This is the show of the week. The one everyone will be talking about. It's the reason foreign press and buyers come to London. Gosling is pumping house music front of stage. Models stalk in one by one to get their hair and make-up done. Whiting's mobile phone is ringing every two minutes. Bennett is making final checks. Today, there are 32 girls in the show. Jade Parfitt, Alec Wek and Jacquetta Wheeler enter. Security is strict. Even the models have to prove who they are before they are let into the warehouse. There's a chart of Polaroids at the entrance and, as they enter, they are ticked off like school pupils. Erin O'Connor and Karen Elson are next in. They sit drinking coffee, smoking, laughing, waiting to be dressed. 3.15pm: Katy England, clad in the skinniest denim hipsters and a cropped T-shirt, is busy unpacking insane creations. There's a dress made entirely from mussels and an ostrich-feather bodice made from polythene bags. McQueen, sporting his usual uniform of jeans, trainers, T-shirt and tattoos, is silent, laying out accessories and checking garments like a six-year-old boy tending a new railway set. He is pensive as he wanders around checking that everything is perfect. Hairdresser Guido and his team are binding models' heads in bandages. Make-up artist Val Garland is painting faces a pallid, creamy shade. 'Is anyone looking at what I am doing?' she scowls at her team, who are busy gossiping with Erin and Alec. There are rows and rows of clothes (feathery concoctions, brocade suits, wooden bodices, sea-shell dresses), trays of accessories, and there's an old man in a dark room with a box of exotic moths, bred specially for the show's finale. He is making sure they don't come alive too soon. There are girls at sewing machines, working quickly, putting finishing touches to garments. Shaun Leane, the avant-garde jewellery designer, is unpacking an elaborate mother-of-pearl corset trimmed with a lethal-looking metal neckpiece that looks like a piece of samurai armour. 6.15pm: Kate Moss waltzes in with a pregnant Sadie Frost and plants a big kiss on Guido's cheek. All the models were meant to be here by 4pm, but this is Kate, and Kate can do anything. 'Right, who's doing Kate?' screams Garland, looking eagerly for a free assistant. Everyone knows everyone else, except the new girls, who sit there daunted, a little scared and clearly bemused by the whole pantomime. Jade has just been fitted into her elaborate eagle dress and had two stuffed birds placed either side of her head. 8pm: The show is an hour late. The audience are sitting staring at reflections of themselves in the glass chamber. Whooosssh - the baseline kicks in. The show begins. First on is Kate Moss, who whirls herself into the capsule shaking her head in a mad frenzy and staring only at her reflection on the walls. Then Jade, with her eagle-head dress, followed by Erin in a heavy shell number. Karen Elson comes off, trips up and nearly impales herself on the spiky Shaun Leane neckpiece. For a split second, everyone stops breathing, before Elson erupts into hysterical laughter. The last model goes on, then the capsule within the chamber shatters and a voluptuous nude lies there as moths flap around the chamber like a scene from Silence of the Lambs. 8.20pm: McQueen is sweating, his heart racing, looking deadly serious and slightly confused. The A-list tumble backstage. 'Kaaaaaaate,' shouts Gywneth Paltrow across the room. 'Daaaaarrrhling, how are you?' The two embrace. Champagne corks pop, TV crews and paparazzi photographers join the scene while McQueen dashes behind a black curtain to do a private interview. The guests will head off to the glittering after party at the Mayfair Club for champagne. Meanwhile, the clothes will be packed and sent back to the studio. Tomorrow, the set will be pulled down and emptied. And the moths will all soon be dead.

webTitle: On the trail of the shy abbot

fields.headline: On the trail of the shy abbot
fields.standfirst: Daniel Whitaker  heads for a secluded Bulgarian monastery  that is slowly giving up centuries-old secrets to a wave of modern-day pilgrims
fields.trailText: Daniel Whitaker heads for a secluded Bulgarian monastery that is slowly giving up centuries-old secrets to a wave of modern-day pilgrims.
fields.body:
The full-bearded, cheerfully stout monk who checked me in for my stay at Rila monastery did not speak much English. I wanted to meet the Igumen, or abbot, whom I hoped could explain a life in monastic seclusion perched on the steep mountainside, and perhaps some of the mysteries of Bulgaria itself. And when I asked about the Igumen, the monk beamed and reassured me: 'Will come later'.

For now I was happy that after closing its doors during the Communist era, the monastery was open to foreigners weary from hiking or curious to escape the temporal world for a night or two. An aged key in my hand, I trudged the winding corridors to my guest cell. Inside was a thin mattress barely covering a metal-framed bed. The Bulgarian Orthodox Church allows no curtains, hot water or shower to come between you and God.

What Rila lacks in comfort it more than gains in its setting. At daybreak a chorus of sparrows heralded the sun, which in turn brought into glorious focus the soaring pine-carpeted peaks that surround the monastery.

More than a thousand years ago, Rila was home to Bulgaria's patron saint, the mystical hermit John Rilski. He shunned the church, living in a cave, an early example of the Bulgarian enigmatic and spiritual tendency. In true medieval fashion, he was considered so holy that Hungarian and Byzantine kings fought wars over his bones; his left hand toured Russia in the sixteenth century as a church fund-raising exercise.

But the monastery that followed him became important because without it the Balkans would be different today. Throughout five centuries of Ottoman rule, behind Rila monastery's high stone walls was one of the few places where monks were able to keep alive Christian and Slavic culture. Rila was an island of peace. Around it, say local guides, surged a hostile sea of violent Ottoman despots and their henchmen, alternating rape and pillage with innovative ways to martyr local peasants.

While further north, in Transylvania, Count Drakul set about impaling Turks on stakes, Rila's monks trod a quieter path, seeking to copy as many books as possible in a country where written languages other than Turkish were disappearing. They taught poetry and song, and prayed for deliverance.

I was not the only one drawn to Rila. A steady trickle of Bulgarians, Greeks and Russians came, though I seemed to be the only one staying. I thought the Igumen would be able to tell me more of what Rila meant to these pilgrims, but a smiling shrug indicated that I wouldn't be seeing him immediately. So I ventured out for breakfast in one of two restaurants behind the monastery. I had a freshly baked loaf steaming in the cold air, salty, feta-like sirene cheese and bozá, a tepid beige drink apparently made from barley and honey.

I had been encouraged to drink it as something very Balkan: 'Europe ends when people begin to drink bozá,' I was told. I felt very un-Balkan and, thirsty though I was, could not finish it.

A group of friendly Polish students camping nearby said that further south, at Rozhen monastery, locals had told them the monks there were linked to the Bulgarian mafia and drove BMWs. But Rila's brethren did not seem like that - those floor- length black habits, beards and contemplative gazes surely were not just for show?

I still wanted to know more of the monastic life. After learning that there were now only nine resident monks left - down from 400 before the Communist regime - I was told that only the Igumen could answer further questions. Where was he? 'Soon will come,' said one brother.

Out of the building and along a path through dense conifers I passed the well-tended grave of James Bourchier, the Times' s Balkan correspondent for 33 years, who went on regular walks nearby with Tsar Ferdinand, ruler of Bulgaria from 1887 until 1918. Bourchier loved Rila so much he asked to be buried there.

The men's rambling must have seemed normal in Bulgaria, where hill walking was declared patriotic in the nineteenth century. Hiking makes sense in a country without much money and Bulgaria has some of Europe's finest highland scenery.

I walked another mile up the path to the 'miracle hole', where the hermit Rilski spent his last 20 years. Legend has it that a sinner would be unable to pass through the narrow back exit. The Polish students who were with me slithered lithely through. In fact, it was the well fed, rather than the sinful, that the passageway seemed to discriminate against. I just made it, but probably would not have done after the lunch I was to eat back behind the monastery. Along with what may be the world's best tomatoes and peppers in a shopska salad, there was pileski tridki (Pope's nose, a chicken dish), washed down with Kamenitsa beer, a fine way to slake a hiker's thirst. Afterwards, leaden clouds and my nagging curiosity about Rila's mysterious abbot persuaded me to make a final search for him.

First, I took in for the last time the unwelcoming sheer walls that surround the monastery. Venturing through the deep entrance arch, you enter what seems to be another world. Carnivalesque murals cover the central cloister - biblical terror for a pre-cinema age. With all the grotesque detail you could hope for, they vividly explain the Seven Deadly Sins and what awaits in hell (and, with less passion, or precision, heaven) so that even illiterates would know what was at stake in daily life. These frescoes, by the Samokovan Zahari Zogrof, won the classification for the monastery as a World Cultural Heritage Site.

The interior of Rila's central church is thickly fragrant with incense and the smell of rich, dark wood. The only sound is the crackle of the slender yellow wax candles. A side chapel holds the heart of Tsar Boris (Ferdinand's son), who refused to hand over Bulgaria's Jews to the Nazis, then died suddenly after a meeting in Berlin. This being the Balkans, poisoning is the only explanation that people will accept.

The entire monastery complex is a work of art in itself. An outer loop of four-storey, painted wood and stone galleries hold the monks' quarters. They create a colonnaded passage around the open central courtyard, which houses the church, frescoes and a medieval tower with the mountains as a towering solid backdrop. If you decide to spend your life in a remote monastery, why not let it be beautiful?

As captivating as the buildings is the monks' collection of illuminated manuscripts and artworks. I spent longest looking at Raphael's cross, a 3ft high wooden carving containing 140 biblical scenes with more than 1,500 human figures, each the height of a fingernail. Brother Raphael laboured a dozen years carving it, losing his sight, but embodying dedication.

'But where is the Igumen?' I asked anyone in black. I received the same answers and smiles as before. Disappointed, I set off back to Sofia by car in drizzle on the narrow, winding road down the mountains. I looked back and glimpsed a ghostly, white-robed, silver-haired figure gliding along an upper gallery. It could only be the Igumen.

But I had absorbed some of the monks' fatalism now, taken in Bulgaria's spiritual mystique, and I didn't want too many answers. I opted to respect the leader's elusiveness and went on driving.

Getting there

Balkan Bulgarian Airlines offers flights from London to Sofia from £193, including tax. Tours, including negotiations with ecclesiastical authorities, can be arranged through Balkania Travel (Tel: 020 7538 8654).

Staying at Rila monastery costs £15 a night. Rila is about two hours' drive from Sofia.

fields.headline: Putting on the glitz
fields.standfirst: At 21,  Julie Myerson ventured to Milan in search of romance and adventure. Now, older, wiser and with lots more cash, she returns to Italy's capital of fashion
fields.trailText: At 21, Julie Myerson ventured to Milan in search of romance and adventure. Now, older, wiser and with lots more cash, she returns to Italy's capital of fashion.
fields.body:
In 1981 I despaired of life at Nottingham Central Library and ran off to Milan. I was 21 and two things urgently beckoned: a vague offer of a job teaching English and an even vaguer hope of a boy called Franco. I'd fallen badly for him while au-pairing in Florence two years earlier.

I stepped off the train at the Stazione Centrale. In my bag, a giant bar of Toblerone and a return ticket. Also: Simone de Beauvoir's autobiography, two pairs of knickers and my Charlie lip gloss. I had nowhere to stay and enough lire to survive for two days, maybe three. It was July, late afternoon. The city was empty, sulking under a haze of heat. On the steps of the station, the scattering of slumbering backpackers looked like Michelangelo frescoes, stubbly faces tender in sleep.

I spent the first night in a goodish hotel. It swallowed half my money, but I hoped that next morning I could track down the English Woman With The Job Offer. I slept well, washed myself and my other pair of knickers, ate one packet of complimentary breadsticks and bagged everything else - fruit, sewing kit, shoe wipes. I found the English Woman's apartment in a yellow, crumbling Palazzo on the Bohemian edges of the Brera district. I rang the bell. Eventually a boy's smoke-wreathed head appeared at the window and told me Signora Robinson was 'away at the lakes - not expected back for ages - maybe try again in September?' I went to a bar, ordered a glass of water and tried not to cry.

That night I chose the cheapest pensione I could find. It was airless, sweaty and throbbed with mosquitoes. The communal WC was at the end of a corridor up and down which hobbled a sinister one-legged man with an eye patch. I listened all night to the relentless pock-pock of his crutches and waited for dawn.

I decided to force myself to eat one triangle of Toblerone each hour while I worked out what to do. I wandered through the streets around the Duomo, gazed dizzily up at the vertiginous ceilings of the Galleria Vittorio Emanuele. Girls rushed past me into the pink neon-lit palace that was Fiorucci, a place of velvet jeans and feather boas. I looked at my shabby, stained dungarees and thought about getting the first train home.

Then something extraordinary happened. Something so serendipitous that it seemed straight off the pages of my De Beauvoir. I bumped into a hurrying woman laden with Ferragamo carrier bags. 'La Julie! Madonna, non lo credo! Che fai qui a Milano?' It was the mother of the boy I'd au-paired two years previously. She pushed her Gucci shades up into her honey-streaked hair and demanded to know where I was staying. When I hesitated, she explained that she was off on holiday and her Milan apartment was about to be empty for three weeks. Would I house-sit? Within hours, I was soaking in her huge marble bath, nibbling on Buitoni toasts from her cupboards and prowling reverently around her bedroom, sniffing unguents.

Next day I met up with Franco. We sat in the Piazza Cavour and discovered that we had nothing to say to each other. He admitted that he 'sort of' had a girlfriend these days. Relieved, I returned to the safety of my hushed marble apartment, relishing the romance of my aloneness in this big, seething city.

That was then. Now, 20 years on, I have a man, three kids, four cats, a mortgage, a dog. I no longer catch trains to unknown cities in search of hazy jobs and hazier boys.

On a rainy morning in November, Jonathan and I touch down for a romantic break in Milan. My first glimpse of the city in 20 years is from a taxi as we are whisked through the Alpine downpour to the five-star Hotel Carlton Baglioni in the chic fashion district. Past Emporio Armani, Hugo Boss, Versace and in through the revolving doors to the chintzy gilt reception.

Our room, with its heavy pink opulence, looks straight down on the Prada lingerie shop. This is a city where one branch of Prada will not do (ultimately we counted four). Instead of crutches, this time Miu Miu heels clop past my window.

There's something magical about leaving England in the drizzly morning and having lunch in another country. It justifies any chilly 6am trip to Heathrow. By one, we're eating squid salad and garlic spaghetti at the quirky, muralled Ristorante Bagutta - here they hatched the Milanese equivalent of the Booker Prize, the Premio Bagutta. We then stroll through the Lombardy cloud to the Piazza del Duomo where I struggle to get my bearings: on which side of the Galleria did I bump into Donatella? Where was that Hellhole Pensione?

We walk past Foot Locker, the Rinascente department store and a couple of CD megastores. 'But it used to be so glamorous around here,' I sigh.

'It hasn't changed. You were cheaply satisfied then.'

I insist we check out Fiorucci. But though the neon pink glow is unchanged, it's just tacky and kitsch now - a place for skinny, moping teenagers, not Mothers of Three who have their eye on Dolce and Gabbana.

On the immaculate paved white stones of della Spiga and Montenapoleone, my good humour is suddenly restored. Here, every Italian designer you've ever heard of nestles invitingly in the autumn dusk. Inside, huge granite spaces and perfect girls in black with sleek hair and sleeker senses of humour stand rigidly at your shoulder as you look in the mirror.

In Romeo Gigli, a rust velvet dress seems to have no price tag. After groping for an uncool amount of time around the sleeve and neckline, I give up and slink out. Another shop has price tags but no mirrors - mere minimal slivers of glass to offer back a collage version of yourself.

We refresh ourselves with drinks in Bar Zucca in the Galleria. After that eked-out coffee in 1981, I take a vengeful pleasure in sipping a Campari (invented in this very bar) and eating olives while watching the world go by. 'There's nothing much to do here really except eat and drink and shop, is there?' I say happily. And shepherd my five carrier bags closer to my legs.

Next day, after coffee and brioches in the elegant, eternal Cafe Cova on the Via Gesu, we stroll over to see Mantegna's hyperperspective Dead Christ at the Pinoteca di Brera, where art lovers gaze reverently at the Bellinis and Tintorettos and Caravaggios, and art students from the adjoining school roll joints on the guano-covered steps below.

Then it's lunch round the corner at the Santini Bistrot on Via Ancona, where I eat something that now supplants mashed potato as All-Time Favourite Food. A cowpat of runny polenta is topped with two almost-orange fried eggs and then shavings of white truffle. J tells me someone just paid five grand for a truffle the size of a potato. Pounds, not lire.

And if the trip is turning into a catalogue of meals, then what better revenge for the girl who previously existed here on Toblerone and hope? In the Sant'Ambroeus tearoom on Corso Matteoti near La Scala, the tiny pastry horns that garnish J's latte would then have fed me for a day. If only, back then, I'd visited Coquetel in the Via Vetere where the fashionable Milanese young pick from free pizza, tortillas and olives along with their margaritas and bloody marys - and Grande Fratello on a giant TV screen.

Yes, Milan boasts Leonardo's Last Supper and more galleries and churches than you can count, but it's a modern city, a vortex of industries devoted to meeting the pleasures of now. You don't go to Milan for the Renaissance charm of Florence or the earthenware simplicity of Naples, it's all about wallowing in that Italian ability to beautify life and meet all its sensual possibilities.

So, to hell with culture, we're here to shop and eat. We find the extraordinary Osteria dell-Operetta in the Corso di Porta Ticinese by chance. One moment we're in a dark street in the taxiless drizzle, next we're trying a curtained door and suddenly in the middle of the funkiest osteria in town. Here, freshly made pastas come in ice-bucket-sized copper cauldrons, insalata, soppressa and cotoletti swamp giant plates.

Admittedly, the sophisticated ambience is sporadically shattered when, without warning, the lights dim and Boney M or Wham! hit the speakers as some blushing (female) customer receives a slice of torta with a sparkling sparkler - and an obligatory dance with the waiter. So many birthdays? Odds against it. I eat my second course in trepidation.

And three nights later, back home, kids, cats, dog and family maelstrom also seem a little more manageable.

'But, hang on, you never saw the English woman about the job?' says J, ever unwilling to leave a narrative strand untied.

'She rang once I was back home in Nottingham and offered me something. I turned her down. I'd only have fallen in love with another Franco and got stuck there forever.'

'You might have fallen for a rich Milanese businessman,' he says, 'with groomed hair and one of those handbaggy briefcases. Just think, all that polenta, all those carrier bags.'

'But I'd have missed Peter Jones. And mashed potato,' I say loyally (fingers crossed behind my back).

Getting there

Julie Myerson travelled to Milan with Kirker Holidays (020 7231 3333). A three-night break staying at the five-star Carlton Baglioni costs from £628 per person, including flights with British Midland and transfers.

For further information contact the Italian Tourist Office on 020 7408 1254.

 Julie Myerson's novel 'Laura Blundy' is published in paperback this month by Fourth Estate.

Che fai qui a Milano?' It was the mother of the boy I'd au-paired two years previously. She pushed her Gucci shades up into her honey-streaked hair and demanded to know where I was staying. When I hesitated, she explained that she was off on holiday and her Milan apartment was about to be empty for three weeks. Would I house-sit? Within hours, I was soaking in her huge marble bath, nibbling on Buitoni toasts from her cupboards and prowling reverently around her bedroom, sniffing unguents. Next day I met up with Franco. We sat in the Piazza Cavour and discovered that we had nothing to say to each other. He admitted that he 'sort of' had a girlfriend these days. Relieved, I returned to the safety of my hushed marble apartment, relishing the romance of my aloneness in this big, seething city. That was then. Now, 20 years on, I have a man, three kids, four cats, a mortgage, a dog. I no longer catch trains to unknown cities in search of hazy jobs and hazier boys. On a rainy morning in November, Jonathan and I touch down for a romantic break in Milan. My first glimpse of the city in 20 years is from a taxi as we are whisked through the Alpine downpour to the five-star Hotel Carlton Baglioni in the chic fashion district. Past Emporio Armani, Hugo Boss, Versace and in through the revolving doors to the chintzy gilt reception. Our room, with its heavy pink opulence, looks straight down on the Prada lingerie shop. This is a city where one branch of Prada will not do (ultimately we counted four). Instead of crutches, this time Miu Miu heels clop past my window. There's something magical about leaving England in the drizzly morning and having lunch in another country. It justifies any chilly 6am trip to Heathrow. By one, we're eating squid salad and garlic spaghetti at the quirky, muralled Ristorante Bagutta - here they hatched the Milanese equivalent of the Booker Prize, the Premio Bagutta. We then stroll through the Lombardy cloud to the Piazza del Duomo where I struggle to get my bearings: on which side of the Galleria did I bump into Donatella? Where was that Hellhole Pensione? We walk past Foot Locker, the Rinascente department store and a couple of CD megastores. 'But it used to be so glamorous around here,' I sigh. 'It hasn't changed. You were cheaply satisfied then.' I insist we check out Fiorucci. But though the neon pink glow is unchanged, it's just tacky and kitsch now - a place for skinny, moping teenagers, not Mothers of Three who have their eye on Dolce and Gabbana. On the immaculate paved white stones of della Spiga and Montenapoleone, my good humour is suddenly restored. Here, every Italian designer you've ever heard of nestles invitingly in the autumn dusk. Inside, huge granite spaces and perfect girls in black with sleek hair and sleeker senses of humour stand rigidly at your shoulder as you look in the mirror. In Romeo Gigli, a rust velvet dress seems to have no price tag. After groping for an uncool amount of time around the sleeve and neckline, I give up and slink out. Another shop has price tags but no mirrors - mere minimal slivers of glass to offer back a collage version of yourself. We refresh ourselves with drinks in Bar Zucca in the Galleria. After that eked-out coffee in 1981, I take a vengeful pleasure in sipping a Campari (invented in this very bar) and eating olives while watching the world go by. 'There's nothing much to do here really except eat and drink and shop, is there?' I say happily. And shepherd my five carrier bags closer to my legs. Next day, after coffee and brioches in the elegant, eternal Cafe Cova on the Via Gesu, we stroll over to see Mantegna's hyperperspective Dead Christ at the Pinoteca di Brera, where art lovers gaze reverently at the Bellinis and Tintorettos and Caravaggios, and art students from the adjoining school roll joints on the guano-covered steps below. Then it's lunch round the corner at the Santini Bistrot on Via Ancona, where I eat something that now supplants mashed potato as All-Time Favourite Food. A cowpat of runny polenta is topped with two almost-orange fried eggs and then shavings of white truffle. J tells me someone just paid five grand for a truffle the size of a potato. Pounds, not lire. And if the trip is turning into a catalogue of meals, then what better revenge for the girl who previously existed here on Toblerone and hope? In the Sant'Ambroeus tearoom on Corso Matteoti near La Scala, the tiny pastry horns that garnish J's latte would then have fed me for a day. If only, back then, I'd visited Coquetel in the Via Vetere where the fashionable Milanese young pick from free pizza, tortillas and olives along with their margaritas and bloody marys - and Grande Fratello on a giant TV screen. Yes, Milan boasts Leonardo's Last Supper and more galleries and churches than you can count, but it's a modern city, a vortex of industries devoted to meeting the pleasures of now. You don't go to Milan for the Renaissance charm of Florence or the earthenware simplicity of Naples, it's all about wallowing in that Italian ability to beautify life and meet all its sensual possibilities. So, to hell with culture, we're here to shop and eat. We find the extraordinary Osteria dell-Operetta in the Corso di Porta Ticinese by chance. One moment we're in a dark street in the taxiless drizzle, next we're trying a curtained door and suddenly in the middle of the funkiest osteria in town. Here, freshly made pastas come in ice-bucket-sized copper cauldrons, insalata, soppressa and cotoletti swamp giant plates. Admittedly, the sophisticated ambience is sporadically shattered when, without warning, the lights dim and Boney M or Wham! hit the speakers as some blushing (female) customer receives a slice of torta with a sparkling sparkler - and an obligatory dance with the waiter. So many birthdays? Odds against it. I eat my second course in trepidation. And three nights later, back home, kids, cats, dog and family maelstrom also seem a little more manageable. 'But, hang on, you never saw the English woman about the job?' says J, ever unwilling to leave a narrative strand untied. 'She rang once I was back home in Nottingham and offered me something. I turned her down. I'd only have fallen in love with another Franco and got stuck there forever.' 'You might have fallen for a rich Milanese businessman,' he says, 'with groomed hair and one of those handbaggy briefcases. Just think, all that polenta, all those carrier bags.' 'But I'd have missed Peter Jones. And mashed potato,' I say loyally (fingers crossed behind my back). Getting there Julie Myerson travelled to Milan with Kirker Holidays (020 7231 3333). A three-night break staying at the five-star Carlton Baglioni costs from £628 per person, including flights with British Midland and transfers. For further information contact the Italian Tourist Office on 020 7408 1254.  Julie Myerson's novel 'Laura Blundy' is published in paperback this month by Fourth Estate.

fields.headline: Nigel Lloyd's snow reports
fields.trailText: There's enough snow everywhere for lucky British families to enjoy their half-term ski holidays. But it is still a strange high season, with temperatures more spring-like than usual; thankfully colder days are expected across Europe.
fields.body:
There's enough snow everywhere for lucky British families to enjoy their half-term ski holidays. But it is still a strange high season, with temperatures more spring-like than usual; thankfully colder days are expected across Europe.

Andorra: Sunshine and mild temperatures aren't the best conditions but things looked good for Arcalis (110cm on lower slopes, 170cm higher up), Pal/Arinsal (70/105cm), Pas de la Casa (90/ 120cm) and Soldeu (80/140cm), with almost all runs open.

Austria: St Anton (55/200cm) had all its slopes well-groomed after the World Championships while upmarket Zürs (95/175cm) got its share of publicity with Princess Caroline's fall. Niederau (60/100cm) is fully open with well-packed pistes. Kitzbühel (20/75cm) was hoping for more snow, as were Schladming (50/80cm) and Sölden (10/50cm). Higher up the Ötztal, Obergurgl (60/160cm) was doing much better.

Bulgaria: Borovets and Pamporovo (both 15/30cm) had some light snowfalls.

Canada: Snow depths are still less than usual. Whistler (165/235cm) and Lake Louise (55/70cm) were sunny. Tremblant (45/85cm) was helped by more snow.

France: All the French resorts are busy with staggered school holidays but the weather has been more like March than February. Val d'Isère (63/212cm) was gloomy - weather 'hot', pistes only 'fair' and conditions 'expected to worsen'. Argentière (40/160cm) lower runs have suffered. At Courchevel (20/100cm), Méribel (40/ 110cm), Les Ménuires (25/120cm) and Val Thorens (70/170cm) search out the best snow higher up. In Les Arcs (90/240cm) lower runs were icy and off-piste crusty, which most skiers find difficult.

Italy: Conditions are still remarkably good. In the vast Super Dolomiti area, 460 lifts and 1,220km of piste are up and running well, with lower depths of at least 20cm. The 42km night marathon on cross-country skis around the Sella Ronda is scheduled to start at 6pm on Friday. The Milky Way is doing well with even more snow. Sauze d'Oulx (60/140cm), Sestriere (80/140cm), Claviere (60/140cm) and, just over in France, Montgenèvre (150/210cm) all report excellent piste skiing and powder off-piste. The only problem has been poor visibility in heavy snowfalls. Further north, Courmayeur (90/300cm), Cervinia (120/200cm) and Cortina (25/200cm) have excellent pistes and powder off them.

Norway: Less cold. Hemsedal (140/210cm) and Geilo (135/ 150cm) have great skiing. Over in Sweden, Åre (45/65cm) is good on higher slopes.

Spain: On the Sierra Nevada (120/300cm), some glorious weather and great skiing.

Switzerland: It was hoped colder weather would slow the loss of snow depth. St Moritz (150/300cm) had very good conditions, as did Saas Fee (98/208cm). Elsewhere skiing was mainly good and sometimes outstanding. Depths were: Anzère 40/130cm; Arosa 90/110cm; Champery 20/80cm; Flims/Laax 10/ 200cm; Klosters 15/140cm; Verbier 30/100cm; and Zermatt 55/200cm.

US: In California, Mammoth (210/240cm) was boasting more than 150cms snowfall in three days. In Wyoming, Jackson Hole (137/152cm) was claiming thigh-high powder in the Casper Bowls with more on the way. In Colorado, Winter Park (147/ 160cm) was expecting more flurries, as was Aspen Snowmass (90/120cm), Breckenridge (105/145cm) and Vail (110/ 165cm). All were cold, getting colder. In Vermont, Killington (88/200ccm) and Stowe (95/140cm) reflect the generally chilly but satisfactory skiing throughout.

On the nursery slopes: John McCarthy has been learning to ski in Les Arcs, home of ski evolutif.

Best skiing: Breckenridge, departing 24 February, seven nights Victoria Chalet, flights and transfers, £639pp. Ski Independence (08705 550555).

The AITO directory of ski operators, whose reps help with this report, is available free on 020 8607 9080.

webTitle: Bumps can cost a royal sum

fields.headline: Bumps can cost a royal sum
fields.trailText: Princess Caroline of Monaco may have decided against suing the skier who crashed into her in the Austrian resort of Zürs last week, but an increasing number of British people are taking legal action against dangerous skiers.
fields.body:
Princess Caroline of Monaco may have decided against suing the skier who crashed into her in the Austrian resort of Zürs last week, but an increasing number of British people are taking legal action against dangerous skiers.

Travel insurance specialist Options reported a 25 per cent increase in cases of UK clients being sued by or suing other skiers for dangerous skiing this season.

'There is a general move towards litigation in the UK - a feeling that someone is to blame when things go wrong,' said Andrew Blowers, managing director of Options. 'You only have to look at the increasing number of TV adverts from companies specialising in representing people who have been injured.'

He warned people to make sure they were adequately insured when they went skiing. Thousands are still heading to the slopes every year armed with the Form E111, which covers only medical costs - not third-party liability.

Even with E111 cover, a straightforward broken leg in France could leave a skier £1,500 out of pocket.

webTitle: Winging it: Lost in thin air

fields.headline: Lost in thin air
fields.standfirst: Martin Buckley continues his global flight with a tribute to a flying legend
fields.trailText: Martin Buckley continues his global flight with a tribute to a flying legend.
fields.body:
I am taking off from an airfield from which the legendary pilot and author of The Little Prince, Antoine de St-Exupéry, made a flight on 31 July 1944 - a flight from which he never returned. For me, this will be an aerial homage. But ominously, rain begins to dot the windscreen as we taxi.

I haven't flown a Piper Arrow before. It's a straightforward small plane, but its controls are different from the Cessnas I've learned on. Airborne, I feel more confident. But the weather has other ideas. The snow-capped mountains that loom 8,000 feet over the Mediterranean are suddenly hidden under a bank of inky cloud. The rain whips itself into a squall. I return south, and make a God-awful hash of landing. Happily I have beside me René Amoretti, the president of the Aéroclub St-Exupéry and a skilled instructor, who is unlikely to let me bend his club aeroplane.

Fifty seven years ago Bastia airport was just a grass strip where the French II/33 Squadron was flying reconnaissance missions over occupied France. Standing out from its youth ful pilots was an international celebrity, St-Exupéry, a man who had enthralled the world with pioneering long-distance flights in primitive aircraft, and turned his adventures into successful novels and films. 'St-Ex' was too old for combat flight, and suffered from injuries sustained in a dozen major crashes. But he pulled every known string - all the way to Roosevelt - to get into the war.

Back on the ground at Bastia, I made friends with Jo-Jo Alfonsi, a pilot and engineer who has just built himself an aeroplane which was sitting in its hangar waiting for clement weather. Jo-Jo's fascination with flying goes back to the Second World War: 'One night as a child I watched a British night fighter chase a German bomber across the sky, firing as it went. The German crashed into the mountains and the explosion lit up the sky for miles around.'

A proud Corsican, Jo-Jo takes me to a restaurant famous for its local cuisine. Corsica's combination of sea and sun and lofty mountains produces everything from wild boar to lobster and wine. The speciality here is an extraordinary crème caramel made from farine de chatignes - the chestnuts that carpet the island. We are lunching with a friend of Jo-Jo's, François Marchisio - Corsica's greatest expert on St-Exupéry. When he died, 'St-Ex' had just published the book that was to prove his most famous: today, The Little Prince still sells more than 100,000 copies annually around the world. But he was not destined for a shrine, or even a marked grave.

The story of his last day, François tells me, piles mystery on mystery. 'For a start, St-Ex didn't sleep in his bed that night, and no one knows where he went. The next day - amazingly - no one actually saw him take off. And then, he disappeared. The Germans, who kept fanatical records, insist to this day that they didn't shoot down a P-38 on the 31st. St-Ex vanished into thin air.'

Jo-Jo and François told me there was an allied war grave nearby. The next morning I visited the neat, wooded grove where 60 Commonwealth servicemen are buried, most of them aircrew. These were young men: their average age is 22. One grave was unidentified, an airman of theRAF, 'Known unto God.' Where the five crew of one plane were buried their gravestones touched, the men shoulder-to-shoulder in death as in life. I walked alone among the graves, reading the poignant inscriptions: 'Tell England we died for her and here we rest content.' 'The only son of...' 'Remembered by your loving wife and baby daughter_' 'Sleep well, darling.'

The next day, the sky began to clear. Jo-Jo and I took off an hour before sunset and flew, as St-Ex would have done, straight at the mountains, where a pass miraculously opens and you fly with walls of forested rock seemingly just beyond each wingtip. I had brought with me from England the petals of a dozen red roses. The setting sun was staining the sea red - the sea beneath which many believe St-Ex to lie - as I let fly the petals, in the memory of St-Ex, and of the young Commonwealth airmen who died in Corsica.

 Email Martin Buckley about his round-the-world flight on mbwinging it@hotmail.com.

fields.headline: Let's go!
fields.standfirst: Late bargains, chosen by Liz Bird
fields.trailText: Late bargains, chosen by Liz Bird.
fields.body:
Holidays

UK

Take advantage of free kids' activities at two Pontin's (08705 331199) centres at Southport in Lancashire and Camber Sands in Sussex during half-term week. Prices start at £19 per person for a three-night weekend break from 23 February at both centres.

Milan

Go shopping in Milan with Travelscene (0870 777 4445). A three-night break staying at the three-star Hotel Corallo starts from £218 per person for departures on 23 February or 2 March. The price includes B&B accommodation, return flights with British Airways from Gatwick.

Istanbul

Metak Holidays (020 7935 6961) is offering three-night breaks in Istanbul from £339 per person. The price includes return flights from Heathrow or Manchester, transfers and B&B accommodation at the Orient Express Hotel, which is near the Blue Mosque, St Sophia and Topkapi Palace.

Goa

Grab some winter sun in Goa with Hayes & Jarvis (0870 89 89 890). A seven-night stay departing between 3 and 24 March costs from £445 per person. Return flights from Gatwick, transfers and B&B accommodation at the Alphaville Hotel in north Goa are included in the price.

Cyprus

Spend seven nights at the five-star Coral Beach Hotel in Paphos with Cyplon Holidays (020 8348 8866). Prices start at £375 per adult for a twin inland view room and include return scheduled flights on Cyprus Airways, B&B accommodation and free car hire (excluding insurance at £5 per day).

Tunisia

Live it up at the five-star The Residence hotel, north of Carthage with Wigmore Holidays (020 7836 4999). All rooms have balconies overlooking the sea or garden, marble bathrooms and air conditioning. A four-night stay between 21 February and 31 March is £580 per person including B&B accommodation, scheduled flights from Heathrow or Gatwick and transfers.

At sea

Escape to the Caribbean sunshine with P&O Cruises (020 7800 2222). A 14-night Taste of the Tropics cruise on board Victoria visits Barbados, St Lucia, Dominica, Tortola and Antigua. Prices start from £1,595 per person including all on-board meals and entertainment for departures on 23 March.

Flights

Faro

Avro (020 8695 4440) is offering return flights for departures on 4 March for £109, including taxes.

Round the world

Student and youth travel specialist STA Travel (0870 160 6070) is selling a round the world ticket from £655 for departures between 21 April and 30 June. Flights are via Kuala Lumpur, Sydney, surface travel to Cairns and Los Angeles with Virgin Atlantic, Air New Zealand and United Airlines.

Hong Kong

Airline Network (0800 727747) is offering flights with Lufthansa via Frankfurt departing on 31 March for £434, including taxes. Departures are from Heathrow or Manchester with a minimum stay of seven nights and maximum stay of three months.

webTitle: Stay cool and drive a bargain

fields.headline: Stay cool and drive a bargain
fields.standfirst: Stephen Lee  guides America-bound skiers through the tricky slalom of car hire, insurance hassles and taxes
fields.trailText: Stephen Lee guides America-bound skiers through the tricky slalom of car hire, insurance hassles and taxes.
fields.body:
'This way to the rental desk, sir,' said the beaming volunteer at Denver airport. Outside, shuttle driver Lamont grabbed my bags: 'Take you right to the car, sir. You know how to get outta town? OK. Head straight for that mountain, take I-70 all the way to Grand Junction.' Welcome to American service.

The Alamo rental car park had a seemingly infinite number of four-wheel-drive 'sport utilities'. These are now so popular in the US that you wonder whether the right to own a 4x4 is enshrined in the Constitution.

My vehicle was a GMC Jimmy, the 4x4 workhorse of rental fleets. Hired on arrival at the airport this could cost $1,200 (£800) a week for unlimited mileage. At least half of the price is for insurance, a collision damage waiver (CDW) and a swingeing 23.5 per cent tax. It is these extras that can break the bank. My first American rental cost $150 a week, a seemingly excellent deal until the insurance extras bumped up the total to $600. But US car rental does not have to be expensive if you book in advance from Britain. A deal like that for the Jimmy would have cost around $450 (£300), less than half the airport price. Getting the right car hire deal is the key to an affordable US skiing holiday.

'There are many good reasons for renting a car,' says Jenn Gleckman, Crystal Holidays' western area manager. 'If you don't want to ski all the time it opens up possibilities.' A hire car can take you, for example, to neighbouring resorts that cannot be reached on skis, allowing visitors to take advantage of good price deals on area lift tickets. And a car gives the freedom to make detours en route to the resort.

Essential cover

After a long flight, the choices at the rental desks may be bewildering, but remember that CDW (see above) and Additional Liability Insurance (ALI) are essential. CDW, or Loss Damage Waiver, covers liability for damage to the car. Some UK credit card companies offer worldwide CDW for about £65 a year, but most US rental firms insist that this is linked to the insurance covering your own car at home. The conundrum is that no UK insurance company will touch US motor cover. Thus there is no practical alternative to taking CDW on the hire firm's terms. Make sure, however, that the deal is for full CDW, without an excess.

The ALI third party insurance, which is also known as 'top-up' or 'extended insur ance', must be bought in the US to ensure you have the minimum sensible cover of up to $1 million. Beware of deals which offer the 'legal minimum': $100,000 is inadequate in such a litigious country.

'Always take both CDW and ALI,' says David Ovendale, Crystal Holidays' US general manager, 'or you could spend the rest of your life working for someone else.' Crystal's representatives lean on clients, for their own good, to take full cover. Cover is usually offered for personal accidents and effects, but these are not essential if you have a good travel policy. Non-inclusive car rentals attract state sales taxes of 5-15 per cent. Colorado's is 13.5 per cent. There may be an additional 10 per cent 'facility user fee', a form of airport tax for cars. This combination adds 23.5 per cent to the bill. But you can avoid paying this by pre-booking from the UK (see below).

On the road

Disorientated, jet-lagged motorists are notoriously accident-prone, especially at high altitudes. Take advantage of the free first-night hotel offered by some hire firms, or pay for a room. This is infinitely preferable to a night drive over an icy 10,500ft pass to a resort 9,000ft up.

Petrol (or 'gas') costs about 80p a gallon, a quarter of the UK price. When planning, remember that any US state is the size of a European country. A typical drive from Denver to Vail takes two hours. Telluride or Crested Butte are seven hours from the airport. Automatic transmission is the norm. Cruise control is ideal to rest the right foot and minimise the risk of a speeding ticket. American drivers do not use snow chains, so they are rarely provided. In any event a 4x4 will deal with most conditions.

A mobile phone is strongly advised. UK digital 'world' phones have poor US coverage, except around major cities. You can hire a US analogue mobile. Through Alamo this costs about £8.70 a day, plus insurance. Calls cost about £1.30 a minute.

Leave enough time at the end of the holi day to agree the final car and phone bills at the airport. It is much easier to pursue any queries from there rather than the UK .

Getting the best deal

Advance booking in the UK can be done directly with US car hire companies or through UK tour operators. Beware of phrases such as 'fully inclusive'. Clarify in detail whether the deal includes full insurance, a facility user fee and sales tax. If you don't ask, you may be in for a shock later.

The UK offices of four US hire companies were asked to quote for a week's hire from Denver airport for two drivers, with unlimited mileage and a genuinely fully-inclusive deal with CDW, ALI and all taxes. Quotes were obtained for a compact car and for a medium-sized 4x4 vehicle.

Alamo (0990 99 4000) offered a car at £200 with a free tank of fuel. A similar 4X4 deal was £294.

Avis (0870 6060100) had a car at £225 and a 4x4 at £304.

The best deals from Budget ( 0541 565 656) were booked in advance, with the bill paid in Denver in dollars. A car was $364 and a 4x4 was $510.

Connect Car Rental (0800 634 0644) had a car at £209. No 4x4 was available.Ski racks, which are almost essential, cost about £10 a day.

The following were much cheaper and offered excellent pre-paid insurance:

Crystal Holidays (0870 848 7000) offers free rental of a compact car with a resort holiday or package. £133 buys the seven-day Alamo Gold USA coverage which, in addition to the normal inclusive deals, offers a superior check-in service on arrival, a free tank of fuel, insures three additional drivers and a free ski rack. A 4x4 costs £115 through Crystal/Alamo plus the £133 Alamo Gold package, a total of £248.

Thomson (0870 606 1470) offers a free compact car to parties of two skiers buying a resort package.

United Vacations (0870 606 2222) has a fly-drive package from £339 per person in the low ski season. Pre-booked all-inclusive insurance costs £154, with about £60 extra for 4x4 vehicles.

United Airlines offers similar free car deal on its fly-drive holidays in Denver. The holiday prices start at £345 for two adults together. The Alamo Gold package, discounted to £139 for seven days, includes full CDW and ALI, a free tank of petrol and covers up to three additional drivers. A 4x4 vehicle costs £120 a week extra. With Alamo Gold this makes a total of £259.

It is better to buy an all-inclusive car hire deal from a UK tour operator than to use the UK office of a US car rental company. For a week's hire this saves an average of £110 on a car and £88 on a 4x4. Skiers who are not on a fly-drive or holiday deal will find it cheaper to book an inclusive deal with the UK office of a US car rental firm. Hiring at an American airport is the worst deal of all.

All the prices quoted above were obtained on a single day, but they often vary according to supply and demand. Booking through a tour operator means that the firm takes the risk of those fluctuations while the holidaymaker gets a fixed-price bargain.

 Stephen Lee flew to Denver with United Airlines (0870 606 2222) and hired the car from Alamo Car Rental (0990 994000). He stayed in Telluride, Colorado at the Camel's Garden Hotel and Riverside Condominiums.

fields.headline: A top concierge reveals all
fields.standfirst: Larry Klein, senior assistant manager at the Greenbrier, White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia, US
fields.trailText: Larry Klein, senior assistant manager at the Greenbrier, White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia, US.
fields.body:
Where is the Greenbrier?

The Greenbrier is tucked away in the beautiful Allegheny Mountains. The hotel traces its roots back to 1778 when one Mrs Anderson was miraculously cured of rheumatism by the sulphur spring in the grounds. Guests of the resort still bathe in these waters in our spa. Dorothy Draper redecorated the hotel after World War II, during which the Greenbrier served as an army hospital. She travelled the world and acquired 35,000 pieces of furniture and art.

Any famous guests?

We have hosted US Presidents, royalty and heads of state from all corners of the globe as well as celebrities, athletes and many well-known business leaders.

What do you suggest for a day out?

My recommendation would begin with breakfast in the main dining room, then a one-hour golf clinic at the Sam Snead Golf Academy followed by a two-hour Land Rover driving excursion. For lunch, Sam Snead's at the Golf Club, with a view of all three championship courses. The afternoon would include a falconry class followed by the Greenbrier treatment in the spa. There are numerous activities, including indoor and outdoor tennis, hunting and fishing, croquet, indoor and outdoor pools, mountain biking, riding, cooking classes, white water rafting, hiking, kayaking, theatre, and tours of the nuclear bunker.

Nuclear bunker?

In 1956 the US government asked C&O Railway, parent company of the Greenbrier, to construct a 112,000 sq ft top secret relocation facility that would have been used by Congress in the event of a national emergency. It was kept in a constant state of readiness until 1992, when an article in the Washington Post Magazine revealed its location. The bunker was designed to accommodate 1,100 people for up to 60 days and included a power plant, medical facility and state-of-the-art communications equipment. In 1995, the government gave it to the Greenbrier.

What about the nightlife?

Choose from movies, contemporary music at Slammin' Sammy's and live music for dancing in the Old White Club.

 Greenbrier reservations: 00 1 304 536 1110. One-week winter packages from £1,649, including flights, with North American Travel Service (020 7938 3737)

fields.headline: Sheridan's now a rival
fields.standfirst: The political world was simpler in 1882 when W.S. Gilbert wrote, in  Iolanthe, that every boy or girl is either 'a little Liberal or else a little Conservative'.
fields.trailText: In Scotland, our political world is undoubtedly growing more complicated because of the two-tier voting system. We, of course, developed a four-party system in the decades before the Scottish Parliament. Now the list has brought the Tories back to parliamentary life and found a place at Holyrood for the leader of the Scottish Socialist Party, Tommy Sheridan, and the Greens.
fields.body:
The political world was simpler in 1882 when W.S. Gilbert wrote, in Iolanthe, that every boy or girl is either 'a little Liberal or else a little Conservative'. They were even simpler back in the fifteenth century when the Papal Bull of 1493 and the Treaty of Tordesillas divided the Christian world into two zones of influence by drawing a line on the map.

Nations rise and fall; political parties decline. Yet Gilbert's doctrine loosely applies still, if you substitute Labour for Liberal, though his age, which predated universal suffrage, was innocent of floating voters, focus groups or the 'pebbledash people' identified by William Hague as a key cohort in the electorate.

And in Scotland, our political world is undoubtedly growing more complicated because of the two-tier voting system. We, of course, developed a four-party system in the decades before the Scottish Parliament. Now the list has brought the Tories back to parliamentary life and found a place at Holyrood for the leader of the Scottish Socialist Party, Tommy Sheridan, and the Greens.

The SSP held its conference earlier this month and reported that it now has more than 2,000 members. It is appealing for £100,000 to fund its plan to field a candidate in every Scottish Westminster seat; it hopes to gather 100,00 votes. And Sheridan has high hopes for the next Scottish elections in 2003, pointing out that opinion polls give the party six per cent of the second vote, behind the Tories' nine per cent.

Sheridan's socialists are not the only ones gnawing at New Labour. Arthur Scargill's Socialist Labour Party is fielding candidates in Peter Mandelson's Hartlepool and elsewhere, but typically Scargill is standing aside from the Socialist Alliance, to which Sheridan's party subscribes. In England, where it was formed in Coventry nine years ago out of the remnants of the old anti- poll tax campaign, it hopes to contest 65 seats. Masterminded by the former Labour member for Coventry South-East, Dave Nellist, it is targeting the constituencies of at least 20 Labour Ministers, including Jack Straw and David Blunkett. In a gesture of unreciprocated generosity, it is yielding Hartlepool and Mandelson to Scargill.

So far these are stirrings in the undergrowth. Trying to read the political future is as easy as understanding a Dylan lyric: some scholars, for example, claim that the incomprehensible 'It takes a lot to laugh, it takes a train to cry' contains biblical allusions.

More probably, Dylan, like Beckett, preferred ambiguity because it has a greater artistic effect than clarity. But if art is obscure, the future is inscrutable. Not unnaturally, political scientists are very cautious about claims that the Socialist Alliance is opening up a significant new constituency in British politics.

Indeed, David Denver, professor of politics at Lancaster University and co-author of standard works on Scottish political behaviour, believes that Sheridan's hopes of a glorious future at Holyrood may be inflated, although he acknowledges the alliance's success in recent council by-elections in England, where its subscribing parties have nine seats - in Coventry, Lewisham, Preston and Burnley.

Although Sheridan, a genuine hero of the working class and a man of charm and sincerity, enjoys a significant personal vote, his party, Denver believes, is more likely to secure between 2 and 4 per cent of the vote, although Scotland Decides, an account of the 1999 elections which Denver jointly authored, shows that many who voted for one party in the first-past-vote contest switched when it came to the list.

But it would be foolish to write Sheridan off: he has already forced the Executive to retreat on the issue of warrant sales. Many Labour members must in spirit have been with Sheridan, George Galloway and the others who were arrested at Faslane on Monday. Most, after all, privately believe in nuclear disarmament. With a fair wind, he will surely become a substantial player in Scotland's political future.
