webTitle: Ken vows 'I do' to weddings for all

fields.headline: Ken vows 'I do' to weddings for all
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone has managed to upstage both Margaret Thatcher and Tony Blair during his turbulent political career, and soon he will be stealing the show from your mother-in-law too.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone has managed to upstage both Margaret Thatcher and Tony Blair during his turbulent political career, and soon he will be stealing the show from your mother-in-law too. Advisers to London's first elected Mayor, who has pledged to introduce partnership registration ceremonies in the capital, have proposed that Livingstone should conduct the new service.

'Ken is absolutely committed to registration,' confirmed a source close to Livingstone last night. 'He would be perfectly prepared to preside over these ceremonies if that is what people want.'

When the partnership pledge was made, it was envisaged that the facility would be offered only to lesbian and gay couples. However, the Mayor's advisory group on registration has agreed that the amenity will be offered to all couples.

'There will be flexibility around the formal signing of the register,' confirmed Angela Mason, an adviser to the Mayor. 'Some people will want to have a more sombre service; others may wish to just come in and sign, but it will still be a serious event.' Livingstone hopes to be saying, 'You may now kiss the bride,' later this year.

It was originally intended that couples would register their partnerships in local authority registry offices. However, opposition from some registrars and the unwillingness of Conservative local authorities to welcome gay marriages on their premises has persuaded mayoral staff that ceremonies performed by an elected official on mayoral premises would be a more satisfactory way to fulfil the pledge.

Romney House, the current Westminster home of the Mayor and the Greater London Assembly, is a rather seedy venue in which to spend the most important day of your life. However, next year both Livingstone and the GLA will move to a new home on London's South Bank designed by Norman Foster. The £60 million glass building will provide a stunning backdrop for 'wedding' photographs.

Vita Lewis, 36, from north London, said: 'After a 10-year relationship we are looking forward to being able to register our commitment to one another without the religious ceremony required in a church or the stuffiness of a registry office. Being registered by Ken Livingstone could be as important to some Londoners as having your baby christened by the Pope is to some Roman Catholics.'

But Londoners seeking to have their ceremony presided over by Livingstone may have to hold weekday events. He likes to spend weekends with his own long-term partner in Brighton.

However, next year both Livingstone and the GLA will move to a new home on London's South Bank designed by Norman Foster. The £60 million glass building will provide a stunning backdrop for 'wedding' photographs. Vita Lewis, 36, from north London, said: 'After a 10-year relationship we are looking forward to being able to register our commitment to one another without the religious ceremony required in a church or the stuffiness of a registry office. Being registered by Ken Livingstone could be as important to some Londoners as having your baby christened by the Pope is to some Roman Catholics.' But Londoners seeking to have their ceremony presided over by Livingstone may have to hold weekday events. He likes to spend weekends with his own long-term partner in Brighton.

webTitle: Welsh MPs consider legal action to save Corus jobs

fields.headline: Welsh MPs consider legal action to save Corus jobs
fields.trailText: Officials in the Welsh Assembly have drawn up a legal challenge to Corus's plans for the closure of steelmaking plants in Wales unless negotiations with unions to save them succeed.
fields.body:
Officials in the Welsh Assembly have drawn up a legal challenge to Corus's plans for the closure of steelmaking plants in Wales unless negotiations with unions to save them succeed.

The assembly's Counsel-General, its chief legal officer, has produced a written opinion indicating that the Anglo-Dutch giant's proposals to axe 2,500 jobs by ending raw steelmaking at the Llanwern integrated plant, and to close the Ebbw Vale finishing works, could be challenged under European Law. Assembly members commissioned the opinion after Corus dismissed a bid from the ISTC steel union to buy Llanwern, saying that inviting 'additional competition' would 'totally undermine the objectives of our proposed restructuring'.

One assembly source said: 'We now think there may be a way forward using European competition law to prevent the closures and possibly to facilitate a buyout at the heavy [steelmaking] end of Llanwern and Ebbw Vale.'

Officials have examined regulations under the European Coal and Steel Community Treaty, and believe Corus's actions can be challenged.

The Counsel-General's opinion argues that closing plants could be anti-competitive because it would reduce production, putting customers at a disadvantage. It also points out that Corus would not have to intend this outcome for there to be an action under the treaty.

However, officials believe there could be complications with the case, as many of the consumers of Ebbw Vale's production are packaging companies, which have experienced rapid diversification away from steel as a core raw material. They could therefore source other materials, nullifying an anti-competition argument.

Nevertheless, Assembly Ministers are determined to challenge the Corus cuts if proposals by the ISTC to avoid redundancies by switching to part-time working are rejected.

They believe a successful legal challenge could re-open the prospect of successful buyouts. Welsh Assembly sources add that Ministers believe there is a commercial case for retaining the plants in future, particularly since the Government has indicated its intention to decide on a euro referendum within two years of the election. Corus blames the strength of the pound against the single currency for undermining its competitiveness in Europe, and wants early UK entry.

Mike German, Deputy First Minister in the assembly, said: 'We believe the union proposals should be given a fair wind and we are not going to act until they have run their course. But we are looking at all options and that includes how the law can help us.'

webTitle: Blair admits fears over voter apathy

fields.headline: Blair admits fears over voter apathy
fields.standfirst:
PM says the public has a duty to vote

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: PM says the public has a duty to vote
fields.body:
Tony Blair is to admit that voters' apathy and increasing disillusionment with politics is jeopardising Labour's chances of winning the next election.

In his most honest appraisal yet of the mood of the nation, the Prime Minister will use his keynote speech at the party's spring conference in Glasgow to say that cynicism in the electorate and a growing belief that 'all politicians are the same' is the most dangerous threat to his dreams of a second term.

He will accuse the Conservatives of encouraging the negative mood so that they have a better chance of winning.

Blair will say that the British public have a duty to vote, and that 'a decision to stay at home is a decision to vote Tory'. A Labour Party spokesman said that it was a 'civic duty to take part in democracy' but ruled out any moves to compulsory voting.

The party has identified 60 target seats where the Labour party could lose to the Tories or the Liberal Democrats if their core vote does not turn out.

Blair will say that it is 'choice not chance' that the Government has been able to bring in reforms and that the British public should understand that their vote counts.

He will also re-iterate his commitment to tackling crime and is expected to launch new initiatives aimed attackling 'a hardcore of offenders'.

He will also insist that the hard won reputation for economic competence must not be thrown away by a pre-election tax cut give away. The Prime Minister will warn against complacency and say that without a Labour second term the country would inevitably return to the 'boom and bust' of the last Conservative Government.

The speech will be the clearest indication yet that the Government is gearing up for an election campaign to be announced in the next few weeks. Most experts believe that the election will take place on 3 May.

The Prime Minister hopes that the blizzard of announcements at the conference yesterday from John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, David Blunkett, the Education Secretary, Jack Straw, the Home Secretary, and Alan Milburn, the Health Secretary, will convince voters that Labour still has the will to achieve more in a second term.

Party officials admitted that the conference had never seen such a parade of senior Ministers.

The Cabinet Ministers peppered their speeches with election pledges on better schools, an improved health service and more help for crime victims.

At the end of his speech. Prescott returned to the rostrum and shouted: 'Are you ready? Let's go to it.'

The Deputy Prime Minister also revealed that the age when older people can receive concessionary bus passes will be equalised at the age of 60 for men and women. The effective reduction in the qualification age for men from 65 to 60 will mean that 1.5 million more people can take advantage of the scheme.

The move comes as the Government backs down over a legal battle with the European Union which has said that having different ages for qualification could be discriminatory and therefore illegal.

During his speech Milburn promised more money for cancer care and targets for bringing the mortality rate for underprivileged children up to the average for better off families.

The Health Secretary also said that doctors who agreed to give up private work for the first seven years of their career would be paid a bonus and that the health service still needed to go through a revolution if the public were to have faith in it.

'Despite the efforts of staff, the NHS is still too much like the world of the Forties, with too many patients queueing for too long for treatment, with too many staff shortages, too few doctors and nurses, staff too often run off their feet,' he added.

A spokesman for the BMA said that politicians were sapping morale by saying that the NHS was backward looking. 'The medical profession does not see itself as stuck in the Forties,' he said.

'There has been enormous change, it is quite ridiculous to say that doctors or nurses have not changed. There is a major problem with low morale among doctors and comments like this simply do not help.'

webTitle: Heaven is a 24-hour travel superstore in... Hull

fields.headline: Heaven is a 24-hour travel superstore in... Hull
fields.trailText: The reality of Holiday Hypermarket's 24-hour trial didn't quite live up to the hype.
fields.body:
The two security guards thought they had died and gone to heaven. Their task of guarding a travel agency on an industrial estate in Hull was probably the most exciting nightshift they had had for a long time.

No constant patrols around the perimeter fence or scanning TV security screens. While the travel agency staff tried to busy themselves doing administrative work, the two men skied a few slopes on the ski simulator. When they tired of that, they moved on to the imported Lincoln Continental car fitted with a simulator to practice driving on the right hand side of the road in a left-hand- drive car. When the photographer came to take some pictures, they took off their jackets and posed as customers scanning the late availability cards.

The rest of us were finding it a little harder to stay awake. I had come to Hull to take part in the 24-hour trial opening of one of Holiday Hypermarket's travel superstores and I had believed the hype. I had expected to see factory and care home workers popping in on their way to their nightshift to book their next holiday in the sun or clubbers returning from a night on the town to check availability for their next holiday to Ibiza. But the posters advertising the 24-hour opening 'Due to Demand' on the agency walls did not quite match the reality.

By 11.30pm the number of customers had dwindled to two. A couple came in to buy a cruise but couldn't book it because the cruise company's booking system had shut down for the night. From midnight to 6am not a soul walked through the door. The only living thing that tried to get in was a cat.

Flyers advertising the 24-hour opening had been sent round local factories and care homes and even nightclubs. An advert had also been placed in the local paper. Research had shown that the 24-hour Asda next door was particularly busy on Thursday and Friday evenings. But while I can see the logic of buying a pint of milk and loaf of bread on the way home from a nightshift, it's hard to imagine someone having the urge to book their holiday.

The eight staff who had volunteered to take part in the 24-hour trial were in remarkably good spirits - buoyed by regular doses of Red Bull and Pro Plus. General manager Rebecca Mackay tried to encourage them to eat bananas 'for slow release energy' from the buffet in the staff room. She even tried taking them out into the bracing night air to do star jumps to keep them awake.

By 4am the head of worldwide sales, Sarah Tough, was begging Jon from the Customer Service Desk not to play any more Elvis songs on the jukebox: 'It's driving me mad - he keeps playing the same one over and over again,' she said.

Holiday Hypermarket founder and managing director John Donnelly believes it is only a matter of time before 24-hour opening becomes the norm. 'Two and a half years ago we created Sunday trading - it is now the second biggest shopping day of the year,' he said. On Saturdays the superstores are packed with some customers waiting up to three hours to be served. 'Why not come and book late at night when you know there won't be the same queues?'

Picture this...

The Holiday Hypermarket in Hull is not like the average high-street travel agent.For a start it is massive: 10,000 sq ft filled with a movie theatre, TV screens and lots of Hollywood-style theming. Over in the USA department the music from Psycho plays as a figure in a chair rocks back and forth beneath a neon sign advertising Bates Hotel. Customers can pay their balances at a mock Pyramid or can read holiday brochures in front of a massive mural of Venice's Rialto Bridge. In the middle of the room a mock Pirate ship houses Customer Services and the short-haul section.

Managing director John Donnelly said he wanted to create a holiday atmosphere when people booked their trip. 'Outside it's Hull, inside its Holidayland. People walk in and smile - the whole concept puts them in a holiday mood.'

The concept has been a big success. In the past two and a half years 31 superstores have opened around the country. Five more are planned to open by June.

webTitle: Country 'n' western crazy in  a town where Willie is king

fields.headline: Country 'n' western crazy in  a town where Willie is king
fields.standfirst: Forget Nashville... Even without Dubya, Austin, Texas, is the live music capital of the world, says  Tina Ogle, who fits in four gigs a night
fields.trailText: Forget Nashville... Even without Dubya, Austin, Texas, is the live music capital of the world, says Tina Ogle, who fits in four gigs a night.
fields.body:
If you believe Willie Nelson is god, Townes Van Zandt is the greatest poet of the twentieth century and your internal organs quiver at the sound of a pedal steel guitar, there is a place on earth where you can find your own personal paradise.

In Austin, Texas, these beliefs are not considered strange; indeed share them with strangers in any number of gloriously divey bars and you will make lifelong friends. George W. Bush has recently left this nirvana for the swampier climes of Washington DC, but he was never a true Austinite. No one I met had even laid eyes on the former Texas Governor, but everyone, and I mean everyone, had a Willie anecdote.

From the bedraggled-looking biker in the Horseshoe Lounge who offered me free samples of his tamales and told me he'd seen Willie play 50 times in 20 years, to the has-been football coach lounging in the Broken Spoke with his posed picture in his wallet, everyone loves Willie. And it was the great man himself who turned Austin into the self-proclaimed 'Live Music Capital of the World' when he relocated here in the early Seventies, tired of the Nashville nonsense and intent on going his own musical way.

Ever since, musicians keen to do their finest work without commercial considerations have gathered and now play nightly in more than 100 live music venues. Fans of all musical genres can slake their thirst for grunge, heavy metal, thrash, jazz, Tejano and any combination besides.

But for lovers of pure country music, there is no better place. You won't find ersatz cow boys here, no 'hat' acts, and definitely no line dancing. What you will find are passionate musicians intent on keeping the roots of real country intact and giving you a good time into the bargain.

For an Austin novice there is no finer place to start than Tuesday night at Jovita's Cantina, a small Mexican restaurant in south Austin. Order a plate of enchiladas and an ice-cold margarita and sit back and soak up the yodelling genius of Don Walser.

No matter how miserable you are, the astonishing vocals of this 66-year-old ex-Texas state employee will have you in raptures. Nicknamed the 'abdominal showman' by fellow local legend Cornell Hurd, this giant of a man will wow you with old country classics as well as his own compositions. Small wonder he was recently awarded a National Heritage Award by the US government.

If you're spending any time in Austin, you will want to master the Texas two-step, a dance practised by everyone from conservative elderly couples to hard-drinking lesbians. It looks magnificent but is surprisingly easy, and you won't find any shortage of volunteers to teach you. For women it's a simple right-right-left step and the man leads. But as my new west Texan friend Amy, the self-proclaimed rodeo bitch from hell, warns: 'Every cowboy is different.' There are variations, but drink enough long-neck Pearl or Lone Star beer and you'll be flying across the floor of the Broken Spoke in no time.

The Spoke is an Austin classic, a dance hall and diner that attracts top local talent and is packed at weekends. You'll find plenty of pickups in the parking lot and plenty of Stetsons and Wranglers inside. The Wednesday night I was in town, Kinky Friedman was joined by Billy Joe Shaver, Joe Ely and Kimmie Rhodes on stage for a heavenly marriage of country talent. If you do want to dance, this is the best place in Austin.

If you make it to Thursday and heartbreak king Dale Watson is in town then there is only one place to be come 10pm: Ginny's Little Longhorn. The 'honkiest tonkiest beerjoint' of Watson's song, Ginny's is a tiny shack in north Austin where you can't even see the band because so many people cram in and on to the tiny dance floor. If an innocent looking 82-year-old man asks you to dance, don't do it. He will press you so close you will think you are never going to breathe again. And mind your language, as a sign warns: 'No fussin', no cussin', no hasslin', no wrasslin'.' Otherwise, stay upright, knock back the beer and Watson and his Lone Stars will give you an evening of hardcore honkytonk you will never forget.

Amazingly, music of this quality is on offer every night and you can fit three or four gigs into an evening if you plan well. Another venue you won't want to miss is the Continental Club, where a handful of different acts play each evening. Top class local talent such as blues-tinged Toni Price play free happy-hour gigs from 6.30pm and if you stay you won't have to pay the cover charge for the rest of the night's entertainment.

In the unlikely event that you ever tire of Austin there are two places country music lovers may want to venture.

The first is Luckenbach, Texas, made famous by the Willie Nelson/Waylon Jennings song of 1970. Buy a map because there are no signs to this hamlet that consists of a beer joint-cum-post office and a dance hall: fans have stolen them all.

The other is the historic town of Gruene (pronounced Green), where stands the oldest dance hall in Texas. On your way out to these places in the Texas hill country, you would be advised to stop off at the Salt Lick, 12 miles from Austin. Here you will find what locals consider to be the finest barbecued meat in these parts, and barbecue is a religion rather than a hobby in Texas. The blackberry cobbler, with Texan Blue Bell ice cream, is not to be sniffed at either.

The only problem with Austin is leaving it. You will pore over the pages of the free Austin Chronicle as you head for the airport, just wishing you had time to catch the new country voice, Roger Wallace at the Saxon Pub, or 'cosmic cowboy' Rusty Wier at Gino's.

But you can come back, and you will. Just remember that knowing all the words to 'Pancho and Lefty' is all the passport you'll need.

Top cry-in-your beer juke joints

The Poodle Dog Lounge, 6407 Burnet Road. A terrifying looking female bartender will greet you. Rock to 'Trashy Women' by Confederate Railroad, cry with George Jones or laugh with John Prine.

Lala's Little Nugget, 2207 Justin Lane. Christmas decorations stay up all year and the jukebox offers Glen Miller, Dean Martin and Johnny Gonzalez.

The Horseshoe Lounge, 2430 South Lamar Boulevard. Made famous by local boy Slaid Cleaves's song of the same name.

Deep Eddy Cabaret, 2315 Lake Austin Boulevard. Neighbourhood bar where you can listen to Tom Waits and Dwight Yoakam.

The Dry Creek Saloon, Mount Bonnell Road. An extraordinary two-tiered shack open only 4pm-8pm and not on Sundays. Run by 90-year-old Sarah, this is not somewhere to request a martini.

Where to stay

There are two historic hotels at the heart of downtown Austin. The Driskill, 604 Brazos Street, (001 512 474 5911) was founded by oil baron Jesse Driskill in 1886. Rates from $205-$2,500 a night.

The Hotel Intercontinental Stephen F Austin, 701 Congress Avenue, (001 512 457 8800) opened in 1924 and is named after the 'father of Texas'. Prices start at $159 for special weekend deals.

A cheaper option and with the slogan 'so close, yet so far out' is the Austin Motel, 1220 South Congress, (001 512 441 1157). A twin-bedded room costs from $80.

Getting there

American Airlines' return fares from Heathrow to Austin from £347, including taxes,to £769 in the summer (08457 789 789).

For a free information pack on Austin and the rest of Texas, call the Texas Tourism UK office on 0207 978 5233.

Another venue you won't want to miss is the Continental Club, where a handful of different acts play each evening. Top class local talent such as blues-tinged Toni Price play free happy-hour gigs from 6.30pm and if you stay you won't have to pay the cover charge for the rest of the night's entertainment. In the unlikely event that you ever tire of Austin there are two places country music lovers may want to venture. The first is Luckenbach, Texas, made famous by the Willie Nelson/Waylon Jennings song of 1970. Buy a map because there are no signs to this hamlet that consists of a beer joint-cum-post office and a dance hall: fans have stolen them all. The other is the historic town of Gruene (pronounced Green), where stands the oldest dance hall in Texas. On your way out to these places in the Texas hill country, you would be advised to stop off at the Salt Lick, 12 miles from Austin. Here you will find what locals consider to be the finest barbecued meat in these parts, and barbecue is a religion rather than a hobby in Texas. The blackberry cobbler, with Texan Blue Bell ice cream, is not to be sniffed at either. The only problem with Austin is leaving it. You will pore over the pages of the free Austin Chronicle as you head for the airport, just wishing you had time to catch the new country voice, Roger Wallace at the Saxon Pub, or 'cosmic cowboy' Rusty Wier at Gino's. But you can come back, and you will. Just remember that knowing all the words to 'Pancho and Lefty' is all the passport you'll need. Top cry-in-your beer juke joints The Poodle Dog Lounge, 6407 Burnet Road. A terrifying looking female bartender will greet you. Rock to 'Trashy Women' by Confederate Railroad, cry with George Jones or laugh with John Prine. Lala's Little Nugget, 2207 Justin Lane. Christmas decorations stay up all year and the jukebox offers Glen Miller, Dean Martin and Johnny Gonzalez. The Horseshoe Lounge, 2430 South Lamar Boulevard. Made famous by local boy Slaid Cleaves's song of the same name. Deep Eddy Cabaret, 2315 Lake Austin Boulevard. Neighbourhood bar where you can listen to Tom Waits and Dwight Yoakam. The Dry Creek Saloon, Mount Bonnell Road. An extraordinary two-tiered shack open only 4pm-8pm and not on Sundays. Run by 90-year-old Sarah, this is not somewhere to request a martini. Where to stay There are two historic hotels at the heart of downtown Austin. The Driskill, 604 Brazos Street, (001 512 474 5911) was founded by oil baron Jesse Driskill in 1886. Rates from $205-$2,500 a night. The Hotel Intercontinental Stephen F Austin, 701 Congress Avenue, (001 512 457 8800) opened in 1924 and is named after the 'father of Texas'. Prices start at $159 for special weekend deals. A cheaper option and with the slogan 'so close, yet so far out' is the Austin Motel, 1220 South Congress, (001 512 441 1157). A twin-bedded room costs from $80. Getting there American Airlines' return fares from Heathrow to Austin from £347, including taxes,to £769 in the summer (08457 789 789). For a free information pack on Austin and the rest of Texas, call the Texas Tourism UK office on 0207 978 5233.

fields.headline: World of natural wonder
fields.standfirst: From chasing twisters to tuning in to turtles,  Sarah Turner offers the pick of holidays with a difference
fields.trailText: From chasing twisters to tuning in to turtles, Sarah Turner offers the pick of holidays with a difference.
fields.body:
Twisting

What: tornado chasers, who would claim that the film Twister is unrealistic, spend hours on buses each day in Kansas and other Midwest states in pursuit of meteorological excitement, accompanied by weather satellite systems, designed to help them get close to tornado action.

Where: Tornado Alley - around Texas, Oklahoma, Wyoming, Colorado, Nebraska and Iowa as well as Kansas.

When: May and June.

How: Tempest Tours, (001 817 274 9313) has several trips this year from $1,900 (£1,300). Prices do not include flights from Britain.

Eclipse

What: Africa is a long way to go to experience a total eclipse of the sun, but in the next 18 months the continent will see two of them. Unlike Britain in 1999, when the eclipse was clouded by lack of visibility, this is not likely to be a problem. This year's eclipse takes place at the height of the dry season when cloud cover is likely to minimal. It will undoubtedly be an awe-inspiring occasion. Eclipsomaniacs would argue otherwise, but it is possibly a bit sad to visit a continent just for an experience that lasts between three minutes (Mozambique) and four minutes 34 seconds (Angola). However, combining it with other holiday options, including safaris, offers an unrivalled chance to see African wildlife get confused by an unexpected nightfall. (After Africa, the next solar eclipse will be in the Antarctic in 2003 and Turkey and Libya in 2006.)

Where: Africa - parts of Angola, Zambia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique and Madagascar in 2001. Angola, Zambia, Namibia, Botswana, Zimbabwe, South Africa, Mozambique (and the coast of South Australia) in 2002.

When: 21 June 2001 and 2 December 2002 (although in 2002 totality might be impaired as the eclipse takes place in the rainy season).

How: Sunvil (020 8232 9777) has limited availability on a variety of eclipse safaris. Prices from £2,589.

Northern lights

What: first the science bit. The Northern Lights - properly called the Aurora Borealis - occur when the earth's magnetic fields interact with solar storms. Meaning that, on a clear night near the Arctic Circle in winter, there is a spectacular light show with pulsating patches of green, yellow, blue (and occasionally red) light. In the winter of 2001/2002 the sun will be at the peak of its 11-year cycle which means that that the Northern Lights will be at their strongest.

Where: Northern Scandinavia, Iceland, North Canada and Alaska.

When: October to April.

How: Arctic Experience (01737 214214) has a four-day trip to Lake Myvatn in Iceland from £495.

Flamingos

What: the supermodel of the animal kingdom, the flamingo is an exquisitely pointless creature, whose life is largely devoted to feeding on the algae that gives it its distinctive colouring. It is the ultimate fashion victim - its spindly legs and non aero-dynamic body make it enormously attractive to predators. As a result, flamingos are forced to live in vast packs up to a million strong (looking not unlike a giant pink duvet); but create one of the most beautiful spectacles in the world at the same time.

Where: the Great Rift Valley in Africa, particularly Lakes Nakuru, Elmenteita, Bogoria and Natron.

When: all year.

How: Limosa Holidays (01263 578143) visits Lake Nakuru as part of its 15-day birdwatching safari The African Experience between 20 October and 3November 2001, from £2,895.

Wildebeest

What: making the London rush hour look like a cakewalk, each year millions of animals trek through the Serengeti and Masai Mara national parks. The stars are the million-odd wildebeest that arrive at the banks of the Grumeti River in July and August, plucking up courage to plunge through the crocodile-infested water to reach the pasture lands on the other side. Not for the fainthearted; lions and hyenas are also lying in wait to attack the wildebeest and zebras as they try to cross.

Where: Tanzania and Kenya.

When: July and August.

How: Cox and Kings (01233 211401) has an eight-day safari to the Serengeti from £2,855.

Namaqualand flowers

What: each year the semi-desert of Namaqualand, 400 miles north of Cape Town, is transformed into a multicoloured carpet of wild flowers containing more than 4,000 different species, including Michaelmas daisies, aloes, gladioli and lilies.

Where: South Africa.

When: late August/early September.

How: Rainbow Tours (020 7226 1004) offers a four-day flower tour from £1,095.

Polar bears

What: while waiting for Hudson Bay to freeze over, the world's largest posse of polar bears - around a thousand - head to the remote Canadian town of Churchill to forage for food and generally make a spectacle of themselves - even though the town instigates a polar bear prison for those it catches (the bears are removed to a more suitable environment by helicopter). Churchill is also the ideal base to take trips in reinforced vehicles to see bears in the tundra (polar bears are not as mellow as a Fox's Glacier Mints advert would suggest).

Where: Canada.

When: late October and November

How: Discover the World (01737 218802) has a variety of trips including the nine-day trip Kingdom of the Ice Bear and the five-day Polar Bear Weekend (both £1,995).

Monarch butterflies

What: each winter, the Monarch butterfly flies south from the more northern parts of North America and congregates just below San Francisco to see in the winter in style. They shelter in their thousands in the Monterey pines and Eucalyptus trees - and spread their orange and black wings each morning to find food. The holiday of a lifetime; particularly for the butterflies (since their life span doesn't permit them to make a return trip).

Where: Monterey, California.

When: October to February.

How: Discover the World (01737 218802) has an eight-day trip to Monterey Foray from £1,595.

Bear fest

What: it depends whether you prefer fish to bears, but twice a year, in rivers north of Vancouver, native bears (mostly black with a few brown ones) are guaranteed to be at the water's edge in large numbers when thousands of spawning salmon head upriver, presenting easy pickings for bear and photographer alike.

Where: Alaska.

When: May and especially July to mid- August.

How: North American Highways (01902 851138) has an 11-day trip, Totem, Bears, Whales and Glaciers in Southeast Alaska, which includes a three-night stay near the Anan Bear Sanctuary on the Stikine River from £2,200.

Icebergs and penguins

What: white on white makes for some of the most stunning images in the natural world, and nowhere more so than Antarctica. Prime sights include the four million penguins on Macquarie Island, as well as the largest concentration of whales in the world; plus icefloes and icebergs galore.

Where: Antarctica.

When: Between November and March (heavy ice makes it impossible to navigate the Antarctic outside these dates).

How: Wildlife Worldwide (020 8667 9158) has a 29-day cruise abroad the Kapitan Khlebnikov from £9,045.

Manta rays

What: manta rays are friendly, fascinating but not exactly beautiful. However, even a fish that is clearly modelled on a 1970s-style spaceship has pride. They turn up in the Ari Atoll in the Maldives each year to get a spring clean from wrasse and crustacea which remove parasites and dead skin.

Where: Maldives.

When: December to April.

How: Regal Diving (0870 220 1777) has an eight-day trip from £1,129 until April.

Turtles

What: green and Leatherback turtles practice their one-stop motherhood experience by scrabbling onshore at Tortuguero, a national park on the Caribbean coast of Costa Rica. They arrive to lay their eggs on a protected beach before swimming away to continue a life of blissful irresponsibility (hunting has now been banned).

Where: Costa Rica.

When: July to August for green turtles, February to July for Leatherbacks.

How: Trips Worldwide (0117 311 4402) offers a 15-day holiday to Costa Rica, including three nights in Tortuguero, from £1,850.

Whale births

What: right now, pregnant great grey whales are going for the push in the world's biggest birthing pool - the warm shallow waters of the San Ignacio and Magdalena Bays of Baja California. Grey whales are friendly, which makes this one of the closest encounters humans can have with wildlife. Boats are prevented by law from approaching the whales but, like new parents everywhere, the mothers seem anxious to show off their offspring by repeatedly bringing them to the boats.

Where: Baja California (which - despite the name - is in Mexico).

When: Late January to late February.

How: Wildlife Worldwide (020 8667 9158) from £1,545 for a nine-day trip.

 All prices are per person, including flights and accommodation, based on two people sharing.

fields.headline: American yellow school buses come to Britain in safety drive
fields.trailText: Yellow school buses, the national icon of the American education system, are to be brought to Britain in a multi-million pound scheme to improve the safety of children travelling to school.
fields.body:
Yellow school buses, the national icon of the American education system, are to be brought to Britain in a multi-million pound scheme to improve the safety of children travelling to school.

The Government will use 18 pilot schemes around the country to test the buses, which are famous for their flashing lights, bright colours and taking Bart Simpson to and from school. One hundred buses will be shipped over from America to start in the autumn term.

'Parents want to be sure their children arrive at school safe and sound,' said John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister who is responsible for transport. 'Parents want buses they can trust and children feel secure in. They have such yellow buses in America. If they are good enough for American children why shouldn't our children have them?'

Officials said that the Government expects local authorities, who will be responsible for the new services, to vet drivers for criminal convictions, particularly in areas of child abuse. Councils can use similar powers to check on drivers' backgrounds that are available for people applying to run youth clubs.

Although the Government said no new money would be made available for the scheme, officials said local authorities could use a general increase in education funding from Whitehall to buy the new vehicles.

The pilot schemes will be launched in Manchester, Bristol and West Yorkshire. If successful, the buses will be made compulsory for all schools across the country. Sources said the Government did not want to see a 'two-tier' system developing where richer councils would buy the buses and poorer councils would be left with buses too old to continue on normal passenger routes.

The move has been sparked by increasing fears that old buses and coaches without the latest safety features such as seatbelts are being dumped on schools by bus companies.

The Government also hopes that using the buses will encourage parents to abandon the daily 'school run', which clogs up roads during rush hour, leads to higher levels of pollution and causes accidents outside schools as parents jostle for parking spaces. If successful, the use of the new buses over private cars could reduce peak hour traffic by a fifth.

The new buses will be fitted with seats designed for young people, seat belts and the usual American panoply of flashing red lights, large 'stop' flags on either side of the vehicle and interior video cameras to enforce discipline.

The buses will offer a door-to-door service for children, a guaranteed seat and will always have the same driver. In America, bus drivers are known as 'children's friends' because of the relationship they build up with the school over many years.

Children who live more than two miles away from their school will be able to use the buses by right. Children who live closer than that will be able to use the buses if they pay a fare.

The buses will be built by FirstGroup, the British bus and train company that has a contract to build the buses in America.

webTitle: Welsh MPs consider legal action to save Corus jobs

fields.headline: Welsh MPs consider legal action to save Corus jobs
fields.trailText: Officials in the Welsh Assembly have drawn up a legal challenge to Corus's plans for the closure of steelmaking plants in Wales unless negotiations with unions to save them succeed.
fields.body:
Officials in the Welsh Assembly have drawn up a legal challenge to Corus's plans for the closure of steelmaking plants in Wales unless negotiations with unions to save them succeed.

The assembly's Counsel-General, its chief legal officer, has produced a written opinion indicating that the Anglo-Dutch giant's proposals to axe 2,500 jobs by ending raw steelmaking at the Llanwern integrated plant, and to close the Ebbw Vale finishing works, could be challenged under European Law. Assembly members commissioned the opinion after Corus dismissed a bid from the ISTC steel union to buy Llanwern, saying that inviting 'additional competition' would 'totally undermine the objectives of our proposed restructuring'.

One assembly source said: 'We now think there may be a way forward using European competition law to prevent the closures and possibly to facilitate a buyout at the heavy [steelmaking] end of Llanwern and Ebbw Vale.'

Officials have examined regulations under the European Coal and Steel Community Treaty, and believe Corus's actions can be challenged.

The Counsel-General's opinion argues that closing plants could be anti-competitive because it would reduce production, putting customers at a disadvantage. It also points out that Corus would not have to intend this outcome for there to be an action under the treaty.

However, officials believe there could be complications with the case, as many of the consumers of Ebbw Vale's production are packaging companies, which have expe rienced rapid diversification away from steel as a core raw material. They could therefore source other materials, nullifying an anti-competition argument.

Nevertheless, Assembly Ministers are determined to challenge the Corus cuts if proposals by the ISTC to avoid redundancies by switching to part-time working are rejected.

They believe a successful legal challenge could re-open the prospect of successful buyouts. Welsh Assembly sources add that Ministers believe there is a commercial case for retaining the plants in future, particularly since the Government has indicated its intention to decide on a euro referendum within two years of the election. Corus blames the strength of the pound against the single currency for undermining its competitiveness in Europe, and wants early UK entry.

Mike German, Deputy First Minister in the assembly, said: 'We believe the union proposals should be given a fair wind and we are not going to act until they have run their course. But we are looking at all options and that includes how the law can help us.'

webTitle: Bush doesn't need a beautiful friendship

fields.headline: Bush doesn't need a beautiful friendship
fields.standfirst:
Being allowed to join in Washington's bombing raids on Iraq doesn't signal the start of a new 'special relationship'
The Bush files - Observer special
Guardian Unlimited special report: Iraq
Guardian Unlimited special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Being allowed to join in Washington's bombing raids on Iraq doesn't signal the start of a new 'special relationship'.
fields.body:
It could be the start of a beautiful friendship.' Whoever chose that headline for Robin Cook's recent article about Anglo-American relations can hardly have expected the friendship to be affirmed - or tested? - in such an explosive way. On Friday, just days before Tony Blair is due to fly in to Washington to meet the new American President George W. Bush, a fleet of American and British jets bombed military targets near Baghdad.

It's tempting to interpret this as a reminder of Anglo-American friendship in practice. 'What Dad did with your predecessor, I can do with you,' you can imagine Bush Junior saying as he shows Mr Blair around the White House. 'Together we can zap those towel-heads.'

Well, maybe. In reality, Friday's raid represents only a minor escalation of a campaign against Iraqi air power that has been going on without interruption since the time of the Gulf War. Still, it's not without significance that throughout that period it has been British planes as well as American that have been enforcing the so-called 'no-fly zone'. Not so much the beginning of a beautiful friendship as its continuation, then.

Yet before he engages in any macho backslapping on the White House lawn, Mr Blair should bear in mind where that quote about a 'beautiful friendship' comes from. It is at the very end of Casablanca that Humphrey Bogart's Rick utters the immortal line. But, significantly, he addresses it to a Frenchman, not an Englishman.

But the film cleverly avoids alluding to the fact that until this point Britain has been fighting the war against Hitler alone. The war Bogart joins is to free France - remember the famous scene when they all sing the 'Marseillaise' - not to help Britain, much less the British Empire.

A new version is doing the rounds, to the effect that Britain faces a choice between this special relationship and wholehearted commitment to Europe. The Economist recently made the case, citing as evidence of the dilemma American criticism of the projected European army and French criticism of the American missile defence programme. Many Eurosceptics, including Conrad Black, argue that Britain would be better off in North American Free Trade Agreement than in the European Union.

It's fantasy. There is no question of a choice between America and Europe. American wants Britain in Europe, where it can act as an Anglophone check on the French. 'Hurry up and join the euro' will be George W.'s parting shot. That most British voters trust Washington far more than Brussels could not interest Bush less.

What makes Blair's position awkward has little to do with his shameless cuddling up to Mr Bush's predecessor. It is the bigger problem all British politicians face when they go to America: we think we matter more than they think we do.

The resilience of our belief in the specialness of the transatlantic relationship is rather mysterious considering how the US has treated us in the past century. True, the Americans fought on our side in the world wars. But they fought for quite different objectives, and in the Second World War one of these was the break-up of the British Empire. The last volume of Robert Skidelsky's biography of Keynes makes this very clear.

More recently, American Anglophobia has become unexpectedly visible in Hollywood. Who would have predicted that when the Russians ceased to be credible movie villains the Brits would take their place? And yet there we are - most recently in the outrageous film The Patriot - cast as the SS in red coats.

Nor should we be reassured by the apparent Anglophilia that spawned the film Notting Hill . It is rather worse to be regarded as a nation of Hugh Grants: picturesque, endearing, amusing, effete.

Nevertheless, Mr Blair should resist the temptation to cringe as he enters the Oval Office. After all, we are their political and cultural ancestor. Britain's fate - to decline from being the world's greatest empire to a position of dog-like inferiority - should be a warning to the US that pride can come before a big fall.

American hubris is understandable. In the wake of the collapse of the Soviet Union, they are the only superpower in town. Their economy is vast, their people the richest in all history. The crisis of confidence that afflicted the US in the 1970s is long forgotten. Above all, they seem so far ahead of the competition in the realm of military technology that they need fear no one.

Yet it is instructive to compare the American position today with that enjoyed by the Victorians at the time of Lord Salisbury. In those days the British economy still led the world (it was not until the 1920s that American productivity overtook Britain's). And the Royal Navy occupied the same position as the US Air Force occupies today, lobbying shells at troublesome regimes more or less at will. Unlike the US, which in past decades has become the world's largest borrower, the UK's power abroad was firmly based on high levels of capital export. We were the world's banker.

What went wrong? Historians - notably Paul Kennedy - used to argue that Britain was a victim of 'overstretch': its imperial commitments became so great that ultimately the burden became an economic handicap. Yet this theory falls apart when the actual cost of defending the British Empire is worked out. Rather, it was the failure of the UK to meet the military challenge posed by the newly united Germany that was fatal to British power. There is a lesson here for the US. Superficially, American power is vast. But its foundations may be less solid than Mr Bush assumes.

There was a whiff of hubris in the remarks last week of new Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill. Financial crises, he opined, don't 'have anything to do with the failure of capitalism. It's to do with the absence of capitalism.' He posed the alarming question: 'Why [in the event of a crisis in foreign economy] do we have to intervene?'

The reality is that the US cannot afford to be indifferent to a financial crisis in, for example, Asia, when so much of the headlong growth of the past decade has been financed by foreign investors. Nor can the US simply withdraw like some well-fed snail into its missile-proof shell when the most serious threats it faces are from terrorist-borne devices. After all, where do most terrorists come from? From far-away places of which American voters know nothing. And who might equip them with enough plutonium to flatten Manhattan? Those same rogue states that the US Air Force periodically drops bombs on.

So Tony should not expect the beginning of a beautiful friendship. He should not even bank on the continuation of the old 'special relationship', since no such thing has ever really existed. Instead, he should be prepared to counter American condescension with a warning: Beware the hubris that besets today's 'top nation'. A century ago Britain that bestrode the globe.

No one can say what form the future challenge to American hegemony will take. Only two things are certain. It will not come from the militarily insignificant United States of Europe that Americans would like to see Britain absorbed by. And whatever form the threat does take, a complacent and insular US may be the last to spot it.

fields.headline: Scottish Value Management Isa
fields.trailText: Contact: 0131 226 7660
fields.body:
Contact: 0131 226 7660

Aim: To generate capital growth by investing in one or more funds from SVM's Dublin based range.

Bells & whistles: Of the five funds on offer, SVM New Economy (a technology fund investing in the UK and Europe) has grown by 89% since its launch in March last year to the end January this year, while UK Opportunities, a portfolio of medium and smaller UK companies, has grown by 50.45% over the same period. In contrast the FTSE All-share has fallen by about 3%.

How it works: All five funds - UK Growth, European Growth, Continental Europe, New Economy and UK Opportunities - reflect SVM's distinctive 'value' investment style. Managers concentrate on the real intrinsic value of companies rather than following popular perception or stock market trends. The trusts are managed in a 'collegiate' manner by a team of seven fund managers led by investment guru Colin McLean, who is also lead manager on the SVM UK Growth fund.

Minimum: Lump sum £1,000, monthly £50.

Charges: Initial charge 5%, annual 1.25%.

Tax: Free from income and capital gains tax. Pep transfers available from April 6.

Risk: Medium/high, depending on your choice of funds.

Should you invest? Nick Holmes of London independent financial adviser Brooks Macdonald Gayer is enthusiastic: 'McLean is industry renowned for his stock picking ability and the funds' performance is excellent. The only concern I would have is that their speciality is the UK and Europe.' John Hutton-Attenborough of Berry Birch & Noble is less keen: 'Scottish Value Management has a reasonable reputation, largely based on the investment trust of the same name, but most of their other funds are mediocre. I would stick to more conventional UK based funds.'

Points out of 10: Holmes - 7, Hutton-Attenborough - 6.

fields.headline: Freudian clicks
fields.standfirst:
Sue Webster makes an appointment with her e-shrink and finds online therapy a virtual success
Read 'Hooked on addiction' here
fields.trailText: Sue Webster makes an appointment with her e-shrink and finds online therapy a virtual success.
fields.body:
As Sigmund Freud once said, there is not one human relationship which is not tinged with ambivalence. The same might be said of modern man's relationship with technology. Take the worldwide web: some people love it for its instant access to knowledge, its ability to reach out through cyberspace and create a sense of community, its convenience and speed. Some hate it for its unedited maelstrom of information, its inevitable American bias and its frustrated commercialism.

But most of us both love and hate it at the same time, so it's hardly surprising if the idea of therapy via the internet is the subject of hot debate. Certain psychological schools are inherently opposed to e-counselling. Ann Shearer, a Jungian analyst who can be contacted through her website but only works face to face, explained: 'We do in-depth work with the unconscious over a period of time of some intensity. The relationship is crucially important and cannot be replicated by tapping up a picture on screen or sending written messages. But counselling is for one specific problem, whereas analysis is much deeper.'

Since face-to-face therapy places great emphasis on body language, tone of voice and other non-verbal signals to diagnose state of mind, many of the fears uninitiated therapists have about online work relate to lack of such peripheral information. 'How can you tell if a client is lying?' is a popular question, according to Kate Anthony, an online counselling consultant and trainer (www.onlinecounsellors.co.uk). Her answer is always: 'Why should they, since online counselling has to be paid for? In any case, Freudians would argue that any part of a person, real or invented, is still a part of them. "Acting out" in cyberspace may be immensely therapeutic.'

Anthony is in a better position than most commentators on the subject. As a member of the British Association for Counselling's working party for drawing up ethics and guidelines for online counselling, she was commissioned last year to research the differences between e-counselling and face-to-face work.

She talks about the unique features of online therapeutic relationships. The way in which the client's lack of concrete knowledge about his counsellor can allow him to picture him in whatever way suits his therapeutic growth best - there are no 'first impressions' to get over.

Then there's electronic rapport or telepresence (being able to communicate so effectively online that the medium of communication between counsellor and client - the computer - seems to disappear), and net-iquette.

But these effects clearly have to be experienced to be believed. Of the 20 or so psychologists, psychotherapists, psychiatrists, counsellors and former clients whom I canvassed for this article, all those who expressed grave misgivings about online work had little or no experience of it. Those who had experience were uniformly positive - mostly enthusing about the opportunity to communicate directly with another person's psyche without any of the usual prejudices relating to personal appearance, lifestyle, etc - while at the same time being honest about its limitations.

More worrying for potential e-clients, perhaps, is the scope for charlatanism - but here the internet is no different from real life (except that there are no opportunities for physical seduction). Several experienced on- and offline therapists interviewed report the occasional brush with dotcom fever. Nicola Blakeney (no longer online due to pressure of conventional work) notes that counsellors who enquire about how much money there is to be made, or wonder idly whether they could increase their client load via the net, are due for a rude awakening.

'It's just as time-consuming, if not more so, than face-to-face therapy,' she says. 'And some counsellors naively think they need not impose such rigid boundaries, because of the physical distance. Of course that's not true: your mailbox will be overflowing with the most distressing stories and you have to be clear about how you will deal with them.'

It was time to try out cybershrinking for myself. I had been in conventional therapy before, at a time in my life when a long-term relationship was breaking up and I was so miserable I felt I couldn't afford not to go. This time I would use the issues I had confronted then to test out the responses of therapists working by email.

Getting started was tough. I typed 'online counselling' into a search engine and came up with 2,000 hits. Some sites give helpful guidance to prospective e-clients but by no means offer recommendations. I plodded on. Among the first sites I looked at was one devoted to the 'totally unique' Thought Field Therapy developed by a Californian psychologist, which, unlike any other therapy, is able to offer a 'cure' for psychological problems within minutes. And without requiring the individual to talk about their problem. Then there was a psychodynamics site, http://web.ukonline.co.uk/psychodynamics/index.htm, which claimed to use 'the most advanced Psycho-technologies' to resolve personal problems. These were listed alphabetically in a sort of tragicomic shopping list, from abuse, abusive relationships, affairs and alcoholism through to stress management, snoring, transsexuals, transvestites, unfaithfulness, unreasonable behaviour and vaginismus. Oddly, perhaps, I did not feel my problems could be quite so easily categorised. And I certainly did not believe they could be cured within minutes - with or without dialogue.

Eventually I found a site (www.onlinecounsellingandtherapy.com) with a slightly tacky picture of a sunrise and a terrestrial address in Seaford. I didn't feel especially drawn to the 'senior email counsellor' who allegedly had 10 years' experience, but I reasoned that the service was (perhaps unwisely) generous. It cost £40 per week for an unlimited number of emails, which would be promptly answered, with the first email free. I wrote a careful résumé of a previous failed relationship involving the demon drink and sent it into the ether. I still wonder why there was no reply. Were the problems described too insignificant? Is it possible to detect inauthenticity across cyberspace? Do online counsellors quit without posting a message on their site?

Luckily, in the meantime, I had stumbled across another site called The Fellow Traveller, which appealed to me at once. Free information on counselling was set out in a warm, unpretentious style. It promised no certainties and warned against the sort of dependency which can be created by unscrupulous therapists. Better still, the site, which plays soothing classical music as you browse and uses a flickering candle flame and a message in a bottle bobbing in the sea among its interactive images, had been designed 'to be therapy in and of itself'.

I felt a rush of empathy towards the author, one Kim Smith, and poured out my ancient troubles to her in the first of half-a-dozen emails and instant-messaging sessions. These cost £26.50 each - no more than the face-to-face sessions I had known years earlier but often twice as long as the normally strict 'shrink's hour' (which is 50 minutes).

If it's hard to describe what took place in those sessions, that is only because the intangibles in any therapeutic relationship are its main point. But I felt accepted and understood, no matter how shocking or shameful the situations I posed might be. Of course I didn't see or hear Kim, but I responded to her challenges and felt her empathy. If I shilly-shallied with excuses, she saw through them; if I was self-pitying, she was ironic; but if I was honest and thoughtful, she seemed to embrace me through her words. She was the wise, generous mother I had always wished for.

Although I knew on one level that this idealisation was a fantasy, I still felt let down when I eventually made telephone contact with her. In fact, I was absolutely furious. Kim Smith is a man. A very nice, sympathetic man with a northern accent who used to live on a boat and admits to wearing sandals with socks. He wasn't what I had in mind - but once I had adjusted to the new reality, I had to admit that this was surely a positive aspect to online counselling.

After all, in the classic model of psychoanalysis, the client lies on a couch with the analyst out of view in order to facilitate any and all projections. Is a computer screen so very different from that blank wall? Freud himself might have approved.

Resources

There are three main regulatory bodies for off- and online counsellors, with lists of registered members: CCC; BAC and UKCP.

Qualifications and methodology

First, read up on the various counselling methods to see if they suit you, eg psychodynamic, person-centred, Gestalt. If the counsellor claims accreditation, check it against the awarding body (eg BAC, CCC, UKCP). But bear in mind that many therapists in their forties and fifties may be very experienced but have no qualifications, as accreditation schemes are a relatively recent phenomenon. It may be as relevant to check the counsellor's identity beyond the net - or ask why their ID is withheld.

Supervision

This is an essential component of the therapist's work, on- or offline: it keeps the client safe and the counsellor sharp, although, since every session is effectively recorded, e-counsellors are more exposed than most to criticism.

Privacy

Consider the counsellor's claims about confidentiality and the methods (eg encryption) which might ensure this.

Costs and payment

Pitfalls regarding online payment are well-known, but in addition, consider whether the time taken to type replies during instant messaging means the normal counselling session (50 minutes) is no longer such a bargain. Take care with payment methods over the net!

Email

How long is an email? How many emails may you send? How swift is the response guaranteed to be?

Instinct

If the style of the counsellor's website seems in some way tacky or does not inspire you with confidence, then move on - their understanding of working online may be naive. Once you're in a relationship with a therapist, beware of becoming trapped in it. A good counsellor's job is to make him/herself redundant, not to gain an income for life.

If it's hard to describe what took place in those sessions, that is only because the intangibles in any therapeutic relationship are its main point. But I felt accepted and understood, no matter how shocking or shameful the situations I posed might be. Of course I didn't see or hear Kim, but I responded to her challenges and felt her empathy. If I shilly-shallied with excuses, she saw through them; if I was self-pitying, she was ironic; but if I was honest and thoughtful, she seemed to embrace me through her words. She was the wise, generous mother I had always wished for. Although I knew on one level that this idealisation was a fantasy, I still felt let down when I eventually made telephone contact with her. In fact, I was absolutely furious. Kim Smith is a man. A very nice, sympathetic man with a northern accent who used to live on a boat and admits to wearing sandals with socks. He wasn't what I had in mind - but once I had adjusted to the new reality, I had to admit that this was surely a positive aspect to online counselling. After all, in the classic model of psychoanalysis, the client lies on a couch with the analyst out of view in order to facilitate any and all projections. Is a computer screen so very different from that blank wall? Freud himself might have approved. Resources There are three main regulatory bodies for off- and online counsellors, with lists of registered members: CCC; BAC and UKCP. Qualifications and methodology First, read up on the various counselling methods to see if they suit you, eg psychodynamic, person-centred, Gestalt. If the counsellor claims accreditation, check it against the awarding body (eg BAC, CCC, UKCP). But bear in mind that many therapists in their forties and fifties may be very experienced but have no qualifications, as accreditation schemes are a relatively recent phenomenon. It may be as relevant to check the counsellor's identity beyond the net - or ask why their ID is withheld. Supervision This is an essential component of the therapist's work, on- or offline: it keeps the client safe and the counsellor sharp, although, since every session is effectively recorded, e-counsellors are more exposed than most to criticism. fields.headline: Hooked on addiction
fields.standfirst:
It used to be just drink and drugs. But these days it seems we're even hooked on sex, work and food... Have we become addicted to addiction? Ursula Kenny reports on a nation in search of a fix
Read Sue Webster's guide to online therapy here
fields.trailText: It used to be just drink and drugs. But these days it seems we're even hooked on sex, work and food... Have we become addicted to addiction? Ursula Kenny reports on a nation in search of a fix
fields.body:
' When I go to meetings and I introduce myself, I say, "My name is David and I am an addict.' I go to four groups - AA, NA and SA - because I've been addicted to painkillers and alcohol and sex, but my primary addiction is to helping people, so I go to Helpers Anonymous because I'm a compulsive helper... '
David, 36, addict

Addiction used to live on the fringes, the periphery of society, but has spent the last 20 years worming its way into the everyday, the commonplace even. In 1980, this country had fewer than 10 residential addiction centres; there are now 150. Never before have the terms addict, addicts and addiction had such common currency; in 1990, newspapers used these words 428 times; by the year 2000, this figure had risen dramatically to 11,707.

And whereas we used to know exactly what we meant by an addict - 'Exhibit A' might be the characters in Trainspotting - now we're not so sure. Along with 'traditional' ideas of addictions to drugs and alcohol, there is now a move to include an ever-increasing number of activities, some of which are, frankly, hard to take seriously. The rise of 12-step therapy groups has contributed to a growing acceptance that there is now almost nothing that cannot be talked of in terms of addiction. There are currently 26 UK 12-step fellowships listed in Addiction Today magazine, including Gamblers Anonymous, Helpers Anonymous, Sex Addicts Anonymous, Overeaters Anonymous and Workaholics Anonymous. All 'behavioural' addictions and the logical conclusion is out there too: in the US, there is apparently a 12-step group for those who are addicted to going to 12-step groups.

The concept of behavioural addictions like these is nothing new in itself. As Deirdre Boyd, the editor of Addiction Today points out, you could say that the first behavioural addiction was identified in the 50s, 15 years after AA was founded, when Al-Anon started for the relatives and friends of alcoholics - 'the addiction to the addict, so to speak'. What is new, though, is the sheer range and number of, on the face of it, rather less obviously damaging behaviours and activities that are currently having the language and treatment of addiction applied to them.

There are obvious reasons for the rise in addiction and addicts - the sheer availability of drugs, for one thing. As Boyd says, 'Alcohol, nicotine and other drugs are currently available on a scale that has never been seen before, and it's causing problems.' There is also the fact that more of us have more money. 'At a very simple and crude level, the rise in addiction relates to the fact that we're much more affluent nowadays, because most addictions involve expenditure,' says psychologist Oliver James. 'Something like the rise of smoking and drinking among young women is certainly partly do to with that.'

'Alcohol was my passport to another place where none of the negative things in my life mattered any more. I entered an internal world where I could say anything, do everything, be anybody.'
Paul, 55, alcoholic

The rise in addictions also has a lot to do with our new-found willingness to talk about ourselves in terms of our emotional wellbeing, which in turn is part of our new-found willingness to call ourselves addicts. As James says, we use different language to define ourselves nowadays: 'Instead of talking about our social role in life, we talk about our internal state.' After a century of psychoanalysis and more than 50 years of peace, our lives tend not to be about mere survival any more. These days, we talk in terms of quality of life and self-realisation.

Addiction - as one of the big three mental-health issues along with depression and anxiety - is part of that landscape. There is also, as Boyd points out, 'an international media now that communicates all this stuff'. And certainly a day barely goes by without yet another celebrity admitting to an addiction openly and without shame: Naomi goes to Narcotics Anonymous, Geri attends Overeaters Anonymous, Robbie's an alcoholic, Mel Smith was addicted to painkillers, Michael Douglas to sex. Addiction is well and truly out.

And, of course, there is a way in which this is very healthy and positive, but there is also concern among some specialists, a feeling that we need to engage rather more critically with the concept of addiction. There are worries around the numbers of people who now see themselves as addicts. Not least of all because addiction is such a potent and powerful concept to buy into.

Neil Hunt, a lecturer in addictive behaviours at Kent University, feels that the word addiction is used too variously. 'The word is misused. There is a place for it, but it's being misused, and I think that people are genuinely confused. I believe in compulsive habitual behaviours, but I think it is unhelpful to describe them as addictions. In some ways, it's similar to when people who've got a cold tell you they've got flu; it's simply a way of making a grander claim.'

Hand in hand with this lies what Hunt sees as a general trend toward the 'pathologising' of any and all discomforts or anxieties. Which he feels in turn can be seen as a knock-on effect of the new and increasing workforce of people 'who have an interest in understanding problems and their solutions in these terms'.

'Obviously this isn't always a bad thing,' Hunt admits. But when it is, it can be disempowering. 'I think one of the messages that comes out of that way of thinking is that you can't sort out your own life - other people, experts, have to do it for you, and that's undermining.' There is a sense in which, he feels, we systematically underestimate the extent to which people can sort things out for themselves. 'I think we are discouraging that by problematising things more and more.'

'I went to NA and allowed myself the window to experience other people who had been where I had been and who loved me, for want of a better word, when I could not love myself. That is NA. That's what it's about. If you've got a problem with your teeth ,you go to the dentist. With drugs, you go to NA.'
Kate, 39, drug addict

Having a problem with addiction and going for treatment might mean detox, or therapy, or staying in a residential unit, or indeed all three in the short term, but in the long term it will nearly always involve attending a 12-step group. Attending a 12-step group means seeing yourself as having a disease called addiction that you will have for the rest of your life. Despite not necessarily agreeing with this, practically all professionals who work in addiction recommend 12-step, simply because as crisis intervention and for ongoing support, it works.

Professor Nick Heather, an expert in alcoholism, explains. 'If someone gives up alcohol, it leaves an enormous vacuum in their life; they have nothing to do with the time they spent in the pub, and life becomes less meaningful because it was so structured around this behaviour. But if you link up with a whole bunch of people who have this problem, you have a new identity.' A new way of being, if you like, but the point is, first and foremost you are an addict, lots of your friends will be addicts and it will inform everything you do... which is a potent way to define oneself and perhaps just not always appropriate. It's quite a leap to go from having a behaviour that you use too much to seeing yourself in these terms.

On top of this, Professor John Davies, a psychologist at Strathclyde University and the author of The Myth of Addiction , says that seeing oneself as an addict is an incapacitating belief. 'Research shows that if someone has a damaging habit, the belief that they are addicted to it makes them less likely to attempt to stop and more likely to fail when they try.'

'I came to a meeting and said, "My name is Simon and I'm a sex addict." I found describing myself as an addict incredibly helpful when I first came to recover. Suddenly the reality of what I had become clicked in to focus.'
Simon, 47, sex addict

There is great debate among experts these days about when behaviour should be seen as an addiction. There is little doubt that drugs like alcohol, nicotine and hard drugs are potentially addictive, that is, they have an external pharmacology that acts on our nervous system and their long-term use involves tolerance and withdrawal if we stop using them. They are also clearly damaging to our health in the long term.

But what about behaviours like sex, shopping and surfing the net, even - behaviours which aren't inherently damaging, that don't have an external pharmacology, but which are routinely talked about in terms of addiction nowadays?

Even among experts there isn't one clear line of thought about this. Professor Griffith Edwards at the National Addiction Centre believes, for example, that talking of shopping or exercise addiction in the same way as, say, alcohol or crack-cocaine addiction can be dangerous. 'You can trivialise the idea of dependency by saying, "What about shopping, what about pinching cars", but it's playing with words, really; it's not very like what's going on with heroin.'

Jim Offord, professor of psychology at Birmingham University and the author of Excessive Appetites , wants us to extend our understanding of addiction so we don't just see it as being about drugs, but he would only want to include other activities/behaviours that, as he puts it, 'really are a major problem for people - as with, say, sex addiction, overeating and gambling. These are activities that change one's mood dramatically. They're very pleasurable, they can be very reinforcing and therefore it's not surprising that some people get out of control with them and that they cause people terrible problems on a large scale. The problem is that there is a tendency for people to then rush from that and say, "I'm addicted to shopping", or chocolate, or to talk about "love addiction" or being "a workaholic".'

For Offord, this is extending the concept a little further than he feels comfortable with. 'There's a danger of seeing addiction as a pan concept when sometimes what people are really talking about are attachments. Caffeine is quite a good example; people get attached to caffeine to the point where they can't easily go out without having a cup of coffee or tea, but it doesn't matter very much.'

So have we been overstating the case for addiction? Leaping to use the term more often than we should and in a way that isn't always appropriate or healthy? John Davies's assertion that 'talking about habits, un- fortunate habits that people persist in, like the internet, shopping or working as addictions, is a totally bogus concept' may seem a little strong, but at the very least we should acknowledge the dangers of talking oneself into such a loaded position, of calling oneself an addict and buying into all that implies, or of accepting the label unquestioningly.

As Davies points out, 'The Diagnostic and Statistical manual of the American Psychiatric Association says that a hallmark of addiction is that a person continues to do something despite clear knowledge that it is damaging. Well, I climb a bit, and one of my heroes carries on climbing despite incurring lots of injuries, which are clearly damaging. Do we therefore conclude that he needs treatment because he's sick? I don't think so.'

Of course the irony is, as Deirdre Boyd says, 'If you're not an addict, you'll probably rush to say you are; if you are, you'll deny it for a long time.'
