fields.headline: New raiders hit Auld Reekie
fields.standfirst: Irate investors want City watchdogs to investigate whether a Scottish unit trust was wrong to surrender to a US vulture fund.   Paul Farrelly  on a battle pitching London against Edinburgh
fields.trailText: Irate investors want City watchdogs to investigate whether a Scottish unit trust was wrong to surrender to a US vulture fund. Paul Farrelly on a battle pitching London against Edinburgh
fields.body:
Arise Sir Jimmy Goldsmith, you have a worthy successor. Sierra Trading, a secretive US 'vulture fund' that targets underperformers, has been cast as a villain in the mould of the worst corporate raiders.

And if it is allowed to get away with its antics - which, it must be stressed, are perfectly legal - Britain might yet import some of the nastiest, dirtiest corporate tactics, that ravaged the United States in the 1980s, but have now been all but stamped out across the Atlantic. Or so predicts Hermes, one of the City's most powerful institutions with more than £50 billion to spend.

However, the real target of Hermes' spleen is Scottish Investment Trust (SIT), run by some of Scotland's biggest movers and shakers. According to Hermes, SIT has made a pact with the devil. Worse, its blue-blooded chairman, the venerable Sir Angus Grossart, has dismissed Hermes' concerns with a patrician flick of the wrist. In doing so, he has turned the spotlight on the cosy, tight-knit Edinburgh financial community and the olde worlde sector of investment trusts, which the Scots dominate.

'What is odd about this industry is that it is run for itself. Boards are just stuffed with worthies,' says an agitated David Pitt-Watson, the commercial director of Hermes Lens Asset management, an Anglo-US joint venture set up quietly three years ago to shake up complacent companies. 'We prefer to work with managements to solve problems. We offered support against Sierra. But what they've done is to cave in to something very close to "greenmail". They've favoured one particular shareholder over another. So now it's no more Mr Hermes Nice Guy.'

At first sight New Jersey-based Sierra, a relatively small arbitrage house, hardly seems to fit the shadow of Carl Icahn, the veteran stock market predator who claimed to have discovered 'greenmail' by accident in the 1980s. Buying a strategic stake and then persuading, cajoling or simply coercing companies to buy it back at a tidy profit was more lucrative than trying to take over the whole shooting match.

Now 64, Icahn turned 'greenmail' into an art form: over 20 years, he has pocketed billions by turning the screw on some of the biggest corporations in the world. US Steel, Texaco, Trans World Airlines, Phillips Petroleum, tyremaker Goodrich-Uniroyal, RJR Nabisco and, most recently, General Motors. All hang on hooks in Icahn's trophy room.

So lucrative the practice proved to be that all sorts of corporate wolves, including Goldsmith and Rupert Murdoch, took time off to make a killing through Wall Street raids.

Sierra, certainly, is not in that league. For starters, it picks on investment trusts, quoted vehicles that buy shares in other stock market companies. Glamorous the sector is not. But it is a huge industry, worth £55 billion, which is a key part of Britain's savings and investment scene. And like any other sector, it goes through periodic bouts of vicious blood-letting.

More often than not, it is a touch of the Hannibal Lecters that stirs the sleepy industry from slumber. Ten years ago, the British Coal pension funds pounced in a £1.1bn hostile bid for Globe Investment Trust and broke it up. Last year 3i, the giant of the industry, just failed to snap up rival Electra for £1.25bn. What stirs the cannibal instinct is 'the discount'. All trust managers levy charges and, as a rule, most underper form the market. This manifests itself in the 'discount', the difference between the trust's market capitalisation and the value of the shares it owns. If the discount becomes too great, it pays to bid for a trust and, as British Coal did, sell the shares it owns.

Over the past four years, Sierra, fronted by Alex Hanson, a 35-year-old arbitrageur, has made a tidy living for its rich US private investors by targeting floundering trusts in the UK. Its typical modus operandi is not to bid but threaten effectively to liquidate the trust, a vote of corporate hara-kiri. No wonder, then, that the cufflinks and braces brigade of fund-managers prefer to buy the likes of Sierra off when the comfortable job and Christmas bonus is on the line.

Hanson stresses, of course, that Sierra's tactics have been vetted by some of the sharpest legal minds in the City. He spits blood at the connotations 'greenmail' conjures up (the practice is still legal in the US but, since a 1987 Act of Congress, the profits have been simply taxed away) and a letter from his City solicitors has already winged its way to Pitt-Watson. With justification, Hanson says it is up to trust boards to ensure they follow the rules. After all, what's at issue here is not the law but the sacred rule 9.16 of the UK stock exchange regulations, which says: 'A company having listed shares must ensure equality of treatment for all holders of such shares.'

Hanson said: 'We have no control over these boards. We have been well-advised and there were leading brokers, like Cazenove, involved in all these transactions. The accusation of greenmail is totally misapplied in this case. They are making a huge thing out of it just to get more leverage over SIT. By cutting the discount, all shareholders benefit from our activity and none more so than Hermes.'

Hermes first locked horns with Sierra in 1997, when the US arbitrageur took a tilt at Kleinwort's Overseas Invest ment Trust. Since then, Sierra has collected several scalps and in December mounted its biggest assault yet, threatening the liquidation of up to seven trusts, including SIT and the huge Foreign & Colonial. To do so, Sierra ploughed £270 million into key stakes. Invariably, it was bought off, but in each case, except SIT, the trust made the same buy-back offer to all shareholders. In F&C's case, Sierra declined the offer as not generous enough.

Initially, SIT came out all guns blazing. But what has angered Hermes and other shareholders was SIT's volte- face on 11 January when it announced it had bought back the whole of Sierra's stake, nearly 8 million shares at 458p each - a generous 9.5 per cent discount to net asset value, against the prevailing 13 per cent in the market. However, SIT's subsequent offer to other investors, like Hermes, was limited to just 30 per cent of their shares. SIT's board, namely, only had authority to buy back 15 per cent of its stock in any one year and had used most of that already. 'I think the SIT board blew it. They should have given the other shareholders opportunity to sell,' Hanson told The Observer .

The Scots, however, have so far refused to cede any ground to their disgruntled investors. 'There was quite a lot of uncertainty and we felt it was desirable to end that,' SIT managing director Ian McLeish said, justifying the Sierra about-turn. 'We have operated in accordance with the buy-back rules. We have 33,000 investors. It's just not possible to make a buy-back offer to all shareholders.'

It is a hard-nosed stance Hermes intends to break by confronting SIT chairman Sir Angus Grossart at the trust's annual meeting this Friday in Edinburgh's Roxburghe Hotel in Charlotte Square, the heart of the Scottish financial establishment. Pitt-Watson will demand that SIT uses its new 15 per cent authority to launch a new buy-back - worth up to £150m - on the same terms given to Sierra. Otherwise, Hermes is prepared to recruit other City institutions and possibly remove SIT's board next year in a battle that would pitch London against Edinburgh.

In the meantime, it has also asked the Financial Services Authority, the City watchdog, to investigate and plug any loopholes in stock exchange regulations. SIT denies any breach, but Hermes begs to differ. 'We think the rules have been broken. If they haven't, greenmail would be allowed and the FSA should tighten the rules,' Pitt-Watson said. 'The problem with greenmail is that if one person does it, everyone will. Greenmail benefits the aggressive, disruptive, des-tructive shareholders, not people like us who prefer to work alongside companies.'

Who's who in Charlotte Square

Edinburgh is Britain's second financial centre and its public school, royalist old guard is deeply suspicious - in equal measure - of new Labour politicians who brought devolution and the brash American money-men who have bought up the City of London.

Edinburgh's fund managers - the 'Charlotte Square mafia' - invest £350 billion of pension and insurance funds, while in nearby St Andrews Square the banks and insurers, 'the Scotia Nostra', have been zealous in maintaining Scotland's distinct financial identity.

In the middle, in Princes Street and George Street respectively, lie two bastions of the Scottish establishment network: the New Club, Edinburgh's leading 'gentleman's club', and Scottish Financial Enterprise, a private business club which promotes Edinburgh's money skills.

With the arrival of self-made tycoons such as Stagecoach's Brian Souter, the sway of the old elite may be diminishing. But the blue-blooded establishment still wields considerable clout, and here are its current doyens:

Sir Angus Grossart, 63, chairs Edinburgh merchant bank Noble Grossart and Scottish Investment Trust (SIT). Among 16 other board positions, he is vice-chair of the Royal Bank of Scotland and Edinburgh Fund Managers, a director of brewer Scottish & Newcastle and chair of the Scottish Daily Record and Sunday Mail. He also belongs to the New Club and the Royal Ancient Golf Club of St Andrews.

Sir George Mathewson, 60, is deputy chairman and former chief executive of the Royal Bank of Scotland and a director of SIT. He also chairs insurer Direct Line and in the Eighties was chief executive of the Scottish Development Agency. He, too, frequents the New Club.

Viscount Younger of Leckie, 69, is the former Tory Minister of Defence and Scottish Secretary, George Younger. He now chairs the Royal Bank of Scotland and is on the board of two investment trusts in the Fleming and Murray stables. A member of the Caledonian Club, he is also a brigadier in the Royal Company of Archers and the Queen's Scottish 'bodyguard'.

Sir John Shaw, 68, Governor of the Bank of Scotland, chair of Scottish Financial Enterprise and the Scottish American Investment Co, a director of five other trusts and numerous public and private bodies. Scotland's most prominent accountant, he is a member of both the New Club and Caledonian Club.

Sir Charles Fraser, 72, is Scotland's most prominent corporate lawyer. A former vice-chair of United Biscuits, he has been on the board of umpteen Scottish firms and is still a director of insurer Scottish Widows and two investment trusts. He is, of course, a member of the New Club and plays golf at St Andrews.

fields.headline: Sebastian Coe: the running mate
fields.standfirst: What does William Hague's best mate and chief of staff actually do? And why is this former Olympic champion and world-record holder firing off insults at our greatest-ever sprinter?
fields.trailText: February 18 2001: You could be forgiven for believing that the two great athletic champions of British sport, middle distance runner Sebastian Coe and sprinter Linford Christie, had once more taken to the track in the ultimate Clash of the Titans.
fields.body:
· DoB: 29 September 1956
· Married to: Nicola McIrvine, 1990 (two sons, two daughters)
· Educated: Loughborough University (BSc Honours, Economics and Social History)
· Good at: Running - Olympic gold 1,500m, silver 800m, in 1980 and 1984 set world records in 1981 for the 800m, 1,000m and mile
· Job: William Hague's chief of staff and judo partner

It sounds like another sporting triumph for the golden boy of the 800 metres. And you could be forgiven for believing that the two great athletic champions of British sport, middle distance runner Sebastian Coe and sprinter Linford Christie, had once more taken to the track in the ultimate Clash of the Titans.

But the latest contest, sparked by an article in the women's magazine Eve , is more like an old-fashioned street brawl where accusations of drug abuse, cheating, boorishness, snobbery and racism fly thick and fast.

The contrast between both men could hardly be greater. Linford Christie is a tough, irreverent black south Londoner with a volatile temper. Coe, with his luxuriant hair and chiselled face, was always viewed as the Cliff Richard of sport, the clean-living son-in-law of mothers' dreams. Like butter, steroids wouldn't melt in his mouth. Yet there are a few similarities: both Seb and Linford are famous enough to be known by their first names and both are multi-millionaires who have relayed track achievements into hard cash.

Round one opened in Eve where Christie laid into the sporting officials who had down the years dogged him for drugs tests. Athletics, he claimed, was 'corrupt' and he never wanted his kids to take part. Round two came in the Daily Telegraph when Coe, with barely suppressed fury, took apart the reputation, records and personality of his former team mate. Christie was a 'boor', a cheat, a mean-spirited egotist, an ungrateful wretch. That was just starters.

'I sat in one team meeting when he made himself deliberately unintelligible to all but those who had a passing knowledge of jive and, if officialdom was to blame for anything it was for turning a blind eye to his boorish behaviour and then making him team captain to buy some peace,' noted now ennobled Baron Coe of Ranmore in the County of Surrey. Coe all but accused Christie of abusing drugs throughout his career, thereby tarnishing the sprinter's greatest triumph in taking the 100-metre Olympic gold at Barcelona in 1992.

'In 1988, however, he [Christie] avoided suspension for failing a drug test at the Seoul Olympics by one vote of the International Olympic Committee's medical commission. The test result was attributed to ginseng and he was given the benefit of the doubt by a sport he now despises. Some thought him lucky. Me included.' The language was intemperate, reckless and vicious. Coe's ugly reference to 'jive' sparked accusations of racism and an almost bemused retort from Christie. 'He is supposed to be Lord Coe - maybe he did not get the recognition he wanted from judo.'

The barb was apt as Coe's more recent media appearances are connected not with old sporting glories but with his new judo partner, Conservative leader William Hague. To prepare the unsporty William for the rigours of Prime Minister's Question Time, and cast off the nerdy image, Coe recruited an Olympic judo pal, Ray Stevens, to teach them both the art of throwing your opponent.

The sessions went well. Hague is said to have knocked Coe down in one particularly ferocious assault. And for a brief moment Conservative Central Office toyed with the idea of letting the cameras in on their weekly session in the gym below Jeffrey Archer's penthouse. Wiser counsel prevailed.

But number one judo partner is just one of the roles Coe now occupies in the Hague kitchen cabinet. He is First Best Mate, chief confidant, chief of staff, head gatekeeper and chief factotum. If you ring Hague, Coe answers. No one, probably not even Ffion, spends more time in the Opposition leader's company.

Coe's vicious spat with Christie has turned into another skirmish on William Hague's Via Dolorosa. As the row raged, Hague was forced to intervene and issue the (usually terminal) statement of confidence in his aide-de-camp. It's all rather embarrassing for a party that is already dogged by accusations of playing the race card over refugees.

Once again Hague's judgement has been called into question. 'Part of the whole problem is that Hague surrounds himself with people who are not really suited to their role,' says an observer of the Tory leadership. 'Coe is reputedly some kind of chief of staff. But who is he? The grandees never take him seriously - he was only in Parliament for one term. He has no political weight. If he is a big wheeler-dealer than he should be wheeling and dealing. At the moment he just gets in the way, like in that Channel 4 film where you see him on the mobile: "We'll be there in two minutes." What does he do?'

For the past two years Coe has devoted himself to Hague's career, organising his diary, calibrating the leader's time down to the minute. He goes everywhere with William but never speaks. He is often the only aide in the meeting but no secrets leak from his lips. He has made a virtue of public invisibility. That is until now when, from fighting the battles of an old war, he has backed foolishly into the media limelight on the eve of the election campaign.

Coe's allies insist that he was, as president of the Amateur Athletics Association, defending both the sport he loved and the legions of amateur coaches who give up their evenings and weekends to train youngsters for nothing more than a cold bench and a vague dream of glory. Other souls in the Conservative party are less forgiving. 'He's nice but dim,' said a Tory MP. 'He really believes in William, that he's a man of integrity, that he'll make a great Prime Minister. That's how dim he is.'

The wonder boy of British athletics was born in London in 1956 but moved to Sheffield, close to Hague's birthplace, Rotherham, when he was eight. He failed his 11-plus and ended up in a secondary modern. Unlike Hague, who shot to fame in the political equivalent of A Star is Born with that speech at the 1977 Conservative Party Conference, Coe's entry on to to the national stage was a process of attrition. Encouraged by his father, Peter, who coached him, he began to run when he was 12.

'Everywhere from my front door was effectively up,' said Coe, 'and there was a run we used to do that was uphill for 10 miles. We'd be out in all weathers, me running and my father driving, an odd couple having conversations through the car window. Often he would have music on and once in a storm of swirling snow and hail, when I had 14 miles on the road to do, he said: "I don't know what you've got out there, but I've got Wagner in here." I told him it was pretty Wagnerian where I was too.'

He later studied at Loughborough University but his real career was always running and his regime centred on a punishing amount of training - even now he likes to clock 25 miles a week just for the fun of it. Coe's philosophy was to strip himself down by single-mindedly and obsessively focusing on the goal ahead. 'You present yourself at the starting line in the best physical and mental condition,' he explained to bemused Tory MPs. He was Britain's greatest-ever middle distance runner Britain - a double 1500 metre Olympic gold medallist in Moscow in 1980 and Los Angeles in 1984. He broke 11 world records and his 1981 800-metre world record was only bettered in 1997.

With his good looks, he was a sponsor's dream and soon accumulated a serious amount of cash - he draws no salary from Central Office. His interests range from health clubs to hotel chains, sports facilities and media consultancies. He is well off and, suitably, has a big house in the country, a wife, Nicola, who trains horses, and four children. He is discreetly flash about his wealth - the gold Rolex just peeks out from under the silk shirt with its fancy cufflinks.

Maybe it was the competition of the track or the individuality of being a winner or loser, but Coe was a natural Tory and joined the party when he was 19. After his sports career ended, he was still a star, a genuine hero, and soon found a vacant seat, Falmouth and Cambourne in Cornwall, and was elected in 1992.

But the gilded path upwards stopped dead in its tracks in the House of Commons. Coe was a failure as an MP. He found the ritual contests across the debating floor alien and unnatural. He is not much of a public speaker. 'He did not like the confrontation, the fight, the whole debate thing that William is so brilliant at,' said a colleague. With dogged determination he made it into the Whips office in the final days of John Major's government but was turfed out in 1997.

In Parliament, Coe had built up close links with Hague and in February 1998 returned to the centre stage of the party as Hague's private secretary. Publicly his role is straightforward he organises things - planes, schedules, speaking engagements - and even acts as a kind of unofficial bodyguard. But privately his role remains a mystery even to many members of the Shadow Cabinet. Coe is undoubtedly Hague's closest confidant - the two men speak several times a day - but the content of their conversations remains veiled. It is a pragmatic relationship, not an ideological one. Coe admits he does not 'do policy', he is no Alastair Campbell. Perhaps the closest analogy is drawn from Coe's own background he acts like a coach, encouraging Hague to run that little bit faster in a contest he could never undertake.

Some of those who know them say they are still a matey double act. Others detect a shift in their relationship as Hague has grown in authority as Opposition leader. Seb, the star, is no longer a soul-mate but just another part of the machine that surrounds the leader.

But Seb Coe should hardly be surprised. As he well knows, it is the mark of every successful athlete that they outrun and outgrow their original coaches.

The barb was apt as Coe's more recent media appearances are connected not with old sporting glories but with his new judo partner, Conservative leader William Hague. To prepare the unsporty William for the rigours of Prime Minister's Question Time, and cast off the nerdy image, Coe recruited an Olympic judo pal, Ray Stevens, to teach them both the art of throwing your opponent. The sessions went well. Hague is said to have knocked Coe down in one particularly ferocious assault. And for a brief moment Conservative Central Office toyed with the idea of letting the cameras in on their weekly session in the gym below Jeffrey Archer's penthouse. Wiser counsel prevailed. But number one judo partner is just one of the roles Coe now occupies in the Hague kitchen cabinet. He is First Best Mate, chief confidant, chief of staff, head gatekeeper and chief factotum. If you ring Hague, Coe answers. No one, probably not even Ffion, spends more time in the Opposition leader's company. Coe's vicious spat with Christie has turned into another skirmish on William Hague's Via Dolorosa. As the row raged, Hague was forced to intervene and issue the (usually terminal) statement of confidence in his aide-de-camp. It's all rather embarrassing for a party that is already dogged by accusations of playing the race card over refugees. Once again Hague's judgement has been called into question. 'Part of the whole problem is that Hague surrounds himself with people who are not really suited to their role,' says an observer of the Tory leadership. 'Coe is reputedly some kind of chief of staff. But who is he? The grandees never take him seriously - he was only in Parliament for one term. He has no political weight. If he is a big wheeler-dealer than he should be wheeling and dealing. At the moment he just gets in the way, like in that Channel 4 film where you see him on the mobile: "We'll be there in two minutes." What does he do?' For the past two years Coe has devoted himself to Hague's career, organising his diary, calibrating the leader's time down to the minute. He goes everywhere with William but never speaks. He is often the only aide in the meeting but no secrets leak from his lips. He has made a virtue of public invisibility. That is until now when, from fighting the battles of an old war, he has backed foolishly into the media limelight on the eve of the election campaign. Coe's allies insist that he was, as president of the Amateur Athletics Association, defending both the sport he loved and the legions of amateur coaches who give up their evenings and weekends to train youngsters for nothing more than a cold bench and a vague dream of glory. Other souls in the Conservative party are less forgiving. 'He's nice but dim,' said a Tory MP. 'He really believes in William, that he's a man of integrity, that he'll make a great Prime Minister. That's how dim he is.' The wonder boy of British athletics was born in London in 1956 but moved to Sheffield, close to Hague's birthplace, Rotherham, when he was eight. He failed his 11-plus and ended up in a secondary modern. Unlike Hague, who shot to fame in the political equivalent of A Star is Born with that speech at the 1977 Conservative Party Conference, Coe's entry on to to the national stage was a process of attrition. Encouraged by his father, Peter, who coached him, he began to run when he was 12. 'Everywhere from my front door was effectively up,' said Coe, 'and there was a run we used to do that was uphill for 10 miles. We'd be out in all weathers, me running and my father driving, an odd couple having conversations through the car window. Often he would have music on and once in a storm of swirling snow and hail, when I had 14 miles on the road to do, he said: "I don't know what you've got out there, but I've got Wagner in here." I told him it was pretty Wagnerian where I was too.' He later studied at Loughborough University but his real career was always running and his regime centred on a punishing amount of training - even now he likes to clock 25 miles a week just for the fun of it. Coe's philosophy was to strip himself down by single-mindedly and obsessively focusing on the goal ahead. 'You present yourself at the starting line in the best physical and mental condition,' he explained to bemused Tory MPs. He was Britain's greatest-ever middle distance runner Britain - a double 1500 metre Olympic gold medallist in Moscow in 1980 and Los Angeles in 1984. He broke 11 world records and his 1981 800-metre world record was only bettered in 1997. With his good looks, he was a sponsor's dream and soon accumulated a serious amount of cash - he draws no salary from Central Office. His interests range from health clubs to hotel chains, sports facilities and media consultancies. He is well off and, suitably, has a big house in the country, a wife, Nicola, who trains horses, and four children. He is discreetly flash about his wealth - the gold Rolex just peeks out from under the silk shirt with its fancy cufflinks. Maybe it was the competition of the track or the individuality of being a winner or loser, but Coe was a natural Tory and joined the party when he was 19. After his sports career ended, he was still a star, a genuine hero, and soon found a vacant seat, Falmouth and Cambourne in Cornwall, and was elected in 1992. But the gilded path upwards stopped dead in its tracks in the House of Commons. Coe was a failure as an MP. He found the ritual contests across the debating floor alien and unnatural. He is not much of a public speaker. 'He did not like the confrontation, the fight, the whole debate thing that William is so brilliant at,' said a colleague. With dogged determination he made it into the Whips office in the final days of John Major's government but was turfed out in 1997. In Parliament, Coe had built up close links with Hague and in February 1998 returned to the centre stage of the party as Hague's private secretary. Publicly his role is straightforward he organises things - planes, schedules, speaking engagements - and even acts as a kind of unofficial bodyguard. But privately his role remains a mystery even to many members of the Shadow Cabinet. Coe is undoubtedly Hague's closest confidant - the two men speak several times a day - but the content of their conversations remains veiled. It is a pragmatic relationship, not an ideological one. Coe admits he does not 'do policy', he is no Alastair Campbell. Perhaps the closest analogy is drawn from Coe's own background he acts like a coach, encouraging Hague to run that little bit faster in a contest he could never undertake. Some of those who know them say they are still a matey double act. Others detect a shift in their relationship as Hague has grown in authority as Opposition leader. Seb, the star, is no longer a soul-mate but just another part of the machine that surrounds the leader. But Seb Coe should hardly be surprised. As he well knows, it is the mark of every successful athlete that they outrun and outgrow their original coaches.

webTitle: Potter boy's contract spells trouble for film

fields.headline: Potter boy's contract spells trouble for film
fields.trailText: The production of Britain's most talked about film -  Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone - is in jeopardy this weekend due to a legal confusion surrounding its young star, Daniel Radcliffe
fields.body:
The production of Britain's most talked about film - Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone - is in jeopardy this weekend due to a legal confusion surrounding its young star, Daniel Radcliffe.

The career of the 11-year-old, who plays Potter, is in danger of being cut short due to regulations which govern the amount of time children are allowed to work. The bureaucratic obstacle would mark a dismal end to a magical story for Daniel, who was picked from thousands for the starring role of the young wizard.

Principal photography on the £110 million film of J. K. Rowling's first bestseller was due to finish next month, but bad weather has delayed location filming around Britain and the film's director, Christopher Columbus, desperately needs more time. The Observer can reveal that he does not have it.

On Friday the staff of the legal department of a London council confirmed that the vast Hollywood machine will have to grind to a halt because Daniel has been licensed to play the role only until the end of March. As a schoolboy, permission for him to take up professional film work had to be legally granted last year by his local education authority, in this case Hammersmith and Fulham. The authority has confirmed that it has not licensed an extension for Daniel beyond the 140-day permission he was granted from 15 September last year.

'At the moment Daniel is licensed to work until the end of March. We have categorically not agreed on an extension for the extra days yet, and in fact we have not seen an application for an extension,' said a spokesman for Hammersmith and Fulham.

'Although Daniel attends a private school, his application for permission to work must come to us and we must be satisfied that his education is being organised properly. It is our statutory duty to consider this and to worry about exploitation.'

Actors Maggie Smith, Robbie Coltrane, Alan Rickman, Rik Mayall, Richard Harris, Zoe Wanamaker, John Hurt and John Cleese have all joined Daniel on the set at Leavesden Studios in Hertfordshire and on location King's Cross Station in London was used to film Potter's train journey to Hogwarts School, which famously leaves from Platform 9 3/4 .

The production team on the film say they have been careful to look after all their child stars, who include Emma Watson, who plays Hermione, and Rupert Grint, who plays Ron. Private tuition has been organised for all three on the set and they are not allowed to work more than five days in seven. But Warner Brothers has not been able to control the English weather, and without speedy work from the studio's legal department this will be the film's undoing.

All three young stars will also need separate permissions to start any work on the second film in the series - planned to begin filming later this year, before the release of the first film in November.

'It is a very complicated issue,' a spokeswoman for the film told The Observer on Friday as the production team finished a day's filming in Gloucestershire. 'It is hugely logistically difficult to look after all these children, and our arrangements for Daniel are absolutely confidential. We have a legal team working on the film and he is our star. If the right letter has not been sent out yet, I am sure the right questions will be asked and the law will be adhered to.'

The spokeswoman added that there was no scheduled date for the start of the second film and that all the details would be agreed with the children's parents.

'There would certainly be a break between the two films,' she said. 'There is no "green light" for the second film yet and we are not going back to back.' To finish the first film, Warner Brothers needs to use Daniel for an additional 20 days and they want to extend his permission to work into July. The question of permission for the second film has not yet been broached.

A spokeswoman for the Department of Health, which deals with working practices for children, confirmed that, however good working conditions are on location, filming would have to stop if the permissions are not granted.

'The terms of the licence mean what they say in these cases, no matter how much money is involved,' she said.

webTitle: Blair and Bush defy world fury

fields.headline: Blair and Bush defy world fury
fields.standfirst:
Fresh raids on Iraq threatened as outrage grows
The Bush Files
Guardian Unlimited special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Fresh raids on Iraq threatened as outrage grows
fields.byline: Jason Burke, Kamal Ahmed and Ed Vulliamy in Washington
fields.body:
Britain and America vowed to launch fresh air raids against Iraq yesterday despite facing international isolation after Friday's strikes on radar sites near Baghdad.

Tony Blair yesterday brushed off the almost universal condemnation of the raids and said Britain was ready to authorise further action if President Saddam Hussein continued to threaten British aircrews.

The Prime Minister said the raids against air defence systems were 'a limited operation with the sole purpose of defending... pilots'. They would stop 'if Saddam stopped attacking us. But as long as he does, I will... protect our forces and prevent Saddam from... wreaking havoc, suffering and death'.

Britain's stance is exceptional. Israel appears to be the only state that has backed the strikes. Russia and China have led the protests. They have been joined by France - a member of the Gulf war coalition that ended Iraq's 1990-91 occupation of Kuwait and has now fallen apart. Algeria, India, Iran, Jordan, Egypt, Malaysia, Syria, Pakistan, Cuba and even Turkey, a staunch regional ally of the US and Britain in the past, have strongly criticised the strikes.

The Arab League, the regional organisation of Arab states based in Cairo, said the first Western air strike in the vicinity of the Iraqi capital since December 1998 had violated international law and would fuel anger across the Arab world.

There were voices of dissent even within the US, including the former Ambassador to Baghdad, Edward Peck, and Scott Ritter, the spearhead of the UN disarmament team expelled from Iraq in 1999. Iraqi opposition leaders in Syria said the attack would merely boost support for Saddam.

Israel however expressed understanding, saying that the country that occupied Kuwait in 1990-91 still posed a threat as it was rebuilding its military.

Baghdad's official press have reacted furiously. 'The Americans' and Britons' new, savage crime will not pass unpunished and without decisive retaliation,' the official Qadissiya newspaper said. 'We will teach the new American administration and the Zionist entity (Israel) lessons on jihad (holy war) and steadfastness,' it went on, adding that the strike targets were civilian.

'We will fight them in the air, on land and sea and their aggression will achieve nothing but failure,' said an official statement broadcast on Iraqi television after a meeting of Iraqi leaders in Baghdad chaired by Saddam which discussed possible ways of retaliate.

The Iraqi statement also blamed Kuwait and Saudi Arabia for providing bases for coalition forces in the region. Even the Gulf states that have been consistently loyal to Britain and America failed to wholeheartedly endorse Friday's military action.

The Iraqi Health Ministry announced that the raids killed two Iraqi civilians, one an 18-year-old woman and wounded more than 20 others.

However the atmosphere on Iraq's streets yesterday was defiant. Several hundred Iraqis and Palestinians living in Iraq marched in Baghdad to protest against the raids. Demonstrators burnt an Israeli flag and chanted slogans in praise of Saddam. 'With our soul and blood, we defend you, Saddam,' they shouted.

'All [the victims] were innocent [people] who did not mean anything to America,' said Tamader Jassim, 19, a college student. 'They expect us to hate our leader by doing this, but they are wrong. We have started hating anything American because of these strikes.' US officials said 24 US and British planes 'successfully' struck five Iraqi military targets five to 20 miles from the Iraqi capital, using long-range precision-guided weapons. Iraqi television showed houses and shops in an area in Baghdad it said was damaged by the strikes.

Geoff Hoon, the Defence Secretary, said that the attacks were to protect pilots patrolling the no-fly zones set up after the Gulf war to protect Iraqi minorities living in the North and South of Iraq from repression by Saddam.

Despite the joint strikes, analysts predict that the first meeting of the two leaders - Blair will visit Washington this week - is likely to be strained. There is already tension over the controversial national missile defence system.

Although Pentagon spokesmen said they saw no need for further strikes soon, officials said privately that more were on the way.

One told The Observer that the raids signalled the start of escalating attacks. 'This has sent a signal, but you have to do more - you've got to go after him like we did Milosevic, you've got to go for the money, you've got to challenge his control.'

One official said that a more 'active backing' for Iraqi rebels in Kurdistan and the Shia south was likely. Sources suggested that Bush and his team wanted to enforce every detail of the surrender signed by Saddam at the end of the Gulf war, including tight sanctions and the no-fly zones.

fields.headline: Games head for £60m shortfall
fields.standfirst: A cash crisis looms for next year's British sporting showpiece, the Commonwealth Games - and taxpayers will have to foot the bill, reports  Denis Campbell
fields.trailText: A cash crisis looms for next year's British sporting showpiece, the Commonwealth Games - and taxpayers will have to foot the bill, reports Denis Campbell
fields.body:
It was supposed to show the world that England could host a glittering sporting event. But the next Commonwealth Games in Manchester could be a financial disaster, with losses reaching £60 million, the Government has been warned.

Ministers may have to bale out the event with tens of millions of pounds to stop it becoming another high-profile fiasco like the Dome and the reconstruction of Wembley Stadium.

Cabinet Office Minister Ian McCartney, the ministerial troubleshooter in charge of the Games, has warned colleagues that a cash shortfall that is already thought to be £25m may grow to as much as £60m. An emergency injection of taxpayers' money could be the only way to avoid Britain suffering worldwide embarrassment for its apparent inability to organise prestigious projects.

Ministers fear the Queen's image is in danger of being tarnished by the event's failure to generate enough money to cover its costs. The Games are being billed as the centrepiece of next year's celebrations to mark her 50 years on the throne, and she will attend both the opening and closing ceremonies to show her support.

Concern is growing in Whitehall that the event organisers, Manchester 2002, have no chance of finding the £62m they need in sponsorship and overseas television rights. Only £18m of that has been raised so far. Although organisers insist money-raising efforts are 'on track', and new sponsors will be unveiled shortly, McCartney fears the £62m will never be found.

'The finances are a huge, huge mess, and McCartney has warned that cash is short. The targets the Manchester 2002 people have set themselves have always been ambitious and probably over-ambitious', said a Whitehall insider. 'The shortfall could now be as much as £60m, which is pretty staggering, especially as the original budget for the whole event was meant to be £68m.'

Sources close to McCartney say £10m to £15m of the projected £60m deficit is down to the new stadium in east Manchester, which will be the main focus of the Games, running over its £90m budget. The Games have already received £147m of Lottery money - £77m of which went into that stadium - and £10.5m of government funds to build new sports venues and ensure the opening and closing ceremonies are grand enough to help mark the Queen's golden jubilee.

Organisers have not yet asked for extra cash and will continue with their attempts to bridge the gap, and McCartney has not submitted a formal bid for funding to the Treasury. But insiders say it is only a matter of time before he has to ask the Government to bail out the event.

Manchester 2002 spokeswoman Jane Price said last night: 'Talk of a funding shortfall is premature, as we are still talking to many potential sponsors. You could say that the gap between what we've raised so far and our £62m target is £46m, but there's more money still to come in.' Asked if the £62m figure would be realised, she replied: 'That's our target and it's a very challenging target. We are working very hard to reach it, but we won't know if we do until we do.'

Labour MP Derek Wyatt, a member of the Commons Culture, Media and Sport Select Committee, said: 'Britain's credibility and reputation are on the line here. After the mess and muddle of the Dome and Wembley, we need to prove to the world we can do something big. If the Commonwealth Games don't go well, we will never recover our international sporting respect and we can forget about bidding for the Olympic Games or football World Cup for a generation. We can't let that happen. If need be, we will have to get Manchester 2002 out of its financial hole.'

The Games, sponsored by the Guardian Media Group, publishers of the Manchester Evening News , The Observer and the Guardian , are the biggest multi-sport event ever to have been staged in Britain. Some 2,500 athletes from 72 Commonwealth countries will compete for medals in 17 different sports. Unlike the Olympics, where there is a combined British team, England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland will compete separately.

While some sponsors have been deterred by the Dome, part of the shortfall may be down to the event's unglamorous image compared with the Olympics or World Cup. When sprinter Ato Boldon of Trinidad and Tobago re-turned to his training base in California after winning gold in the 200m at the last Games in Kuala Lumpur in 1998, and told his US training partner Maurice Greene he was now the Commonwealth champion, Greene just laughed.

'People say it's the Mickey Mouse games, and there's a perception that it's not as important as it used to be. But it still means a lot to a lot of people', explained Jason Henderson of Athletics Weekly magazine. 'British athletes like it.'

Mike Cooper, chief executive of the Commonwealth Games Federation, said Manchester 2002 would be 'a wonderful spectacle that will cap ture the public's imagination. It's a top-quality sports event. Commonwealth countries won 135 medals at the Sydney Olympics, 36 of them gold...

'I get sick of cynical people who say it's a third-rate event.'

But it still means a lot to a lot of people', explained Jason Henderson of Athletics Weekly magazine. 'British athletes like it.' Mike Cooper, chief executive of the Commonwealth Games Federation, said Manchester 2002 would be 'a wonderful spectacle that will cap ture the public's imagination. It's a top-quality sports event. Commonwealth countries won 135 medals at the Sydney Olympics, 36 of them gold... 'I get sick of cynical people who say it's a third-rate event.' denis.campbell@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: People on Sunday | Snatch | The House of Mirth
fields.trailText: People on Sunday | Snatch | The House of Mirth
fields.body:
People on Sunday
(1929, E, BFI, VHS, Rental/Retail)
This German film, the last of the silent classics, is an influential landmark that remains as vital, humane and unsentimental as when first shown. It centres on three Berlin women, one of whom spends Sunday in bed while the other two go into the country with a womanising salesman and a taxi driver. The film is part fiction, part documentary with wonderful touches in the acting and observation. The haunt ing images of an active city slowing down on Sunday can take their place beside the best photographs of Kertesz, Sandor, and Cartier-Bresson. The only experienced filmmaker involved was cinematographer Eugen Schüfftan. The rest were tyros, all of whom became major figures outside Germany - co-directors Robert Siodmak and Edgar G. Ulmer, screenwriters Billy Wilder (above) and Curt Siodmak, and camera assistant Fred Zinnemann.

Snatch
(2000, 18, Col-TriStar, VHS/Rental)
In a self-consciously stylised follow-up to his directorial debut Lock, Stock and Two Smoking Barrels , Guy Ritchie offers a similar mixture of romanticised London villains, speaking stylised Mockney as they pursue an 86-carat diamond stolen in Amsterdam and engage in promoting and betting on bare-knuckle boxing. A larger budget has enabled Ritchie to engage some top-ranking American talent (including Brad Pitt as a deliberately unintelligible Irish traveller) to join such local suspects as Vinnie Jones and Mike Reid. Violent, sentimental, Runyonesque.

The House of Mirth
(2000, U, FilmFour, VHS, Retail/Rental)
Gifted British director Terence Davies, best-known for his sensitive evocations of British working-class Catholic life, makes a superb job of adapting Edith Wharton's 1906 novel of patrician, WASP New York. Leading a strong cast, Gillian Anderson is excellent as the wilful, 29-year-old orphan who is destroyed for breaking the unwritten rules of this snobbish society in which old money is being challenged by the nouveaux riches. Despite the apparent opulence, the movie was shot on a modest budget, mainly in Scotland.

fields.headline: And the winner isn't...
fields.standfirst: American.  Or the chances are he won't be this time, says Philip French
fields.trailText: The most striking thing about the Oscars this year is how unparochial and international they are, according to Philip French
fields.body:
This year the Colin Welland Award for Chauvinistic Hubris goes to the Times for its headline 'Billy Elliot takes on Gladiator'. That is to say, our own little Oscar contender with nominations for best direction, original screenplay and supporting actress is a formidable challenge to a picture with 12 nominations including all the major categories except best actress and supporting actress. The Alice in Wonderland Prize for Condescending Solicitude goes to the nominated Julie Walters, who said of her non-nominated co-star Jamie Bell: 'It's a shame, but he's only 14 - he's got the whole of his life ahead of him. And if you win an Oscar at 14 what have you got to look forward to?' You no longer have to wait for Oscar night to get buried in sentimental showbiz garbage.

Britain is the only country that annually asserts its right to be a contender in what is in effect and intention a ceremony to celebrate the achievement of the American cinema as art and industry. No continental countries expect to figure in the nominations (other than the Best Foreign Film). Australia, which has a bigger movie industry than ours, will not be proclaiming 'The Aussies Are Coming' just because two Australians - Russell Crowe for Gladiator, Geoffrey Rush for Quills - are among the five nominated for Best Actor.

In fact what is most striking about the Oscars this year is how unparochial and international they are. At the very centre, with respectively 10 and 12 nominations each, are Ang Lee's Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon and Ridley Scott's Gladiator, which deserve their acclaim for offering visual entertainment on a scale that only a large screen in a big cinema can accommodate. But just as important, one is directed by a Taiwanese filmmaker, working with a largely Asian cast and crew, though with an American co-screenwriter, while the other is directed by an Englishman, working in Europe with a largely British cast and British cinematographer. In fact, of the five cinematographers nominated only one - Caleb Deschanel for The Patriot - is American, and he was working on a film directed and produced by Germans.

Indeed, if the arts reporters were to scrutinise the nominations they would discover that British talents, if not British movies, are represented in virtually every category. Take Chocolat for instance, which has nominations for best film, actress, supporting actress, adapted screenplay, and original score. This is an American-financed Hollywood production - but it's set in France, based on a novel by Joanne Harris, who lives in Barnsley, and directed by a Swede, Lasse Hallström, working with a British crew. The film that should get the award for Best Documentary Feature, Into the Arms of Strangers: Stories of the Kindertransport, is an American production, but deals with the experience of Jewish refugee children taken into pre-war Britain, and is narrated by Judi Dench.

One thing that's pretty certain about the Oscars is that afterwards critics will say the awards went to the wrong people, or to the right people but for the wrong movie. I doubt if they'll say that about Julia Roberts (should she win for Erin Brockovich) but if Russell Crowe is honoured for his muscular Maximus, they'll be saying his whistle-blower in The Insider was superior.

There are occasions, I think, when the Academy voters are swayed by local and national sentiments, and two are likely to occur this year. I'd be astonished if Tinseltown can resist giving a statuette to a performer with a much-loved Hollywood parent - Goldie Hawn's daughter Kate Hudson as supporting actress in Almost Famous. And it wouldn't surprise me if the Oscar for Best Original Song goes to the nation's troubadour, Bob Dylan, for 'Things Have Changed' in Wonder Boys. Dylan should have won in 1973 for 'Knocking on Heaven's Door' from Peckinpah's Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid, but he wasn't even nominated.

webTitle: Vietnamese beauty falls for Greene's real Quiet American

fields.headline: Vietnamese beauty falls for Greene's real Quiet American
fields.trailText: Work has started on an Australian adaptation of Graham Greene's eerie prophecy of the US debacle in Indochina,  The Quiet American.
fields.byline: David Brunnstrom in Ho Chi Minh City
fields.body:
The centre of old Saigon stepped back nearly 50 years yesterday as filming started of an Australian adaptation of Graham Greene's eerie prophecy of the US debacle in Indochina, The Quiet American.

Directed by Phillip Noyce, whose credits include Patriot Games and The Saint, the film is set in early 1950s Vietnam, a country wracked by war as the curtain comes down on French colonial rule.

It tells the story of a doomed love triangle involving a jaded British war correspondent, Fowler, played by Sir Michael Caine, an idealistic American agent, Pyle, played by Brendan Fraser, and a young Vietnamese girl, Phuong, played by local newcomer Hai Yen.

Fraser's character, Alden Pyle, is The Quiet American of the title, a man in the words of Greene's 1955 novel 'determined... to do good, not to any individual person but to a country, a continent, a world' - with disastrous results.

The makers say they are aiming for a far more faithful adaptation of Greene's work than a 1950s Hollywood version, which turned the plot on its head to make Pyle an anti-communist hero.

Scriptwriter Christopher Hampton, an Academy Award winner with Dangerous Liaisons, said he hoped Greene, with whom he worked on an adaptation of his later novel The Honorary Consul - which also starred Caine - would have been somewhat happier with this version of The Quiet American .

But he said the author, who died in 1991, was a notoriously difficult man to please. 'I think he would be slightly happier,' Hampton said. 'But he was not disposed to be terribly happy with any of the adaptations of his books. When I did The Honorary Consul while he was still alive, I tried to be very faithful with that as well, but he wasn't too happy with it.'

He said Greene had been 'outraged' by the original version of The Quiet American by Joseph L Mankiewicz, seeing it as a complete betrayal of the book's message.

'It was turned from an accurate representation of the historical circumstances of the time into an anti-communist tract, brought about, I suppose, by the climate of the time in America, where you couldn't take an objective view,' Hampton said. 'In fact, that's what the novel's all about - the incapability of people to take an objective view.'

Hampton said he believed Greene's work still carried an important message today.'It's always timely to say "Don't interfere in the affairs of other countries".'

The script has clearly struck the right note with the communist authorities in Vietnam, who gave approval on the grounds that 'it condemns the manoeuvres of hostile forces and foreign aggressors against the Vietnamese people'.

They have allowed the film-makers to shut off a key section of a city centre thoroughfare renamed Dong Khoi - or 'Uprising' Street - after Saigon itself became Ho Chi Minh City with the Communist victory in the Vietnam War in 1975, to recreate the colonial-era rue Catinat.

The production team say they have also secured permission to recreate a 1952 bomb attack Greene was to blame on a 'Third Force' - neither colonialist nor communist - that Pyle championed.

The film-makers have succeeded in creating an authentically period feel on the set, with the ubiquitous Japanese motorcycles and cars of today giving way to vintage Peugeots, Citröens, bicycles and three-wheeled 'cyclo' pedal taxis of the colonial era.

And more than 45 years after France's ignominious exit from Indochina, the kepis and khaki of its colonial police force and military again graced the streets of a city once dubbed 'Paris of the East'.

The crew is scheduled to film for five weeks in Vietnam, with shooting also scheduled in Hanoi, the national capital, as well as the towns of Hoi An and Danang.

fields.headline: Famous five
fields.standfirst: The pick of The Bunch, a group of like-minded merchants, would win TS Eliot's vote
fields.trailText: The pick of The Bunch, a group of like-minded merchants, would win TS Eliot's vote.
fields.body:
I've never agreed with TS Eliot about April. Anyone who's lived through the last six weeks in Britain will know that January and February are far crueller months, especially if you to have to travel by tube. Endless gloomy days of endless gloomy drizzle make me long for the southern hemisphere. I'm not alone in this. Half the British wine-writing fraternity seemed to have made the journey to New Zealand this month. Frankly, it would have been churlish not to join them.

There aren't many bright moments on the tasting calendar at this time of year. The Australia Day tasting, when a swarm of winemakers breezes in from Down Under buzzing with news of shark attacks and beach barbies, is one. But the most enjoyable of all is the annual tasting held by The Bunch.

If you buy most of your wine from supermarkets or high street chains, you probably won't be aware of The Bunch's existence. This like-minded group of independent wine merchants sounds like something directed by Sam Peckinpah, but its aims are a good deal more sociable. Their purpose, this and every other year, is to present what one of their number calls 'wines which express the individual character of their markers as well as a vivid sense of place'.

It has to be said that they don't always succeed. Some of the wines they show are overpriced - any takers for 1997 Chteau Le Tertre Roteboeuf, St Emilion at £61 a bottle? - but most are interesting and many delicious. At a time when wine styles are moving towards over-processed homogeneity, it's good to taste wines that provoke debate.

The Bunch doesn't include all of my favourite independent merchants, but it's still a pretty good line up. Tanners, Yapp Brothers, Lay & Wheeler, John Armit, Corney & Barrow and Adnams are some of finest operations in the land. I'd like to see a larger group including the likes of Morris & Verdin, Berry Brothers, Justerini & Brooks, Vin du Van, Lea & Sandeman, Raeburn Fine Wines and The Vine Trail, but The Bunch's aim is to stay small enough to sit around a table for lunch.

Members of The Bunch are bound by a code of practice covering stock records of wines held on customers' behalf, mail order and, best of all, the promise that 'If you don't like any wine you buy from us, for whatever reason, return it within a month and we shall refund your money.' Against the odds, the independent sector has survived the rise of the supermarkets and the depredations of cross-Channel trade. It's all part of the shift towards 'authenticity'. Just as my spirits perk up every time I see a new farmers' market, so I smile at the sight of a flourishing local wine merchant. Not before time, there are signs we are learning to value expertise and quality. He might be wrong about April, but I have a feeling TS Eliot would approve.

Best cellars

Five great wines from the five members of The Bunch.

Mariscal Manzanilla, Tanners (£6.85, Tanners, 01743 234 500). A Tanners exclusive, sourced from Dolores Bustillo Delgado in Sanlúcar de Barrameda, this is a brilliant example of Sherry's most delicate style. It's fresh and yeasty with a salty, seafaring tang.

1998 Les Terrasses, Alavaro Palacios, Priorato (£12.03, Corney & Barrow, 020 7539 3200). A blend of old vine Cariñena, Garnacha and Cabernet Sauvignon. Dense and darkly coloured with subtle oak, sweet tannins and notes of plum and cassis.

1999 Cullen Sauvignon/Semillon, Margaret River (£11.95, Adnams, 01502 727 220). Vanya Cullen is one of Australia's finest winemakers, as demonstrated by this take on a classic Bordeaux blend. A citrus-tinged white with remarkable harmony and length.

1999 Seresin Pinot Noir, Marlborough (£15.83, John Armit, 020 7908 0600). New Zealand's Pinot Noirs are as good as anyone's outside Burgundy. From filmmaker Michael Seresin's showpiece estate, this Pinot has the balance to age for five years.

1997 Barbera d'Alba, Vigna Martina, Elio Grasso (£19.40, Lay & Wheeler, 01206 764 446). An early contender for my wine of the year, Elio Grasso's latest release takes Barbera to new levels. A swirling, passionate masterpiece of a red. A stunner.

fields.headline: Root master
fields.standfirst: Whether it's living it up with garlic and chilli or taking it easy with butter and beans, the beloved potato knows how to get about
fields.trailText: Whether it's living it up with garlic and chilli or taking it easy with butter and beans, the beloved potato knows how to get about.
fields.body:
The contemporary diet is one of extremes. Vietnamese hot-and-sour vegetable soup one day, cauliflower cheese the next; today nigiri sushi with pickled ginger, tomorrow rice pudding with a blob of plum jam. And yesterday afternoon's cucumber sandwiches and Earl Grey tea will be all the sweeter for being followed by a supper of chicken vindaloo and its ensuing ring of fire. Pushing our tastebuds to the limit is what makes our eating - and cooking - interesting.

There cannot be much wrong with a diet that can run the gamut from custard tart to kick-ass chilli sauce. In fact, I see everything right with the ability to savour extremes. The only diet that does not appeal is the humdrum, the ordinary, meat-and-two-veg cooking that is the equivalent of dressing permanently in beige. Food that goes without remark. Cooking for those who couldn't care less what they eat, just so long as it is hot and on time. To eat well, we need to be open-minded as well as open-mouthed.

Quack diets for the rich and famous aside, most of us like to take in our daily dose of carbohydrate. No food group is quite so receptive to the extremes of seasoning as the pasta, noodles, rice and beans that our eclectic diet now includes. Pasta is just as welcome as part of a gently flavoured lasagne as it is slathered in a fierce arrabbiata sauce. Rice may come as a soporific risotto or as a bolster for a mouth-popping prawn curry, and beans seem just as suited to the sweet tomato sauce of commerce as to be hidden in an explosively hot Deep Southern spicy bean bake. Yet none of them is quite so amenable as our beloved potato.

A love for the spud is something ingrained in our collective culinary psyche, an essential part of our national dish, our favourite street food, our Christmas feast. No national celebration is complete without the tattie, be it baked in embers of the Guy Fawkes pyre or scrubbed and delicately buttered to toast the first of the wild salmon. It is the first food we turn to for warmth and comfort, the food we find most difficult to spurn on a weight-loss diet. I suppose it must say something for the spud that when I excitedly, briefly, met my idol Marianne Faithfull at a party, we spent the whole time discussing the Irish potato famine. This guy sure knows how to party.

Whether it is steamed over Evian water or interred under a bubbling blanket of tear-jerking chilli sauce, the potato never fails to satisfy. Whether we are in the mood for chips and beer or toying with the light-as-air balloons known as pommes soufflé, we will probably be just as happy. The potato is the ultimate good-time food, good naturedly taking any mood we care to throw at it.

Feel the need for a sinus-clearing curry? Dying for a spoonful of sleepy, buttery mash? Then look no further than Solanum tuberosum . You can take this vegetable in whatever direction you desire. This week, with the cold winter rain still pattering on the kitchen skylights, I set my compass for comfort cooking. There are times, like now, when it is cold enough to wear a fleece indoors as well as out, when bland is a good thing. By bland I mean creamy and starchy and as unchallenging as a Mills & Boon novel.

The floury winter potatoes - Maris Piper, King Edward, Golden Wonder and their ilk - are all better at soaking up copious quantities of cream or stock than the waxy summer varieties. There is a god. There is also something about a starchy root sodden with salty stock or garlic-enriched double cream that is as comforting as a cashmere hot-water bottle cover. The gambit here is to lightly boil the potatoes first. They seem more inclined to sponge up the liquid that way. You know how roast potatoes are always more moist in the middle if you boil them before you add them to the fat round the roast - well, likewise any potato that is to be baked with chicken stock or cream. Try it. Whether or not it works for you, it is certain to cut down the baking time - important to anyone who has ever waited in vain for their pommes Dauphinoise to tenderise.

If a balmy dish of tubers is not what you had in mind, then take the other extreme. Take your daily dose of carbs salt-crusted with ginger, chilli and mustard seed then add stark contrast with a slick of sharp, natural yogurt. Bland or mind-blowing, hot enough to make your eyes water and your tongue swell or as smooth as a dish of whipped cream, the potato is up for anything. Just what we need for these extreme times.

Potato and celeriac tart

If there is one thing better than slices of potato cooked slowly with garlic and cream, it is when they also come wrapped in a pastry crust. Extreme comfort cooking, this. I put it on the table with a bowl of salad - oak-leaf lettuce, trendy red trevisse and hot watercress tossed in a mustard dressing. A lively salad with which everyone mopped up the garlicky cream left on their plates.

5 medium to large potatoes
1 large head of celeriac
425g puff pastry
2 large cloves of garlic
2 or 3 bay leaves
2 eggs
400ml double cream
100ml full cream milk
nutmeg

You will also need a large, heavy frying pan or a baking tin - about 30cm in diameter.

Bring a large, deep pan of water to the boil. Peel the potatoes and the celeriac and slice no thicker than a pound coin, add them to the boiling water, then salt and turn down to a simmer. After 5 minutes or so, they will be tender but far from falling apart. Drain them carefully and set aside.

Roll half of the pastry to fit your baking tin or frying pan. It needs to come all the way up the sides. Lightly oil or butter the pan, then place the pastry in the bottom and push it gently up the sides. It is important that there are no holes in the pastry, otherwise the cream will leak.

Set the oven at 200 C/gas mark 6. Peel and slice the garlic. Layer the potatoes and celeriac on top of the pastry, tucking in the slices of garlic and the bay leaves as you go. Beat the eggs with a fork, then stir in the cream and milk and season with salt, black pepper and a grating of nutmeg, then pour it over the potatoes.

Cut the second piece of pastry to fit the top of the pie, wet the edges with beaten egg, milk or water, then lay the pastry on top of the potatoes and squeeze the edges firmly together.

Cut two small holes in the top to let out the steam, brush the top with a little beaten egg or milk, and bake for 45 minutes to 1 hour, until the top is golden brown.

Spiced roast potatoes

I usually make these little cubes of spiced, crisp potatoes to go with cold roast meat for a Monday supper. I make a cooling spinach salad to go with it, too. Serves 4 as a side dish.

2 large potatoes (about 600g)
2 tbsp groundnut or vegetable oil
1 onion
2 fat cloves of garlic
1 or 2 small, hot red chillis, depending on your heat threshold
a 3cm-long knob of ginger
1 tsp black mustard seeds
scant tsp ground turmeric
the juice of half a small lemon
natural yogurt to serve

Put a medium-sized pan of water on to boil. This is a rustic recipe and there is no need to peel the potatoes, but you can if you wish. Cut them into thick slices then into large dice - about 1cm - then boil them for 7 or 8 minutes in the boiling water. When they are almost tender, drain them.

While the potatoes are boiling, peel and finely chop the onion and garlic, deseed and chop the chilli, and skin and finely shred the ginger.

Set the oven at 200 C/gas mark 6. Warm the oil in a baking dish or shallow enamelled casserole over a moderate heat. Add the onion, garlic, ginger and chopped chilli and leave to cook, gently, so that the onion softens but does not brown. Add the mustard seed and the turmeric, then the drained potatoes. Toss gently (with a wooden spoon, so as not to mash the potatoes), then squeeze over the lemon juice and add a grinding of freshly ground pepper and a generous seasoning of salt. Bake for about 35 minutes until they are golden brown and crisp around the edges.

When they come from the oven, spoon over a little yogurt - 3 or 4 tbsp should be enough - and serve.

fields.headline: The Trevi, London N5
fields.standfirst: Man and boy, Tony Parsons has been eating at his local trattoria for at least 15 years. Jay Rayner joins him for lunch and finds a taste of Tuscany just off the No 19 bus route
fields.trailText: Man and boy, Tony Parsons has been eating at his local trattoria for at least 15 years. Jay Rayner joins him for lunch and finds a taste of Tuscany just off the No 19 bus route.
fields.body:
Telephone: 020 7700 7161
Address: 16-18 Highbury Corner, London N5
Lunch for two, including service, £18.

Dorothy Parker had the round table at the Algonquin in New York. Jean-Paul Sartre had his berth at Les Deux Magots in Paris. And Tony Parsons, our own wit and philosopher of the male ego? Tony has a booth at an Italian caff called the Trevi, hard by Highbury Corner in north London, the better to fuel up for his kung-fu lessons after a hard day's graft at the literary coalface. From the outside, the Trevi looks like - as Churchill almost said of Atlee - a modest place with much to be modest about. Likewise, its location is hardly something to arouse the ardour of estate agents, sitting, as it does, on one of the least-lovely stretches of the Holloway Road (though, granted, identifying such a thing is a little like trying to identify the least-lovely stretch of the late Arthur Mullard; one is hideously spoilt for choice).

But then flimsy attributes such as prettiness and aspect are for those soft tossers who tiptoe past the boutiques and bistros of Islington's Upper Street, just a stone's throw away across Highbury Corner. No, up here they are made of much sterner stuff. They look for authenticity and value, for credibility and consistency, and on all these counts the Trevi scores highly. It is a Highbury Corner landmark with a herd of regulars who will happily queue out the door for the chance to down substantial platefuls of the Trevi's food, which could best be described as Italian trattoria meets (high-class) school dinners.

'Come 1.30pm, you've got less chance of getting a table here than you have at the Ivy,' Tony says as we slip into a booth in the simple dining room that leads off the sandwich bar area. The walls are sunflower yellow and delicately half-timbered, the floors tiled in that utilitarian way of sports changing rooms. It is a room in which to eat. Happily it is midday and, though it is already three-quarters full, there is space. Later, it will fill up with solicitors from the inner-city law firm up the road. The guy from the gay opticians across the road is usually here most lunchtimes, too.

And there's Tony, of course. 'I probably come here three, four times a week,' he says. 'Sometimes for breakfast, sometimes for tea. I come in for lunch at least once a week - particularly if I have some hard work to do.' Like those kung-fu lessons on a Thursday evening. He started coming 15 years ago when he used to drive over from Stoke Newington. Now he lives just round the corner and he's become almost part of the furniture. Up on a shelf behind the sandwich bar they have two copies of Tony's bestselling novel Man and Boy , one in Italian and one in English. It represents the neat dichotomy of the place. 'Up front all the talk is of West Ham and Arsenal,' Tony says. 'In the kitchens everybody speaks Italian and it's Juventus and Inter Milan.'

Likewise with the food. Regulars don't bother looking at the menu, preferring instead to pick lunch off the changing list of daily specials on the blackboard. But I am not a regular, so I'll look at the menu, if only for its refreshing simplicity. In a restaurant world obsessed with the listing of every ingredient, there is something almost indecently refreshing about a list that says: prawn cocktail, minestrone, spaghetti bolognese, lasagne. I tried the latter on my previous visit here and a grand meaty dishful it was: crispy and chewy on top, lush and sticky beneath. A lasagne from the olden days - and all for £4.50.

In the end, we choose off the blackboard. Tony has the gnocchi pomodoro, a rustling plateful of plump dumplings in a rich tomato sauce at £4.40. I go for the risotto alla marinara at £4.50. It, too, is a grand serving, the soft rice thick with mussels, prawns and extraordinarily tender rings of calamari. It's the kind of straight-up, robust Italian food we would eulogise for its peasant earthiness if eaten at a roadside inn amid the olive groves of Tuscany. The fact that the view is less olive groves than the splutter and grunt of number 19 buses should not make the food any less admirable.

Each day there is always what Tony refers to as the school-dinner option. Today, the main course is steak pie and veg which, he says, they do very well. Down the bottom right-hand corner of the blackboard is the matching pudding. Today, it's apple crumble with custard at £1.80 a shot, which we just had to have: the crumble was crisp and sugary, the fruit soft, the custard just as smooth and sweet as you remember it. You can get wine by the glass, though some people bring in their own bottles. Robert Biagioni, current owner and son of the man who first started here 40 years ago, says he doesn't really mind, though he'd prefer it if people drank his wine.

The total bill, including a couple of fine cappuccinos, a Coke and a mineral water comes to £16.70, which Tony insists on paying. 'It's the Trevi,' he says. 'I'll do it.' We're on his patch today, so it's his shout. Fair enough: both I, and The Observer 's accounts department, salute him. At the Trevi, there's really not much point arguing over the bill.

Contact Jay Rayner on jay.rayner@observer.co.uk.
