webTitle: The hidden truth behind  race crimes in Britain

fields.headline: The hidden truth behind  race crimes in Britain
fields.standfirst:
Jay Rayner has spent two months creating a race map of Britain that reflects the true rates of recorded abuse and assault. Two years after the Lawrence inquiry, he finds that it is rural areas, not inner cities, that are the flashpoints

Special report: race issues in the UK
Risk of race attacks highest outside Britain's big cities, survey reveals
fields.trailText: Jay Rayner  has spent two months creating a race map of Britain that reflects the true rates of recorded abuse and assault. Two years after the Lawrence inquiry, he finds that it is rural areas, not inner cities, that are the flashpoints
fields.body:
Jan Marthin Pasalbessy only wanted his daughter to be safe. Christina, 14, was the victim of a racist attack last June near where she lived with her widower father in Newport, Gwent. Mr Pasalbessy, a 48-year-old former merchant seaman from Indonesia, took her to the Royal Gwent Hospital for head X-rays. There, by chance, he ran into members of the group who had attacked his daughter. This time it was the father who got the racist abuse; the gang, some just teenagers, laid in to him, kicking and punching him to the ground, while Christina looked on, terrified.

'As the 16-year-old attacked her dad she remembers him saying, "Come on you black bastard",' the prosecution told a court in Newport at the trial of the assailants. 'The attack was unprovoked, gratuitous violence.'

Mr Pasalbessy died the next day from head injuries, leaving his daughter an orphan. Last week at Newport Crown Court the gang of four were all convicted of murder.

The murder of Christina's father was one of at least eight killings in Britain with a racist element since the publication two years ago of Sir William Macpherson's ground-breaking report into the botched Stephen Lawrence murder inquiry. It is proof that while the report marked a watershed in our understanding of racism in Britain, and sounded a warning to all the agencies and institutions charged with fighting it, racism itself has not gone away.

Curiously, the judge at the trial of Pasalbessy's killers ruled that, despite use of racist language, the murder was not racially motivated. Though it has no statutory force, Macpherson defines a racist incident as one 'perceived to be racist by the victim or any other person'. As Mr Pasalbessy's stepson Paul Heard said after the trial: 'If Jan had been a white person he would be here today.'

The same doubtless applies to the other cases we highlight today: Zahid Mubarek, 19, murdered by his cellmate, a known racist, at Feltham Young Offenders Institution; Kombra Divakaren, beaten to death by a gang outside his shop in west London; Ben Kamanalagi, beaten to death with baseball bats in Salford. They, and all the other victims pictured here, show where hatred based on the colour of another's skin can lead.

But they do not give us the true picture of racism in Britain. For most members of ethnic minority groups racism is about verbal harassment and intimidation, petty attacks that build up over time, an air of menace that kills the spirit while leaving the body intact. The problem is that, for years, it has been impossible to get a true picture of that kind of racist crime. Victims, convinced the authorities didn't give a damn, would fail to report what had happened to them. Macpherson drew a line in the sand: the police and other agencies had to record racist incidents. Only when we know what's going on, he said, can we begin to do something about it.

And here there have been results. Each year the Home Office publishes statistics on race and the criminal justice system. Last month the figures covering April 1999 to April 2000 - the first full year since the Lawrence Report was published - were made available. The results were staggering: a 107 per cent increase in England and Wales in reported racist incidents, leaping from 23,049 to 47,814.

In some constabularies, like Kent and Gloucestershire, the leap was over 200 per cent. In Devon and Cornwall it was 364 per cent. In West Mercia - which covers Shropshire - it was 459 per cent.

These are not necessarily hard, violent crimes. It might be verbal abuse, graffiti or anything that comes with the dirty stain of racism. These figures begin to give a real picture of what daily life is like for Britain's ethnic minorities.

But these statistics are not enough. There were over 23,000 racist incidents in the London area in the year covered. On paper that would seem to make the capital a dangerous place for people from ethnic minority groups. But then London has the highest ethnic minority population in the country at nearly 1.2 million. Clearly, to get a real picture of what is going on, more analysis is needed.

And so, for the first time ever, The Observer has created a map of racism in England and Wales by comparing the number of incidents recorded to the size of the local ethnic minority population, the only true measure. Swiftly a pattern emerges: the worst areas are not places like London or Manchester or the West Midlands with high numbers of visible ethnic minorities, but the more rural parts of Britain, where fewer members of the Asian and Afro-Caribbean community choose to live.

It's places like Northumbria, where one in 12 of the ethnic minority community is likely, on average, to have experienced a racist incident. It's South Wales, near where Jan Pasalbessy was killed (one in 15). Or Devon and Cornwall (one in 16). These are the hotspots. London, where racist incidents will have affected less than one in 50 of the population, is relatively safe. Likewise in the West Midlands, the figure is almost one in 200.

A similar exercise for Scotland would have been useful, but the wheels move disgracefully slowly there. Ten days ago the Scottish Executive Stephen Lawrence Inquiry Steering Group, set up to tackle problems of racism in Scottish society, issued its second report. It announced that police in Scotland still need to develop 'performance indicators for tackling racism'. It also proposed that all officers be given 'credit cards' with Macpherson's definition of a race crime on it as an aide memoir . Until the Scottish police sort out these basics - until they can be trusted to know what a race crime is - there's no point trying to draw conclusions from the scant figures they have collected. 'We recognise there is a need to have a better and more comprehensive system,' a spokesman for the Scottish Executive said last week, 'and we will be taking steps to address that.'

Questions also hang over the figures for England and Wales. There is little doubt that the statistics represent not a sudden leap in the volume of racist incidents but a sudden leap in their reporting. We must ask, though, whether that willingness to report is consistent across the country. The answer is definitely not. At the same time as the figures on race and the criminal justice system were released, Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary issued its third report on the way the 43 constabularies deal with race issues. The Metropolitan and West Midlands police, which reported those comparatively low race crime figures, did receive praise from the Inspectorate for the systems they have put in place to deal with the issue.

Another to receive praise was Northumbria police, which recorded the highest rate of race crime in the country. 'I think what these numbers show is that there is a confidence building in the community that we now take this issue seriously,' says Chief Inspector Judith Connon of Northumbria's Community Safety Unit. 'We have developed links with the community and while no one would claim that racist violence has been dealt with ,we are developing systems to help us tackle it.'

This is also the view in the community. Zafar Khan is a councillor in Newcastle's West End, where many of the city's ethnic minorities live, and a leader of his mosque. 'Certainly there is racist crime. People receive verbal harassment. My car is scratched. That sort of thing. But now we are making sure these crimes are reported.' Tony Burden, Chief Constable of South Wales, and also president of the Association of Chief Police Officers, puts forward a similar explanation for the high figures on his patch. 'There is absolutely no cause for complacency, but I do think it represents confidence in the way we are working.'

Others do not find the police argument convincing. 'The police are always claiming it's about confidence in them,' says Jazz Iheanacho of Race Equality First, a Cardiff organisation. 'We believe it represents the confidence the communities now have in themselves. They are demanding to be taken seriously. If there really was that satisfaction with the police we would not have among our clients so many making racial harassment claims against police officers.'

The same question marks lurk over some of the low scores. In Bedfordshire - which includes Luton - racist incidents appear to affect just 0.73 per cent of the ethnic minority population. 'That figure is totally unrepresentative,' says Cyril Dennemont of Bedford's Race Equality Council. 'We are meant to have a race crime forum in this county but it doesn't function at all. We have been appealing for funds for a full-time worker so we can get out there and find out what is going on but we have yet to be given the grant. Anecdotally we know that individual Asian families are getting abused but we have no statistics on it.'

Above and beyond the simple issue of raw data is the implicit question of what we do with it. Wringing our hands over the 'sudden' discovery that there is race crime in Britain is not enough. 'We are meant to see this leap in recorded race crime as a source of optimism, but you can be sure the number of racist incidents in Britain since Macpherson certainly haven't gone down,' says Ben Bowling, a law lecturer at King's College London, and an expert on race crime.

'What's more, when people come forward to report an incident there is now an expectation that something will be done,' Bowling says. 'But it may not be the case. True, some very important things have happened. The police service now says it is an anti-racist organisation where before it would only say it was neutral on the issue.

'The intelligence-based approach that they now have - the gathering of all this data - is vital. The real question is when someone picks up the phone and calls the police what can the officer do to give real reassurance that they will not be victimised again? This is a very long road.'

The Met imagines itself to be further down that road than many of the other constabularies in Britain. It established the Race Crime Task Force under Assistant Commissioner John Grieve, which has produced the handbook on identifying and combating hate crime for the entire country's police, and which achieved a notable coup when it caught the killers of the black musician Michael Menson. And it has established Community Safety Units (CSU) across the borough.

He speaks the language of diversity policing, and there's no doubt that he means it: 'It's not just about doing the right thing. It's about being seen to do the right thing. And Michael, who is Jamaican, has been pulled over in his car by police 30 or 40 times but charged with nothing. 'I don't think the police are racist,' he says. 'I know they are.'

And this, remember, is the West Midlands apparently one of the safest areas on our map. The problem, according to Maxie Hayles, chairman of the unit, is that whatever high thinking is going on at the top of the police it is not getting down to officers on the beat. Hayles, it should be said, is not completely condemnatory. 'There are good police initiatives. We have sat on police advisory groups. But over the years the police have behaved so badly and so immorally that it's going to take an awfully long time to reform.'

Next Saturday marks the second anniversary of the Macpherson report. Much will be said about progress that has been made - and doubtless there has been progress. But as we report on our news pages today, despite all of that, all the heart-searching, all the initiatives, over 70 per cent of the public think the police are still as racist or even more so than they were on 24 February 1999 when Macpherson's report was first published. And where these issues are concerned it is the view of the public - who are, after all, also the victims of racist crime - which counts the most.

Mr Pasalbessy, a 48-year-old former merchant seaman from Indonesia, took her to the Royal Gwent Hospital for head X-rays. There, by chance, he ran into members of the group who had attacked his daughter. This time it was the father who got the racist abuse; the gang, some just teenagers, laid in to him, kicking and punching him to the ground, while Christina looked on, terrified. 'As the 16-year-old attacked her dad she remembers him saying, "Come on you black bastard",' the prosecution told a court in Newport at the trial of the assailants. 'The attack was unprovoked, gratuitous violence.' Mr Pasalbessy died the next day from head injuries, leaving his daughter an orphan. Last week at Newport Crown Court the gang of four were all convicted of murder. The murder of Christina's father was one of at least eight killings in Britain with a racist element since the publication two years ago of Sir William Macpherson's ground-breaking report into the botched Stephen Lawrence murder inquiry. It is proof that while the report marked a watershed in our understanding of racism in Britain, and sounded a warning to all the agencies and institutions charged with fighting it, racism itself has not gone away. Curiously, the judge at the trial of Pasalbessy's killers ruled that, despite use of racist language, the murder was not racially motivated. Though it has no statutory force, Macpherson defines a racist incident as one 'perceived to be racist by the victim or any other person'. As Mr Pasalbessy's stepson Paul Heard said after the trial: 'If Jan had been a white person he would be here today.' The same doubtless applies to the other cases we highlight today: Zahid Mubarek, 19, murdered by his cellmate, a known racist, at Feltham Young Offenders Institution; Kombra Divakaren, beaten to death by a gang outside his shop in west London; Ben Kamanalagi, beaten to death with baseball bats in Salford. They, and all the other victims pictured here, show where hatred based on the colour of another's skin can lead. But they do not give us the true picture of racism in Britain. For most members of ethnic minority groups racism is about verbal harassment and intimidation, petty attacks that build up over time, an air of menace that kills the spirit while leaving the body intact. The problem is that, for years, it has been impossible to get a true picture of that kind of racist crime. Victims, convinced the authorities didn't give a damn, would fail to report what had happened to them. Macpherson drew a line in the sand: the police and other agencies had to record racist incidents. Only when we know what's going on, he said, can we begin to do something about it. Last month the figures covering April 1999 to April 2000 - the first full year since the Lawrence Report was published - were made available. These are not necessarily hard, violent crimes. It might be verbal abuse, graffiti or anything that comes with the dirty stain of racism. These figures begin to give a real picture of what daily life is like for Britain's ethnic minorities. But these statistics are not enough. There were over 23,000 racist incidents in the London area in the year covered. On paper that would seem to make the capital a dangerous place for people from ethnic minority groups. But then London has the highest ethnic minority population in the country at nearly 1.2 million. Clearly, to get a real picture of what is going on, more analysis is needed. And so, for the first time ever, The Observer has created a map of racism in England and Wales by comparing the number of incidents recorded to the size of the local ethnic minority population, the only true measure. Swiftly a pattern emerges: the worst areas are not places like London or Manchester or the West Midlands with high numbers of visible ethnic minorities, but the more rural parts of Britain, where fewer members of the Asian and Afro-Caribbean community choose to live. It also proposed that all officers be given 'credit cards' with Macpherson's definition of a race crime on it as an aide memoir . Until the Scottish police sort out these basics - until they can be trusted to know what a race crime is - there's no point trying to draw conclusions from the scant figures they have collected. 'We recognise there is a need to have a better and more comprehensive system,' a spokesman for the Scottish Executive said last week, 'and we will be taking steps to address that.' Questions also hang over the figures for England and Wales. There is little doubt that the statistics represent not a sudden leap in the volume of racist incidents but a sudden leap in their reporting. We must ask, though, whether that willingness to report is consistent across the country. The answer is definitely not. webTitle: Risk of race attacks highest outside Britain's big cities, survey reveals

fields.headline: Risk of race attacks highest outside Britain's big cities, survey reveals
fields.standfirst:
Hidden truth behind race crimes in Britain

Special report: race issues in the UK
The hidden truth behind race crimes in Britain
fields.trailText: Race attacks are almost 10 times more likely to happen in rural areas, according to an exclusive survey for The Observer , which also shows that more than two thirds of people think the police are as racist as ever.
fields.body:
Race attacks are almost 10 times more likely to happen in rural areas, according to an exclusive survey for The Observer , which also shows that more than two thirds of people think the police are as racist as ever.

Two years after the publication of Sir William Macpherson's report into the Stephen Lawrence murder inquiry, our findings show that one in 12 of the ethnic minority population in Northumbria have reported a racist incident since February 1999, compared with one in 200 in the West Midlands.

Confidence in police handling of race-related incidents has also plunged. An exclusive poll by ICM for The Observer found that more than 70 per cent of the public think the police are as racist, or more so, than they were when the Macpherson Report was published.

Sir John Stevens, the Commissioner of the Metropolitan Police, which serves the country's largest ethnic minority community, last night yesterday described the survey's findings as 'disappointing'.

Using official Home Office figures on racist incidents in each constabulary and plotting them against the size of the local ethnic minority population, a startling racial audit shows a country where safety lies in numbers.

The most dangerous areas for ethnic minorities are also those where there are the smallest communities. Northumbria tops the list, but is closely followed by Devon and Cornwall and south Wales, where racial crimes affect one in 15 and one in 16 respectively. Other race crime hotspots are Norfolk, Avon and Somerset, Durham and Cumbria. Between them, the top 10 worst constabularies in England and Wales for racist incidents are home to just 5 per cent of the total ethnic minority population.

By contrast it is the urban centres - London, Greater Manchester, West Yorkshire and Leicestershire - which appear to be the safest. Racist incidents affected just one in 200 of the ethnic minority population in the West Midlands, according to statistics.

 ICM Research interviewed a random selection of 1,206 adults aged 18-plus from 25-30 January 2001 across the country.

fields.headline: Bannister's back in pop
fields.standfirst: The ex-BBC boss who ousted veteran DJs from Radio1 is now promoting their superstar successors.  Mark Morris  reports
fields.trailText: The ex-BBC boss who ousted veteran DJs from Radio1 is now promoting their superstar successors. Mark Morris reports
fields.body:
The offices of Trust the DJ are what you would expect of a company launching itself in the music business: relaxed, slightly scruffy, all hip moulded plastic chairs and crumpled posters announcing long past Ibiza club nights.

What you may not expect is its new boss: a man once shortlisted as a possible director-general of the BBC. Here, in a blue jacket and an open-necked white shirt, is Matthew Bannister, former scourge of Radio 1's veteran DJs, John Birt's right-hand man and now the new chairman and chief executive of this combined record label, music management business, and website operation.

Sitting next to him and looking more the part, is Lynn Cosgrave, who co-founded the company with Tammy Smulders and was formerly vice-president in charge of dance music at Sony Music UK.

Trust the DJ has evolved from Cosgrave's existing business of managing the new breed of super-DJs, whose work is light years from the Smashey and Nicey Seventies stereotype. 'I found when I started speaking to DJs that no one had a clue what they were doing with their digital rights - how they should be exploited.'

What unites the three arms of the company is a certainty that, in Britain at least, no one any longer questions that idea that the men and women who play records at clubs are as important as the people who make the music.

The starting point is the talent agency which, as well as managing the DJs, will run events and tours. Second, Bannister says, comes 'a traditional offline record label that will issue compilation albums with a particular eye on the US market'. It expects to finalise a US distribution deal in the next two weeks.

Finally, there will be the DJs' internet home pages: 'More than 60 have signed up for this so far. Online, you will be able to buy exclusive [music] mix content from those DJs, their top 20 recommendations of the week and their entire discography - and have it delivered by us.'

But how will the internet side of the business make money? 'Through sales of recorded music and sponsorship,' Bannister says. 'The events business can make money, the management agency will make money, so there are a number of revenue streams. The company is not dependent on the internet.'

Financial backing comes from Lynx New Media Ventures, a collaboration between Virgin Media and Bear Stearns. There are also private investors including Primedia chief executive Tom Rogers and Michael Lynton, head of AOL International.

Trust the DJ employs 23 people. The stars handled by its clearly viable management side include Danny Rampling and John Digweed, world renowned for their work in clubs and their successful mixes of music on albums. The DJs' home pages will almost certainly be popular, but immediate profits seem unlikely. This may change with the evolution of the digital music, but after the Napster case Bannister says they are not rushing ahead because of 'the uncertainties on copyright about digital downloading'.

Which leaves the record label, whose main business will be dance compilations for the US market. The reasoning is roughly as follows: the success of these albums in Britain has been extraordinary; compilations account for a quarter of the UK popular music market; and the Ministry Of Sound label, which Cosgrave set up, has 15.6 per cent of the sector. Trust the DJ would need only a fraction of that success in the US to do well. 'The US market is 10 years behind the UK in terms of dance, and it a huge market,' Bannister says.

Surely others have seen this too? Cosgrave thinks UK companies have passed on the chance: 'Virgin over here has a great compilation division. They have had every opportunity to release music in America. Is it doing it? No. It's just laziness.

'That is what is so exciting to me. I've watched the compilation market get bigger and bigger and the rise of the DJ in records. The exciting challenge is going to be doing that in America.'

Her assessment of the US market is not shared by Michael Paoletta, dance editor at US music trade magazine Billboard . 'It's almost over-exploited. It's not growing fast; it has grown. The market is glutted.'

Paoletta thinks UK labels have failed to realise that there is not a US market so much as several US markets: 'It's 50 mini-countries.'

But he does think Trust The DJ has one thing going for it. 'Lynn Cosgrave is pretty connected over here, so anything is possible.'

Cosgrave, at 30, has a huge reputation in her field. Bannister says: 'Lynn's record in dance music compilation albums is second to none.'

With her record in founding the Ministry of Sound's successful label and her work at Sony, why did she need the former BBC man?

'We turned to Matthew because he has huge management experience and a phenomenal reputation with talent and for seeing things into the next five, 10 years,' Cosgrave says.

Bannister, now 43, spent 22 years at the BBC. He started as a news reporter on Radio 1, and converted the old Radio London into the more upmarket GLR. Then came his time at Radio 1 - when he drove out the likes of Simon Bates and Dave Lee Travis, as recounted in a recent episode of BBC2's Blood On The Carpet - followed by promotions to director of radio and director of production.

A key ally of Birt, he was responsible for the Birtist manifesto, 'Extending Choice'. He was widely expected to leave when Greg Dyke was appointed director-general ahead of him, but stayed on as director of marketing. He resigned last October after only a short time in that job 'because I got fed up with the central bureaucracy'.

He says no company of that size can be run without some bureaucracy, and turned down job offers in big corporations. It is fantastic 'to be working with people who are inspiring and creative and where you can call all the company together and get them into one room and agree what you are going to do and do it'.

He adds: 'In another sense it feels like the Radio 1 experience, because although that was part of the BBC, it was a microcosm on its own, and it was about music and about managing talent and about building a brand.'

And if Trust the DJ's three-forked approach works, especially its US adventure, Bannister is ready to retake familiar territory.

'There are opportunities to expand into radio and TV out of this: syndicated radio, working with DJs. I don't think television has ever successfully captured dance culture. I've got some ideas about how we might do that down the line as well, so I can see this becoming a proper multi-media, multi-talented brand over time.'

The websites and record label should be operational by early summer, although Bannister and Cosgrave are wily enough not to pin themselves down to any firm dates.

It must be said that there is something slightly puzzling about a new company attacking on three fronts at once.

But given that Bannister and Cosgrave have both helped to change the course of British pop music, only the unwise would underestimate Trust the DJ. After all, when the arrival of house music in this country 15 years ago set off the dance explosion, no one would have believed it would still be with us in the next century, nor that superstar DJs would be a reality rather than a joke.

Why shouldn't the Americans come round eventually?

The market is glutted.' Paoletta thinks UK labels have failed to realise that there is not a US market so much as several US markets: 'It's 50 mini-countries.' But he does think Trust The DJ has one thing going for it. 'Lynn Cosgrave is pretty connected over here, so anything is possible.' Cosgrave, at 30, has a huge reputation in her field. Bannister says: 'Lynn's record in dance music compilation albums is second to none.' With her record in founding the Ministry of Sound's successful label and her work at Sony, why did she need the former BBC man? 'We turned to Matthew because he has huge management experience and a phenomenal reputation with talent and for seeing things into the next five, 10 years,' Cosgrave says. Bannister, now 43, spent 22 years at the BBC. He started as a news reporter on Radio 1, and converted the old Radio London into the more upmarket GLR. Then came his time at Radio 1 - when he drove out the likes of Simon Bates and Dave Lee Travis, as recounted in a recent episode of BBC2's Blood On The Carpet - followed by promotions to director of radio and director of production. A key ally of Birt, he was responsible for the Birtist manifesto, 'Extending Choice'. He was widely expected to leave when Greg Dyke was appointed director-general ahead of him, but stayed on as director of marketing. He resigned last October after only a short time in that job 'because I got fed up with the central bureaucracy'. He says no company of that size can be run without some bureaucracy, and turned down job offers in big corporations. It is fantastic 'to be working with people who are inspiring and creative and where you can call all the company together and get them into one room and agree what you are going to do and do it'. He adds: 'In another sense it feels like the Radio 1 experience, because although that was part of the BBC, it was a microcosm on its own, and it was about music and about managing talent and about building a brand.' Why shouldn't the Americans come round eventually?

fields.headline: London calling
fields.standfirst: In the first of a monthly series, Monty travels around Britain in search of soil and a sense of place. First stop, the capital...
fields.trailText: In the first of a monthly series, Monty travels around Britain in search of soil and a sense of place. First stop, the capital...
fields.body:
For the first time in four years, I have been involved in television work that is not about gardening. It is not 'about' anything at all, really. The brief is to capture the essence of a place that has a definable local identity, on the basis that although we use big concepts like 'English' or 'Welsh' we are all tribally parochial and our instinct is to belong to quite a small, localised area. Understand these modest identities and, my theory goes, you come closer to an understanding of the real identity of a nation than a sweeping overview. It is a jigsaw. The whole only emerges from the sum of its parts, and the secret is to let the picture assemble itself.

When I approach a place for the first time, my instinct is to see what is growing. I want to know what the soil is like and what it wants to produce. If it is in countryside, then the chances are that hedgerows, woods and fields will reveal this quickly enough. Sandy, acidic soil will be betrayed by birches and rhododendrons, hollies, furze and heathers. Chalk cannot help but sprout beeches, hawthorn, yew and fields of barley, whereas rich clay loam will be marked by big oaks and ashes, wheat in the fields and cattle grazing. Chalky air smells different to clay.

The landscape gets read like a map. The line and pattern of a hedge is crowded with signs of its past - the sinuous s-shaped curve of the turning single plough that marked out enclosed ridge-and-furrow, or the grid-pattern of later enclosures. The number of different species in a stretch of hedge as the car whizzes by offers further historical evidence, and the angle of trees along the roadside probably says as much about prevailing winds as studious internet weather research.

But the most telling feature is the soil itself. Until I have felt it and smelt it and recognised its true colour, I cannot know any place at all. Picking up a handful of earth, I have a connection to the people who live above it. From this comes their building material, their flowers, their water table, their view. This is their cultural gene-bank.

But what of towns? Almost all of the above applies here, too. If not your bricks or stones, then your streets and back gardens are shaped more by the soil below them than by the playful artfulness of come-lately designers. You are hornbeam and poplar as much as you are shopping mall and ring road, sycamore and sweet chestnut as much as car park and office block.

For the last few weeks of January, I was in London, trying to nail the separateness of Greenwich, the Isle of Dogs, the City, Westminster and Chelsea. Even the muddled tangle of the capital, with its identities squeezed and saturated like a bathtime sponge, revealed its identity as much in the little corners of its gardens as in its towers and monuments.

Starting at the Dome on the Greenwich peninsula, the landscaping was finished and confident, with ranks of young trees staked and tied cheek by jowl - a landscaping trick that is used to provide protection for the growing trees before they mature and can be thinned. The paths were straight and crisp, flanked by hard-edged granite blocks somewhere in the territory between sculpture and benches. Water poured from granite holes in granite walls and ran round to come back again. The grass, looking tended and weed-free, turned out to be almost floating in its wetness, presumably because of the inevitable compaction caused by contractors ferrying back and forth over the ground with their fork-lifts. But it hardly mattered. There was no one to walk on it. An empty landscape put together like a stage set with the audience all gone home.

The Millennium Village is, predictably, more intimate and almost severely devoted to environmental and ecological correctness, which, severity and all, I heartily applaud. In the centre of a huge courtyard of houses and flats is a muddy site that is to become a communal water garden. But the conditions of sharing in this public space are that when you move into your new, incredibly exciting and interesting millennium home, you promise not to dig up the paved area that passes for a garden, not to hang washing on a line, not to keep a dog, not to park the car outside - not, in short, to sacrifice communal happiness in pursuit of creating the traditional English garden-as-castle.

If you go up to the Royal Observatory and look down over the Queen's house and the naval college and beyond across the river to the Isle of Dogs, the parkland that you can see is in every sense a communal garden. Londoners readily accept the rules and limitations of these parks. Without them, the city would be an intolerable place to live.

The City itself has no park within its walls, although the Corporation of London does own swathes of woods and parkland outside London - such as Epping Forest. Nevertheless, the City is touched with gardens in an almost abstract, shadowy way. The only way to discover these is to walk around, poking and prying - but I had time to do neither, as I was accompanying the Lord Mayor. This, of course, meant going round in his Roller, pennant fluttering and all. We did, however, have time for a pit stop at St Dunstan-in-the-East, a Wren church that was bombed in the Blitz, whose tower still remains but whose shell now shelters a garden.

The City, apparently, is several degrees warmer than the rest of London and is, in effect, a walled garden, big enough to let in light but very protected. The soil is gritty and thin, scarcely more than grey soot with brickdust and gravel - exactly the same as the soil of my old London garden a mile north of there. But this unappetising earth is actually surprisingly fertile and, with a bit of beefing up, will grow almost anything. In January, the camellia buds were flickering and a huge Magnolia sempirvirens grew on an east-facing wall. I wonder if, even there, it had sun enough to flower. The most extraordinary thing about the City is that among its rapacious hustling and insatiable trading, it is a very personal and human place.

I'll finish with my favourite London garden of all - the Chelsea Physic Garden. Filming any garden in January can be a nightmare as you struggle to construct a worthwhile piece without endless referral to what the place will look like later in the year. But the Physic Garden (which, during my few days filming in Chelsea I had solemnly described to me as 'the physical garden', 'the psychological garden' and 'the physics garden') bypasses that problem just by virtue of being so fascinating. It does not strain its aesthetic muscles. Surrounded by the slightly repellent wealth of Chelsea, it is low-key, strapped for cash and has an endearing touch of amateurism. Function almost entirely dictates form. An important part of that function is educational and therefore it is very accessible.

It started as a training ground for apprenticed apothecaries who came to the garden each day by river from their hall at Blackfriars, and although there were other physic gardens in Britain - including Oxford, Kew and Edinburgh - it remains the only extant physic garden. Most of the beds are laid out in a series of rectangular blocks divided by narrow grass paths, amounting to a horticultural filing system. Put off? Don't be. The effect is somehow a welcome release from the trials of performance. This is a garden that is unselfconsciously modest in an age when intimacy and subtlety are valued less than the spectacular display. It is my favourite place in London.

My roots

My hands are as soft and clean as they have been for years. They feel odd - like someone else's hands stuck on the end of my arms. You can read my state of mind in my hands. I need dirt and manual labour to think straight. All the time I was in London, the focus of work was on kitting out the new potting shed. This has involved building a potting bench with two containers as part of it, so that we can have two mixes going at the same time. There's aspiration for you.

You can buy plastic potting trays, but I find them too small. So we have a simple four-sided bay built into the bench, with a front lip only 6in high but the back and sides rising to twice that, and the whole thing big enough to hold a large bag of compost and its volume again of grit, perlite, leaf mould or whatever the mix dictates. Then all the sowing and potting on happens inside the bay, on the levelled-out mixture.

While I was away, Gareth edited our plastic pots and ditched any that we have not used in the last two years. The remainder have new shelves built for them from reclaimed timber, with small cubicles for each size of pot, all laid on edge so you can get at them, and their size chalked on the lip that stops them tumbling out. If this attention to detail sounds slightly fetishistic then no apologies: I love this kind of order. It makes me feel like a grown-up. I am certain that if the engine room is chaotic and unloved, then this will be reflected in the garden.

I have sown rocket, curly endive, mizuna and mibuna in plugs for planting out into the greenhouse, and the first seed onions are coming up now, along with tomatoes and peas in pots. I wanted to get the broad beans, onion sets and shallots in outside, but it has been torrentially wet again.

In principle, I always battle with the urge to sow masses in the greenhouse now, knowing the chances are that the ground won't be ready to accommodate them for months - by which time everything will be etiolated and need potting on.

Mike Evans came by the other day. Mike is a local sheep farmer and woodman, who has supplied me with the hazel rods I have used over the years for weaving protective fences. He will bring 25 more bundles of 10ft hazel rods soon so I can repair the fences that support the raised beds in the vegetable garden. This takes time and must be done before the hazel dries out too much, otherwise it doesn't bend properly. So If I don't get it done, we end up with an awful lot of beansticks.

webTitle: BBC turns its vengeful fire on Murdoch

fields.headline: BBC turns its vengeful fire on Murdoch
fields.standfirst:
Shoot to Kill director turns his sights on the Sunday Times in a new £1m drama

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Shoot to Kill director turns his sights on the Sunday Times in a new £1m drama
fields.body:
The newspaper has bitterly criticised the BBC, accusing it of waste, mismanagement and dull programming, and calling for the abolition of the licence fee. It cost the corporation's director-general, Greg Dyke, hundreds of thousands of pounds when an investigation into his share-holdings forced him to sell his £6 million stake in a rival broadcaster.

But now the BBC is poised to take revenge on the Sunday Times . Peter Kosminsky, the director behind the acclaimed BBC film Warriors and the Shoot to Kill drama-documentary which was banned in Northern Ireland, is turning his sights on the title. A £1m drama about the life of journalists on the paper is due to be screened on BBC1.

News of the programme has sparked paranoia at the Sunday Times , which is owned by Rupert Murdoch, whose global media empire also includes the digital satellite broadcaster Sky. Staff risk losing their jobs if they talk to BBC researchers.

One insider told The Observer : 'Everyone is wondering whether anyone has said anything. It is not just people who work here. There are lots of people who have left to go to other papers who might be willing to talk.'

News of the film comes just weeks after it emerged that former Sunday Times literary editor Harry Ritchie is writing a thinly veiled portrait of life on the paper. His novel, The Friday Night Club , fea tures an editor called Jonathan Witherington. The editor of the Sunday Times is John Witherow.

In an operation worthy of a Sunday Times Insight investigation, BBC researchers began tracking down hundreds of present and former journalists on the paper three weeks ago. One writer who met a researcher says the film will focus on allegations of unethical practices on the paper.

'They kept asking how stories got into the paper,' he said. 'Did people bend facts? Were reporters told to go out and make stories work, whatever it took? Were people put under intolerable pressure to deliver? Was the Sunday Times simply a tabloid in broadsheet clothing? They were looking for conspiracies, an exposé.'

Another former reporter, who was contacted by the BBC last month, said: 'They are being very thorough. They were interested to find out how Michael Foot was falsely accused of being a KGB agent and how a male trainee reporter was asked to infiltrate a lesbian pressure group. They wanted to know whether the paper ever employed people to break in to places to steal sensitive material.'

Kosminsky, who is currently in Los Angeles filming a movie starring Michelle Pfeiffer, said he could not discuss the project, but BBC insiders say the film could be screened as early as next year. One said: 'Although he is in the media himself, Peter has very strong opinions about the press. The drama will absolutely not be an exercise in muck-raking. It will present a well-researched accurate picture.'

The Sunday Times is enormously successful, making millions of pounds in profit each year. But many media figures took against the paper when Murdoch successfully smashed the print unions by moving all his newspaper titles to a new headquarters in Wapping, east London, 15 years ago. Journalists at the paper believe its critics are simply jealous of its success.

Friends of Kosminsky say he came up with the idea for the film when newspapers wrote a series of misleading stories about his forthcoming £2m BBC drama The Project , which exposes the lives and loves of Tony Blair's shadowy clique of fanatical young advisers in the run-up to the 1997 General Election. 'Peter was incandescent with rage about what some of the newspapers said about his film. He could not believe they could get away with - as he saw it - telling lies.'

BBC researchers are understood to have consid ered making a film about the Daily Mail , but believe the Sunday Times would make a more 'colourful' story.

Jane Tranter, controller of drama commissioning at the BBC, confirmed the corporation was planning a newspaper drama which she described as 'spikey'. 'We are working with Peter Kosminsky. We have several ideas in varied stages of development. There is one about the press.

'We are looking at what it is like to be a modern journalist. What the temperature of a newspaper office is like. What does it mean when you are working on the treadmill of a paper? What does it mean if you have been there for 20 years and feel you are thrown on the scrapheap? What happens when you trip up as a bright young thing?'

She 'categorically denied' that the film would focus on a single title that had criticised the BBC. 'We are not stupid enough to think the nation is interested in watching a drama about the BBC scoring points. We will make prats of ourselves if that is all we are going to do. Peter will take an analytical look and home in on the human areas.'

But one senior BBC insider said: 'If you speak to anyone in the BBC about Rupert Murdoch you will hear strong views. No one would like to put one over on the Sunday Times more than the BBC.'

A spokesman for the Sunday Times said: 'We know about the film and look forward to seeing it - if it ever sees the light of day.'

webTitle: Esther Rantzen's memoir prompts family feud

fields.headline: Esther Rantzen's memoir prompts family feud
fields.trailText: It has all the compelling ingredients of  Esther , the hit daytime TV show. First, the devoted widow discloses the heart-rending circumstances of her husband's recent death. Quite unembarrassed, she shares his touching last moments with millions. Then she tantalisingly hints at the bitterness she still feels towards his first wife.
fields.body:
It has all the compelling ingredients of Esther , the hit daytime TV show. First, the devoted widow discloses the heart-rending circumstances of her husband's recent death. Quite unembarrassed, she shares his touching last moments with millions. Then she tantalisingly hints at the bitterness she still feels towards his first wife.

Enter with dramatic flourish the aggrieved step-daughter. Her father's apparently blonde second wife was once a 'toothy overweight brunette', she claims, who has a craven desire for publicity and has shown terrible insensitivity towards her entire family.

But these are not ordinary folk from middle Britain, the normal protagonists on Esther Rantzen's afternoon programme. This time, the devoted widow is Miss Rantzen herself.

And the embittered step-daughter is Cassandra, the child of legendary TV producer Desmond Wilcox, to whom Rantzen was happily and very publicly devoted for 32 years.

Last week, Esther - who became a huge TV star 30 years ago as host of BBC1's That's Life - published the first extracts from her autobiography. It includes intimate details not only of her 32-year relationship with Wilcox and the triumphs of their television work together but also of his painful death shortly after they had re-celebrated their marriage vows. She said of Wilcox: 'He radiated warmth and light into our lives and for the moment we fear that we have lost the sunshine we depended on.'

But yesterday Cassandra retaliated, with a barrage of accusations of inaccuracy, cruelty and unpleasantness. 'Esther has claimed that when my father was dying, he took off his oxygen mask and gave her "a kiss so passionate that it made the children blush". I was in the hospital during the last hours of my father's life. His breathing was shallow and he was on morphine and other drugs.' That is one of the gentler rebukes to the accuracy of Rantzen's recollections.

Most wounding of all, Cassandra claims that the TV star left Desmond Wilcox alone on the night before he died. But a source close to Rantzen said yesterday: 'Esther left Desmond's side briefly to fetch a Jewish prayer book and she is terribly keen to set the record straight over that. But she was very definitely with Desmond when he died.'

However, that is only the first of a string of contentious claims. Cassandra complains that Esther had 'stolen' Wilcox from her mother Patsy, that she had 'no hesitation in exposing her children to the press' and, most acid of all, that the TV star had redecorated the Wilcox family home from 'floor to ceiling in chintz and Tiffany lamps'.

'When your mother is dead and may be under attack, you have no choice but to speak out,' insists Cassandra. She even makes a remarkable claim of insensitivity over an incident during a trivia quiz at TV production company Man Alive shortly after Patsy Wilcox's cremation two years ago. 'One of the obscure questions was "What burned in Richmond?" The moment the question was read out, Esther shrieked: "My husband's ex-wife." The right answer was a shed owned by Man Alive's Mike Johnstone, which burned down.'

The bizarre dispute between Rantzen and her step-daughter is likely to catapault Rantzen back into the public arena. While her current TV vehicle has been a success for BBC2's daytime schedules, it attracts 1.5 million viewers. That is just a tenth of the audience which That's Life pulled in its heyday, with its unmissable, but slightly forgettable, recipe of safety outrages, dodgy builders and vegetables which looked like genitals. Or was it the other way round?

Unlike That's Life - axed for becoming 'dull and predictable' - the Rantzen family feud has plenty of mileage left. Cassandra has now promised that tomorrow she will reveal 'my mother's unpublished manuscript, which tells of her marriage to my father, how she felt Esther stole him from her and how my mother felt.'

Rantzen's friend told The Observer: 'Esther is simply not going to engage with all this. She has no intention of getting into a dispute with her step-daughter.' But her complete memoir, as the publicists are always keen to point out, will be in all good bookshops soon.

fields.headline: Enigmatic variations
fields.standfirst: Where does the character stop and the man behind him start? On the location in Savannah, Georgia for his latest film, Keanu Reeves remains as elusive as ever
fields.trailText: Where does the character stop and the man behind him start? On the location in Savannah, Georgia for his latest film, Keanu Reeves remains as elusive as ever
fields.body:
'Hey ya'll. Is this the parole office?' A podgy little man with a bumfluff beard and glasses, wearing baggy shorts and a purple, tie-dyed T-shirt, is standing in the doorway, peering in at the people inside, trying to find a familiar face. They laugh. In fact, they're tempted to play along with the joke and tell him, in a parody of his Southern accent: 'Yes, suh - and we're setting y'all free!' But the laughter just makes him all the more confused and suddenly the penny drops. This is not a member of the visiting film crew playing a prank on the others - he's a real-life criminal, checking in.

What used to be the parole office is now a makeshift workstation for the cast and crew of The Gift, a supernatural thriller directed by Sam Raimi and being shot on location in Savannah, Georgia. Raimi is a maverick whose exhilarating camerawork came to prominence in the dizzying, bloody Evil Dead series. But like his 1997 thriller, A Simple Plan, The Gift is a much more muted affair, resting on a grounded performance by Oscar nominee Cate Blanchett, herself taking a break from more serious projects. But while the star is Blanchett, the revelation is Keanu Reeves. He plays Donnie Barksdale, six snarling feet of redneck fury and the abusive husband of Valerie (Hilary Swank), turning his clean-cut Matrix messiah boy image on its head.

Reeves is anxious not to be typecast. In the same week The Gift is released here, we'll also see him in The Watcher, in which he plays Griffin, a serial killer who teases the FBI by staging elaborate murders and laying false trails. But where Griffin is a cold, elusive psychopath, whose good looks seem actually superfluous to the role, Barksdale is a physically intimidating bully who, in one especially well-crafted scene, bursts into Annie's house and drags his screaming wife out by the hair.

It's all very far from the Gen-X clown capers of Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure or the high-cheekbone heroics of Speed and the Wachowski brothers' The Matrix. And when he makes his entrance, taking a break between shots, Reeves is an impressive presence. He looks much bigger - taller and wider - than his usual, lean self and his new bulk is squeezed into a cheap, polyester WalMart suit. Although not technically in character, he's adopted some of Donnie Barksdale's mannerisms for the time being, lolling back in his chair and making strong, assertive gestures with his arms and shoulders. Taking the guise of a good ol' boy, just sitting there, hanging out, like a regular Joe. But his eyes seem nervous and distant, as though someone else is inside, working the machinery.

Today, they're filming a courtroom scene, with Keanu in the dock, and because it requires some concentration he will be conducting the interview in a Southern accent. Thankfully, this has improved somewhat since his turn in the awful horror thriller, The Devil's Advocate. His hair straggles at his shirt collar and a weird, angular beard, grows in clumps on his chin. 'Sam wanted me to be less recognisable and it just started to grow,' he explains. 'So we decided not to cut it.'

Reeves has been working on this new 'look' for several weeks now. 'I didn't want to just play "a Southerner", you know?' he says. 'And in working with the dialect coach, all of us tried to find a certain region that our characters were from. And then, once we'd decided on a region, I found a county called Rankin and went there. No one could believe it. I'd come back to the set and people would be, like, "Rankin? What were you doing thar ?"'

There are several myths surrounding this 36-year-old actor. One is that he is inarticulate and moody. Indeed, before he finally appears, it is even suggested that he might not speak at all; he is, variously, 'tired', 'ill' and 'working on an intense scene'. Another is that, well, he's simply not an actor. But despite the oddness of talking to someone in character, Reeves gives a surprisingly good account of himself. He's not exactly a Method actor, but he's willing put his back into it.

'When I first got here,' he says, 'I just couldn't get it. Then I went out to a couple of bars and I met a couple of guys. Suddenly I was like, "Oh, right, that's what I gotta get". Because there's something about people from the South, they just exude where they're from. I wanted to get that down, so that if I just walked into a room, people would think, "Whoah, that's a redneck!"'

So he hired a souped-up pick-up truck, bought a hat and a pair of boots and checked out the local nightlife.

'A couple of times it's been good,' he says, 'but there's a certain style in Rankin that's just confrontational. They come up to you and sort of test you. They push you - like, "Where you from?" They might make fun of where you're from or what you look like. In a nice way, smiling. And then they see how you respond.

'I remember I went into Rankin once and this pick-up truck pulled up next to me and I got scared. This black truck, with black windows, a Confederate flag, a gun rack, antennae.'

His voice drops to an almost conspiratorial level and his shoulders snap back, as if he's about to reveal that something bad happened. But nothing did happen; the truck (presumably) drove away. And for the first time, it's possible to see a glimpse of the real Keanu Reeves beneath Donnie Barksdale's bravado, the unshaven, grungy figure who turned up at the Glastonbury festival two years back with his ropey band, Dogstar, wearing a grubby black suit and woolly hat jammed down over his ears. The Keanu Reeves who literally answered the first three questions of a press conference there with the following, unforgettable answers: 'No', 'No' and 'Uh, we just got here.'

Donnie Barksdale seems to be getting under his skin and the result, he says, is his temper is closer to the surface. 'I call it my Donnie,' he chuckles. 'Like, "I gotta get my Donnie on", you know?'

Is it difficult juggling these personalities?

'Sometimes, it can take a while to get back,' he nods. 'It means, if it's been very intense, some of the habits and ways of being kind of come with you back home and you kind of have to readjust to your life. For me sometimes, it's so great to have change. When you get back, sometimes, it's like your relationships and where you're at kind of puts you back into the rhythm of how you were before you left. Sometimes, I find myself trying not to do that. But then there's other times when I miss how I was, or am. So there's always a kind of schism.'

Reeves's commitment will be put to the test in his next two films, which for 16 months will take him to Australia and plunge him back into the world of The Matrix. Reeves is saying nothing except that he has the scripts, which he's very pleased with, although internet rumours suggest that his character, Neo, will develop new superpowers and do battle with a new crew of supervillains who weave in and out of the storyline. 'They're going to film two films, but not in order,' he says.

So how much training will that require?

'Basic training is four months, and my first fight after that won't be for another month and a half. So it's more like five months.'

Is there much pressure to deliver two more hits?

'I'm sure there is, especially for the directors. But I like that pressure. I know when I made The Matrix it was important for me to be there every day and be ready. I had this vision of a mountain, like, "OK, do what you have to do but get there". I enjoyed that, I think because I'm just part of the film. It's not like I'm carrying the film the way Mel Gibson carried the Lethal Weapon series. I'm part of The Matrix.'

And what can we expect this time round?

'What they're doing with some of the digital aspects that are available now is amazing; technology has been developed that will allow the brothers, Andy and Larry, to move the camera around sequences that have never been done before. They want the actors to do more, and we're gonna be using even more weapons this time.'

Before this, Keanu will be concentrating on a couple of smaller movies, starting with a weepie called Sweet November, with Charlize Theron. Is he ever disappointed by the scripts he gets? Does he ever feel typecast as an action bimbo?

'I find it...'

(Suddenly, the familiar, hesitant Keanu emerges and it becomes apparent that he's struggling to keep up the façade. Though he's trying to be sociable and outgoing, it just doesn't seem to come naturally and his eyes maintain a definite aversion strategy. Beneath the Donnie Barksdale persona is still the reluctant star who feels uncomfortable with attention and who reacts with abrupt defensiveness. And it quickly becomes apparent that Reeves is perhaps even marginalised in his own profession. He isn't merely an actor, he's a movie star and desperately needs to be taken seriously, hence the deep-cover research, the accent, the 'Donnie'.)

'I find it mixed,' he decides. 'You see a lot of clichés, you see a lot of people following other people who've broken ground, then you get scripts you can relate to - like, "Wow, that's the truth! That's good". But those movies are few and far between. It seems like with American movies it's hard to get, not day to day stuff, but stuff like [Todd Solondz's] Happiness. Or even American Beauty, where you have a simple storyline and people are able to just "be real" and tell the story through that. On the surface, that doesn't seem to be interesting and yet those are the films that people remember. Those are the films that are hard to find, those simple stories that are as big as life, as opposed to spectacle.'

And at that moment, the publicist appears, ready to whisk him back to the set.

"I appreciate it,' he drawls, before shaking hands. 'Have a good day, man.'

Keanu Reeves: the real thing

Born 2 September 1964, Beirut, Lebanon. His father, Samuel Nowlin Reeves, was a geologist; his mother, Patricia, was a showgirl.

Name Means 'cool breeze over the mountains' in Hawaiian.

Significant other None.

Nickname 'The Wall', a reference to his high school days as an ice hockey goalie.

Big Break Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure (1989). The time-travelling goofball became his signature role.

Hits Point Break (1991), Speed (1994), The Matrix (1999).

Misses Even Cowgirls Get the Blues (1993), Chain Reaction, Feeling Minnesota (1996).

Film fact He turned down a role opposite Al Pacino and Robert De Niro in Heat to play Hamlet in Winnipeg, Canada.

Current fee $15 million.

Other career Bass player in rock band Dogstar. They played Glastonbury in 1999, where unimpressed revellers pelted them with fruit.

On Keanu: 'You cannot get close to him, he is somehow unattainable. That makes him very, very attractive' - Kenneth Branagh.

Keanu says: 'I don't want to live a stupid life. I know I'm doomed. I'm a dog. But I'm trying to shake the dog, y'know?'

The Gift and The Watcher open 2 March

fields.headline: Closely observed brains
fields.standfirst: Anthony Hopkins offers a masterclass in malevolence in the sequel to Silence of the Lambs
fields.trailText: Philip French: ...they were more interesting when he was playing mind games while helping her investigations than now when the two of them are outsiders and uneasy allies...
fields.body:
The midpoint of the twentieth century and its end were both dominated by cinematic villains with identical initials whose brief appearances in secondary roles enabled them to hijack the films in which they appeared and to insist upon a separate life. In 1949, Harry Lime, the vicious postwar racketeer, whose contaminated penicillin maimed and killed children in Vienna, somehow became the hero of The Third Man. Subsequently, in somewhat laundered form, Lime became the eponymous protagonist of radio and TV series starring respectively Orson Welles and Michael Rennie.

Forty years later, the cannibalistic murderer, Dr Hannibal Lecter, though scarcely seen outside his dungeon, dominated The Silence of the Lambs, and for a decade his creator, Thomas Harris, worked on a novel putting him stage centre, which now reaches the screen as Hannibal, with Anthony Hopkins reprising his Oscar-winning role. On the face of it, Hannibal is far worse than Lime, but in fact all his despicable victims are somehow culpable, while Lime's were innocents. Both Welles and Hopkins are smooth-faced performers, resembling evil babies and are given to ingratiating themselves with smiling eyes and sinister grins.

Welles came to The Third Man from playing Cesare Borgia in The Prince of Foxes, and immediately before Hannibal Hopkins took the title role in a film of Shakespeare's Titus Andronicus, a similar story of cannibalism and mutilation that probably influenced Harris. What Lime and Hannibal have in common is the way they are drawn to the Renaissance world where civilised values and exquisite cruelty intermingle.

The fugitive Hannibal has found a perfect billet, running a quattrocento library in a Florentine palazzo and studying Renaissance iconography. The self-justifying lines that Welles put into the mouth of Lime could as easily have been spoken by Lecter - 'In Italy for 30 years under the Borgias they had warfare, terror, murder, bloodshed - they produced Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci and the Renaissance. In Switzerland, they had brotherly love, 500 years of democracy and peace and what did that produce? The cuckoo clock.' Perhaps we feel that Lime and Hannibal help to make sense of the terrible twentieth century.

Ridley Scott's Hannibal, which has been adapted with considerable fidelity by David Mamet, Steven Zaillian and uncredited others, differs considerably from the two previous films featuring Lecter. Both Manhunter and The Silence of the Lambs are police procedural movies in which the FBI's behavioural science department tracks down colourful serial killers. In the first, Brian Cox's Lecter helps veteran agent Will Graham (William Petersen) pursue the infamous 'Tooth Fairy'. In the second, Hopkins's Lecter assists the tyro agent Clarice Starling to understand the mentality of the sadistic 'Buffalo Bill'. Hannibal, on the other hand, is a combination of Jacobean revenge drama and Edgar Allan Poe gothic tale.

It begins like a police procedural piece with a brilliantly staged drug raid in Washington's open-air fish market (a raffish location that recalls the streets in Blade Runner) that concludes with the raid's leader, Special Agent Clarice Starling (Julianne Moore), washing the HIV blood of a dangerous Hispanic woman gangster from the baby she's been carrying as cover. The shot prepares the way for a series of bloody images that punctuate the film. But this opening is designed as a way of isolating Clarice, a woman of unimpeachable probity, from her dishonest, cowardly, self-seeking colleagues in a variety of federal agencies and, most especially, from the devious, misogynistic Paul Krendler (Ray Liotta) from the Justice Department, a creepy philistine who can't even pronounce 'fiefdom' (his version rhymes with 'knifed'em').

Krendler is in league with billionaire Mason Verger (Gary Oldman unrecognisable behind his prosthetic disguise and named only in the final credits), a hideously disfigured cripple who lives on the magnificent Biltmore Estate in North Carolina, the biggest private mansion in America. Verger, a vicious paedophile whose face Lecter peeled and fed to the dogs, is Hannibal's only surviving victim and he intends to take his revenge by feeding him to a herd of ravenous wild boars specially bred in Sardinia (where else?).

In order to lure the elusive doctor, Clarice is put back on the case, but at the very moment she's tracking him down to Florence, he's located by Inspector Rinaldo Pazzi (Giancarlo Giannini). Pazzi is a Florentine aristocrat by name (an ancestor was hanged for murdering a Medici in the fifteenth century) and a patsy by nature, a fool who thinks he can tangle with Hannibal. With an expensive young wife and a taste for Armani threads, the sad Pazzi decides to sell the fugitive American to Verger. Lecter, who likes to combine massive retaliation with witty conceits, prepares an elaborate death fit for a Renaissance Pazzi.

The film's Florence is far removed from the elegant, glowing city of A Room with a View. As lit by the talented British cameraman John Mathieson (who worked with Scott on Gladiator), this is a dark, satanic place of renaissance intrigue.

The only convincing explanation for a man on the FBI's '10 Most Wanted' list deciding to live here in plain sight is that everyone walks around in the shadows. Even when Hannibal goes to the opera, it's a gloomy work based on Dante's Inferno staged at night in the cloisters of a Renaissance palace. But the stylised, highly-charged atmosphere deters us from looking at the movie in any literal way, just as later on when Clarice comes to Hannibal's rescue, Verger's stronghold proves to be like the lair of a Bond villain, at once impregnable and easy to penetrate.

Much of the feeling we have for the relationship of Clarice and Hannibal we bring from The Silence of the Lambs. Moore's likeable Clarice is older, tougher, yet no less vulnerable than Jodie Foster's. She is, however, much more disillusioned, and thus, while retaining a strong sense of right and wrong, she's closer in her view of the world to the Machiavellian joker, Hannibal, with whom Hopkins has so much fun. But they were more interesting when he was playing mind games while helping her investigations than now when the two of them are outsiders and uneasy allies, in her case fighting a Protestant conscience that insists Lecter be turned over to the authorities.

Clarice and Hannibal first make contact through an exotic clue he plants in a letter to her, and then accidentally via a third party's cellphone. But they are never in close proximity until they stalk each other in a dynamic sequence set in Washington's Union Station (a place now given over to boutiques and fairground shows) and don't meet until the last couple of reels. In this, the film resembles a macabre variation of Nora Ephron's Sleepless in Seattle and You've Got Mail, those chastely romantic comedies of consummation postponed starring Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan.

There are a couple of scenes - one involving a disembowelling, the other gourmet cranial surgery - that are deliberately excessive, intended to make us flinch as we laugh at Hannibal's terrible wit. Mostly, though, the movie is pretty restrained. Lecter's cannibalism, we learn, has so endeared him to connoisseurs in a society devoted to the culinary arts that a former male nurse at the Baltimore Hospital for the Criminally Insane has sold Hannibal's signed copy of The Joy of Cooking to a collector for $6,000.

In 1949, Harry Lime, the vicious postwar racketeer, whose contaminated penicillin maimed and killed children in Vienna, somehow became the hero of The Third Man. Subsequently, in somewhat laundered form, Lime became the eponymous protagonist of radio and TV series starring respectively Orson Welles and Michael Rennie. Forty years later, the cannibalistic murderer, Dr Hannibal Lecter, though scarcely seen outside his dungeon, dominated The Silence of the Lambs, and for a decade his creator, Thomas Harris, worked on a novel putting him stage centre, which now reaches the screen as Hannibal, with Anthony Hopkins reprising his Oscar-winning role. fields.headline: Whose story is it anyway?
fields.standfirst: As the creator of Cracker, Jimmy McGovern was used to getting his own way. Then he wrote a script for Stephen Frears and found that playing second fiddle drove him to drink
fields.trailText: As the creator of Cracker, Jimmy McGovern was used to getting his own way. Then he wrote a script for Stephen Frears and found that playing second fiddle drove him to drink
fields.body:
The Rewrite

In an early draft of Liam, the title character saw a prostitute plying her trade. His young head couldn't make sense of this but he vaguely knew it was sinful, something he had to tell the priest at his first confession. Thus began Liam's dramatic journey. Not a great start, I told myself, but it did its job. I emailed the draft to Stephen Frears.

Stephen summoned me to the office. I found him poring over the script. I waited, pencil poised. 'This bit here,' he said, pointing to the prostitute scene, 'it's er, it's er...' I licked my pencil. Any moment now, a brilliant insight from the great director. 'It's not quite good enough,' he said. And that was it.

I got home, opened a bottle and paced the floor all night. 'Not quite good enough.' What kind of a script note was that? Some middle-class Jew reads a working-class Catholic script and all he can say is, 'It's not quite good enough.'

Halfway down the bottle I realised that that was the best note I'd ever been given. What Stephen had said to me, in effect, was this: 'Look, I can't tell you what should be there; this is your story, not mine. And it's truthful and it comes from the heart. But the prostitute scene isn't truthful. It's simply a scene that does its job. Replace it with a scene that does the job and comes from the heart.'

So I thought back to when I was Liam's age and I walked into the back kitchen and saw my mother naked. I saw, too, her pubic hair and for months after that I thought my mother was deformed.

I had thought of describing this incident early on in my career, particularly in the first episodes of Cracker . But my mother was still alive; I loved her so much; I didn't want her to think anything she had done, no matter how innocently, had traumatised me. But now she was dead, so I wrote it. And, looking at it now, it seems (the acid test of rewrites) that it was always there - so central is it to Liam's story, so organic .

I asked Stephen if I could follow him on the shoot. Up to this point I'd always locked myself in my room when the cameras rolled - apart from Hillsborough, of course, when I couldn't keep away - but here was a chance to watch Stephen Frears in action. I grabbed it.

The Shoot

Stephen worked like this.

He'd pull a tatty page out of his back pocket - the little piece of my script he intended to shoot. 'Inch by motherfucking inch,' he'd say, quoting Oliver Stone. 'That's how films are made. Inch by motherfucking inch.'

He'd assemble the actors. 'How do you want to do this?' he'd say. This would dumbfound those actors used to directors instructing them, but most of them responded enthusiastically, chipping in with actions, movements, etc. Stephen would veto some, accept some and then turn to Andrew Dunn (the best cameraman I've ever seen, a genius) and say, 'Can we do this, Andrew?'

Andrew would move around the set, arms swinging for tracking shots, hands plunging forward for close-ups. Stephen would nod, nod, interject and, finally satisfied, he'd say, 'Let's do it.'

Now I know that sounds ridiculously simple. I know I'm talking of a cameraman and director steeped in experience, knowledge and technique but, for the life of me, I cannot think of a better way to shoot a scene.

Not all went smoothly, but at times of crisis Stephen would walk into the middle of the set, spread his hands in mock-despair and, like a little-boy-lost, announce to the world, 'I don't know what to do.' People would then steam in from all directions. The cameraman would suggest something, the sound man, props, make-up, design, even catering.

Stephen, wise old dog, would take everything offered, assimilate it, synthesise it and, problem solved, the shoot would continue. This taught me a fundamental truth. People who work in film want to give . And only a fool would refuse to take from them.

Post-production

Stephen shot the entire script (a rarity in the British film industry), took it to London and left me kicking my heels in Liverpool. But a week or two later I was able to see the first rough assembly. It was love at first sight: every scene beautifully shot, perfectly acted, and all in the order in which I had written them. In my ecstasy I didn't hear the ominous warnings from Stephen that further work was needed.

Further work was done and I sat down at home and watched the result. Now look, nobody told me that this was work in progress. Nobody told me that this was Stephen trying things out. I just sat down in total ignorance and watched this latest cut. Watched with mounting horror. When it finished, I opened up a bottle and drank and drank and drank. Three-quarters down the bottle I phoned Colin McKeown, the co-producer. This is roughly what I said.

That bastard Frears. He's tossed my script in the air, seen how it landed, and cut it accordingly. I spent years on that structure, Colin. Years. And he's chopping and changing it after two lousy weeks in the edit suite. He's a middle-class Jew (my ace, this; I'd played it repeatedly throughout the shoot) and this is a working-class Catholic film. Talk to him!

My wife, Eileen, told me I was wrong to scream at Colin. This assembly was Stephen's doing and it was Stephen I should berate. I downed the rest of the bottle, picked up the phone and repeated the whole thing into Stephen Frears's answer-machine. Look, nobody told me he was just trying things out.

Next morning I woke with a guilt-fuelled hangover. This was not the first time in my life I'd woken with a guilt-fuelled hangover, but hitherto the flashbacks had made me cringe every hour. These made me cringe every 10 seconds.

I faxed Stephen, gave it an hour for my grovelling to sink in, then phoned to grovel even more. He was ultra-polite, but the subtext I heard beneath every sentence (although Stephen will deny it) was: Fuck you, you ungrateful, drunken Scouser. A good relationship with a top-class director - wrecked in five drunken minutes. Why did I do it?

Do you really need the shark?

As a writer, your early years (in some cases all your years) are full of rejections. Then, one day, someone says he'll produce your script. You're delighted obviously but, above all, you're grateful . He tells you it's a wonderful script but his budget is limited, so the scene on the banks of the Mersey, could you live with doing it in the main character's back room? Yes, you say. And could you live without the helicopter? Oh yes. He suggests other rewrites. They'll take you a week at least, but could you have them done by teatime tomorrow? Yes, yes, yes.

British producer, on the first draft of Jaws: Do you really need the shark?

You go on saying yes throughout your career. If you were to say no, if you were to fight for the things you believed in, they'd label you 'difficult' (which is bad) or 'precious' (even worse) and you'd never work again. So all the time, through compromise after compromise, you suppress a frustrated monster within you until, emboldened by rage or drugs or alcohol, it bursts forth and wrecks everything in sight. When this happens, you tell yourself you're simply asserting the primacy of the writer. But, the morning after, you realise you should have done it without the alibi of rage, drugs or alcohol, you should have done it in the cold sober light of day, but that was impossible because, in the cold sober light of day, all a writer ever says is yes, yes, yes.

To order Jimmy McGovern's Liam screenplay (ScreenPress Books £7.99) for £5.99 plus p&p, call 0800 3168 171. Liam opens on Friday
