September 1960: Mandy Rice Davies starts work at Murray's. February 1961: Keeler moves into Ward's Wimpole Mews flat where she says she witnessed him meeting Eugene Ivanov, the director general of MI5 Sir Roger Hollis and Anthony Blunt. June 1961: Keith Wagstaffe, a Hollis underling from MI5, comes to Ward's Wimpole Mews flat. The security services have become suspicious of Ivanov and of Ward's friendship with him. Ward starts to see Keeler as a 'ticking bomb'. 8 July 1961: Ward introduces Keeler to John Profumo, Secretary of State for War, at Cliveden. Ward's aim was for Christine to find out from Profumo through 'pillow talk... when nuclear warheads were being moved to Germany'. October 1961: Keeler becomes pregnant by Profumo. She has an abortion three months later. 14 December 1962: Keeler's ex-boyfriend Johnnie Edgecombe tries to shoot her at the Wimpole Mews flat. The police are called and the attention of the media is drawn to Ward and the people (and agents) who come and go from his flat. 22 March 1963: Profumo makes a personal statement to the House of Commons denying his involvement with Keeler. 5 June 1963: Jack Profumo resigns. 30 July 1963: Stephen Ward obtains Nembutal and kills himself. 1963: Keeler is jailed for nine months for perjury. The Photographer, His Chair, That Image and the Copycats... Lewis Morley: Christine came into my studio at the Establishment Club in Soho for a publicity shoot for a movie that never got made. The session was very quick. I took a couple of rolls of her in a little jerkin she was wearing. Then there was a bit of a tiswas because the movie producers wanted her to be photographed nude and she wasn't keen. So I got rid of everybody from the studio. I told her I would turn my back and she took all her clothes off. She later said she kept her knickers on. She didn't, but I won't argue with that. She was quite coy. Not blatant at all. I said to her: 'Sit behind that chair and you'll still be fulfilling the nude bit in your contract.' It was a cheap copy of an Arne Jacobson chair from Heals' sale. I've still got it. I only took one roll of her on the chair. It all took 10 minutes at the most. The whole thing was very relaxed as far as I was concerned. I didn't think about what was happening. It was a job. It just happened to snowball. Its been good and bad in that I've done a lot of work, but on the other hand people only know me through the Keeler photograph. For years I hardly made a penny out of it: maybe £3,000, when it could have been worth a hundred times that. In 1989 I won back the copyright. Matt Groening sent me a drawing of Homer Simpson on the chair. I like that very much. In The Photographer's Chair After taking the iconic shot of Keeler, Morley was regularly asked to shoot other people in the same pose. Those who have straddled the chair for him include: David Frost at the height of the Profumo scandal, as a publicity stunt for That Was The Week That Was. Joe Orton in 1965, as a publicity shot for his play Loot. Edina Ronay the fashion designer Barry Humphries as Dame Edna Everage Others who have copied the chair pose over the years include: The Spice Girls to publicise their song, Naked in 1998 Emma Milne, the Vets In Practice celebrity, to publicise an anti-hunt campaign in 1999 Keith Chegwin with socks on, May 2000 Jodie Kidd in an ad for developer Saxon Homes, June 2000 Alison Steadman to publicise her current appearance at the Arts Theatre in London in Joe Orton's Entertaining Mr Sloane. The male cast did the pose too Christine Keeler replicated the pose eight years ago with Terry O'Neill for a newspaper article to mark the thirtieth anniversary of the Profumo Scandal. webTitle: Paperback of the week: Belle de Jour

fields.headline: Paperback of the week
fields.trailText: A literary look at Buñuel's controversial masterpiece
fields.body:
Belle de Jour
Michael Wood
BFI Publishing £8.99, pp80
Buy it at a discount at BOL

The British Film Institute's handsomely designed Film Classic series was launched 10 years ago to provide accompanying monographs to a repertory of 360 movies to be shown on a year-round basis at the Museum of the Moving Image. They are written by critics and scholars, not all of them film specialists, and this study of Luis Buñuel's surreal masterpiece, the sixtieth in the series, is by a British literary academic who is currently professor of English and comparative studies at Princeton University.

Buñuel is the sixth director so far to be the subject of two BFI Film Classics (the previous ones are Bergman, Lang, Ford, Welles and Hawks). The earlier book was on his outrageous, long-banned avant-garde L'Age d'Or (1930); Wood's monograph concerns the equally controversial picture he made when he was 66, his hearing seriously impaired and his daily intake of alcohol phenomenal.

Buñuel had disappeared from Europe in the Thirties to emerge in Mexico in 1950 with Los Olvidados. A decade later, he returned to Europe to shake Franco's Spain with the subversive Viridiana (1961). Then, with Belle de Jour, he was accorded his first large budget, the services of a great colour cinematographer, Sacha Vierny, and the perfect screenwriter in Jean-Claude Carrière. He was to make another five films, four scripted by Carrière. These tough, mature, far from mellow pictures are among the great late flowerings of any artist of the last century.

The story of Belle de Jour is simple. A haute-bourgeoisie Parisian wife, Severine (Catherine Deneuve), takes an afternoon job in a smart brothel in search of a cure for her frigidity. The narrative treatment, however, unlike Joseph Kessel's 1928 novel on which it's based, dovetails reality, fantasy and autobiographical flashbacks in a uniformly direct style.

'I myself couldn't say what is real and what is imaginary in the film,' Buñuel observed. 'For me, they form a single thing.' Wood doesn't try to provide answers, or guess what Severine's plump oriental client kept in that famous lacquered box. What he does is to clarify the social and aesthetic questions this film raises. He vividly describes Buñuel's style as 'a way of flinging a world at us, like litter, rather than laying it out like a lawn'. The best comment, as always, is by the old surrealist himself: 'Belle de Jour is a pornographic film; by that, I mean chaste eroticism.'

fields.headline: Paperbacks
fields.trailText: Robert Henig produces an odd hybrid of fact and fiction in his account of the life of Gregor Mendel, plus Preston Falls, Grits, The Night of the Hunter, Observatory Mansions
fields.body:
A Monk and Two Peas
Robert Marantz Henig
Phoenix £7.99, pp278
Buy it at a discount at BOL

American author Robert Henig works with scant material to recount the life and influence of Gregor Mendel, a solitary nineteenth-century Catholic monk who meticulously recorded and analysed generations of peas, finally giving scientific grounding to theories of inheritance. The book does little to address whether Mendel was alone in his discoveries or aware of their implications. Henig uses the space provided by the vast gaps in Mendel's life as an opportunity to get down to some florid and self-confessed 'indulgent' fiction, leaving you wondering about the intentions behind his chosen subject.

Taking the idea of popular science to almost patronising extremes, Henig often lapses into pleasing descriptions best suited to a Newsround report. But the pace of the book does provoke relaxing reflection on the distinction between genius and the obsessive determination. Mendel, it seems, was the latter - a plodder.

Preston Falls
David Gates
Phoenix £6.99, pp340
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Doug Willis is sure that he is a badass, but is held back by an uninspiring PR job, wife and two kids. This domestic cliché is amplified when, feeling his 'life ticking away', Doug takes two months to indulge his bohemian destiny in the family holiday home. A spell hangin' with the locals in a self-conscious mist of prison, drugs and rock 'n' roll leaves him satisfied with his imposed solitude, but in a motel, just around the corner form his suburban home.

It is tempting to compare Preston Falls to a sexless American Beauty, but Gates's novel is a distinctive and complex scrutiny of midlife frustration. He skilfully deposits us inside Doug's head which is an infuriating location full of half-chewed philosophical tangles. Then his wife's more practical thought-processes play host, fuelled by kids and Advil, but a relief from Doug's inspiration: cocaine, Bunyan and Public Enemy.

The clipped stream-of-consciousness reveals that a jumble of motivations lie behind human action and interaction, and underlines the disturbing ability of thoughts to clog emotion.

Grits
Niall Griffiths
Vintage £6.99, pp482
Buy it at a discount at BOL

A book about drugs and aimless youths written in the vernacular - sound familiar? Niall Griffiths's debut novel will never escape being 'the new Trainspotting'. A common fate, but this time reinforced by Irvine Welsh who describes Griffiths as 'a magnificently good writer'. Doing the dialects of nine rough-edged twentysomethings drawn from all over the country and stuck in shared flats in Aberystwyth, in a drugged dislocation, Grits convincingly relates a series of narrativeless, angry and insular lives. Though only the sediments of a plot can be found, this angry fable is firmly grounded by its clear polemical message. But after almost 500 pages of monologues from each of the nine characters, Grits becomes exhilarating to the point of exhaustion.

The Night of the Hunter
Simon Callow
BFI Publishing £8.99, pp80
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Books written by celebrities can grate - particularly those composed by serious and exuberant actors - but Simon Callow writes with ease and insight on actor Charles Laughton's The Night of the Hunter, a horrific fairytale turning Robert Mitchum into a corrupt priest pursuing two children's money and innocence. Laughton's directorial debut turned out to be his first and last expressionist masterpiece. Callow presents Laughton and his crew as inspired innocents. The making of The Night of the Hunter was an unusually harmonious affair and Laughton 'created a mood of democratic commitment which is apparent in every frame of the film'. Callow has written a biography of Laughton and his affection and admiration for him is more than apparent here on every page. Amusing anecdotes squeeze out social context and in-depth analysis, but at least now, safely canonised in this BFI classic, this astonishing film will abide.

Observatory Mansions
Edward Carey
Picador £9.99, pp356
Buy it at a discount at BOL

Carey's first novel is a darkly humorous reflection on loneliness, memory and obsession. A group of misanthropists and misfits encase themselves in Observatory Mansions, secure from the outside world until the unwelcome arrival of Anna Tap. Anna manages to communicate with Peter Bugg who continually cries over his past; she strokes Twenty who believes that she's a dog; and listens to the lovesick TV addict Claire Higg. All are seduced from their isolation except Francis Orme, who is committed to being still, alone and separate. Francis works as a bubble-blowing living statue. Ghosts of Mervyn Peake and Beckett are evident in Observatory Mansions, but Carey's unique surreal style and looping sentences expertly enclose the reader in his characters' unravelling thoughts.

webTitle: The Book I'd Give: The Drama of Being a Child

fields.headline: The Book I'd Give
fields.trailText: Read The Drama of Being a Child and save the world from your own home
fields.body:
The Drama of Being a Child
Alice Miller
Virago £7.99, pp174
Buy it at a discount at BOL

If I could sit the whole world down and force them to read one book, it would be Alice Miller's The Drama of Being a Child, because it explains how all our feelings of unworthiness and the behavioural dysfunction that arises as a result has its roots in our conventions of child-rearing. Unwittingly, many parents use their children to meet their own unacknowledged needs and, as a result, the children become estranged from their real selves.

She describes how we grow up to be unbalanced and unfulfilled, our moods swinging from depression to grandiosity. Sounds familiar. Read this book and save the world from your own home.

webTitle: Observer review: The Strength of Poetry by James Fenton

fields.headline: Hurrah for Auden and other weaklings
fields.standfirst: James Fenton argues that the poet gains power from his own weakness in this collection of lectures, The Strength of Poetry
fields.trailText: James Fenton argues that the poet gains power from his own weakness in this collection of lectures, The Strength of Poetry
fields.body:
The Strength of Poetry
James Fenton
Oxford University Press £15.99, pp288

I have a dim memory of travelling from Oxford to London with James Fenton one afternoon during the Falklands campaign. He looked more than usually morose. During the journey, he gripped or tenderly patted various parts of himself that seemed to be in pain. I asked what ailed him: his head, his teeth, his gut? 'It's this war,' he replied and emitted a muffled groan as we passed High Wycombe.

The poetic vocation, in his view, entails such miseries and imaginary dyspepsias. As his hero Auden put it, the writer must volunteer to suffer all the wrongs of man. Thatcher's bellicose escapade had made Fenton feel physically ill.

The strength of poetry, in these lectures delivered during Fenton's tenure as professor of poetry at Oxford between 1995 and 1999, turns out to depend on the poet's personal weaknesses, his liability to feel the woes of others or to translate a war into an intimate ache.

Isherwood argued that the symptomatic modern hero was the Truly Weak Man, whose epic achievements were not the reflex of valour but an attempt to compensate for feebleness and effeminacy. The example he always cited was T. E. Lawrence; it is not surprising to find that Fenton, in a superbly embattled lecture on imperialism in poetry, transcribes a quotation from Lawrence of Arabia, which he saw pinned on the wall of the US embassy in Saigon at the end of the Vietnam War. The text advised the resident spooks and soldiers to behave like weaklings and desert their posts.

Artists who imagine themselves to be strong arouse Fenton's suspicion. He begins with the story of Michelangelo crushing a sculpture brought to him by Giambologna, a feat of muscular bravado which exposed a secret fragility, since Michelangelo was destroying a potential rival. He finds the same violent egomania in Wordsworth's dismissal of Keats, and even explains the morbidity and pessimism of Larkin in military terms, as 'a critical scorched-earth policy'. Larkin declared the twentieth century to be null and void so as to ensure that no poets needed to be read after Hardy 'or none until you reach you know who'.

Fenton, by contrast, admires weakness. He remarks on Wilfred Owen's 'desperate vulnerability to male beauty' and explains Auden's embarrassed reference to Wilde's 'The Portrait of Mr W. H. Auden', a fantasia about Shakespeare's erotic infatuation with the young man to whom he addressed the sonnets, by admitting that we always wince in later life when we revisit the books 'which meant most to us in our vulnerable youth'. (Incidentally, this sympathy with juvenile rawness must have endeared Fenton to his undergraduate audience and he is good throughout on the callow or bumptious antics of adolescent poets: Elizabeth Bishop at Vassar attending a recital by Edna St Vincent Millay and doubling up with hilarity at the old girl's prophetic posturing, or Sylvia Plath at Smith prissily censuring her fellow students when they altered the dress code in summer and exchanged Bermuda shorts for tattered jeans.)

The Truly Weak Man, in Isherwood's psychiatric theory, hurls himself into combat self-destructively. War won't prove his strength; rather, it will confirm his weakness and conveniently expunge him. Fenton, whose books of poetry include The Memory of War, is in the odd position of being a non-combatant war poet. On the home front, he has had to make do with literary skirmishes, in which the participants wield imaginary guns with real bullets in them. Thus, recalling the way Al Alvarez denigrated Seamus Heaney in 1980 by mobilising the authority of T. S. Eliot, Fenton remarks: 'This is the cannon, and shares its determination to kill.'

Nevertheless, polemical fury is no substitute for courage under fire. In these lectures, Fenton seems to be wondering out loud about whether he has missed a blooding which might have been an essential rite of passage for a poet or, perhaps, simply for a man. He muses on the case of Hemingway, whose near-crippling injuries incurred as an ambulance driver during the First World War, 'did not settle the question of his manhood'.

But the forebear to whom he most insistently returns is Auden, who was never forgiven, or who maybe never forgave himself, for chickening out of a war. In 1939, he left for America, while the accusations of betrayal were still current in 1957 when, as Fenton reports with evident commiseration, 'he was terrified of giving his inaugural lecture as professor of poetry at Oxford'.

Fenton's own last and best lecture considers Auden's plight and venerates him as a weak man, a specialist in unrequited love, who consoled himself for his private griefs by reasoning that 'art is born of humiliation', and a strong poet. The peroration, recalling a sermon in the form of graduation address delivered by Auden at Smith College in 1940, is startlingly eloquent. The lectern resembles a pulpit as, in biblical phraseology, Fenton chides England and especially Oxford for its rejection of Auden: 'It was given him to know this, and to doubt it, to know and to doubt it.' What Auden knew and doubted was his own poetic gift, described by Fenton (in a quote from Blake) as his 'lap full of seed'. The homosexual poet's seeds inseminate no one; the deracinated Auden considered himself homeless, and when he bought a house in the Vienna woods he called it a habitat, not a home.

The book ends by accusing 'this lean country' in Auden's name. But since giving his last lecture, Fenton has concentrated on rewriting the sad end of Auden's life. His own map of seed won't be squandered, even if he writes no more poems: he has racinated himself in the countryside outside Oxford and you can read his gardening column every Saturday in the Guardian.

(Incidentally, this sympathy with juvenile rawness must have endeared Fenton to his undergraduate audience and he is good throughout on the callow or bumptious antics of adolescent poets: Elizabeth Bishop at Vassar attending a recital by Edna St Vincent Millay and doubling up with hilarity at the old girl's prophetic posturing, or Sylvia Plath at Smith prissily censuring her fellow students when they altered the dress code in summer and exchanged Bermuda shorts for tattered jeans.) The Truly Weak Man, in Isherwood's psychiatric theory, hurls himself into combat self-destructively. War won't prove his strength; rather, it will confirm his weakness and conveniently expunge him. Fenton, whose books of poetry include The Memory of War, is in the odd position of being a non-combatant war poet. On the home front, he has had to make do with literary skirmishes, in which the participants wield imaginary guns with real bullets in them. Thus, recalling the way Al Alvarez denigrated Seamus Heaney in 1980 by mobilising the authority of T. S. Eliot, Fenton remarks: 'This is the cannon, and shares its determination to kill.' Nevertheless, polemical fury is no substitute for courage under fire. In these lectures, Fenton seems to be wondering out loud about whether he has missed a blooding which might have been an essential rite of passage for a poet or, perhaps, simply for a man. He muses on the case of Hemingway, whose near-crippling injuries incurred as an ambulance driver during the First World War, 'did not settle the question of his manhood'. But the forebear to whom he most insistently returns is Auden, who was never forgiven, or who maybe never forgave himself, for chickening out of a war. In 1939, he left for America, while the accusations of betrayal were still current in 1957 when, as Fenton reports with evident commiseration, 'he was terrified of giving his inaugural lecture as professor of poetry at Oxford'. Fenton's own last and best lecture considers Auden's plight and venerates him as a weak man, a specialist in unrequited love, who consoled himself for his private griefs by reasoning that 'art is born of humiliation', and a strong poet. The peroration, recalling a sermon in the form of graduation address delivered by Auden at Smith College in 1940, is startlingly eloquent. The lectern resembles a pulpit as, in biblical phraseology, Fenton chides England and especially Oxford for its rejection of Auden: 'It was given him to know this, and to doubt it, to know and to doubt it.' What Auden knew and doubted was his own poetic gift, described by Fenton (in a quote from Blake) as his 'lap full of seed'. The homosexual poet's seeds inseminate no one; the deracinated Auden considered himself homeless, and when he bought a house in the Vienna woods he called it a habitat, not a home. The book ends by accusing 'this lean country' in Auden's name. But since giving his last lecture, Fenton has concentrated on rewriting the sad end of Auden's life. His own map of seed won't be squandered, even if he writes no more poems: he has racinated himself in the countryside outside Oxford and you can read his gardening column every Saturday in the Guardian.

fields.headline: It's better to travel hopelessly
fields.standfirst: Tim Moore's reputation as our funniest travel writer will be confirmed by his new book on the Grand Tour
fields.trailText: Tim Moore's reputation as our funniest travel writer will be confirmed by his new book on the Grand Tour
fields.body:
There was once a time when travel writing was straightforward. The would-be writer had only to find his way to a remote destination, climb a mountain, have one or two intimidating encounters with wildlife, perhaps discover a lost tribe and, above all, evince pluck, boldness and stolid English humour in the face of chilblains or bears eating his tent.

But, gradually, the world grew smaller, everyone and his brother had already visited the earth's remote corners on package tours and travel writers found that the ante had to be upped considerably. For example, if you wanted to climb Mount Kilimanjaro, you would have to do it in your underwear with a penguin strapped to your back as the result of a pub bet or at least attempt to recreate the journey of a long-dead adventurer with a contemporary comic slant.

'As soon as I hear the words "travelling in the footsteps of" come out of my mouth, I think, "Oh God, that sounds so trite",' says Tim Moore, author of Frost on My Moustache and now Continental Drifter, who favours the latter approach.

'The temptation is for writers to go to more and more obscure places or to well-known places in more obscure ways, but I think people like to read about places they're familiar with and know a bit about.'

Moore doesn't look like an adventurer; in fact, he looks as if he should play bass in a hopeful indy band. This is partly the point. 'The good thing about this kind of self-deprecating humour is that you can get away with highlighting how pathetic you are. You can say, "Then I got really homesick and gave up", whereas if you're more hairy-chested you can't.'

Frost on My Moustache used this contrast to great effect. Moore, whose wife is Icelandic, followed the Icelandic voyage of Lord Dufferin, an indisputably hirsute nineteenth-century explorer, pitting his own feebleness against Dufferin's daring. In Continental Drifter, he uses the same device to follow the route of the Grand Tour, which, in his own description, began as a mobile academy of cultural betterment for the flower of English aristocratic youth and deteriorated rapidly into 'the Club 18-30 of the 1830s'.

'The Grand Tour struck me as a good idea because when you see the average travelling Briton in Europe these days they're so ludicrous. It's astonishing to think that this is the legacy of Lord Byron going around Venice. I thought that if this is what British continental travel has come to, I wanted to find where it first started.'

After some research, he turned up Thomas Coryate, author of the little-known Coryate's Crudities, which might properly be called the first English travelogue, 'a sort of "Ruff Guide to Europe".' Coryate was a parson's son from Somerset, who undertook his journey through Europe in 1608 for the purpose of garnering anecdotes, the better to impress the Prince of Wales. Moore decided to capitalise on Coryate's delusions of grandeur by undertaking his journey in a cantankerous Rolls-Royce Silver Shadow while wearing a velvet suit.

'You get into these situations when you're driving an enormous, unreliable Rolls-Royce on your own. People will think they can take advantage of you; these Basil Fawlty-style hoteliers will pick on you because they can,' he says, which may partially explain his often less than flattering observations of our European neighbours. 'I read a lot of Evelyn Waugh,' he confesses. 'I liked his style of travel writing, kind of rude and scathing. Which is unfortunate, but there we are, I'm stuck with it.'

Moore began writing for Record Mirror after leaving university, but the travelling seems to have been a legacy from his grandfather. 'He was a great traveller - he drove to India in a Land Rover when he was 74 - and when he died he left all his grandchildren three grand each, with the proviso that they used it for travel. I set off in a clapped-out Saab round eastern Europe and wrote a kind of potted account of that; everyone rejected it except the Independent. I was approached to write a book, but I'm so lazy it took me four years to come up with the proposal.'

On the evidence, though, sloth is not a sin you would immediately accuse him of. Apart from this Grand Tour through France, Italy, Switzerland, Germany and Holland, he has also completed a third book, to be published in June, in which he follows the route of the Tour de France ('What's the gimmick there?' I ask. He looks outraged. 'The gimmick is me cycling 3,000 f***ing kilometres; how much more of a gimmick do you want? I've cycled the second highest road in Europe!') and is planning a jaunt through the length of the Roman Empire - 'It would mean going from Libya to Hadrian's Wall, which I thought would be an interesting idea. Now everyone will nick it.'

Despite his family legacy and his secure place as the British heir to Bill Bryson's comic travel mantle, he has a dark secret. 'I've got this enormous phobia about insects. It's a shame because all the places that I could go to write about are places that I would pay a lot of money not to have to go to, because they're full of things I wouldn't want to encounter.' (I can confirm this: he refused to have his photograph taken until the photographer removed a spider from the pub doorway. Unfortunately, it landed on his foot.) 'A friend has booked me in for hypnotherapy because I need to get over it. There are only so many books you can do travelling in Europe. That was one of the nice things about Iceland.'

There is also a limit to the number of genuinely funny anecdotes you can obtain in a two-month trip, and one of the difficulties of this kind of travel writing is the obligation to keep the humour at full throttle throughout, so that at times the book labours under a weight of irrelevant reminiscences about his schooldays or family.

But there are some splendid moments; his search for cannabis in a small Dutch town ('I managed to find the one person in Holland who didn't speak English, and I had to stand in a dark street bellowing, "I want to buy drugs!" through an intercom') and his near-fatal attempt to pilot a boat in Venice: 'I still have nightmares about it, it was really scary. I forced myself because I felt that Coryate was such a nutcase; he did all kinds of things that he shouldn't have done, and I thought I ought to try instead of taking the easy option and staying in hotels. But it was terrible. They have one-way canals and the gondoliers kept hitting me with their poles and yelling at me to get out of the way. Then the motor cut out.' He shudders. 'I can't even think about it now.'

But for all its digressions, Continental Drifter is vivid, if a little caustic, in its observations of Europe and has a stamp of authenticity, which Moore attributes to 'a stunted imagination'. 'I'd love to write fiction, but I'm not good enough. I'm not able to think of things unless I've seen them with my own eyes, which is my stock answer to anyone who claims that a lot of travel writing is fictionalised.' So he has no plans to put any of his strange acquaintances into a novel? 'If only I could.'

 Tim Moore's first book, Frost on My Moustache: The Arctic Exploits of a Lord and a Loafer, was published to great acclaim in 1999. For his new book, Continental Drifter (Abacus £10.99) he forsakes Iceland for Europe

webTitle: Killed in Crossfire by Tom Paulin

fields.headline: Killed in Crossfire
fields.trailText:
We're fed this inert

this lying phrase

like comfort food...
fields.body:
To me the Zionists, who want to go back to the Jewish state of 70 AD (destruction of Jerusalem by Titus), are just as offensive as the Nazis. With their nosing after blood, their ancient 'cultural roots', their partly canting, partly obtuse winding back of the world, they are altogether a match for the National Socialists. - Victor Klemperer, 13 June 1934

We're fed this inert

this lying phrase

like comfort food

as another little Palestinian boy

in trainers jeans and a white teeshirt

is gunned down by the Zionist SS

whose initials we should

- but we don't - dumb goys -

clock in that weasel word crossfire

fields.headline: Death of the Editor
fields.trailText: Publishing is going through one of its periodic fits of musical chairs.
fields.body:
Publishing is going through one of its periodic fits of musical chairs. Open the Bookseller and you might be forgiven for thinking that the managing directors of British publishing houses have the career prospects of Battle of Britain pilots: Weidenfeld, Faber, Little, Brown, Holtzbrinck - wherever you look, there's a changing of the guard.

In Britain, where the book trade is innately conservative, this flurry of sudden change will be experienced by many within the industry as a sign of crisis. You don't have to listen very closely to hear a swarm of clichés buzzing through the conversation of partygoing publishing executives: 'decline of standards... profits before quality... tyranny of the bottom-line... mass-market pressures...' Quite soon, you find that this spirited rendering of 'Fings Ain't What They Used To Be' resolves into an unaccompanied threnody for the Death of the Editor.

It's certainly true that, compared to a generation ago, there are fewer editors at work within the successful imprints of the day, while those who do continue to ply their trade have a correspondingly diminished influence over the counsels of their boards. Two decades of synergy (dread concept) have reduced the fine flower of Anglo-American editorial talent to an arid window-box teetering on the edge of oblivion. Or, to put it another way, a generation of now middle-aged executives has been cruelly exposed to commercial pressure and found wanting.

No one (certainly not I) disputes the crucial importance to the health of British and American publishing of the editorial contribution. Quite simply, the editor is the propeller, the compass and the rudder of the whole enterprise. Over the years, various people have tried to marginalise editors; to a greater or lesser degree, they have all come unstuck.

Yet when I consider the editors now in business, I do not find myself suffused with a longing for the good old days. To my mind, there is no question that the editorial talents at work today are the equal of their recently redundant predecessors. True, they are not so colourful. They don't, for example, consume oceans of wine at lunch, nor do they dress like out-of-work actors or bring dogs or parrots to work. No doubt, compared to the previous generation, they are a trifle dull. They wear suits; they return phone calls; they write letters; they keep office hours; they have wives and children; they are balanced, thoughtful, conscientious, enthusiastic and hard-working.

Yes, under pressure from a system gone mad, they produce far too many books, approximately 110,000 per annum. A lot of these are pretty bad (this was always the case), but many are excellent. For every book littered with typos, split infinitives and hanging participles, there will be the slim volume that's beautifully produced, edited and printed, a delight to read and to hold. If this is the result of the Death of the Editor, then roll out the tumbrils.

And yet the people who drone on about the end of civilisation as they know it are half right.There has been a serious evolutionary change in the ecosystem of the book trade, but not at the editorial level. You have to look further up the food chain.

A generation ago, in London and New York, there was a cadre of men and women who could not only read and evaluate an unpublished typescript, but who would also know how to present this new book to a cynical and hard-to-please book trade to maximum advantage. These publishers, of whom Morgan Entrekin, of Grove Atlantic, and Roger Straus Sr, of Farrar Straus & Giroux, are probably the supreme living examples, were an exquisite mixture of aesthete and mafioso, people of the most refined sensibilities who would, at the same time, take no hostages in the cut-and-thrust of book business. The nearest we've had to such figures in this country are Carmen Callil, the co-founder of Virago, and Christopher MacLehose, the publisher of Harvill.

They don't make them like that any more. And for one very good reason. Two decades of merger and takeover, coupled with a dizzying tempo of technological change, have made publishing houses so massive and complex that they are now beyond the competence of one individual to manage. Historically, talented editors got promoted into management, then learnt through a gruelling process of trial and error how to read a balance sheet and to manage an inventory. Many of them did not survive. A few exceptional ones came through. They had names like Victor Gollancz, Jonathan Cape and Allen Lane.

Today, in a much less forgiving and far more costly business environment, there is no longer room for such experimentation, as the recent career obituaries in the trade press have vividly illustrated.

webTitle: Observer review: The Same Sea by Amos Oz

fields.headline: A voice crying in the wilderness
fields.standfirst: Amos Oz's allegory of the Middle East crisis, The Same Sea, is a classic of quiet eloquence
fields.trailText: Amos Oz's allegory of the Middle East crisis, The Same Sea, is a classic of quiet eloquence
fields.body:
The Same Sea
Amos Oz
Chatto & Windus £15.99, pp201
Buy it at a discount at BOL

When Amos Oz recently contemplated the one-step-forward-three-steps-back prospects for Arab-Israeli peace he noted, drily, that perhaps Yasser Arafat might find in Ariel Sharon what he had not found in his predecessors, Rabin, Peres or Barak: a twin soul. 'A fanatic nationalist to face a fanatic nationalist, a blood-shedder confronting a blood-shedder, yesterday's man confronting yesterday's man. It might just,' he suggested, echoing the Catch 22 ironies of Yossarian, 'be love at first sight.'

For a writer who has been so involved in his nation's struggles, so critical of the wrong turnings on the road to a settlement, and so humanely hopeful of a solution, it must be difficult for Oz to keep his sense of sanity at the present time. In this respect, you might say that The Same Sea is the most timely of books to come out of Israel. Not because it addresses the issues of conflict, but rather, as Oz suggests at one point here, because it steadfastly does not: 'At times like these, quiet is the most precious commodity in the country,' his narrator observes. 'And let there be no misunderstanding, I'm talking about quiet, definitely not about silence.'

In a wonderful, lucid, poetic account of intersecting lives, this sense of quiet sometimes seems almost environmental. It is tempting to think that it is. For the past 15 years, Oz has lived as a resettler on the outskirts of the desert city of Arad in ancient Judea, and his writing seems to have taken on some of the qualities of the rarefied air and desiccated terrain around him.

This book is written in lapidary stanzas, each layered with adamantine shards of imagery that suddenly catch the light. It is a love story of sorts, involving a father and son, entranced, in different ways, by the same two women, one living and one dead. At certain points in their unfolding sequence of limpid, dramatic monologues, Oz, as narrator, steps in to question or explain his motivation in telling the story.

One of these interventions describes the interior landscape from which this tale seems composed: 'as for the Narrator, on these late September days he gets up each morning/
before five and writes for an hour or so until the paper arrives. Then/
he goes outside to check if there is anything new in the desert. To date/
there is nothing...'

What he finds himself writing in those hours before the news comes, with it familiar stories of war and intransigence, is of the intersecting triangles of love (an intimate Star of David) that form between Albert Danon, a reticent and recently widowed tax accountant, and his son, Rico, who 'thought the world/ was in a bad way' and is mountaineering in Tibet.

Both men are haunted by the ghost of Nadia, wife to Albert and mother to Rico. They both seek solace in Dita, Rico's girlfriend, a filmmaker who, in her boyfriend's absence, comes to share a home with his father. Detailing their desires and fears in his elegant (and expertly translated) poetry, Oz achieves something that feels almost mythic.

In descrbing how he would like to write, as he nears his sixtieth year, the author, or his narrator, suggests at one point that he aspires to the condition of 'an old Greek, who calls up the dead and shakes up the living'; the ambition is not a vain one. Writing in verse returns the author, he suggests, to 'the bad old days of his youth when he used to run away at night to be all alone in the reading-room of the kibbutz where he would cover page after page with jackals' howls'.

The writing here is anything but a howl; it is both wise and affecting, moving by turns from the youthful ideals of the backpacking son to the mature hopes of his father. Nadia, one aspect of their shared muse, fusses equally over both. Lying in his sleeping-bag on the chill mountainside, drinking fresh goat's milk for breakfast, the master of all he surveys, Rico feels the presence of his mother's spirit clucking round him:

'She's worried. She's found/
a hole in the elbow of my sweater, the soles of my boots/
are worn thin, and what's that cut on my cheek? She lays/

fields.bodyText: The Same Sea Amos Oz Chatto & Windus £15.99, pp201 Buy it at a discount at BOL When Amos Oz recently contemplated the one-step-forward-three-steps-back prospects for Arab-Israeli peace he noted, drily, that perhaps Yasser Arafat might find in Ariel Sharon what he had not found in his predecessors, Rabin, Peres or Barak: a twin soul. 'A fanatic nationalist to face a fanatic nationalist, a blood-shedder confronting a blood-shedder, yesterday's man confronting yesterday's man. It might just,' he suggested, echoing the Catch 22 ironies of Yossarian, 'be love at first sight.' For a writer who has been so involved in his nation's struggles, so critical of the wrong turnings on the road to a settlement, and so humanely hopeful of a solution, it must be difficult for Oz to keep his sense of sanity at the present time. In this respect, you might say that The Same Sea is the most timely of books to come out of Israel. Not because it addresses the issues of conflict, but rather, as Oz suggests at one point here, because it steadfastly does not: 'At times like these, quiet is the most precious commodity in the country,' his narrator observes. 'And let there be no misunderstanding, I'm talking about quiet, definitely not about silence.' In a wonderful, lucid, poetic account of intersecting lives, this sense of quiet sometimes seems almost environmental. It is tempting to think that it is. For the past 15 years, Oz has lived as a resettler on the outskirts of the desert city of Arad in ancient Judea, and his writing seems to have taken on some of the qualities of the rarefied air and desiccated terrain around him. This book is written in lapidary stanzas, each layered with adamantine shards of imagery that suddenly catch the light. It is a love story of sorts, involving a father and son, entranced, in different ways, by the same two women, one living and one dead. At certain points in their unfolding sequence of limpid, dramatic monologues, Oz, as narrator, steps in to question or explain his motivation in telling the story. One of these interventions describes the interior landscape from which this tale seems composed: 'as for the Narrator, on these late September days he gets up each morning/ before five and writes for an hour or so until the paper arrives. Then/ he goes outside to check if there is anything new in the desert. To date/ there is nothing...' What he finds himself writing in those hours before the news comes, with it familiar stories of war and intransigence, is of the intersecting triangles of love (an intimate Star of David) that form between Albert Danon, a reticent and recently widowed tax accountant, and his son, Rico, who 'thought the world/ was in a bad way' and is mountaineering in Tibet. Both men are haunted by the ghost of Nadia, wife to Albert and mother to Rico. They both seek solace in Dita, Rico's girlfriend, a filmmaker who, in her boyfriend's absence, comes to share a home with his father. Detailing their desires and fears in his elegant (and expertly translated) poetry, Oz achieves something that feels almost mythic. In descrbing how he would like to write, as he nears his sixtieth year, the author, or his narrator, suggests at one point that he aspires to the condition of 'an old Greek, who calls up the dead and shakes up the living'; the ambition is not a vain one. Writing in verse returns the author, he suggests, to 'the bad old days of his youth when he used to run away at night to be all alone in the reading-room of the kibbutz where he would cover page after page with jackals' howls'. The writing here is anything but a howl; it is both wise and affecting, moving by turns from the youthful ideals of the backpacking son to the mature hopes of his father. Nadia, one aspect of their shared muse, fusses equally over both. Lying in his sleeping-bag on the chill mountainside, drinking fresh goat's milk for breakfast, the master of all he surveys, Rico feels the presence of his mother's spirit clucking round him: 'She's worried. She's found/ a hole in the elbow of my sweater, the soles of my boots/ are worn thin, and what's that cut on my cheek? She lays/ a cold hand on my forehead/ and another on her own, compares, naturally I'm warmer./ She doesn't trust me...' In the pace of Oz's voice, in his control of the minute silences of line endings, he hints at hopes unfulfilled, truths half realised and compromises made, the stuff of real life. This is a political book only in the very broadest sense, but all the more profound for that. At its heart is the idea that 'only what is truly/ a matter of life and death should not be negotiable...' It is an article of faith that this writer understands more fully than most.

fields.headline: Underpants and overwhelmed
fields.standfirst: I don't always get the joke, but does that mean I should be fired as the family's book-chooser?
fields.trailText: I don't always get the joke, but does that mean I should be fired as the family's book-chooser?
fields.body:
It is easy to become a dictator about picture books: I like to make my children's choices for them. If I am enthusiastic, this will usually be catching. It has always seemed fair to be in charge. It is, after all, grown-ups that have to read the books over and over again. When you ask young children whether they like a book, they almost always say 'Yes', but can seldom tell you why. It has suited me to conclude that young children are undiscriminating and to ignore any evidence to the contrary.

But recently I have been confounded by my son Ted, who - at two - has made it clear that he not only has strong preferences but will overrule my choices, often throwing the book that I am offering him to the ground and thrusting his own choice on to my lap in its place. It is he - this flamboyant critic - who has led me, reluctantly, to concede that I may have been wrong for a long time. I have even started to observe that the other children also often smuggle unwelcome books on to my knee. They have opinions of their own. So this is a piece about my children's favourite books. Their choices sometimes coincide with mine. But not always. Some have forced their way in against my better judgment.

Family choice (at least we agree about this one)

Every now and then a picture book comes along which instantly roots itself in our lives. If it gets lost, it is a mini-disaster. Right now, The Terrible Underpants by Kaz Cooke (Viking £9.99) is that book. Cooke is an Australian cartoonist and the book should, ideally, be read aloud in a thick, laconic Australian accent.

Meet a girl called Wanda Linda and Glenda, a hairy-nosed wombat. Wanda Linda has parents who cannot control the laundry and, in particular, the underwear situation. Result: Wanda Linda has to wear a hyperbolically dreadful pair of underpants. We are not spared any details: the grey, drooping backview, the defective elastic, the torn front complete with cordial stain.

We all love the crazily overblown plot in which the minor humiliation of wearing the pants becomes an international affair when somebody in a helicopter takes a picture of Wanda in them and puts it on TV: 'And EVERYBODY in the WHOLE WORLD saw The Terrible Underpants.' It also works beautifully as drama. I play Wanda. My oldest son Leo (nine) plays Glenda the traumatised wombat. (He finds it hysterically funny.) All ends happily with what might become an Australian dejeuner sur l'herbe. Wanda takes the disgraceful pants off and (still decent) sits down to enjoy a cuppa. The weird thing is that, unlike the terrible underpants, this great book never seems to wear thin.

Os's choice (age four and a half)

Some Things are Scary by Florence Parry Heide, illustrated by Jules Feiffer (Walker £9.99) This book troubles me. Why introduce into children's heads the idea that things are scary? They find so much frightening without throwing new ingredients into the already murky pot.

This book is a list of scary ideas that ends with a picture of a child swamped in a grown-up's clothes: an overwhelming overcoat, heavy briefcase, shirt and tie. The child's face is wan; its mouth is turned down. The text reads: 'Knowing you're going to grow up to be a grown-up is scary.' Os loves it. He goes through it with his twin agreeing or disagreeing with each proposition. Long after we have finished reading, he will sit leafing through it and brooding. And he is not fazed by the last picture at all. On the contrary, he explained to me: everyone grows up so there is no use being scared.

Ted's choice (age two)

I am devoted to Shirley Hughes books but not - how could I be? - as devoted as Ted. He will not read anything that has not been written and illustrated by Shirley Hughes. He will go through piles of books and select her unmistakable style every time.

Perhaps she reflects the way he would like his life to be? She paints a picture of ideal, middle-class family life: mothers who are calm, kind and industrious, wiping away tears, baking cakes, presiding over playtime. And Ted identifies with Hughes's portrayal of busy people like himself. (His favourites include: Playing; Being Together; Helping; Keeping Busy (Walker each at £2.99); Bathwater's Hot; (Walker £4.99) Noisy (Walker £4.99) Colours (Walker £4.99).

For similarly besotted children, The Shirley Hughes Collection (Bodley Head, £19.99) is a good way to kill several birds with one stone. And there is a new Alfie book Alfie Weather (Bodley Head £9.99) to look forward to coming out in March - Alfie, amazingly, is 20 this year.

There is one non-fictional exception to the Hughes monopoly: a Dorling Kindersley book Kitty's Adventure (part of a series that includes a fire engine, a car and a puppy). It is easy to underrate the Dorling Kindersley style, if only because most of its books depend on the same formula. But the formula is brilliant and it works: children love the literal quality of the photographs - the absence of imagination or fudging. And this book is a lovely example of the genre with a large but charming marmalade kitten pursuing a shocking pink feather. It is produced in firm, toddler-proof cardboard with a blue button that will let out a most authentic meow. I find it lacking in narrative interest, but it has been fantastically popular. There has been fighting over this book so that when it is not being read, it now lives on a high shelf.

Bernie's choice (age four and a half)

Rattletrap Car by Phyllis Root illustrated by Jill Barton (Viking £9.99). I fancy we are back in Australia in this jolly book. It is about trying to get a derelict car to a lake on a boiling summer's day. Every time the car breaks down, which is very often, a new and fanciful remedy is found: regular use is made of chocolate marshmallow fudge delight. It appeals to the car mechanic in Bernie. He loves examining the car and trying to work out exactly what is wrong with it (though one can only pray he will never apply its lessons).

Os, Bernie and Ted

Sometimes it is necessary to make a picture book so simple it is almost non-existent. Jez Alborough's Hug ( Walker £9.99) is not a book I like. It is too simple, sentimental and jauntily pleased with itself. On the cover, there is a cheeky monkey and the single word in chubby red letters HUG. The monkey is hoping for a hug from its absentee parents. It passes affectionate elephants and devoted hippos hugging each other enthusiastically. There is almost no text save the word 'hug'. The children clamour for second helpings. They seem to regard the little monkey with almost patronising understanding. And they adore the drama of the eventual mother and child reunion.

Bernie and Os

Beetle in the Bathroom by Brian Moses and Sonia Holleyman (Puffin £4.99) It has been decided (not by me) that this happily infested book must live in the bathroom with the plastic ducks and be read during bathtime. It is a bubbly read about assorted insects who use the bathroom as a kind of leisure centre. Ladybirds ski down the sides of the bath; ants skate in the basin. But the favourite line is this: 'A caterpillar was washing his hair with my shampoo. I don't think that's fair.' The children love shouting the last line at the top of their voices. I don't understand the joke. I can only report that it cracks them up.

fields.headline: Undersexed and the city
fields.trailText: 'Is 4 Blondes, Candace Bushnell's follow-up to Sex and the City, a literary Exhibit A in the case for how irredeemably ghastly women have become?'
fields.body:
Most of you will know New York writer Candace Bushnell from Sex and the City, the column that begat the book that begat the television series that begat the phenomenon. Maybe, like me, you rather like the sharp, witty series, and so bought her new book, 4 Blondes, in a three-for-the-price-of-two deal. Trouble is, after reading it, I'm not so sure I haven't been had.

Is 4 Blondes, as advertised, a collection of short stories revolving around the trials and tribulations of contemporary femininity in the urban jungle of the 21st century? Or, is it, as it reads, a literary Exhibit A in the case for how irredeemably ghastly women have become. Not women like me or you, you understand. Women like Candace. Professional 'blondes' like Candace. Misanthropic, flint hearted, Brazilian-waxed, hustling pieces of work like Candace. And, excuse my xenophobia (the bad breath of international relations), certain American women like Candace.

Because reading 4 Blondes, my recurring thought was: for all our sins, for all our problems, this couldn't happen here. British women don't hate themselves enough to buy the crude sketches of femininity offered up as 'characters' in 4 Blondes: a good-time girl signing up for sexual slavery in return for summer at the Hamptons; a wife who despises her husband for not being successful enough; a pill-popping trophy wife, and a revised version of an article Bushnell wrote for a British newspaper a few years ago about how lousy British men are in bed - how they all have tiny penises, never wash, and last approximately two minutes. As I said at the time: this is what you get when you do all your research within a square mile of Mayfair.

Pushing aside for one moment how tragic it is for Bushnell to deem it classy to call her book 4 Blondes (most blondes have realised by now that they're merely affordable glamour for men who can't afford Ferraris), isn't it a bit rich for an American woman to insult British men in this way, not least as Bushnell is currently hooked up with a Brit? During the war, American GIs were famously denounced as over-paid, over-sexed and over here. Now we seem to have been lumbered with a female American writer who is over-paid, under-sexed and over here. What price progress? At least the GIs dolled out nylons and chocolate. All we get from Bushnell is tacky, unnecessary remarks about our menfolk's penis size, which, frankly, Candace darling, is not the British way. For all that the likes of Fay Weldon are always wailing and whining about British women hating men, the fact is that we don't. It's all just sport.

While British women adore to slag off our men, we do it in such a way that we actually talk them up. When we call them immature commitment-phobic slobs, we do so safe in the knowledge that we're making the sorriest of wimps feel a bit 'dangerous'. In return, men rant about how British women are 'such ballbreakers!' even though everyone knows that scented candles are still outselling female knuckledusters a million to one. Like I said, it's just sport - fun, bloodless, all but victimless. Everyone gets their round in, and there's no tears by bedtime. Compare and contrast this playful inter-gender sparring to Bushnell's acid emasculation, all that scary, nasty stuff about 'very small willies', and you get some clue as to why she and her mates spent so many hours bitterly sipping Manhattans alone in East Village bars.

In my opinion, Bushnell's essay on British men has exposed her as a fraud. It reminds me of when I was enjoying PJ O'Rourke's collections of travelogues in war zones, Holidays in Hell, until I came to his appalling, trite essay on The Irish Troubles. It was only then that I realised that O'Rourke had probably been just as crap on, say, Cuba, only I'd been too thick and ill-informed to realise it. So it is with Bushnell. It is only when she writes so badly about British culture that you start to twig that she may not be the oracle on New York sexual mores we've been led to believe. Frankly, Bushnell could have claimed that New Yorkers like to have sex wearing Minnie Mouse ears, and Twinkies up their nostrils, and we wouldn't have known any better.

It also seems salient to note that, of all the Sex and the City spin-offs, the TV series has proved to be the most accomplished. So, that'll be the TV series that is not written by Bushnell. That'll be the hit TV series about heterosexual odysseys, adored by women worldwide, but written, one hears, by a talented team of homosexual male writers. All things considered, that little sociological factette seems to say more about the state of play on Planet Hetero 2001 than Candace Bushnell ever could.

webTitle: Observer review: Five Photos of My Wife by Agnès Desarthe

fields.headline: Pictures of Telma
fields.standfirst: Agnès Desarthe gives a rounded picture of old age in her perceptive study of grief and art, Five Photos of My Wife
fields.trailText: Agnès Desarthe gives a rounded picture of old age in her perceptive study of grief and art, Five Photos of My Wife
fields.body:
Five Photos of My Wife
Agnès Desarthe
translated by Adriana Hunter
Flamingo £9.99, pp165
Buy it at a discount at BOL

When Telma, Max Opass's 76-year-old wife, dies after a lengthy illness, Max senses her presence trailing him throughout his home. Contrary to popular sentimental beliefs, he does not find this particularly comforting. Indeed, 'the day that he broke her favourite cup when he was doing the washing up', writes Desarthe, 'he put his hands up to protect his head, like a child afraid of being smacked'. Fearful of some unimaginable punishment, Max decides to commission a portrait of his late wife. This is not only a tribute but a 'counter-attack' to the haunting: a portrait as peace offering, so to speak.

Five Photos of My Wife is Agnès Desarthe's English debut. One of France's bestselling authors, her third novel is a funny, unpredictable tale: just as it seems to be one thing, it turns into another, and a study of loss and grief becomes a gentle poke at art and its pretensions.

Max chooses at random five artists from the Parisian equivalent of the Yellow Pages, for each of whom he has selected the same five photographs of his wife in order for them to complete their task: to produce a straightforward, painterly rendition of Telma. This simple request, almost pathetic in its doomed hopefulness, is - like Max - at odds with the times.

'I am stealing your image. You agree to the theft, but the infraction is still there. It's all part of it,' lectures Fredéric, a young art student and one of those commissioned. As payment for painting Telma, Max has agreed to be videoed by Fredéric, sitting still and doing nothing. Bewildered and faintly irritated, none the less Max is no slouch: he recognises that the boy is 'a hippie [who has] silenced his own opinions to fall back on slogans'.

Desarthe is not so simplistic as to interpret extreme age as a constant state of passive naïvety. In Max, an 80-year-old man, she has created a constant source of surprise. Not only is he trying to make sense of his loss and his often bitter memories of Telma, but he is looking forward, evaluating this shocking new world, his future and his relationships with his adult children.

The novel is interspersed with Max's letters to his son and daughter, in which he is at his most vulnerable and at his funniest: 'I can't say that I've taught you everything that I know,' he writes to his son, 'because, in amongst it all, there were quite a lot of odds and ends that wouldn't have been any use to you.' And to his daughter: 'I've had a letter from your brother and I don't understand a word of it. He doesn't say hello or tell me how he is. If it weren't for the envelope I wouldn't have even understood that it was a letter.'

Desarthe is less opaque than her (equally successful) contemporary, Marie Darrieussecq, but she is as daring and imaginative a writer. Through Max Opass, she lets her lucid prose plunder dreams and question the meaning of existence. Most of all, with wit and fondness, she expresses the pity of old age.

Contrary to popular sentimental beliefs, he does not find this particularly comforting. Indeed, 'the day that he broke her favourite cup when he was doing the washing up', writes Desarthe, 'he put his hands up to protect his head, like a child afraid of being smacked'. fields.headline: Football confronts its Nazi past
fields.standfirst: Hitler turned matches into rallies and Jewish players were banned and then killed. Clubs are being told to examine their part, writes Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: Hitler turned matches into rallies and Jewish players were banned and then killed. Clubs are being told to examine their part, writes Kate Connolly.
fields.body:
They are some of the most famous names in world football. But now clubs such as Bayern Munich and Borussia Dortmund look set to achieve a new notoriety as a spotlight is cast over their relationship with Adolf Hitler's Nazi Party.

The German football federation, which for years has attempted to whitewash its close relationship with the Nazis, has finally bowed to intense pressure to open its archives to historians.

German historians have already begun to chronicle the darkest chapter in the sport's history that began when it was 'taken over' by the Nazi Party in 1933.

Jewish players and Jewish club chiefs were first sidelined and excluded from international games, and then later unceremoniously kicked out, a process that began in the early 30s. More than 300 Jewish players disappeared during the Nazi era: some died in suspicious circumstances and several others perished later in concentration camps. There has been little attempt to find out what happened to them.

Hitler hated football but quickly learnt how useful it would be to exploit a sport that had become popular in the 1920s as a means of propaganda to promote the aggressive German style. He also realised the political potential in the mass gatherings of football fans. 'Winning a match,' Goebbels wrote, 'is of more importance to the people than the capture of a town in the east.'

Football practice was turned into paramilitary training, and footballers were forced to give the Nazi salute as well as undergoing regular 'Nazi tests', where they were questioned on such facts as Hitler's birthday. Even the English team was forced to give the Nazi salute as a sign of respect for Germany during one match between the two countries.

But plans by Goebbels to 'force victories' were unachievable. Defeat after embarrassing defeat led to Goebbels banning all international games.

Until now, German football authorities have been reluctant to reveal details of the game's history.

The federation (DFB) claims that it has been able to help on the subject because most of its documents were destroyed by the Allies. 'At the moment there is very little material in our archives,' said DFB general secretary Horst R. Schmidt in a recent statement. 'This is because the entire property of the headquarters when it was in Berlin fell victim to an air raid, which burnt the building down.'

But historians specialising in the period hotly refute this version of events, saying that historical documents from various sources prove that the parts of the building on Berlin's so-called Reichs Sport field, where the DFB had its headquarters, were not touched by the bomb. Insiders have instead spoken of huge stacks of archive material being 'spirited away' over the years in an attempt to keep the truth hidden.

Germany is to host the World Cup in 2006 and, say commentators, is keen to 'clear up' this unhappy chapter in its history before it receives too much adverse publicity from abroad. The DFB issued a directive to all its clubs six weeks ago, calling on them to 'work through and come to terms with' their Nazi pasts, and produce documentation with which histo rians could work. Close attention will be paid to the way in which FC Bayern Munich deals with its past. It recently refused to pay into a compensation fund for former Nazi slave labourers to which Ger man firms and commercial institutions have been asked to contribute, saying that it was itself a victim of the Nazis.

Many critics said it had gravely missed the point of the fund. Before 1933 the club offered refuge to Munich's Jews, earning itself the nickname 'Jews Club'. FC Bayern's rise to the top of the league in the Twenties and Thirties was largely due to its Jewish president Kurt Landauer, who later had to flee Germany and was replaced with an Aryan chief.

Borussia Dortmund was the first top-league club to respond to the DFB's demands for critical reappraisal, commissioning its archivist to fulfil the task.

The make-up of Borussia Dortmund before the war was typical of others from the Rhineland, full of players and supporters from the socialist and communist milieu. Pressure from the Nazis forced it in 1933 to change its left-leaning club chief, Egon Pentrup, with August Busse, a member of the Nazi Party. Like most clubs, Borussia has over the years claimed that its members were split over Nazi ideology. But already in 1939, 80 per cent of the first team were members of Hitler's Stormtroopers.

Berlin's Schalke 04 club, which was national champion six times between 1933 and 1945, was also successfully turned into a Nazi team.

Some people fear that Germany's football history may come full circle. Much attention has been paid in recent years to the Berlin football club Dynamo, the former club of East Germany's Stasi police, which now has a reputation for being the club of Germany's rightwing skinheads.

Six million and counting

fields.headline: When the injury gets personal
fields.standfirst: Jill Insley looks into the claims management revolution
fields.trailText: Jill Insley looks into the claims management revolution.
fields.body:
Turn on your TV during the day and you'll be bombarded with advertising for 'no win, no fee' personal injury litigation services.

Claims management companies have mushroomed since April last year, when legal aid for most personal injury cases was abolished. Although the British have traditionally eschewed the 'compensation culture' of the US, high-profile advertising promoting the chance to pursue a claim at no apparent cost to the claimant are winning customers.

These new services are intended to help anyone who has been hurt in an accident through no fault of their own to claim compensation. Any accident could give rise to a potential claim, from tripping on an uneven paving slab to suffering injuries in a car crash. With the exception of certain cases involving minors or medical negligence, the claim must be lodged within three years of the accident. On contacting a claims management service, your claim will be given an initial assessment. If the service believes you have a good chance (generally 51 per cent or more) of winning damages, you will be referred to a solicitor and asked to undergo a medical assessment.

However, further legislative changes introduced in April 2000 have encouraged the introduction of 'success' fees by solicitors and the sale of expensive 'after the event' insurance policies, designed to protect claimants from costs if they lose their case. Insurers are contesting the validity of these extra costs, claiming that in many cases these costs are unnecessary because the insurer has admitted liability. The Association of British Insurers says that the increased cost of personal injury claims is already feeding into the cost of car insurance, and it believes that if the practice of selling expensive 'after the event' policies and charging success fees continues, insurance premiums will inevitably rise.

The disagreement over costs has resulted in a stand-off, with some insurers refusing to pay the success fees and insurance policy costs demanded by solicitors. Since April last year, Claims Direct has managed to recover the cost of its insurance premium in just 100 cases. Insurers have refused to pay up in a further 400 cases. In many of the cases, Claims Direct has deducted the full cost of the insurance premium (£1,312) from the claimant's damages until the insurer pays up.

Norwich Union is considering trying to settle the argument once and for all by appealing against the costs awarded to one claimant injured in a car crash.

Martin Cockx, senior partner with Manchester solicitors Amerlans, explains that before the widespread introduction of 'after the event' policies, many potential claimants were put off claiming for fear of ending up out of pocket if they lost. Before April 2000, claimants usually had to pay their solicitors an hourly rate as their case proceeded. If they won their case, they could recoup these costs from the defendant, but if they lost they would not only have to foot their own solicitor's fees but also those of the opposing side.

However, insurers believe that some claims management firms are taking advantage of the new legislation to push up costs. Suzanne Moore of the ABI says: 'There is a concern that some of the claims for costs are not at a reasonable level. Where insurers feel the costs are not reasonable, they won't pay them.'

The policies being offered by some claims management firms certainly vary widely in cost. 121legals, which charges a set fee of £900, says the costs vary because each firm's policy offers different levels of cover. Claims Direct spokesman Tony Wright defends his firm's higher charge, saying that the fee is all encompassing, covering the insurance premium, solicitor's fees and any other costs.

In theory, the claimant does not have to pay anything from his own pocket, as the premium is arranged as a personal loan which the claimant is not responsible for repaying. If the claim is successful, the defendant pays the premium as part of the costs, and if the claim is unsuccessful, the policy pays out to cover all disbursements, including the premium.

But Andrew Flowers, of the online claims firm easyClaims.com, warns that while 'reasonable' costs can be recovered from the defendant's insurer under the Access to Justice Act, inflated costs may be rejected. 'Any shortfall between the claims management company and the amount of unrecovered costs is deducted from the claimant's damages,' says Flowers.

The ABI's Suzanne Moore says that the insurance industry needs clarification about what should be considered a reasonable cost. However a precedent is unlikely to be set by just one case, as the circumstances vary widely from one case to another.

She says: 'This [clarification] is gradually happening through the courts as cases are settled. In some cases the judges find in favour of the claimants and in others they find for the insurers. But it is a very slow process. Ideally we would like formal guidance from the Lord Chancellor's Department.'

Until this happens, the ABI is hoping that the parties involved - the claims management firms, the solicitors, and the insurers - can come to some agreement over how much can reasonably be charged. In the meantime, potential claimants can save money and aggravation by checking whether they already have legal expenses insurance as part of existing general insurance policies. In these circumstances they are unlikely to need 'after the event' insurance.

They should also be careful in their choice of claims management company - remember that these firms are not regulated - and check the terms and conditions applied. easyClaims.com, for example, promises that none of its customers' damages will be used to cover legal costs or insurance premiums. 'The client is guaranteed to get 100 per cent of damages if they win and incur no costs if they lose. The client pays nothing at any stage,' says Flowers.

Alternatively, claimants can cut out the middlemen by going directly to a firm of solicitors specialising in personal injury work, and will work on a no-win, no-fee basis. Look in Yellow Pages or contact the Law Society's helpline, which will provide the names and addresses of three solicitors' firms dealing in this area of work (0870 6066575)
