fields.headline: What's in an award?
fields.standfirst: Fiona Williams  tests the medals of fund-rankers
fields.trailText: Fiona Williams tests the medals of fund-rankers
fields.body:
Winning an award brings pride only if it is a mark of genuine achievement. It is a lot less valued if everyone gets one, the competition is sparse, or it was a fluke.

So what do the awards and rankings that adorn promotional literature for collective funds mean?

The Standard & Poor's Micropal star rankings, and the more demanding Standard & Poor's Fund Research ratings, are both frequently cited in marketing efforts directed at private investors. Lipper ARC medals are aimed at professional managers, and the full list is currently only available to subscribers. However, they are often cited as a claim to fame, so investors need to know what they mean.

All three sets of awards start with performance over the past three years.

The Lipper ARC medals and Micropal rankings are based purely on these performance figures and are recalculated monthly. Micropal says star rankings are held, on average, for four months, so by the time you consider buying a fund, its rating may be about to change. The Fund Research ratings start by picking the top 38 per cent of funds in each sector on the basis of their performance over the past three years. If fund managers agree to pay £1,500 or more per trust, extensive research is conducted to determine whether the fund should receive a rating. Around 20 per cent prove successful.

Funds hold their Funds Research rating for one year. But quarterly qualitative checks are conducted, and if there is a dramatic change, such as a new manager, for example, the rating is put 'under review'.

Only around 10 per cent of rated funds gain an AAA rating, the highest accolade, with the majority clustered in the AA sector. Some manage to hold their ranking for many years. Newton Income Fund, for instance, has retained its AAA rating for a decade.

The Lipper ARC medals and Micropal rankings have several important differences. All funds receive a Micropal ranking, whereas funds must beat their benchmark to achieve a Lipper ARC medal. Normally fewer than 2 per cent gain a Lipper ARC platinum medal, whereas the top 10 per cent of funds invariably gain a five-star Micropal ranking.

Micropal starts with a fund's average investment return relative to the rest of its sector in each of the last 36 months then divides it by the volatility of that outperformance (the amount by which it has varied from month to month) to arrive at a relative return/volatility ratio. The fund is ranked on the basis of this ratio. The funds in a sector could all be doing badly, but the top risk-adjusted performers would still get a top rating.

Lipper compares funds against an index, which it selects on the basis of the funds' objectives and composition. Lipper claims this is more objective than comparison within a sector, which can have a bias to underperformance, and it contends that its method of measuring risk and consistency is more objective.

Both methods assess risk-adjusted performance over discreet monthly periods. But whereas Micropal gives equal weighting to each month, Lipper gives greater weight to more recent results.

Both use bid-to-bid figures for funds and Micropal uses mid price-to-mid price for investment trusts, which Lipper does not cover. 'Bid-to-bid takes into account the management fee, custodian charges, and all the other running costs,' says Lipper spokesperson Dale Hubber-Richard.

While the Lipper ARC medals aim to reflect recent changes more rapidly than the Micropal star rankings, they remain purely quantitative and retrospective. Fund Research ratings, on the other hand, attempt to predict whether a fund can maintain past performance. Only 40 per cent of the rating score is quantitative.

The qualitative screening is carried out by a team of analysts, many of whom are former fund managers. They assess the fund and score it on a spread of criteria mainly relating to the fund management group, portfolio manager and the team. The results are discussed by an analyst committee, sometimes after considerable debate.

Because of the qualitative overlay, ratings can be com paratively stable and will not necessarily be affected by one year's poor performance. But they are likely to more swiftly reflect potentially important changes, such as a takeover of the management company, a shift in style or a big change in funds under management, particularly if these are associated with a loss of form.'We believe that managers who have a clear philosophy and continually implement it through a disciplined process are more likely to be able to replicate their results,' says Fund Research.

Investors use past performance as a means to choose funds, but the Financial Services Authority seems determined to move the focus to hard facts such as costs.

Anne McMeehan, spoke-sperson for the Association of Unit Trusts & Investment Funds, believes this approach is misguided: 'I don't agree with the contention that past performance is eminently dismissible. The past can't tell you precisely what the future is, but it is highly relevant.

If a fund has performed abysmally in the past there is usually a reason, which needs to be explored. The focus that consumerist types have, to look at costs alone, is not a good thing.'

She added: 'Past performance incorporates all the costs. Investors need to take it as a starting point, then look at factors such as the way a fund is managed, by whom and how big it is.'

This is what Fund Research seeks to supply. For private investors, it is the more beneficial of the three rating systems.

From platinum to bronze - trusts you can trust

Lipper Arc medals are awarded on the basis of risk-adjusted performance in each of the last 36 months relative to a suitable index, weighted in favour of recent months.

There is no pre-allocated percentage of medals, which are updated monthly, and around 30-40 per cent of trusts fail to achieve a medal. Platinum indicates a consistency of risk-adjusted outperformance of its benchmark above all reasonable expectation.

Gold indicates outperformance that suggests the investment process has been more important than luck.

Silver indicates outperformance on a risk-adjusted basis, with more added value than a passive investment policy would achieve.

Bronze indicates funds that have performed in line with reasonable expectations on a risk-adjusted basis; this means they could be slightly below the benchmark.

How to star for Micropal

Funds are ranked on a relative return/volatility ratio within respective sectors over each of the last 36 months on an unweighted basis, updated monthly. A trust with an exceptional average monthly performance but high volatility may have the same star ranking as a trust with a less impressive performance but lower volatility, and the top-ranking funds have not necessarily beaten their benchmark.

***** top 10 per cent of funds in each sector

**** next 20 per cent

*** next 20 per cent

** third quartile

* bottom quartile

Funds must have a three-year record, and trusts cannot be ranked if their sector is less than five strong or so varied as to invalidate comparisons.

Fund Research's rate expectations

AAA: An extremely strong ability to adhere to consistent investment processes and provide above-average, volatility-adjusted returns relative to funds with similar objectives.

AA: A very strong ability to adhere to consistent investment processes and provide above-average, volatility-adjusted returns relative to funds with similar objectives.

A: A high standard of quality in a fund's sector based on its investment process and management's consistency of performance compared with funds with similar objectives.

UR: Under review due to significant changes at the fund manager or team level, which have yet to be fully evaluated.

NR: Not rated either because it failed to pass the quantitative or qualitative test, or because the managers of the funds were not interested in being rated.

Ratings, rankings and reports are available on the internet at: www.funds-sp.com

Only around 10 per cent of rated funds gain an AAA rating, the highest accolade, with the majority clustered in the AA sector. Some manage to hold their ranking for many years. Newton Income Fund, for instance, has retained its AAA rating for a decade. The Lipper ARC medals and Micropal rankings have several important differences. All funds receive a Micropal ranking, whereas funds must beat their benchmark to achieve a Lipper ARC medal. Normally fewer than 2 per cent gain a Lipper ARC platinum medal, whereas the top 10 per cent of funds invariably gain a five-star Micropal ranking. Micropal starts with a fund's average investment return relative to the rest of its sector in each of the last 36 months then divides it by the volatility of that outperformance (the amount by which it has varied from month to month) to arrive at a relative return/volatility ratio. The fund is ranked on the basis of this ratio. The funds in a sector could all be doing badly, but the top risk-adjusted performers would still get a top rating. Lipper compares funds against an index, which it selects on the basis of the funds' objectives and composition. Lipper claims this is more objective than comparison within a sector, which can have a bias to underperformance, and it contends that its method of measuring risk and consistency is more objective. Both methods assess risk-adjusted performance over discreet monthly periods. But whereas Micropal gives equal weighting to each month, Lipper gives greater weight to more recent results. Both use bid-to-bid figures for funds and Micropal uses mid price-to-mid price for investment trusts, which Lipper does not cover. 'Bid-to-bid takes into account the management fee, custodian charges, and all the other running costs,' says Lipper spokesperson Dale Hubber-Richard. While the Lipper ARC medals aim to reflect recent changes more rapidly than the Micropal star rankings, they remain purely quantitative and retrospective. Fund Research ratings, on the other hand, attempt to predict whether a fund can maintain past performance. Only 40 per cent of the rating score is quantitative. The qualitative screening is carried out by a team of analysts, many of whom are former fund managers. They assess the fund and score it on a spread of criteria mainly relating to the fund management group, portfolio manager and the team. The results are discussed by an analyst committee, sometimes after considerable debate. Because of the qualitative overlay, ratings can be com paratively stable and will not necessarily be affected by one year's poor performance. But they are likely to more swiftly reflect potentially important changes, such as a takeover of the management company, a shift in style or a big change in funds under management, particularly if these are associated with a loss of form.'We believe that managers who have a clear philosophy and continually implement it through a disciplined process are more likely to be able to replicate their results,' says Fund Research. Investors use past performance as a means to choose funds, but the Financial Services Authority seems determined to move the focus to hard facts such as costs. Anne McMeehan, spoke-sperson for the Association of Unit Trusts & Investment Funds, believes this approach is misguided: 'I don't agree with the contention that past performance is eminently dismissible. The past can't tell you precisely what the future is, but it is highly relevant. If a fund has performed abysmally in the past there is usually a reason, which needs to be explored. The focus that consumerist types have, to look at costs alone, is not a good thing.' She added: 'Past performance incorporates all the costs. Investors need to take it as a starting point, then look at factors such as the way a fund is managed, by whom and how big it is.' This is what Fund Research seeks to supply. For private investors, it is the more beneficial of the three rating systems. From platinum to bronze - trusts you can trust Lipper Arc medals are awarded on the basis of risk-adjusted performance in each of the last 36 months relative to a suitable index, weighted in favour of recent months. There is no pre-allocated percentage of medals, which are updated monthly, and around 30-40 per cent of trusts fail to achieve a medal. Platinum indicates a consistency of risk-adjusted outperformance of its benchmark above all reasonable expectation. Gold indicates outperformance that suggests the investment process has been more important than luck. Silver indicates outperformance on a risk-adjusted basis, with more added value than a passive investment policy would achieve. Bronze indicates funds that have performed in line with reasonable expectations on a risk-adjusted basis; this means they could be slightly below the benchmark. How to star for Micropal Funds are ranked on a relative return/volatility ratio within respective sectors over each of the last 36 months on an unweighted basis, updated monthly. A trust with an exceptional average monthly performance but high volatility may have the same star ranking as a trust with a less impressive performance but lower volatility, and the top-ranking funds have not necessarily beaten their benchmark. ***** top 10 per cent of funds in each sector **** next 20 per cent *** next 20 per cent ** third quartile * bottom quartile Funds must have a three-year record, and trusts cannot be ranked if their sector is less than five strong or so varied as to invalidate comparisons. Fund Research's rate expectations AAA: An extremely strong ability to adhere to consistent investment processes and provide above-average, volatility-adjusted returns relative to funds with similar objectives. AA: A very strong ability to adhere to consistent investment processes and provide above-average, volatility-adjusted returns relative to funds with similar objectives. A: A high standard of quality in a fund's sector based on its investment process and management's consistency of performance compared with funds with similar objectives. UR: Under review due to significant changes at the fund manager or team level, which have yet to be fully evaluated. NR: Not rated either because it failed to pass the quantitative or qualitative test, or because the managers of the funds were not interested in being rated. fields.headline: Brown targets breadline
fields.standfirst: Tax cuts will have to wait, experts tell  Maria Scott
fields.trailText: Tax cuts will have to wait, experts tell Maria Scott.
fields.body:
Stand by for a cappuccino Budget, with lots of froth on top, a few sprinkles of something sweet but not much underneath.

This is what John Whiting, tax specialist at accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers, is expecting in Chancellor Gordon Brown's pre-election package on 7 March. Whiting and other analysts expect it to be laced with public spending sweeteners. But if there are extra shots for flavour, they won't be in the form of tax cuts, they predict.

Whiting says that although reducing the basic income tax rate from 22 per cent to 20 per cent would allow Brown to tease the tax-cutting Tories, the Chancellor is more likely merely to announce a timetable for cutting the basic rate. Instead he is expected to extend the 10 per cent starting rate to a greater proportion of people's income. This rate now applies to the first £1,520 of income after the personal allowance.

This could be coupled with a slightly above-inflation rise in the starting point for the 40 per cent higher rate, which now applies to taxable income of more than £28,400.

Carl Emmerson of the Institute for Fiscal Studies agrees that while the Chancellor can easily afford to cut 1p cut off the basic rate - he has between £3 billion and £4bn to spend - he may go instead for widening the 10p band.

The experts expect him to develop the tax credit schemes that have become his hallmark. These help specific groups, mainly families and the low paid.

Whiting expects confirmation of an increase in the new Children's Tax Credit, which is due to replace the married couple's allowance on 6 April. The starting level already announced is up to £442 a year - £8.50 a week - for families with at least one child under 16. Brown's aim, he said in his pre-Budget report last November, was to raise that to £10 a week, or£520 a year.

Mike Warburton of accountant Grant Thornton sees an even bigger gesture: 'If he made it £12 a week, this would cost £500m, little more than a tenth of what he can give away.'

Some families may want a more fundamental change to end an anomaly in the way the credit will work. It tapers away for higher-rate taxpay ers, disqualifying someone earning £40,000 or more. A couple who each earn £30,000 are due to get the credit in full, but a couple with one earner on £40,000 would get nothing.

Warburton thinks it would be hard to correct this yet because it is written into the rules of the scheme.

The Chancellor wants to streamline the fiendishly complex system of support for children. Warburton expects him to make the first moves toward an integrated child credit in 2003, drawing together a maze of schemes: child benefit, income support, the income-related jobseekers' allowance, the working families tax credit, disabled person's tax credit and the children's tax credit.

Elderly people could hear more about Brown's plan, announced in the pre-Budget report, to develop a credit to reward lower-income pensioners for saving. Many poor pensioners miss out on means-tested income support because they have put aside modest amounts.

The credit is earmarked for introduction in 2003, but Warburton says: 'Perhaps he could bring it forward.'

One thing seems certain: the Budget is unlikely to simplify a tax system that accountants and taxpayers agree has grown much more complicated since this Chancellor has been in office.

The complexity makes it difficult, if not impossible, for most people to work out whether they are better or worse off under Labour, something millions of voters will want to know as election day nears.

There is a strong body of opinion that people earning between £25,000 and £30,000 or more are paying more tax than they did in the Tory years. Tim O'Brien of accountant Moore Stephens says: 'I don't think there is any doubt. Virtually every way you turn the statistics there is a bigger tax burden on the individual.'

Yet Labour has cut the basic rate once, from 23p to 22p. The increases lie in so-called stealth rises such as the abolition of mortgage tax relief, removing the right of non-taxpayers to reclaim tax on share dividends and the barely noticed loss of dividend tax credits on pension funds. The latter, from Brown's first Budget, is now feeding through to decreased returns on pension funds.

Whiting agrees that the UK tax burden is higher. 'We pay more as a percentage of gross domestic product than we used to - around 37 per cent now against 35.2 per cent in 1996/97.'

Economic prosperity, low unemployment and low interest rates have taken the sting out of the rises for those in work, but Warburton says the gap between rich and poor has widened.

With the election coming up and tax bound to be a flashpoint, taxpayers could take some basic advice from the expert O'Brien: 'Try to understand how much taxable income you have,' he says. 'A lot of people don't even know that.'

Top 10 Budget predictions

... from PricewaterhouseCoopers

1. An increase in the 10 per cent income tax band
A 'significant' rise in the amount of income that qualifies for the 10 per cent tax rate to benefit low earners

2. Duty on cigarettes

A modest increase on duty on tobacco to help the health service, with perhaps a small percentage earmarked for anti-smuggling efforts

3. Tax-free payments for volunteers

Possible tax deduction for salaries of staff who do voluntary work, and any expenses their employer pays

4. VAT recovery for museums

Galleries and museums that allow free entry would be able to recover their VAT costs

5. Reform of betting tax

Abolition of tax paid by punters when they place a bet, to be replaced with a special betting profits tax

6. Moving closer to a 20 per cent basic income tax rate

Timetable for implementation of the 20 per cent rate - perhaps 1 per cent next year and 1 per cent soon after

7. Pensions

Changes to how pension funds invest their money following review last year of investment policies introduced to protect pensions after the Maxwell scandal.

8. Stamp duty

Reform to cope with electronic conveyancing but no rate rises this time

9. Further changes to capital gains tax

Inflation-linked rise to £7,200 annual exemption. Adjustments to iron out anomalies in the complex 'tapering' system that encourages investors to hold assets long term

10. Raising the starting point for 40 per cent tax

The £28,400 threshold of taxable income at which the higher rate starts will be lifted, but only marginally

fields.headline: Toujours Provence: Part two
fields.standfirst: Properties in France still offer great value for Britons looking for a holiday home - or more
fields.trailText: Properties in France still offer great value for Britons looking for a holiday home - or more.
fields.body:
The strong pound and the rising values of many British homes have made the dream of owning a house in France increasingly realisable.

One estimate says 400,000 houses in France are now owned by Britons, most of them in Normandy and the South East of the country, with many purchased using capital released by remortgaging UK homes.

The Channel Tunnel, low-cost airline routes to places such as Nice, Lyon, Bordeaux and Marseilles, plus ferries to French ports from Plymouth and Dover, make the idea of escape to France more feasible than ever.

There is now a small property industry for Britons wanting to buy. A European Union report in the early Nineties said more than 1,000 French companies and 200 British ones (mostly estate agents) were involved in selling French homes to the British.

French Property News, a magazine and advice service for prospective buyers, organises exhibitions for developers and estate agents selling French homes, and individuals wanting to buy - the next one is in Birmingham on 9-11 March. 'We had over 12,700 visitors to our last exhibition in January - a record for any event of this kind in Britain, we think,' says Dick Schrader, the magazine's managing director.

'The interesting thing this year is that more people are looking to move to France permanently, not just for a holiday home. They're looking at the NHS, crime and transport, and saying that there must be somewhere better than the UK. Whether they're right or not is another matter, but there's a move in that direction. One of France's most appealing aspects is that it is large, and most British people who stay there for weekends or permanently want to become French in the way they live.

So there isn't any 'Costa' mentality, with certain towns being identified with the British or the Germans - it's all just French.

But the days of ultra-cheap French property are over - speculative purchasers from Britain, Germany and Holland have seen to that. But Gallic property is still outstandingly good value, and so far most regions have avoided becoming British enclaves.

In the Loire a two-bedroom stone house with large outbuildings, overlooking the river in the village of Lange, with electricity, water and drainage all connected, is on the market for just £27,000 through Dorset-based Agence Maison René. Near Mayenne in Normandy you can find a seventeenth-century farmhouse with five acres of land and lots of outbuildings for around £90,000 through agents Maison France.

At the top of the market Knight Frank is offering Domaine de Ranguin, 11 kilometres from the Cannes Croisette. This seventeenth-century estate has eight bedrooms in the main house, two staff apartments, a guest cottage plus 44 acres of land - including olive grove. It is on sale for Ff35,000,000 (£3.53m) - a lot less than a similar house in the UK, despite being in one of Europe's most desirable (and sunny) locations.

Whatever your price range, there are six key steps every buyer should follow:

 Get a British-based solicitor with French property experience to navigate the maze of European property law - some are listed on the internet, and any British estate agent selling French homes should be able to refer you. Some experts believe French solicitors (notaires) are less likely to point out shortcomings in a property deal because they usually work for both seller and buyer.

 Organise how you will pay for your new home. Abbey National is the main UK lender for French purchases, followed by Barclays and the Woolwich. A broker will find the best deals.

 Personally visit houses which are for sale. In rural France it is common to sell properties in a condition generally unacceptable in Britain, and pre-sale surveys are still rare. Local authority and utility searches will also be required, as in this country, to find out about future development proposals and rights of way.

 Get your solicitor to check the proposed sale agreement. Signing an agreement in France can make you liable to pay some or all of the cost even if you later withdraw from the deal, so it is crucial to ensure the maximum information is contained in the contract at this stage.

 Clarify whether your new home is subject to French inheritance tax, which favours children ahead of a spouse if the owner dies without a will. If this arrangement does not suit you, simply set out your wishes in a will.

 Use a local French agency to manage your home if you wish to rent it out. It is expensive to make emergency trips from the UK to parts of France which can take 24 hours to reach - and many agency charges will be tax-deductible anyway.

Enjoy your gite or apartment - but do not expect it to make you rich. British property inflation is unheard of in France, where owner-occupation rates (and, for that matter, interest rates) are lower than in the UK. French nationals can borrow only up to 80 per cent of a property's value, with a maximum loan-to-income ratio of around 1 to 2.5; in Britain it is up to 100 per cent, with a ratio of up to 3.5 or even more. Even in Paris it is rare to have property inflation over 3 per cent a year - so look on a French property as something to enjoy, and not mainly as an investment.

Contacts

French Property News (020 8543 3113)

Agency Maison René (023 9259 9409)

Maison France (01427 628537)

Knight Frank (020 7629 8171)

webTitle: Long-term care: Scots show the way

fields.headline: Scots can show the way, but  Westminster may not follow
fields.standfirst: North of the border the elderly will get free help for their everyday needs.  Neasa MacErlean  reports
fields.trailText: North of the border the elderly will get free help for their everyday needs. Neasa MacErlean reports.
fields.body:
Moves in Scotland to offer free personal care to the elderly are unlikely to be mirrored south of the border, experts on long-term care say.

Campaigners in the UK have been hoping that Westminster could be persuaded to follow the recommendations of the Royal Commission on Long-Term Care and provide free personal care as well as free nursing care for the elderly.

This would mean that the costs of helping someone to get dressed and giving them a bath, for example, would be covered, as well as the nursing costs of dispensing medicine to them and giving them other medical treat ment. If a nursing home resident typically pays about £400 a week, they would continue to pay their own bed-and-board costs (perhaps £200 a week), but their nursing costs (perhaps £60 to £100) and personal care costs (perhaps £120) would be met by the state.

The hopes of campaigners were stimulated last month when the Scottish Parliament - after some wobbling by the ruling minority Labour group - agreed to offer free personal care. The bill could come into effect by early 2002.

Another source of encouragement was the January announcement from the Liberal Democrats in Westminster that 'free personal care will be a central plank of the Liberal Democrats' health policy in the manifesto for the general election'. This move means that if the grey power lobby could organise itself it would have a flag to gather under.The Lib Dem candidate fighting Peter Mandelson's Hartlepool seat, for instance, has made it clear that long-term care will be one of his three main campaigning issues.

More fuel could be added to the debate if the Northern Ireland Assembly decides - as it could - to follow the Scottish route. 'We don't yet know what route they will take,' says Tom Cairns of Age Concern Northern Ireland.

But the Northern Ireland Health Minister is currently studying both the English and Scottish proposals and will have to bring out her own plans. In Wales, there are those who would like to follow the Scottish example, but the Welsh Assembly does not yet have the budgetary freedom to go out on a limb from England - so the Welsh will, for the time being, follow England.

But, despite these encouraging signs, experts in the field are not optimistic. 'My gut feeling is that this Government will stand fast and not follow the Scottish route,' says Philip Spiers of independent financial adviser the Nursing Home Fees Agency. 'If the Government allowed free personal care, it would open up the floodgates and cost the Government billions.'

Agreeing to provide free personal care could encourage the country's estimated 6 million carers to get some free care instead of doing it all themselves - a move that would certainly mean that taxes would have to go up. Peter Gatenby of Age Concern Financial Partnerships takes a similar view: 'We would be ecstatic if they decided to give free personal care, but there's very little chance they will change their mind. In fact, when the Scottish group reports back, it probably will still include some elements of personal care,but I wouldn't be surprised if they didn't end up covering far less than people think they will get at the moment.'

Age Concern Scotland hopes to be closely involved in the development group's consultations and, not surprisingly, wants to keep the definition of personal care as broad as possible.

The problem that both Spiers and Gatenby foresee is the cost of funding personal care outside residential and nursing homes. They do not believe that it would be a massive financial burden for personal care to be provided free in these institutions. But once a government accepted the principle of giving free personal care, it would be difficult to argue that such care should only be provided free to residents of homes.

In fact, Spiers believes that providing free personal care might cost the Government just £6 a week for many older people. This is because many of them already get Attendance Allowance of £53.55 a week, but they would stop getting this assistance if they were given free care instead. Spiers estimates that personal care costs would be about £60 a week for many people.

The Westminster Government is pushing ahead with the Health and Social Care Bill which will start introducing some of its long-term care plans from April. The bill could get Royal Assent in April, and may be out of the way before a general election. Even if the Liberal Democrats won more seats in Westminster and could have the kind of influence they currently wield in the Scottish Parliament, it would probably be too late for most of these issues apart from their implementation.

From April, the Government will formally require local authorities to disregard a person's house for the first three months of a stay in a home. This means that they cannot start putting pressure on that person to sell the home to pay nursing home fees. Government Ministers often cite this move as a way in which they are helping the elderly and frail. But Spiers says: 'This softens the blow but it's nothing new.' Local authorities can already disregard the house if it looks as if someone's stay in a home will be temporary. At the same time, the means test threshold is due to go up - from £16,000 to £18,500. State help is potentially avail able for people with assessable assets below this level - if their pension and other income is not enough to cover the bills.

Another disappointing outcome of the Westminster Government's policy on long-term care is its guidance to local authorities on how they should charge people for home helps and other Social Services assistance.

The Department of Health had previously promised to standardise arrangements so that local authorities could no longer have completely different systems from each other. But the guidance which is due to go out to authorities in May, for implementation by April 2002, is seen as rather feeble and, although it encourages consistency and fairness, it still allows authorities to continue as they wish.
fields.bodyText: Moves in Scotland to offer free personal care to the elderly are unlikely to be mirrored south of the border, experts on long-term care say. Campaigners in the UK have been hoping that Westminster could be persuaded to follow the recommendations of the Royal Commission on Long-Term Care and provide free personal care as well as free nursing care for the elderly. This would mean that the costs of helping someone to get dressed and giving them a bath, for example, would be covered, as well as the nursing costs of dispensing medicine to them and giving them other medical treat ment. If a nursing home resident typically pays about £400 a week, they would continue to pay their own bed-and-board costs (perhaps £200 a week), but their nursing costs (perhaps £60 to £100) and personal care costs (perhaps £120) would be met by the state. The hopes of campaigners were stimulated last month when the Scottish Parliament - after some wobbling by the ruling minority Labour group - agreed to offer free personal care. The bill could come into effect by early 2002. Another source of encouragement was the January announcement from the Liberal Democrats in Westminster that 'free personal care will be a central plank of the Liberal Democrats' health policy in the manifesto for the general election'. This move means that if the grey power lobby could organise itself it would have a flag to gather under.The Lib Dem candidate fighting Peter Mandelson's Hartlepool seat, for instance, has made it clear that long-term care will be one of his three main campaigning issues. More fuel could be added to the debate if the Northern Ireland Assembly decides - as it could - to follow the Scottish route. 'We don't yet know what route they will take,' says Tom Cairns of Age Concern Northern Ireland. But the Northern Ireland Health Minister is currently studying both the English and Scottish proposals and will have to bring out her own plans. In Wales, there are those who would like to follow the Scottish example, but the Welsh Assembly does not yet have the budgetary freedom to go out on a limb from England - so the Welsh will, for the time being, follow England. 'My gut feeling is that this Government will stand fast and not follow the Scottish route,' says Philip Spiers of independent financial adviser the Nursing Home Fees Agency. fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText: Taxman's incentive to share shares with the needy | Bad creditors on borrowed time | Loan roaming
fields.body:
Taxman's incentive to share shares with the needy

Giving shares to charity before 5 April can significantly reduce your tax bill for the current tax year, according to the Charities Aid Foundation.

Since last year's Budget the value of shares gifted can now be offset against the donor's taxable income. Someone earning a taxable salary of £60,000, for example, can donate shares worth £10,000 to charity and, by filling in a self-assessment form, need pay income tax on only £50,000.

CAF has already noted a rise in this form of support among donors using its service subsequent to the 2000 Budget. It says gifts of shares for charitable purposes have risen from £8 million to more than £26m.

For more information about giving shares to charity contact CAF on: 01732 520 026.

Bad creditors on borrowed time

Borrowers can now check whether they are being treated fairly by lenders and other organisations offering credit by consulting new guidelines from the Office of Fair Trading.

The OFT wants to make it clear what sort of behaviour is acceptable from consumer credit licence holders. Dishonesty, discrimination, hard selling and failing to offer redress are all grounds for complaint.

The guidelines will cover everyone from mortgage lenders to car dealers. Sectors traditionally attracting high levels of complaint include debt collection, used car dealers and home improvement companies.

If you feel aggrieved, your first port of call should be your local trading standards department. It will contact the OFT on your behalf. Companies face having their licence revoked for repeated breaches.

'Consumer Credit Licences - Guidance for holders and applicants' is available on www.oft.gov.uk.

Loan roaming

Four million homeowners could switch out of standard variable rates without any penalty and save themselves £1,000 each a year - £4 billion collectively, according to Tesco Personal Finance.

Tesco is urging customers to check their forthcoming annual mortgage statements to see whether they are marooned on an 'uncompetitive' standard variable rate.

It also reminds people that switching a mortgage can now be a speedy and hassle-free process.

Tesco is offering its own mortgage-finder service on www.tesco.com/finance: this features more than 500 products from 45 lenders. You can browse for mortgages and apply online.

Beyond compare

A new internet service being backed by Barclaycard will allow consumers to compare, choose and buy financial products.

iMoney will allow consumers to compare mortgages, unit trusts, car, home and travel insurance, personal loans, savings and current accounts and stocks and shares. You will be able to buy some of the products on the site, including mortgages and insurance products. The site, coming this summer, hopes to attract 200,000 registered users by the end of the year.

Heavily charged

The worst-performing UK Isa over one year is CF UK's, according to a survey by industry paper Money Marketing . The best in the same period is Solus UK Special Situations.

The survey, which also looks at Europe, highlights the effects of charges as well as differences in past performance. Charges can take away up to 35 per cent of the fund's value over 10 years.

Over the same period the most expensive fund in the UK all companies sector is Jupiter Growth and Income. The cheapest fund in any time period is the Abbey National Stockmarket 100 Tracker Growth fund. Copies of the survey are available from 020 7292 3730.

Green machines

Employees who use company bicycles to get to work will not be taxed for receiving a 'benefit in kind'. But, contrary to a gremlin that got into our report last week, they cannot claim a mileage allowance on travel between home and work.

webTitle: How to buy yourself a Rembrandt for only £1,000

fields.headline: How to buy yourself a Rembrandt for only £1,000
fields.standfirst: Prints can soar in value, says John Windsor
fields.trailText: Prints can soar in value, says John Windsor.
fields.body:
You can buy a respectable paper print by Rembrandt at an auction for £1,000.

The seventeenth century Dutch master was probably the most accomplished print maker of all time. After nearly four centuries, many of these works are torn, holed, creased and stained, or patched up with filler like an old car. The big auction houses reject the majority, abetted by accountants who think selling lots at less than£1,000 is bad business.

Your £1,000 buys a print with defects that are less than horrifying, and that price could double or triple in between 10 and 15 years. For the same amount, you could buy at auction a contemporary print by avant garde artists Gilbert and George, a toy Batman robot or a silk scarf worn by Elvis Presley.

But do you really want a Rembrandt? Now is the time to find out. The finest of them are on show at the British Museum. The 200 being exhibited until 8 April are the cream of the world's two most comprehensive collections, the British Museum's own and that of the Rijksmuseum in Amsterdam.

Ask yourself whether the facial expressions of his portraits have a deep emotional appeal. Is there something sublime about the tonal contrasts of his landscapes? Do his low-life characters look modern? In short, does the exhibition convey a hint that the art of an Old Master might still have more lasting appeal than flashy contemporary art or memorabilia?

Or are you more impressed by the fact that Rembrandt prints are disappearing from the market into museums, making those still available rarer and more valuable? And that Old Master exhibitions in Britain are pulling in record-breaking crowds?

The next print auctions at Christie's, Sotheby's and Phillips are not until June, so there is time for research before you enter a saleroom where three quarters of the bidders for Old Master prints are dealers with 20 or 30 years' experience. The dealers know each Rembrandt image like an old friend, but private buyers have an advantage over the trade. They do not need to sell their purchases for a profit, at least not in the short term. So when the dealers have bid as close to their resale price as they dare, a last-minute private bid can win.

These auctions are more like second-hand car auctions than they appear. Demand for a print can be largely a matter of taste. Would you rather a low-mileage, one-owner Volk swagen or a clapped-out Rolls-Royce - a Rembrandt print that is a feeble impression but in tip-top condition, or a rich impression that has been damaged? The prices could differ by thousands of pounds, but who is to say which is the better buy?

Two prints of Rembrandt's Raising of Lazarus (1642), virtually identical to the untrained eye, sold for widely differing prices - lot 94 fetched £6,815 and lot 95 brought a mere £940 - at Christie's last December.

I asked Richard Lloyd, head of Christie's Old Master, modern and contemporary print department, to explain. First, the cheaper lot, 95, with a pre-sale estimate of between £1,000 and £1,500, has wider margins around the image. To a beginner, perhaps used to buying Victorian prints, it might look the more attractive. But in Rembrandt's day, when paper was very expensive, prints were routinely trimmed and the offcuts used for smaller prints.

Experts do not regard the trimming of these prints as a defect, unless the plate mark (the ridge left by the edges of the plate), or the image itself, has been cut.

One respected dealer, the late Martin Gordon, of Florida, irked by amateurs' preoccupation with trimming, jokingly proposed a selling exhibition of blank offcut margins, priced according to the reputation of the artist! The Lazarus in lot 94, whose estimated price was £4,000 to £6,000, is one of the first prints that Rembrandt pulled from the plate before doing more work on it, while lot 95 is a print from the same plate in its final state.

A beginner might assume that the final one is preferable as it is Rembrandt's final expression of his intentions. This is sometimes true, but the difference between the two states of The Raising of Lazarus is trivial: the addition of three fine lines behind Lazarus's head. Which makes the difference in price even more puzzling. Until the burr on Christ's right thumb is considered.

The what? How arcane can you get? It is quite simple, really. The burr is the spikes of copper ploughed up by the artist's needle as he scores a line on the plate, a process known as drypoint. The spikes hold extra droplets of ink, which slowly seep into the paper, like blots, giving a velvety, watercolour-like effect which collectors prize.

The Raising of Lazarus has touches of drypoint. The rest is etched - a different process in which the image is scratched on a wax-coated plate that is then plunged into acid, which bites into the exposed metal. Rembrandt frequently used both processes on the same plate. Plates wear with use. The burr of drypoint is delicate and has a much shorter lifespan than etched lines.

Which is where Christ's right thumb comes in. It is accepted among connoisseurs that, in this print, the burr on His thumb was among the first touches of drypoint to wear away. In the first state of the print, the burr is intact. In the second state it has disappeared. So do you prefer the final state, which includes the master's final strokes, or the first state, with burr intact?

The saleroom's verdict was made clear by different prices. But both were good buys. The impressions were catalogued by Christie's as 'very good' (the more expensive one) and 'good'. The more expensive one had an added advantage: a collector's mark giving known provenance.

Condition counted; the less expensive one had repairs to spots of thin paper. Consult a paper conservationist if you fear that the print you want is badly damaged, or has defects that you cannot live with. They can wash out all but the most livid fox marks (brown spots of mould), and invisibly knit tears and smooth creases. Only loss of printed paper need genuinely worry you.

Differing qualities of impression and condition meant that, at Christie's last June, two portraits by Rembrandt of Jan Lutma, the goldsmith (1656), both second states, sold for £3,760 and £2,115, while a third (final) state fetched only £1,057.

It is essential to learn how many states Rembrandt made of each print, and how they differ, so buy a few catalogues raisonnés, scholarly works that list them all. Beginners will appreciate the American G.W. Nowell-Usticke's catalogue; although it classifies minor damage, such as accidental scratches, as distinct states, which is considered pedan tic, it does advise on rarity. The current British Museum exhibition has published a magnificent illustrated catalogue containing new research on Rembrandt's reworkings. It also contains details of catalogues raisonnés; look in the bibliography for the authors Hollstein, Hind and the popular White & Boon.

Consult auction house specialists as well as the textbooks. They may have valuable tips that do not appear in the sale catalogue.

You will, of course, have to avoid the pitfall of 'later' impressions, printed from Rembrandt's plates by others after his death in 1669.

A Rembrandt print priced at less than £1,000 is likely to be either damaged or a later impression. The exceptions prove that Rembrandt collectors really do go for quality - as proved by the occasional high auction price for a later impression. comparatively paltry £3,290 at Christie's in June.

Lloyd of Christie's advises: 'Decide how much you want to spend, then go for the finest print that your money will buy. And bear in mind that you need to invest not just money, but time.'

 'Rembrandt the Printmaker' is published by British Museum Publications (2000) at £50 (p&p £5 UK, £7.50 abroad) (Tel: 0207 323 8492). 'Rembrandt's Etchings, States and Values' by GW Nowell-Usticke, Livingstone (1967).

webTitle: Wealthcheck: A far cry from the Riviera

fields.headline: A far cry from the Riviera
fields.standfirst: I need to get organised, Frenchman Laurent explains to  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: I need to get organised, Frenchman Laurent explains to Helen Pridham.
fields.body:
Laurent de Alberti

Age 25

Lives in North London

Occupation Travel agent

Earns c. £14,000

Mortgage None

Debts No more than £100 on credit card

Investments £350 in instant access account

Pension None

Aims To make better use of his money and find out whether a pension or an Isa would be better, bearing in mind his eventual return to France

Laurent, who comes from Nice, arrived in London three years ago as an exchange student. He spent a year at Thames Valley University completing a degree in languages and economics and decided to stay on.

'When the time came for me to return to France, the French economy was rather depressed, so I thought it would be easier for me to find a job here in London.'

He has been working as a travel agent and is very happy with his current employer, Trailfinders, where he has been for a year. He hopes to stay with the company for the foreseeable future and work his way up.

At present he is not eligible for the company pension scheme and is wondering about the best way to save for the future.

He feels he needs to do something to stop himself spending nearly all his salary, which fluctuates depending on overtime.

He says: 'I am completely disorganised financially. Because my salary is different every month, I don't manage my money properly and seem to spend it on small things - clothes, cinema - that add up and leave me with hardly anything at the end of the month.'

He has no debts as he has paid off all his student loans, no overdraft and a minimal credit card balance, never more than about £100. He has £350 in a Barclays instant access savings account, but tends to use that money for holidays rather than long-term saving.

He takes plenty of holidays. One of the perks of his job is cheap travel and flexible hours which allow him to take time off every couple of months. Recently he travelled to San Francisco, New York and Budapest, and in the summer he is planning a month-long round-the-world trip.

He shares a friend's flat, paying £400 a month for rent and bills. He thought of buying a property, but feels it is not worth it as he is not planning to stay here permanently - and doesn't think his earnings would enable him to buy much anyway.

However, he would like to start building up some capital, and thinks he could afford to save £50 or possibly £100 a month. But he is not sure whether a pension or an Isa would be best, nor how difficult it would be to transfer his money should he go back to France, which he estimates won't be for another five years at least.

'I would like to know if there are any rules about transferring pension and investment funds to another European country and how convenient it is.'

Adviser 1: Gillian Cardy

Under stakeholder pension rules, Laurent's employer may soon have to offer him a pension. But it may not be the best thing for him - his money will be tied up until he is 50. If his employer is prepared to make a contribution, it probably would be better to let this money be invested on his behalf but review what he does with his own contributions.

Although the Inland Revenue permits transfers to qualifying pension schemes overseas, he may do better to make regular savings into an Isa, earmarking it as his retirement fund. He will then be free to either leave it invested in the UK or use it to invest in a suitable pension plan in France. He should not underestimate the possibility of needing a cash reserve for house purchase or other major items of capital expenditure.

He should have no concerns about transferring funds overseas. But there are other ways in which Laurent can make better use of his money. For example, he could change his current account to a high-interest cheque account with a bank such as Cahoot. He could also try being disciplined about how much cash he withdraws each week.

He should make sure his credit card has a low rate of interest. His provider charges 19.1 per cent. He would also gain from moving his savings from Barclays' high interest account, which does not pay a competitive rate of interest.

An internet savings account such as Nationwide e-savings or an Egg savings account would be better, or he could use a mini cash Isa, which means he gets his interest tax free. Smile is paying one of the best rates.

Gillian Cardy works for financial adviser Professional Partnerships

Adviser 2: Andrew Jones

If Laurent's company employs more than five staff, he will soon find he is offered a pension arrangement and, if he joins, he should be able to take the benefits to France with him.

The benefits cannot be taken until age 50, and only 25 per cent of the fund can be withdrawn as cash, with the remainder used to purchase an annuity.

Laurent's best option would be to set up a direct debit arrangement to take the agreed amount from his bank account each month. If he intends to save for three years or more, he could consider an equities Isa, but for a shorter period a cash Isa would be more appropriate.

If he returns to France, he can either leave his Isa invested, although he could not make further contributions, or cash it in and take the money with him.

Given his intention to return to France, Laurent may be considered non-domiciled in the UK. As such he can hold investments offshore, in the Channel Islands for example, which are not liable for UK tax unless the income or capital gains are brought back into the UK. He could consider investing offshore, although for smaller amounts an Isa may be more practical.

fields.headline: Savings secret that held Einstein in awe
fields.standfirst: Compound interest has been lauded as the eighth wonder of the world - and anyone can benefit, reports  Colin Cottell
fields.trailText: Compound interest has been lauded as the eighth wonder of the world - and anyone can benefit, reports Colin Cottell.
fields.body:
Compound interest has been called the financial world's best-kept secret by investment guru Jim Slater. Which is surprising given that Albert Einstein, Benjamin Franklin and John Maynard Keynes have all been credited with describing it as the eighth wonder of the world.

Take £5,000 and invest it in equities for 30 years at a growth rate of 18 per cent. Reinvest the dividends. Do not withdraw any capital. How much will your pot have grown to - £70,000, £150,000? The answer may surprise you: more than £700,000. That's compound interest. And the scenario is not beyond the realms of possibility: 18 per cent is the average growth rate of the UK stock market over the past 20 years. And though inflation and tax will reduce the real rate of return, even a growth rate of 10 per cent will see your original £5,000 grow to over £87,000 - a rate of return of more than 1,640 per cent.

Tom Stevenson, co-author with Jim Slater of How To Become A Millionaire , talks of the magic of 'compound interest' and describes it as a powerful force over time. But if, as he says, it's not rocket science what is the secret?

Interest on interest, says Neil Wright, a director in personal financial planning at PriceWaterhouseCoopers. Save a £1,000 a year for 25 years, and grow your money by 10 per cent a year without withdrawing any capital. After one year your pot will have grown to £1,100 - an increase of £100. After two years the increase will be £110, but after 25 years the final 10 per cent rise is worth £985 - nearly 10 times that in the first year. (See table.)After 25 years, because of compound interest, you end up with £10,835. However, had you withdrawn your interest at the end of each year you would have only £,3,500 (your original £1,000 plus 25 x £100).

So how does the ordinary investor or saver take advantage of such an extraordinary phenomenon?

The amount you end up with depends on how much you put in, the rate of return, and the number of years you keep the investments compounding. And as the absolute returns increase in the latter years, it is better to do so for as long as you can, says Tom Stevenson. But, he adds, there are other key factors. Taking out profits and interest will massively limit returns in the long run, especially if this is done in the early years. Ten per cent versus 13 per cent in one year isn't very much, but over 20-25 years it is significant. This is borne out by performance figures for UK unit trusts for the 10 years up to 18 December, says Neil Wright. For the basic- rate taxpayer, an investment of £100 in an average UK equity income would have grown to £347 had income been reinvested, but only £240 had the income been distributed.

Taxation is another negative factor. The effect of capital gains tax on a higher rate taxpayer is to reduce capital growth from 15 per cent to 9 per cent, which clearly reduces the ability of compounding to work its magic. Taxation is a very big factor if investment is not in a tax-exempt wrapper, says Stevenson. One of the easiest and most accessible ways of sheltering your investment is by making use of your Isa allowances, he advises.

Inflation is also a bugbear. Between 1959 and 1999 buying power reduced thirteen-fold, says Stevenson. What was £1 million then is worth £77,000 today, even though during most of that time the inflation rate was not enormous. Without compound interest on your side, maintaining the real value of savings is impossible, and the return on equity based investments is significantly reduced.

Though compounding can transform relatively small investments and savings into significant sums, it has its downside. For people who owe money it works in reverse, but no less powerfully. Compound interest explains why debt will increase exponentially if left unchecked, and why anyone doubling the repayments on their credit card will pay it off in less than half the time originally planned.

If that is still too much like rocket science, the rule of 72 demonstrates the power of compounding more easily. It tells you approximately how many years it takes for compound interest to double your money. Assuming a growth rate of 9 per cent a year £10,000 will become £20,000 in eight years (72/9). And after another eight years, it will have doubled again to £40,000.

Wright describes compound interest as a misunderstood concept (See example below.) Yet he says he has rarely if ever seen a client who understood the importance of whether interest is paid quarterly, six-monthly or annually. People look at the headline rate rather than the frequency, and as a result if it is paid less frequently they may be getting a worse rate than they thought, he says.

Say you start off with £1,000. Five per cent a year with interest paid quarterly means you get 1.25 per cent each quarter (5 per cent divided by 4 per cent). Multiply the £1,000 by 1.0125 and you get £1012.50. This is how much you will have after one quarter. Use this figure and multiply it by 1.0125. After 6 months you will have £1025.16. Do this twice more and at the end of the year your £1,000 will have grown to £1050.95, an annual rate of return of 5.095.

That's compound interest. Whether it is the eighth wonder of the world is questionable, but one thing is undeniable - if you let it, compound interest certainly grows on you.

webTitle: Heather Connon: Crouching tigers, hidden profits

fields.headline: Crouching tigers, hidden profits
fields.trailText: 'Over the last four years or so, investments in Korea, Brazil, Taiwan and the other countries which attract the emerging label have lagged well behind both the US and the British markets.'
fields.body:
Who would want to buy an emerging market fund? Over the last four years or so, investments in Korea, Brazil, Taiwan and the other countries which attract the emerging label have lagged well behind both the US and the British markets.

They are risky and volatile; anything from an unexpected hike in US interest rates to a crisis in Russia can send them careering downwards. And even the most sophisticated investor will have only a superficial idea at best of what makes their economies tick.

Why, then, are so many fund managers - Foreign & Colonial, Threadneedle and Aberdeen to name but three - so keen on these funds? The key reason, as so often for emerging markets, is the US. Interest rates have already been cut by 1 per cent since the start of the year and economists expect them to fall further. Falling interest rates are usually good news for stock markets generally, and high-risk ones particularly. Indeed, emerging markets have enjoyed a strong rally so far this year. But the experts think there should be much more to go.

For the last few years, it has been difficult to persuade anyone to put their money into emerging markets. Professional and private investors alike were chasing the technology bubble, rather than the Chinese dragon. Even now, retail investors are wondering whether it is time to go back into technology rather than thinking about alternative areas to look for growth.

The result is that the markets look cheap. Jeff Chowdhry, who runs F & C's emerging markets investment trust, estimates that the average emerging markets are valued at only half the rate of the US Standards & Poors 500 index, yet their economies are expected to grow more than twice as fast as those in the developed world.

The Asian and Russian crises were disastrous for emerging markets in the short-term but there were long-term benefits for the local economies. Companies are restructuring, exchange rates are now generally floating, rather than pegged to the US dollar at an artificial rate, costs are being cut and efficiency improved. The result, say the experts, is a better outlook for emerging markets than we have seen for years. That does not mean they are suitable for everyone. Emerging markets should only be considered by investors who already have a good spread of less risky investments, such as UK stocks and shares and European funds. They should also represent only a small part of your portfolio.

It is also best to choose a general emerging markets fund as investing in just one country will increase the risks. Investment trusts are a good way of taking a position in these markets. The fact that emerging markets have been unpopular means that discounts - the gap between the share price and the value of the underlying investments - is high. They could fall, adding an extra fillip to your investment. Among those which look attractive are F&C's fund, Templeton Emerging Markets and Aberdeen Emerging Economies.

fields.headline: Learn your lesson - it's worth £150
fields.standfirst: Andrew Bibby examines a new government training initiative
fields.trailText: Andrew Bibby examines a new government training initiative
fields.body:
Almost all schemes which claim to be able to transform £25 into £175 overnight are scams, to be put straight into the dustbin. The exception, however, may be a little-known new initiative from the government which effectively does just that.

The Individual Learning Account scheme, launched by the Department for Education and Employment last year, is the latest government ploy to persuade us of the value of life-long learning. The first million people to apply - and there appears to be a long way to go before this limit is reached - are eligible for a £150 grant towards the costs of studying, provided that they chip in with at least £25 of their own money.

The offer covers training courses which are obviously work-related but it also extends to more recreational activities. Whilst there won't be government money to encourage you, for example, to do an evening class in cake decorating, there could be assistance if you are planning to improve your surfing ability on the internet.

As well as the initial £150 grant, there is also an opportunity thereafter to benefit in future years from 20 per cent off the cost of training. For IT courses (including the popular CLAIT and European Computer Driving Licence courses) the discount on offer goes up to 80 per cent (£200 maximum per year), a measure of the government's enthusiasm in ensuring that we are prepared for the digital world.

However, driving lessons are excluded from ILA support, as are flying lessons, skiing tuition and what the government refers to as 'other activities where the outcome is in pursuit of leisure rather than learning'. School and higher education courses are also excluded, as are professional qualifications which are considered to be of degree equivalence or above. This means, for example, that Open University degree courses cannot attract ILA support, although, confusingly, some pre-degree OU courses are eligible. More positively, ILA incentives can be used for course books, exam fees and course software. Most training providers and colleges are now registered with the scheme, and should be able to advise on whether ILA discounts or grants are available to you when you sign up for courses.

Unfortunately (if predictably) the actual mechanism for accessing this support is cumbersome. The first government pronouncements on Individual Learning Accounts suggested that they would be quasi-monetary accounts, which could be topped up directly with government grants for use in training and adult learning. The reality is rather less radical, and much more like the now-withdrawn tax relief scheme for vocational training: the government simply reimburses course providers for the cost of the ILA incentives.

The first step is to apply to open an Individual Learning Account. The application form is available on www.my-ila.com, or from 0800 072 5678 (separate numbers apply outside England - see below). ILAs are restricted to people aged 19 and above.

How can I sign up?

England: 0800 072 5678

Scotland: 0800 072 0625

Northern Ireland: 0800 072 1888

Wales: contact your local Training and Enterprise Council

webTitle: Prince Charles new urban regenration initiative

fields.headline: Homes fit for a future king
fields.standfirst: Prince Charles's new initiative reflects his passion for urban regeneration, writes  Graham Norwood
fields.trailText: Prince Charles's new initiative reflects his passion for urban regeneration, writes Graham Norwood.
fields.body:
The Prince of Wales and property. We all know that he owns a lot of it - arguably at taxpayers' expense - and has an occasional outspoken interest in architecture. But there is another connection. He has created the Prince's Foundation (020 7613 8500), a new charity, to combine his interest in the environment with practical help on urban regeneration projects, heritage activities and the training of young architects and designers.

The project is symbolically based in a former warehouse in London's down-at-heel Hackney. Although the conversion into offices and studios has been lavish - hard-carved sculptures and polished wooden floors set the tone - much of the space is given over to classes and resources for young creative people.

During a typical day there have been sculptors and metalworkers using a basement studio, a life-drawing class, local children using facilities, and university students researching in its library - a creative hothouse in the centre of one of London's poorest boroughs.

'Everything we have here,' says chief executive David Lunts, 'is aimed at trying to highlight the importance of raising standards in the urban environment, whether it is for potential architects to study different forms, or for people from community projects to come in and use this as a resource centre to assist their housing estate. Put simply, people want and deserve nicer places to live.'

The foundation's initiatives include:

 A School of Architecture and Building Arts, including a traditional Islamic arts department. The Foundation Course teaches drawing, painting, photography, model-making and metal and woodwork all aimed at improving building design

 An Urban Villages Forum, periodically bringing together 400 leading housebuilders, planners, developers and urban designers to discuss how to make developments more sustainable

 The Phoenix Trust, which acquires, repairs and finds new uses for major historic buildings which otherwise might fall into decay - projects include a disused colliery at Penallta in south Wales, a former bakery in Devon and the Sowerby Bridge Canal Basin

 A project called Regeneration Through Heritage, which helps community groups develop long-term improvements to buildings and local environments in industrial areas

It is its community group support service which has most direct impact on ordinary people. It is involved in 18 projects in England and Wales, some of which existed before the foundation's involvement and get help through council and lottery funding as well as practical support from the foundation.

'We might send in a project manager to organise the local people, or train someone from a local community group to keep those skills for future work in the area,' says Olive Boles, director of corporate development.

One of the projects is at Devonport in Plymouth, where the foundation is working with residents, the local authority and development agencies to create an 'urban village' with coordinated housing, transport and economic infrastructure of shops and facilities.

The plans include improved job training for local people and moves to attract other industries to an area dominated by the naval dockyard.

At Everton Park in north Liverpool, where a 65 per cent population reduction since the 1970s has led to school closures and the loss of local services, the foundation has offered support to local residents. Together they have drawn up plans for 1,500 new homes for 4,000 people in the area.

The Prince sees the foundation as a way of working in the community - he often visits the Hackney office, sometimes at short notice - but the charity also has a more fundamental task, according to Lunts.

'He genuinely feels that most people want to live and work in a cleaner and more attractive environment, and that to a great extent they can provide that for themselves if they work with the right agencies and have some basic skills - and the skills are what we help provide.'

The project is symbolically based in a former warehouse in London's down-at-heel Hackney. Although the conversion into offices and studios has been lavish - hard-carved sculptures and polished wooden floors set the tone - much of the space is given over to classes and resources for young creative people. During a typical day there have been sculptors and metalworkers using a basement studio, a life-drawing class, local children using facilities, and university students researching in its library - a creative hothouse in the centre of one of London's poorest boroughs. fields.headline: Better by design
fields.trailText: An employer and a financial manager explain the attractions a stakeholder pension holds for each of them.
fields.body:
Wilson Harvey could be seen as a classic example of the kind of employer that the stakeholder pension was set up for. Most of its 33 employees are in their mid-twenties and have not started saving for their retirement. Stakeholder was envisaged as a lower-cost plan to encourage more people to start their pensions at a younger age.

The design company's managing director, Charlie Hoult, 33, has chosen a scheme from Standard Life. Previously he had been put off installing a company scheme because of high charges and doubts following the pensions mis-selling scandal. But he believes the Government has got things right with stakeholder.

He says: 'The annual management charge on our pension is 0.85 per cent, the minimum is just £20 a month, you can stop paying at any time and the flexibility of the whole package is good.

'There are also no transfer penalties and you can start taking the money out when you are 50.'

He chose Standard Life on the advice of his independent financial adviser. Wilson Harvey plans to make contributions into its new pension on behalf of employees. Hoult will now add stakeholder pensions to his list of perks alongside critical illness cover.

The staff certainly seem keen: 75 per cent have expressed an interest in signing up. Hoult thought only half would be interested.

Hoult jokes: 'I almost wish they hadn't because we will be contributing up to 3 per cent of their salary ourselves. If an employee earning £20,000 puts in £50 a month, we will also put in £50 a month.'

Liz Langdon, 25, an account manager with Wilson Harvey, says: 'Who can argue with a 3 per cent pay rise for doing nothing?'

The company scheme has come at just the right time for her. She says: 'I always said I would get a pension when I was 25. It is hard when you want to spend your money on going out, but it is sensible.'

Shocked into doing something

The publicity for stake-holder pensions has shocked financial manager Beth Cookson into looking at how she will provide for herself in retirement. 'It has made me realise that I can't rely on my husband's pension,' she says. 'I have a Tessa and want to take out an Isa, and I am likely to have a house when I reach retirement age - but they are not enough.'

Beth, 38, has not set aside any money for her retirement. She is now considering joining her company's stakeholder scheme. The company is setting up a scheme for 20 people.

Beth is attracted to the flexibility stakeholder pensions can offer. She says: 'I will be able to pay in very little at some points and much more at others.' She intends to save a couple of hundred pounds a month at first.

Stakeholder pensions at a glance

 Launched on 6 April this year.

 Built on the personal pension model, but with much lower charges. Maximum annual charge of 1 per cent; no initial charge.

 You can contribute up to £3,600 in a year (£2,808 by you, the rest in tax relief ) as a lump sum regardless of how much you earn or whether you earn at all.

 If you want to put more in you can, provided you don't breach limits, ranging from 17.5 per cent of post-tax earnings at 35, rising to 40 per cent at ages 61 to 74.

 It can be used at the same time as a company scheme to top up a pension if you earn less than 30,000 a year.

 Employers must offer access to a stakeholder plan from October this year but won't be obliged to contribute.

 It will be sold by insurers, banks and building societies.

 Employers may offer cheaper deals than the financial services companies; charges could be less than 1 per cent a year.

 If you contribute to a scheme nominated by an employer you can keep putting money in when you leave.

 There are no transfer penalties so you should be able to switch to another stakeholder at any time.

 It was originally aimed at people earning from around £9,500-£20,000, but advisers expect stakeholder pensions to be as popular with 'middle-earner' savers getting above the £20,000 mark, as with the less well off.

 You can make contributions for someone else such as a child or non-working partner.

 The choice of investment fund is likely to be more limited than with personal pensions. Index tracking funds are likely to dominate. People wanting a wider choice may want to look at personal pensions.

webTitle: Maria Scott: Get a Stakeholder pension - but lose a life

fields.headline: Get a Stakeholder pension - but lose a life
fields.trailText: 'There is quite a buzz about the imminent launch of the Stakeholder pension that suggests it could catch the public's attention where past pension schemes have failed.'
fields.body:
There is quite a buzz about the imminent launch of the Stakeholder pension that suggests it could catch the public's attention where past pension schemes have failed. Personal pensions, the Stakeholder's Tory predecessor, sold well but in millions of cases to the wrong people.

In contrast to its dealings with other areas of big busi ness, the Labour Government actually got tough with the pensions industry in putting a limit on charges for the Stakeholder. There were howls of protest but the industry has managed to launch schemes that meet the criteria and, in some cases, cut charges on old personal pension plans. The Stakeholder pension looks fit for its purpose, but whether it will sell in the numbers needed to lift middle-income earners away from dependence on the state is still in question.

As our lead feature this week points out, this requires a serious commitment to saving. If an employer will help you out, that's half the battle. But employers are increasingly reluctant to do so and employers are favouring stock market-linked schemes over salary-linked schemes. Individuals are having to take on greater responsibility for pensions and many will be on their own in future in meeting the demanding savings targets required for comfortable retirement. To a certain extent, getting a pension will mean losing a life because there will be less money available to enjoy yourself today.

Already advisers are reporting that the Stake-holder is attracting most interest from the young and upwardly mobile, in the £20,000-plus earning bracket, who can afford to save. People earning less may simply find it all too much.

General sentiment about the private pensions industry may also be an off-putting factor. As key players in the Equitable Life saga were hauled before the Treasury Select Committee last week to explain themselves, savers received a grim reminder that while you may not be able to trust a politician with your pension, you certainly can't be complacent about the private sector.

As the Government prepares for an election, it can probably count the Stake-holder as an achievement. But if take-up and contribution levels are poor, a second-term Labour Government might feel brave enough to require compulsory private pension provision.
