webTitle: Begin at birth - but it's never  too late

fields.headline: Begin at birth - but it's never  too late
fields.standfirst: It's best to start a fund early, but our action plan aims to help whatever your age
fields.trailText: It's best to start a fund early, but our action plan aims to help whatever your age.
fields.body:
In the cradle

You can now have a pension as soon as you are born. A doting relative can pay up to £3,600 a year into one of the Government's new stakeholder plans. For a basic rate taxpayer this works out at an outlay of £2,808 from April, after tax relief. It does not matter if the payment is made for someone who is not a taxpayer, but high-earning benefactors should note that they cannot claim the difference between basic rate tax and the higher rate, of 40 per cent.

The money can be paid from savings rather than earnings, as it was under the old personal pension rules. Given the powerful effect compound interest (see feature page 13) can have on small investments held over a long period of time, this could provide a child with a good start towards a reasonable pension.

In your twenties

For most of us, this is the point when retirement planning should begin.

Figures from insurer NPI show that a 25-year-old must put £233 a month, topped up to £299 by tax relief, into a stakeholder pension to achieve an income at 65 equivalent to £15,000 a year now. A 40-year-old with no pension would have to spend £451, or £579 after relief.

It is important for young women to build pensions of their own because of the way time off to bring up children can play havoc with income. Marriage breakdown later in life can stretch finances, and when you retire you discover that every pound saved could buy you 8 per cent less in income than a man (see 'in your sixties').

Twentysomethings seem acutely aware of the need to save for retirement, even though their spending may outstrip their commitment. A pension should not be the dominant financial aim if you have debts however.

Jackie Holmes, of accountant PriceWaterhouse Coopers, says: 'Probably the priority needs to be to pay off debt, and you have to look at affordability. It is important to look at what other commitments you have, especially if you have a mortgage.'

If your debts are under control, your priority should be an employer's scheme if it is available. 'It is a no-brainer that you should join it,' says Holmes.

The company will contribute up to 10 per cent of your salary to the fund, while you will pay, perhaps, 5 per cent. Some employers have pensions that require no contribution by the employee - a particularly valuable benefit.

If your employer has no scheme, the main option now is a personal pension, although from 6 April the new stakeholder pension will be available (for details see box). Employers without schemes of their own will be obliged to give access to stakeholder plans by October, and nominate a provider. But they won't have to pay into a stakeholder plan (see below).

Many insurance companies are already offering personal pensions that mirror the stakeholder plans they will offer from April, so these are worth considering.

But John Turton of adviser Best Pension says it may be worthwhile waiting to see what an employer offers, even if they do not contribute.

'If an employer introduces a scheme charging 0.7 per cent against an outside stakeholder charging 0.9 per cent, little things like that matter,' Turton says.

Don't forget that while a pension has good tax breaks - up to 40 per cent on contributions - you can also supplement pension savings with other forms of investments such as Individual Savings Accounts. If you delay starting a pension you should certainly still be setting aside long-term savings.

In your thirties

Act now if you want to have a pension equivalent to between half and two-thirds of your income. You may need to save more than 10 to 15 per cent of salary if you've done nothing so far.

A rule of thumb used by pensions experts suggests that to work out what you should be saving for retirement, halve your age and invest the equivalent percentage of income in your pension. So by your late thirties, if you've done nothing so far you need to start with contributions of nearly 20 per cent. If you took out a personal pension five years ago, paying £25 a month and have not increased contributions since you will almost certainly need to bump up contributions.

If you're starting from scratch an employer's scheme should be the first thing to look at. If you want to catch up on saving not done in your twenties, and you have access to an employer's scheme, look at its Additional Voluntary Contribution plan. If the employer will pay into your AVC it's hard to argue against this form of saving.

But you might also want to use a stakeholder pension. This is because the proceeds of AVC schemes must be used entirely to buy an annuity. Annuity rates are low and likely to remain so. A stakeholder scheme allows you to take 25 per cent of the maturity value as a cash lump sum which you might be able to invest for a higher return or use as you wish when you retire.

Pension rules limit the amount you can contribute to a company scheme - including AVCs - to 15 per cent of your salary. But if you earn less than £30,000 a year you can put another £3,600 into a stakeholder plan. Another option is the free standing additional voluntary contribution scheme (Fsavc), a private version of the company AVC.

Charges tend to be high and most people should consider their company scheme first and then a stakeholder.

If you don't have access to an employer's scheme, look at a stakeholder or, possibly, a low-cost personal pension.

If you want to save more than the rules allow, look first at other forms of saving with tax breaks, primarily Individual Savings Accounts where you can now contribute up to £7,000 a year. Then try investments that don't carry tax breaks, such as unit trust or investment trust savings schemes. Remember, there is nothing magical about a pension; it is merely a wrapper around investments that will one day provide an income.

If you took out a personal pension in your twenties you may be wondering whether to transfer your funds into a stakeholder plan, or to divert your monthly savings to one of the new schemes. Transfers can be expensive because of exit penalties.

Even so, Best Pension adviser John Turton has just done a forecast for a client who stands to have his £13,500 fund reduced by £5,600 on transfer.

'He will be 0.4 per cent better off he he jumps to stakeholder,' says Turton, who stresses that people usually need independent advice to work out whether a transfer is worthwhile.

For older savers with schemes that had high initial charges, a switch is less likely to be worthwhile. Others will want more choice of investment funds than is likely to be available in stakeholder plans.

Another issue is whether your personal pension firm plans to cut its charges to bring them in line with those of stakeholder plans.

Even if you started a pension in your twenties, planning can become trickier and more time consuming if you have taken career breaks to bring up children. Broken income means that you may not be able to afford to contribute to a pension.

Employers must continue to paying into occupational schemes for women on paid maternity leave. If you are receiving statutory maternity pay you will need to claim national insurance credits towards your state pension, though you should receive them automatically if are receiving maternity allowance. If you don't return to work, you should get automatic state pension credits after claiming child benefit for a year.

Mothers who do not carry out paid work will be able to save in a stakeholder pension, or their partners can contribute for them.

The thirties might be the time when you start a business, or become self-employed. You will then be on your own for pension provision. Stakeholder pen sions, or personal pensions are suitable for middle-income earners, but higher earners who like managing their investments might consider small self invested pension schemes (Sipps, see below), which allow you to choose your own, while contracting a specialist to do the administrative work.

Until recently these schemes were viable only for pension savers putting away £10,000 or more a year. But a new breed of internet-based Sipp providers is reducing costs and opening them to a wider audience.

The pioneer was Sippdeal, which has a start-up fee of £100 and a minimum dealing charge of £50.

If you are running a small business you may want to consider a Small Self Administered Scheme, which will allow your firm to invest in its own property, or to set up a company scheme (if you're employing more than five people, remember that you have to offer a stakeholder plan), but this is an area for specialist advice.

In your forties

Retirement is coming closer, so it is time for more detailed planning. If you have done nothing about a pension yet, you will be shocked by the large amount you will now have to contribute. From a standing start, you may need to save between 20 and 25 per cent of income. Even if you have been saving steadily, this is the time to think about when you will want to retire and whether you need to top up your savings. You can obtain a forecast for your state pension by asking for form BR19 from Department of Social Security offices.

Don't forget to ask about any entitlement to the State Earnings Related Pension Scheme (Serps), the top-up state plan for employees. Contact past employers' schemes for forecasts of what these might produce. If you've lost track of a past scheme, contact the Occupational Pensions Regulatory Authority (tel: 01273 627600) which operates a tracing service.

If you need to top up an employer's scheme you can, as in your thirties, use an AVC, buy extra entitlement through 'added years' schemes or use a stakeholder pension. If you are making your own arrangements, make sure you are paying enough into your plan to keep you on track. However, if you are catching up and have little money to spare consider whether you can really afford to lock away savings that cannot be accessed until you retire. If you expect to have to finance children through university, for example or to fund an endowment shortfall and you are also under-pensioned you may need to save in an Isa or through unit trusts or investment trusts that allow you access to your cash at short notice.

Don't forget that paying lump sums off a mortgage are a form of saving. Early repayment can save tens of thousands of pounds over the life of a mortgage, putting equity into a home that you might consider swapping for a smaller one when you retire. Another option might to buy property to rent out.

Many middle aged divorced women, in particular are now facing up to the possibility of financial difficulty in retirement because they had no independent pension. The courts can now split pensions between divorcing partners, giving one a transfer value from the other's scheme to put into a pension of their own. Alternatively the courts can make an 'earmarking' order allowing one partner to collect a pension in retirement from the other's scheme. The splitting arrangement is likely to become more common than earmarking as it allows for a clean break.

If you are in a stable, long-term relationship with a partner who has a good pension but you are not married, this may be the time to tie the knot. Some schemes do not automatically grant pensions to unmarried partners.

In your fifties

If you've saved steadily since your twenties, reviewed your pension regularly and knew you wanted to retire early, congratulations. You may now be able to cash in.

If you are 50 and want to retire at 55, however, the sad truth is that you are unlikely to be able to afford it unless you have worked continuously for an employer with a top scheme, and it is prepared to pay you a handsome early retirement settlement.

For many fiftysomethings, this will be a period of frantic catching-up, with retirement only years away. You need to review your pension forecasts (as for the forties, above) to see where you stand. A well funded personal pension may allow you to retire from 50 onwards.

If any part of your pension depends on a 'money purchase' arrangement - which means it is invested in the stock market, rather than depending on your salary - you need to start looking at whether money should be transferred from high-risk to medium or low-risk investments. Most schemes prompt you over this, but check if you hear nothing.

Start acquainting yourself with the finer points of annuities and their pitfalls. These provide annual income and are bought with the proceeds of money purchase pensions. A man of 65 retiring with a £10,000 fund today would receive less than £900 a year, while a woman might get only £800 because she is likely to live longer and need more income.

This does not provide for any form of inflation proofing or any repayment to your estate if you die within five years of taking the annuity. These guarantees would mean an even lower income.

If you are still topping up your pension you may need to weigh up the tax breaks on AVC contributions against the flexibility of investment outside pensions. If you are saving in AVCs you may want to consider diverting that money to something more flexible that does not require annuity purchase, but remember that returns from most forms of investment are likely to be in single figures, unless you take a big risk with your money.

In your sixties

If you haven't yet retired, look at whether any of your pension fund is invested in high risk funds. If you have money in AVCs or other 'money purchase' plans you need to start looking seriously at annuities.

Peter Quinton of specialist adviser the Annuity Bureau believes that as many as 50 per cent of buyers go to the company that managed their pension funds when they might raise their retirement income by at least 10 per cent per cent by shopping around.

Women reaching retirement will quickly discover that they do significantly worse out of annuities than men because of their longer lives.

A woman of 60 retiring with a £100,000 pension fund could expect less than £7,500 a year from one of the best annuities, against £8,029 for a man.

Another option is to consider a with profit annuity, where the income depends on bonus. Returns on these now compare favourably with those from conventional annuities, although they may not always give a higher return when you first retire. The hope is that income may rise, rather than remain static and at low levels as with a conventional annuity. The disadvantage is that your annual income is not guaranteed because returns on with profits funds vary from year to year.

For people with large funds, the main alternative to an annuity is an income drawdown plan, or a phased retirement scheme.

Both of these schemes involve leaving your pension fund invested to continue to growand drawing an income meanwhile, or taking sections of the fund to convert to annuities gradually.

You must convert pension funds to an annuity by the time you are 75. The Income Drawdown Advisory Bureau, a specialist adviser, usually recommends this only for investors with funds of at least £250,000.

Turton at Best Pension says another option for people who have non-pension investments they can live on is to leave the pension invested, and convert it into an annuity later.

Many insurance companies are already offering personal pensions that mirror the stakeholder plans they will offer from April, so these are worth considering. But John Turton of adviser Best Pension says it may be worthwhile waiting to see what an employer offers, even if they do not contribute. 'If an employer introduces a scheme charging 0.7 per cent against an outside stakeholder charging 0.9 per cent, little things like that matter,' Turton says. Don't forget that while a pension has good tax breaks - up to 40 per cent on contributions - you can also supplement pension savings with other forms of investments such as Individual Savings Accounts. If you delay starting a pension you should certainly still be setting aside long-term savings. In your thirties Act now if you want to have a pension equivalent to between half and two-thirds of your income. You may need to save more than 10 to 15 per cent of salary if you've done nothing so far. A rule of thumb used by pensions experts suggests that to work out what you should be saving for retirement, halve your age and invest the equivalent percentage of income in your pension. So by your late thirties, if you've done nothing so far you need to start with contributions of nearly 20 per cent. If you took out a personal pension five years ago, paying £25 a month and have not increased contributions since you will almost certainly need to bump up contributions. If you're starting from scratch an employer's scheme should be the first thing to look at. If you want to catch up on saving not done in your twenties, and you have access to an employer's scheme, look at its Additional Voluntary Contribution plan. If the employer will pay into your AVC it's hard to argue against this form of saving. But you might also want to use a stakeholder pension. This is because the proceeds of AVC schemes must be used entirely to buy an annuity. Annuity rates are low and likely to remain so. A stakeholder scheme allows you to take 25 per cent of the maturity value as a cash lump sum which you might be able to invest for a higher return or use as you wish when you retire. Pension rules limit the amount you can contribute to a company scheme - including AVCs - to 15 per cent of your salary. But if you earn less than £30,000 a year you can put another £3,600 into a stakeholder plan. Another option is the free standing additional voluntary contribution scheme (Fsavc), a private version of the company AVC. Charges tend to be high and most people should consider their company scheme first and then a stakeholder. If you don't have access to an employer's scheme, look at a stakeholder or, possibly, a low-cost personal pension. If you want to save more than the rules allow, look first at other forms of saving with tax breaks, primarily Individual Savings Accounts where you can now contribute up to £7,000 a year. Then try investments that don't carry tax breaks, such as unit trust or investment trust savings schemes. Remember, there is nothing magical about a pension; it is merely a wrapper around investments that will one day provide an income. If you took out a personal pension in your twenties you may be wondering whether to transfer your funds into a stakeholder plan, or to divert your monthly savings to one of the new schemes. Transfers can be expensive because of exit penalties. Even so, Best Pension adviser John Turton has just done a forecast for a client who stands to have his £13,500 fund reduced by £5,600 on transfer. 'He will be 0.4 per cent better off he he jumps to stakeholder,' says Turton, who stresses that people usually need independent advice to work out whether a transfer is worthwhile. For older savers with schemes that had high initial charges, a switch is less likely to be worthwhile. Others will want more choice of investment funds than is likely to be available in stakeholder plans. Another issue is whether your personal pension firm plans to cut its charges to bring them in line with those of stakeholder plans. Even if you started a pension in your twenties, planning can become trickier and more time consuming if you have taken career breaks to bring up children. Broken income means that you may not be able to afford to contribute to a pension. Employers must continue to paying into occupational schemes for women on paid maternity leave. If you are receiving statutory maternity pay you will need to claim national insurance credits towards your state pension, though you should receive them automatically if are receiving maternity allowance. If you don't return to work, you should get automatic state pension credits after claiming child benefit for a year. Mothers who do not carry out paid work will be able to save in a stakeholder pension, or their partners can contribute for them. The thirties might be the time when you start a business, or become self-employed. You will then be on your own for pension provision. Stakeholder pen sions, or personal pensions are suitable for middle-income earners, but higher earners who like managing their investments might consider small self invested pension schemes (Sipps, see below), which allow you to choose your own, while contracting a specialist to do the administrative work. Until recently these schemes were viable only for pension savers putting away £10,000 or more a year. But a new breed of internet-based Sipp providers is reducing costs and opening them to a wider audience. The pioneer was Sippdeal, which has a start-up fee of £100 and a minimum dealing charge of £50. If you are running a small business you may want to consider a Small Self Administered Scheme, which will allow your firm to invest in its own property, or to set up a company scheme (if you're employing more than five people, remember that you have to offer a stakeholder plan), but this is an area for specialist advice. In your forties Retirement is coming closer, so it is time for more detailed planning. If you have done nothing about a pension yet, you will be shocked by the large amount you will now have to contribute. From a standing start, you may need to save between 20 and 25 per cent of income. Even if you have been saving steadily, this is the time to think about when you will want to retire and whether you need to top up your savings. You can obtain a forecast for your state pension by asking for form BR19 from Department of Social Security offices. Don't forget to ask about any entitlement to the State Earnings Related Pension Scheme (Serps), the top-up state plan for employees. Contact past employers' schemes for forecasts of what these might produce. If you've lost track of a past scheme, contact the Occupational Pensions Regulatory Authority (tel: 01273 627600) which operates a tracing service. If you need to top up an employer's scheme you can, as in your thirties, use an AVC, buy extra entitlement through 'added years' schemes or use a stakeholder pension. If you are making your own arrangements, make sure you are paying enough into your plan to keep you on track. However, if you are catching up and have little money to spare consider whether you can really afford to lock away savings that cannot be accessed until you retire. If you expect to have to finance children through university, for example or to fund an endowment shortfall and you are also under-pensioned you may need to save in an Isa or through unit trusts or investment trusts that allow you access to your cash at short notice. Don't forget that paying lump sums off a mortgage are a form of saving. Early repayment can save tens of thousands of pounds over the life of a mortgage, putting equity into a home that you might consider swapping for a smaller one when you retire. Another option might to buy property to rent out. Many middle aged divorced women, in particular are now facing up to the possibility of financial difficulty in retirement because they had no independent pension. The courts can now split pensions between divorcing partners, giving one a transfer value from the other's scheme to put into a pension of their own. Alternatively the courts can make an 'earmarking' order allowing one partner to collect a pension in retirement from the other's scheme. The splitting arrangement is likely to become more common than earmarking as it allows for a clean break. If you are in a stable, long-term relationship with a partner who has a good pension but you are not married, this may be the time to tie the knot. Some schemes do not automatically grant pensions to unmarried partners. In your fifties If you've saved steadily since your twenties, reviewed your pension regularly and knew you wanted to retire early, congratulations. You may now be able to cash in. If you are 50 and want to retire at 55, however, the sad truth is that you are unlikely to be able to afford it unless you have worked continuously for an employer with a top scheme, and it is prepared to pay you a handsome early retirement settlement. For many fiftysomethings, this will be a period of frantic catching-up, with retirement only years away. You need to review your pension forecasts (as for the forties, above) to see where you stand. A well funded personal pension may allow you to retire from 50 onwards. If any part of your pension depends on a 'money purchase' arrangement - which means it is invested in the stock market, rather than depending on your salary - you need to start looking at whether money should be transferred from high-risk to medium or low-risk investments. Most schemes prompt you over this, but check if you hear nothing. Start acquainting yourself with the finer points of annuities and their pitfalls. These provide annual income and are bought with the proceeds of money purchase pensions. A man of 65 retiring with a £10,000 fund today would receive less than £900 a year, while a woman might get only £800 because she is likely to live longer and need more income. This does not provide for any form of inflation proofing or any repayment to your estate if you die within five years of taking the annuity. These guarantees would mean an even lower income. If you are still topping up your pension you may need to weigh up the tax breaks on AVC contributions against the flexibility of investment outside pensions. If you are saving in AVCs you may want to consider diverting that money to something more flexible that does not require annuity purchase, but remember that returns from most forms of investment are likely to be in single figures, unless you take a big risk with your money. In your sixties If you haven't yet retired, look at whether any of your pension fund is invested in high risk funds. If you have money in AVCs or other 'money purchase' plans you need to start looking seriously at annuities. Peter Quinton of specialist adviser the Annuity Bureau believes that as many as 50 per cent of buyers go to the company that managed their pension funds when they might raise their retirement income by at least 10 per cent per cent by shopping around. Women reaching retirement will quickly discover that they do significantly worse out of annuities than men because of their longer lives. A woman of 60 retiring with a £100,000 pension fund could expect less than £7,500 a year from one of the best annuities, against £8,029 for a man. Another option is to consider a with profit annuity, where the income depends on bonus. Returns on these now compare favourably with those from conventional annuities, although they may not always give a higher return when you first retire. The hope is that income may rise, rather than remain static and at low levels as with a conventional annuity. The disadvantage is that your annual income is not guaranteed because returns on with profits funds vary from year to year. For people with large funds, the main alternative to an annuity is an income drawdown plan, or a phased retirement scheme. Both of these schemes involve leaving your pension fund invested to continue to growand drawing an income meanwhile, or taking sections of the fund to convert to annuities gradually. You must convert pension funds to an annuity by the time you are 75. The Income Drawdown Advisory Bureau, a specialist adviser, usually recommends this only for investors with funds of at least £250,000. Turton at Best Pension says another option for people who have non-pension investments they can live on is to leave the pension invested, and convert it into an annuity later.

webTitle: How can I get a better rate for my savings?

fields.headline: How can I get a better rate for my savings?
fields.trailText: How can I get a better rate for my savings?
fields.body:
Investors stuck in a low-paying savings accounts are being advised to vote with their feet and move their money elsewhere by Which? , the Consumers' Association magazine.

Researchers found that banks and building societies were paying loyal savers a pittance while offering new customers better rates on savings accounts. It named Abbey National, Bristol & West and Woolwich as the worst offenders. All have live easy-access accounts that pay 1 per cent or less even on balances of £2,500. Which? compares this with Nationwide's Invest Direct account which pays 5.55 per cent on balances of just £500.

Some notice accounts also offer meagre returns, although restricted access is traditionally rewarded. Abbey National, NatWest and Woolwich offer accounts that pay savers less than 2.5 per cent on balances of £5,000. By contrast, Yorkshire Building Society's notice account pays 5.75 per cent.

If your money is languishing in one of the low-paying accounts, where can you find a better rate? Moneyfacts compiles charts of savings accounts rates that can be found in the Observer (page 14), on the personal finance sections of Ceefax or Skytext or on the at Moneyfacts website. Which? also publishes the rates in its monthly savings monitor.

Vicki Burn of Moneyfacts says the savings rate will depend on how much you have to invest and the mode of access you choose. Branch-based accounts tend to pay lower rates than those with postal, phone or internet access. She says: 'For example, on balances of £1-plus, Nationwide pays 5.3 per cent to postal account holders, 6.7 per cent to internet customers but 1.2 per cent to branch-based accounts.'

Those with notice accounts may have to wait until the notice period is up before they can switch accounts.

Remember just because an account offers a competitive rate today it doesn't mean it always will. Unless you keep a close eye on it you could find the rate has tumbled, and that other savers are getting better rates on newer accounts.

webTitle: The hard reality of our retirement prospects

fields.headline: Old age dream withers away
fields.standfirst: In the sixth of our fix your finances series,  Maria Scott looks at the hard reality of our retirement prospects
fields.trailText: In the sixth of our fix your finances series, Maria Scott looks at the hard reality of our retirement prospects.
fields.body:
Most of us think we will be better of when we retire than we really will, according to recent research, and our expectations have become less realistic in recent years.

The study by Barclays Bank last year looked at how well our pensions are measuring up against what we must save to achieve a comfortable retirement income. In 1996, the average 40 year old intending to retire at 65 on a pension of two thirds salary should have saved £164 a month in a private pension, but was actually contributing only £100. By 2000, the same person should have paid in £226 a month, but was saving only £138. So there was a 37.5 per cent rise in what the bank calls the 'misery gap'.

The contribution needed from a private pension goes up every year because UK state pensions are falling in comparison with average earnings. The basic pension has risen in line with prices rather than earnings since the early Eighties, when the Thatcher government scaled back state provision. The effect was gradual, but two decades on pensioners are feeling the pinch.

Many adults still think the state will provide for them. Forty-three per cent of those in the Barclays survey expected their living standards in retirement to be better than at work. A third had no private pension.

Of those that did have private cover, 45 per cent saved less than £50 a month. A little over a fifth put in less than £25 a month and 27 per cent were saving, but had no idea how much.

Yet nearly 80 per cent of those questioned wanted to go on at least one holiday abroad every year in their old age. Two thirds expected to be able to afford to eat out and make regular trips to the theatre or cinema.

The reality for people already living on pensions was very different, Barclays found. Forty per cent of them were living on less than £10,000 a year, while 57 per cent wished they had planned better.

Barclays, of course, wants to sell pensions. But the charity Age Concern has no doubt that life for many pensioners is a struggle. It points to Government statistics showing that the median income of single pensioners after housing costs two years ago was £88 a week , or £4,576 a year, and £195 a week (£10,140 a year) for couples. This compared with average full-time earnings of £384.50 a week (£19,994 a year).

Elderly people have begun to get militant about the state pension - a 75p increase in the basic state pension last April angered many of them - and the Government has begun to feel uncomfortable about their clout as voters.

In April there will be an above-inflation £5 rise in the basic pension for single people, to £72.50 a week, and £115.90 for couples. But the Government refuses to restore the link between pensions and average pay.

Age Concern says if the basic state pension had kept pace with average earnings a single pensioner would be looking forward to a weekly income of £101.15 from April, while couples would be getting £161.70.

Instead, the Government is putting more emphasis on means testing. Its 'minimum income guarantee' ensures £92.15 a week for single people from April and £140.55 for couples. But the gap between the basic pension and the minimum guarantee is made up of income support, a means-tested benefit based on a person's own income and savings. This is not given automatically, and around 700,000 pensioners who are entitled to it do not receive it.

Means testing can penalise people who have saved enough to disqualify them from a state top-up, but not enough to make them significantly better off. The Government is working on a plan to remedy this, to be called the 'pensioners' credit'. This will give credits for savings up to a certain level, but the mechanics are complex. It is also introducing the low-cost stakeholder pension, making it cheaper and easier to save for retirement (see below).

Age Concern asks whether it is worth people on low incomes saving for retirement if this just disqualifies them from state help.

Rhian Beynon, an official of the charity, says: 'Ideally everyone should be saving for the future but it may be that you will save and still end up on income support.

'The issue is whether they want to be dependent on means testing. One reason people may want to save for the future is that they will extricate themselves from that.' So what does it take to comfortably avoid means testing?

Most pensions experts suggest aiming for a retirement income of at least half, and preferably two thirds, of what you will be earning when you retire. Jackie Holmes, senior manager of personal financial planning at accountant PricewaterhouseCoopers, explains: 'If you take public sector pension schemes as a blueprint, after 40 years you are looking for a 50 per cent pension and a lump sum of one and a half times pay at retirement.'

Private sector pension schemes aim to provide two-thirds of a member's final salary and a smaller lump sum. To achieve this you need to save about 10 to 15 per cent of your income, including employers' contributions - for your entire working life. If you start late, the saving required increases dramatically.

The antics of the pensions industry will have knocked many people's faith in this form of saving. The mis-selling scandal, where salesmen persuaded millions to cash in good employers' schemes to buy poorer-value personal pensions, seemed to make a nonsense of the message that saving for retirement was always worthwhile. Confidence in occupational pensions was knocked by the Maxwell scandal and recently the crisis at Equitable Life, one of the top names in the business, has raised questions about entrusting one's savings to large institutions in a country where regulation seems regularly to fail small investors.

Yet pensions are not the only way to save for old age. They are increasingly seen as inflex ible. Contributions to them benefit from tax relief, but the proceeds of Isa saving plans are tax-free. The boom in buy-to-let homes shows that many people see property as a ticket to a pension. Another option is to retire to a country with lower living costs.

Increasingly, the notion of retirement as leaving the workforce altogether is being questioned. If the demographers are correct, a shortage of young labour will soon force employers to rely on older workers - a trend likely to be helped by the new Government proposal to end the formal retirement age.

If you are determined not to work past a certain point, though, the only answer is to save - and save consistently.

Pension schemes unscrambled

Basic state scheme

Paid for by National Insurance at full amount if you have a full NI record. Will be £72.50 a week for a single person from April, £115.90 for a couple.

Minimum income guarantee

Means-tested top-up for low-income pensioners: £92.15 for singles from April and £140.55 for couples.

SERPS

State earnings-related scheme built up through National Insurance when you work for an employer. Some company schemes contract out of Serps and pay equivalent benefits.

Graduated pension

State scheme from 1961 and 1975. Older workers may have entitlements.

Second state pension

Planned for introduction in next two years as replacement for Serps. Another earnings-related scheme for the employed (rather than self-employed) but aimed at people on low incomes, particularly those earning up to £10,000. Benefits for higher earners will be scaled down and eventually they will be encouraged to contract out.

Stakeholder pensions

To be launched in April for people earning £10,000 or more to provide for themselves if they don't have access to an employer's scheme

Occupational pensions

Run by employers in two varieties: final salary, where pensions are paid according to earnings, and the more risky money purchase variety, where contributions go into investments to build a fund that buys an annuity.

Personal pensions

Tory forerunner to the stakeholder. Funds invested; aimed at the self-employed and employed with no access to company schemes. They were discredited by high charges and mis-selling, but will continue to be available after stakeholders come in. They may offer a wider choice of funds. A variation is the group personal pension, offered by smaller employers.

Individual pension account

Another new scheme from the Government due for launch on 6 April. The aim is for it to allow unit trust and investment trusts to make their products available as pensions. It will be similar to a personal pension but charging structures should be easier to understand. Won't have capped charges, as stakeholder plans will.

AVCs

Additional Voluntary Contribution plans: top-up schemes offered by employers.

FSAVCs

Top-up schemes from insurers. Charges are usually higher than company plans.

SIPPS

Self-invested personal pension plans. DIY plans for people who like to manage their own investments. Becoming more affordable with launch of internet schemes.

SSASS

Small Self Administered Schemes - for small companies offering a wide range of investment options.

fields.headline: Lovers of the Left
fields.standfirst: He was a hardliner in prison over his poll tax campaign. She flew the world, teasing him with postcards saying 'Wish you were here'.   As Tommy Sheridan again faces the threat of jail,  Arnold Kemp  meets the couple who put the heart back into politics
fields.trailText: He was a hardliner in prison over his poll tax campaign. She flew the world, teasing him with postcards saying 'Wish you were here'.   As Tommy Sheridan again faces the threat of jail,  Arnold Kemp  meets the couple who put the heart back into politics
fields.body:
Tommy Sheridan is a well-dressed working-class hero with film-star looks who frightens the life out of New Labour, an ideologue with high-octane charm. His wife Gail is an elegant British Airways stewardess who once helped to lead a strike against the airline. Together they are investing the political Left with a glamour it has perhaps never known.

When Tommy was first in jail for contempt of court, in 1991 after his campaign against the poll tax, their romance, intermittent since their school days, was starting to blossom. Gail says when he was in jail she used to send him teasing 'wish-you-were-here' postcards from exotic places, 'for badness'.

Last July they got married after living together for eight years. By December Tommy was in prison again, serving five days at Greenock for failing to pay a fine after a demo against the Trident nuclear submarine base at Faslane. And if Tommy goes to prison once more, after the demo on 12 February at Faslane when he and 372 others were arrested, Gail will, if BA schedules permit, be waiting at the prison gates when he gets out.

She is a committed member of his Scottish Socialist Party, which plans to contest all 72 Scottish seats in the general election. The party subscribes to the Socialist Alliance, descended from the proscribed Militant Tendency and the old poll tax protests.

It is targeting the dissatisfied Labour Left and is fielding about 65 candidates in England, standing in the constituencies of 20 Ministers, including Jack Straw, David Blunkett and Geoff Hoon.

But it is leaving Peter Mandelson's Hartlepool to Arthur Scargill and his Socialist Labour Party. Characteristically, Scargill is not returning the compliment and is not planning to co-operate with the alliance.

If Gail has a complaint, it is that with her travels and his obsessive workload as an MSP and Glasgow councillor they see too little of each other. Another bone of contention is that she earns more than he does - he gives half his pay to the party. 'It's a constant source of ribbing,' he says.

On Thursday, St Valentine's night, Tommy was on a three-line whip. Gail closed the curtains and took the phone off the hook at their home in Cardonald, near Glasgow, for a rare hour or so of privacy.

Gail and Tommy were always attracted to each other, but their love ripened slowly. Both are 37. He grew up in Pollok, she in nearby Cardonald, and they went to the same school.

His mother was an active trade unionist and his father helped to run the local football team, Pollok United, washing the strips every week. Her family originally came from Govan, where her father and her grandfather worked in the shipyards.

He went to Stirling, discovering Marx and the Militant Tendency. She studied social sciences for a couple of years before joining British Airways. After a spell in London she returned to Glasgow, where she is now based, flying on the shuttle and European routes.

From time to time they bumped into each other. She says: 'When we were about 18 we'd had a wee liaison - and then again when we were about 23. Then, when he was going into prison, I met him in the local pub. Tommy doesn't drink, but he would go in with his pals. He said he was going to prison. I couldn't quite believe he was really serious.

'They joked that I'd written him a letter in prison amid the hundreds he was getting. This is where our story differs. He wrote to me. I did send postcards, for badness, from places like Paris and Barbados. I would write, "Having a wonderful time, hope you are too".'

She admits she gets fed up sometimes. 'Of course. Tommy is in the sort of job where it's constant. It's not just the early morning and coming home late at night. It's non-stop. The phone goes constantly. And then it's on his days off.

'This is just the way it is and I'm not going to slag it - he's a public figure and public figures, their time is never their own. And he's got to watch the television and read the papers.

'And when you go into the town with Tommy, to the pictures say, then everybody stares and people keep coming over to talk to him. They say nice things. He's never had anybody shout something bad or anything like that.

It's always "Brilliant, Tommy", things like that. You'll get people saying, "I don't support your policies but I really admire you". It gives you a big boost, but it doesn't make a nice romantic night out.'

Did she agree with his politics? 'Absolutely. I'm a trade unionist. I was a shop steward in the British Airways strike in 1997. I've always heavily been involved. My family are very steeped in it.'

After the arrests at Faslane the police are sending reports to the procurator-fiscal. Tommy is not sure whether he or any of the 372 others held, including the maverick MP George Galloway and 15 clerics, will be prosecuted.

After last year's demo about 25 per cent of those arrested came before the courts. Sheridan is taking his stand on an issue of principle - on the point, now before an appeal court, that the Trident base is illegal under international law because it is a weapon which does not discriminate between military and civilian targets.

He is ready, though hardly eager, for another jail sentence.

'It's not something I look forward to. It's not a pleasant experience. I feel the actions I took last year were helpful to the cause and I will continue to take those actions. There's a matter of principle here.'

webTitle: Nuclear subs 'poisoned my family' cast shadow of cancer

fields.headline: Nuclear subs 'poisoned my family' cast shadow of cancer
fields.standfirst: Family struck by double tragedy demands inquiry as Trident contractor plans to release more radiation
fields.trailText: Family struck by double tragedy demands inquiry as Trident contractor plans to release more radiation
fields.body:
The first time anyone knew something was wrong was when Lorraine Kelly felt a lump on her husband Paul's stomach. She persuaded him to see a doctor. The diagnosis was cancer.

Three years later he died, aged 47, and now his brother, Peter Kelly, is going to the High Court for answers. He also wants to know why his daughter, Sarah, developed cancer when she was eight.

He believes the cause of his family's tragedy lies just yards from his home where the nuclear submarines dock at Plymouth's Devonport naval base. Paul had worked for months as a roofer in the site, sometimes carrying out projects within the submarine compound. Sarah grew up in its shadow, in one of the tightly packed streets that nestle right up to the docks.

'I don't want anything else to happen to my family,' Peter Kelly said. 'I want to know if we are safe or not.'

Kelly has launched a legal fight to have a public hearing held into the environmental risks of the work that goes on at Devonport's nuclear dock and a plan to increase radioactive discharges.His case is expected to be heard within the next three months.

DML, a company that is going to refit the Trident nuclear submarines, wants to boost the amount of tritium released into the River Tamar by 700 per cent and into the atmosphere as steam by 500 per cent.

Tritium is radioactive water used as a coolant in submarines' reactors. DML has also applied for permission to emit radioactive carbon-14 and argon-41.

Company officials insist their plans are safe and that levels of radiation would be indistinguishable from natural background radiation. 'We take our environmental and public health responsibilities very seriously indeed,' a DML spokesman said.

But some scientists have concerns. Tritium's radiation passes easily into the human body because it is carried by water molecules. Also known as 'heavy water', it was used in the Seventies to make luminous exit signs and phone dials, but was banned because it was thought to be too dangerous. Tritium radiation fixes firmly to chemicals in human cells, including DNA, by a process called organic bonding. This can then disrupt a cell when it replicates, leading to mutations, which in turn can lead to cancer.

With a half-life of 12 years, tritium could build up in the Tamar estuary and eventually enter the human food chain. Most of the tritium released at Devonport is piped directly into the river in an area rich in wrecks and sealife and popular with diving clubs.

Another possible concern is tritium fog, condensing from effluent released by the docks into the air. Tritium has a higher freezing point than water and so could condense into a fine mist indistinguishable from normal fog.

Concerns about the possible risks for pregnant women, whose foetuses may be vulnerable to tritium radiation, were raised by Dr Ian Fairlie, a radiation biologist who works as an independent consultant. 'I would advise all pregnant women not to be near the docks when the emissions are taking place. I don't think that is an unreasonable request at all.'

DML, however, insists the risks are small. Tritium can be produced naturally from cosmic rays reacting with the atmosphere. DML also says its proposed emissions are within government safety guidelines. 'We are being as careful as we can,' a spokesman said.

But critics point out it was only two years ago that DML discovered it had unknowingly been producing radioactive carbon-14 as a waste prod uct. Carbon-14 can be dangerous if ingested.

DML's parent company, Brown and Root, paid $750 million after being sued for mismanaging a nuclear construction project in Texas.

Residents and environmentalists are concerned that Plymouth is becoming a nuclear dumping ground for the whole country. As well as becoming the sole British yard for refitting Trident submarines, Devonport is also to become a future site for storing up to 26 nuclear reactors from submarines going out of service.

The council has put an emergency radiation leak plan on its website which reads like a throwback to the Cold War. It advises people to stay indoors and take iodine tablets to thwart the effects of radiation.

A special plan, called DevPubSafe, has been developed for those living in and around the docks. The local primary school nearest the naval base, Barne Barton, has an annual nuclear emergency drill.

Certainly Sarah Kelly, now aged 20, is afraid. After five years of chemotherapy her thyroid cancer went into remission, though she still has to have annual checks. She is concerned for her young son, Harry, born on the day Paul Kelly died.

'You just worry about it all the time now. You can't go swimming in the river or walking down the streets without wondering what exactly you might be breathing in,' she said.

webTitle: A call centre job? That's the real pits

fields.headline: A call centre job? That's the real pits
fields.standfirst: Mining just refuses to die. Scotland's last deep mine has 130 vacancies and no shortage of potential recruits, drawn by camaraderie and tradition, reports  Burhan Wazir
fields.trailText: Mining just refuses to die. Scotland's last deep mine has 130 vacancies and no shortage of potential recruits, drawn by camaraderie and tradition, reports  Burhan Wazir.
fields.body:
What is better than working in a call centre? The unlikely answer, in the post-industrial age, is going down the pit. The last deep mine in Scotland has begun recruiting after receiving a £17.5 million lifeline from the European Commission, one of six mines in the UK to do so. And among the applicants for the 130 vacancies are former miners who ended up working in call centres.

It's not simply a question of better wages - in fact the pay offered by the private mining company Scottish Coal at Longannet, Fife, is only marginally better than what can be earned at call centres. Wages can peak at £500 a week with overtime and bonus, but the average take-home wage is about £350. It's more a matter of comradeship, tradition and the revival of skills that seemed in danger of being lost. Among the jobs will be 30 new apprenticeships for electri cians and mechanical engineers. The news has raised the spirits of the mining communities dependent on Longannet's 650 jobs.

Jim 'Chuckles' Hunter, 49, stands near the entrance to the mine shaft. The 1pm shifters clamber into a caged trolley that will eventually lower them 400 feet beneath the surface.

'They're a good bunch, you get some real characters around here,' says Hunter, who inherited his nickname from his father.

Hunter started mining in 1967 in nearby Blairhall; his father was a miner before him. 'My Dad had chest complications in the end: y'know dust in his lungs.'

Last summer, routine tests at Longannet discovered that nine miners at the colliery had developed pneumoconiosis, or black lung. The condition, which can often lead to debilitating and sometimes fatal respiratory disease, was thought to have disappeared with the introduction of new safety measure introduced in the 1970s.

Under regulations introduced in 1975 miners are only supposed to work seven-hour shifts, but many work overtime. Miners are also expected to have lung X-rays every five years, but at Longannet, only around 70 per cent of men took part on the last occasion.

But Hunter still wants his son, Ryan, to follow him into mining. Wiping coal dust off his face, he says: 'The apprenticeship would be good for him. And mining is a lot safer these days.' He motions down the mine shaft where the latest shifters are joshing their way down to the coal face. 'Besides, where else do you get camaraderie like this?'

Nearby, a group of miners stand sharing cigarettes and swigging cups of tea. Their faces scarred with dirt, their uniforms filthy, the miners look like refugees from another age. But they resist the notion that they are the last of a dying breed.

'I wouldn't see it that way,' says Hunter. 'Maybe we'll see a renaissance in the mining industry. Maybe, 50 years from now, the sons of sons who once worked here will still have jobs.'

The last 30 years have seen the emergence of the 'industrial gypsy' - the jobbing miner who moves from mine to mine. 'I've been moved on virtually every five years,' says Andy Lapsley, 44. 'I guess I shouldn't complain because I've always had work.'

Lapsley has been mining in and around Fife since 1977, with spells at Bowness and Castlehill. 'It creates a lot of uncertainty in the family,' he says. 'You're always wondering when the pit will close. Would I want my kids to come down the mine? I don't think so: I'd rather they had something a bit more stable.

'There's been a lot of uncertainty for a few years now,' says Ramsay Dow, colliery manager at Longannet, owned by Scottish Coal Ltd. Tonnage at the mine was affected by geological difficulties last year - the 2000 total of 1.2 million tonnes should reach 2m by the end of this year. 'That would comfortably see us into a profit,' continues Dow. 'And hopefully, the new jobs will reinvigorate the surrounding area.'

He says optimistically: 'Who knows? Perhaps this is an industry that isn't on its last legs at all.'

Nicky Wilson, general secretary of the National Union of Mineworkers (Scotland) sits at his desk in Longannet's union cabin, within paces of the mine shaft. Behind him, two photographs of topless models decorate an otherwise bare wall - not the sort of thing you see in call centres.

'Of course, this is still a macho society,' says Wilson. 'There aren't that many jobs; so the men keep their spirits up with jokes. It's difficult being an outsider here. We've had workers come in from England - and that does seem to fuel a little resentment on behalf of the local workforce.'

On Tuesday, the Department of Trade and Industry announced a £60 million package to aid six British coal mines. The European Commission approved government support for Blenkinsopp, in Northumbria; Harworth, in Nottinghamshire; Hatfield, Maltby, and Rossington in the Doncaster area, South Yorkshire, and Selby in North Yorkshire.

fields.headline: Thorpe's new lease of life
fields.standfirst: England's middle-order batsman tells how his break from touring has made him a more rounded player
fields.trailText: Exclusive interview: Hero of Pakistan Tour looks ahead to Sri Kanka and the Ashes.
fields.body:
Graham Thorpe is the man,' wrote Arjuna Ranatunga in these pages last week before rather tempering the compliment by adding: 'What can I say, the man plays like me.' Nasser Hussain has been even more generous. 'Thorpe is the key man for us again on this trip,' he said. 'Muralitharan does not do as well against left-handers as right-handers and we are hoping Graham can capitalise on that.'

Thorpe is now the middle-order mainstay of the England batting line-up. He is the man who can build on a good start, who can help England, perhaps more than any other batsman, to a formidable total; the man who can keep his head down when all about him are losing their wickets. When England were dismissed for 46 in Trinidad in 1994 it was Thorpe who batted for an hour and half to make a gritty three. He is adept against pace and flourishes against spin. It is this last quality that will be crucial in the Test series against Sri Lanka, starting this week, and in the Ashes contest in the summer.

Given their current run, it is hard to believe that the last time Australia visited England, they found themselves one-nil down after the second Test. In the first, they were bowled out by Caddick (5-50) and Gough (3-43) before Hussain (207) and Thorpe (138) put on 288 and batted England to victory. In the next, Hussain and Thorpe were again the top scorers, but this time with 19 and 21, and the rain saved England. Thereafter it was less a contest than an embarrassment as England stumbled from innings defeat to innings defeat and ended up selecting both the Hollioakes.

Things can only get better, but don't expect Thorpe to become carried away. 'Ideally, this summer we want to be competitive against Australia. I haven't played in a series against them where it's been tooth and nail. And last time they were here even though we went 1-0 up they just went into another gear.

The Aussies have set the benchmark. They are miles ahead. Miles ahead.' Not very gung-ho, no echoes of Tony Greig's 'We'll make them grovel' there, but it can't be a coincidence that since those in charge of English cricket started talking small they have exceeded expectations rather than depressed them. Ever since those in charge of the game admitted England were not very good - a no-brainer of a confession after you've lost, by a fair way, at home to New Zealand - the team have been playing half-decent cricket.

This new approach is evident as Thorpe talks you through the recent tour of Pakistan, where England were expected, at best, what with Saqlain and the other spinners and the fact we couldn't play spin, to nick a couple of draws. 'We hung on to the reins for the first two Test matches,' says Thorpe. 'In Lahore we made it safe and in Faisalabad it was a matter of staying in there. Then when it came to the crunch we were able to put our foot down.'

Traditionally - recent tradition, anyway - when it comes to the crunch, English cricket crumbles. This time they accelerated. Albeit very carefully. 'Going into the last day most of us thought it could and probably should be a draw. Then Nasser and Fletch [coach Duncan Fletcher] and I came together in the physio's room at lunch to work out a strategy for what might happen. If the target was five an over we would have sent in the main hitters. Alec [Stewart] would have opened, Craig White would have gone in at three and Hicky at four and I was going to come down to six or seven. But as it was four an over we stuck with the normal batting line-up and I was going to be held back in case we had to play for a draw.'

With the benefit of hindsight and ignoring recent English cricket history, I interrupt to suggest this was a bit negative. 'It can happen,' says Thorpe. 'I've seen it fall apart very quickly. And if they'd picked up four or five wickets with 20 overs to go and everyone's round the bat... ' Enough said. 'We didn't want to be too reckless. And I wasn't even going to bat and didn't have my pads on and then the leggy came on, which was good for me what with the rough, and Naz said, "Get your pads on".' And Thorpe went out and achieved exactly what he had envisaged achieving earlier in the day. 'While I was fielding I was thinking what a great game this would be to win. What a great time to get 50 not out and win.' He reached 50 but he was still not confident of the win.

'The last four or five overs were worrying. We were so close when Hicky got out and I was concerned when Naz came in and I asked Steve Bucknor if he would offer the light to the fielding side and he said he wouldn't.'

Would he have done so if there had been a big crowd in? 'No, but there might have been a riot and we'd have been off for that. It was very dark. I've never played in conditions like that. I took a few risks, got 10 in an over and we were over the wire. In a matter of minutes there was complete darkness. It was the highest point of most of our careers.'

The 'our' is significant. One of Fletcher and Hussain's successes is that they preside over a cohesive unit. 'I've always thought there was talent in England,' says Thorpe. 'It was just being led in the wrong direction. But now they've given us a great deal of confidence to be ourselves. Fletcher is a very shrewd guy and I like the way he operates.' 'When it's work time it's work time, but at other times you can let your hair down. That fits my character. I've never been a great one for wearing the right trousers or making sure I've shaved for the second or third day in a row. Naz summed it up when he said this feels like our team. It has the feeling of a county side. The players feel very much wanted and part of it.'

It is clear that Thorpe's enthusiasm for the game has returned; yet only a year ago, when he decided to spend his winter with his family rather than among South Africans, it was on the wane. 'I was 30 when I made the decision and genuinely concerned by my lifestyle. It was constant cricket. Constant cricket. And my young family was not fitting into it at all. I needed some balance in my life.'

After 10 consecutive years touring, last Valentine's Day was the first one he had ever spent with his wife, Nicky. He was in Sharjah when his daughter was born. Before his break, Nicky said: 'We don't have Sundays. Weekends for us haven't existed for 10 years.' 'Missing a tour hadn't been done for years,' says Thorpe, 'and a few people thought I shouldn't have done it. But it was important that I spend a lot of time with my family knowing that I might not come back. If two or three people score fantastic runs you're history.'

Surprise, surprise, that didn't happen. Instead, Thorpe returned from his family break - 'It's a godsend to find out we can all live with each other' - a more relaxed performer. 'There's no fear, now. When you're playing constantly the very small things can become very important. I don't worry about my stats any more, but I do worry about my family. I worry about how the kids are progressing, not whether I'm averaging 35 or 45.'

It is an approach that worked in Pakistan when, on his first tour since the break, he easily topped the batting averages with a mark over 50. And one that helped him overcome his embarrassment after Courtney Walsh bamboozled him with a slower ball on his return to the team . 'Yeah, that was a great return. If I'd been weary I would have tried to find a reason why it happened and condemned myself and felt sorry for myself. But I saw Mike Atherton in the dressing-room having a giggle to himself and so I had a giggle too.'

Atherton is another who seems more at ease in the new surroundings. 'He's been in great form ever since Duncan Fletcher came in,' says Thorpe. 'He's an old cynic, really. When we were playing the West Indies and everyone was trying to bowl me slower balls Athers would be at the other end pissing himself and I'd look up and see that and it was great.'

Despite all their protestations to the contrary, perhaps this England side can giggle and weave their way to an Ashes victory. Before that, though, they have to follow the Pakistan success in Sri Lanka. And the last time Australia - the team who are 'miles ahead, miles ahead' - toured there they were defeated. So the official line must be that England have no chance. They will do well to eke out a draw. Just remember to keep a straight face when you're predicting it.

fields.headline: Saudis wrong
fields.trailText: No one doubts the right of the authorities in Saudi Arabia to investigate serious crimes committed on their soil (Focus, last week). But the television 'confessions' of Alexander Mitchell and others to bombings in Riyadh are a serious worry to all who care about due legal process.
fields.body:
No one doubts the right of the authorities in Saudi Arabia to investigate serious crimes committed on their soil (Focus, last week). But the television 'confessions' of Alexander Mitchell and others to bombings in Riyadh are a serious worry to all who care about due legal process.

Recent reports indicate that the Saudi authorities are riding roughshod over international standards concerning access and lawyers - most especially the UN's 'basic principles' specifying that all detainees should get lawyers within 48 hours. The truth is that the Saudis have violated these and other rights on countless occasions. It is high time that Britain's diplomatic kid-gloves came off.
Maggie Paterson
Communications Director
Amnesty International UK

 Brilliant. After four years of Government, David Blunkett concludes that children from poor families should have the same access as wealthy ones to new sports, music coaching etc (News, last week).

Community projects by residents in deprived areas have been doing this for years. The project with which I am a volunteer in Easterhouse, Glasgow, arranges horse-riding, street hockey, art sessions, music. Now that an unemployed teenager has won a pop singing contest, it is paying for coaching from a professional with a view to making demonstration tapes. Projects rooted in their neighbourhoods are aware of both the wishes of and the talents of local young people. Yet Mr Blunkett's New Labour constantly refuses to ensure that projects organised by people at the hard end receive adequate funding.
Bob Holman
Easterhouse
Glasgow

 Congratulations to the Government on ditching 35 years of a failed comprehensive education system. It is common sense to have IQ testing in order to match a child's ability to a suitably designed educational course at a level the pupil feels most comfortable with. Mixed ability classes never worked and created more problems than they solved. The refusal of educational psychologists to admit this is part of the deep malaise in education.
M. Bell
Motherwell, Lanarkshire

 Now that Tony Blair has decided to abandon another core Labour Party policy (comprehensive education), is there any point in continuing to pretend the Labour Party still exists? The arrogance of New Labour was demonstrated by Blair's éminence grise, the supposedly politically neutral Alastair Campbell, who dismissed comprehensive schools as 'bog standard'.
Leslie Moody
London SE3

 Mr Blunkett acknowledges that life and learning should be buttressed by easier access to arts training which breeds interests outside the variant levels of academic achievement. Hopefully, there is now an opportunity for more young people to engage in the pursuit of excellence alongside subjects other than the national curriculum in which drama for one is marginalised.
Dan Shaw
The Society of Teachers of Speech and Drama
Nottingham

fields.headline: Seeking the truth
fields.trailText: Nick Cohen should be compulsory reading for anybody who has ever gossiped about the lies asylum seekers tell, and the luxury in which they live at the taxpayer's expense (Comment, last week).
fields.body:
Nick Cohen should be compulsory reading for anybody who has ever gossiped about the lies asylum seekers tell, and the luxury in which they live at the taxpayer's expense (Comment, last week).

To make such allegations is bad enough for those who are ignorant because they have not bothered to seek out the truth about asylum seekers. Those whose work involves meeting asylum seekers face to face - interpreters, for example - should know better, but some of them also spout poisonous rubbish about liars and scroungers posing a threat to virtuous citizens.

The truth is available for those who will trouble to read articles like Nick Cohen's, and fact sheets and journals from the Refugee Council (020 7820 3085).

fields.headline: Irish victory marred
fields.standfirst: Try, try and try again as Irish score first home win over France since 1983
fields.trailText: Try, try and try again as Irish score first home win over France since 1983
fields.body:
Ireland scored a historic triumph over France at Dublin's Landsdowne Road yesterday, writes Henry McDonald.

But the Irish's first home win against the French since 1983 was marred by a terrorist bomb on the Belfast to Dublin rail link which made hundreds of Northern rugby fans late for the match.

Some supporters even missed the entire game, which ended in a 22-15 victory for Ireland, after disruptions on the rail line between the two cities. The dissident Real IRA - the group responsible for the Omagh atrocity - was being blamed last night for the bomb attack, the third such incident this month.

The line between Portadown and Dundalk in the Republic was closed following reports of two large explosions at Newry, close to the Irish border. Fans were taken by bus from Portadown to Dundalk, causing delays of up to two hours in their journey.

One supporter who made it to Landsdowne Road just before the kick-off said many of his friends who had booked seats on the Belfast to Dublin Enterprise service would miss the first half. Roy Dillon from Belfast said: 'It's disgraceful to think a small band of headcases can disrupt a great day out for people in Ireland north and south..'

Dillon added that many of his friends suspected the line was targeted because many unionists who support the all-Ireland rugby team were travelling to Dublin.

fields.headline: Rise the North
fields.trailText: I like Will Hutton's reinvention of the English regions of the Saxon era (Comment, last week). What will really grab the interest will be the reinvention of Northumbria, defined for modern purposes as Cheshire and Yorkshire and all points north, with the Pennines as a unifying factor and not a boundary.
fields.body:
I like Will Hutton's reinvention of the English regions of the Saxon era (Comment, last week). What will really grab the interest will be the reinvention of Northumbria, defined for modern purposes as Cheshire and Yorkshire and all points north, with the Pennines as a unifying factor and not a boundary.

York as the capital will override the big city rivalries. The area would be powerful enough to really take on Whitehall and Westminster, and could dream, like Scotland and Wales, of being a nation in Europe, not just a region. How Mercia and the rest would cope would be a matter for them.
Roy Parkes
Ashton-under-Lyne
Republic of Northumbria

fields.headline: White smites President's men
fields.trailText: England will make no decision about Ashley Giles's fitness until after nets later this week despite his efforts to shrug off his Achilles injury by batting for more than an hour yesterday. Giles made only 17 but he survived for 64 minutes, apparently unscathed.
fields.body:
England will make no decision about Ashley Giles's fitness until after nets later this week despite his efforts to shrug off his Achilles injury by batting for more than an hour yesterday. Giles made only 17 but he survived for 64 minutes, apparently unscathed.

The real test will come only when Giles bowls in the nets at Galle on Tuesday, but at least England now know his heel is strong enough to enable him to bat. His efforts yesterday both encouraged the tourists about his fitness and helped them claim a 165-run advantage as they reached 418 for seven at the close of the third day.

At the start of the day, Michael Atherton added only 11 runs before being bowled for 85 by left-arm seamer Dinusha Fernando, who also dismissed England's most senior batsman twice during the two-day practice match in Moratuwa.

Graham Thorpe provided England with further encouragement for the Test series by scoring his first half-century of the tour before becoming the second victim for left-arm spinner Niroshan Bandartilleke, who is hoping to force his way into Sri Lanka's line-up in Galle. Driving forcefully off the front foot, Thorpe could reasonably have expected to add to his tally of two boundaries - but instead Bandartilleke stuck out a hand and took a superb catch.

The only disappointment for England as they begin making plans for the Test was the failure of Michael Vaughan to make much of an impression, caught at silly mid-off from the first delivery of the day by off-spinner Muthumu Pushpakumara.

Alec Stewart responded to his inconsistent start to the tour by playing an untypically defensive innings, taking 133 balls to score his first boundary and scoring only 40 after more than three hours at the crease. Once again his weakness against spin was exposed when Bandara bowled him with a leg-break.

Craig White added to his reputation as a fine player of spin by making an unbeaten 84 with four sixes and two fours.

fields.headline: Sheridan's now a rival
fields.standfirst: Special report: devolution in Scotland
fields.trailText: The political world was simpler in 1882 when W.S. Gilbert wrote, in  Iolanthe, that every boy or girl is either 'a little Liberal or else a little Conservative'.
fields.body:
The political world was simpler in 1882 when W.S. Gilbert wrote, in Iolanthe, that every boy or girl is either 'a little Liberal or else a little Conservative'. They were even simpler back in the fifteenth century when the Papal Bull of 1493 and the Treaty of Tordesillas divided the Christian world into two zones of influence by drawing a line on the map.

Nations rise and fall; political parties decline. Yet Gilbert's doctrine loosely applies still, if you substitute Labour for Liberal, though his age, which predated universal suffrage, was innocent of floating voters, focus groups or the 'pebbledash people' identified by William Hague as a key cohort in the electorate.

And in Scotland, our political world is undoubtedly growing more complicated because of the two-tier voting system. We, of course, developed a four-party system in the decades before the Scottish Parliament. Now the list has brought the Tories back to parliamentary life and found a place at Holyrood for the leader of the Scottish Socialist Party, Tommy Sheridan, and the Greens.

The SSP held its conference earlier this month and reported that it now has more than 2,000 members. It is appealing for £100,000 to fund its plan to field a candidate in every Scottish Westminster seat; it hopes to gather 100,00 votes. And Sheridan has high hopes for the next Scottish elections in 2003, pointing out that opinion polls give the party six per cent of the second vote, behind the Tories' nine per cent.

Sheridan's socialists are not the only ones gnawing at New Labour. Arthur Scargill's Socialist Labour Party is fielding candidates in Peter Mandelson's Hartlepool and elsewhere, but typically Scargill is standing aside from the Socialist Alliance, to which Sheridan's party subscribes. In England, where it was formed in Coventry nine years ago out of the remnants of the old anti- poll tax campaign, it hopes to contest 65 seats. Masterminded by the former Labour member for Coventry South-East, Dave Nellist, it is targeting the constituencies of at least 20 Labour Ministers, including Jack Straw and David Blunkett. In a gesture of unreciprocated generosity, it is yielding Hartlepool and Mandelson to Scargill.

So far these are stirrings in the undergrowth. Trying to read the political future is as easy as understanding a Dylan lyric: some scholars, for example, claim that the incomprehensible 'It takes a lot to laugh, it takes a train to cry' contains biblical allusions.

More probably, Dylan, like Beckett, preferred ambiguity because it has a greater artistic effect than clarity. But if art is obscure, the future is inscrutable. Not unnaturally, political scientists are very cautious about claims that the Socialist Alliance is opening up a significant new constituency in British politics.

Indeed, David Denver, professor of politics at Lancaster University and co-author of standard works on Scottish political behaviour, believes that Sheridan's hopes of a glorious future at Holyrood may be inflated, although he acknowledges the alliance's success in recent council by-elections in England, where its subscribing parties have nine seats - in Coventry, Lewisham, Preston and Burnley.

Although Sheridan, a genuine hero of the working class and a man of charm and sincerity, enjoys a significant personal vote, his party, Denver believes, is more likely to secure between 2 and 4 per cent of the vote, although Scotland Decides, an account of the 1999 elections which Denver jointly authored, shows that many who voted for one party in the first-past-vote contest switched when it came to the list.

But it would be foolish to write Sheridan off: he has already forced the Executive to retreat on the issue of warrant sales. Many Labour members must in spirit have been with Sheridan, George Galloway and the others who were arrested at Faslane on Monday. Most, after all, privately believe in nuclear disarmament. With a fair wind, he will surely become a substantial player in Scotland's political future.

fields.headline: Gene genius
fields.trailText: Congratulations to  The Observer  on the discovery that free will resides in the genes - or, rather, in the absence of genes: the fewer the genes, apparently, the greater the freedom (News, last week). Can philosophy now off-load the notoriously intractable problem of free will on to gene-counting machines?
fields.body:
Congratulations to The Observer on the discovery that free will resides in the genes - or, rather, in the absence of genes: the fewer the genes, apparently, the greater the freedom (News, last week). Can philosophy now off-load the notoriously intractable problem of free will on to gene-counting machines?

And should theodicy now tackle the weighty implication that fruit flies, bearing only half our quantity of genes, are blessed with twice our freedom? Or perhaps, more usefully, we should remind ourselves that what's presumably of concern is a more down-to-earth notion of 'freedom'; and that we possess such freedom not in spite of, but thanks to, genes that build human brains. And perhaps, too, we should bear in mind the crucial importance of separating our science from our ideology.
Dr Helena Cronin
London School of Economics
