fields.headline: We can win without risking Murali
fields.standfirst: Arjuna Ranatunga says Sri Lanka's selectors are crucial
fields.trailText: Sri Lanka's selectors are crucial
fields.body:
If Sri Lanka play to their strengths then they will beat England. But it has seemed to me recently that whereas England now know their best eleven, our selectors do not. Last week, I applauded Nasser Hussain's appointment as England captain, for he brings out the best in his men. What is really significant, however, is that it shows how meritocratic and factionless the English set-up has become.

England were so lost in the Nineties. Around the world we were all stunned by the sudden, apparently arbitrary banishment of Ian Botham, then David Gower, then Robin Smith by England. It seemed that non-cricketing reasons were at play. England's subsequent dismal performances showed just how much they were missed. But England have found a solid middle-order now.

This area - once Sri Lanka's strength - has been our Achilles heel recently. All because Aravinda de Silva was dropped last year. They - it was never made clear exactly who - said Aravinda was 'past it, unfit, unmotivated, too slow, too old, too selfish. Not a team man'. Our opponents must have been laughing for the world's bowlers know that few other batsmen in the world can play with as much assurance.

The magnitude of Aravinda's pride and talent allowed him to score some runs without any practice following his sudden recall to the Test arena against South Africa last month. Since then he has been stoking his fire with fitness and form re-ignited. I still expect great things of him. And he's two and a half years younger than Alec Stewart! Our selectors would do well to not pay too much attention to birth certificates. All selectors really have to do is to concentrate on doing what your opponents would least like you to do.

Sri Lanka's unique cricketing culture is currently producing an outstanding crop of young batsmen. Green and a little sappy, yet very talented - but you can't play them all at the same time. Where Sri Lanka went awry in South Africa was in not having any middle-order experience but as long as the selectors learnt from their mistakes, Sri Lanka should not be handicapped against England.

I cannot see Sanath Jayasuriya and Marvan Atapattu being out of form together in the way they were in South Africa. We all know what Sanath is capable of, but Marvan, once in, can bat for close to forever. Number three is a crucial position and it is asking a lot of our wicketkeeper, the dashing Kumar Sangakarra, to bat there when he could always be going in from the second ball of an innings. I would play Russel Arnold there. Great temperament, superb strokes.

The brilliant Mahela Jayawardene - he can really make batting look so easy for one so young - should go in at four and then Aravinda at five.

England are lucky in finally finding a fast-bowling all-rounder in Craig White. He really balances their side. Similarly, who plays at seven for Sri Lanka may be crucial. The offie-all-rounder Kumar Dharmasena might come in. His strengths are in his head, which counts for so much.

Yet I'd be inclined to play the extra batsman, going for the experience of Hashan Tillekaratne. With Aravinda, Sanath and Russel Arnold in the team, there will be plenty of spin-bowling options for Sri Lanka. Mahela's deft little cutters and seam-up varieties could bag a few back-up wickets too.

Sri Lanka's fast men rarely seem to fire together but if Vaas and Zoysa are fully fit they will trouble England. They have put on yards of pace since England last met them in Australia a couple of years ago and have added spite to their spice. Our fastest bowler, Dilhara Fernando, has yet to learn how to use the new ball properly but he has the great ability to hurry even class batsmen.

Two fast men and two spinners would seem to be the ideal line-up for Sri Lanka at home, assuming Muralitharan is one of them. So much attention is focused on Murali that it would be easy to overlook the others who sooner or later will have to step up and win matches for Lanka. We are as rich in spinners as England are in seamers.

If Murali's not 100 per cent, I wouldn't risk him. One or more of the youngsters bubbling under have it in them to be champs.

fields.headline: Bang to rights
fields.trailText: Richard Ingrams need puzzle no more over our justice system. Years ago Lord Hailsham gave the reason in a TV documentary, when compared this country's adversarial system of justice with the inquisitorial system on the Continent.
fields.body:
Richard Ingrams need puzzle no more over our justice system. Years ago Lord Hailsham gave the reason in a TV documentary, when compared this country's adversarial system of justice with the inquisitorial system on the Continent. 'British justice,' he said the noble Lord, 'isn't interested in getting at the truth - only in obtaining a conviction.'
Edward Johnson
London W11

 What has happened to our belief that it is better for 99 guilty people to go free than for one innocent person to lose his/her liberty?
Ellis Thorpe
Inverurie, Aberdeenshire

webTitle: Letters:  Changes ahead for Crown Prosecution Service

fields.headline: Changes ahead
fields.trailText: Mary Riddell will want to reconsider her comments on the Government's proposed reforms of mental health policy and law (Comment, last week) following the conviction of Edward Crowley for the murder of a 12-year-old boy in Covent Garden.
fields.body:
Mary Riddell will want to reconsider her comments on the Government's proposed reforms of mental health policy and law (Comment, last week) following the conviction of Edward Crowley for the murder of a 12-year-old boy in Covent Garden.

The killer, a man with a severe and dangerous personality disorder, was known to a number of statutory agencies. Currently, there are 400-500 such people living in the community. There was nothing anyone could do in this tragic case to protect the boy because personality disorder is now considered by most psychiatrists to be untreatable. Riddell saying a shortage of psychiatrists is to blame misses the point. The Government has recognised the existing situation puts people at risk of serious harm and proposes providing treatment in contained settings.
Michael Howlett
The Zito Trust
Hay-on-Wye, Hereford

 The Crown Prosecution Service is not unaccountable, as Mary Riddell claims. It is accountable to Parliament through the Attorney-General, who has superintendence of the service. We do not make arbitrary decisions. Every decision about whether to prosecute a case and, if so, what charges should be brought is made according to the criteria laid down in the Code for Crown Prosecutors. This is a public document available on www.cps.gov.uk

Although the CPS has been historically under-funded, the Attorney-General recently announced an injection of money which means the resources available to us in 2001-2 will be 23 per cent higher in real terms than this year. This will enable us to further improve the performance of the CPS and the criminal justice system.
David Calvert-Smith QC
Director, Public Prosecutions
Crown Prosecution Service
London EC4

webTitle: A punter's view: 'M Pipe is my best bugger'

fields.headline: A punter's view: 'M Pipe is my best bugger'
fields.standfirst: James Davis, taking time off from his Observer cricket-writing duties, samples the delights of Sri Lanka's betting culture
fields.trailText: James Davis, taking time off from his Observer cricket-writing duties, samples the delights of Sri Lanka's betting culture
fields.body: Michael Ondaatje, the author of The English Patient , who was born and raised in Sri Lanka, wrote: 'In India only the aristocracy gambled; in Ceylon the bankers and the lime-burners and fishmongers and leisured class would spend their afternoons shoulder to shoulder betting compulsively - if it was not horses, it was crows.' I have not come across betting on crows, but a few rupees on a horse is a passion for the men of Sri Lanka - especially a British horse. Walk into a bookmaker's, or turf accountant as they are still called here, and you will hear the distinctive tones of a British horse racing commentator describing the final few furlongs from Sandown, Market Rasen or Sedgefield. Bookies can be found on almost every shopping street and in all the smaller towns throughout Sri Lanka, in rich areas and in poor. They are open all day and close after the last race in Britain at about 11pm local time. During the day, old men can be found poring over the many form guides (I have counted five different daily publications so far, with Saddlers Special being a particular favourite). To keep customers interested into the evening, there is a 10 or 15 per cent commission on your night-time bet (you bet 100 rupees and you receive 10 or 15 back). After dark there is more atmosphere as the men come to spend their hard-earned money. Young and old, some in suits, some in sarong and flip-flops, the most popular bet is for the minimum stake of 25 rupees (20p), still a considerable sum in a place where a big lunch costs only 40 rupees (32p). Some bookmakers offer a VIP lounge for the 'big-spenders' with a minimum bet of 100 rupees (80p). All punters have their favourite jockey, trainer and sometimes owner. 'AP McCoy is my favourite,' is a phrase often heard. It is always 'AP' and never 'Tony'. Initials are all they see in the racing guides, so initials it always is. 'M Pipe is my best bugger,' announced one well-dressed gentleman who had an unusual terminology for trainers. 'C Brittain, T Barron on the flat, and Henderson [never seems to have an initial] with the hurdles.' All the punters seem to know an awful lot about British racing. 'It has been a poor season, too much rain and ice,' said one as Wetherby became the latest victim of the weather. One man was particularly scathing about Uttoxeter, which he considered, from 5,000 miles, 'highly dangerous for novice chases'. I could only nod and agree. Dogs also have a strong following and I have learnt a great deal watching my first televised races from Romford, Monmore, Crayford and Brough Park. The most popular punter was 'Mr Five' - so named because he only bet on the orange jacket. Odds on the Six Nations championship and the Premiership also flash up on the screens, but there has been no talk of betting on cricket. My questions about match-fixing and the upcoming questioning of Arivinda De Silva and Arjuna Ranatunga are met with: 'There is no betting on cricket.' They must think I'm working for Sir Paul Condon. My presence usually causes some excitement. Because I'm British, they assume I know AP McCoy personally and can tell them the winner of the next race. I protest that I know nothing, but my explanations fall on deaf ears, and when my betting slip hits the floor after the finish, so do many others following the same selection. While every man (and a few women) in a humid room full of Sri Lankans will get excited about a race on the all-weather surface at cold and windy Lingfield, very few are interested in racing in their native land - hardly surprising given that it is poorly organised, has suffered doping scandals and has been temporarily banned in recent years. The only racecourse in Sri Lanka is the old hill station of Nuwara Eliya, a town that boasts itself a 'little England' with its golf course and hotels where a tie is required. The racecourse manager, who is also a trainer and private secretary to the mayor, is hoping for six meetings this year. Four will be in Nuwara Eliya's popular 'April season' when the rich and the famous descend to escape Colombo. The Sri Lankans are looking ahead to April, but not for the local racing. They are already talking about the Grand National, and the hot tip is any horse ridden by AP McCoy.

While every man (and a few women) in a humid room full of Sri Lankans will get excited about a race on the all-weather surface at cold and windy Lingfield, very few are interested in racing in their native land - hardly surprising given that it is poorly organised, has suffered doping scandals and has been temporarily banned in recent years. The only racecourse in Sri Lanka is the old hill station of Nuwara Eliya, a town that boasts itself a 'little England' with its golf course and hotels where a tie is required. The racecourse manager, who is also a trainer and private secretary to the mayor, is hoping for six meetings this year. Four will be in Nuwara Eliya's popular 'April season' when the rich and the famous descend to escape Colombo. The Sri Lankans are looking ahead to April, but not for the local racing. They are already talking about the Grand National, and the hot tip is any horse ridden by AP McCoy.

fields.headline: Young, free and... er, simple?
fields.trailText:
Silent Witness BBC1
Tribe BBC2
Blood on the Carpet BBC2
Love In A Cold Climate BBC1
fields.body:
Silent Witness BBC1
Tribe BBC2
Blood on the Carpet BBC2
Love In A Cold Climate BBC1

Teenagers, eh? In Silent Witness, two dead girls were discovered in a Norwegian ski resort and defrosted by Amanda Burton's chilly pathologist, Sam Ryan, to reveal the kind of tangled emotional plots that, had they managed to stay alive long enough, they would probably have left behind by their twenties.

One of the dead girls, Ruth, was a virgin while the other, Louise, had been pregnant with twins. It turned out that one of the twins had been fathered by her uncle (Anthony Head, so sinister he couldn't possibly be the murderer) and the other by a nice, earnest young man who worked for a travel company (obviously guilty). So they weren't really twins at all. I must lead a very sheltered life, but the possibility of this kind of genetic pick'n'mix came as a revelation. Then Anthony Head turned out not to be Louise's uncle, but her father, so one of her unborn children would have been... what, precisely? Her own sister, as well as her daughter? This was a complex set of circumstances even by teenage standards. And then it got worse, as the real murderer turned out to be neither of the prime suspects, but an employee of her father's - or at least the man we had assumed to be her father - who was keen to put Louise and the other girls preyed upon by the amoral Anthony Head out of their perceived misery. He may have had a point.

One could tell that Professor Ryan had got a bit too involved in this case because, very occasionally, she'd reach out to make physical contact with the living, though always with considerably less relish than she showed for the dead. There are signs, however, that like last week's corpses, brittle Sam might be thawing - though we may not like what is revealed when she does. Still, in a bold leap forward for her character, Burton didn't once have to sit in a car in the rain, biting her lip pensively while contemplating the navels, spleens, livers and brains of murder victims. On the wall of her office there is even a recently installed pinboard decorated with postcards and snapshots - all heartwarming signs of life, if not yet quite a life. Hormonal chaos was explored in equally exhausting, occasionally baffling, depth by BBC2's Tribe, a nightly series of short films revealing the dark underbelly of teenagers, though it is entirely possible that in several cases there wasn't anything other than a dark underbelly. I was very worried about Laura, star of the first film, Don't Sleep With Any DJs whose fetishistic attachment to the garage music scene in general ('garage is my whole life') and the Heartless Crew (Mighty Mo, Fonty, Bushkin) in particular, was matched only by her lack of even the most basic self-awareness, marking her out as a young woman of apparently infinite stupidity.

Laura had a job working in a club promotions company, which, somewhat dangerously, further fuelled her fantasy half-life. Laura's young female boss, Sinem, talked about trying to get her 'to apply her enthusiasm for the industry' and 'hopefully, in time, Laura will be a Mini-Me'. There seemed little chance of this. Developmentally arrested, like an overgrown toddler blunderingly testing the boundaries of her world, Laura appeared to lack whatever genetic mechanism it is that allows even a teenager to stand back and say 'hang on, maybe I'm screwing things up?'

Sinem tried to persuade Laura that she shouldn't say 'd'ya know wot I mean?' quite so often, and that she shouldn't talk about 'raving', but use 'clubbing' instead. Laura wouldn't listen, and even argued like it mattered. It was compulsively funny-grotesque to watch, but it hurt too. Laura also argued with her friends. All of them. Prattling at the camera while showing off her Sam Ryan-style pinboard, replete with trophy mugshots, it became clear that Laura had had a lot of friends, but that none of them had lasted. Currently best friends with Sunshine ('I couldn't rave Cream of The Crop without her'), this was a relationship based, in Laura's case, on expediency and, in Sunshine's, probably on laziness ('I think we attached to each other. Like, "you'll compensate for my loss of Vicky, I'll compensate for your loss of Caroline_ ",' explained Sunshine shortly before she stopped returning Laura's calls). Either way, by the end of the film, Laura had a new best friend, Ellie, with whom she could 'rave Cream of the Crop' for a few more weeks at least.

But First Prize in the Self-Delusion Championships had to go to Lola Marie, star of Tuesday's film You Look Like A Proper Presenter . I would have loved to find out how Lola had ever imagined she'd make a TV presenter, but because each film took their subjects as they found them we were denied any background. 'I'm enunciaytin. Enun-see-aytin!' Lola kept explaining to her sweetly supportive (though baffled) boyfriend, as she forced him to watch her paid-for, semi-professional 'showreel' - shots of her accosting shoppers for perky little vox-pops, or standing in a Magnet Kitchens showroom saying 'the Corian worktop works perfect for those accidental spills!' Lola then sent her tape to the producers of Changing Rooms and, as a piece of comparative advertising, it worked brilliantly. Thanks to Lola I now recognise just how talented Carol Smillie really is.

Individually, all the films were illuminating, sometimes funny, occasionally touching, but viewed collectively Tribe was like being suffocated in a dumpster full of teenager's diaries. And you know you're hopelessly out of touch with the yoof of today, in all their raging, raving, hurtling hopelessness, when the only people who seemed to talk any sense at all were their parents. Even the ones who didn't speak English.

But just when I had decided that teenagers have the monopoly on rampant idiocy, along came a cracking edition of Blood on the Carpet to prove that wisdom need not necessarily be the preserve of the physically mature. Conceived by Michael Lang, the man responsible for the first great festival, Woodstock 1999, sounded like a bad idea from the start, particularly given that Peace and Love is not exactly the youthful credo of our times. Wanting to recreate 'the most sacred hippy event of all time' (though, it was, arguably, only the most sacred hippy event of the latter half of one decade in the 20th century), Lang hired a disused airforce base near Rome, upstate New York, booked unlovely headline bands like Insane Clown Posse and Limp Bizkit, and recruited some of his old hippy mates.

Lisa Law had run the original (free) Woodstock soup kitchen, while Wavy Gravy had enforced 1969's 'security' wearing a bear costume and wielding a rubber shovel, but was now mostly famous for having been immortalised, like Jerry Garcia, as an unpleasantly savoury-sounding Ben and Jerry's ice-cream flavour (beef jerky and chocolate chip hippy, or what?). Sadly, by day three of the festival, it was all going very wrong vibewise, so Wavy took to the stage.

'I thought I could kind of sneak the crowd into "Om-ing"... One voice, one sound, have them build it and build it and build it and then send it out for peace on the planet... '

'He tried to sage the crowd,' Lisa added, 'but it didn't really work... '

Sage? Sorry, did I heard that correctly?

'Yeah, light up some sage!' explained Gravy, 'so I'm saging away_ and I'm thinking, is that a swastika on that skinhead?'

'But,' said Lisa, 'the kids are like "who's that?" ' They didn't understand him... ' 'Then the crowd were shouting "fuck Jerry!" - Jerry Garcia! - so I'm off!'

Then, while I was weeping with mild hysteria, it was revealed that the crowd were in fact shouting "Buck Cherry", which was the name of the next band. By the time the organisers had handed out the candles for the Jimi Hendrix tribute, the kids were sick of being charged '4 bucks for water, 6 for soda, 8 for a burger and 12 for a little pizza' so they decided Rome might as well burn instead. Right on kids! I can't remember the last time I have laughed so much in front of the box.

Mind you, I'd laughed quite a lot at Alan Bates's Uncle Matthew and Sheila Gish's Lady Montdore in Love In A Cold Climate and would have liked to laugh a bit more, but two books had been squished into less than three hours viewing so that this adaptation seemed even more scared of commitment than the Bolter. Whizzing through characters and plotlets it left viewers barely enough time to kick off their mules, light a cocktail sobranie, recline on the chaise with a snifter and notice that, aside from swearing and pierced belly-buttons, when it comes to the messy emotional landscape of teenage girls, not so very much has changed since Mitford's day.

fields.headline: Desailly: 'We do try - honest'
fields.standfirst: Can classy Chelsea's tortured travellers possibly win at Highbury?  Amy Lawrence reports
fields.trailText: Can classy Chelsea's tortured travellers possibly win at Highbury? Amy Lawrence reports
fields.body:
There is something incongruous about Marcel Desailly, one of modern football's most lavishly decorated players and gracefully smart individuals, gliding through a creaking, old-fashioned training pavilion built for students. After the sunbaked hills where he practised in Marseille, the opulent luxury of Milan, and the marvels of France's training academy chateau at Clairfontaine, the plastic chairs in Chelsea's canteen do not seem Desailly's style. Nor, for that matter, does a troubled season where the chase for top honours fizzled out prematurely.

With Premiership aspirations long since abandoned and hopes for a Champions League spot all but extinguished, the only way Chelsea can avoid the season being a write-off is in the FA Cup.

France's captain, explaining how important it is for him and his club to go all the way, provides Chelsea with another reason. 'Maybe it's the winning that keeps me motivated enough to have a long career because every year I have been winning something. If it was the opposite, maybe today I would stop.'

While the 32-year-old appreciates the talents of Arsenal's French collection, he is quick to point out that what Chelsea must fear the most this afternoon at Highbury is not the Gunners' qualities but their own travel sickness. It's a touchy subject.

'I don't know,' he groans. 'We have been turning, turning, turning... ' He rolls his hands round and round to emphasise how they have been churning over the problem. 'People say the will, the desire, is not there. All week we have been working. It is not like we are stupid and expect to lose.

'We are definitely ready for those games, the games we have been losing. When you play Leicester, you know it is going to be really, really difficult. We train hard to be quicker and more aggressive, like them. Afterwards, maybe you don't have the luck, or maybe psychologically you think you are ready but inside you say to yourself, "Oh look, we lost last time, we are going to lose again".'

He understands the fans' frustration - unable to fathom how a team that can achieve a win and two draws against Manchester United can lose twice to Leicester. He is equally mystified, but don't suggest it is through lack of effort.

Claudio Ranieri's intensive approach, Desailly believes, will eventually reap rewards. 'His culture, the Italian style, is to make us work a lot - tactically, physically, rapidité, agressivité, ' he spits out the words in a way Ranieri would no doubt admire. 'It will come.'

Aside from the slow change towards a more physically powerful game, Ranieri has also signalled a transformation in tactical thinking - with mixed results so far. One of the times it worked most effectively was during the Premiership game at Highbury last month. After their back three was torn apart for the first half, Chelsea returned to a 'four' and dominated. Desailly hopes they have absorbed how Arsenal should now be tackled: 'We have to try to play like we did in the second half. Don't be afraid of playing.'

Joe Royle remains undaunted at the task facing his Manchester City side - who have won only once in 17 league games - at Liverpool in the day's other televised tie.

A City victory would not surprise anyone with a working knowledge of the club. 'The Roma game you can forget,' he says. 'There is no logic to cup football, that is why upsets happen. I know Liverpool will be odds-on favourites to win but I think Gérard Houllier probably has more respect for us than one or two other people who are writing us off.'

City expect centre-back Steve Howey to play despite having a broken toe.

fields.headline: Closely observed brains
fields.standfirst: Anthony Hopkins offers a masterclass in malevolence in the sequel to Silence of the Lambs
fields.trailText: Hannibal (131 mins, 18) Directed by Ridley Scott; starring Anthony Hopkins, Julianne Moore, Gary Oldman, Giancarlo Giannini
fields.body:
Hannibal (131 mins, 18) Directed by Ridley Scott; starring Anthony Hopkins, Julianne Moore, Gary Oldman, Giancarlo Giannini

The midpoint of the twentieth century and its end were both dominated by cinematic villains with identical initials whose brief appearances in secondary roles enabled them to hijack the films in which they appeared and to insist upon a separate life. In 1949, Harry Lime, the vicious postwar racketeer, whose contaminated penicillin maimed and killed children in Vienna, somehow became the hero of The Third Man. Subsequently, in somewhat laundered form, Lime became the eponymous protagonist of radio and TV series starring respectively Orson Welles and Michael Rennie.

Forty years later, the cannibalistic murderer, Dr Hannibal Lecter, though scarcely seen outside his dungeon, dominated The Silence of the Lambs, and for a decade his creator, Thomas Harris, worked on a novel putting him stage centre, which now reaches the screen as Hannibal, with Anthony Hopkins reprising his Oscar-winning role. On the face of it, Hannibal is far worse than Lime, but in fact all his despicable victims are somehow culpable, while Lime's were innocents. Both Welles and Hopkins are smooth-faced performers, resembling evil babies and are given to ingratiating themselves with smiling eyes and sinister grins.

Welles came to The Third Man from playing Cesare Borgia in The Prince of Foxes, and immediately before Hannibal Hopkins took the title role in a film of Shakespeare's Titus Andronicus, a similar story of cannibalism and mutilation that probably influenced Harris. What Lime and Hannibal have in common is the way they are drawn to the Renaissance world where civilised values and exquisite cruelty intermingle.

The fugitive Hannibal has found a perfect billet, running a quattrocento library in a Florentine palazzo and studying Renaissance iconography. The self-justifying lines that Welles put into the mouth of Lime could as easily have been spoken by Lecter - 'In Italy for 30 years under the Borgias they had warfare, terror, murder, bloodshed - they produced Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci and the Renaissance. In Switzerland, they had brotherly love, 500 years of democracy and peace and what did that produce? The cuckoo clock.' Perhaps we feel that Lime and Hannibal help to make sense of the terrible twentieth century.

Ridley Scott's Hannibal, which has been adapted with considerable fidelity by David Mamet, Steven Zaillian and uncredited others, differs considerably from the two previous films featuring Lecter. Both Manhunter and The Silence of the Lambs are police procedural movies in which the FBI's behavioural science department tracks down colourful serial killers. In the first, Brian Cox's Lecter helps veteran agent Will Graham (William Petersen) pursue the infamous 'Tooth Fairy'. In the second, Hopkins's Lecter assists the tyro agent Clarice Starling to understand the mentality of the sadistic 'Buffalo Bill'. Hannibal, on the other hand, is a combination of Jacobean revenge drama and Edgar Allan Poe gothic tale.

It begins like a police procedural piece with a brilliantly staged drug raid in Washington's open-air fish market (a raffish location that recalls the streets in Blade Runner) that concludes with the raid's leader, Special Agent Clarice Starling (Julianne Moore), washing the HIV blood of a dangerous Hispanic woman gangster from the baby she's been carrying as cover. The shot prepares the way for a series of bloody images that punctuate the film. But this opening is designed as a way of isolating Clarice, a woman of unimpeachable probity, from her dishonest, cowardly, self-seeking colleagues in a variety of federal agencies and, most especially, from the devious, misogynistic Paul Krendler (Ray Liotta) from the Justice Department, a creepy philistine who can't even pronounce 'fiefdom' (his version rhymes with 'knifed'em').

Krendler is in league with billionaire Mason Verger (Gary Oldman unrecognisable behind his prosthetic disguise and named only in the final credits), a hideously disfigured cripple who lives on the magnificent Biltmore Estate in North Carolina, the biggest private mansion in America. Verger, a vicious paedophile whose face Lecter peeled and fed to the dogs, is Hannibal's only surviving victim and he intends to take his revenge by feeding him to a herd of ravenous wild boars specially bred in Sardinia (where else?).

In order to lure the elusive doctor, Clarice is put back on the case, but at the very moment she's tracking him down to Florence, he's located by Inspector Rinaldo Pazzi (Giancarlo Giannini). Pazzi is a Florentine aristocrat by name (an ancestor was hanged for murdering a Medici in the fifteenth century) and a patsy by nature, a fool who thinks he can tangle with Hannibal. With an expensive young wife and a taste for Armani threads, the sad Pazzi decides to sell the fugitive American to Verger. Lecter, who likes to combine massive retaliation with witty conceits, prepares an elaborate death fit for a Renaissance Pazzi.

The film's Florence is far removed from the elegant, glowing city of A Room with a View. As lit by the talented British cameraman John Mathieson (who worked with Scott on Gladiator), this is a dark, satanic place of renaissance intrigue.

The only convincing explanation for a man on the FBI's '10 Most Wanted' list deciding to live here in plain sight is that everyone walks around in the shadows. Even when Hannibal goes to the opera, it's a gloomy work based on Dante's Inferno staged at night in the cloisters of a Renaissance palace. But the stylised, highly-charged atmosphere deters us from looking at the movie in any literal way, just as later on when Clarice comes to Hannibal's rescue, Verger's stronghold proves to be like the lair of a Bond villain, at once impregnable and easy to penetrate.

Much of the feeling we have for the relationship of Clarice and Hannibal we bring from The Silence of the Lambs. Moore's likeable Clarice is older, tougher, yet no less vulnerable than Jodie Foster's. She is, however, much more disillusioned, and thus, while retaining a strong sense of right and wrong, she's closer in her view of the world to the Machiavellian joker, Hannibal, with whom Hopkins has so much fun. But they were more interesting when he was playing mind games while helping her investigations than now when the two of them are outsiders and uneasy allies, in her case fighting a Protestant conscience that insists Lecter be turned over to the authorities.

Clarice and Hannibal first make contact through an exotic clue he plants in a letter to her, and then accidentally via a third party's cellphone. But they are never in close proximity until they stalk each other in a dynamic sequence set in Washington's Union Station (a place now given over to boutiques and fairground shows) and don't meet until the last couple of reels. In this, the film resembles a macabre variation of Nora Ephron's Sleepless in Seattle and You've Got Mail, those chastely romantic comedies of consummation postponed starring Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan.

There are a couple of scenes - one involving a disembowelling, the other gourmet cranial surgery - that are deliberately excessive, intended to make us flinch as we laugh at Hannibal's terrible wit. Mostly, though, the movie is pretty restrained. Lecter's cannibalism, we learn, has so endeared him to connoisseurs in a society devoted to the culinary arts that a former male nurse at the Baltimore Hospital for the Criminally Insane has sold Hannibal's signed copy of The Joy of Cooking to a collector for $6,000.
fields.bodyText: Hannibal (131 mins, 18) Directed by Ridley Scott; starring Anthony Hopkins, Julianne Moore, Gary Oldman, Giancarlo Giannini The midpoint of the twentieth century and its end were both dominated by cinematic villains with identical initials whose brief appearances in secondary roles enabled them to hijack the films in which they appeared and to insist upon a separate life. In 1949, Harry Lime, the vicious postwar racketeer, whose contaminated penicillin maimed and killed children in Vienna, somehow became the hero of The Third Man. Subsequently, in somewhat laundered form, Lime became the eponymous protagonist of radio and TV series starring respectively Orson Welles and Michael Rennie. Forty years later, the cannibalistic murderer, Dr Hannibal Lecter, though scarcely seen outside his dungeon, dominated The Silence of the Lambs, and for a decade his creator, Thomas Harris, worked on a novel putting him stage centre, which now reaches the screen as Hannibal, with Anthony Hopkins reprising his Oscar-winning role. On the face of it, Hannibal is far worse than Lime, but in fact all his despicable victims are somehow culpable, while Lime's were innocents. Both Welles and Hopkins are smooth-faced performers, resembling evil babies and are given to ingratiating themselves with smiling eyes and sinister grins. Welles came to The Third Man from playing Cesare Borgia in The Prince of Foxes, and immediately before Hannibal Hopkins took the title role in a film of Shakespeare's Titus Andronicus, a similar story of cannibalism and mutilation that probably influenced Harris. What Lime and Hannibal have in common is the way they are drawn to the Renaissance world where civilised values and exquisite cruelty intermingle. The fugitive Hannibal has found a perfect billet, running a quattrocento library in a Florentine palazzo and studying Renaissance iconography. The self-justifying lines that Welles put into the mouth of Lime could as easily have been spoken by Lecter - 'In Italy for 30 years under the Borgias they had warfare, terror, murder, bloodshed - they produced Michelangelo, Leonardo da Vinci and the Renaissance. In Switzerland, they had brotherly love, 500 years of democracy and peace and what did that produce? The cuckoo clock.' Perhaps we feel that Lime and Hannibal help to make sense of the terrible twentieth century. Ridley Scott's Hannibal, which has been adapted with considerable fidelity by David Mamet, Steven Zaillian and uncredited others, differs considerably from the two previous films featuring Lecter. Both Manhunter and The Silence of the Lambs are police procedural movies in which the FBI's behavioural science department tracks down colourful serial killers. In the first, Brian Cox's Lecter helps veteran agent Will Graham (William Petersen) pursue the infamous 'Tooth Fairy'. In the second, Hopkins's Lecter assists the tyro agent Clarice Starling to understand the mentality of the sadistic 'Buffalo Bill'. The shot prepares the way for a series of bloody images that punctuate the film. But this opening is designed as a way of isolating Clarice, a woman of unimpeachable probity, from her dishonest, cowardly, self-seeking colleagues in a variety of federal agencies and, most especially, from the devious, misogynistic Paul Krendler (Ray Liotta) from the Justice Department, a creepy philistine who can't even pronounce 'fiefdom' (his version rhymes with 'knifed'em'). Verger, a vicious paedophile whose face Lecter peeled and fed to the dogs, is Hannibal's only surviving victim and he intends to take his revenge by feeding him to a herd of ravenous wild boars specially bred in Sardinia (where else?). In order to lure the elusive doctor, Clarice is put back on the case, but at the very moment she's tracking him down to Florence, he's located by Inspector Rinaldo Pazzi (Giancarlo Giannini). Pazzi is a Florentine aristocrat by name (an ancestor was hanged for murdering a Medici in the fifteenth century) and a patsy by nature, a fool who thinks he can tangle with Hannibal. With an expensive young wife and a taste for Armani threads, the sad Pazzi decides to sell the fugitive American to Verger. Lecter, who likes to combine massive retaliation with witty conceits, prepares an elaborate death fit for a Renaissance Pazzi. The film's Florence is far removed from the elegant, glowing city of A Room with a View. She is, however, much more disillusioned, and thus, while retaining a strong sense of right and wrong, she's closer in her view of the world to the Machiavellian joker, Hannibal, with whom Hopkins has so much fun. fields.headline: Balm for both body and soul - and from a politician to boot
fields.standfirst: Geoffrey Tapper is not a typical well-to-do GP
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Tapper is not a typical well-to-do GP.
fields.body:
Dr Geoffrey Tapper's financial destiny was shaped at the age of 10, when his mother steered him towards medicine rather than his father's vocation in the Methodist ministry. She told him there was no money in being a minister, so Tapper decided instead to aim for a branch of medicine with a strong pastoral element. 'I never deviated from wanting to be a general practitioner - it's the medical equivalent of being a priest with your own parish,' he says.

When Tapper started work, the financial disparity between the two jobs became obvious; in 1955, his first year as a hospital house-physician, his salary was £320- exactly the amount that his father earned in his final year as a superintendent minister. What's more, Tapper's mother underwrote her son's finances when he joined his first practice in North Dorset; she bought him a house for £4,600. Forty years on he still lives there and thinks it's worth about half a million. Tapper and his wife benefit still further from this investment because it's a large former farmhouse, with plenty of extra accommodation to rent out. He retired as a GP in 1990 and his NHS pension is now £22,000 a year. So, as he says, there's never been a problem with money.

And yet Tapper is by no means your typical, comfortably-off retired GP. At nearly 70, he's Dorset County Council's Chairman of Social Services. Although he followed his mother into the Conservative party in his youth, Tapper converted to the Liberals. From 1993 to 1997 he had the distinction of being leader of the Liberal Democrats' largest council: 'In Dorset there were more people under the control of the Liberal Democrats than there had been at any time since Lloyd George,' he says.

Tapper went into local politics out of Christian motives. 'I wanted to help the underprivileged. When we took over from the Conservatives, social services spending was 23 per cent below the figure that the Government reckoned the council should be spending. The Tories had been spending the money on roads. I admit that since my time as leader, the roads in Dorset have deteriorated and I'm not ashamed of that.'

Although Tapper is standing down as a councillor in May, he'll still be busy, working for better care for the elderly through various local organisations he's founded. But he plans to mark his seventieth birthday with a trip to the Eastern Mediterranean to 'follow in the steps of St Paul'. (He's been a Methodist lay preacher for nearly 40 years.)

Looking back, he believes he made the right career choice as a boy - but not because of the money: 'I made a better GP than I would have made a Methodist minister. My father had about a dozen churches during his career because you have to move around. As a GP you can't do that because patients like to get to know their own doctor. I was lucky enough to be able to practice in Dorset, where my family has been since 1572. I love Dorset, and would have hated to leave it.'

fields.headline: What's the catch?
fields.trailText: Insurer Club Direct.
fields.body:
Air travellers worried about the risk of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) may be interested in a new insurance policy designed to cover them for any legal action against an airline as well as medical expenses should they develop DVT.

Insurer Club Direct has altered its standard travel policy to include a provision which pays legal costs of up to £25,000 to passengers or their relatives wanting to make a claim. It says it is the first insurer to change a policy in response to DVT and that the 'vast majority' will not pay out if you want to sue an airline.

But online broker screentrade.co.uk says you can 'pay less for better levels of cover' elsewhere. Although they are not commonplace, other policies will cover you for legal costs when you are making a claim against a third party such as an airline. Medical expenses resulting from DVT should be covered by all policies.

Paul Charles, of brokers Screentrade, says: 'The Club Direct product strikes me as a cheap publicity stunt.'

You should note there is no guarantee you would win a claim, especially if the airline provided advice on reducing the risk of DVT before take-off. The Association of British Insurers says claims against airlines are 'academic' because DVT has not been directly attributed to carriers.

 Seen an advertisement or offer which sounds too good to be true? Then write to What's the Catch? at The Observer, 119 Farringdon Rd, London EC1 3ER.

fields.headline: Post Office branches out
fields.standfirst: Bereft of benefits the PO plc wants to be all things
fields.trailText: Bereft of benefits the PO plc wants to be all things.
fields.body:
You may think of the Post Office as the people who get your letters from A to B each day but the new Post Office has ambitions to be much more. It wants you to pop in and do your banking, buy a pension, sort out your last-minute travel insurance or even collect goods you have bought over the internet.

The PO has been desperate to find money-making opportunities since being told that it will lose £400m a year from 2003, when the social security system is fully computerised and benefits and pensions are paid direct into bank accounts.

As dealing with benefits often accounts for 30 to 40 per cent of sub-postmaster's income - more in disadvantaged areas - experts feared the loss of up to 7,000 rural branches.

The PO - now using the corporate name Consignia, though this won't replace the Post Office brand in high streets - also has to fend off overseas competition as postal markets around the world deregulate. There is only room for three to four big players in the European postal market and Consignia wants to be one of them.

The PO will attain plc status on 26 March, giving it greater commercial freedom. The organisation says it has several potential money-spinners up its sleeve. But what's in it for customers?

You will soon be able to buy a pension over the counter as well as national savings bonds and insurance. Last week the PO announced it would be selling Standard Life stakeholder pensions through its 18,000-strong branch network. The cut-price pensions, whose annual management charge is 0.85 per cent, will be available from April. You will be able to open and put money into the Standard Life plan at any branch.

The Consumer Council for Postal Services has welcomed the introduction of a new financial services product at the PO after 'a period of famine' but warns that the organisation will probably have to sell more than 1 million to see a 'real bottom line benefit'. Consignia says more products are to follow. Pet insurance and mortgages have been suggested.

Home shopping is another service that will feature at the twenty-first century Post Office. From next summer the PO hopes its branches will act as a drop-off point for goods from retailers, including dotcoms, and catalogue suppliers. If you know you will not be in, you can ask for your purchases to be delivered to your local post office instead of your home. The PO will also try out the installation of American-style delivery boxes outside homes.

The development of its delivery services could cast the PO in the unlikely role of dotcom saviour. Consignia's head of home shopping, David Taylor, says: 'We may be able to help dotcoms find customers through direct mailing operations. They could also use our "pick, pack and dispatch"services. We have great experience in warehousing and customer management.' Some 20 internet companies have expressed interest so far.

Consignia is also develop-ing its banking services. Customers of Barclays, the Co-op and Lloyds TSB can already perform basic transactions at the post office, useful in areas where bank branches have closed. The service will be rolled out this autumn.

'People will be able to perform a wider range of transactions on behalf of a larger number of banks,' says Consignia's Melanie Corfield. Improvements in technology will mean you can perform the same transactions as at your normal bank for no extra charge.

Smartcards will be central. The banking smartcard will also allow you to pay utility bills and make contributions to your stakeholder pension. One swipe and your postmaster should be able to call up all your relevant details on screen.

If you are one of the 16 million people who receive benefits or pensions through the post office, you will have the option of receiving your money through the 'universal bank' at the post office.

The universal bank, which will be subsidised by seven high street banks, is a no-frills account for those who have been turned away from a high street bank. It is designed to deal with just pensions and benefits. Payments will be credited to a post office account card. There will be no charge for using the facility.

The various projects sound good, but will the Post Office be able to deliver? Derek French of the Campaign for Community Banking Services believes post offices in small communities will not be able to cope with the increased workload.

'Imagine the queues with people coming in to do all manner of business. Things already grind to a halt for the more complex transactions.'

French thinks the PO has not thought its plans through and is lobbying the Government to rethink.

However, PO spokeswoman Corfield says postmasters will be able to do things much faster than they can now. 'I know post office queues are still laughed at but we are a lot faster than banks or supermarkets.

'Ninety-five per cent of customers are served within five minutes and we will continue to monitor the situation carefully. The changes are to make smaller businesses more viable by increasing business.'

But what if you just want to post a letter or use one of the Post Offices other traditional services?

'We are part of the everyday fabric of life and we intend to stay that way,' says the Royal Mail's new head, Gillian Wilmot.

Consignia gets smart

In the new Post Office you will be able to:

 Bank with all major high street banks and access many internet bank accounts.

 Open an account at the universal bank, which will allow you to receive benefit or pension payments.

 Buy a Standard Life stakeholder pension from 5 April.

 Make stakeholder contributions and pay gas and electricity bills with a smartcard.

 Apply online for passports, driving licences and other government-controlled documents in a special kiosk. A trial starts in July in Leicestershire.

 Charge up a smartcard for bus journeys if you are eligible for free travel. A trial will start in Manchester later this year.

fields.headline: Misleading finance
fields.standfirst: Jill Insley  on an online bank censured for its iffy advertising
fields.trailText: Jill Insley on an online bank censured for its iffy advertising.
fields.body:
If you have found a recent crop of financial adverts quite incomprehensible, you are not alone. Intelligent Finance, the telephone and internet banking subsidiary of the Halifax Plc, was censured by the Advertising Standards Authoritylast week for contravening the advertising code.

The new bank was found guilty of making claims about the interest rates payable on its products in the headlines of three different adverts without substantiating the claims in the body copy and in one case, that its claims were misleading.

Intelligent Finance enables customers to maximise the interest earned on savings, or minimise the amount paid on borrowings by 'connecting' the two. For example, if you have £3,000 in a savings account earning 6 per cent, and a personal loan for £2,000 costing 10.5 per cent, you can choose to have £2,000 from your savings account 'connected' with the loan. This means you will earn no interest on the £2,000 from the savings account, but you will also have nothing to pay on the loan, saving you 4.5 per cent in interest charges.

But as Intelligent Finance has found, explaining the concept and its effects in a clear manner can be difficult.

In one of the offending adverts, the bank says: 'Intelligent Finance is the only bank where you can get a personal loan and pay no interest*.' A separate section of the advert showed the figure 10.5 per cent APR with an arrow below pointing to 0 per cent APR.

The asterisk refers the reader to a note in small print at the bottom of the advert, which explains: 'If you choose to have 0 per cent APR on all or part of your outstanding personal loan balance, we will not pay interest on a corresponding part of your current account or savings...'

However, complainants objected that the advert was misleading because it implied that the loan's interest rate fell from 10.5 per cent to 0 per cent. The complainants challenged this implication on the grounds that consumers would forfeit the interest normally paid on a current or savings account and the ultimate saving would not actually be 10.5 per cent but a smaller amount. The ASA agreed that because the body copy of the advert did not make clear that customers would have to forfeit the interest on their savings or current account, the headline claim was misleading.

Another advert read: 'Intelligent Finance is the only bank that will pay you a massive 10.8 per cent AER/gross* on your current account.'

Again the asterisk refers to the small print, which explains how the current account can be connected with a credit card account: 'We give you the choice of maximising the interest you receive or minimising the interest you pay us. If you choose to earn 10.8 per cent AER/gross on your current account, you will still pay 10.8 per cent on your outstanding credit card balance.'

However, although the ASA accepted that the small print stated that customers would pay the same interest on their outstanding credit card balance as the interest they received on their current account, it considered that this was a significant condition that should be stated in the body copy.

The ASA said that it 'considered the conditions of the offer were not clear and that the adverts were misleading.' Heather Scott, a spokeswoman for Intelligent Finance, says: 'We are disappointed by this decision. We did draw readers' attention to how our products can be connected through the prominent display of an asterisk in the advert "headline".'

The ASA's ruling is likely to amuse compilers of best-buy product tables, including MoneyFacts. Intelligent Finance's chief executive Jim Spowart criticised MoneyFacts for refusing to include the bank's most competitive rates because they could only be achieved if the customer met precise conditions. At the time of the spat, John Woods, chief executive of MoneyFacts, said: 'Best-buy charts can only compare like with like. Intelligent Finance has chosen to bring out an extremely complicated product which a lot of people will find difficult to understand.'

The complainants challenged this implication on the grounds that consumers would forfeit the interest normally paid on a current or savings account and the ultimate saving would not actually be 10.5 per cent but a smaller amount. The ASA agreed that because the body copy of the advert did not make clear that customers would have to forfeit the interest on their savings or current account, the headline claim was misleading. Another advert read: 'Intelligent Finance is the only bank that will pay you a massive 10.8 per cent AER/gross* on your current account.' Again the asterisk refers to the small print, which explains how the current account can be connected with a credit card account: 'We give you the choice of maximising the interest you receive or minimising the interest you pay us. If you choose to earn 10.8 per cent AER/gross on your current account, you will still pay 10.8 per cent on your outstanding credit card balance.' However, although the ASA accepted that the small print stated that customers would pay the same interest on their outstanding credit card balance as the interest they received on their current account, it considered that this was a significant condition that should be stated in the body copy. The ASA said that it 'considered the conditions of the offer were not clear and that the adverts were misleading.' Heather Scott, a spokeswoman for Intelligent Finance, says: 'We are disappointed by this decision. We did draw readers' attention to how our products can be connected through the prominent display of an asterisk in the advert "headline".' The ASA's ruling is likely to amuse compilers of best-buy product tables, including MoneyFacts. Intelligent Finance's chief executive Jim Spowart criticised MoneyFacts for refusing to include the bank's most competitive rates because they could only be achieved if the customer met precise conditions. At the time of the spat, John Woods, chief executive of MoneyFacts, said: 'Best-buy charts can only compare like with like. Intelligent Finance has chosen to bring out an extremely complicated product which a lot of people will find difficult to understand.'

webTitle: Money writes: Am I in hot water over solar panels?

fields.headline: Am I in hot water over solar panels?
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers.
fields.body:
I was visited by a rep from Sunseeker solar panels. After two hours, I had been persuaded to sign an agreement to have the work done for £5,490. He told me that I would be able to claim all this money back in five years' time from the Marine & General International Insurance Company in a cashback deal.

I paid a £1,700 deposit. After he left, I could find no trace of Marine & General on the internet or from BT Enquiries so I cancelled my £1,700 cheque and wrote to Sunseeker explaining my actions.

Sunseeker is now taking me to court unless I pay £1,000 for cancelling the order. I find this very unjust.
JP, Porthmadog

You will not know whether a cashback scheme works until you come to claim, in five years' time. Sunseeker pays a premium to Marine & General International Insurance, which underwrites the scheme.

Then, as Sunseeker makes clear, it is an insurance policy which 'needs the client to remember to claim'. For a successful claim, you must send the original invoice, proof of payment and proof of identity within a limited timescale to the correct address.

You need to be careful with the timing because Marine & General International is based in Turkish Cyprus.

Success also requires the underwriter still to be in business in five years' time. A different cashback scheme, Intervest, was wound up in 1997 by the Department for Trade and Industry.

Obviously, you are not eligible for the cashback scheme now because you cancelled your order. Sunseeker believes you still owe the cancellation charge but says it is a reputable company of four years' standing and 'we will not be pursuing legal proceedings'.

I have forwarded the paperwork you sent me to the Department of Trade and Industry who have indicated that they are interested in hearing from other readers involved in cashback schemes.

Passbook woes: Britannia sorry

When I asked the Britannia building society to update my passbook last August, the cashier said I was getting the wrong interest so they kept my book. Then they wanted my previous cancelled passbook but three weeks later admitted they could not find my papers. In October and November I telephoned again but since then I have heard nothing.
DB, Norwich

Britannia is aghast at the way its staff have handled your simple request. It is down to human error: an assistant manager left and no one picked up responsibility for your transaction. Britannia readily admits that this is no excuse for such disgraceful behaviour and the branch has been made aware of head office's feelings.

Britannia has calculated the interest you have earned from the time you opened the account in 1997 to date and credited £89 to your account plus £50 compensation for its poor service.

House sale profit: Wrong figures

I am an NHS nursing sister working in London. My husband and I took a mortgage with Nationwide Building Society in 1989 under a scheme to help NHS employees. In return for a reduced interest rate, we share our profit with Nationwide when selling.

We bought the house through North British Housing Association who kept a 15 per cent stake. According to Nationwide's figures, if we sold the house for £100,000, once we have repaid North British and Nationwide we would be left with only about £6,000 deposit for a new house.

We would like to move on from our one-bedroom starter home but it will be difficult to find an affordable home with this small deposit.
CG, Hampton

Looking more closely at your question, Nationwide says many current staff have no experience of this scheme which was available for only one year.

It has discovered that the figures you were quoted were wrong and you are not quite so badly off.

You have to pay Nationwide 47 per cent of the difference between the purchase price and selling price but only on your 85 per cent ownership.

Instead of the £17,000 you feared, you have to pay the society only £10,000. You still owe £42,000 on the mortgage so with £52,000 going to Nationwide and £15,000 to North British, you would have £33,000 left if you sell for £100,000.

Water supplier: Bill backdated

We receive our water from a private supply, the Duke of Somerset's Estate. Some months ago, it said we had been undercharged on our bills back to 1998.

I am annoyed at the stance taken by the Estate and so far have refused to pay even though it is only £10.24. Now they are threatening to charge interest on the unpaid amount.

I have previously complained to them about bad water pressure although we have now got used to not being able to brush our teeth just after we have flushed the toilet. They say the pipe to our cottage is too small and that it is our responsibility. They now seem to regard calculating the charge for the water as our responsibility as well.
MF, Frome

The Estate says this clerical error was unfortunate but you still owe the money and most customers have paid up.

As a private water company, it does not come under Ofwat's jurisdiction so you cannot take your complaint to the regulator.

The Estate is aware of the disproportionate cost of chasing small debts and perhaps it will have a rethink.

Tessa yields: Why a shortfall?

I had a Tessa with Save & Prosper Flemings Premier Bank which matured last September for £11,370. The Chase de Vere Tessa maturity tables showed recently that the average Tessa yield is £12,470.

While accepting that there will be above and below average yields, the shortfall is significant.
UR, New Milton

You are not comparing like with like.

You had a Tessa One where you could invest no more than £3,000 in the first year and then decreasing amounts over the next four.

The table you saw is for Tessa Two and based on £9,000 invested for the whole five years.

Even so, Flemings Premier Bank was the worst performing Tessa Two according to Chase de Vere. It delivered £12,050 after five years whereas the best performer was Bristol & West's stockmarket linked Tessa with £15,942.

fields.headline: It's a girl's life
fields.standfirst: How to create a woman-friendly Army
fields.trailText: How to create a woman-friendly Army
fields.body:
The finding last week that women soldiers were eight times more prone to injury in infantry training than their male counterparts came at just the right time for Colonel Blimps from Tunbridge Wells to Harrogate. The case for women serving on the front line was getting rather strong. Senior Army officers had been privately conceding that traditional objections - 'Who'd keep the home fires burning?', 'Can a woman lift a Challenger tank on her back?', 'Could she disembowel the enemy and skewer his/her eyeballs?' - had all more or less been accommodated by the Army proviso that women should undergo 'gender-free' testing and prove they could match male colleagues in physical strength.

But what if women really are more likely to bayonet themselves or their comrades and cannot climb out of trenches, as the Army trials suggest? Wrong trials, we say. A clear case of institutional sexism. Gender-free testing may mean not making allowances for women. But it also means establishing rules that do not advantage men. So, ban those boys' toys - a modern army doesn't need guns and knives; make the trenches shallower and appoint a few dozen women generals.

And does the Army really need so many maps?

webTitle: Leader: Labour should heed voices of Bristol

fields.headline: Short sharp lesson
fields.standfirst: Labour should heed voices of Bristol
fields.trailText: Labour should heed voices of Bristol
fields.body:
The Labour Party has sought to set the tone this weekend for a spring general election campaign. As no party member needs reminding, this is the first time in 100 years that the possibility of a second full term of office is within Labour's reach. An emerging plank of the party's victory strategy is to pledge the better public services which can only be provided by sustained long-term investment.

However, last week the electors of Bristol gave a short, sharp shock to Labour's modernising tendency. In a local plebiscite on future levels of the council tax, 54 per cent of those who voted wanted no increase at all, in spite of explicit warnings that this would mean a cut to the city's education budget, the biggest component of council spending.

Early reaction to this setback for schools - and particularly for school teachers, who may face redundancy - has been all too patronising. Councillors have been accused of framing the wrong questions, voters have been accused of failing to understand the importance of education, and the council has been challenged to ignore the result of its poll.

But if Bristol's voters have spoken, its council should listen. As devolution in Scotland and Wales made clear, the public might not always deliver exactly what politicians want or expect. That does not lessen the value of devolution or, necessarily, local referendums.

The error of Bristol's local politicians last week was not the way in which they posed their pioneering question at all. It was their failure to prosecute and win an explicit public argument for better services funded from higher taxes. Whether that resulted from political cowardice, lack of persuasiveness or mere oversight does not matter. It is a most important lesson that Labour needs to learn now if it is not to expose itself to opportunistic attack from the Conservative Party during a general election campaign.

webTitle: No, honestly, it's a comedy from Sweden

fields.headline: No, honestly, it's a comedy from Sweden
fields.standfirst: Roy Andersson's Cannes winner Songs From the Second Floor is a slice of Buñuel for the new millennium
fields.trailText:
Songs From the Second Floor (98 mins, 15) Directed by Roy Andersson; starring Lars Nordh, Stefan Larsson
State and Main (102 mins, 15) Directed by David Mamet; starring William H. Macy, Alec Baldwin, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Sarah Jessica Parker
Centre Stage (115 mins, 12) Directed by Nicholas Hytner; starring Amanda Schull, Peter Gallagher, Ethan Stiefel
Breakfast at Tiffany's (115 mins, 15) Directed by Blake Edwards; starring Audrey Hepburn, George Peppard, Patricia Neal
The Emperor's New Groove (78 mins, U) Directed by Mark Dindall; featuring the voices of David Spade, John Goodman, Eartha Kitt
Dungeons and Dragons (108 mins, 12) Directed by Courtney Solomon; starring Jeremy Irons, Bruce Payne, Marlon Wayons, Thora Birch
fields.body:
Songs From the Second Floor (98 mins, 15) Directed by Roy Andersson; starring Lars Nordh, Stefan Larsson
State and Main (102 mins, 15) Directed by David Mamet; starring William H. Macy, Alec Baldwin, Philip Seymour Hoffman, Sarah Jessica Parker
Centre Stage (115 mins, 12) Directed by Nicholas Hytner; starring Amanda Schull, Peter Gallagher, Ethan Stiefel
Breakfast at Tiffany's (115 mins, 15) Directed by Blake Edwards; starring Audrey Hepburn, George Peppard, Patricia Neal
The Emperor's New Groove (78 mins, U) Directed by Mark Dindall; featuring the voices of David Spade, John Goodman, Eartha Kitt
Dungeons and Dragons (108 mins, 12) Directed by Courtney Solomon; starring Jeremy Irons, Bruce Payne, Marlon Wayons, Thora Birch

The week's most interesting film, which shared the Jury Prize at Cannes last year with Samira Makhmalbaf's Blackboards, is Songs From the Second Floor, the first feature-length work for 25 years by Roy Andersson, Sweden's most innovative producer of TV commercials. It's a pessimistic comedy, heavily influenced by Buñuel and Ionesco, taking a bleak view of the millennium.

Performed by a non-professional cast, the film unfolds in a series of tableaux, each shot in deep focus in a single take from a fixed point of view. Only once does the camera move, when a tracking shot follows a man down a station platform. Crowds of flagellating penitents walk the streets of a gridlocked city. Heads of the armed forces gather to celebrate the hundredth birth day of a senile fascist. A businessman, whose poet son is in an asylum, walks the streets after burning down his office and gets a job selling crucifixes for the millennium. A magician screws up while sawing a volunteer in half. Representatives of Church and State cast a virgin into a quarry as a form of sacrifice. A party of middle-class Scandinavian xenophobes beat to a pulp a central European who asks for their help. Parties of tourists attempt to cross an airport concourse with impossible quantities of luggage. And so it goes.

Equipped with music by the director's unrelated namesake, Benny Andersson of Abba, Songs From the Second Floor is a technical tour de force. But Andersson brings an end to such nervous laughter as the film has generated by introducing at the halfway mark the ghost of a Holocaust victim whom, in a flashback, we've seen hanged by the SS alongside his sister.

In State and Main, his first disappointing film to date, David Mamet gently mocks the moviemaking business through an account of the crises attendant on the shooting of a minor Hollywood movie in a small Vermont town. The production had to shift there as the result of an unmentionable event that had them ejected from New Hampshire, and though the picture (a costume piece set in the late nineteenth-century) is called The Old Mill, they discover that the local mill was burned down in 1960.

Every character is overly familiar, from the second-rank star with a penchant for underage girls (convincingly played by Alec Baldwin) to the idealistic playwright seeing his first screenplay being mangled (a surprisingly uncertain Philip Seymour Hoffman). The film-within-the-film doesn't ring true and is as remote from Mamet's own work as were the dated plays he sent up in his one truly feeble stage play, A Life in the Theatre. It doesn't compare with his acid satire on Hollywood, Speed the Plow, or Alan Alda's generous comedy about the collision between small-town folk and filmmakers, Sweet Liberty .

Far funnier is Nicholas Hytner's Centre Stage, a virtual anthology of every dance movie cliché packed into a year at the American Ballet Academy in New York. Can Jody cut it? Will talented African-American Eve get over her defensive arrogance? And so on. From a dozen cherishable lines, my favourite is delivered by the coldly disciplined student to the mother who's driven her on to fulfil her frustrated ambitions: 'You didn't have the feet - I didn't have the heart.'

There are, as they say, some staggering dancers here, but fortunately they pull themselves together when they get away from the script and on to the stage. Unfortunately, these performances are sacrificed to those last-minute changes of cast occasioned by broken knees and cold feet. The climactic ballet, though well danced, is intended to be a dramatic allegory about the rivalry between its creator, the company's leading dancer, and the American Ballet's director but is, in fact, excessively vulgar.

It would be pleasant, and characteristic, for me to say how wonderful the reissued 1961 Breakfast at Tiffany's is, and how they don't make them like this anymore. In fact, I'd forgotten just how dreadfully indulgent a celebration of bogus eccentricity it is. The film shifts Truman Capote's novella from the last months of the Second World War to 1960 and turns the narrator into a rather dubious heterosexual, the way I Am a Camera turned the Christopher Isherwood of Goodbye to Berlin into a straight. There's no doubt that Isherwood's wilful Sally Bowles inspired Capote's capricious Holly Golightly, and both help to create the present dramatic tradition of bruised women with sympathetic gay confidantes.

Audrey Hepburn looks beautiful (she's photographed by the great Czech-born veteran who lit her in Roman Holiday, The Nun's Story and The Children's Hour), but she's a pain in the neck (mine, not her swan-like cou) and the film has an ineffable vulgarity in its cultural assumptions and social observation. The endless drinking jokes can be forgiven considering that the following year Blake Edwards made Days of Wine and Roses , one of the best studies of alcoholism. Inexcusable, however, is Mickey Rooney's performance as the irate Japanese photographer on the top floor of Holly's brownstone apartment house. This is racism that comes close to the anti-Semitic caricatures in Julius Streicher's Der Stürmer .

The latest Disney animated feature, The Emperor's New Groove, arrives here after widely publicised production problems and box-office disaster over Christmas. In fact, this tale of a hubristic young prince in pre-Columbian America learning a little humility from a kindly peasant after he's been turned into a llama by a wicked sorceress isn't at all bad. The self-referential post-modernist style is amusing and there are fewer songs than usual, though one of them - Sting and David Hartley's 'My Funny Friend and Me' - has been Oscar nominated.

Inspired by the seminal, 25-year-old adolescent game, Dungeons and Dragons is a slow, oppressive sword-and-sorcery romance. Shot in Prague with an Anglo-American cast headed by Jeremy Irons and including such cult luminaries as Tom Baker and Richard O'Brien, it might well have been called 'Look Who's Tolkien'.

This is racism that comes close to the anti-Semitic caricatures in Julius Streicher's Der Stürmer . The latest Disney animated feature, The Emperor's New Groove, arrives here after widely publicised production problems and box-office disaster over Christmas. In fact, this tale of a hubristic young prince in pre-Columbian America learning a little humility from a kindly peasant after he's been turned into a llama by a wicked sorceress isn't at all bad. The self-referential post-modernist style is amusing and there are fewer songs than usual, though one of them - Sting and David Hartley's 'My Funny Friend and Me' - has been Oscar nominated. Inspired by the seminal, 25-year-old adolescent game, Dungeons and Dragons is a slow, oppressive sword-and-sorcery romance. Shot in Prague with an Anglo-American cast headed by Jeremy Irons and including such cult luminaries as Tom Baker and Richard O'Brien, it might well have been called 'Look Who's Tolkien'.

fields.headline: Helping: David's story
fields.standfirst: Read 'Hooked on addiction' here
fields.trailText: 'I came to treatment thinking I was addicted to codeine tablets, but since I've been here, I've found out that my primary addiction is helping people. But it's not as simple as that: I now know that I have an addictive personality. The centre I go to, Promis, treats addiction across the board; they don't treat the alcoholic or the gambler, they treat the addict. For me, being an addict means I use anything to get what I want.
fields.body:
'I came to treatment thinking I was addicted to codeine tablets, but since I've been here, I've found out that my primary addiction is helping people. But it's not as simple as that: I now know that I have an addictive personality. The centre I go to, Promis, treats addiction across the board; they don't treat the alcoholic or the gambler, they treat the addict. For me, being an addict means I use anything to get what I want.

I go to AA, NA, SAA (Sex Addicts Anonymous) and Helpers Anonymous. Looking back, helping people started when I was eight and I was sexually abused by a 14-year-old boy. Even though the experience was painful, I still let it happen because I wanted him to like me. Then my father died when I was nine, but it was never really discussed. I had no outlet for my emotions. But I didn't raise it with my mother because I didn't want to upset her. So it was me compulsively helping her. Shortly after that, my sex addiction started. I was going out cottaging and cruising at the age of 10, because I wanted to get the attention I wasn't getting at home.

In my adult life, my need to be liked continued. I got a senior position as a manager of a nursing home. But if my boss came down and gave me a huge pile of work, I'd say, "Yes, I'll take it on" and I'd feel really resentful. That turned into anger, and then I'd press the self-destruct button by taking a whole load of pills or just getting drunk. It was really about wanting to be needed, to be a part of something.

For 14 years I was addicted to codeine tablets - I ended up taking 120 tablets a day. Then I lost my job and went into treatment for six weeks, but it only dealt with drug/alcohol problems.

I got off the tablets, but because I thought kicking the codeine habit was the whole answer, I relapsed to alcohol on the train home. Eventually I found a relationship, which is still going, and kind of got myself back on track, but then my codeine usage began again; I was unhappy in my job, basically because of the compulsive helping, so I began using tablets again to compensate for that.

So I'm in treatment again and I understand now that I'm an addict. I'll go to meetings for the rest of my life, but they're just a part of my life, not my main focus. The knack is not to become addicted to, you know, being an addict.'

 Promis has a 24-hour helpline: 0800 374 318.

fields.headline: Alcohol: Paul's story
fields.standfirst: Read 'Hooked on addiction' here
fields.trailText: 'I went to Alcoholics Anonymous via a treatment centre. I went there convinced I was addicted to alcohol, and I still bet my life on that surrender every day. I believe that when I take alcohol, my body reacts in a different way to that of social drinkers. Addiction is an obsession of the mind coupled with an allergy of the body, and I'm grateful to know that I'm an addict, because that discovery has made me happier than I've ever been, before or during drinking.
fields.body:
'I went to Alcoholics Anonymous via a treatment centre. I went there convinced I was addicted to alcohol, and I still bet my life on that surrender every day. I believe that when I take alcohol, my body reacts in a different way to that of social drinkers. Addiction is an obsession of the mind coupled with an allergy of the body, and I'm grateful to know that I'm an addict, because that discovery has made me happier than I've ever been, before or during drinking.

I spent years trying to disprove the fact that I'm an addict. The first time I got drunk I was sick and started a fight with another 16-year-old who was rumoured to carry a knife. I ended the night wiping out four hours of my life completely, between leaving the party and getting home to my distraught parents. Yet within a few days, I was looking forward to repeating the experience. And I had no idea why.

They say alcoholism is so powerful because the victim is the last to recognise the problem.

I was in deep denial. Somewhere along the line, those great semi-drunken feelings and fantasies became more elusive. Bad stuff moved in and I began to share the suffering I'd been dishing out to family and friends.

"If I ever lift my hand to a woman" became "That cow, she'd drive a saint to distraction." And "I never have a drink first thing in the morning" became "There's no point paying outrageous pub prices every lunchtime." Eventually I lost my wife. I lost my son. I lost my profession. Life became very lonely and another drink soon dulled the pain.

Eventually I went to Alcoholics Anonymous.

I didn't really want to stop drinking, but I wanted the trouble to stop. AA meetings gave me hope, identification, information, but it was not enough. I was not convinced that booze had me beaten. I would use my new-found knowledge to drink "properly". A year of further "research" saw me drinking against my will and becoming suicidal. I realised I was an alcoholic then, but couldn't stop. One day I found myself in a tube station going nowhere, terrified in case I threw myself in front of the train. I cried for help again and thousands of dry days have now passed; if I don't lift the first drink, I can't get drunk.

I have been sober for 17 years. But if I don't do the 12-steps, I'm unlikely to stay sober. AA is a lifelong commitment for me.'

 Alcoholics Anonymous can be contacted on 0845 7697 555.
