webTitle: Observer review: IBM and the Holocaust by Edwin Black

fields.headline: Six million and counting
fields.standfirst: Hitler's Holocaust was happening anyway. With IBM's help, it was easier, as Edwin Black demonstrates in IBM and the Holocaust
fields.trailText: Hitler's Holocaust was happening anyway. With IBM's help, it was easier, as Edwin Black demonstrates in IBM and the Holocaust
fields.body:
IBM and the Holocaust
Edwin Black
Little, Brown £20, pp519

Yout thought, perhaps, that there was nothing fresh left to write about the Holocaust. Think, sadly, again. Edwin Black, a dedicated, even driven, researcher, has a new charge sheet to present. It shows, in compelling detail, that IBM, 'the solutions company', was also the company of the final solution.

How did Hitler, from 1933 on, find, herd and exterminate millions of his Jewish victims with such sickening precision? Easy. IBM, through its German subsidiary, Dehomag, ran his censuses and surveys on its unique punch-card tabulators. It provided the vital infrastructure for persecution and the the silence of the gas chambers. What is more, it knew exactly what it was doing.

Thomas Watson, the chief executive who built one of America's greatest international enterprises, did not receive the Merit Cross of the German Eagle for nothing, but for services knowingly rendered. Watson is the villain of this piece. He was a classic American success story, the sewing-machine salesman who became corporate emperor, president of the International Chamber of Commerce and chum of FDR, but also a covert admirer of the Third Reich who peddled his hanging chads with fawning eagerness.

There is no scope for doubt. Black has a relentless flow of memos, letters and speeches. When Watson wrote in 1937 (long after his punch cards had begun their whirring work) that the world 'must extend a sympathetic understanding to the German people and their aims under the leadership of Adolf Hitler', he had the clearest knowledge of what those aims entailed.

His fractious underling at the Dehomag subsidiary put it yet more chillingly: 'We are very much like physicians,' he told his Nazi audience, 'in that we dissect, cell by cell, the German cultural body... these are not dead little cards; quite to the contrary, they prove later on that they come to life when they are sorted at 25,000 an hour according to certain characteristics.'

As the war took hold, Watson found himself trapped between a PR rock and a ruthless hard place. He sent his medal back and disavowed his German clients, but he still kept the tabulators turning, still gathered the profits, was still on hand as the conflict ended to turn Dehomag into IBM Germany and go marching on. That, in a sense, is all you need to know. It is a distinctive contribution to the history of the time. It wholly justifies Black's years of toil. At such a distance, however, the reader inevitably looks for understanding beyond the damning facts, for a more contemporary relevance to set multinational America wriggling uneasily in its chair. Such parallels are easy enough to construct.

'Watson was no fascist. He was pure capitalist. But the horseshoe of political economics finds little distance between extremities. Accretion of wealth by and for the state under a strong autocratic leader fortified by jingoism and hero-worship was appealing to Watson. After all, his followers wore uniforms, sang songs and were expected to display unquestioned loyalty to the company he led.'

Alas, though, Black loads the dice of depravity too relentlessly to make his symbols resonate. He isn't unfair to Watson or the old IBM in the sense that, on such evidence, unfairness is impossible, but the repetitiveness of his polemical interludes grows wearying. Selecting 25 quotes from the New York Times doesn't paint the full context of the era. Eschewing any mention of Britain, Churchill or Chamberlain draws the focus of what he says was 'obvious' to the world too narrowly. If we're to feel the full horror of Watson's deceptions and manoeuvres, we need to see him in the round, not merely as yet another rent-a-tyrant of a tycoon.

The facts (to reiterate) speak for themselves. Hitler would have had his Holocaust without IBM's willing efforts, but it would have been a longer, less clinically efficient business. IBM helped the trains to his concentration camps run on time, spewed out the cards for slave labour and watched its stock-market majesty grow. It was the backbone of Auschwitz and Roosevelt's first social security programme, a 'service industry' which existed to serve whoever paid the bill and not to make moral judgments until forced to confront them.

That, in itself, is a terrible warning from this brilliantly excavated past. It is what Black knows and, thus, all we need to know: findings that need no emotion or righteous anger; findings that speak for themselves.

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Clay-pigeon shooter Richard Faulds had the talent to win a medal at the Sydney Olympics, but it was only when his mentor Peter Terry introduced him to his alter ego 'The Iceman' that he made gold a certainty
fields.trailText: Clay-pigeon shooter Richard Faulds had the talent to win a medal at the Sydney Olympics, but it was only when his mentor Peter Terry introduced him to his alter ego 'The Iceman' that he made gold a certainty
fields.body:
Richard Faulds Shooting is more of a mental battle than a physical sport. I'd been struggling with my concentration for a while - it affected me badly at the 1996 Olympics - so, at my coach Ian Coley's suggestion, in 1998 I hooked up with Peter. My problem was that in between shooting pairs of clays, I thought about silly things like what I was going to have for tea. Irrelevant stuff, but it put me off. I was struggling to keep a one-track mind.

Initially he introduced me to deep-breathing routines, but they didn't work.

I ended up thinking more about breathing than shooting. Then Peter came up with this idea of The Iceman. He said, 'I would describe you as a pretty cool character. I'm going to call you The Iceman'. He meant that I was cool, calm and collected, that nothing would rattle me. That was a good reading of my personality on the outside, but inside I was thinking, 'Bloody hell, I'm so frustrated I want to chuck the empty shotgun cartridges across the shooting range.' He put a little blue-dot sticker in the middle of my watch. The idea was that when I looked at my watch, I would think: 'I am The Iceman' and have a single-track mind.

It sounds silly, but it worked instantly. Within three weeks I won the British Open and the World Championships and set a new world record of 193 clays out of 200. My concentration improved completely. Peter helped me hugely during last year's Olympics in Sydney. Five of us shared a house - myself, Peter, Ian Coley, Ian Peel, another shooter Peter was working with who won a silver medal, and Joe Neville, Ian's coach. Peter was brilliant.

I really benefited from Peter's influence during the head-to-head shoot-off to decide between gold and silver. The crowd was supporting Russell Mark, the defending champion who's Australian. But I blocked all that out and ended up with a gold medal. I couldn't have done it without Peter. He has recently moved to Australia, but he'll continue to play a role in my shooting, like at the World Championships in Cairo in May. Once something's going quite well, you don't like to change it.

Peter Terry Before meeting Richard I'd worked with the England cricket team, Welsh rugby side, snooker players such as Jimmy White, and the British bobsleigh crew which won bronze at the 1998 Winter Olympics. Richard was shooting badly in big competitions because he was getting nervous. He didn't believe he could break through at the highest level. That's an almost universal problem among elite sports people - only a minority think they're going to win. Most only hope to win.

I worked on Richard's thought processes, some of his attitudes about himself and some aspects of his physical control. He had no psychological problems - he was just a normal guy struggling to get the best out of himself. He's an uncomplicated man so I decided to keep it simple and not overload him with things to think about.

The blue dot was meant to keep Richard composed. Every time he saw it, he had to practise his breathing. He needed that to avoid getting into a rapid downward spiral where he starts to think about things going wrong, which leads to physical tension, and he misses clays. The Iceman idea gave him an anchor to fix all his effort on during tournaments. In competition, he'd been more of a nervous child than an Iceman, but he underwent psychological growth.

Richard's mum told Ian Coley and me that the best way to keep him happy in Sydney was to do everything for him, so we did exactly that. All he had to do was hit clays. I played the Whitney Houston song 'One Moment in Time' to make him think he was there to fulfil his destiny. Its lyrics are fantastic for sport - 'You're a winner for a lifetime/if you seize that one moment in time'. At first he sang along but then he went quiet because he was listening to it.

Happily Sydney was Richard's moment in time. Our preparations paid off. In the shoot-off, he really was The Iceman. People say, 'You've helped to create an Olympic champion.' I see it as helping someone become something they were always capable of becoming. He says he couldn't have done it without me, but he may well be wrong about that.

fields.headline: Drugs: Kate's story
fields.standfirst: Read 'Hooked on addiction' here
fields.trailText: 'I would describe myself as having had a very good upbringing, very privileged, all the right schools, and I remember a very happy childhood. But I still ended up homeless in a burnt-out car in Peckham, scoring drugs off the street. For me, the nature of addiction is to be aware but powerless to do anything about it.
fields.body:
'I would describe myself as having had a very good upbringing, very privileged, all the right schools, and I remember a very happy childhood. But I still ended up homeless in a burnt-out car in Peckham, scoring drugs off the street. For me, the nature of addiction is to be aware but powerless to do anything about it.

I was one of those "Thank you what was that" kind of addicts. I'd try anything, do anything. There was a time when I used drugs and their use interfered in my family life, my work life, then I crossed a line and my family and social life impinged on my drug use. At which point I was chronically addicted - anything that got in the way of my addiction got trashed.

I got a habit within the first three months of taking heroin. Then I started on cocaine and crack. I've burnt half my lungs out on the pipe. No holding back. I lived with my then boyfriend and all we did was hang around taking drugs, dealing drugs. I first went into rehab in 1983, but I used the day I came out. Eventually, I went through 12 rehab places.

The last time, I could barely speak, I was so terrified. I was on probation for theft. I was using methadone, crack cocaine, Rohypnol, a heady cocktail. I was constantly overdosing and coming round in hospital. I hated myself. I had burgled my own parents. I'd lost the will to live.

I just wanted it to stop. I went to an NA meeting and a woman who worked for a rehab charity asked if I seriously wanted help, and I said I did. She made me call her every night for a fortnight and then in the third week she said, "My husband's going to drop you off at rehab tomorrow morning." And he did, and bit by bit, I put my head above the parapet.

The really amazing thing, three-and-a-half drug-free years later, is that I feel better now on a daily basis than I ever felt taking serious amounts of chemicals. Going to NA has opened up my mind. I learnt through listening to other people, people who have been there for me.'

 Narcotics Anonymous can be contacted on 020 7251 4007. Write to UK Service Office, PO Box 1980, London N19 3LS

She made me call her every night for a fortnight and then in the third week she said, "My husband's going to drop you off at rehab tomorrow morning." And he did, and bit by bit, I put my head above the parapet. The really amazing thing, three-and-a-half drug-free years later, is that I feel better now on a daily basis than I ever felt taking serious amounts of chemicals. Going to NA has opened up my mind. I learnt through listening to other people, people who have been there for me.'  Narcotics Anonymous can be contacted on 020 7251 4007. Write to UK Service Office, PO Box 1980, London N19 3LS

fields.headline: Sex: Simon's story
fields.standfirst: Read 'Hooked on addiction' here
fields.trailText: 'I first started being treated for sex addiction nine years ago, but it began when I was four or five. My mother had a brain tumour and because my family was all in crisis, it was very easy to accidentally neglect me. So I was faced with the reality of a world where my mother was dying, and there was nobody to comfort me. I found an escape, though, this magical place where I could feel warm and comforted and over which I had complete control. I got stuck in masturbation. My view was, and continued to be: "Reality kills, reality is impossible", therefore at any moment that reality seemed the slightest bit threatening, I slipped out.
fields.body:
'I first started being treated for sex addiction nine years ago, but it began when I was four or five. My mother had a brain tumour and because my family was all in crisis, it was very easy to accidentally neglect me. So I was faced with the reality of a world where my mother was dying, and there was nobody to comfort me. I found an escape, though, this magical place where I could feel warm and comforted and over which I had complete control. I got stuck in masturbation. My view was, and continued to be: "Reality kills, reality is impossible", therefore at any moment that reality seemed the slightest bit threatening, I slipped out.

Sex addiction is nothing to do with frequency. It's to do with preoccupation. When I decided I needed help, I seemed to be spending nine-tenths of my life thinking about sex, looking at pornography or having sex. It's this total preoccupation which is the most damaging thing. There is a contrast between addictive sex and healthy sex. Healthy sex has to do with a relationship which is certainly a friendship, which is based on trust. Addictive sex is this switch, a switch to a different place.

I would say that there was not a single day when this addiction was not part of my life. Addiction starts as a lifesaver and ends up as a killer. The life-saving quality of addiction meant that I avoided suicide because I didn't realise I was depressed . Eventually, though, this complete disconnection from reality makes addiction a killer. I'm gay and I used to have sex with men and I had no idea who they were, they could have been total psychopaths, and I think one or two of them were. Someone mugged me eventually.

I went through 10 years, off and on, of fairly conventional psychotherapy, which really didn't help me. For a long time I saw I had a problem, but I hadn't really recognised the scale of it.

The spiritual connection with the 12-step programme worked for me. I also found it really helpful to see my problem in terms of addiction. And whereas I used to spend 99 per cent of my time preoccupied with sex, nowadays, it's about 1 per cent of my time. Now I recognise the signs. One of the tools used by sex addicts is the three-second rule. If you find yourself in a preoccupation, the answer is to say, "It will take me three seconds to get out of it, to draw myself back to reality." So I go: "One, two, three breathe. Right, I'm back."'

 Sex Addicts Anonymous can be contacted on 020 8442 0026. Write to the SAA Intergroup, BCM, Box 1457, London WC1.

fields.headline: Latin lunches
fields.standfirst: Sue Webster goes in search of the taste of Italy
fields.trailText: Sue Webster goes in search of the taste of Italy.
fields.body:
Orsino, Church Road, Hove (01273 770999). It's not just the pictures of illustrious natives such as Michelangelo and Leonardo da Vinci that make habitués of Orsino describe it as 'very continental'. There are marble columns, arches and tables; quite grand for a seaside eatery where the pasta dishes cost between £4.95 and £5.25. Specials sound like 70s throwbacks - lamb with honey and rosemary sauce or duck with raspberry and plum sauce - but in any case most people go for fish, steak, omelettes and ice cream. The house wine is £7.95. It must make quite a change for London restaurateur Peter Stringfellow, who often goes there with his mum.

Luca's, Morningside Road, Edinburgh (0131 446 0223). Famous for their home-made Italian ice cream, the old-fashioned Olympia Café in Musselburgh (0131 665 2237) spawned this shiny new offshoot last year. People still come 'to see what it's like', and only die-hard traditionalists are disappointed by the bright and airy room, gleaming soda bar and mouthwatering display of fresh chocolates. Staple fare is pizza, pasta, panini and salad, with nothing over £5 and a BYO policy which only charges £1.50 corkage. After 8pm the clientele seems to mainly consist of couples, theatre goers, church groups and exhausted karate-club members.

Zeffirelli's, Compston Road, Ambleside (015394 33845). This wholefood pizzeria comes with a cinema attached on the main drag in a town otherwise known as a hiking centre. Smart, modern and with delicious food, which is simple, yet carefully cooked on the premises, its best deal is the £15.50 three-course supper (choose anything off the menu), including coffee and a reserved cinema seat. Not everyone stays for the movie - you can be in and out with a bill for two people, including wine, for £22 - but the arty atmosphere is pervasive, and the staff have a sense of humour; Hannibal is on at the moment, and they promise a 'gore-met' menu.

Tiggi's, Guildhall Street, Preston (01772 887766). Highly recommended for its lively atmosphere, this city centre Italian is popular for celebrations, when 'the chefs tend to go a bit mad', singing along to a tape of Happy Birthday, for example, and sending out a little cake with a balloon. A three-course lunch menu costs £6.95, house wine £9.50. What with the disco in the basement most weekends and kissograms who are liable to jump out from behind the pot plants, it's hardly surprising that customers are vague about the food, describing it as 'all the old favourites, and good value, too'.

fields.headline: Minding the gap
fields.standfirst: Ever thought of living in a 11ft by 28ft house? Geraldine and Ben Atfield rise to the vertical challenge
fields.trailText: Ever thought of living in a 11ft by 28ft house? Geraldine and Ben Atfield rise to the vertical challenge.
fields.body:
Four years ago, Joe Hagan bought a disused cab office in Clerkenwell. It was an odd site - a ramshackle old one-storey building with little potential, and so cheap it could have virtually been bought on a credit card. But Hagan had a vision; he wanted to fill the 11ft gap between the buildings on each side with glass and light, and make the derelict space his family home - an urban town house for the 21st century. The plans were drawn up and the foundations laid for a building with dimensions of 11ft wide by 28ft deep, but then Hagan, the architect who prefers to be known as a DJ, ran out of money.

The Gap, as it was to be called, was put on hold. But then along came Ben and Geraldine Atfield. Hagan had worked on their Bermondsey warehouse a few years before, and they had followed his new venture with interest. They'd had enough of open-plan living and wanted something that was still modern and urban, but with a little more structure and a few more rooms. It wasn't long before the contractors were back on site and the construction was moving full steam ahead. Hagan would build his dream home after all. He just wouldn't live in it once it was finished.

Eighteen months and around £350,000 later, and the Atfields have moved into their new home, all seven floors of it. They moved just before Christmas, and barely two weeks later, Thomas was born. Geraldine is taking it all in her stride, getting used to having maternity leave from her job as a director for a multinational company, breast-feeding and her new vertical lifestyle all at once. 'Wherever you live, there are great things about having a baby there,' she says, mid-feed, sitting on a chunky leather sofa in the fourth-floor living room. 'In an open-plan place, there are fewer rooms, so the baby stuff would build up in a big pile.' In The Gap, the baby stuff simply builds up in the lift, waiting to be moved from the third-floor kitchen to the ground floor, or from the first-floor nursery to the fourth-floor living room. 'It's like a dumb waiter,' she says.

The lift is central to the building's construction. Left to his own devices, Hagan would have had a simple staircase connecting the floors. 'To me, space and transparency are the most important things,' he says. 'The lift shaft is a static object in the middle of the space. But it's down to the individual. There's always a trade-off between space and utility. Ben wanted it because it's important to him and it's quite a luxurious thing to have. But town houses have stairs.'

We are standing at the top of the building, on the roof terrace, overlooking the building work opposite. Glass doors open out on to the terrace to the front of the house, making the room a mixture of inside and out. Hagan is particularly proud of the timber cladding he has used down one side of the building, making a 'garden fence' on part of the terrace. The architect cut a window out of the fence the same proportions as a widescreen TV, so that the urban landscape beyond is framed for viewing. 'I was brought up in the suburbs and always liked suburban iconography,' he says.

To the back of the house, a window runs the full width of the room, with a view out to architect Nigel Coates's office just next door and the British Telecom Tower in the distance. The views are panoramic, and as you pull the window open you feel as if you might get pulled out with it. 'I'm really bad with heights,' says Hagan. 'But it's great to introduce an element of danger.'

When the weather warms up, the Atfields will make full use of their summer room on the top of the house. It will be the perfect place for dinner parties, or simply sitting and watching the world go by as the sun sets. It's difficult not to watch the world outside from the house. The glass windows are fitted from floor to ceiling, and you are drawn to them. Standing at the edge makes you feel a little dizzy. 'I think some people have a thing about curtains and blinds,' says Geraldine. The only room in the house that has curtains is the couple's bedroom. 'I don't have a problem sitting in the kitchen at night, breast-feeding. I don't have a problem with privacy. Some people like to close out the world. I like to look out of the window and watch the world go by.' She is quick to point out that she is not an exhibitionist. And it's true, it would be crazy to block out the views outside. They are part of the house itself. Having all that open space outside makes the interior feel much more spacious and airy than it actually is.

'You watch people looking up at the house,' says Ben, who works as sales director at ePolitix.com, an online political information service. 'Before, it was a horrible hole in the wall. Now, at night, when it's lit up, it looks stunning. It's one of the most original, exciting domestic spaces to be built in London. Every floor is a room, and every room has a specific function.'

The ground floor, which is raised up slightly to make it feel a bit more theatrical, serves as a utility space, with washing machine and dryer fitted into purpose-built alcoves. A stairway leads down into the basement, which is serving as a workroom until the house is properly finished. It has a shower and bathroom in it, so guests will be able to stay there, and it will also be a study. The first and second floors are also bedrooms, each with their own bath or shower rooms. Thomas's nursery already feels like home, with its cot and baby toys.

The Gap might be a cool bit of modern architecture, but the baby, with all of his primary-coloured toys and equipment, prevents the place being at all precious. When he gets old enough to crawl, Geraldine says the house will become like 'the Which? Guide to safety gates'. But she is confident that the baby will adapt to the space quite easily. 'Kids have a natural sense of depth once they get used to moving,' she says. Above the bedrooms are the kitchen and dining room, and the living room, which has a bright and bold hanging on the outside wall of the lift shaft. 'We've done everything white now because we haven't had time to work out the colours yet,' says Geraldine. 'But I like white - particularly in a building like this.'

The overall affect is both dramatic and homely at the same time. The limestone floors make it feel functional yet luxurious. And every millimetre of available space has been used. There are little alcoves set into the walls around the lift shaft for storage. The bathrooms are ingenious. Two are simply shower rooms, with Philippe Starck fittings and a lip in the limestone floor to stop the water flooding out; one has a bath actually set into the floor. 'It was complex to seal it up,' says Joe. It is made out of timber, and lined with fibreglass. The limestone was laid on top. The result is very Japanese. You have to step down into it, and it's deep enough for the water to support the bather's weight. For Thomas, it is like an Olympic swimming pool.

Both Geraldine and Ben say they could never go back to open-plan loft living. 'When I bought the plot from Joe, it was a completely unique opportunity to create a new freehold building in the centre of London,' says Ben. As an investment, it has probably already doubled in price. 'You're always going to make money if you build properly,' says Joe, who walks past The Gap on his way to work from his Barbican apartment every morning, and when it is lit up in all its glory by night. 'I would like to be living here,' he says. 'It got too expensive, though. It would have swallowed everything for us to build. But I'm not as jealous as I thought I would be. What's been brilliant has been being able to build it. I'm an architect; I build things. Then, once it's done, you just move on to the next bit of theatre.'

Close quarters

Right now, Joe Hagan's three-person practice, USE, is concentrating on a bar in Greenwich called South Pole. It's below a pub called the North Pole. 'The design aesthetic is aircraft meets igloo,' says Joe, who also teaches one day a week at the South Bank University and DJs once a month downstairs at the Great Eastern Dining Rooms in Shoreditch.

Hagan has recently started work on a penthouse extension with a garden in Old Street which he describes as 'Palm Springs comes to Old Street'. In May 2000, he completed the live/work showroom and headquarters ofstreetwear label Maharishi in Shoreditch, and redesigned the interior of a one-bedroom apartment for some neighbours in the Barbican. 'The budgets for these projects aren't vast,' he says. The Barbican interior - redesigned to provide office space under a mezzanine bed, as well as a pied-à-terre for a jet-set couple who have a warehouse in Belgium - was on a budget of £30,000.

USE Architects can be contacted on 020 8986 8111. To find an architect, ring the RIBA's Clients' Advisory Service on 020 7307 3700, or go to www.architecture.com.

webTitle: Wheels: Mitsubishi's in-car DVD route planner

fields.headline: Marriage guidance
fields.standfirst: Why Mitsubishi's in-car DVD route planner is more of a marital aid than a navigation system
fields.trailText: Why Mitsubishi's in-car DVD route planner is more of a marital aid than a navigation system.
fields.body:
Guidance is a good thing in principle. It can light a path. Lead us to pastures new. In most circumstances, we welcome it.

There is an exception, though, a kind of guidance we seldom receive with warmth and gratitude. It wrecks homes, tears families asunder, can lead to violence and horror and bouts of bleak, intractable sulking. You know what I'm talking about. It tends to emanate from the passenger-seat region of automobiles and sounds something like, 'What are you doing? No - there, There, there ! You've missed it now. I said right! No I didn't. RIGHT!! Why can't you ever listen to anything anyone's telling you? Or admit when you're wrong? I blame your mother. I did not say left !! It was the same with the !?&*ing knob 0n the *!??ing cooker - you know it was you. Yes it was. Yes it was !!! Right! That's it, stop the car, I'm getting out. You'll be hearing from my solicitor.'

And the tragedy is that solicitors won't be able to help you with this. No one can. Sure, you might learn your lesson, make the break, start again with someone new. You might imagine yourself to be older and wiser and safe from the Navigation Wars. But you won't be. It will happen again.

The 20th century produced no solution to this primal conflict. The only reliable tactic has been never to get into a car with anyone in whom you are supposed to have a romantic interest, unless you already know where you are going, are both mute, or have agreed to travel with socks in your mouths. Obviously, these measures can be restrictive.

Given all this, it would be hard to exaggerate the scepticism with which I received Mitsubishi's implied claim to have consigned Navigation War to history. It's is not the first satellite guidance system to come on the market, but it is the first to make use of DVD technology and is claimed to be a big improvement on the sketchy stuff which has previously been available - even if, in operation, it's not much different.

Using a mobile phone-sized remote control unit, which is clipped into a small stand when not in use, information is inputted and received through a 7in screen mounted in the dashboard immediately to the driver's left. The supplied disc contains route maps for 10 European countries, in six different languages. Your location is monitored by satellite, enabling the on-board computer to calculate a route, or variety of routes, to wherever you want to go. Four different graphic perspectives are available to help you follow directions, or you can sit back and be guided by voice. 'Which is all very well,' I'm thinking as I circle the big blue Shogun parked outside my house, 'if it works.'

It works. My sense of direction is famously bad among people who know me. The moment intuition enters the equation, I'm pretty pleased simply to end up, or for that matter remain, in the correct town. Yet even I struggled to get lost in the Mitsubishi. You simply key in the name of the street you want to find, using a time-saving 'smart' lexicon that only asks you to choose from a range of the letters that could legitimately follow the ones you've already selected. If there is only one street of that name in the UK, the calculations as to route begin. If there is more than one, you are asked to identify which is yours. It's that easy.

If you know your way around the area you're in, you find that there are shortcuts you habitually take that the DVD system won't recognise. It tends to stick to the main roads, which seldom loses you more than a few minutes and probably saves confusion in parts of the town/country that you're not familiar with (remember that you won't need it on your own patch, anyway).

If you countermand an order, the route is recalculated within five seconds or so and a new option offered. The pleasantly honeyed female voice is realistic enough to suggest a slight huff at these points, which is gratifying. I wondered whether, in the interest of anthropological accuracy, a synthesized male guide is available to straight women and gay men. I also wondered whether Mitsubishi might consider supplying a range of celebrity voices in the future, so that one might choose to place oneself in the hands of, say, George Clooney or Beatrice Dalle. Tragically, the answer at present appears to be 'no'.

A few slightly questionable instructions were issued. Given the people who drive these flashy and absurd pseudo off-roaders, I wasn't entirely surprised one Friday night to be led along a path that took me straight past Stringfellows in the West End of London. A pin-striped man who was waiting to get in tapped excitedly at my window, gushing, 'That's the new shape, isn't it?' The thing clearly knew where to find its own people: there was no direct instruction for me to go in and have a lap dance, but I felt that the suggestion was there.

Which is the shame of it all, because this ingenious and potentially Nobel Peace Prize-winning development is only available on the new Mitsubishi Shogun, at an extra cost of £2,318.55. One day, all cars will have it and the world will be a better place.

There is an exception, though, a kind of guidance we seldom receive with warmth and gratitude. Why can't you ever listen to anything anyone's telling you? Or admit when you're wrong? I blame your mother. I did not say left !! It was the same with the !?&*ing knob 0n the *!??ing cooker - you know it was you. Yes it was. Yes it was !!! Right! That's it, stop the car, I'm getting out. You'll be hearing from my solicitor.' fields.headline: Spreading the word
fields.standfirst: Gentleman's Relish is just too good to leave to men, says Sybil Kapoor
fields.trailText: Gentleman's Relish is just too good to leave to men, says Sybil Kapoor.
fields.body:
Anyone who has ever dieted will know that as soon as hunger strikes, you begin to fantasise about food. Visions of crumpets dripping in butter and gooey chocolate cakes beset you. A useful diversion tactic is a slice of hot, buttered toast, thinly spread with Patum Peperium, The Gentleman's Relish. Somehow, this lightly spiced anchovy paste instantly satisfies taste buds craving excitement.

However, a word of warning, Gentleman's Relish is an acquired taste. One look at the sludgy paste is enough to deter many. And then there is its pungent smell. Brave men have been known to blanch at it. Yet, once these initial reservations are overcome, you will discover a delicate paste that rivals Marmite in its deliciousness.

Opinions differ as to how and when you should eat Gentleman's Relish. According to the Ritz, breakfast is the time to enjoy its piquant flavour, preferably on thinly sliced, brown toast. I prefer to eat it for tea, on white toast with a little mustard and cress. Mrs Beeton suggests that anchovy paste is usually spread on toast as 'an excellent bonne bouche which enables gentlemen at wine-parties to enjoy their port with redoubled gusto'.

It was originally created in 1828 by John Osborn, an English provision merchant in Paris. Like any good marketing man, he created a grandiose name from a fictitious fudge of Latin and Greek implying pepper paste, to tempt his fashion-conscious customers into buying it. It only became known as Gentleman's Relish once his son brought the business to London. According to Elsenham, its current manufacturer, it is still made according to the original recipe. It imports the finest Spanish anchovy fillets, which have been packed in barrels of salt and left to mature for 18 months. Once suitably fruity, they are rinsed in brine and gently cooked before being cooled and blended with butter and rusk. A secret blend of spices and herbs is then added.

Elsenham recommends eating it within six weeks of opening, which is impossible if you buy a large pot. Clearly, a few rumbustious drinking evenings are required once the diet is completed.

 Patum Peperium come in two sizes: 42.5g (£1.63) and 71g (£2.70). They are available from Sainsbury's, Waitrose, Safeway and Tesco. Porcelain pots are available from Harrods, Fortnum & Mason and Selfridges, and range in price from £7.50 (14.2g) to £12.50 (71g).

fields.headline: Tattie treats
fields.standfirst: From tartlets to chips, Jim Ainsworth unearths the most popular potato dishes
fields.trailText: From tartlets to chips, Jim Ainsworth unearths the most popular potato dishes.
fields.body:
Sally Clarke's (124 Kensington Church Street, London W8; 020 7221 9225) savoury potato tartlets constitute one of the most satisfying wintery ways of eating the tuber. She cuts half centimetre slices of the Linzer Delicatesse variety, parboils them, and places them over a bed of sweated leeks or onions in a shortcut pastry case. A thyme-flavoured egg-and-cream mix is poured over, Gruyère cheese is sprinkled on top, and the tartlets baked. Black truffle can also be added to the cream mix, and/or shaved over the ensemble for extra richness.

The combination of potatoes with black truffle is long standing, not least in London W8, and works perfectly well in mash. Jason Atherton at L'Anis (1 Kensington High Street, London W8; 020 7795 6533) serves a creamy and finely puréed version mixed with pear and aromatised with tiny dice of black truffle, to accompany a large juicy rack of pink cooked pork topped with a thin silver foie gras.

A chip butty is one of the easier carbohydrate-rich snacks to knock up, while a potato-topped pizza is not far behind. Annie Nichols in her book Potatoes: From Gnocci to Mash (£9.99, Ryland Peters & Small) tells how to put the pizza together and flavour it with rosemary, and gives a recipe for pasta and potatoes with macadamia pesto, plus a Mexican variation on the potato tart in which roasted tomatoes, garlic and chilli lay the foundation. Perhaps the simplest and most straightforward manifestation of the potato-and-pastry theme is what I used to know as a butter pie, a 'speciality' to be found in the area around Preston, Blackburn, Bolton and Wigan. It may have been so called to make it sound more interesting or mouth-watering than plain potato pie but, as Roger Marsden of Reuben Marsden (36 Chapel Street, Chorley, Lancashire; 01257 263 606) explains, since butter is not the main ingredient, Brussels decrees that it must now be called potato pie.

Marsden's has been making these for 104 years, although for a long time only on Fridays 'to accommodate Catholics', otherwise, maintaining just its regular output of meat pies would have meant the loss of a day's trading. Now they are made every day of the week using Maris Pipers ('because of the flavour. And they fall better'), together with onions, butter and margarine. They cost 72p.

If you notice the media filling end-of-programme slots with items about chips this week, or indeed if you see people dressed as chips, it is because the British Potato Council has declared the next seven days as National Chip Week. Not that we need much encouragement: nearly a third of the national potato crop (some 38,500 tonnes a week) is made into chips, and an experiment organised by the council concluded that the best varieties for this are King Edward and Wilja, preferably fried in corn or vegetable oil. Olley's (67 Norwood Road, London SE24; 020 8671 8259) prefers groundnut oil.

 Jim Ainsworth is editor of The Good Food Guide.

fields.headline: Sunny delights
fields.standfirst: Why citrus juice is sunshine in a glass. Plus, a brush with hair loss and taking the pain out of migraines
fields.trailText: Why citrus juice is sunshine in a glass. Plus, a brush with hair loss and taking the pain out of migraines.
fields.body:
At this time of year, oranges and other citrus fruits are at their best, their tangy taste hinting at their nutritional goodness. Indeed, the vitamin C (ascorbic acid) that they and other fresh fruits contain can protect us from colds, viruses, heart disease, premature ageing of the skin and certain kinds of cancer. And while we've known for some time that the peel of citrus fruits contains a substance called limonene, which has been shown in preclinical tests to prevent cancer of the breast and colon, new research carried out by scientists at the Cancer Prevention and Control Arizona Cancer Center at the University of Arizona suggests that limonene may also play a role in warding off squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.

Drinking freshly squeezed citrus-fruit juice, either on its own or as a smoothie, is also one of the best ways of energising our bodies in the morning and an easy way to down three or four fruits at once.

However, it's best to steer clear of fresh citrus juice for breakfast if you suffer from headaches or migraines (it can cause the blood vessels in the head to expand and contract vigorously) or have too many fats, particularly triglycerides, in your blood (it can dramatically increase the quantity of lipids that are released into the bloodstream, increasing your risk of developing heart disease). In both instances, it's better either to opt for another type of fruit juice or to drink citrus-fruit juice later in the day, when your stomach contains some high-fibre food. Bear in mind, though, that drinking fresh juice does expose your teeth to fructose (fruit sugar) and citric acid, both of which can cause tooth decay, so brush your teeth regularly, especially after drinking a glass of juice last thing at night.

Dose-wise, non-smokers need 60mg of vitamin C a day, a target that can easily be met if, for example, you eat a couple of kiwi fruits, a bowl of strawberries or a large orange. You only need to take more vitamin C if you smoke, the damage that nicotine inflicts on your body increases your requirement to 2,000mg a day, which usually means that you'll have to take a supplement. Also note that oranges - and especially commercially squeezed orange juice (which often contains added sugar and preservatives) - may aggravate the symptoms of children who have behavioural problems or eczema.

Nutrition news

The number of women suffering from hair loss has doubled over the past 10 years, according to the hair-loss support group Hairline. If you are worried about hair loss, it's worth having both your serum ferritin and haemoglobin levels checked by your doctor because low iron stores are a common cause of hair loss in women, usually as a result of either poor diet or heavy menstrual bleeding.

If your ferritin levels are found to be low, boost your intake of iron-rich foods, such as lean, red meat, green, leafy vegetables, game, offal and pulses, and, because the body needs ascorbic acid to help it to absorb this form of iron, also increase your vitamin C intake by eating more fresh fruit and vegetables. Having foods that are rich in iron and ascorbic acid with every meal should replenish your ferritin stores and stimulate hair growth.

Your questions

I used to have migraines occasionally, but they've recently been knocking me for six every week. Can you help?
S Lee, by email

First, drink plenty of water (aim for 2.5 litres a day) and not too much tea, coffee, alcohol or cola, which dehydrate the body. Note down everything that you eat and drink over a couple of weeks, as well as your migraine patterns, and then compare the two lists to see if you can identify the culprit(s). If you notice a connection between your migraines and a certain drink or food, it's best to avoid it, although some of my patients find that they can enjoy a little of the trigger as long as it's not on an empty stomach or when they're stressed.

Try to eat a small, healthy snack, such as fruit, yogurt or a high-fibre biscuit every two to three hours to keep your blood-sugar levels constant. Eating a lot of fibre-rich foods, including wholegrains, pulses, fruits and vegetables, should also help to cushion the hormonal swings that often cause or aggravate headaches and migraines.

Rosemary essential oil can help to relieve headaches and migraines, so try carrying a little bottle of it around with you so that you can dab a few drops on a hanky and press it to your aching head. Alternatively, if you're feeling headachy in the morning, add a few drops of the essential oil to a warm bath.

 Jane Clarke is a state-registered dietician. If you would like her to answer any questions or address any issues in this column, please write to Jane Clarke c/o Life magazine, The Observer , 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER or email her at life@observer.co.uk. Please note that Jane Clarke cannot enter into any personal correspondence.

fields.headline: Well being
fields.standfirst: An alternative look at health issues. This week: what men and women want, how to stop chewing your cheeks, and banishing boils
fields.trailText: An alternative look at health issues. This week: what men and women want, how to stop chewing your cheeks, and banishing boils.
fields.body:
I received the following email from one Ian Simpson and was moved, by its poetic quality and poignant content, to (with his permission) give it the floor: 'I met a lovely Canadian girl, 5ft 9in with elfin bones, while in London, and I feel strangely now I'm not around her. Sick almost. She had such a vibe about her. Is this what aura is, or am I just a lovesick puppy? Respect, Ian.'

I fired off a spontaneous response along the lines of: 'Depends on how romantic a filter you wish to look through. Buddha called it the pain of attachment, Cole Porter, love. Lao Tsu (the infamous Taoist) saw it as the interplay of yin and yang. (Aura just means energy field, by the way.) Personally, I'd say that's merely what happens when (through astrological destiny or just plain accident) you meet a fine girl with whom the pheromones fly, and then have to leave her. Attempt to use it as an opportunity to grow emotionally stronger, philosophically wiser and generally more loving (and lovable).'

As this followed a week when everyone around me, including me, seemed to be discussing relationships, Ian's question sparked off a desire to try and represent the Oriental Taoist yin-yang equation I'd been using to lighten up the conversations, as a way to break down the highly complex issue of intimate relations to its metaphysical rudiments in the hope that this will help us all understand our sociosexual plight a little better.

Fundamentally, there are two abstract qualities, the static and the dynamic - or in Oriental Taoist jargon, yin and yang. Static quality, whether personal or universal, is concerned with keeping things as they are. Dynamic quality is concerned with changing things as much as possible. Naturally, the two are inseparable. If everything stays the same, literally changeless, it becomes stagnant and hence lifeless. If everything changes before it has time to form a structure, it can take on no definable shape and becomes immaterial, nonexistent and hence lifeless. These two qualities are locked in an eternal embrace, sometimes nurturing, sometimes stultifying, sometimes passionate, sometimes coy.

According to Taoists, womankind represents the yin, static, structive quality, and mankind the yang, dynamic quality. Moreover, there is a seed portion of yang in every woman, just as there is of yin in every man. Man meets a woman and falls under the spell of her 'aura' and she of his. Under this spell, colloquially known as 'falling in love' (falling being the operative word), the two weave a web of fantasies together - a business plan, if you like - and then commit more or less to its enactment, however ordinary or farfetched it may be, from trekking the Andes for four years to buying a house in Guildford. One 'hormonal phase' (three months) later, as the first cracks appear in the picture but they're both already hooked, she starts noticing things about him she wouldn't mind changing. If he's a rogue, she wants to change him into a family man. If he's a family man, she wants him to dress more like a rogue. If after a few more 'hormonal phases', he hasn't changed, she starts to grow impatient. This is the yang, dynamic quality within the woman seeking change according to its nature.

The man, on the other hand, doesn't want her to change at all. And when, a few hormonal phases down the line, she comes to resemble someone entirely different from the girl he once knew, he becomes frightened. This is the yin, static quality in the man seeking things to remain as they were.

Simultaneously, the yin, static quality within the woman, almost from the relationship's inception, begins weaving a structure around the man's comings and goings. He, Mr Yang, would rather things were randomised and spontaneous but always on tap (being a dynamic quality is thirsty work) and above all without restriction. She sees things in sequential patterns, forming part of a larger pattern (commonly known as matrimony and kids). She wants to create a structure in which to hold him, their relationship and the human fruit it produces, and yet within this structure requires that he changes. He wants to be free of structure once he gets home from work, yet requires her to remain the way she was the day he met her.

Obviously, yin and yang, are relative. If two men are together (or two women), the one with more dynamic quality will be yang and the other one yin. And when the woman in a man-woman relationship is the dynamic partner, she will be the yang one and he the yin. We need each other, us yins and yangs, and yet we do seem to be making rather a muddle of our liaisons at this momentous time in history. And I just wonder if being able to abstract the dynamics of yin-yang, woman-man, by using this simplistic yet surprisingly evolved formula (considering it was devised well over five millennia back), we may create enough psychological distance to be able to stop taking the whole issue so personally, so we can all enjoy it a lot more. Because surely there can be nothing much nicer than the love, attachment, call it what you will, that passes between two people and leaves them feeling like Ian, no matter how upset it makes you afterwards.

Your questions

Dear Barefoot Doctor, Since I was 13 (I'm 37 now), I have chewed the sides of my mouth and I believe it's beginning to wear down my teeth. Can you advise me as to how to stop?
Anne Leahy, Poole

Oral satisfaction levels, according to the Orientals, are under command of your spleen energy, which can be adjusted by a few acupuncture sessions. Boosting the spleen energy can reduce the compulsive need for oral gratification. Also, before sleep and on waking, gently stretch your face as long as it will go and relax, up to 18 times, to increase energy and blood circulation to the oral region. Apart from releasing accrued muscular stress, where there's sufficient energy, there's sufficient satisfaction, hence no need to chew. Hypnotherapy also can help reset that part of your mind that's bent on chewing you up and help you to relax, which is fundamental.

Dear Barefoot, I've been suffering from boils on my upper back. As soon as one goes, another appears. I am under a lot of stress at the moment, but am having a weekly massage and do yoga to combat it. Any ideas?
Daniel Hassan, by email

By the tenets of Oriental medicine, the organs involved (in maintaining the skin) are the lungs and colon, but boils also appear when the blood is impure, in which case treatment needs to directed at the liver, for which acupuncture might help. A well-used traditional Chinese remedy is to put a poultice of baked onions on the boil, bandage and leave overnight to draw out the poison. This is combined with a juice concoction to cleanse colon and lung 'chi': a half pint of equal amounts of carrot, raw beetroot, spinach and cucumber. Also try the Bach Flower remedy of mustard, which helps with the tendency to suddenly flare up.

I fired off a spontaneous response along the lines of: 'Depends on how romantic a filter you wish to look through. Buddha called it the pain of attachment, Cole Porter, love. Lao Tsu (the infamous Taoist) saw it as the interplay of yin and yang. (Aura just means energy field, by the way.) Personally, I'd say that's merely what happens when (through astrological destiny or just plain accident) you meet a fine girl with whom the pheromones fly, and then have to leave her. Attempt to use it as an opportunity to grow emotionally stronger, philosophically wiser and generally more loving (and lovable).' If everything stays the same, literally changeless, it becomes stagnant and hence lifeless. Moreover, there is a seed portion of yang in every woman, just as there is of yin in every man. Man meets a woman and falls under the spell of her 'aura' and she of his. The man, on the other hand, doesn't want her to change at all. fields.headline: The waiting game
fields.standfirst: Delayed gratification
fields.trailText: Delayed gratification.
fields.body:
Vladimir: What do we do now?
Estragon: Wait.
(From Waiting for Godot by Samuel Beckett)

It's not known if Samuel Beckett ever ordered a sofa from Heal's, but, had he done so, it could have been the spark that ignited his masterpiece of existential angst, at least if the experiences of a friend of mine are anything to go by. Having gone to the store's sale and spotted her dream settee, she was told by an assistant that she could expect it to be delivered - in 14 weeks.

A bunch of bona fide explanations were proferred, though the assistant had to concede that the three months-plus delay was 'pushing the envelope a bit'. But my friend's reaction was instructive. Initial outrage gave way to philosophical detachment, which was in turn superseded by a delicious sense of suspended animation - an anticipatory limbo between desire and fulfilment. The - admittedly enforced - act of waiting to take possession of her settee had become kind of sexy. She mentally rearranged her living-room furniture into innumerable permutations; she even dreamt about it. In short, she had discovered the joys of delayed gratification.

It's a deeply unfashionable concept in the days when the only kind of gratification anyone seems interested in is instant, but the value of DG has long been championed by everyone from economists (to guard against boom and bust), Buddhists (to keep material desires in check), child psychologists (to implant the notion that you can't always get what you want - at least not right away) and sex therapists (to, well, you get the picture), and is ringingly advocated by no less a guru than M Scott Peck: 'It's a process that enhances the pleasure of life by meeting and experiencing pain first and getting it over with,' he writes in The Road Less Travelled ('pain' in my friend's case clearly referring to Pre- and Post-Purchase Anxiety), adding emphatically, 'It's the only decent way to live.'

Indeed, most so-called instant gratification turns out to have more than a hint of the deferred about it; sure, we can email or instant-message a torrent of orders or demands across cyberspace, but we still have to wait for a response (and usually the quicker the method of message-imparting, the more exasperating the vigil until the reply is received - hence the prevalence of net rage), and we can order virtually anything with the click of a mouse, but the tenterhooked waiting-for-the-item-to-be-shipped-from-the-warehouse-and-delivered is good old-fashioned DG incarnate.

The ground zero of DG, at least from a consumer point of view, has to be Savile Row. In an age when any garment of any size can be plucked off any peg, the notion of waiting weeks to have a suit made is so perverse as to be more than mildly titillating. 'Having to wait for anything increases the pleasure of eventually possessing it; better to travel in hope than to arrive, that sort of thing,' says Hugh Holland, managing director of venerable tailors Kilgour French Stanbury, but then he would say that; it can take up to four months for his team to assemble a full bespoke number.

It was a message lost on Chris Eubank, who demanded an outfit be completed in a week, presented the company with his American Express card, and was presented with the still-smoking garments at the Concorde departure lounge seven days later, but the likes of fellow Kilgour customer Noel Gallagher seem more than happy for it to be here, well, whenever. 'I think he likes the novelty,' says Holland. 'Here's someone who can probably get anything he wants any time he wants it. But not in this case. Maybe in his position it's the nearest he gets to denial.'

Of course, the more usual forms of waiting that we encounter are not nearly as delectable as DG. Waiting.com turns out to be a website maintained by a support group for relatives and carers of those in comas; waiting lists, for anything from council houses to Prada bowling bags, can prove anything from frustrating to fatal; waiting rooms, with their institutional torpor and dog-eared copies of OK! , are purgatorial; and there are few with the fortitude to withstand the seemingly endless waiting for the verdicts on life's really important things - medical tests, exam results, job applications, Big Brother winners, what day your cheque might clear, what time the gas man is actually going to turn up, etc.

All of which helps explain Vladimir and Estragon's plaintive lamenting into the void. Of course, their gratification was perpetually deferred - at this stage it's probably safe to say that Godot's never going to show. But, as my friend's case proves, DG, like boredom, is such a rare commodity in the I Want It All And I Want It Now age that, taken in moderation, it can actually be good for the soul. Spiritual enlightenment via suspended arrival of soft furnishings - it's a USP that Heal's would be well advised to plug in their next ad campaign.

fields.headline: The cost of...
fields.standfirst: ... your own airline
fields.trailText: ... your own airline.
fields.body:
Niki Lauda, the retired Formula One champion, was recently asked to desist from piloting his own Lauda Air passenger jets. He was ousted from the board of Lauda Air over two months and has now eschewed the airstrip for the racetrack. But Britain has a valiant, if patchy, record with airline entrepreneurs.

Freddie Laker would have been the first global airline mogul, were it not for a slightly flawed business plan. Instead, Sir Richard Branson seized that crown. But if you want to make a quick return on your investment, go for the short-haul, no-frills market - the sector is growing by 25 per cent every year.

Stelios Haji-Ioannou (Greek admittedly, but an anglophile nonetheless) started easyJet with a £5m-loan from dad and a considerable sum from his own piggy bank. Last year he splashed out on 17 medium-sized Boeing 737s. At £40m each, even with a bulk-purchase discount, this gives some idea of the sort of investment required.

Larger planes, such as the new Airbus A3XX which may cost £90m each, are unnecessary for short-haul routes - and don't even think about a Concorde. The supersonic plane was a financial disaster long before the Paris crash: in 1981 the total cost amounted to £2.3bn, or over £10bn in today's money. Similarly, try to avoid an expensive branding exercise, such as the British Airways tailfin farce (cost: £60m). No-frills airlines tend to have short, sharp monikers - go, buzz.

The most profitable no-frills airline is Ryanair, which now pays its top pilots a salary of £85,000 plus stock options (BA jumbo pilots earn about £75,000), but it is the chief executives who rake in the astronomical amounts. Bob Ayling was on £500,000 per annum before British Airways let him go - with a £2m pay-off and a £260,000 pension in his pocket.

Your flight attendants and baggage handlers will earn much less, with salaries ranging from £10,000 to £20,000. Should you be tempted to take to the controls yourself, bear in mind that you will have to spend about £100 per hour on training for your Private Pilot's Licence, which may take you up to 18 months to gain. Finally, you can't ignore fuel. Last year, aviation fuel cost on average 85.6 cents per gallon - doesn't sound like much but Concorde burns 5,600 gallons per hour and jumbos slightly less.

Boeing 737 from £40m
Flight attendants £20,000 per annum
Senior pilots £85,000 per annum
Chief executive £500,000 per annum
Brand image £60m
Private Pilot's Licence £100 per hour
Aviation fuel 85.6 cents per gallon

fields.headline: Loafer's guide
fields.standfirst: Luella Bartley
fields.trailText: Luella Bartley.
fields.body:
Cruella de who? No, no, Luella. It's Old English for 'elfin'. She's an ex-fashion journalist transmogrified into Elle 's Young Designer of the Year and, according to her sponsors at New Look (for whom she works as a cool-hunter consultant), currently 'the It Girl of fashion'.

And how did she acquire don't-dream-It-be-It status? After going to 'hippy arts school' in Leamington Spa and Central St Martin's, BritFash HQ, she critiqued the trans-seasonal trouser for Vogue and the Evening Standard before going on to design. Now divides her time between style meccas of Clerkenwell (home) and Notting Hill (work) with BFs Kate Moss, Stella McCartney and stylist Katie Grand. Showed her first collection at a 'house party' sleepover and single-handedly spearheaded the 80s revival with collections like this season's Dial F For Fluoro with its pink leggings, white-leather minidresses, shoulder-slashed T-shirts, and - now, this really is taking things too far - pop socks.

And now she's ready to be crowned Queen of London Fashion Week? Bit of a glitch there. She's showing her autumn/winter collection in Milan under the auspices of hotter-than-hot accessories label Bottega Veneta, the 'new Prada'. 'It's only for one season,' protests Luella. 'But London is a part of me. I'll be back in September.'

Traitor! Take her to the Tower! Actually, she joins a long list of previous London luminaries who have decamped (such as Antonio Berardi, Galliano, Vivenne Westwood and Sir Paul Smith) or have pressing reason to decline (Hussein Chalayan, current British Designer of the Year, recently went into liquidation).

Can Luella avoid making the red the new black? As long as she steers clear of tables-that-transform-into-frocks (possibly Chalayan's downfall), and as long as there are enough tonight-Matthew-I'm-going-to-be-Joanne-and-Suzanne-from-The-Human-League style punters around...

fields.headline: Go see...
fields.standfirst: Growth & form
fields.trailText: Growth & form.
fields.body:
Armed with just a handful of Petri dishes, artist Rachel Chapman heads out on to the streets to capture a blast of the fungi-filled air that is all around us. Her aim, she explains, is 'to make visible the breath of the city' by combining art and science. Back in her lab, Chapman examines her catch which has taken root in the dishes, and then, with the help of two mycologists, chooses the fungi she wants for her larger canvas: a giant Petri dish which will give the spores a chance to really take off.

Breathe , the resulting work, is part of the Growth & Form exhibition at the Wellcome Trust in London, which is showing art inspired by the world of medical research, alongside the Biomedical Image Awards for 2001.

The stunning biomedical images are all the result of medical research carried out in the past year. Nerve cells, proteins and a growing eye are brought to life with the help of fluorescent dyes and beams of light and electrons. A developing nervous system shows off its burgeoning internal skeletons, dramatically highlighted with ultramarine, luminous green and a poppy red, while a microscopic close-up of a protein gives the impression of being a riotous field filled with long grasses and electric-blue cornflowers.

The art world's fascination with science goes right back to Da Vinci, Dürer and Michelangelo, who all delved deep below the skin's surface to reveal the body's inner structures, but today's technology obviously allows artists and science photographers to dig even deeper in their efforts to make the invisible visible, which in this instance produces eye-opening results.

 Growth & Form is at the Two10 Gallery, 210 Euston Road, London NW1 (020 7611 7211), from 22 February to 4 May, Monday to Friday, 9am-6pm.

fields.headline: Money's too tight to mention
fields.trailText: 'My wife is taking the children to Butlins for three days in April. Yes, Butlins. Yes, April. This is what it has come to.'
fields.body:
My wife arrives home having bought two colourful bathroom sponges, even though I distinctly remember her signing my latest postnuptial agreement to curtail all gratuitous expenditure with the exception of lottery tickets until such time as she gets herself a highly paid part-time job to suit local woman, flexihours negotiable, substantial 'golden hello', nannying facilities, free food for a family of six and optional air-miles transferable to spouse preferred. '19p each from Wilko,' she says triumphantly, 'one for the bathroom, and one for Butlins!' She is taking the children to Butlins for three days in April. Yes, Butlins. Yes, April. This is what it has come to. Admittedly it could be worse. I could be going too.

Still, the Halifax seem to be doing their bit to stop me spending any money, first by confiscating my card on the grounds that their computer seems to have rather whimsically decided to report it missing, and second by pretending whenever I ring to be just on the point of popping a new one in the post. Naturally I would complain but by coincidence they happen to own our house and I'd hate to be thrown out before our attractive fixed-rate mortgage holiday comes to a sad end in August and our monthly debt mountain moves back to the Andes, obliging us to fall to our deaths.

In the meantime we are tightening our harnesses and looking out for opportunities to increase our income. I notice from the local paper that some local entrepreneurs have hit on the idea of calling taxi firms to a false address and then driving off with the car with £300 inside it while the driver is busy knocking on someone's door. I'm pretty sure this is illegal though it's a reasonable enough stopgap until Robert De Niro rings up to offer me £6m for the film rights to my forthcoming almost-published debut novel, which already has advance orders approaching 14, with possibly up to half that expected again from my wife's side of the family.

Our 12-year-old chooses this moment to arrive home and offer his financial backing by asking us to buy him a mobile phone, which, as I explain not for the first time through a large megaphone, is out of the question until it has been scientifically proven that they don't turn impressionable young minds to alphabet soup. 'Dad, everybody's got one,' he shrieks.

'I haven't,' I say.

He is just about to adopt the slack-jawed glue sniffer's stare he likes to use when he is taking a well-earned break from the word 'sad' when my wife steps in to wonder whether anyone wishing to make demands of a pecuniary nature should ideally be coming home with the hinges hanging off his school briefcase as a result of one of his fellow pranksters changing the combination and as a result having it prised open with an iron bar as part of his Design Technology lesson. All of which is news to me.

'So now he needs a new briefcase?'

'I thought you might buy one on the way back from the dump,' says my wife, which is odd because I don't remember arranging to be sent to the dump in the pouring rain, but apparently, yes, because otherwise how will we get rid of the old MFI cupboard that has to be ripped out of our utility space to make room for the equally old freezer that my wife's friend is giving us? Hang on, this is to save my wife's friend going to the dump? No, no, to save us money because now we will be able to buy 24 loaves of bread at once, silly.

Pretty soon I am in Harlow, whose policy of attracting shoppers back to town centres with the simple ploy of pumping the smell of chips into the air and only allowing teenagers into the shopping centre in groups of 14 is paying off. I'm looking round the bag shop. 'Have you got anything inexpensive without a combination lock?' The woman shakes her head.

'No?' I say. She shakes her head again.

Pity. Still, it's nice to see a local business adhering to Chamber of Commerce quotas requiring all retail outlets to employ at least one person with no tongue. Probably a few economies to be made there too, I shouldn't wonder.

webTitle: Inside politics: How the mandarins squeezed Tony Blair

fields.headline: How the mandarins squeezed Tony Blair
fields.standfirst: The Prime Minister privately believes he'll have a big win at the election, but until he masters Whitehall, he'll never be fully in power
fields.trailText: The Prime Minister privately believes he'll have a big win at the election, but until he masters Whitehall, he'll never be fully in power.
fields.byline: Andrew Rawnsley, columnist of the year
fields.body:
When a virginal Prime Minister arrives at Number 10, the first thing the civil servants do is to relieve him of his passport. The next thing they try to take away is his gonads. This operation is conducted with such skill that many premiers barely feel the pain. Too late do they wake up from the anaesthetic to discover that their aspirations to achieve radical reform have been neutered by Whitehall's forces of conservatism. Before it is too late for Tony Blair, the Prime Minister should make a careful audit of the contents of his boxer shorts.

It is one of the least observed but most profound failures of his supposedly all-conquering regime that they have not mastered the civil service. The Cabinet is eviscerated as a forum for meaningful decision-making. The Commons is marginalised. But where it really matters, Mr Blair is not in command. The permanent government of Whitehall, control of which is critical to the delivery of New Labour's agenda, has not been mastered.

The machine has frustrated the Government over its first term. Unless Tony Blair takes a grip, many of the goals of his second term are at risk. The Prime Minister and a chorus line of backing vocalists from the Cabinet have spent this weekend in Glasgow lavishing the country with promises of sweeping change. And yet the levers of the machine that must fulfil those pledges are still not obedient to the will of the Prime Minister.

He came to office planning to blow a whirlwind of change through the musty corridors of power. Jonathan Powell, the Prime Minister's Chief of Staff, warned the civil service that his master intended to bend the 'feudal barons' to the will of a 'Napoleonic system' run from Number 10. Then, it alarmed the panjandrums of Whitehall; now, it amuses them. Four years on, they quietly chuckle over dinner in St James's at the naivety of the Blairites who thought they were a match for the guile of the British civil service. Those reforms that have happened have been mainly presentational, not least because Mr Blair is a Prime Minister singularly uninterested - bored, in fact - by the nuts and bolts of administrative machinery.

It is time he got interested. Obstruction is never so much ideological as inertial. Whitehall is not riddled with Tory fifth columnists sabotaging a progressive government. Resistance to change is more sinuous and subtle. Like any institution of its venerable age and conservative character, the civil service is a vested interest naturally disposed to the maintenance of the status quo. The higher echelons believe themselves to be a 'Rolls-Royce' service, and the public will tend to esteem an 'independent' civil service higher than partisan politicians.

Fearing to be accused of being bent on the politicisation of Whitehall, Ministers dare not voice aloud their discontent about the inadequacies of the bureaucracy. Privately, they seethe. The fuel blockades last autumn are seared into the souls of those Ministers involved. They were profoundly shocked to make the discovery that not one of the alpha minds of Whitehall had prepared any contingency plan to deal with such a grave emergency.

Efforts to make civil servants assume 'ownership' of government programmes - in other words, to take responsibility for failures - have come to little. Will a head roll for the latest costly computer fiasco at the Home Office? Will anyone be named and shamed for the hundreds of millions squandered on misdirected benefits and fraud by the Department of Social Security? Don't hold your breath unless you are looking forward to an early death.

Some Ministers have simply given up trying to control Whitehall. 'You can't beat them,' one Cabinet member lamented to me recently. He invoked the cautionary tale of Jack Cunningham. That accomplished operator set about trying to kick some life into the most backward department, Agriculture. His punishment was to be undermined by a drip of embarrassing leaks about his allegedly expensive tastes in office furnishings and foreign travel.

It is striking how many, and how easily, Labour Ministers have been captured by their civil servants. Under the tutelage of the eternally Europhiliac Foreign Office, Robin Cook, erstwhile scourge of Brussels, has become the most euro-enthused member of the Government. The civil service's favourite member of the Cabinet is Jack Straw. He does as many red boxes as they give him, and a capacity to eat paper is always admired by officialdom. What they most love about the Home Secretary is the enthusiasm with which he has embraced the mind-set of the most secretive department in Whitehall. Measures that the Home Office bureaucracy could not get past previous Tory Home Secretaries, such as the curtailment of trial by jury and electronic snooping, have been willingly executed by Mr Straw.

Gordon Brown has imposed his tungsten will on the Treasury. Even this exception serves to prove the rule. His awful reputation among colleagues for meddling in everyone else's affairs is not all his own making. The Treasury bureaucracy, knowing the power of their chief, exploit it by dictating to other departments. Just one example: they are trying to force the Department of Education to reduce the levels of qualification required to be a child carer because the Treasury civil servants believe that setting too demanding a standard will make it harder to hit the target for child-care places.

The weapon at the disposal of the Prime Minister is the power of appointment over the heads of the Whitehall departments. Margaret Thatcher was a Prime Minister with balls of steel, metaphorically speaking. She records in her memoirs how she overcame the civil service's aversion to change. 'It became clear to me that it was only by encouraging or appointing individuals, rather than changing attitudes en bloc, that progress would be made. That was to be the method I employed.' Spectacularly so. Two years in, she sacked the head of the home civil service, sending a signal which reverberated through the system.

Purges are not in the nature of the consensual Mr Blair. But an opportunity has just presented itself to demonstrate his determination to command a civil service focused on delivering results. Three vacancies have simultaneously arisen for new Permanent Secretaries at the Home Office, the Department for Education and Employment, and the Department of Trade & Industry, key Ministries all. Number 10 is dismayed to lose Michael Bichard from Education.

One of the most creative and modernising heads in Whitehall, it is surely no coincidence that he is also the only Permanent Secretary to have been recruited from outside the traditional civil service hierarchy. Barely more than a week ago, the Prime Minister announced that he wanted more civil service posts filled externally, forcing Whitehall to compete with talents from business and other professions. Sir Buggins would not automatically get his turn.

Yet Tony Blair has been stymied. Only one of those three vacancies - that at Trade & Industry, the least important - is to be open to competition. Achieving that much was only possible by overcoming resistance from the Cabinet Secretary, Sir Richard Wilson. A Prime Minister who cannot even get his way about how to appoint the most senior civil servants, never mind who are they, is not a Prime Minister in control of Whitehall.

There has been a swagger in New Labour's step at the pre-election rally in Scotland. Tony Blair, usually the least complacent of men, is presently of the private view that he will 'win big'. However large his triumph at the ballot box, victory will not be complete, and many of his ambitions to change Britain will be in jeopardy, until he masters the machinery of government. He will be in office - but not fully in power.
