webTitle: Racist Party Swings Poll in Australia

fields.headline: Racist Party Swings Poll in Australia
fields.trailText: Back from the political wilderness in a blaze of floral frocks and bilious soundbites, the former fish-and-chip shop owner Pauline Hanson and her right-wing party yesterday helped to deliver a devastating blow to Australia's ruling coalition.
fields.body:
Back from the political wilderness in a blaze of floral frocks and bilious soundbites, the former fish-and-chip shop owner Pauline Hanson and her right-wing party yesterday helped to deliver a devastating blow to Australia's ruling coalition. She is now certain to play a key role in federal elections later this year.

Prime Minister John Howard's conservatives were put to the sword in Queensland, the country's second largest state, by voters angered by free-market reforms that have hurt the countryside and a new 10 per cent tax on goods and services.

The conservative vote splintered among smaller parties - including Hanson's One Nation party, which opposes Asian immigration and Aboriginal rights - producing a Labor landslide.

Early results suggested that Queensland's Labor Premier, Peter Beattie, would return to power with up to 70 of the state parliament's 89 seats after a 10 per cent swing.

Howard's Liberal Party appeared to have won only three seats while the National Party - in Queensland the stronger of the two parties which form the federal coalition - was set to win around 12.

National Party candidate Rob Borbidge rapidly conceded defeat. 'It's a significant victory by any standards,' Borbidge said, acknowledging that federal coalition policies had played a role in Labor's crushing victory and One Nation's resurgence.

One Nation stood in only half the districts in Queensland, and got an average vote of 21 per cent. This was expected to give it at least three seats.

That was down from the 11 it won in the last state poll in 1998. But soon afterwards One Nation imploded when its MPs deserted to form the City-Country Alliance or to stand as independents. One committed suicide.

Yesterday's results represented a powerful comeback. It underscored the party's role in the next federal election, expected to be called by November. Last weekend it won 10 per cent in a state vote in Western Australia.

Hanson said that the vote was 'telling them people are not happy. This is a clear message to John Howard. People do not want the GST [tax], people do not want higher fuel prices and they certainly didn't want the deregulation of the dairy industry'.

Hanson skilfully exploited the system of proportional representation, which asks voters to list candidates in order of preference. She campaigned hard in staunch conservative areas, urging voters to put sitting members last. As a result, the mainstream right-wing parties have been hit hard.

She hopes to exploit the preferential voting system in the federal elections to unseat the ruling coalition.

Protesters in central Brisbane burned an effigy of Hanson outside the state's largest polling station.

'Pauline Hanson is igniting racism in Australia, so we are going to ignite racism,' said Action Against Racism protester David Charlton.

Hanson's policies appeal to prejudice rather than reason. Her party's flimsy policy document comprises just 18 pages of beliefs including mandatory capital punishment for drug traffickers and serial killers, a basic right to possess and use firearms, and a call to halt the giving over of land to native Aboriginals.

She also wants to send back the thousands of boat people who arrive on Australia's shores every year.

webTitle: Godfather running out of bolt holes

fields.headline: Godfather running out of bolt holes
fields.standfirst: The Mafia's chief has been in hiding since 1963. Now family letters could trap him, reports  Rory Carroll  in Rome
fields.trailText: The Mafia's chief has been in hiding since 1963. Now family letters could trap him, reports  Rory Carroll  in Rome
fields.body:
In the hills of western Sicily, among the sheep, citrus trees, olive groves and palm dates, an old man is waiting for winter to end. They say he is broad and paunchy, but still strong. Sometimes wind catches the wisps of white hair on either side of his head.

Spring is on its way but the nights are bitter. Shepherds say the cold gets into your bones. From some peaks you can look down on the Mediterranean and see the gulls swooping on ships. Fields covered in snow would swallow up whitewashed farmhouses were it not for their black window frames.

In the stillness footsteps crunch on snow. They say the old man is sick but that his ears are as sharp as ever. They need to be. Bernardo Provenzano is a hunted man. Hundreds of police officers are searching the territory. Behind every bend lurks a potential patrol, road-block or hidden camera. Behind every friend's smile lurks potential treachery. Behind every decision lurks the risk that this will be the mistake, the misjudgment, that costs his liberty. Generations of policemen have come and gone waiting for that mistake.

Provenzano, Italy's most wanted man, the Mafia's legendary boss of bosses, has been on the run for 38 years. His is one of the great fugitive stories of our time. The state has mobilised elite units, recruited dozens of informers, bought the best technology, and still, against all the odds, he remains free. The most recent photograph is from 1959: a chunky, open-faced youngster with brilliantined hair, a grave expression and wearing a suit. A computer-generated Identikit of the 68-year-old has been constructed with the help of informers, but its accuracy is dubious.

Disdaining South America or Spain's Costa del Crime, Provenzano remains in Sicily. He is somewhere in the interior between Palermo and Trapani, a distance shorter than London and Dover. Not for long, perhaps. Breezing through the prosecutor's office in Palermo is an air of giddiness, for the noose is tightening. Last month Provenzano's lieutenant, Benedetto Spera, was arrested in a farmhouse along with Vincenzo Di Noto, a prominent doctor suspected of treating both mobsters.

Last week came another breakthrough. The police announced they had intercepted four letters to the godfather at Mezzojuso, a town 25 miles from Palermo. Handwritten by his wife Saveria, two sons, Angelo, 24, and Paolo, 20, and his younger brother, also called Angelo, tantalising clues were buried amid gossip about business, health and advice to wash socks in cold water.

To the rest of the world he may be known as 'Tractor' for mowing down his opponents, but to Saveria he is 'my beloved sweetheart'. Angelo sought advice about buying land on the outskirts of Corleone which his father did not like - suggesting Provenzano had seen it.

What intrigued investigators most was Saveria's reference to sending on a fleecy jacket and snow trousers that her husband had requested. Hills near Agrigento and Mount Cammarata were immediately searched. Of the Scarlet Pimpernel there was no trace, but some police officers felt they were close enough almost to touch. At stake is more than one man's fate. Mafia mythology and media fictions encrust much of Cosa Nostra but two things are certain. The boss of bosses, the capo di capi , wields enormous power. And Provenzano is that boss. From his hilltop shacks and city bolt holes he controls a vast empire of racketeering, drug-running, extortion, fraud and corruption. He took control when Sicily's Mafia was reeling from a state crackdown and rebuilt it.

From the top down Cosa Nostra is a new organisation, more cautious, quieter, less violent, but just as formidable and ambitious. One of the hugest scams of all is being planned. The state has waged its credibility on capturing Provenzano. Every day of his liberty is a defiance. Secret negotiations are under way with jailed mobsters to bring him down.

His story could start on 31 January 1933, when he was born to peasant parents in Corleone, a dirt-poor town about 40 miles south of Palermo. Perhaps a better place to begin is the day in 1958 when 112 bullets were pumped into the car of Corleone's godfather, Michele Navarra. Among those pulling the triggers were the rising men of honour, Toto Riina and Provenzano. A five-year war of extermination between rival factions followed, with more than 140 corpses and countless missing. Amid the mayhem the Tractor turned fugitive but emerged in the 1970s to rival Riina for leadership of Cosa Nostra's ruling executive, the cupoloa , after Luciano Liggio retired. fields.headline: Zimbabwe throws out journalists
fields.trailText: As part of an intensified wave of repression, Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe's government yesterday expelled two foreign journalists, giving them 24 hours to leave the country.
fields.body:
As part of an intensified wave of repression, Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe's government yesterday expelled two foreign journalists, giving them 24 hours to leave the country.

The action is the latest in a series of assaults on journalists, judges and opposition politicians.

The government yesterday revoked the work permits of Joseph Winter, correspondent for the BBC African Service, and Mercedes Sayagues, correspondent for the South African paper the Weekly Mail and Guardian. No reason was given except that they were journalists.

Ms Sayagues was on business in South Africa and returned to Harare yesterday. Immigration officials initially refused to let her enter Zimbabwe but she pleaded to be allowed to be reunited with her nine-year-old daughter and so was given 24 hours to wind up her affairs and quit the country.

'As a journalist I have been reporting on human rights abuses and the general breakdown of the rule of law in Zimbabwe. The action taken against me is small compared to those Zimbabweans who have been murdered, tortured and beaten,' said a defiant Ms Sayagues.

The two journalists are taking urgent legal action against their expulsion, but are expected to leave Zimbabwe later today.

Supporters of the Mugabe government have already beaten and threatened Zimbabwean journalists and earlier this month the printing press of the independent Daily News was destroyed in a massive bomb blast.

In the past week the government has threatened Supreme Court judges, arrested opposition politicians on spurious charges and sent army troops into Harare's townships to beat residents at random.

Three hundred of Mr Mugabe's war veterans invaded the Supreme Court and forced the five judges to flee. The judges have received death threats.

Supreme Court Chief Justice Anthony Gubbay succumbed to the pressure and resigned. But the other Supreme Court judges are making a stand against the government. Justice Nick McNally refused to accept early retirement. Justices Wilson Sandura and Simbarashe Muchechetere refused to meet with Justice Minister Patrick Chinamasa.

Zimbabwe's Supreme Court has been admirably independent and in December issued carefully considered reversals to Mr Mugabe's 'fast track' land seizures, ordering police to remove thousands of Mr Mugabe's supporters from lands they were illegally occupying.

In January the Supreme Court ruled unconstitutional Mr Mugabe's amendment to the Electoral Act which stated that no legal challenge could be made to the results of parliamentary elections. The Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) is pressing court cases against the results of 40 parliamentary seats with strong evidence of state-sponsored violence, intimidation and fraud.

To make it more difficult for the MDC, its president, Morgan Tsvangirai, was on Thursday charged with inciting violence against the president, along with four MDC members of parliament. In September last year Mr Tsvangirai said, 'We call on Mugabe to resign peacefully or he will risk being overthrown violently.' They all deny the charges.

Mr Mugabe's new crackdown on independent voices, using state violence and intimidation, is widely seen as preparation for the presidential elections. There is speculation that he is trying to strengthen his position to call them this year instead of on the due date of April 2002.

webTitle: Aids vaccine gives Africa ray of hope

fields.headline: Aids vaccine gives Africa ray of hope
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: An Anglo-Kenyan team will begin trials in Nairobi this week of the first Aids vaccine specifically designed for Africa, where 90 per cent of Aids victims live.
fields.body:
An Anglo-Kenyan team will begin trials in Nairobi this week of the first Aids vaccine specifically designed for Africa, where 90 per cent of Aids victims live.

The radical new vaccine is the result of a partnership between scientists from the universities of Oxford and Nairobi, which nearly came unstuck over a patent war last year. Parallel trials have already begun on 18 volunteers in Britain to see if the vaccine has any toxic effects.

The vaccine stems from the discovery that 60 prostitutes in Nairobi's Majengo slum - around 5 per cent of the total - were immune to HIV despite massive exposure to it. The women had between five and 10 sexual partners every day, and rarely used condoms. Up to 25 per cent of Kenyans are estimated to be HIV positive, and in Nairobi's slums even more.

'They didn't have the virus or the antibodies. So they must have been getting rid of the virus so quickly that it couldn't get established,' said Dr Job Bwayo, leader of the Kenyan team, yesterday.

Nairobi scientists discovered the women's immune systems were utilising an aggressive cell against the virus. The instant other cells became infected these 'killer T-cells' destroyed them.

'We took the HIV virus and white blood cells from the prostitutes, put them in a test-tube and - bang! - they reacted. The cells killed the virus,' said Bwayo.

The discovery spawned similar studies around the world. A team from Oxford's Institute of Molecular Medicine found the same phenomenon in prostitutes in the Gambia. In 1995 the Oxford and Nairobi teams joined forces. Backed by the New York-based International Aids Vaccine Initiative, their efforts have so far cost $4.5 million - a comparative snip.

The idea of a vaccine is to train the body's immune system to recognise characteristics of an enemy virus in advance, so that it will tell foe from friend when the attack comes. Traditionally, that has meant injecting people with a weakened or killed version of the virus itself, triggering antibodies.

Around 25 experimental Aids vaccines based on this principle are on trial globally. All except one have failed to get past the preliminary test stage. The new vaccine aims to trigger a different kind of immuno-response, producing not antibodies but cells - killer T-cells. Results in animals have been encouraging. Around 30 per cent of monkeys injected with the vaccine proved immune to extremely high doses of Simian Immunodeficiency Virus, HIV's close cousin.

Professor Andrew Mc-Michael, leader of the Oxford team, said yesterday: 'I believe we have a really good chance of this thing working; somewhere in the region of 70 per cent.'

McMichael confirmed that the trialists in Britain, himself included, had suffered no side-effects. 'We didn't expect any and we're very happy,' he said.

If the Kenyan trials go as well , the vaccine will be tried on a large, high-risk population in 18 months. Kenya will be the perfect testing ground because the vaccine is designed for subtype A of the virus, the predominant strain in East Africa. All existing vaccines target subtype B, predominating in Europe, Asia and America. 'As a vaccine for people in the UK this would not be optimal, though we believe we could adapt it quite easily,' said McMichael.

The best case scenario would see manufacturers called in after two years of population trials, and the vaccine widely available in another two years: around six years from now. Bwayo said: 'This vaccine may not prove to be the one. But we have hopes that, if not, one of the modifications currently being produced in Oxford will be.'

Three months ago, such co-operation briefly seemed a distant dream. Reports that McMichael and a colleague, Dr Thomas Hanke, had patented the vaccine without mention of their Kenya colleagues caused a storm in the region's media. McMichael and his colleagues flew to Nairobi for emergency talks, and the two teams agreed to leave all patent matters to an independent panel of experts.

webTitle: Russians beg Putin to save Mir

fields.headline: Russians beg Putin to save Mir
fields.standfirst:
As the ageing space station nears its watery grave, millions mourn the passing of a national status symbol

Special report: space exploration
fields.trailText: As the ageing space station nears its watery grave, millions mourn the passing of a national status symbol
fields.byline: Amelia Gentleman in Moscow  and Robin McKie
fields.body:
To the West, it is a dilapidated rustbucket whose demise cannot come soon enough. European and US space officials are already rubbing their hands. But to Russia, the Mir space station - now scheduled to splash into the Pacific between 13 and 18 March - remains a potent symbol of patriotic pride.

Its destruction is viewed as a betrayal of the nation's once-glorious space history. 'We will become a banana republic without any bananas,' says cosmonaut Georgy Grechko, who blames the US for engineering the death of Mir and Russia's space programme. 'America will siphon off a few hundred of our best specialists, but some 100,000 will be out of work.'

It costs £150 million a year to keep Mir in orbit, a price Russia can no longer afford if it is to participate in the US-led International Space Station now being constructed above Earth. Hence Putin's decision to axe the craft that has been dubbed Starship Lada by the West, but which is seen as '130 tonnes of intellectual metal' by his countrymen.

A poll last week revealed that 67 per cent of Russians oppose the destruction of Mir. A letter signed by former cosmonauts and rocket scientists and 16,000 Muscovites has been handed to Putin. It claims Mir's death sentence is 'anti-Russian'.

On Tuesday, the fifteenth anniversary of Mir's launch, thousands of demonstrators are expected to protest about its fate, and feelings will run high. According to the left-wing daily Soviet Russia , the government is planning 'the killing of a living organism'.

The West may recall the station's worst year in 1997 when a fire and then a collision with a cargo spaceship nearly destroyed Mir, but Russians prefer to remember its other 14 years of success. Nor could the timing of Mir's end be worse, for it has coincided with the election of a US administration committed to the development of a sophisticated star wars defence programme.

'Russia's space programme is being destroyed,' says Vyacheslav Tetekin, leader of the Save Mir campaign. 'America has squeezed everything they needed and now they are ditching our specialists like unnecessary ballast.'

Such protests are understandable, but ignore a basic fact: that the 40ft-long space ship, whose bristling solar panels give it the appearance of a railway carriage with wings, can no longer function safely.

'The technology is outdated, and we don't have money for repairs,' says space agency official Alexei Gorbunov.

Worst of all, Mir's giant gyros are broken and the craft can only hold its position in space by using its thruster rockets, which burn fuel at an alarming rate. Two months ago, engineers at Star City announced they had had enough. 'We cannot continue with this game - which I call Russian roulette,' said one.

An unmanned Progress spacecraft carrying fuel was launched and docked with Mir a couple of weeks ago. 'Now all the Russians have to do is let the craft sink of its own accord until it reaches a critical height of 250 kilome tres,' said Richard Crowther of the British National Space Centre. 'It now orbits at 280km but is dropping by more than a kilometre a day.'

Once it has reached 250km, Star City engineers will fire the Progress capsule's rockets, causing Mir to slow down rapidly, and plunge into the atmosphere. This final burn will be timed precisely to allow Mir to make a last sweep over Asia before plummeting into the Pacific.

'In the past, 25 to 30 per cent of large spaceships survive re-entry,' said Crowther. 'We can therefore expect that about 35 tonnes worth of Mir will still hit Earth - at about 120mph - though not in one lump. There should be a spray of bits and pieces that will fall into the sea.'

Mir should have reached its 250km re-entry height by now, but has been saved by - of all things - the sun. 'We are going through an intense period of solar activity called the Solar Max which heats up the upper atmosphere, causing it to rise and drag on Mir and thus slow it down,' said Crowther.

'But for some mysterious reason that activity stopped a few weeks ago. The drag on Mir has been reduced, and this has extended its life.'

The sun's intervention has therefore given Mir an unexpected stay of execution, but not one that will soothe the feelings of the spaceship's millions of Russian fans.

'We are going through an intense period of solar activity called the Solar Max which heats up the upper atmosphere, causing it to rise and drag on Mir and thus slow it down,' said Crowther. 'But for some mysterious reason that activity stopped a few weeks ago. The drag on Mir has been reduced, and this has extended its life.' The sun's intervention has therefore given Mir an unexpected stay of execution, but not one that will soothe the feelings of the spaceship's millions of Russian fans.

webTitle: Comment: Allowing girls to become mini-adults endangers them

fields.headline: Stolen innocence
fields.standfirst:
Allowing little girls to become mini-adults puts them in danger

Special report: child protection
fields.trailText: Allowing little girls to become mini-adults puts them in danger.
fields.body:
She preens in the mirror, her mouth a glossy pout, her tight little Lycra top riding above her belly button. She stands beside me in the changing room, trying on a pair of hip-hugging jeans, and as she turns her back to the mirror she wails: 'Mum... You didn't tell me I've got VPL!'

I didn't know about Visible Panty Line when I was her age - but then, I didn't wear lip-gloss or revealing Lycra tops, either. The girl standing beside me is about eight years old.

What kind of a childhood will she have? Not the kind you or I had. She can step out of this High Street shop and buy Tweeny mags that share tips on how to snog; or buy the video of the teenaged Britney Spears gyrating in a school uniform and pigtails - and know that men (even Ally Campbell) find this get-up sexy.

This Lycra childhood is a recent construct. It is also dangerous: in allowing children to ape adults in clothes and manners, are we not colluding with child pornographers and child abusers?

When seven paedophiles - one a married father of two - were jailed for membership of the world's biggest child pornography ring last week, newspapers and children's charities rushed to condemn the leniency of the sentences, which averaged 15 months. But when I argued on 'Thought For the Day' on Radio 4's Today programme that we were feeding these men's appetites by confronting them, day in day out, with children got up as tarts, I was rounded on by a spokesman for the Probation Service, by a tabloid paper and by a Labour MP. Suddenly, my two-minute God slot had given paedophiles a green light and my message was that children were asking for trouble.

The brouhaha should not have surprised me in a society that refuses to recognise that actions have consequences. We can parade our toddlers in boob-tubes and join the News of the World in hunting paedophiles; we can produce videos starring all-singing, all-dancing nymphettes and cry shock-horror when internet pornographers sit glued to screens that feature depraved images of children. Such faulty logic is popular because it absolves us from any guilt with regard to the evil perpetrated by child abusers and pornographers. The cosy consensus allows us to represent the criminals as monsters operating in a vacuum - the Hannibal Lecters of childhood.

But we too are chewing up and spitting out innocence like so much gristle. Encouraging little girls to act and dress provocatively risks not only turning on some 'pervert' (tabloid shorthand for paedophiles), but forcing the child into the world of sex. She will sense, however unconsciously, that she is an object of covert desires and sinister fantasies.

We risk shrinking childhood to the period when you can fit in a crib. After that, baby, you're on your own. Your parents, the media, and any industry (from clothing to mobile phones) that can milk your tastes for profit will treat you as a mini-adult without any special protection.

It is true that our nostalgia for a blessed period of unknowing may be rooted more in wishful thinking than historic truth. For generations children have toiled in fields and factories (indeed, in developing countries still do); child abuse - statistically more likely to be perpetrated by a family member - has been around since families first shared shelter. Study any Renaissance portrait, and you see children in adult garb.

Adult, yes; but sexy, no. No corsets push prepubescent chests into a decolletage; skirts are not worn to make the child seductively reveal a petticoat or leg. Children may not have been precious - but they were not depicted as sexually precocious.

Today, the converse is true. We idealise childhood as a Teletubby cosy world where the only shadows are cast by Walt Disney Cruellas and the wicked Durselys in Harry Potter. And yet, while we cherish this impossibly glowing image, we conspire, by the products we buy and the popular narratives to which we subscribe, in the sexualisation of the very young.

This contradiction confuses the child - am I Tinky-Winky or am I Britney Spears? - and implicates the adult in creating an erotically charged image of childhood. Most adults may be impervious to it and some who are not may resist it; but can we really wash our hands of responsibility for those who can't?

When Vladimir Nabokov wrote, exquisitely, of Humbert Humbert's obsession with his young step-daughter Lolita (whose age is never revealed), he touched a raw nerve - and was censored as a result. He forced us to confront base and dark instinct: an adult's lust for childish flesh may be taboo, but it is not the exclusive preserve of the 'sicko'.

We may find Nabokov's brutal honesty unpalatable - but unless we recognise that we have constructed an environment that draws out the Humbert Humbert in all of us, we risk promoting the very evil we are so eager to denounce.

There may never have been a time when children enjoyed the untroubled innocence we like to think of as their domain; but must we drag them, made up and tarted up, into a dangerous and premature adulthood?

fields.headline: On the golden coast of the Riviera, a modern exodus is washed ashore
fields.standfirst: 'Appalled' French rescue 1,000 Kurds crammed into migrant ship: Observer report by Peter Beaumont, Jon Henley in Paris and David Barnes in St Raphael
fields.trailText: 'Appalled' French rescue 1,000 Kurds crammed into migrant ship: Observer report by Peter Beaumont, Jon Henley in Paris and David Barnes in St Raphael.
fields.byline: Peter Beaumont, Jon Henley in Paris and David Barnes in St Raphael
fields.body:
The first rescuers to reach the ship were sickened by what they found. Crammed into the stinking hold of the East Sea, a rusting Cambodian-flagged freighter beached by its crew on the rocks of southern France, were hundreds of illegal migrants - men, women and children - packed so tightly in the darkened holds they could not even sit down. After seven days at sea, all were dehydrated and malnourished.

French officials from the Marine Prefecture in St Raphael, near Nice, described scenes of appalling degradation. Up to 1,000 Iraqi and Turkish Kurds, including 200 children under five, were standing in their own excreta and vomit, many close to collapse. Medical staff were shocked to find that four babies had been born during the crossing from Turkey.

The grounding of the East Sea - the biggest-ever landing of illegal immigrants on French shores - has come as a profound shock. For although France is a destination for many illegal migrants, most come across its land borders. As French police launched a hunt for the Greek crew and Syrian owner of the beached vessel - who are understood to have taken $1,000 from each of the migrants to transport them from Turkey to Italy - Serge Ortis, head of the regional civil protection service in the Var region, described the physical condition of the passengers as deplorable.

'They made the whole crossing standing up in a deep, dark, unventilated space,' he said. 'Hygiene conditions were catastrophic. There are many whole families, including women, children and grandparents, some of whom move with difficulty. They all need warmth, food, and above all water. They are being taken care of as soon as we get them off the boat.'

One Kurd told reporters the migrants had paid between $500 and $1,000 for the passage, but the living conditions were appalling. 'We were down in the holds. You couldn't tell if it was night or day. There wasn't even room to lie down,' he said, speaking in broken English.

Another said: 'Children were crying, there was nowhere to sleep and we stayed alive with just a little food and water. Some talked about getting to England one day, but we were only promised to get to a European country for our money. We were given no warning that the ship was going aground; the first thing we knew was when it crashed against the rocks. We thought we were all going to die.'

It has been called the 'modern slave trade', a business the United Nations estimates is worth £5 billion a year to organised crime. The grounding of the East Sea by its crew of Greek people- smugglers in the early hours of yesterday has provided a graphic reason why. Like occupants of some modern-day slave ship, the hundreds of Kurds had sweated in the holds for days, unfed and barely cared for, en route to the promise of a new life in Italy. The only difference was that these people had paid the smugglers thousands of dollars for the privilege of their incarceration. Now the East Sea case is certain to increase pressure for further action to clamp down on the world's fastest-growing criminal activity, which - UN experts believe - has already affected 200 million lives.

The drama began when the Greek crew - who had apparently lost their way - decided to ditch their ship and flee. In doing so they brought two worlds into collision, abandoning a human cargo from the war-torn fringes of Europe on one of its richest strands, the Riviera.

The crisis brings back memories of one of Europe's darkest episodes when for three weeks in the summer of 1947 more than 4,500 Jews - many of them survivors of Nazi concentration camps - sat packed in sweltering heat aboard three British prison ships off Port-de-Bouc, close to St Raphael.

This time the first thing the tiny nearby port of Boulouris knew about the unfolding crisis came with a hammering at a resident's door at 3.30am. He found a small group of men. 'They made clear that they were Kurds, that there were many more of them in a boat, that they were seeking asylum, and that they needed help,' he told French radio. 'We contacted the police straight away.'

What the police saw when they went down to the beach, looming in the early morning light, was an ageing freighter sitting in a few feet of oily water, its propellers still turning to prevent it from drifting off the rocks.

Doctors were flown to the ship by helicopter and several were dropped on to the deck. They reported around 200 children under the age of five aboard, including the four babies born during the voyage.

Gendarmerie Captain Roland-Marie Germain said between 60 and 100 migrants were thought to have scrambled ashore after the ship ran aground. They lit a fire on the beach to keep themselves warm, he said, and a small but unknown number seized the opportunity to head inland, some of them making for the nearby centre of St Raphael. 'We are preparing to take all the remaining people, who have hygiene rather than serious health problems, to the army base at Fréjus,' he said. 'There are families here, children and even babies who were born on board.'

Within an hour a major rescue operation had been launched. As the details of the horrific voyage of the East Sea began to emerge, French officials said yesterday they believed the vessel was deliberately beached, and no SOS had been received. 'The captain has fled, leaving the boat facing land, the propellers turned, so that the boat cannot drift away. It was professional work,' said Georges Ginestat, the mayor of St Raphael.

'There are around 1,000 people on board,' he added. 'The bow was pointing towards the shore and the engines were still running, so it couldn't return to sea.'

According to the accounts of the first migrants to be rescued from the boat and ferried to a holding centre at the 21st Marine Infantry Regiment base at the nearby city of Fréjus in a fleet of re-quisitioned buses, the voyage of the East Sea began in Turkey from where it sailed for Italy, stopping off in Greece.

Yesterday, standing by a driftwood fire, some of the refugees took the opportunity to experiment in broken English with French journalists. 'We wish to claim asylum. We want to live in peace,' said one. Another Kurd told reporters that the crew had been Greek. Another described the harrowing conditions on the sea crossing: 'We were given nothing at all.'

Crowded, unsafe refugee vessels of this sort, packed with migrants who have often paid large sums to highly organised smuggling groups, routinely make it to the Italian coast by what is know as the Mediterranean Blue Route. Few make it as far as France. For many the ultimate goal is Britain, considered Europe's land of plenty.

In recent years Greek and Turkish captains and crews have been heavily implicated in the trade, which has seen the use of unseaworthy boats, bought cheaply and anonymously for the trade.

Some 25,000 illegal migrants were caught trying to cross the Channel at Calais and neighbouring ports last year, with a further 1,700 cases reported in January alone. A sprawling Red Cross refugee centre at Sangatte, near Calais, provides shelter for up to 1,000 refugees at any one time, mainly Afghans, Iraqi Kurds and Iranians.

Sweden, which holds the rotating presidency of the EU, has made immigration one of the priorities of its term.

EU Interior Ministers meeting in Stockholm two weeks ago agreed to speed up co-ordination of asylum policies to cut the number of 'bogus' applicants, while trying not to ignore genuine refugees fleeing persecution. The British Home Secretary, Jack Straw, has been particularly vocal in calling for enhanced collaboration. Britain received the largest number of asylum applications last year, 98,000, followed by Germany with 79,000. About 50,000 applied for asylum in France.

Europe has been the destination in recent years for a growing wave of immigrants, many of whom pay large sums to smugglers for places on crowded boats bound for what they hope will be a better, safer life.

webTitle: City forgives as Compass points in new direction

fields.headline: City forgives as Compass points in new direction
fields.trailText: Compass Group has lost no time in getting back on the acquisition trail. Less than two weeks after it completed its tortuous merger and demerger arrangements with Granada, it has added two new businesses to its portfolio.
fields.body:
Compass Group has lost no time in getting back on the acquisition trail. Less than two weeks after it completed its tortuous merger and demerger arrangements with Granada, it has added two new businesses to its portfolio.

The deals are reassuring. Not only are they attractive businesses in their own right, they also confirm that, now the distractions of the Granada deal are over, Compass will continue its job of building a global food service - the current jargon for catering - empire.

The two deals do a lot to further that ambition. The first, Morrison Management Specialists, is the second biggest caterer to the healthcare and retirement market in the US. That takes Compass into hospitals and also greatly increases its presence in the fast-growing retirement home market.

The second deal was to bring its 33 per cent stake in Selecta, the European vending machine business, up to 100 per cent. Michael Bailey, Compass's chief executive, believes that much of the growth in its US business has come from providing vending machines that employees can use when canteens are closed.

Combining the two services is already common in the US, and Europe is starting to move along that route. Taking control of Selecta, which has contracts in 15 European countries, will help Compass take advantage of that. The deals also go some way to restoring Compass's status as an international business. Before the Granada swap, just 17 per cent of its sales were in the UK. Add in Granada's Sutcliffe catering operations, motorway service stations and Little Chef, and the proportion rose to 37 per cent - and more than 60 per cent of its profits.

A few more add-on deals like these will help redress that balance. And it will have plenty of firepower once it has sold Granada's hotel business, which it is still promising to do by the end of March.

That will leave the roadside services as the key area of concern in new Compass. Investors were anxious about Compass taking them on - they are busy, messy, expensive and unpleasant to use. In investment terms, that translates into low growth and poor margins.

Compass is confident that it can improve this performance, through measures such as using its branded catering operations - Upper Crust, say - in service stations. The City has yet to be convinced. While it waits, however, there is the prospect of a promised £70 million of cost savings.

The City is starting to forgive Compass for the Granada deal. Its shares have risen from 482p when they started trading in the new form, to 565p in just two weeks, although that is still some way from the premium rating they used to enjoy. Sentiment should improve further when the sale of the hotels is completed. In the meantime, buy.

Not a minute to wait

Isn't lastminute.com a wonderful idea? We all like to think of ourselves as impulsive and adventurous. It was very clever of Martha Lane Fox and Brent Hoberman to think of an internet site which panders to that.

But clever ideas do not always translate into clever investments.Take the first-quarter results. Critics made great play of the fact that subscriber numbers were static but, with 2.9 million people already signed up to the site, growth was always going to be slow. As Hoberman points out, the more important thing is what the subscribers do with the newsletters they get. Now that most of its subscribers have been transferred to the jazzy version, complete with graphics and - crucially - other people's adverts, an impressive 7 per cent of them actually clicked on those adverts and signed on to the sites.

That means money for lastminute.com. More of its subscribers are also buying from the site. In the three months to December, the number of customers, as a proportion of subscribers, rose from 5.5 to 8.9 per cent.

But look at what it cost to get there. In the third quarter it spent £7.2m on sales and marketing alone, then there is the £8m paid out for product development and admin. In total, its costs were almost seven times its £2.9m turnover. As Hoberman points out, sales and marketing spend per customer is falling but, at £92 per customer in the three months to December, it is still astronomical.

All new businesses have to spend heavily to establish themselves. The problem is, lastminute's revenues are so small - a large proportion of the £2.9m turnover was from advertising, not commissions - and its costs so high, it takes a great leap of faith to see the profits emerging.

The share price says they will. Although the shares have fallen from a high of 550p to just 65p, that still represents £470 for every customer who has bought from it since inception, or almost £50 per newsletter subscriber. On the heroic assumption that turnover doubles every quarter this year, the market value would still be almost three times sales. That is much too expensive. Sell your shares now.

Still in the rinse cycle

Don't fight the Fed, goes the old adage, and the markets have taken it to heart. Nasdaq, in particular, has soared since Alan Greenspan made his first rate cut at the beginning of January and is now 11 per cent ahead of its low for the year.

The theory is simple. Interest-rate cuts are good for shares, and cyclical stocks in particular, so they tend to rise first. In practice, however, investors spent much of last year persuading themselves that technology stocks were not cyclical, so it seems perverse to be buying them on the back of a cyclical rally.

Second, and more important, the blind rush into technology ignores the damage last year's boom did. Investment was accelerated on the assumption that the good times would go on for ever, stocks and borrowings to fund the stock increases are both unhealthily high.

That is worrying for two reasons. First, unwinding the stock positions will keep production, and hence demand for raw materials, low for some time - a vicious circle. Second, banks are becoming nervous about debt levels so companies could be forced to tap stock markets for funds, as the telecoms companies are doing. A flood of new shares on to the market is hardly conducive to roaring prices.

Michael Taylor, head of institutional investment at Threadneedle, thinks Nasdaq could have 30 per cent to fall. At best, it will go nowhere for 18 months.

It is too early to buy into tech recovery.

Not only are they attractive businesses in their own right, they also confirm that, now the distractions of the Granada deal are over, Compass will continue its job of building a global food service - the current jargon for catering - empire. That takes Compass into hospitals and also greatly increases its presence in the fast-growing retirement home market. The second deal was to bring its 33 per cent stake in Selecta, the European vending machine business, up to 100 per cent. Michael Bailey, Compass's chief executive, believes that much of the growth in its US business has come from providing vending machines that employees can use when canteens are closed. Combining the two services is already common in the US, and Europe is starting to move along that route. Taking control of Selecta, which has contracts in 15 European countries, will help Compass take advantage of that. The deals also go some way to restoring Compass's status as an international business. Before the Granada swap, just 17 per cent of its sales were in the UK. Add in Granada's Sutcliffe catering operations, motorway service stations and Little Chef, and the proportion rose to 37 per cent - and more than 60 per cent of its profits. A few more add-on deals like these will help redress that balance. And it will have plenty of firepower once it has sold Granada's hotel business, which it is still promising to do by the end of March. That will leave the roadside services as the key area of concern in new Compass. Investors were anxious about Compass taking them on - they are busy, messy, expensive and unpleasant to use. In investment terms, that translates into low growth and poor margins. Compass is confident that it can improve this performance, through measures such as using its branded catering operations - Upper Crust, say - in service stations. The City has yet to be convinced. While it waits, however, there is the prospect of a promised £70 million of cost savings. The City is starting to forgive Compass for the Granada deal. Its shares have risen from 482p when they started trading in the new form, to 565p in just two weeks, although that is still some way from the premium rating they used to enjoy. Sentiment should improve further when the sale of the hotels is completed. In the meantime, buy. Not a minute to wait Isn't lastminute.com a wonderful idea? We all like to think of ourselves as impulsive and adventurous. It was very clever of Martha Lane Fox and Brent Hoberman to think of an internet site which panders to that. But clever ideas do not always translate into clever investments.Take the first-quarter results. Critics made great play of the fact that subscriber numbers were static but, with 2.9 million people already signed up to the site, growth was always going to be slow. As Hoberman points out, the more important thing is what the subscribers do with the newsletters they get. Now that most of its subscribers have been transferred to the jazzy version, complete with graphics and - crucially - other people's adverts, an impressive 7 per cent of them actually clicked on those adverts and signed on to the sites. That means money for lastminute.com. More of its subscribers are also buying from the site. In the three months to December, the number of customers, as a proportion of subscribers, rose from 5.5 to 8.9 per cent. But look at what it cost to get there. In the third quarter it spent £7.2m on sales and marketing alone, then there is the £8m paid out for product development and admin. In total, its costs were almost seven times its £2.9m turnover. As Hoberman points out, sales and marketing spend per customer is falling but, at £92 per customer in the three months to December, it is still astronomical. All new businesses have to spend heavily to establish themselves. The problem is, lastminute's revenues are so small - a large proportion of the £2.9m turnover was from advertising, not commissions - and its costs so high, it takes a great leap of faith to see the profits emerging. The share price says they will. Although the shares have fallen from a high of 550p to just 65p, that still represents £470 for every customer who has bought from it since inception, or almost £50 per newsletter subscriber. On the heroic assumption that turnover doubles every quarter this year, the market value would still be almost three times sales. That is much too expensive. Sell your shares now. Still in the rinse cycle Don't fight the Fed, goes the old adage, and the markets have taken it to heart. Nasdaq, in particular, has soared since Alan Greenspan made his first rate cut at the beginning of January and is now 11 per cent ahead of its low for the year. The theory is simple. Interest-rate cuts are good for shares, and cyclical stocks in particular, so they tend to rise first. In practice, however, investors spent much of last year persuading themselves that technology stocks were not cyclical, so it seems perverse to be buying them on the back of a cyclical rally. Second, and more important, the blind rush into technology ignores the damage last year's boom did. Investment was accelerated on the assumption that the good times would go on for ever, stocks and borrowings to fund the stock increases are both unhealthily high. That is worrying for two reasons. First, unwinding the stock positions will keep production, and hence demand for raw materials, low for some time - a vicious circle. Second, banks are becoming nervous about debt levels so companies could be forced to tap stock markets for funds, as the telecoms companies are doing. A flood of new shares on to the market is hardly conducive to roaring prices. Michael Taylor, head of institutional investment at Threadneedle, thinks Nasdaq could have 30 per cent to fall. At best, it will go nowhere for 18 months. It is too early to buy into tech recovery.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: Musik to EMI ears
fields.body:
Musik to EMI ears

Will Bertelsmann banish EMI's blues? Recent news of a European Commission and Office of Fair Trading probe into alleged CD price-fixing has done nothing to improve sentiment for Britain's big white music hope.

EMI shares have been on the slide for a year, since its dream deal with Time Warner collapsed. At just over 520p, the stock has plunged a third in 12 months.

Three weeks ago Bertelsmann announced that talks with EMI, started in November, would carry on into this month, with a 50-50 chance of a deal. Clearly, therefore, EMI still carries risks, but broker Investec Henderson Crosthwaite, for one, believes the upside outweighs the downside. A deal is now close, it reckons, and the Germans should be able to structure it to gain EC approval.

Nor is the price-fixing inquiry a deal-breaker. Assuming a 50-50 merger with Bertelsmann Music Group, the broker reckons a deal may be worth an extra 310p per EMI share on top of its standalone target of 618p. That factors in 87p compensation to EMI investors and 100p for ceding control. And Investec's downside of 546p - if the deal is blocked and nasty things happen - is still above EMI's current price. With the upside at 928p, the shares are a buy.

Bank teller

Barclays is in the happy position of exactly the reverse happening. Over the past 12 months, its shares have rocketed by more than 50 per cent.

Following a series of public relations gaffes, Canadian chief executive Matt Barrett has managed to pull off the trick of paying a full price for the Woolwich, yet gaining credit for a sound move. He has also avoided repeating NatWest's mistake - overbidding for Legal & General - instead tying up a sensible insurance alliance with L&G.

Results this month were bang in line with expectations; Barclays is now looking for Euro-alliances. It still has an eye on any fallout if, against expectations, LloydsTSB's bid for Abbey National is cleared this week and Bank of Scotland is left at the altar again.

At £23.21 however, analysts are starting to turn cautious following the shares' meteoric rise. Several have cut profit forecasts for this year, and broker Teather & Greenwood thinks Barclays has more exposure to business bad debts in a downturn than other UK banks. Time to take profits.

Drug is the love

Now for something with decidedly greater risk. Biotechnology is hardly a sector for widows and orphans, but shares in Oxford Glycosciences (OGS), at £14 apiece, may now be worth a look.

The stock dropped from a high of £32 a year ago and has been bumbling along of late following a poor reception to its recent fund-raising. The firm is, however, confident of applying for marketing approval in Europe and the US this year for Vevesca, one of its most promising drugs. This is a new treatment for Gauchers disease, a genetic disorder affecting the liver, spleen and bone marrow, which is cheaper than the current drug from US rival Genzyme.

Broker Schroder Salomon Smith Barney values Vevesca at £440 million - 812p per share - if it wins US approval. Taking into account OGS's £200m cash reserves, that implies a value of just £140m for the current core business. The broker thinks that is low, considering its partners include Pfizer, GlaxoSmithKline, Merck and Bayer and has set a price target of £20.

High spirits

Drinks giant Diageo, one of our shares of the year last year, continues to gain support. Profits this week are expected to come in at around £1.2bn, with both spirits and Guinness showing good momentum. At 693p, broker Merrill Lynch thinks the shares are worth nearer 900p.

webTitle: Blessed are the rich, for they get the service

fields.headline: Blessed are the rich, for they get the service
fields.standfirst: As more of us become affluent,banks are focusing their efforts on wealth management, say s  Heather Connon
fields.trailText: As more of us become affluent,banks are focusing their efforts on wealth management, say s Heather Connon
fields.body:
Millions of pounds are being invested in services to help us deal with the problem of the new millennium: what to do with our new-found riches. Ten years ago, the high street banks were piling into investment banking. Five years ago, they were queueing up to buy building societies and fund managers. Today, despite Credit Suisse's decision to pull out of the market, the holy grail for the retail banks is wealth management.

Abbey National, HSBC, Lloyds TSB, Royal Bank of Scotland, Barclays - you name it, they are all setting up wealth management services. All have one aim: to make money from advising the so-called 'mass affluent' on investing their money.

Wealth management is nothing new. Companies such as Coutts, the Queen's bankers, and Hoare & Co have been doing it for years, but they call it private banking. What is new is the number of companies keen to jump on the private banking bandwagon.

The growth is being driven by two key factors. First, more and more of us are getting rich - through inheritance and the increase in the value of private businesses. Abbey National estimates that more than 4 million people in Britain have at least £50,000, excluding the value of their houses, to invest; Lloyds TSB predicts that number will grow by at least 10 per cent a year.

The second driver is technology. The growth of telephone and internet-based services means that companies can now offer quite sophisticated advice relatively cheaply. And that means banks are able to offer services that were once the province of the seriously rich to the moderately affluent.

In what Huw van Steenis, an analyst at J P Morgan, calls the'skinny bricks and clicks' approach, banks will have real centres - Lloyds TSB will have 31, Abbey National six - but much of the admin will be done over the phone or internet. Significantly, however, most of those who were planning an internet-only service - like JP Morgan itself - are retrenching. Abbey National says its research showed that customers thinking of handing over more than £50,000 of their savings wanted to meet the recipient face to face.

Providing the services may be cheap, setting them up is not. Lloyds TSB spent £36 million last year and will invest a further £100m this year in its Create service; HSBC and Merrill Lynch are investing $1 billion between them setting up an international service targeting the mass affluent - the UK launch is due in the spring. And it is not just British banks that are doing it; virtually every European and US bank worth its salt has some sort of wealth management strategy.

Some are very ambitious - Deutsche Bank is seeking 1 million customers by the end of 2004. Merrill Lynch-HSBC has not enunciated targets but it will need high take-up rates to justify its investment.

If the history of banking is anything to go by, not all will make a decent return on their investment. JP Morgan's van Steenis expects only between six and 12 players to make 'serious money, long-term'. Given the amount of activity globally, that will mean major fall-out. Currently, there are 40 online brokerages, for example: that number must surely fall. '

He refuses to predict who will win out. But he says that, on paper, the plans by Merrill Lynch HSBC look promising. Putting together one of the biggest, most international retail banks and a leading US investment bank is a powerful combination.

'Bringing products that were formerly the province of the institutional market to the retail is every investment banker's dream,' said van Steenis. In the US, the revolution in brokerage came when Merrill Lynch launched CMAs - cash management accounts. These combine cheque accounts with securities dealing, mutual funds and other investment services. Similar accounts have taken Australia by storm - 72 per cent of all mutual fund sales (similar to our unit trusts) were made into such accounts.

Here, we have been slow to follow. Woolwich's Open Plan system - which Barclays found so attractive it decided to buy it - is supposed to be similar but is based around mortgages, rather than investments.

Merrill Lynch's product promises to be similar to a CMA. Already, customers can sign up to receive company research reports from HSBC and Merrill Lynch analysts. When the product is launched, it will add an online dealing facility, cheque account in various currencies - with access to link cash machines - and high-interest savings accounts. It will, says Merrill Lynch HSBC, be 'a single on-screen place to manage your shares and money online'.

Others are seeking to emulate this service. Lloyds TSB's Create, for example, has teamed up with Goldman Sachs to provide broking services; Barclays is working towards combining its Premier Banking clients, aimed at those earning £60,000 or more, with Barclays Stockbrokers; Abbey National's Inscape will provide one statement showing all the various parts of the account.

'The advent of the omnibus account will transform the market,' said van Steenis. 'I doubt it will be the only winner, but it will send ripples everywhere.'

Ironically, all Britain's retail banks have had the ability to offer wealth management services for years - Barclays, for example, made £500m profit from it last year, Lloyds TSB makes about £300m. The problem has been persuading us to use them.

Laurel Powers-Freeling, managing director of wealth management at Lloyds TSB, said: 'If you look at our existing customer base, we have got 1 million people who qualify for wealth management on our definition (those earning more than £60,000, or with liquid assets of at least £100,000). But we only serve 40,000. That is because the offer we have in place does not appeal to them.'

Certainly, banks' investment products have generally been poor. That is why Barclays has agreed to sell Legal & General branded products, instead of its own. It also explains why Abbey's Inscape will use the best fund managers - Goldman Sachs, Merrill Lynch and Schroders among them - as well as its own. Combine that with the fact that, when we go into branches, we are usually met with long queues and indifferent services and it is hardly surprising that our local bank branch is not the first place most of us think of when we find ourselves with £50,000 lying around doing nothing.

Will relaunches, rebrands and fancy names make any difference? It will be at least five years before that is clear, but their record suggests it is more likely the winners will be American or European.

Where does all this activity leave the traditional private banks?

Largely unperturbed, judging by the reaction of Ray Entwistle of Adam & Company, the Edinburgh-based private bank owned by Royal Bank of Scotland. 'Already in banking, a lot of people are fed up with the service they get from their banks. If you go into your branch, someone just wants to sell you something.

'The interesting thing to us is that Hoare & Co and ourselves are the only private banks where the focus is on service, not sale of products.'

webTitle: Cobra lager works like a charm for its creator

fields.headline: Cobra lager works like a charm for its creator
fields.standfirst: Karan Bilimoria's  curry house beer could soon be burning up the market. Profile by  Faisal Islam
fields.trailText: Karan Bilimoria's curry house beer could soon be burning up the market. Profile by Faisal Islam
fields.body:
When it comes to upper-crust Asians in Britain, Karan Bilimoria is one of the most pukka.

The 39-year-old is managing director of Cobra Beer ('the Indian beer'), one of the UK's fastest-growing companies. A Sunday newspaper described him as one of a new generation of Asians 'who have swapped the corner shop for the high street', but there is nothing remotely corner shop about the former captain of the Cambridge University polo team.

Indeed, when he first started Cobra back in 1990, he was so far removed from the economic sharp end that he confesses to have been caught out by the slowdown: 'The recession started, but I hadn't realised at the time. We had a lot of problems.'

Bilimoria met The Observer at an upmarket Indian restaurant near his offices in Fulham, south-west London. His father was commander-in-chief of the Indian army. And Bilimoria's measured demeanour suggests nothing less than an upbringing in keeping with the 'more British than the British' Indian military. Tally ho and it's polo sticks at dawn.

And polo was at the dawn of Bilimoria's career: he earned his entrepreneurial spurs selling Indian-made polo sticks.

Born in the south Indian city of Hyderabad - the home of Mughal cuisine such as the biryani - Bilimoria moved to Britain at the age of 19. He trained as a chartered accountant at Ernst & Young, but his Indian qualifications were not recognised here so he had to study for two extra years. 'It was highly unfair,' he says.

Still, he went on to study law at Cambridge University, and he constantly sings the praises of the institution and his time there.

A former captain of a winning Blues polo team, he still retains some of the rivalry with Oxford. He is unequivocal about Cambridge's Judge Institute of Management Studies.

'It's far ahead of the Said - are they even in their own premises yet?' he says of Oxford University's business school.

After Cambridge he began importing those polo sticks from India for sale in Harrods and Lilywhites, transporting the first batches in his battered Citroën 2CV.

He had a clear strategy.

'I tried to see where I could add value, for example, by being a bridge between India and the UK,' he said. 'My big idea was beer. When I started at university I hated lager. It was too fizzy and too gassy to drink and I acquired a taste for real ale. But ale doesn't go with Indian food. Instead, I used to empty two bottles of pilsner into my pint glass.'

At the same time there was a revolution in British eating habits. 'I saw Indian food get more and more popular between 1980 and 1990,' says Bilimoria. The number of Indian restaurants in Britain increased from 3,000 to 8,000 over this period, he says.

Then a chance meeting with the brewer of choice for the Indian army led to the development of Cobra beer, a deliberately less gassy, smoother lager. It was to be brewed in Bangalore, then more famous for its beer than its software specialists. Branding, marketing and all sales were in the UK. Bilimoria literally travelled from restaurant to restaurant and grocer to grocer to promote Cobra.

It took five years for revenue to hit the £1 million mark. Another five years on, it is approaching £10m, and grew by 65 per cent over the last year.

Looking around the restaurant as the well-heeled Kings Road set gathers for lunch, it is clear that Cobra is a craze. Every table of businessmen has a clutch of the giant 660ml bottles of the lager.

Crucially for Bilimoria, the clientele are somewhat more generous about sharing their drink than the average pubgoer.

He says: 'We've changed the territoriality of beer - it's the way beer is drunk over there [in India].'

But is Cobra very Indian? It has never been sold there, and brewing shifted from Bangalore in 1997 to Charles May in Bedford, Britain's largest independent brewer.

Says Bilimoria: 'I never wanted it to be sold in India. If I had released it there, getting hold of supply would have been difficult.'

The only real Indian connections are Bilimoria's origins and the recipe. Such claims have attracted scorn from the likes of Kingfisher, a popular Indian beer brewed under licence by Shepherd Neame - in Faversham.

Perhaps it's a measure of multicultural Britain that two English brewers are fighting over which of their products is more 'Indian' in the belief that such authenticity would offer greater appeal to the British public.

But can Cobra go mass-market without breaking its umbilical link to curry? Marketing centred around 'Curryholic Dave' has won plaudits. A sustained advertising onslaught will be required for growth to continue until an expected flotation in April 2002.

Cobra is on the hunt to fund an expansion in its 22 export markets. Indeed Bilimoria has been approached by a number of venture capitalists keen to take up some of his 72 per cent stake in the company. And if Cobra can't project from its niche into the mass market, there are a number of other revenue winners.

Bilimoria's next project is the launch of a range of wines called General Bilimoria, after his father. It's even more difficult for wine to complement the flavours in a curry. Given the lack of vineyards in India, it is handy that the Languedoc region of France offers a grape with just such a quality.

In fact, much of the value of his business is beyond the products - it is about a distribution network and a strong relationship with the fragmented but lucrative Indian curryhouse sector. This relationship has been cemented with e-commerce ventures such as the curryzone.co.uk site and publishing. 'Everybody eats curry, everyone goes to Indian restaurants,' says Bilimoria.

He is untroubled by academic research from Nottingham Trent University that posited that curries were 'addictive'. He says: 'These days addiction needn't be a bad thing.'

Bilimoria is a passionate evangelist for entrepreneurialism.

'There's an emerging meritocracy in Britain. Anyone can come up with an idea and pursue it,' he says.

He is involved in The Indus Entrepreneurs (TiE), a Silicon Valley-based global business networking organisation for people with interests in the subcontinent. When Bilimoria appeared on the BBC's Question Time earlier this month, the zeal with which he embraced Britishness elicited a quizzical expression from Tory co-panelist Andrew Lansley.

Responding to a question about whether anti-euro sentiment was caused by xenophobia, Bilimoria said: 'The fact that the British are proud to be British is a great thing.'

fields.bodyText: When it comes to upper-crust Asians in Britain, Karan Bilimoria is one of the most pukka. The 39-year-old is managing director of Cobra Beer ('the Indian beer'), one of the UK's fastest-growing companies. A Sunday newspaper described him as one of a new generation of Asians 'who have swapped the corner shop for the high street', but there is nothing remotely corner shop about the former captain of the Cambridge University polo team. Indeed, when he first started Cobra back in 1990, he was so far removed from the economic sharp end that he confesses to have been caught out by the slowdown: 'The recession started, but I hadn't realised at the time. We had a lot of problems.' Bilimoria met The Observer at an upmarket Indian restaurant near his offices in Fulham, south-west London. His father was commander-in-chief of the Indian army. And Bilimoria's measured demeanour suggests nothing less than an upbringing in keeping with the 'more British than the British' Indian military. Tally ho and it's polo sticks at dawn. And polo was at the dawn of Bilimoria's career: he earned his entrepreneurial spurs selling Indian-made polo sticks. Born in the south Indian city of Hyderabad - the home of Mughal cuisine such as the biryani - Bilimoria moved to Britain at the age of 19. He trained as a chartered accountant at Ernst & Young, but his Indian qualifications were not recognised here so he had to study for two extra years. 'It was highly unfair,' he says. Still, he went on to study law at Cambridge University, and he constantly sings the praises of the institution and his time there. A former captain of a winning Blues polo team, he still retains some of the rivalry with Oxford. He is unequivocal about Cambridge's Judge Institute of Management Studies. 'It's far ahead of the Said - are they even in their own premises yet?' he says of Oxford University's business school. After Cambridge he began importing those polo sticks from India for sale in Harrods and Lilywhites, transporting the first batches in his battered Citroën 2CV. He had a clear strategy. 'I tried to see where I could add value, for example, by being a bridge between India and the UK,' he said. 'My big idea was beer. When I started at university I hated lager. It was too fizzy and too gassy to drink and I acquired a taste for real ale. But ale doesn't go with Indian food. Instead, I used to empty two bottles of pilsner into my pint glass.' At the same time there was a revolution in British eating habits. 'I saw Indian food get more and more popular between 1980 and 1990,' says Bilimoria. The number of Indian restaurants in Britain increased from 3,000 to 8,000 over this period, he says. Then a chance meeting with the brewer of choice for the Indian army led to the development of Cobra beer, a deliberately less gassy, smoother lager. It was to be brewed in Bangalore, then more famous for its beer than its software specialists. Branding, marketing and all sales were in the UK. Bilimoria literally travelled from restaurant to restaurant and grocer to grocer to promote Cobra. It took five years for revenue to hit the £1 million mark. Another five years on, it is approaching £10m, and grew by 65 per cent over the last year. Looking around the restaurant as the well-heeled Kings Road set gathers for lunch, it is clear that Cobra is a craze. Every table of businessmen has a clutch of the giant 660ml bottles of the lager. Crucially for Bilimoria, the clientele are somewhat more generous about sharing their drink than the average pubgoer. He says: 'We've changed the territoriality of beer - it's the way beer is drunk over there [in India].' But is Cobra very Indian? It has never been sold there, and brewing shifted from Bangalore in 1997 to Charles May in Bedford, Britain's largest independent brewer. Says Bilimoria: 'I never wanted it to be sold in India. If I had released it there, getting hold of supply would have been difficult.' The only real Indian connections are Bilimoria's origins and the recipe. Such claims have attracted scorn from the likes of Kingfisher, a popular Indian beer brewed under licence by Shepherd Neame - in Faversham. Perhaps it's a measure of multicultural Britain that two English brewers are fighting over which of their products is more 'Indian' in the belief that such authenticity would offer greater appeal to the British public. But can Cobra go mass-market without breaking its umbilical link to curry? Marketing centred around 'Curryholic Dave' has won plaudits. A sustained advertising onslaught will be required for growth to continue until an expected flotation in April 2002. Cobra is on the hunt to fund an expansion in its 22 export markets. Indeed Bilimoria has been approached by a number of venture capitalists keen to take up some of his 72 per cent stake in the company. And if Cobra can't project from its niche into the mass market, there are a number of other revenue winners. Bilimoria's next project is the launch of a range of wines called General Bilimoria, after his father. It's even more difficult for wine to complement the flavours in a curry. Given the lack of vineyards in India, it is handy that the Languedoc region of France offers a grape with just such a quality. In fact, much of the value of his business is beyond the products - it is about a distribution network and a strong relationship with the fragmented but lucrative Indian curryhouse sector. He is untroubled by academic research from Nottingham Trent University that posited that curries were 'addictive'. He says: 'These days addiction needn't be a bad thing.' webTitle: They tried to murder Napster - but shot themselves instead

fields.headline: They tried to murder Napster - but shot themselves instead
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: So Napster is a dead duck. The jubilation of the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) over its success in the 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals has brought a whole new interpretation to the term Pyrrhic victory. It also made one wonder what the goons who run the RIAA are on.
fields.body:
So Napster is a dead duck. The jubilation of the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA) over its success in the 9th US Circuit Court of Appeals has brought a whole new interpretation to the term Pyrrhic victory. It also made one wonder what the goons who run the RIAA are on.

Consider what it has achieved. In December 1999, it launched a high-profile lawsuit against a file-sharing service which - however much it may have been a thorn in the RIAA's side - had hitherto been a relatively marginal player on the internet.The main effect of the legal action was to alert millions of kids worldwide to the fact that it was possible (a) to store music files on one's hard disk and (b) to swap same over the net. These discoveries brought hordes of new users to Napster who might otherwise have never heard of the service. When the lawsuit began, the service had less than a million users a month. Since then it has climbed steadily to around 9 million a month and a total subscriber base of around 50 million people.

For most teenagers, Napster was a concept only marginally inferior to sex. Of course the fact that it enabled them to build up collections of free music on their (or their parents') hard disks was a large part of the attraction . But what was also significant was that Napster enabled them to undermine the recording industry's practice of selling music only in album-sized bundles - which forces music fans to shell out for an entire disk even if all they really want is a couple of tracks (for which most of them would be willing to pay). These twin attractions were what made Napster the fastest-growing network in history - from zero to 50 million subscribers in less than two years - a faster growth rate than the web itself.

The RIAA moguls rejoicing that they have finally put a stop to this nonsense seem to have overlooked a few vital points. The first is that the majority of Napster users are (a) music lovers and (b) young. That is to say, they are the prime customers of the aforementioned moguls and their best hope of cashing in their stock options before retirement.

Second, there are now 50 million of these prime customers with music tracks on their hard disks who have acquired the habit of swapping them over the net.

The publicity surrounding the court case has alerted them to the fact that they need not abandon this agreeable practice - they can turn to systems like OpenNap, iMESH or Aimster which do similar things. 'The entire Napster-using public is going to figure out that they don't need Napster to share files,' wrote Eben Moglen, a Columbia University law professor, in Salon. 'The music industry will then discover that the lawsuit was the stupidest part of five years of stupidity. It will discover that this lawsuit fully popularised, publicised, promoted and spurred the development of the very alternative distribution system it was trying to eliminate.'

The RIAA may have succeeded in closing down Napster the company. What then? Are RIAA lawyers going to knock on 50 million doors? 'They've attempted to murder Napster, and they've actually shot themselves in the head,' says Professor Moglen. 'Self-murder or suicide, they're dead either way - it's an untenable business strategy in the long run to be at war with your own customers. But shutting down Napster will give them no one to sue but the listeners. This is one of those rare, but important, situations in which victory in a lawsuit is defeat in the world.' My only concern about calling it a Pyrrhic victory is that old Pyrrhus might sue for defamation.
