fields.headline: Siberia's great smelting pot
fields.standfirst:
Should Western banks do business with a Russian aluminium giant accused of murder, extortion, fraud and money laundering? Why ever not, ask the institutions. Simon Pirani reports

Special report: Russia
fields.trailText: Should Western banks do business with a Russian aluminium giant accused of murder, extortion, fraud and money laundering? Why ever not, ask the institutions. Simon Pirani reports
fields.body:
A mighty aluminium producer, the second-largest in the world, has risen from the wilds of Siberia - and the big European banks don't know what to do with it.

Russian Aluminium has an annual turnover of more than $5 billion, produces one in every 10 tonnes of the world's primary aluminium, and the commodities finance specialists say they can't afford not to lend to it. But credit committees caution that its general director and others face a $2.7 million damages civil action in a New York court alleging 'numerous criminal acts, including murder, extortion, mail and wire fraud and money laundering'.

The New York case was lodged in December by trading companies that claim they lost business when a group headed by Russian Aluminium's general director, Oleg Deripaska, took control of Novokuznetsk aluminium smelter in western Siberia.

The group's bankers weren't the only ones to get nervous: the organisers of the World Economic Forum at Davos in January cancelled Deripaska's invitation.

But Deripaska insists the law suit is 'baseless', and that double standards were at work at Davos. He asked why he should be ostracised when other figures facing legal action - billionaire financier George Soros is due to stand trial in France for insider dealing - were welcomed.

On 22 January Deripaska flew to London to dispel fears among bankers who have lent, or are intending to lend, to Russian Aluminium. Their response was positive. A source at one bank said: 'Publicity such as that generated in New York never helps, but the company's economic fundamentals are sound, and that's what really mattered.'

Banks visited by Deripaska included those in France (Société Générale, BNP Paribas, Crédit Lyonnais), Germany (West LB, Hypo Vereinsbank), the Netherlands, (ING Barings), Belgium (Fortis, KBC), Austria (Raiffeisen Bank) and the UK (Standard Bank London).

WestLB has already syndicated a $100m loan to Russian Aluminium and is negotiating a further $50m. Loans from two other banks are close to approval. These are short-term deals, collateralised on proceeds from aluminium exports.

Russian Aluminium, formed last April from a merger of assets controlled by oil magnate Roman Abramovich with Deripaska's Siberian Aluminium, now needs not so much ready cash as a credit history to allow it to tap the capital markets for future investment projects.

Aleksandr Bulygin, deputy general director of Russian Aluminium, told The Observer: 'We will follow the issues raised in the New York case right through, and get to the bottom of it. We discussed this at last month's meeting with the banks and had clear indications, from their top managements, that our relationship will continue unchanged.'

Bulygin said Russian Aluminium hoped to increase its loan commitments from Western banks to $450m from the $250m it has now, and to replace shorter loans with longer-term money for investment. It has also borrowed $250m from Russian banks.

Bankers who favour doing business with Russian Aluminium say the lurid New York allegations are simply testimony to methods widespread in Russian industry, where accusations of criminal conspiracies, whether baseless or not, are as common as the conspiracies themselves.

The complainants - three trading companies based in Switzerland, the Channel Islands and Cyprus respectively - allege that when Siberian Aluminium took control of the Novokuznetsk smelter last year, it did so by means of a criminal conspiracy, and then cancelled the complainants' contracts to divert business to insiders.

The companies did not identify their owners, claiming they feared reprisals, but Russian Aluminium says they are linked to Mikhail Zhivilo, head of Mikom, which managed Novokuznetsk until the takeover.

Zhivilo is subject to an international arrest warrant after being charged with the attempted murder of Aman Tuleyev, the governor of Kemerovo, where the smelter is based. Zhivilo and the New York complainants say that the charges against Zhivilo are politically motivated.

Svetlana Smirnova, metals analyst at Renaissance Capital investment group in Moscow, said the New York suit was just another weapon in the battle for control: 'Mikom and its partners were angry. They couldn't get Tuleyev's support and they lost the battle for Novokuznetsk. The $2bn damages figure is ridiculous: the smelter's annual turnover is no more than $450m.'

On the long view, the consolidation of the aluminium industry - Russian Aluminium and a rival, SUAL, now control more than 90 per cent - will help end a dark age in which criminal gangs fought for control of the giant Russian smelters and export proceeds often poured into the coffers of shady offshore trading companies.

After the USSR collapsed, the industry was divided by means of 'aluminium wars' in which smelter managers, metals traders, journalists and others who fell foul of the gangs were slaughtered. The fiercest battle was for control of the world's biggest aluminium smelter, Krasnoyarsk in Siberia.

During this period Anatoly Bykov rose from being head of security at the smelter to chairman of its board in 1997. By last year his star had fallen and he fled the country. He was arrested in Hungary in April and extradited to Russia on murder, gun-running and money-laundering charges. After being released pending trial in August, Bykov - who still owns a 28 per cent stake in the Krasnoyarsk smelter - was bizarrely rearrested in Moscow and charged with murdering, and then conspiring to murder, a businessman who turned out to be alive, his death having been elaborately faked by the prosecutor's office. Bykov denies wrong doing and says the forthcoming trial is politically inspired.

During Bykov's heyday, much aluminium from Krasnoyarsk and the Bratsk smelter was traded by Trans World Group, a London trading company owned by multimillionaires Simon and David Reuben. The group owned a web of more than 100 trading companies and banks. Until last year it also had a controlling stake at Bratsk and smaller holdings in the other large Russian smelters.

At its height, in 1997, Trans World Group had sales of $6bn and produced half of Russia's aluminium and a fifth of its steel. It was heavily criticised by Russian authorities, who said the system was a leech on the nation's economy.

Trans World's ability to perform so well during this period raised eyebrows. Inquiries by Russian prosecutors and parliamentary sub-committees were inconclusive and no action was taken. In 1997 the company was investigated by the Russian police and the UK National Criminal Intelligence Service, but no charges were brought.

In the end, Trans World was pushed out of the aluminium industry not by any suggestion of wrongdoing, but by bigger, stronger business interests. Last year its holdings in Krasnoyarsk and Bratsk and an alumina refinery, Achinsk, were sold to companies controlled by Roman Abramovich, governor of the distant province of Chukotka, key shareholder in the Sibneft oil company and one of Russia's biggest oligarchs (politically influential businessmen).

Then, in the biggest merger in the history of post-Soviet business, these assets were put together in May last year with Deripaska's Siberian Aluminium to form Russian Aluminium. Permission from Russia's anti-monopoly ministry is still pending, but Bulygin does not doubt it will come through. 'We have had favourable indications from the ministry,' he says.

The liberal newspaper Novaya Gazeta went so far as to claim, in an article entitled 'A country for two', that Abramovich and Aleksandr Mamut, who heads MDM Bank - now one of Russia's strongest, and a key lender to Russian Aluminium - could soon control '50 per cent of Russian industry'.

The primitive 'gangster capitalism' that developed in the wake of the USSR's collapse is giving way to new monopolists. It's a natural process, say western enthusiasts for Russian Aluminium, who believe those who want to spurn the company because of its strife-torn origins are hypocrites.

After all, they argue, the history of the French Fifth Republic is being rewritten in the Elf-Aquitaine case to show how oil oligarchs funded Gaullism. Former German chancellor Helmut Kohl had similar problems with funding.

And in the US, prosecutors are fuming at Bill Clinton's pardon for the oil trading oligarch Marc Rich, who was wanted for tax evasion.

One Moscow-based banker said: 'To those who say that for westerners to work with a company as dynamic and exciting as Russian Aluminium is morally questionable, I would say: physician, heal thyself.'

webTitle: Holding back the beans - to perk up the price of coffee

fields.headline: Holding back the beans - to perk up the price of coffee
fields.standfirst: It may not show in the cost of your latte, but producers are struggling with plummeting world prices, writes  John Madeley
fields.trailText: It may not show in the cost of your latte, but producers are struggling with plummeting world prices, writes John Madeley
fields.body:
An international plan by coffee-producing countries to hold back 20 per cent of exports seems to have done nothing to convince coffee traders that world prices could soon be back on the boil.

The prices of the best coffee bean, arabica, halved on world markets in the year to January, from 126 cents to 63 cents a pound, slipping to 59.80 cents this week, the lowest for a generation. Robusta beans, used for blended and instant coffees, have fared much the same and now stand at around 30 cents.

Last October members of the Association of Coffee Producing Countries (ACPC) agreed to retain a fifth of exports in order to raise prices, which they claim are too low to provide an economic return. Vietnam, the world's second-largest producer, last week backed the plan and will hold back 2.5 million 60kg bags - the standard measure for coffee and amounting to 150,000 tonnes - from the market.

In real terms, world coffee prices are less than a quarter of 1970 levels. The emergence of Vietnam as a major producer, accounting for a tenth of global output, is a chief factor behind a rise in world production and a slump in prices. The fall has been catastrophic for countries such as Ethiopia and Uganda, which rely on coffee for most of their foreign exchange earnings.

After an ACPC meeting in London in January, the association's secretary-general, Roberio Silva, predicted that the retention plan would raise prices 'within a month'. Brazil, the largest producer, accounting for more than a quarter of world output, has so far retained 2.2 million 60kg bags, more than 10 per cent of its exports last year, Colombia 600,000 bags and Mexico 90,000 bags. 'I'm confident that as stocks decrease in consuming countries, so we shall see a recovery in world prices,' said Silva.

Yet, despite the mushrooming of coffee bars in the high streets of western countries, supply still exceeds demand. The International Coffee Organisation estimates that production in 2000-2001 will be 113 million bags, of which nearly 11 million will remain unsold. A total of 88.5 million bags were exported in 2000, and the retention by the producers of 20 per cent of that - 18 million bags - means demand would run ahead of supply, swinging the price back in the producers' favour.

This happened in the mid-Seventies, when frost in Brazil and disruptions to supplies from other countries reduced world output by a quarter. The price of coffee more than tripled as a result. A cutback of 20 per cent could now be expected to at least double the world price.

But the retention plan requires discipline on the part of producers. Holding back exports leaves unsold coffee in producing countries, which growers may be tempted to dispose of in 'back door' deals at low prices rather than see it rot. Burning the surpluses is one option. The other is for producers to agree to cut acreages under coffee. But production quotas would be even more difficult to enforce than export quotas.

The existing low prices are, however, likely to mean 'natural' cutbacks in output. Mexico, which last year harvested 6.3 million bags, is this year expected to produce only 3.5 million as growers find it uneconomic to tend the crop.

The tragedy for most of the 10 million people who grow coffee is that, although higher world prices will benefit the ACPC, on the ground they could make little difference. Most coffee is traded down a line of dealers before export and can change hands as many as 150 times.The growers' returns will remain meagre. A sustained period of low prices in the early Nineties left many growers destitute; some lost their land while others neglected their crop.

But around half a million coffee growers are now receiving more than three times the world price in an alternative market. They are those who grouped together in farmers' organisations to sell directly to coffee roasting companies who have been awarded the 'Fairtrade Mark'. These companies must pay a price that gives growers a guaranteed return, including a premium for social investment. Sales of 'Fairtrade' coffee in the UK are booming - they rose by an average 47 per cent a year between 1994 and 1999.

Fairtrade roasters such as Edinburgh-based Café Direct, which buys from 17 farmers' organisations in nine countries, pay arabica growers 126 cents a pound and robusta growers 106 cents, whatever the world price.

But outside of this system, for consumers as for growers, changes in world price make little difference. Although it has halved in the past year, there has been little change in shop prices. 'The price of the beans is very small part of the cost of a jar of coffee,' said a Nestlé spokesman.

That so much is spent on packaging, marketing and distribution can be of little comfort to those at either end of the chain.

The daily grind

Grown in around 80 warm countries, coffee is normally the world's most valuable traded primary commodity after oil, but the market has long been volatile.

Arabica coffee grows in relatively high altitudes - over 600 metres - in countries such as Colombia, Kenya and Ethiopia, where it originated. Robustas grow in lowland areas such as Vietnam and West Africa. Brazil grows both varieties, but 73 per cent arabica.

Around 70 per cent of growers are small farmers who grow coffee to earn a cash income.

Output of coffee is measured in 60kg bags, but the beans are priced in US cents a pound or US$ a tonne.

Every year, in Britain alone, we drink 31,000 million cups of coffee. That's 85 million cups a day.

webTitle: Supply and demand? Try that on teachers

fields.headline: Supply and demand? Try that on teachers
fields.trailText: The perennial campaign of British business against the tangle of government red tape it claims is threatening its very existence was given a boost last week by Forbes magazine. How its survey must have cheered them up at the Institute of Directors.
fields.body:
The perennial campaign of British business against the tangle of government red tape it claims is threatening its very existence was given a boost last week by Forbes magazine. How its survey must have cheered them up at the Institute of Directors.

But there are plenty of studies that show the UK to be less burdened by regulation than our European counterparts. So, oh dear, once again we find ourselves in the middle of the age-old argument. Should we be looking across the Atlantic or across the Channel?

Those that favour the former are most likely also to believe that, far from government regulating commerce, the private sector should be running public services. Even Ministers are disciples of this principle.

In the second of our series - opposite - Faisal Islam considers the success of corporate involvement in the provision of information technology to Whitehall. Last week we looked at the virtues of the private sector's increasing penetration of the schools' 'market'.

At best one could say the jury is still out. But if we are to subject things such as health and education to the rigorous - and profitable - discipline of the market, we should at least follow our own logic. In many areas even a good advocate may have trouble justifying the eventual worth of applying the unfettered tenets of capitalism to public services. One thinks, for example, of the short-term gain but long-term loss to the taxpayer of the cost of building hospitals under the private finance initiative.

But there is one area where the application of a very simple economic law - that of supply and demand - seems to be the obvious answer.

Many schools in London, and much of the South East, cannot recruit sufficient teachers. Some good comprehensives are now only able to offer either French or Spanish - not because their pupils cannot cope with two languages, but because there are not enough staff.

Of course, the authorities are aware of this problem. Only last week a delegation was dispatched to seek recruits in South Africa. Earlier, less contentious, missions to places such as Australia have yielded a good crop of teachers for London boroughs such as Croydon.

But this sticking plaster is not going to stop the slow haemorrhaging of permanent staff from these schools. Nor is the offer of repaying student loans in return for a long-term commitment to teaching. The sad fact is that on an average classroom teacher's salary it is impossible to bring up a family in London.

One primary school head confirmed to me that she had no problem attracting the newly qualified, for whom the first years at work are an extension of university and living in a shared flat or bedsit is fun. But when their thoughts turn to children of their own - or even having a little privacy and the space to swing a cat - they are off to places where a small three-bedroom semi is not an impossible dream.

The average 29- to 34-year-old teacher earns £22,350. Enough, at three and a half times earnings, to afford a mortgage on a three-bedroom house in, say, Lincolnshire. The same teacher in London, with the maximum allowance for working in the inner-city, is on about £27,000. So the largest mortgage she or he could safely take out would be about £94,000. But the average equivalent house in a not-so-smart London borough such as Lewisham costs £203,000. Even in the outer reaches of the capital - Bexley, say - you are looking at £137,000.

How do you bridge the gap which, it is widely held in the profession, would restore demand and supply to balance? The immediate answer would appear to be to increase London weighting. But by how much?

Let's assume our average South London teacher - and south is cheaper than west or north - has to live in the cheapest district. Even then his or her salary would have to be increased by £12,000 to afford that average house - a rise of 44 per cent.

Apoplexy ensues. An outrageous burden on taxpayers - after all, teachers get 13 weeks' holiday. Can't they flip burgers in their spare time?

But this is the 'market rate' so beloved of chief executives when their remuneration committees up their own 'package' by a similar percentage. And surely the production of a well-taught, highly skilled workforce is in the long-term interests of business and the country as a whole?

Of course, it's a pipe dream. But without it, or some other inspired initiative, we face a nightmare.

webTitle: Why the Bank's hawks suddenly started to coo

fields.headline: Why the Bank's hawks suddenly started to coo
fields.standfirst: A cut in interest rates was far from inevitable.  William Keegan  charts how the MPC 'politburo' changed its mind
fields.trailText: A cut in interest rates was far from inevitable. William Keegan charts how the MPC 'politburo' changed its mind
fields.body:
When the nine members of the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) sat down on Wednesday 7 February to discuss the economy, their decision to cut interest rates was far from the racing certainty assumed by the City and the press.

This was in spite of the narrow five-four vote in favour of 'no change' the previous month, and notwithstanding some teasing remarks by a potential swing voter, David Clementi, in a speech in New York. Clementi, the joint deputy governor responsible for financial stability, said that in the light of developments in the US economy the February MPC meeting promised to be especially 'interesting'. For a central banker, that was quite an adventurous statement.

On 11 January Clementi had voted in favour of holding rates at the 6 per cent level that had prevailed since February 2000. So had a long-serving Bank official, Ian Plenderleith, who had been reported in the world's press as 'relaxed' about the threat of a potential spillover from the US slowdown to the UK economy.

As chairman of the Group of 10 leading central bankers who meet regularly in Basle, Bank Governor Sir Edward George had stoutly held the line that Britain and Europe should not be assumed to be in danger of catching a transatlantic cold from the collapse of confidence in the US. Indeed, there were strong signs, both up to and during the next meeting on 7 and 8 February, that what had been dubbed 'the Basle Consensus' might yet prevail in keeping interest rates at 6 per cent.

This was bad news for the 'doves' on the MPC, led by Sushil Wadhwani and DeAnne Julius, who had long argued that the MPC as a whole had been exaggerating inflationary fears and underestimating the scope for productivity improvements. The doves had been joined in January by Oxford economist Christopher Allsopp and Bank chief economist Charles Bean in advocating a cut.

Wadhwani is an acknowledged expert on the markets, and Julius has long experience of industry. It can be taken that they were the members who in January, according to the official minutes, worried that 'the implications of recent developments in the US and in the world economy more generally were more disinflationary for the United Kingdom and the risks to the world economy more acute'.

The doves thought the threat to the UK from the US lay not just in 'trade and price channels' but that 'financial and confidence channels could be at least as important'. They also thought the consensus view of prospects for the euro area looked 'a little complacent' and the Japanese outlook was worrying. By contrast, the mainstream view of George, Mervyn King, Clementi and Plenderleith was that 'it would be sensible to wait for clearer evidence that the labour market and the pace of consumption growth were easing, before relaxing the stance of policy'.

King, the joint deputy governor responsible for monetary policy, is generally considered to be the MPC's leading hawk, with the Governor a pretty close second. Nothing happened between the January and February meetings to alleviate their fears about the pace of consumption or the potential inflationary effects of a tight labour market. Indeed, last week's statistics on unemployment and wage earnings indicate that, if anything, the position from their point of view is more threatening than it appeared in January.

But these members of what is sometimes known as the Bank's politburo also tied themselves in further at the January meeting. As the minutes record: 'Circumstances in the UK were significantly different from those in the US and to cut the repo rate today would send a misleading signal.' Then came the 'Basle Consensus' point: 'Indeed, it might damage confidence here rather than improve it, by giving unwarranted credence to the view that the circumstances were comparable'.

Bean, a recruit from the London School of Economics, with much Treasury experience, is proving to be more independent of the politburo than his predecessor John Vickers. The view he and Allsopp took appears to have been caught by the reference in the minutes that 'with inflation below target, there was sufficient scope to cut rates this month [January] by 25 basis points as insurance against the risk of a worse outcome without putting achievement of the target over the medium term in doubt'.

This extract from the January minutes seems to capture the essence of the stance that evolved during the February meeting, when the MPC finally voted for its first alteration in rates for a year.

Since the 'Basle Consensus' was very firmly held within the politburo - especially the view that they did not wish to be seen to panic - it was clear that if there was to be a rate cut in February, the politburo, or at least one of its members, needed some news to get them, or him, off the hook.

The February meeting was especially important because it was one of four during the year that coincide with the preparation of the MPC's quarterly inflation report, and the new inflation forecasts.

It is well-known that the MPC has consistently undershot its 2.5 per cent target, and that the quarterly exercise usually ends with a magical forecast that inflation will be on target in two years' time - accompanied in recent issues by acknowledgement that some MPC members expect inflation to be lower.

The February minutes are not yet available, but as he presented the Inflation Report last week, King tried to deal with the fact that 'much has been made of the low out-turn for inflation as an influence on policy'.

Speaking on behalf of the MPC, he said: 'It is true that inflation averaged 2.1 per cent in each quarter last year. But month to month, the numbers have been very volatile.'

The Bank's deputy governor added: 'It would be foolish to let that volatility affect policy. In any event, because of the time it takes for interest rate changes to influence inflation, anything we do now will have almost no effect on inflation out-turns over the next few months. We must continue to look ahead over the next two years.'

King cited the strength of the pound as a major reason for the undershooting of the target, and central banks are always worried about what a sudden dive in a currency can do to inflation.

So what moved one or more of the hawks earlier this month? The answer appears to be that at a vital stage in their deliberations they received a flash estimate from the Government statistical service that inflation between January 2000 and January 2001 had fallen to 1.8 per cent - a statistic that was officially unveiled to the public the following Tuesday.

This was some 0.2 per cent lower than the general expectation, and - despite the Bank's worries about the continued strength of domestic demand, especially consumer spending - focused attention on the possibility that inflation could fall to 1.5 per cent.

Under the rules laid down by the Chancellor, it is understood that precision is difficult in these matters, and that inflation could easily work out at 1 percentage point higher or lower than the official target.

But if inflation hits 1.5 per cent or 3.5 per cent, the Governor is charged with ex-plaining himself in an official letter to the Chancellor, and specifying plans for returning towards the target.

That hasn't happened yet, but most members of the MPC - past and present - are amazed at their luck in so successfully keeping inflation within range. If anything concentrated the minds of the politburo this month, it was the thought of having to write that letter.

fields.headline: The record that doesn't play
fields.trailText: 'We now have inflation at its lowest for 25 years,' the Chancellor boasted on Friday.
fields.body:
'We now have inflation at its lowest for 25 years,' the Chancellor boasted on Friday.

Some boast: 25 years ago - in 1976 - inflation was 16.6 per cent. It should not be too difficult to improve on that, you might have thought.

Earlier in the week a news bulletin had also informed us: 'Inflation is at its lowest since records began 25 years ago.' Oh yes? There seems to have been some heavy Government briefing on the inflation figures last week; but even for a Labour Party that thinks history began on 1 May 1997, the idea that inflation records go back only to 1976 is a little far-fetched.

As a matter of fact, this country's inflation records go back to within 200 years of the arrival of William the Conqueror. Anybody who is interested can find them in tables produced by the late Douglas Jay in his book Sterling (1985). They show that, even without the benefit of Gordon Brown's invention of the Monetary Policy Committee, prices in 1464 were barely above their level in 1264, when records began.

What the 25-year claims seem to refer to is the relatively new index for measuring inflation, known by the ungainly initials RPIX, standing for Retail Prices Index Excluding mortgage interest payments. It is this index that is at the core of this Government's macro-economic policy, a policy which places great weight on the achievement of an annual rate of inflation of 2.5 per cent.

The reason for the exclusion of mortgage rates from the index is to avoid a situation where, in its attempts to curb inflation, the Bank's actions make things worse. When it raises interest rates, it attempts to slow the economy down by restricting credit or making the pound less competitive (higher interest rates attract money to London, pushing the pound up). Mortgage rates automatically rise when base rates rise, pushing the cost of living up in the short term, before the other consequences of higher interest rates take effect. A huge volume of economic literature has been devoted to what went wrong on the inflation front in the Seventies. The trouble started in 1969, when, partly as a consequence of the devaluation of the pound in 1967, inflation rose to 5.4 per cent. Harold Wilson, Prime Minister at the time, had famously claimed: 'The pound in your pocket has not been devalued.' Oh yes it had - to the extent that import prices were higher.

The war in Vietnam was also proving inflationary for the key world economy, the US. Oil producers, whose prices were quoted in dollars, did not like the way the money in their pockets was devalued when the dollar itself was devalued in the early Seventies. That led to the oil price explosion. Meanwhile, trade unions became more active in their wage claims, and a vicious price-wage-price spiral developed. The policies of Tony Blair, Gordon Brown and, until recently, Peter Mandelson are essentially a reaction to the troubles Labour had with inflation in the Seventies. In August 1975 year-on-year inflation reached 26.9 per cent. I recall Sir Kenneth Berrill, then head of the Government's think-tank (they had one in those days) saying that at that rate the miners would soon be earning a million pounds a year.

But the mid-Seventies experience was frightening: everybody knew what hyper-inflation had done to other societies. The latest fashionable cure being advocated for Japan is that it should have an inflation target, to boost credit and get the economy moving again. Meanwhile the European Central Bank, with no obligation to boost demand, is being criticised for failing to lead the way in response to deteriorating business surveys in Germany and cut interest rates.

But perhaps the best news last week was that Britain had edged even nearer to full employment, an issue about which I know the Chancellor feels passionately. The fact is that, when inflation is not a problem, governments and central banks have it in their power to create conditions for as much employment as people want.

But it must be said that, even now, unemployment in this country is not the lowest since records began...

fields.headline: Allied's vodka coup under threat
fields.trailText: Russia is preparing to renationalise Stolichnaya, the world's biggest vodka brand, to which Britain's Allied Domecq gained valuable distribution rights last year.
fields.body:
Russia is preparing to renationalise Stolichnaya, the world's biggest vodka brand, to which Britain's Allied Domecq gained valuable distribution rights last year.

Industry sources say the move threatens Allied's coup before Christmas in snatching 'Stoli's' US rights away from rival British spirits giant Diageo.

The Stoli deal was seen as a key consolation prize for Allied, which lost out in December to Diageo and France's Pernod Ricard in the battle for Canada's Seagram.

Allied's other consolation, a side-deal to buy the rights to Captain Morgan rum, is currently the subject of a Puerto Rican court battle with Seagram which may not be resolved until next year.

The Russian police and tax authorities have been investigating the transfer of ownership of Stolichnaya and other top vodka brands to Russian companies controlled secretly offshore. In all 43 brands, including Stoli and Moskovskaya, were sold for 1.7 million roubles - only £43,500 - two years ago.

The Moscow government is battling to regain control of crucial vodka revenues and, as revealed by The Observer last November, a Russian federal body has declared the transfer illegal. The move came just a day after Allied's US deal and now, according to Russian sources, the Kremlin is taking steps to vest the vodka trademarks in Rosspirtprom, a new state-owned holding company.

'The government is preparing the necessary organisational measures for the re-instatement of VVOSPI [the former state owner] or its legal successor [Rospirtprom] to the ownership of the trademarks Stolichnaya and Moskovskaya,' it has said.

Stoli is the world's biggest selling vodka by volume and the third best-selling premium vodka in the US after Diageo's Smirnoff and Sweden's Absolut, which was distributed by Seagram.

This weekend Allied had no comment on the Russian moves. Any threat to its new rights, however, would be a further blow to the group's ambitious chief executive, Philip Bowman.

This month Allied has also lost out in a bidding war for Montana, New Zealand's biggest winemaker, to Australian brewer Lion Nathan. Diageo is keen to expand its wine interests and promises stiff competition to other attempted Allied deals.

fields.headline: A Prodigy returns
fields.standfirst: Leeroy Thornhill was the one in The Prodigy who didn't play or sing, but even dancers can make albums, says Sheryl Garratt
fields.trailText: Leeroy Thornhill was the one in The Prodigy who didn't play or sing, but even dancers can make albums, says Sheryl Garratt
fields.body:
There was A tendency for bands coming out of the acid house club explosion to have dancers - Cressa in the Stone Roses, Bez with the Happy Mondays. For bands that had formed out on the dancefloor, it seemed logical to bring your mates onstage with you, even if they couldn't actually play.

But as these bands matured or split up, the dancers tended to fade away. No one seriously expected Bez to make a solo album. So, when the Prodigy's dancer, Leeroy Thornhill, left at the start of 1999, the group's linchpin, Liam Howlett, sneered: 'It obviously won't make any difference to the music.'

Shortly afterwards, Thornhill also separated from his high-profile fiancée, Radio One breakfast DJ Sara Cox, apparently because of the strain her job put on the relationship. A tabloid newspaper reported that his hair had fallen out due to the stress of it all. And Thornhill seemed set to fade into obscurity.

Except he didn't. Under the name Flightcrank, a type of BMX bike he revered as a child, he began turning out some fine dance remixes. Then a dark, inventive Flightcrank EP, 'Twisted', was released to critical acclaim.

And next month there's an album on which Thornhill sings, plays many of the instruments and writes some surprisingly strong songs. Mixing up dub reggae, breakbeats and scratching, gentle ballads and a nod to the spirit of 1977 in the shape of a cover of punk troubadour Patrick Fitzgerald's 'Famous', it's not at all what you'd expect. For one thing, it's rather good.

In person, Thornhill is all pointy angles, impossibly tall and skinny. But his wide, warm smile and relaxed demeanour seem to indicate that the depression he suffered before leaving the Prodigy is long over. His hair really did fall out: 'I had a bald patch at the front.' But it had nothing to do with leaving the band or his girlfriend. He blames his windmill.

He bought the windmill, in the Essex countryside, in 1998, a year or so after the Prodigy had become global stars with their Fat of the Land album. He wanted an old property and it was the only place he found with ceilings high enough to accommodate his seven-foot frame. Buying it stretched him to the limit financially.

'I've got more in my life than I ever would have had, but I wasn't the money-earner of the band. I made my money doing the live shows.' So when Liam Howlett decided to take a year off to start the new album, Thornhill got edgy. When the year turned into two, he was in trouble. 'Every penny I was spending was borrowed money and I don't live like that.'

Eventually, he decided to leave. 'It was just the right time. Everyone had grown up and changed. The band didn't need a dancer any more, and I didn't want to carry on dancing.' Thornhill had no formal dance training and throwing himself around the stage was getting painful. 'I wanted to stop travelling, living out of a bag. It had been 10 years, the best years I could ever have, but it wasn't challenging any more.'

Then there was the relationship with Cox. 'We'd turned into friends again and although we still loved each other as mates, it was time to move on.' There had been talk of a double wedding with Norman Cook and Zoë Ball, and when I ask if living out a relationship so publicly added to the pressure, Thornhill just laughs.

'Sara was very public, not me,' he says, pointing out that most of the time, the paparazzi who photographed them outside parties had to ask him who he was. Which is how he likes it. 'It's Sara's little world, TV people, Chris Evans and all that stuff. It's about being a big, famous star in England. Everyone has to know your business. I may be English, but it's a very small world to me. The next country is just two minutes away. I've got a slightly bigger view on life than a little island.'

Travelling with the Prodigy, he's seen more than he ever dreamed possible, from war-torn Bosnia and the poverty in post-apartheid South Africa to playing in Moscow's Red Square and at the Knebworth gigs that were the peak of Oasis's career. He laughs at the memory of getting stoned on flights in the early days and says he was lucky to do it all again first class towards the end.

'We were the best live band in the world for a while. No one could rock a crowd like us. I've tasted it, done it; 250,000 people all jumping up and down at the same time is a pretty intense buzz.'

The split was more amica ble than Howlett's statement may have made it seem. It was simply the truth, shrugs Thornhill. 'I had nothing to do with the music.'

He still sees the rest of the band. 'We're brothers. They know things about me that no one will ever know, and me likewise. If anything, for me, it's probably a better relationship now because I'm not waiting around for Liam to let me start earning my living. I'm in control of my life.'

So Thornhill went back to his windmill and started recording there, choosing to release his music quietly on the small, independent Copasetik label, in much the same way the Prodigy started on XL.

There's the Patrick Fitzgerald track that his older sisters introduced him to when going through their punk phase. A mellow dub improvisation with Finley Quaye. A collaboration with a sweet-voiced 18-year-old Essex girl called Charli Tucker and a remix of 'Twisted' by Jamaican dub genius Lee 'Scratch' Perry.

But none of it is too polished. 'It's very honest and DIY,' he says. 'I can't play instruments, I just blag it, really. Musos could pick faults all over it, but it reflects my life over the last year. If people like it, they like it. It's just a start.'

Thornhill says he called his album Beyond All Reasonable Doubt because: 'I know the last few decisions I've made in my life have been right. The minute I split up with Coxy and left the band, my hair grew back. I had to take my life into my own hands and make myself happy again.'

Beyond All Reasonable Doubt is released on Copasetik on 12 March

fields.headline: Hermes tackles Scottish elite
fields.trailText: Hermes, one of the City's most powerful institutions, is set to take on the might of Scotland's financial elite in a row dividing the £55 billion investment trust industry.
fields.body:
Hermes, one of the City's most powerful institutions, is set to take on the might of Scotland's financial elite in a row dividing the £55 billion investment trust industry.

Hermes is furious that the £1.1bn Scottish Investment Trust (SIT), one of the biggest in the industry, capitulated to a US 'vulture fund' last month by buying back shares in itself in a £36m deal not available to all investors.

SIT's board includes such doyens of the Scottish financial establishment as Sir Angus Grossart, SIT's chairman, and Sir George Mathewson, head of the Royal Bank of Scotland. Grossart rejects the claims.

Hermes is incensed by what it sees as 'clubbiness' on SIT's board. 'What's objectionable is that they've favoured one shareholder over another,' said David Pitt-Watson, commercial director of Hermes' Focus Fund.

Hermes runs the £50bn British Telecom and Post Office pension funds; its Focus Fund is an active campaigner for better corporate governance. It claims a fundamental stock exchange rule - the right of investors to be treated equally - was broken in the deal with New Jersey-based Sierra Trading.

If the deal goes unchallenged, Hermes claims, it will be tantamount to allowing 'greenmail' into the UK - the practice of US corporate raiders who intimidated swathes of US industry in the Eighties by threatening hostile bids if their stakes were not bought back at a huge profit.

Sierra has, perfectly legally, targeted underperforming investment trusts. It tabled a motion for SIT's annual meeting in Edinburgh this week which would effectively have liquidated the trust. After the buy-back, it withdrew the motion.

Hermes plans to confront SIT's board at the meeting. It has also asked the FSA to make sure 'greenmail' is outlawed. And it has not ruled out legal action.

Sierra, meanwhile, has fired off a legal warning to Hermes. 'I'm really angry they're using the word "greenmail". It's very unfair,' said Sierra partner Alex Hanson. 'They're trying to paint us as immoral.'

SIT denies any breach of stock exchange rules.


New raiders hit Auld Reekie

fields.headline: Railtrack's SOS for £2bn
fields.standfirst:
Crisis firm appeals to Cabinet as SRA says no  Marshall denies cash is for Hatfield crash

More about transport
Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Railtrack is appealing directly to the Government for a £2 billion bail-out to prevent a financial crisis after it was turned down by Sir Alastair Morton and the Strategic Rail Authority.
fields.body:
Railtrack is appealing directly to the Government for a £2 billion bail-out to prevent a financial crisis after it was turned down by Sir Alastair Morton and the Strategic Rail Authority.

The desperate move effectively means that the company expects the taxpayer to cover the cost of the Hatfield crash - it originally said its shareholders would pay for it - and even to support basic maintenance of the lines and signalling network.

Railtrack chief executive Steve Marshall said the extra money was to keep debt under control. He denied it amounted to using public funds to cover the cost of Hatfield, which City and train operator sources have put at up to £900m, compared with Marshall's estimate of £580m.

He said the company was 'absolutely committed' to projects such as the TPWS safety system, the £5.8 billion West Coast mainline modernisation and the Thameslink 2000 scheme to rebuild London's King's Cross interchange. It would borrow to fund them if there was no extra subsidy.

Such a move would put the company's debt and interest payments at crisis levels, however, and is the equivalent of a threat to the Government that such vital projects are reliant on a bail-out.

And Marshall admitted that the company was not able to commit itself to any other projects and could not even afford to upgrade the East Coast mainline without extra funding. 'Apart from the work under way at Leeds station,' he said, 'the rest of East Coast is not a committed scheme. It is in the balance.'

The admission will infuriate the Government and makes last week's row about the East Coast - provoked when Railtrack's initial estimate of £1.9bn for the work soared to between £2.5bn and £3.8bn - seem almost academic.

Nigel Davies, transport analyst at stockbroker WestLB Panmure, said the City believed Railtrack's share price, which closed down 60p on the week at 949p, was surviving at its current level only on the assumption that the Treasury was going to inject rescue cash.

There is pressure on Railtrack to appoint a new, Government-approved executive chairman to take control of the company from Marshall.

If the company cannot achieve a bail-out by the end of March, it will turn to rail regulator Tom Winsor for an emergency financial review. Marshall insisted this weekend that his finance team was 'still working with the SRA', but admitted he was talking to the Government.

The train operator source said: 'Railtrack have had discussions with Treasury about extra money, but it cannot be counted as part of the SRA budget. They have had a chat with Morton but the door remains closed.'

The SRA had been due to feed £4.5bn of government grants to Railtrack over the next five years. But now the company wants it all to be handed over in the next three years to ensure it can perform basic maintenance and complete projects without being crippled by debt and losing its 'single A' credit rating.

The source said: 'At the moment neither the Treasury nor Morton is prepared to give handouts to the Railtrack management.'

Morton has already decided to strip Railtrack of monopoly control of new projects to expand the network.

webTitle: Lloyds set to up its Abbey offer

fields.headline: Lloyds set to up its Abbey offer
fields.trailText: Lloyds TSB will increase the cash element of its £19 billion bid for Abbey National by around 10 per cent if it escapes a reference to the Competition Commission. But there are growing signs that Bank of Scotland could walk away even if Lloyds' offer is referred.
fields.body:
Lloyds TSB will increase the cash element of its £19 billion bid for Abbey National by around 10 per cent if it escapes a reference to the Competition Commission. But there are growing signs that Bank of Scotland could walk away even if Lloyds' offer is referred.

Lloyds is currently offering 260p in cash and 1.5 of its shares which, following the sharp drop in its shares after it announced its results on Friday, values each Abbey share at 1,281p. Sources close to the Lloyds camp ruled out an increase in the total bid - that would probably wait until later in the timetable - but indicated that the cash element could be increased.

That would probably be funded through loan stock or other similar financial instruments.'Abbey needs a fig leaf to cover its embarrassment,' one observer said. 'That would provide it.'

Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers has until Friday to decide whether to refer the bid.

Observers are split over which way he will go. Some analysts think that the possibility of a May election makes a referral more likely, as the Government would not want a fierce row about job cuts during the campaign.

Other believe there is such strong evidence that competition in banking is squeezing margins and cutting market share - as demonstrated in results from both Lloyds and Abbey last week - that he will have to give Lloyds the green light.

Bank of Scotland has already indicated it will walk away if the Lloyds bid is cleared. There were indications this weekend, however, that it could decide against pressing ahead with the merger even if it is referred, if there is a realistic chance of Lloyds' bid being cleared following the inquiry.

'We would have to see what both Lloyds and the market's reaction is before deciding to go ahead,' said a Bank of Scotland source. 'For example, if Byers said it was finely balanced and after much thought, he had decided on a reference, that would keep Lloyds in the frame. But if it was a categorical referral, with absolutely clear-cut competition issues, Lloyds could decide that the probability of success made it not worth pursuing, or the market might think it had no chance anyway.'

That is tacit recognition that most Abbey shareholders would prefer a Lloyds bid, which gives them some cash, to an agreed merger with Bank of Scotland. If there is the prospect that Lloyds could be cleared to bid following an inquiry, most shareholders would prefer to wait for it to be completed before making a decision.

fields.headline: Cammell seeks French lifeline
fields.trailText: Shipbuilder Cammell Laird and new cruise line Luxus have applied for aid from the French government to seal a $500m contract for two new ships. The two are already in talks with the British government for a similar aid package but a deal with the French would mean the ships were built there - and British jobs lost.
fields.body:
Shipbuilder Cammell Laird and new cruise line Luxus have applied for aid from the French government to seal a $500m contract for two new ships. The two are already in talks with the British government for a similar aid package but a deal with the French would mean the ships were built there - and British jobs lost.

The news puts political pressure on the Department of Trade and Industry days before it is due to make a final offer to Cammell and Luxus, who need an aid and loan guarantee package in order to get commercial backing for the deal.

If the DTI offer does not add up, there will be dismay among unions and workers on Merseyside and in the North East. Cammell Laird recently laid off 440 people and warned that 1,500 jobs would be at risk if the two 28,000-tonne Luxus ships were to be built overseas.

Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers approved a package of Shipbuilding Intervention Fund aid and mortgage guarantees on the project before Christmas, but sources close to Luxus and Cammell Laird say the initial terms were not bankable.

They are awaiting new proposals, but have drawn up plans under which Cammell Laird would act as project manager for the bulk of the work in France. The majority of construction would take place at the St Nazaire yards of French builder Chantiers d'Atlantique, with further work at yards Cammell Laird operates in Marseilles.

Sources close to the companies said that during 'interim' negotiations with the French, government officials had been positive about aid from France's intervention fund for up to 9 per cent of the contract's worth, plus mortgage guarantees covering up to $300 million. Intervention funds were allowable under EU rules only until December last year, but the application was made before the deadline.

Cammell and Luxus met DTI officials last week to put the finishing touches to negotiations over the British government's revised offer. Sources close to the company say that of the $500m total cost, $450m would come from Luxus's bankers, with $150m unsecured and $300m secured by the Government's mortgage guarantee. Around $40m would be intervention funding. Further negotiations are needed over provisions for working capital.

But the key sticking point is that the Government will not give a mortgage guarantee without Cammell raising a performance bond. This would partially indemnify the Government if Cammell failed to fulfill the contract.

The Government initially asked for $250m; Cammell said a figure nearer to $50m was more realistic. It is now a question off how low the Government is prepared to go.

webTitle: Nice day for a Welsh wedding

fields.headline: Nice day for a Welsh wedding
fields.standfirst: Figaro's wedding can seem awfully long-winded when done badly but WNO gets us to the church on time
fields.trailText:
Marriage of Figaro Welsh National Opera, New Theatre, Cardiff
Marcus Ullman Wigmore Hall, London W1
fields.body:
Marriage of Figaro Welsh National Opera, New Theatre, Cardiff
Marcus Ullman Wigmore Hall, London W1

It had all the makings of a gruesome evening. Count Almaviva strode in, hair flowing and torso bared, like Samson ready to tear down the gates of Gaza rather than merely to have his seigneurial way with his wife's maid (though since we learned this week that the Hebrew hero suffered from a severe personality disorder, the reference may have been more apt than it appeared).

Cherubino, the rutting teenage page, gyrated strangely against an ironing board and the dribbling, stuttering lawyer Don Curzio (a brilliant Robert Tear) flashed around in a high-tech wheelchair.

Most of Act I seemed to take place inside a cave made of brown tissue paper. The Countess's bed-chamber, in shades of marzipan, would have looked good in the Kingdom of Sweets. The grand salon in which Figaro and Susanna marry was more Hall of the Mountain King than stately home.

None of this much mattered in WNO's new Marriage of Figaro. It would be easy to be distracted by irksome detail and overlook the energy of the enterprise. Audiences (do I mean critics?) are more than usually proprietorial about Figaro. They are discomforted by solecism more acutely than any princess by a pea. Prized above all others as the 'perfect opera', this work is nevertheless rarely endowed with a perfect production.

How can it be? All have their own ideas about how it should look and the degree to which tragedy and comedy, politics and class, love and lust should be stressed or muted. We pounce on the merest hint of deviation: excessive prettiness or levity is judged superficial in a work harried with pain. Robustness and vulgarity, of which there is plenty - overtly in Da Ponte's libretto, implicitly in Mozart's music - must be reined in for fear of trampling on grace and beauty.

But for Mozart the beauty is used to manipulate us and the grace to seduce. Artfulness is evident in every bar. What seems is never what is. In their third act duet, the Count expresses his ardour with mock-melodramatic anguish; Susanna, the object of his desire, replies in music of simple, almost commonplace charm. He thinks he is in control. We know she is. He puffs up his power and influence; she deflates that same vanity and ego in answering phrase. The score tells us everything we need to know. Fresh truths are revealed with each hearing. Badly done, however, it can feel one of the longest operas ever written.

This was not so in Cardiff. The evening raced along, some oddly slow tempos notwithstanding. The second-night audience responded warmly to the comedy with ready laughter. Some of the action was clumsy, or occasionally gross, but musical standards were high, with the WNO orchestra showing verve despite fluffs, and the singers well matched.

An important feature of Mozart's operas is that he uses voices as part of an ensemble rather than as vehicles for virtuosity. Singers and orchestra are equal partners as they never were in Baroque opera, where the chief task of instruments was to accompany. The conductor, Rinaldo Alessandrini, who made this point in a programme note, brought out the orchestral polyphony and counterpoint to vigorous effect. The woodwind, especially, had all the potency and harmonic pulling power of a late Mozart symphony or piano concerto; we may have heard it all before, but have we noticed?

The production, designed by Dale Ferguson and directed by Neil Armfield, opted for a murky, oppressive look, costumes and sets suggesting an air of decay, the result not of dissipation but of vitality. The Count's abode was only too lived-in, his household bustling with Hogarthian life. Susanna (a bright, crisp Nuccia Focile) had shrewish charm. Nicola Ulivieri's Figaro was both sanguine and quick-witted, Cherubino (Imelda Drumm) engagingly gawky. Instead of the usual steely opulence, Geraldine McGreevey's Countess wore an air of passive expectation; if this reduced her as a character, it gave her perversely even more credibility as the spurned wife. The baritone, Gidon Saks, a towering figure with a sumptuous dark voice, had potent stage presence as the Count. Next week Birmingham, then on tour.

Schubert, despite efforts at the real thing, found his true operatic skills in writing songs, each one a drama in miniature depicting a world, a mood, a situation. His 1823 song-cycle Die Schöne Müllerin (The Fair Maid of the Mill), at first glance, appears a charming pastoral collection about nature and love.

Hidden within is an agonising saga of rejection and suicide, expressed in some of the most bleakly melancholy music ever written. The young German tenor, Marcus Ullman, preceded by a louder than usual fanfare of pre-publicity, was ensured a full house for his London debut. An attentive Wigmore Hall audience called him (and his pianist Alexander Schmalcz) back four times for applause.

Deft though his handling was, with an effective change of timbre for the urgent, angry songs mid-cycle, Ullman has far to go before achieving the intensity and variety of a really great Lieder singer - Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau in the past, Ian Bostridge now.

The advance praise may have been a little premature. He struggled audibly for the high notes, straining rather than floating and often at the expense of intonation. Schubert's songs have infinite meaning. The circumstances of their composition (he was being treated for syphilis at the time) add to their poignancy.

If the singing sounds effortful, this other worldiness is lost. Bostridge performs the same cycle next month. It's sold out of course, but you could always hang around outside with a plaintive look, or a cosh.

fields.headline: Who's a pretty Polly?
fields.standfirst: PJ Harvey takes to the stage with a sexy enthusiasm even Tina Turner would admire
fields.trailText: PJ Harvey Shepherd's Bush Empire, London W12
fields.body:
PJ Harvey Shepherd's Bush Empire, London W12

'At least say hello, Polly,' shouts someone about 15 minutes into PJ Harvey's electrifying set. Harvey stops, smiles and approaches the microphone. 'Hello.' Pause. 'It's great to be back in London and thank you all very much for coming.' The charmingly corrected omission is the only thing so far to give tonight's crowd cause to feel short-changed.

She had signalled her intent right from the start, strolling on to stage and launching into 'Rid of Me', her uncompromising song about being dumped. It was a sensational start. She stood rigid, square-shouldered, strumming energetically and belting out the lyrics without restraint. She ended the song with the a cappella proclamation: 'Lick my legs, I'm on fire' to the whoops of the crowd. This was Polly of old: defiant, punky and passionate. When she sings like this her angst and rage are indistinguishable. It's an opening that leaves you breathless with its emotional immediacy: the rest of the show has a lot to live up to.

With the release last year of her swaggering, catchy New York-influenced album Stories From the City, Stories From the Sea, a new, lighter Polly emerged. The familiar themes of lost love, degradation, anguish, were largely absent, prompting speculation that the singer had set sail on a new course. Well, up to a point. Tonight's confident performance is an exercise in the potency of an artist enjoying a purple patch. Although her last album was her most commercial to date, it was also a risk for the Mercury Music Prize shortlist perennial with a loyal and discerning fanbase.

Old-school Polly fans I spoke to before the gig liked the last record but admitted they 'preferred the old stuff'. It wasn't quite the same as Dylan plugging his guitar into an amp and embracing heresy but Harvey had got something to prove. Looking around, her fans, who on tonight's evidence range from casual-clad dad-rockers to hip twentysomethings, clearly want to be impressed.

Her slight figure commands the stage, especially when she is still. Her unique voice, sometimes stentorian, sometimes coquettish, rises above the competing guitars, reaching parts other singers can't. At times there are three loud guitarists, including Harvey, firing off low riffs and jangling chords in glorious tandem, but Polly's larynx rules. Her versatile band even play musical chairs, swapping instruments and stage positions. There are two guitars, two keyboards and drums for the ethereal 'A Place Called Home', while there is a compact drums, bass, guitar combo for 'Dry'.

The changes lend the show an unmistakable element of theatre; this is a performance rather than a gig. The crowd respond with head-nodding appreciation for all but a couple of the more up-tempo songs. For all the energy on stage, however, there is something that doesn't quite transfer to the audience; perhaps it's just a bit too calculated. The show has certainly been well staged. The band are mostly clad in black, while Harvey favours a clinging scarlet dress with matching heels. The contradiction between her slick guise and her music is intentional and effective. It's an outfit that draws intermittent lascivious comments from male punters which Harvey chooses to ignore. Her sex appeal is obvious: uncompromising, fervent, unpredictable and slightly aloof. She is the poster girl for the thinking music fan. You can say 'Phwoar' at Polly and no one will mistake you for a refugee from a Jennifer Lopez concert. Her new image is certainly more sophisticated than the shocking pink catsuit she wore onstage a few years back.

The sanguine songs from her latest album dominate the set. After 'Rid of Me', she goes into the compelling and melodic 'This Is Love' and follows it with the jaunty 'Good Fortune', which fuses a Patti Smith lick with Chrissie Hynde's attitude. The lyrics sparkle with optimism: 'And I feel like some bird of paradise/ My bad fortune slipping away/ And I feel the innocence of a child/ Everybody's got something good to say.' Even though this isn't a new song, it's strange to watch her sing these lyrics while tottering around the stage with an enthusiasm Tina Turner would admire.

Favourite songs from Stories are lifted when performed live. 'Kamikaze' builds to a marvellous, noisy crescendo before it ends abruptly and the audience lets out a collective breath. The album's opener, 'Big Exit', is an incendiary showstopper: 'I wanna pistol/ I wanna gun/ I'm scared baby/ I wanna run,' yells Harvey.

Polly purists would have been heartened by 'Man Size' and 'Send His Love To Me', which boasts spiralling Celtic-style guitars to match Harvey's romantic pleading. The crowd greet the sombre 'Angelene' like an old favourite and are rewarded with a beautiful rendition.

Unfortunately, Thom Yorke does not make an appearance for the encore, 'The Mess We're In', the haunting track on which he guested last year. Instead Harvey takes up the vocal duties and the results are mixed. Her low voice can't match Yorke's delicate quality and the impact of the surreal lyrics is diminished.

So the night ends on an ambiguous note. But Polly has appeased the faithful and impressed the rest. It's difficult to imagine there will be many better gigs in the coming months than her masterful performance tonight. She exits tired and emotional, and we do too.

Old-school Polly fans I spoke to before the gig liked the last record but admitted they 'preferred the old stuff'. It wasn't quite the same as Dylan plugging his guitar into an amp and embracing heresy but Harvey had got something to prove. Looking around, her fans, who on tonight's evidence range from casual-clad dad-rockers to hip twentysomethings, clearly want to be impressed. Her slight figure commands the stage, especially when she is still. Her unique voice, sometimes stentorian, sometimes coquettish, rises above the competing guitars, reaching parts other singers can't. At times there are three loud guitarists, including Harvey, firing off low riffs and jangling chords in glorious tandem, but Polly's larynx rules. Her versatile band even play musical chairs, swapping instruments and stage positions. There are two guitars, two keyboards and drums for the ethereal 'A Place Called Home', while there is a compact drums, bass, guitar combo for 'Dry'. The changes lend the show an unmistakable element of theatre; this is a performance rather than a gig. The crowd respond with head-nodding appreciation for all but a couple of the more up-tempo songs. For all the energy on stage, however, there is something that doesn't quite transfer to the audience; perhaps it's just a bit too calculated. The show has certainly been well staged. The band are mostly clad in black, while Harvey favours a clinging scarlet dress with matching heels. The contradiction between her slick guise and her music is intentional and effective. It's an outfit that draws intermittent lascivious comments from male punters which Harvey chooses to ignore. Her sex appeal is obvious: uncompromising, fervent, unpredictable and slightly aloof. She is the poster girl for the thinking music fan. You can say 'Phwoar' at Polly and no one will mistake you for a refugee from a Jennifer Lopez concert. Her new image is certainly more sophisticated than the shocking pink catsuit she wore onstage a few years back. The sanguine songs from her latest album dominate the set. After 'Rid of Me', she goes into the compelling and melodic 'This Is Love' and follows it with the jaunty 'Good Fortune', which fuses a Patti Smith lick with Chrissie Hynde's attitude. The lyrics sparkle with optimism: 'And I feel like some bird of paradise/ My bad fortune slipping away/ And I feel the innocence of a child/ Everybody's got something good to say.' Even though this isn't a new song, it's strange to watch her sing these lyrics while tottering around the stage with an enthusiasm Tina Turner would admire. Favourite songs from Stories are lifted when performed live. 'Kamikaze' builds to a marvellous, noisy crescendo before it ends abruptly and the audience lets out a collective breath. The album's opener, 'Big Exit', is an incendiary showstopper: 'I wanna pistol/ I wanna gun/ I'm scared baby/ I wanna run,' yells Harvey. Polly purists would have been heartened by 'Man Size' and 'Send His Love To Me', which boasts spiralling Celtic-style guitars to match Harvey's romantic pleading. The crowd greet the sombre 'Angelene' like an old favourite and are rewarded with a beautiful rendition. Unfortunately, Thom Yorke does not make an appearance for the encore, 'The Mess We're In', the haunting track on which he guested last year. Instead Harvey takes up the vocal duties and the results are mixed. Her low voice can't match Yorke's delicate quality and the impact of the surreal lyrics is diminished. So the night ends on an ambiguous note. But Polly has appeased the faithful and impressed the rest. It's difficult to imagine there will be many better gigs in the coming months than her masterful performance tonight. She exits tired and emotional, and we do too.

fields.headline: Tamara booms today
fields.trailText:
Romeo and Juliet, La Fille mal gardée Royal Opera House, London WC2
Mark Baldwin Dance Company Wycombe Swan, High Wycombe, touring to April
fields.body:
Romeo and Juliet, La Fille mal gardée Royal Opera House, London WC2
Mark Baldwin Dance Company Wycombe Swan, High Wycombe, touring to April

Tamara Rojo's doom-eager Juliet transforms Kenneth MacMillan's ballet into 'Juliet and Romeo'. At her Royal Ballet debut on Thursday, Inaki Urlezaga's Romeo was simply the catalyst who sets the tragedy in train. We mourned the wastage of love: she should never have thrown herself away on him; he shouldn't have been there in the first place.

Rojo has already danced Cranko's version of Romeo and Juliet with Scottish Ballet, as well as Derek Deane's arena production in the Royal Albert Hall.

Her body now contains her foreknowledge of Juliet's fate, so that even as she takes her first steps in the ballroom scene, the premonition of death is present, as it is in the music. Unlike Sylvie Guillem, Rojo does not impose her interpretation on the choreography; she lets it speak through her, so that she is both MacMillan's creature and her own.

She starts out headstrong, an overwrought girl whose slender, craning neck reveals her passionate curiosity about Romeo, the interloper at her coming-out ball. We see him through her eyes, a young man dancing his heart out. Without her in the second act, he is a cypher, lost in the crowd. She drives the story, taking the burden of Verona's tribal hatreds on her fledgling shoulders. Rojo's Juliet is one of MacMillan's deeply damaged heroines, who conveys her pain visibly as though she had been flayed.

The ballet's narrowing focus in the last act accentuates her loneliness. She becomes a pale flame in the darkness surrounding her, fighting extinction. Her fury at discovering Romeo's still-warm body is a flare-up of rage at the universe. The searing final image is rightly hers, body arched heart-upwards over the tomb slab, Romeo lost in the gloom.

Ashton's sunny La Fille mal gardée is running in tandem with MacMillan's tragedy, an antidote to Juliet's bitter potion. Ethan Stiefel has arrived from the United States to partner Sarah Wildor (their last performance this Wednesday) as well as being seen on screen in Nicholas Hytner's film, Centre Stage.

Stiefel is a bright spark, as cheery as his yellow breeches. His midwestern Colas strides into the French farmyard, twirling a ribbon instead of a lariat. He knows all about impersonating a high-stepping pony to entertain his girlfriend, Lise. But their attempt at making a cat's cradle with the ribbon was a trick too far at his matinée debut. Wildor's Lise is sweetly, soppily in love with him, though she can be as mischievous as he. Stiefel dances with the extra clarity an American training provides, pinging off the stage as though bouncing on a trampoline. He and Wildor, well matched, are so frank in their feelings that Ashton's open positions for the rural lovers, arms and legs flung wide, read like XXXs for Valentine's Day kisses.

Mark Baldwin has taken on the Orpheus and Eurydice myth for his new work, The Bird Sings With its Fingers . It is to a commissioned score by Julian Anderson, played on Radio 3 as the ballet premiered on tour. Baldwin's triple bill is a collaboration with the 35-piece Sinfonia 21 orchestra, aiming to bring modern dance and music audiences together for a concert on equal terms.

The music dominates, though, for a mere seven dancers cannot meet the demands of the big, intricate scores Baldwin has chosen. Anderson's music is so concentrated that the 15-minute piece seems to be imploding, sucking its material into the black hole of the underworld.

Baldwin counters by dressing his cast in white, placing them in an ashen limbo. Although the characters are not identified, Kate Coyne is Death and Laurent Cavanna Orpheus, defying her over the body of Sarah Worsop's tender Eurydice. Elusive as mercury, echoes of Cocteau's Orpheus films haunt the music and dance. We need time to tease out the references, rehear the score; a second or third encounter should be more enlightening.

The rest of the programme, set to Stravinsky's Danses Concertantes and Louis Andriessen's De Staat, is far more stimulating to the ears than the eyes. Baldwin's choreography recedes into background dancing, the visual equivalent of Muzak.

webTitle: This is primordial London calling, where no building lasts forever

fields.headline: This is primordial London calling, where no building lasts forever
fields.standfirst: The past is oozing to the surface as drills demolish City blocks of the 1970s
fields.trailText: 88 Wood Street and 100 Wood Street London EC2
fields.body:
88 Wood Street and 100 Wood Street London EC2

Sudden death by demolition is claiming an entire generation of buildings in the City of London, thrown up in the 1970s when development was a crude hit-and-run business. The air is full of hammering pneumatic drills and swinging cranes. Block upon block has been cleared and fenced off, making the Square Mile look like a mouthful of hollowed-out molars in the midst of a prolonged and painful bout of dentistry.

Profoundly unmemorable though the vanished buildings were, they nevertheless leave behind a strange, dislocating sense of loss. We can't remember ever having looked at them, but now that they have gone we know we will never get the chance again. Even more disturbing is the sense that the fragile surface order of urban life has been fractured, allowing the past to ooze up through the cracks, dragging London back to its primordial state when it was still a series of gravel outcrops in the Thames.

The City is literally dissolving into a sea of mud, as earth-moving monsters grasp the flimsy aluminium and glass façades of the Seventies in their claws, leaving brittle fragments of crumbling masonry.

Architecture comes and goes all the time, but streets last a little longer. They survive to provide the urban DNA for the City to rebuild itself. Take Wood Street, for example, just emerging from its latest architectural make over. There is no better place to understand the history of postwar British architecture and the way in which one generation has reacted against the next.

It was originally created by the Romans as a parade ground for a fort just outside the city wall. In the course of just 50 yards, it boasts a tower designed by Christopher Wren, the last surviving relic of a church that started out as the royal chapel of the Saxon kings. There is a remarkable police station built in the early Sixties by McMorran and Whitby, in dignified classical style. A Terry Farrell art deco-on-steroids high-rise from the Eighties rears over the street at one end, looking as cheerfully embarrassing as Abba's satin flares. Now there is Richard Rogers's office block (No 88), occupied last year, and, immediately next door, Norman Foster has just finished a block of financial trading rooms (No 100).

Look at these buildings in Wood Street and you can see with startling clarity exactly how much two architects who began their careers together have diverged. Foster's building looks as if he is trying to challenge the sneaking suspicion that after the genius of such early buildings as the Hong Kong and Shanghai Bank tower, he is now content to operate the controls of a giant architectural machine that churns out a seemingly endless stream of well-bred but formulaic buildings. The Wood Street building explores new territory for Foster. It has a Portland stone façade, with a deliberately dumb, chequer-board rhythm of alternating storey-height stone panels and glass windows, that shift back and forth, one bay at a time on each level. It is a mannerism calculated to show that this is a building that does not share the sensibility of its more conventional stone-clad neighbour, which plays by the rules. To underscore the point, Foster has put a vertical black line to cut himself off from that building. He does not touch Rogers, his other neighbour, at all.

On the other side of the air gap, Rogers is sticking to what his office does best - romantic modernity. By pulling the structure, stairs and lifts out of the basic envelope, he creates a jagged, picturesque skyline. The piece closest to Foster is wall-to-wall glass, in an elegant concrete frame that is braced by gunmetal grey and stainless steel rods .

Round the corner, there is some muscular exposed cross-bracing, beautifully rendered in stainless steel that has the delicacy of jewellery. There is even a touching little cabbage patch of sprouting red and blue funnels to remind us that this is the work of the firm that built the Pompidou Centre. This being a Rogers building, the cascades of steel stairs like streamers inside are painted bright yellow.

We talk about buildings as if they were individual works of art, to be understood as discrete aesthetic experiences. But in a dense city like London, they can't exist in isolation. They are inevitably seen as part of a street or in the context of one street interacting with another.

We see buildings as the product of chance visual juxtapositions and accidental oblique views, built layer upon layer, that shape the way that buildings are actually experienced much more than the architect's original vision.

Last year, Wood Street still backed on to a tight little alley, squashed between a City livery hall and the graveyard of a lost church. But that tight, intimate space has disappeared now, exploded temporarily by the rebuilding of the City. And the junction of Foster's and Rogers's buildings is on centre stage, visible in long views as well as close up.

Unlike his stone front to Wood Street, at the back of the building, Foster has scooped out a curved glass skin, hoisted up on a colonnade of raked steel legs. And for all its lack of formal acknowledgment to Rogers's building next door, the clearest image it leaves behind is the reflection of the shiny steel skin next door. It's a mirror just waiting to reflect the next newcomer to take its place in the City, and revealing just how brittle and impermanent even the glossiest of new architecture can be.
