webTitle: What am I bid for these grubby little urchins?

fields.headline: What am I bid for these grubby little urchins?
fields.standfirst: The object of veneration and then vilification, Murillo is once again the subject of critical evaluation
fields.trailText: Murillo: Scenes of Childhood Dulwich Picture Gallery, London SE21 until 13 May
fields.body:
Murillo: Scenes of Childhood Dulwich Picture Gallery, London SE21 until 13 May

Some shows aim to change your picture of an artist. Others succeed - and Murillo: Scenes of Childhood is among them. This is no small feat when you consider that Murillo has been out of fashion for more than a century. Hazlitt thought him 'the triumph... almost of art', but that was in pre-Victorian times, when Murillo got a great press. For the last 100 years or so, he has been routinely spurned as a painter of fondant cherubs, soft-focus saints and unfeasibly cheerful urchins.

The reversal was sudden and hard. Born in 1617, Murillo was the leading Sevillian artist of the seventeenth century. He was bigger than Zurbarán, more successful than Velázquez, and prized above both on the international market. Eighty years after his death, the Spanish government had to impose an export ban to stop Murillos flooding out of the country. Gainsborough owned and loved his work; Tennyson and Browning swooned before it. Painters from Chardin to Picasso studied his art; scratch more than one Manet and traces of Murillo will emerge.

Then, just around the time his paintings were fetching record-breaking prices, Ruskin launched an apoplectic attack in front of some Murillos at the Dulwich Picture Gallery, declaring that they should be torched. He despised the 'vicious slurrings and softness' of his devotional art almost as much as he loathed the urchins' dirt-caked feet.

From then on, the hostility ran to free-range contradiction: Murillo was too sentimental, too realistic, too graceful or grimy, too secular or nothing but a propagandist for the Catholic church. Which is where most people happen upon his art today, reduced to the size of a prayer card.

After all that, it comes as quite a surprise to stand where Ruskin once stood and find the view so unimposing and mild. Dulwich owns three Murillos: two groups of ragged kids and a Virgin and Child that seems to have been worked in tinted Vaseline. Though the gallery doubtless loves them as much as Hazlitt did, they represent the tail end of Murillo's career, when his pictures were flaccid, illogical or hard to read; who knows exactly what those children are playing at?

You aren't asked to worry about that if you visit this show because those paintings are left to fend for themselves in the main collection. Instead, the gallery has borrowed 20 other Murillos and hung them beautifully, in intimate little rooms next to pictures by his Spanish contemporaries. Right away, you see how innovative he was in an early picture on loan from the Louvre, in which a boy with a crew cut and tattered rags sits in the ruins of a derelict building.

Murillo has taken something from Velázquez in the fine light that circles the rim of a water jug and the glinting prawn husks that litter the floor. But look at the dust on the soles of his feet - it's both ingrained and newly acquired - and you understand why Manet admired Murillo's singular 'studies in dirt'. Everything is empathetic to this boy's experience, from the awkward pose to the down-turned, introspective face. Even the hot light shafting through a broken window emphasises his isolation, alone and hidden on a summer day.

This is not a generalised illustration of poverty, but a study of one particular child. He went on to paint more ingratiating pictures, in which urchins seem to have been hired to smile at the viewer or chuckle sweetly at the antics of dogs. He understood something about children away from parents, having been an orphan himself. But it's only when he bypasses the grown-ups - his patrons - that this knowledge comes into effect.

Take the two boys stuffing their faces with fruit in some rocky landscape outside the city. They are surrounded by the battered and spent: junked rinds, scattered seeds, frayed rags, broken wicker. If you want poverty, it's there in every patch of the canvas. But it's immaterial to the central image, namely, the way children like to keep a beady eye on each other while eating, partly because it's funny, but also out of sheer fascination to see their own actions reproduced in copycat.

This painting just doesn't square with the notion of Murillo as all schmaltz. Nor do the two really startling pictures in this show, both on loan from America. In The Galicians, two women are looking out of a large open window. One has settled into position, leaning over the sill. The other is just arriving from the dark interior of the room. That they're fixed on you is not in doubt; the beautiful girl at the sill offers her most winning gaze, while the older woman clutches a coy veil to her laughing mouth. It's a marvellous image: soft light playing over the girl's glowing skin, pale bodice and scarlet ribbons, and reaching just far enough into the room to illuminate the veil before vanishing into deep shadow.

You can see why the curators find echoes of Velázquez, Goya and Manet here, from the interior space to the angled back of the shutters. But there's something unfamiliar and odd. Unlike the faces in portraits, these Galicians are doing all the looking: they aren't just returning your gaze.

Murillo takes this even further with Four Figures on a Step, a frankly alarming picture. Again, there's a double time scheme. The old woman on the right, her penetrating stare magnified behind massive spectacles, has clearly been there for a while, nursing an urchin's head in her lap. The dandy on the left has just rushed forward to thrust his opportunistic mug in your face, while the girl behind him has caught up only to discover that it's you again, if that's what her face-pulling registers.

The relationship between these people is completely enigmatic. Two of them also ignore the central child with the hole in his trouser-seat, unignorable from our point of view. But that's just it: we are strangely more intriguing than the child to them, at least for this passing moment.

Murillo's pictorial imagination proves wonderfully flexible, creating an equal tension between viewer and painted viewer. What's going on with these people is anyone's guess - and they seem to feel the same about you.

But it's immaterial to the central image, namely, the way children like to keep a beady eye on each other while eating, partly because it's funny, but also out of sheer fascination to see their own actions reproduced in copycat. This painting just doesn't square with the notion of Murillo as all schmaltz. Nor do the two really startling pictures in this show, both on loan from America. In The Galicians, two women are looking out of a large open window. One has settled into position, leaning over the sill. The other is just arriving from the dark interior of the room. That they're fixed on you is not in doubt; the beautiful girl at the sill offers her most winning gaze, while the older woman clutches a coy veil to her laughing mouth. It's a marvellous image: soft light playing over the girl's glowing skin, pale bodice and scarlet ribbons, and reaching just far enough into the room to illuminate the veil before vanishing into deep shadow. You can see why the curators find echoes of Velázquez, Goya and Manet here, from the interior space to the angled back of the shutters. But there's something unfamiliar and odd. Unlike the faces in portraits, these Galicians are doing all the looking: they aren't just returning your gaze. Murillo takes this even further with Four Figures on a Step, a frankly alarming picture. Again, there's a double time scheme. The old woman on the right, her penetrating stare magnified behind massive spectacles, has clearly been there for a while, nursing an urchin's head in her lap. The dandy on the left has just rushed forward to thrust his opportunistic mug in your face, while the girl behind him has caught up only to discover that it's you again, if that's what her face-pulling registers. The relationship between these people is completely enigmatic. Two of them also ignore the central child with the hole in his trouser-seat, unignorable from our point of view. But that's just it: we are strangely more intriguing than the child to them, at least for this passing moment. Murillo's pictorial imagination proves wonderfully flexible, creating an equal tension between viewer and painted viewer. What's going on with these people is anyone's guess - and they seem to feel the same about you.

fields.headline: You should see her Brünnhilde
fields.standfirst: ... not to mention her Turandot, revealed to long-deprived British fans this week. But far from acting the diva offstage, Jane Eaglen is a regular Lincoln lass. And, no, she didn't do Don Giovanni without knickers
fields.trailText: ... not to mention her Turandot, revealed to long-deprived British fans this week. But far from acting the diva offstage, Jane Eaglen is a regular Lincoln lass. And, no, she didn't do Don Giovanni without knickers
fields.body:
Usually Puccini's Turandot confronts you, like Hitchcock's Mrs Bates, at the top of a staircase, armed not with a knife but a lethal fusillade of high Cs, discharged to fend off importunate wooers. Jane Eaglen, who returns to the Royal Opera tomorrow to sing this killingly difficult role, also awaited me on the stairs. Puffing up to the third floor in a London mansion block, I heard her clearing her throat somewhere above, and wondered what to expect.

Instead of Puccini's man-eater, I found a jolly, welcoming and resplendently plump young woman. 'I should,' she admitted, 'be chopping off the Prince of Persia's head round about now.' That is Turandot's first action in the opera, achieved by silently giving her spurned suitor the thumbs down; but Eaglen, with nothing to sing in this scene, had been excused from the morning's rehearsal. Rather than indulging in a spot of decapitation, she made me a cup of coffee.

Eaglen last sang with the Royal Opera in 1992. For the rest of the decade the management ignored her, despite her successes in roles as testing as Bellini's Norma in Ravenna and New York, Weber's Rezia in Oberon in Salzburg, and Wagner's Brünnhilde and Isolde at the Metropolitan Opera. In 1989 the Royal Opera had asked her to understudy the chronically capricious Margaret Price in Norma . 'First she didn't want to rehearse with the chorus. Then some days she wouldn't come in at all, so I did more and more of the preparation. Finally it opened, and she cancelled one performance. Twice during the day they told me I was going on, but meanwhile they were trying to find someone who could fly in to save the show. John Pritchard, who was conducting, thought I wouldn't have the constitution or the nerves to do it. Was he wrong! Eventually in mid-afternoon they found a replacement in Germany, and sent me home. I was bitterly disappointed. But at least they gave me a bottle of champagne.' She nonchalantly shrugged off the memory of that particular rejection.

Born in Lincoln, Eaglen all the same feistily insists: 'I'm not an English singer.' By which she means she's not chaste and churchy-sounding. Since her marriage a year ago - to a fan she met at a Tower Records signing session - she has been based in Seattle, but her repatriation, at least partially, is under way. In September she even impersonated Britannia in a rollicking, coloratura-ridden self-parody at the Last Night of the Proms. The English National Opera is putting on Spontini's La Vestale - 'a mini-Norma ', she says, about a somewhat tainted Vestal virgin - for her next season, though after Turandot there are no more plans for Covent Garden: a rumoured Isolde has evaporated, and it saddens her that she won't have the chance to sing Wagner in England.

Even so, intending to spend more time here from now on, she has invested in a rowing machine, which sprawls expectantly on the floor inside the front door. I doubt whether it will get much use. Eaglen, who has a sound mind in a very sound body, takes a defiant pride in her size.

Her humour is earthy, her personality grounded, even though her job requires her to dress up as spear-wielding goddesses or as 'that ice cow princess' (which is how she describes Turandot). 'Opera is entertainment, it's not brain surgery,' she said to me. 'I had a working-class upbringing, and I'm proud of that too. We only got an inside toilet when I was about 10. My father worked in a steel foundry and ran the local soccer team. Perhaps that's why I'm such a sports fan. I'm crazy about baseball, and I can see a connection between hitting a home run and singing a high C: it's the same sort of achievement.

'I'm going up to Lincoln to fetch my mother down to see Turandot . She was 80 last week, and she's not too interested in opera, but luckily this one's short.'

Her mother, despite this indifference to opera, seems certain of a place in backstage lore. A while ago she travelled to New York to see her daughter in Turandot with Pavarotti. The night before, Eaglen prepped her by telling her the plot, and tried out on her the riddles with which Turandot lethally quizzes her suitors. One clue refers to 'a flame that is not a flame'. The answer, predictably enough, is love, but her mother, after a long period of cogitation, brightly asked 'Could it be mustard?' At the premiere, Pavarotti presented Eaglen with 10 pots of mustard. She doesn't even like the stuff, she told me, and gave it all away.

Strong-minded herself, she requires her characters to be so too. Singing Isolde, she relishes the sarcastic raillery with which she addresses Tristan. 'I love it when she says "And guess what, you killed my lover and sent me his head in a box. That was so nice of you!" Isn't that a great line?'

She has no regrets about bypassing the younger Wagner heroines - for instance the ardent Sieglinde, a rival to the war-like Brünnhilde in Die Walküre: 'She's a wimp. You want to give her a good slap when she starts with the hysterics. But funnily enough, it's always the soprano singing Sieglinde who has a limo waiting at the stage door. Poor old Brünnhilde just trudges to the corner and hails a cab.'

She also has doubts about the martyred heroines of Verdi. 'I'm not a simperer - though I am doing Aida soon, and she grovels a lot and apologises, which is not my line. She always seems to be kneeling. Well, I'm fit and supple, I can kneel - but should I?'

She will not, I predict, look very Ethiopian. 'The important thing,' she chuckled, 'is to make sure the costume has sleeves. Then you don't have to do much blacking-up!'

Eaglen has often been criticised for her immobility on stage. Dionysian frenzy is not an option for her; meeting her, you come to respect the monumental placidity of a woman who stands apart from the esoteric mania of her own artform. She is happy to be remembered in Lincoln as Ron Eaglen's daughter, and shakes her head over the besotted fans for whom opera resembles a religious cult. 'It's only around the Met that anyone recognises me in the street. Once I was getting money from a cash machine on Broadway, and I could sense these people hovering behind me. When I turned round, they gushed "Oh, we just loved your Isolde", but all I could think of was "Did they see my PIN number?" '

Like many singers, she whiles away the hours of solitary confinement in hotel rooms by idling through cyberspace, and is aghast at the 'evil energy' she finds in the chat rooms where the aficionados exchange tittle-tattle. 'They do write sick things about me sometimes, but I try not to take it seriously. There was a rumour circulating on the internet that I'd done a run of Don Giovanni performances without any underwear!'

She tried to look sternly disapproving, then burst into rorty laughter at the thought. But the libel reminded her of a Turandot in Bologna, when - after spending the first two acts riding on an elevator, with just her head peeping out into view through a metal globe - she was finally set free to walk around wearing a costume with a train which had 10 dancers hidden beneath it to make it move. 'So you had 10 Italians up your legs,' I commented. 'Was that fun?' 'Not really,' she said with a guffaw. 'It did get a bit ticklish!'

Turandot is a gelid monster, encased in ice; Jane Eaglen, I suspect, is a red-hot mama.

Turandot opens tomorrow and continues in rep until 19 March at the Royal Opera House, London WC2 (0207 304 4000)

fields.headline: Really losing the plot
fields.standfirst: The confusing world of directionless souls, asylum seekers and arranged marriages on Valentine's Day
fields.trailText:
Six Characters in Search of an Author Young Vic, London SE1
Credible Witness Jerwood Theatre Upstairs, Royal Court, London SW1
Fourteen Songs, Two Weddings and a Funeral Lyric Theatre Hammersmith, London W6
fields.body:
Six Characters in Search of an Author Young Vic, London SE1
Credible Witness Jerwood Theatre Upstairs, Royal Court, London SW1
Fourteen Songs, Two Weddings and a Funeral Lyric Theatre Hammersmith, London W6

Richard Jones's inspired production of Six Characters in Search of an Author left me feeling agitated yet vacant - like a room that has been suddenly cleared of people or an empty stage. You have been through it, the characters have been through it. But through what exactly?

Pirandello's teasing 1921 masterpiece begins with six characters turning up out of the blue, looking for an author. Nothing else in the play can compete with the moment of their arrival, beautifully refined here by Jones. A screen (upon whichslides on the life of Pirandello have just been shown) is slit down the middle and the characters step through it. They all wear black, in mourning for their lack of a life. They are almost comic, almost tragic. But, denied a decent plot, they can never convincingly be either. The characters break in on a group of actors and a director and thus begins a dazzling examination of what is meant by reality. Unsteadily, the realisation dawns: the characters' dilemma is not as different from our own as we might wish. Who is in charge of the plot of our lives?

Giles's Cadle's set is wonderful: the Young Vic has converted itself from the round to a proscenium stage (which is wide and long) and the audience is seated on pert red and gold ballroom chairs. Overhead hang two chandeliers (and even they behave unconventionally). I loved the symbolic opening: a projected black and white photograph of a writer's hands tapping on to an ancient typewriter before pulling out the page and screwing it up. There is a burst of opera, then nothing.

The father (Stephen Boxer) looks as though his features have set. He is a stickler for correctness: suffering, pedantic, not without desire. The mother (Yolanda Vasquez) maintains a tragic attitude throughout, to troubling effect. But it is the stepdaughter (Leah Muller) who is the energetic heart of the piece. She is like a giant child, with a slash of scarlet lipstick for a mouth - she could have escaped from a Paula Rego painting. She is tremendous. Her sexuality is free-range, underplotted, as if promiscuity came from a lack of narrative direction.

All the 'characters' frustrate and compel: they veer alarmingly between confession and sales pitch, trying to interest the director in their broken piece of story. The 'actors' have a satisfied, lofty look: they wear minks and netted, top-heavy hats. The leading lady (Liza Sadovy) kisses the air and looks pleased with life. The younger actress (Elizabeth Hopley) is flaxen, debonair: amusingly certain she can act her rivals off the stage. The hilarious stage manageress (Catherine Malone) runs around in an unproductive panic. The director (Darrel D'Silva) is desperate and it is hardly surprising he ends up with blood on his hands. But Jones and his cast come out smelling of roses.

The play that made Timberlake Wertenbaker's name, Our Country's Good (1989), was about convicts sent to a military settlement in Australia, in the late eighteenth century. Her new play, Credible Witness, is about modern-day asylum seekers in Britain. She has always been drawn to exile as a subject. But why has she herself been exiled to the theatre upstairs at the Royal Court when once she would have been on the main stage? It is a puzzle - for her play is something to write home about.

Olympia Dukakis gives a stupendous performance as Petra Karagy, the Macedonian mother who has flown to England to search for her son. She is absolutely convincing: it is as if she has strayed into the Royal Court, mistaking it for Heathrow. She is a mother to end all mothers, holding on to her history as tightly as her handbag. Wertenbaker asks: how much does history matter? Might it turn out to be excess baggage? But she will not permit herself the security of definitive answers.

The most powerful scenes are between Petra and Simon, a self-pitying immigration officer (skilfully played by Clive Merrison). He has acquired the official's habit of talking to other people as he were the only person in the room. But he is diminished by the astonishing Petra. Adam Kotz is marvellous as Petra's son, a teacher with ideals which do not suit his life in exile. The play has the balance it needs to contain its different elements, its refugees and their histories: Aziz from Algeria is wonderfully played by Anthony Barclay who makes his lunacy lively; Vincent Ebrahim's Shivan is impressive too and Ameena from Somalia (Leona Ekembe) is memorable as she breaks her own silence, reveals the cigarette burns on her body, and becomes the credible witness of the title.

I saw Fourteen Songs, Two Weddings and a Funeral on Valentine's Day. It was fun to reflect upon arranged marriages on a day when Cupid likes to do his worst, and the musical was greeted by the audience with rapture. Tamasha (the Asian theatre company) have based their drama on the Bollywood film Hum Aapke Hain Koun, about one arranged marriage and one misarranged one.

Mala Ghedia is delightful as Nisha, in a sparkling cardigan with character to match. She pretends to mock Prem (cheeky Pushpinder Chani). But no one is fooled. Meanwhile, Nisha's beautiful sister Pooja (Meneka Das) and Prem's relative Rajesh (Shammi Aulakh) are brought together. The awk wardness of their arranged union is nicely conveyed, a combination of bonhomie, bashfulness and hilarity.

The soundtrack is by the original 1998 cast, with the result that the actors sometimes look like enthusiastic goldfish, but nothing spoils the charm of the show. Indeed, the frisky vitality of Kristine Landon-Smith's production is such that when tragedy strikes and Pooja dies unexpectedly, plummeting down a flight of stairs, it is intensely funny, not least because she has just been singing a perky song called 'Here I go'...

Susannah Clapp is on holiday

webTitle: Cheap racial jibes are on the up even in your average comedy club

fields.headline: Cheap racial jibes are on the up even in your average comedy club
fields.trailText: 'Yiddo... Yiddo... ' This is what I hear regularly when I walk on stage. 'Yiddo... Yiddo' like I didn't already know. I haven't even opened my mouth but the crowd has spotted the profile and it's enough. Sometimes, the whole audience decides to join in. White liberals, lads from the suburbs, even black people. Other Jews aren't surprised. They never had any illusions about the British indeed it confirms their prejudices. 'People abusing you because you look Jewish? And your point is?'
fields.body:
'Yiddo... Yiddo... ' This is what I hear regularly when I walk on stage. 'Yiddo... Yiddo' like I didn't already know. I haven't even opened my mouth but the crowd has spotted the profile and it's enough. Sometimes, the whole audience decides to join in. White liberals, lads from the suburbs, even black people. Other Jews aren't surprised. They never had any illusions about the British indeed it confirms their prejudices. 'People abusing you because you look Jewish? And your point is?'

This is not me having an attack of artistic sensitivity. To give you some perspective, Trevor Nunn once said to Mark Lawson that 'luvvie' was as bad a term of abuse as 'yiddo' or 'nigger'. Now I know waiting on tables can be demeaning but hang on a minute. Trevor should've been at the Glee Club in Birmingham, when a drunken man blurted out stuff about Jews and ovens and gas. The red mist descended and I leapt off stage and dragged him out of the room. Not only was it a shock for him and the audience, I was a bit taken aback as well. At that moment I understood how Eric Cantona felt, although I know I didn't completely lose control. While I was dragging him out, I was holding a glass of red wine and kept saying to myself 'don't spill any of it on your suit'. Anyway, the bouncers pulled me off him, he was thrown out and it went no further. Except the next night, I was introduced with the theme from Rocky and the phrase 'let's get ready to rumble'.

Welcome to Britain in the new millennium. A Britain in which according to the Jewish Chronicle, racial attacks against Jews doubled last year, mainly because of the worsening conflict in the Middle East. (The election of Ariel Sharon should calm things down). And, although there are no published figures, I think the heckling's got worse as well.

Two weeks ago at the Comedy Store, I asked if anyone had ever been to India? An Indian man responded 'At least we spend money you tight Jew'. A heckler suggested I should tell the Indian man that his minicab was on fire. Very helpful. The doormen had a word and we never heard a peep out of them after that. I ignore most of the comments, often because it's difficult to locate the culprit.

Anonymity can make people ever so brave. Anyway, comedians say the most appalling things to hecklers so we should expect a fair bit of stick from them. I've had various missiles thrown at me including money, beer, beer cans, pies - both meat and mince - and a plastic goldfish. At a particularly sweaty gig, I was offered underarm deodorant by a man in the front row. A drunk man once threw up on my two-day-old suede shoes, and a woman took a swing at me because I called her a slapper (you have to believe me when I tell you it was in context). My favourite was a woman in Galway who put her hand up and asked whether I'd like a heckle. Well, it's nice to be given the choice.

This is all part of the cut and thrust of your average comedy club. I know things are said in the heat of the moment. Passions can run high after 17 pints of lager. But sometimes you start to wonder why things can get so vitriolic.

A fellow Jewish comic I know, who's never mentioned the fact that he's a Jew, was once told to 'Fuck off back to Golders Green'. Seven years later, when he talks about it, and he still does, a shadow passes across his face. And as for the Yiddo thing, do they just not like Jews? Is there an Aryan thing going on? Are they expressing their dislike of Israel's continued occupation of the West Bank by shouting Yiddo at me? Well, all I can say is I might be occupying centre stage but I haven't kicked an Arab comedian off there first. Or is it just the fact that they think I'm a Tottenham fan? How insulting is that? I'm Arsenal.

Ian Stone is appearing at the Manchester Comedy Store on Saturday and Sunday and at London's Comedy Store on 1, 2 and 3 March

fields.headline: Look, no parents...
fields.standfirst: Can't be fagged with the kids this half-term? Switch the TV on, they'll love you for it, says  Fiona Gibson
fields.trailText: Can't be fagged with the kids this half-term? Switch the TV on, they'll love you for it, says  Fiona Gibson
fields.body:
I never intended to use kids' TV in order to grab five minutes' peace. Oh, the odd documentary showing dinosaur bones being pieced together might just about be OK: but not any old twaddle. Not cartoons. Not grown-ups with over-enthusiastic eyebrows, bounding across vivid backdrops.

My twin sons, Sam and Dexter, (almost four) would do, not watch. I planned to be an active mother - cutting and sticking, fishing frog spawn out of the river. I would do things 'good' parents do. And I try. My children regularly spoon horrible pink goo into bun cases. Yet when I say, 'Boys, would you like to watch...' they drop their wooden spoons, charge towards the telly and sit a foot away from it, panting.

If this did not make me feel like a failing parent, I would happily plug them in and supply a stream of snacks. But you cannot help shifting uncomfortably when your child correctly identifies Downy in the supermarket and informs you, 'It stops clothes from creasing.'

'There is no doubt that Holly watches too much TV,' says Ellie Stott, from Solihull, West Midlands, of her seven-year-old daughter. 'Her class had been writing about themselves under the heading "My favourite thing". Other children had listed ballet, their kitten or playing football. Holly had written Sky TV.'

Stott says she is strict about what Holly watches - 'Disney videos over TV programmes' - but not how much. 'She watches a couple of hours a day. After school she wants to relax. It bothers me, but I do think how hypocritical I would be to insist that she spends all her time making clay models when, the minute I've put her to bed, I flop out in front of some vacuous docu-soap?'

Yet the current parenting mood is geared to make us feel wretched if we so much as fondle the remote control. As a new parent I devoured child-rearing manuals and faithfully obeyed suggestions to 'arrange a fresh array of objects to greet your child every time he wakes from his nap'. If our children do watch TV, we are advised to jam ourselves next to them and utterly ruin their enjoyment by babbling about what's happening on screen.

The language employed hardly implies that TV offers a worthwhile learning experience. We don't say: 'I am allowing my child valuable quiet time in order to enhance their understanding of form and content.' We say: 'I've plonked him in front of the telly. That'll shut him up for half an hour.'

To further fuel parental guilt, the American Academy of Pediatrics has published a policy paper urging parents to avoid television for children under two. It states: 'Research on early brain development shows that babies and toddlers have a critical need for direct interactions with parents... for healthy brain growth and the development of appropriate social, emotional and cognitive skills.'

This implies an all-or-nothing dilemma: spend 13 hours a day interacting madly, or permit round-the-clock Cartoon Network and live with the unsettling notion that you should probably never have had children. Anne Wood, creative director at Ragdoll Productions and creator of Teletubbies, Tots TV and Rosie and Jim, observes: 'It is often assumed that children are laboratory specimens that can be "plonked" in front of the TV. No child wants to watch TV 24 hours a day. They will do whatever interests them. But we need to accept that huge technological changes have redefined childhood; naturally, children need real experience but they are surrounded by the virtual world and need to play with that too.'

Madonna said recently that she does not allow her daughter Lourdes to watch TV because 'it's too passive'. Presumably Madonna has enough hands-on help to allow her the five minutes it takes to go to the bathroom without small people attempting to hammer down the door. Regular parents are more likely to experience a euphoric surge - not dissimilar to orgasm - on discovering that flickering, brightly-coloured images have the remarkable effect of keeping children silent and still.

You wouldn't do it - because you're too busy constructing a treehouse - but you could, should you so desire, tune into Nickelodeon and sneak off for a coffee/fag/fortnight in St Lucia, confident that your children will remain precisely where you left them.

'Adults need to get on with things,' says Dorothy Einon, childhood psychologist and author of Learning Early (Marshall). 'Sometimes you have to be first in the queue, and no parent should feel guilty about not playing directly with their child every minute of the day. TV has helped to make children a good deal more knowledgeable about the world beyond their street. It provides common ground, something to gossip about. Those "Did you see?" conversations spark off social activity and are, quite simply, fun.'

Gillian Grassy, a secondary school teacher from Edinburgh, says: 'Friends have pointed out that we might not be so strict about TV if we had more children. As it is, if Sam [five] has been good all week, he can watch a video on a Thursday night. I'm not keen on him seeing much more. I worry that TV overload makes children hyperactive or a bit flat. Some seem to have difficulty in filtering speech requiring action from general background chat.'

Grassy suspects that her own mother's attitudes helped shape her opinions. 'When I was a child, TV was strictly rationed. I would desperately want to watch Pan's People on Top of the Pops but my mother said it was lewd.'

As parents, we cannot help being influenced by nostalgia (Top Cat = good) and our unfamiliarity with modern, murkier 'action' cartoons (X-Men = bad). Research conducted by the Independent Television Commission says 'Some parents have registered their disquiet about material in modern cartoons that they perceive to be too violent, or sinister, or frightening for young children to watch.' The ITC has received complaints about computer-generated cartoon Reboot, in particular over a scene with a chainsaw, another in which a dog is shot, and the female character's scanty outfit. We are not talking Penelope Pitstop.

However, the research indicates that children make a clear distinction between 'toons' and 'action cartoons', generally finding 'toons' funny, easy to dip in and out of and far preferable to scarier action cartoons such as Spiderman and Street Sharks. The report concludes: 'Although television fills most of [children's] leisure time, computer and video games are also important, as is sport and children's own imaginary games. Television has to compete with children's other activities - it has to fit into their lives.'

And so we battle with parental guilt. We use TV as a bargain babysitter that won't drink our beer or snog boys on the sofa. But as soon as the credits roll, we leap up and announce 'All done', forcing our children to troop miserably back to their baking. When the kids protest, parents resort to devious measures: switching off at the socket and claiming, 'It's broken', or fibbing: 'Cartoons are only on at Granny's.'

As in most aspects of modern parenting, moderation appears to be the key. Einon recommends: 'Two hours a day but not at a stretch - an hour at a time should be the absolute max. Break it up with other activities.'

It still sounds a lot to me. I have a 'one hour per day' rule and my son Dexter has still developed an American accent. It doesn't appear to worry my partner. On Saturday mornings, when I am silently congratulating myself on all the outdoorsy things we've done that week, he - rather sensibly - bungs on CITV so we can read the papers. Wood points out: 'Women are obsessed with ideas of perfection in parenting. No father would feel guilty about not making cupcakes.'

I am aware that my strict rationing is more to do with my own neuroses than any real threat to my sons' development. Certain videos have undoubtedly enriched their imagination: a Peter Pan obsession inspired endless games of Indians, pirates and attempts to fly across their bedroom.

No parent wants their child to stare miserably at the ground as his friends chat excitedly about The Simpsons . I intend to stop harassing my children to play and learn. When they return from nursery tomorrow, I shall turn on, chill out and accept it's impossible to cram a child's every waking moment with drawing, painting and nature walks. They simply wouldn't stand for it.

What the kids like...

Sam 'I like making cakes sometimes but not much times. We made pretend soup and I didn't like the taste of it. I love watching programmes and videos. Can I watch a video now? Can I watch Wallace and Gromit? Hong Kong Phooey is my favourite. He wears a red dressing gown. I like funny programmes - Catch the Pigeon and Robin Hood video. The best thing I like to do is play football and play with my friends.'

Dexter 'I like playing the police game and Daddy is the baddie. I like drawing but not all day long. I love it when Mummy lets us watch TV. Cartoon Network I like. Scooby Doo is scary but I am brave, I love it. It is great at Rascals [their nursery] when we watch a video. But sometimes Daddy comes early to take us home and we can't watch the end of Fox and the Hound. That makes me upset.'

fields.headline: Going for broke
fields.standfirst: Michael Landy is destroying all his possessions - including clothes, photos and an archive of valuable art - in his new show. But, he tells  Gaby Wood,  the hardest bit will be shredding a sheepskin coat
fields.trailText: Michael Landy is destroying all his possessions - including clothes, photos and an archive of valuable art - in his new show. But, he tells  Gaby Wood,  the hardest bit will be shredding a sheepskin coat
fields.body:
Who is, or was, Michael Landy? He is a man who until last week possessed more art works than clothes, although he was also quite a dandy dresser. Many of the art works were his own, and some were by other young British artists: by his Turner prize-winning girlfriend Gillian Wearing, by Gary Hume, by Chris Ofili, Tracey Emin, Damien Hirst. He owned more than one Savile Row suit, some Patrick Cox shoes, and his underwear was Calvin Klein. He once lived, worked, or at least removed the locks from 7-9 Fashion Street in London's East End. Judging by the contents of his kitchen, he was a keen chef and, until last week, he still had a mincemeat grinder he inherited from his mother. He banks with NatWest. He sends his love letters by fax. He lost his mobile phone in Heathrow airport and stole a calculator from an art gallery. His social circle includes at least one minor royal and a number of artists, one of whose forgotten swimming trunks he never returned. He has travelled widely (Turkey, Ireland, Greece), but cannot now seem to find his passport. There is evidence to suggest that he reads The Observer and supports West Ham.

But now Michael Landy is a man who is destroying this evidence. You will find a record of it in an inventory he has made of every item he possesses. He has given each a number, bagged those that will fit in plastic, and pasted the inventory up on a wall in what used to be C&A on Oxford Street, near Marble Arch. All this week, you can go there and watch Landy dispose of his life. His car, his art archive, his family photographs - everything, as the windows of this very department store shouted only recently, must go.

Stretched out behind the big shop windows, between empty clothes racks and deserted escalators, is Landy's public art installation, entitled Breakdown. He has built a conveyor belt and designed it to look like a gigantic toy train set or futuristic factory. It is painted turquoise blue, laden with bright yellow plastic crates containing his things, and is operated by men and women wearing matching blue boiler suits. The same objects go round and round: a shredded pair of 'indestructible' Levi 501s, his father's sheepskin coat, which has remained untouched for days, a dissected rubber lobster with its echo of Salvador Dali. There is a bay for his Saab, another for large objects, a place to put his stereo and an alcove for weighing and logging every item.

There is a happy, Mike and the Mechanics sort of atmosphere. The music is his; it has been catalogued and will eventually go too. Huge machines drive the fantasy factory, which is based on material reclamation facilities - a shredder, a granulator and various drills. The aesthetic is one of manufacture but the activity is its opposite: these things are being sorted and taken apart. The whole effect is of a forensic investigation being conducted in an airport, except in this case the luggage is not being reclaimed but disclaimed. The new Michael Landy, it seems to be saying, will come with no baggage.

Landy's stated objective is to comment on consumerism, to show us how attached we are to our possessions and how we tend to define ourselves according to the stuff that surrounds us. Retail is even called therapy.

This installation, commissioned by Artangel, the organisation behind Rachel Whiteread's House, is closely related to many of his others. Closing Down Sale (1992) featured laminated signs that read 'Buy Now', 'Massive Clearance Sale', '£s off'. Scrapheap Services, which was bought by the Tate in 1996, was composed of a waste-disposal team clearing up heaps of little people cut out of branded packaging - Boddington's, Coca-Cola, KFC. Landy even designed a satirical logo to make anti-corporate culture-jammers proud: a 'Keep Britain Tidy' spoof in which the object being thrown into the rubbish bin is a tiny person. In 1997 he created the Tate Gallery's Christmas tree: a heap of mauled toys and gluttonous waste, a prediction of Boxing Day fall-out. So close to life has Landy's satire been that one exhibition was slightly scuppered when the gallery's cleaners took it to be rubbish and threw parts of it away. A spokesperson for the cleaning contractors at the time offered a sharp piece of art criticism along with her apology: 'What is rubbish to me is art to somebody else. You have to be very careful.'

Landy's critics have found his work a little preachy, slightly holier-than-thou, while his supporters believe him to be one of the few truly political artists working in Britain at the moment. It could easily be said that Landy is destroying possessions he could be giving to the dispossessed, and that Oxford Street is filled with homeless people as well as consumers. In fact, Landy will not be left with nothing next week: he is exchanging what he owns for cultural capital - he will be a better, and better-known, artist at the end of it.

But this installation is undeniably uncompromising: some of Landy's friends are concerned about him getting rid of his own work, which, quite aside from the question of prospective art history, was all potential revenue (his drawings are valued at up to £6,000 each, and there are hundreds of them). Other friends are worried about their own work going (the Gary Hume painting is worth £20,000). The car was not an old banger, but, I am told, in perfectly good nick.

Landy himself says: 'I'm not here to make people feel guilty or bad - that's not really my role.' He also says that the fact that people care about the value of things is part of the show, part of the interactive point he is making. 'There is a theatre in it,' Landy says. 'You can see people coming in from Oxford Street, and they are still acting as shoppers - they see things going round and they think, oh, I'd like that, or I don't like that. And it was important to me that the only thing you can take away from this is your experience of it. It doesn't get commodified. It's not for sale. Often with contemporary art people get sidetracked - instead of talking about their experience of it they just talk about how much it is.'

What makes Breakdown a triumph, I think, is that beyond its political message it has a number of accidental components. It is not just a comment on consumerism; it can at times be quite funny. It is also a rumination on the nature of memory and identity, and as such it is totally unpredictable to Landy, totally out of his grasp. He has created something that continues to work despite him, a monster almost. He vowed to destroy all his possessions, but he didn't know how he would feel about doing it, and he has found surprises in the process.

'I'm going to kill the operative who destroys my dad's coat.' We are having a cup of tea in what used to be C&A's fitting rooms. Landy calls the people in boiler suits 'operatives'. There are about 12 of them working on Breakdown - most of them are art students or artists; Dave Nutt, who is taking apart the car, is a Saab mechanic.

'I thought you were destroying everything,' I say.

'I am, but, some things are harder to part with. I think that coat's going to be the last to go.' The brown sheepskin coat, carefully folded in a yellow crate, belonged to his father in the Seventies. He bought it when he was 37, the same age Landy is now, and it was so expensive he had to pay it off in installments. But soon afterwards, he had a serious accident at work, and the coat was too heavy and uncomfortable for him to wear. It took Landy's mother a whole year to pay it off; Landy was too small to wear it then, but it fits him now, now that he is about to destroy it. 'I did say at the beginning to all the people working here to try and do it as lovingly as they possibly can,' Landy says.

A drill whizzes loudly on the shop floor. Landy looks around. 'It's funny sitting here nonchalantly having a cup of tea as someone jigsaws my tumble dryer.' Gail, who is working on the sofa, comes in looking for a plaster from the first aid kit. 'It's really enjoyable taking apart well-made things,' she complains, 'but Michael's sofa is just stapled together.' She says that at the beginning they were all really gung-ho about taking things to pieces, but after a couple of days they started getting attached to Michael's things: 'You're sad to see them go.'

Landy explains that everyone has taken on certain roles within the breakdown system. Clive is in charge of all the shredding and granulating. Jakob, an iconoclast, takes particular pleasure in destroying the artworks. Barry does the cat toys because he hates cats, and Nina works with Dave on the car, arranging the parts in the crates in aesthetically pleasing ways. 'I do find the way Barry tears up my photographs quite disturbing,' Landy comments. 'And he takes coins and scratches the faces on them - it's like vandalism.' Barry used to come to this C&A all the way from Northampton as a kid. Now he's a mature art student, having had a career as a chemical engineer. 'I've worked in a textile factory,' he says, 'and I can tell you that the management-worker relations here are exactly the same. This really is a microcosm of industrial life.'

Dave Nutt stands out from the rest: he's wearing a dark blue suit and baseball cap. I ask him what he can tell about Landy from the car. 'I'll tell you what I know about Michael - he's the kind of guy who pays 500 quid for someone to fix his car with a drinking straw. Honestly - I found a drinking straw in it! That's why the turbo wasn't working.'

Apart from being a Saab mechanic, Dave is also a practising Tibetan Buddhist. As he tells me about the renunciate path it becomes clear that he has become a sort of spokesman for the entire installation. 'It's like death,' he says, offering me an organic fruity digestive. 'Death is non-negotiable.'

'You could say this is a suicide piece,' Landy reflects, 'but I don't think it is. I see it as very joyous. In some respects this is a full-stop. But hopefully it will be another beginning. My major investment is that I've spent three years working on this project and I've got two weeks to live with it, and enjoy it.'

I ask him what is left at his home. 'Just Gillian's stuff,' he says. All sorts of things have changed in the few days he has been doing Breakdown: he keeps looking at his watch and finding a bare wrist, he has blisters on his feet from walking everywhere, he has no clothes but the boilersuit on his back.

I ask him if the evidence, and the inventory, add up to a true picture of who he is. 'Yeh,' he replies, 'I'm an artist, and I have my own interests, and none of them are embarrassing. There's nothing on there that's actually really embarrassing' - he pauses - 'apart from a Phil Collins single... and some underwear that was slightly the worse for wear.

'I'd like to have had more love letters, but the first girlfriend I ever went out with demanded the letters back. And more things from when I was younger - from seven or eight up until the age of 18 - I'd like to have had more things like that, to build a picture of what I used to be like when I was younger.' When he found some things of his in his father's loft recently, he sat looking over his youth, remembering friends, tastes, experiences. That, I suggest, is the last time he'll be able to do such a thing, but Landy doesn't care, either about the sentimentalism or about posterity. 'This is a celebration of a life, but I'm still alive. People come in who I haven't seen for years. It's really nice. I'm happy every day. It's like my own funeral, but I'm alive to watch it.'

Breakdown is on at C&A, 499-523 Oxford Street, London W1, until Saturday
fields.bodyText: Who is, or was, Michael Landy? He is a man who until last week possessed more art works than clothes, although he was also quite a dandy dresser. Many of the art works were his own, and some were by other young British artists: by his Turner prize-winning girlfriend Gillian Wearing, by Gary Hume, by Chris Ofili, Tracey Emin, Damien Hirst. He owned more than one Savile Row suit, some Patrick Cox shoes, and his underwear was Calvin Klein. He once lived, worked, or at least removed the locks from 7-9 Fashion Street in London's East End. Judging by the contents of his kitchen, he was a keen chef and, until last week, he still had a mincemeat grinder he inherited from his mother. He banks with NatWest. He sends his love letters by fax. He lost his mobile phone in Heathrow airport and stole a calculator from an art gallery. His social circle includes at least one minor royal and a number of artists, one of whose forgotten swimming trunks he never returned. He has travelled widely (Turkey, Ireland, Greece), but cannot now seem to find his passport. There is evidence to suggest that he reads The Observer and supports West Ham. But now Michael Landy is a man who is destroying this evidence. You will find a record of it in an inventory he has made of every item he possesses. He has given each a number, bagged those that will fit in plastic, and pasted the inventory up on a wall in what used to be C&A on Oxford Street, near Marble Arch. All this week, you can go there and watch Landy dispose of his life. His car, his art archive, his family photographs - everything, as the windows of this very department store shouted only recently, must go. Stretched out behind the big shop windows, between empty clothes racks and deserted escalators, is Landy's public art installation, entitled Breakdown. He has built a conveyor belt and designed it to look like a gigantic toy train set or futuristic factory. It is painted turquoise blue, laden with bright yellow plastic crates containing his things, and is operated by men and women wearing matching blue boiler suits. The same objects go round and round: a shredded pair of 'indestructible' Levi 501s, his father's sheepskin coat, which has remained untouched for days, a dissected rubber lobster with its echo of Salvador Dali. There is a bay for his Saab, another for large objects, a place to put his stereo and an alcove for weighing and logging every item. There is a happy, Mike and the Mechanics sort of atmosphere. The music is his; it has been catalogued and will eventually go too. Huge machines drive the fantasy factory, which is based on material reclamation facilities - a shredder, a granulator and various drills. The aesthetic is one of manufacture but the activity is its opposite: these things are being sorted and taken apart. The whole effect is of a forensic investigation being conducted in an airport, except in this case the luggage is not being reclaimed but disclaimed. The new Michael Landy, it seems to be saying, will come with no baggage. Landy's stated objective is to comment on consumerism, to show us how attached we are to our possessions and how we tend to define ourselves according to the stuff that surrounds us. Retail is even called therapy. This installation, commissioned by Artangel, the organisation behind Rachel Whiteread's House, is closely related to many of his others. Closing Down Sale (1992) featured laminated signs that read 'Buy Now', 'Massive Clearance Sale', '£s off'. Scrapheap Services, which was bought by the Tate in 1996, was composed of a waste-disposal team clearing up heaps of little people cut out of branded packaging - Boddington's, Coca-Cola, KFC. Landy even designed a satirical logo to make anti-corporate culture-jammers proud: a 'Keep Britain Tidy' spoof in which the object being thrown into the rubbish bin is a tiny person. In 1997 he created the Tate Gallery's Christmas tree: a heap of mauled toys and gluttonous waste, a prediction of Boxing Day fall-out. So close to life has Landy's satire been that one exhibition was slightly scuppered when the gallery's cleaners took it to be rubbish and threw parts of it away. A spokesperson for the cleaning contractors at the time offered a sharp piece of art criticism along with her apology: 'What is rubbish to me is art to somebody else. You have to be very careful.' Landy's critics have found his work a little preachy, slightly holier-than-thou, while his supporters believe him to be one of the few truly political artists working in Britain at the moment. It could easily be said that Landy is destroying possessions he could be giving to the dispossessed, and that Oxford Street is filled with homeless people as well as consumers. In fact, Landy will not be left with nothing next week: he is exchanging what he owns for cultural capital - he will be a better, and better-known, artist at the end of it. But this installation is undeniably uncompromising: some of Landy's friends are concerned about him getting rid of his own work, which, quite aside from the question of prospective art history, was all potential revenue (his drawings are valued at up to £6,000 each, and there are hundreds of them). Other friends are worried about their own work going (the Gary Hume painting is worth £20,000). The car was not an old banger, but, I am told, in perfectly good nick. Landy himself says: 'I'm not here to make people feel guilty or bad - that's not really my role.' He also says that the fact that people care about the value of things is part of the show, part of the interactive point he is making. 'There is a theatre in it,' Landy says. 'You can see people coming in from Oxford Street, and they are still acting as shoppers - they see things going round and they think, oh, I'd like that, or I don't like that. And it was important to me that the only thing you can take away from this is your experience of it. It doesn't get commodified. It's not for sale. Often with contemporary art people get sidetracked - instead of talking about their experience of it they just talk about how much it is.' What makes Breakdown a triumph, I think, is that beyond its political message it has a number of accidental components. It is not just a comment on consumerism; it can at times be quite funny. It is also a rumination on the nature of memory and identity, and as such it is totally unpredictable to Landy, totally out of his grasp. He has created something that continues to work despite him, a monster almost. He vowed to destroy all his possessions, but he didn't know how he would feel about doing it, and he has found surprises in the process. 'I'm going to kill the operative who destroys my dad's coat.' We are having a cup of tea in what used to be C&A's fitting rooms. Landy calls the people in boiler suits 'operatives'. There are about 12 of them working on Breakdown - most of them are art students or artists; Dave Nutt, who is taking apart the car, is a Saab mechanic. 'I thought you were destroying everything,' I say. 'I am, but, some things are harder to part with. I think that coat's going to be the last to go.' He bought it when he was 37, the same age Landy is now, and it was so expensive he had to pay it off in installments. webTitle: Should I confront my son over his sex diaries?

fields.headline: Should I confront my son over his sex diaries?
fields.trailText:
I recently moved house and cleared out my son's bedroom (he is 24 and has left home). I came across a bundle of notebooks he'd kept as a teenager. The life I discovered bore little resemblance to the life I thought he'd led. He was sexually promiscuous and had sex with a girl of 12 when he was 16. I blame myself for reading the diary and want to confront him.
W.D. of Wales
fields.body:
I recently moved house and cleared out my son's bedroom (he is 24 and has left home). I came across a bundle of notebooks he'd kept as a teenager. The life I discovered bore little resemblance to the life I thought he'd led. He was sexually promiscuous and had sex with a girl of 12 when he was 16. I blame myself for reading the diary and want to confront him.
W.D. of Wales

Don't, please don't confront him. You've got to check your impulse to charge in and cause a family breach. Your son is a free-wheeling adult now and is not going to accept strictures on a personal issue which, in any case, will seem out of touch with modern life. He is a separate individual. Actually, he always was, and less amenable to your influence than you believed.

The habit of secrecy is innate to humans, so much so that it may be as protective of a well-balanced psyche as sleep. It is arrogant to assume that you know someone through and through. You only know that facet which is presented to you, and if you happen to be a busy, talkative, controlling person, you won't even know that very well. Keeping things hidden gives a measure of power to someone who is otherwise vulnerable. Our race is most especially secretive about sex, which creates an impediment for those who would like to know what human behaviour is really all about.

Most people thumb their noses at the Christian code of celibacy outside marriage and fidelity within, and in recent decades the pretence of upholding it has been pretty well demolished. Your son probably behaved in the same way as his peers, seizing what opportunities were available to him. Age is an arbitrary dividing line when biology takes over.

The rules a parent sets a child are designed for protection, both physical and mental. I found myself gradually easing up on a number of these as my sons grew up, often to their surprise. They have to learn about the world as it really is, not as you would like it to be. They also have to learn to deal with powerful emotions, without suffering agonies of guilt and distorted perception over normal responses.

Your son may understand this better than you do, as he must realise that he left behind some explosive material and that you'd find it sooner or later. Maybe he assumed you would accept his inner life as rationally as I hope you'll be able to do in the future. Perhaps one day you will hand him those notebooks without rancour or comment, and neither of you will bat an eyelid.

Readers' replies

I cannot believe that you read something very personal belonging to someone who is now an adult. I have two daughters of similar age to your son and would not dream of invading their privacy in such a way. There is a fairly high probability that much, if not all, of what you read was a teenager fantasising. However, you can never raise the issue with your son as he will undoubtedly be most aggrieved. If you are troubled at what you read then you can only blame yourself for opening this Pandora's Box.
D.C. via email

Next week's problem

My wife is desperate for a second child. I am adamant that I do not want another one. We have a happy home life and I enjoy and love my daughter, but I do not have the time or money to commit to a second child. Should I give in to my wife, who I don't want to be unhappy and sacrifice the stability of our relationship, or should I hold my ground?
A.B. of Bucks

Write to Observer Review or email margaret.cook@observer.co.uk Views on the problem must reach us by Wednesday. Margaret Cook writes for Woman's Journal

fields.headline: Poorest children are getting poorer
fields.trailText: Almost 250,000 children in Britain's poorest households have become worse off since 1997 when Labour took power, says a new study published this week.
fields.body:
Almost 250,000 children in Britain's poorest households have become worse off since 1997 when Labour took power, says a new study published this week.

Two million British children still live below the poverty line, according to the research, that reveals child poverty is almost 50 per cent higher than in 1979.

The news will embarrass Ministers, particularly Chancellor Gordon Brown, who launched Labour's election offensive last week with a speech condemning child poverty as 'a scar on the soul of Britain'.

Figures will show 1.2 million children have been lifted out of poverty since Labour came to office. But researcher Holly Sutherland of Cambridge University said: 'This has mainly happened as a consequence of abolishing the lone-parent benefit. That decision has hit single parents with older children in particular.

'Sometimes the drop in income families suffer is regarded as small but can still be highly significant in the poorest households. Thankfully more families are taking up income support which will help. However, it's time the Treasury acknowledged there have been some losers due to their changes.'

Cuts to lone-parent benefit shortly after Labour came to office in 1997 split the party. Many Labour backbenchers refused to support the proposal piloted by then Social Security Secretary Harriet Harman. A lone parent with two children who is unable to work would currently receive just £52.20 a week in income support and £27.55 in child benefit.

Kate Green of the National Council for One Parent Families said: 'This doesn't come as a surprise. The Government's emphasis has been on lifting people out of poverty by getting them back to work. But this can be especially difficult for lone parents.'

Martin Barnes of the Child Poverty Action Group said: 'Almost nothing was done for child poverty in the first two years of the Labour government. Of course we welcome any action, but a determined commitment to solving this problem could eradicate child poverty in 10 years, not the 20 years Gordon Brown has promised.'

Addressing Labour's spring conference in Glasgow, Brown claimed ending child poverty was one of 'five radical economic goals for our generation' alongside full employment and delivering better public services.

The Microsimulation Unit at Cambridge assessed the effect of all tax and benefit changes between 1997 and last year, and the effect of the new minimum wage, on Britain's poorest families. The results will be published in the Economic Journal . Another international study to be published this week will confirm that Britain still has almost the worst levels of child poverty in the industrialised world.

fields.headline: Ministers attack Campbell
fields.trailText: Two of the Government's most senior figures yesterday attacked Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, for saying that the education system was littered with 'bog standard comprehensives'.
fields.body:
Two of the Government's most senior figures yesterday attacked Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, for saying that the education system was littered with 'bog standard comprehensives'.

In an unprecedented and coordinated move against Campbell - often described as the second most powerful man in the Government behind Tony Blair - John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, and David Blunkett, the Education Secretary, said his criticism undermined improvements in the education system.

Both Prescott and Blunkett used speeches at Labour's spring conference in Glasgow to deliver the unprecedented public dressing down.

Both men are furious that Campbell's comments, made at the launch of the Government's 10-year education plan last week, overshadowed a raft of policy initiatives.

Campbell was also criticised by teaching unions and members of his own party.

Senior Labour figures were predicting last night that such an attack by two such well-respected figures in the party would undermine Campbell's position.

'Personally, I am surprised that they both so clearly said it,' one party official said. 'Tony must be angry that this has blown up like this.'

Blair arrives in Glasgow today to make his keynote speech and party strategists fear that the row will undermine his appearance.

The put-down comes three weeks after Campbell plunged the Government into a furious row when he described Peter Mandelson as 'semi-detached' after the former Northern Ireland Secretary resigned over the Hinduja passports affair. In a briefing to journalists he also suggested that Mandelson was 'unfocused' and that he wanted a complete break from politics.

Prescott's direct attack on Campbell came in the middle of his speech to 2,000 Labour Party members. When the audience realised what he was saying, there was applause. 'We all want better standards,' the Deputy Prime Minister said. 'So let's have more substance and less spin. Let's have more talk about specialisation and high standards and less talk about bog-standard provision. We want every school to be a good school.'

His criticisms were echoed by Blunkett. The Education Secretary said of the 'bog standard' comment: 'I don't recognise or use the term.'

He went on to praise the work secondary schools were doing.

But despite the attack, a senior Labour spokesman said that the party still officially stood by the comment, revealing a serious split between three of the most powerful men in the Prime Minister's administration. This division is worrying many officials in the party as the general election approaches.

webTitle: Sicilian held over playing card killings

fields.headline: Sicilian held over playing card killings
fields.trailText: Italian police were last night questioning a suspected double murderer who threatened to litter the city of Padua with the corpses of estate agents.
fields.body:
Italian police were last night questioning a suspected double murderer who threatened to litter the city of Padua with the corpses of estate agents.

Michele Profeta, 53, a debt collector, was arrested after allegedly taunting police with a series of clues thought to be inspired by the novelist Patricia Cornwell. Police traced a series of calls to Palermo, in Profeta's native Sicily, from public telephone boxes which used the same phone card to contact the second victim, an estate agent.

Profeta, who had lived in the northern university town for years, was arrested on Friday night driving past the spot of the first killing.

He denied the accusations and had not been charged by last night. 'He denied even those things which to us seemed evidential,' said prosecutor Paolo Luca.

Police said they found three pistols in his apartment, which he shared with a girlfriend, one of which matched the calibre of the murder weapon.

Stencils of the type used in three anonymous letters to police and newspapers were discovered. The author threatened a bloodbath unless 12bn lire (£3.9m) was paid.

A pack of playing cards was also found to be missing its four kings. Walter Boscolo, an estate agent made to kneel and then shot in the forehead after being lured to a luxury apartment, was found on 10 February with the king of hearts and diamonds next to his corpse.

Police suggested Profeta may have been planning another killing as the king of clubs was in his pocket. The first victim, taxi driver Pierpaolo Lissandron, was shot in the back of the neck by his passenger on 29 January. webTitle: Royal penny blacks up for sale in May auction

fields.headline: Royal penny blacks up for sale in May auction
fields.trailText: The Queen is to put some of the rarest stamps on the market - including a 'penny black' sent on the first day of Britain's world postal service in 1840.
fields.body:
The Queen is to put some of the rarest stamps on the market - including a 'penny black' sent on the first day of Britain's world postal service in 1840.

The stamp, fixed to a wrapper posted in Liverpool to Abergavenny on 6 May of that year is expected to fetch up to £8,000 and went on show yesterday, along with 200 other British and Empire stamps from the Royal Philatelic Collection worth an estimated £400,000. They will go under the hammer at the London auctioneers Spink on 17 May.

The Queen has agreed to the sale of 200 items from her collection in order to fund 'a programme of enhancement' which has already begun with the £250,000 purchase of a first-day cover of 10 penny blacks also sent in 1840, the year Sir Rowland Hill introduced penny postage for all items of a certain weight.

'The integrity of the collection will not be damaged by the sale,' said Richard Watkins, director of the stamp department at Spink. 'Purely duplicated or items surplus to requirements will be offered so that if a unique item comes up it can be acquired.'

Included in the auction will be mint examples of 1840 'penny blacks' and 'twopenny blues', in singles and multiples, and an 1883 10-shilling stamp with a rare watermark, which should fetch up to £6,000. Another rarity, a 1910 British 2d 'Tyrian plum' which was never used because of the death of Edward VII, is estimated at £10,000.

George V, an obsessive and astute collector, began collecting stamps when he was Prince of Wales and quickly built up the best collection of its type. He struck a deal with the International Postal Union and received a copy of every stamp issued anywhere in the world. All the foreign issues were subsequently donated to the Royal Philatelic Society, but the royal family's remaining British and Commonwealth Collection still fills 325 albums and they regularly lend stamps for exhibitions.

Catalogues from the May sale are expected to become collectors' items.

fields.headline: Style stars cold-shouldered
fields.trailText: Catwalk shows by the designers Calvin Klein, right, and Donna Karan rounded off New York Fashion Week yesterday. Klein used leather to create classically tailored coats and jackets, while Karan mixed classic suiting with tribal influences.
fields.body:
Catwalk shows by the designers Calvin Klein, right, and Donna Karan rounded off New York Fashion Week yesterday. Klein used leather to create classically tailored coats and jackets, while Karan mixed classic suiting with tribal influences.

Fashion writers agreed that this year's autumn collections, from some of the world's leading design houses, were stylish and luxurious but lacked the innovation and originality that are the quintessential ingredients of haute couture at its best.

The New York Times said that, while Paris was the brains of the fashion world and Milan its factory, designers would now be looking for inspiration to the young talent that will be on show from today in London Fashion Week. This will feature such established stars as Alexander McQueen, who is renowned for shows that shock, and newcomers such as Hamish Morrow and Michelle Lowe-Holder.

fields.headline: New battle engulfs Royal Oak
fields.standfirst: Drilling has started at 'war grave' to stem oil threat to wildlife
fields.trailText: When the torpedoes hit, soon after 1am on 14 October 1939, 1,223 men were below decks, asleep in their hammocks.
fields.body:
When the torpedoes hit, soon after 1am on 14 October 1939, 1,223 men were below decks, asleep in their hammocks. Sailors frantically tried to clamber out of the hatches as the Royal Navy destroyer Royal Oak, fully armed and fueled, toppled on to its side and began to sink beneath the freezing waters of Scapa Flow in Orkney.

More than 800 men died and their bodies still lie in what has become Britain's most sacred maritime war grave.

Now, more than six decades on, the carcass of the Royal Oak is at the centre of a deadly new battle. This time the threat is not to man, but to rare species of seal, por poise and sea birds.

Oil is leaking from the damaged hull of the stricken vessel and the Royal Navy has the agonising dilemma of how to stop the flow without destroying the sanctity of the grave.

Up to one-and-a-half tonnes of oil escapes from the rotting fuel bunkers each week and is washed up on nearby beaches. If the hull splits in two, 1,800 tonnes of heavy fuel oil will pollute the beaches and the fish farms which are the basis of the island's tourism and farming economy.

This week Ministry of Defence divers will - for the first time - begin drilling into the hull, where hundreds of bodies have lain undisturbed for more than half a century, and begin to pump out the oil. Two vessels, the Seaspring and the Cameron, are moored off the wreck waiting for calm weather to begin the delicate operation.

To reassure survivors of the tragedy and the victims' families that the site will be protected, ministers are considering introducing new laws to protect all maritime war graves.

Lewis Moonie, the Defence Minister, who travelled to Orkney to approve the drilling operation last week, said: 'We want to ensure that the victims of all wartime tragedies are treated with the utmost respect. Graves must remain undisturbed and protected wherever practical.'

The Royal Oak was torpedoed at her moorings by a German U-boat which sailed undetected through a blockade at the entrance to Scapa Flow, a key naval base. She sank in 15 minutes; 833 men died and 390 survived.

The dead sailors are honoured every year with an annual remembrance service in which divers swim down to the wreck and place the white ensign on the hull.

Ministry of Defence engineers have tried to solve the problem of the leaking oil without resorting to drilling into the wreck. Over the past three years huge steel patches have been laid on the ship's hull, more than 500 sandbags have been placed over the worst of the leaking areas, and a £200,000 steel canopy, designed to catch the oil as it rose to the surface, was built. But in the storms and heavy seas that affect Orkney, none of the solutions worked.

Navy officers have approved the drilling operation as a last resort. Rear Admiral Brian Perowne, head of the naval bases and supply agency, said: 'The leaks have increased dramatically and we have had to change our tactics. Containment is no longer an option. We have got to go in.'

MoD chief salvage officer David Keogh added: 'We are confident we can remove the chance of an environmental disaster. It is a tricky operation, not only because we have to preserve the sanctity of the wreck, but also because we are recovering a highly flammable substance and there is always the risk posed by unexploded ordnance.

'We don't know exactly how much oil we are going to get out, but we are confident we are going to get a good result.'

Environmentalists, who have expressed concern at the constant leaks, have welcomed the MoD's move. Ross Flett of Orkney Seal Rescue said: 'Scapa Flow is an important area for seals, and while the oil is down there, there is a possibility it could leak from other parts of the ship.'

Survivors of the tragedy have approved the operation. Joe Instance, 84, who was badly burnt in the disaster, said: 'The MoD contacted the Royal Oak Survivors' Association and asked what we felt about breaching the hull. We said: "Just get the damned stuff out of there. It's caused enough problems."

'It is not messing about with a war grave. I know the boys down there would have felt the same. The oil caused enough grief in Scapa Flow at the time. Nobody wants it to cause any more.'

The operation will be completed by the end of the year.

fields.headline: Freed man set for £8m apology
fields.standfirst: Downing lawyers hope for massive compensation after murder appeal
fields.trailText: A man jailed for 27 years for a murder he says he did not commit is set to become a multi-millionaire within weeks, The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
A man jailed for 27 years for a murder he says he did not commit is set to become a multi-millionaire within weeks, The Observer can reveal.

Stephen Downing, a victim of what campaigners describe as one of Britain's worst miscarriages of justice, earned just £28 a month before the murder of Wendy Sewell in 1973.

Freed on bail at Derbyshire Crown Court two weeks ago, legal experts predict Downing could receive up to £8 million when his High Court appeal to have the conviction quashed is heard.

The disclosure came as it was revealed that the net was closing on five local men believed to hold the key to Sewell's death - one of whom is widely believed to be responsible.

Sewell, from Bakewell in the Peak District, was murdered in the town cemetery. Downing, a cemetery worker, was subsequently jailed for life, and refused parole because he would not admit his part in the killing.

Experts have confirmed that Downing could make four separate claims for compensation:

 Downing was forced to spend 10 years more than the 17-year sentence handed down by the courts in 1973 because his refusal to confess made him ineligible for parole. Claim: around £900,000.

 The behaviour of Derbyshire police was criticised by the judge at Downing's bail hearing and his arrest was ruled unsafe. Pending a successful appeal, Downing could claim for wrongful arrest and 27 years unlawful detention. Claim: up to £1m.

 Downing could also sue his original lawyers for failing to identify basic faults in the police case which led to his conviction on the basis of a statement which has now been declared unsafe. Claim: £1m.

 If Downing's conviction is quashed by the High Court in the forthcoming appeal, the one-time county council gardener could also sue the Government for unlawful detention. Claim: up to £5m.

A sum of up to £900,000 has secretly been agreed in prin cipal by the Government to partially compensate Downing for the 10 years he spent in jail over his original tariff.

'Stephen is entitled to this money for the 27 years he spent suffering behind bars,' said Don Hale, editor of the local newspaper, the Matlock Mercury , who campaigned ceaselessly over six years for Downing's release despite repeated attempts on his life by those he believes to be the real killers.

'Stephen is not a money grabber but he rightfully feels he is entitled to some compensation,' added Hale, nominated as The Observer 's Man of the Year last December and dubbed the 'Poirot of the Peaks'.

According to Hale, Downing will use some of the money to buy a new house for his family in the Bakewell village in which he was born. 'His family is his key concern at the moment,' he said. 'He wants somewhere with more privacy than the small council flat they live in at the moment.'

Downing is looking forward to taking his family on holiday to Weymouth. 'He's a modest man and that's his height of ambition once this is all over,' said Hale. Downing had his first driving lesson last week from a former policeman who helped investigate the murder in 1973.
