webTitle: Milburn turns his fire on rigid and outdated NHS

fields.headline: Milburn turns his fire on rigid and outdated NHS
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Britain's health service is stuck in the Forties with too many patients queueing for treatment, overstretched staff and a paternalistic attitude that does not put the public first, the Government has admitted.
fields.body:
Britain's health service is stuck in the Forties with too many patients queueing for treatment, overstretched staff and a paternalistic attitude that does not put the public first, the Government has admitted.

In a surprisingly critical speech to the Labour Party spring conference yesterday, Health Secretary Alan Milburn said that, despite some change, there was still not enough being done.

It is the second time in a week the Government has attacked one of Britain's key public services. Last week Alastair Campbell, the Prime Minister's official spokesman, attacked secondary education provision, saying the day of the 'bog-standard comprehensive' was over.

The statement upset teaching unions and Labour members who said public services needed support rather than constant criticism. There are also fears that regular attacks on the public sector will lead to disillusionment among voters. Prime Minister Tony Blair will admit in a speech today that apathy among Labour supporters could lose the party the next election.

David Blunkett, the Education Secretary, and John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, both used speeches yesterday to show their anger at the use of the 'bog-standard' phrase. 'Let's have less talk about bog-standard provision,' Prescott said to warm applause from the audience.

But despite efforts last year to put out a more positive message about the public sector, Milburn used his speech to criticise NHS attitudes.

'We are the best friends of the National Health Service and there are some things that only your best friends will tell you,' he said.

'[It is] a system that is too rigid, too paternalistic. Quite simply too bureaucratic. We must summon the same courage and conviction it took to create the NHS to reform the NHS. The challenge we must meet is to bring this Forties system into the twenty-first century.'

Milburn's attack, which is likely to be condemned by medical groups, comes as the Prime Minister prepares to admit that disillusionment and cynicism could affect Labour's performance in the General Election, expected on 3 May. Blair will say that the British public have a duty to vote and 'a decision to stay at home is a decision to vote Tory'.

The party has identified 60 target seats where the Labour party could lose to the Tories or Liberal Democrats if their core vote does not turn out.

Blair will say that it is 'choice not chance' that the Government has been able to bring in reforms and that the British public should understand that their vote counts.

He will also reiterate his commitment to tackling crime and is expected to launch new initiatives aimed at tackling 'a hardcore of offenders'.

The Prime Minister hopes his speech to 2,000 of the party faithful will ready them for the election campaign ahead, which Cabinet Ministers yesterday all but admitted was going to be called in the near future.

webTitle: MI5 and police ordered illegal break-ins at mosques

fields.headline: MI5 and police ordered illegal break-ins at mosques
fields.standfirst: Focus: How Britain betrayed me
fields.trailText: British security services ordered illegal burglaries in Muslim places of worship to gather information on alleged Islamic militants, a key MI5 and police informer has told  The Observer .
fields.body:
British security services ordered illegal burglaries in Muslim places of worship to gather information on alleged Islamic militants, a key MI5 and police informer has told The Observer .

In one of the most detailed descriptions of secret opera tions on the British mainland, Reda Hassaine, an Algerian former journalist, has revealed how he infiltrated the tight-knit community of Islamic militants in the UK for MI5 and the Special Branch, the police squad with responsibility for gathering information on suspected terrorists.

Hassaine, an asylum-seeker, disclosed how officers blackmailed him into carrying out the burglaries by threatening him with expulsion if he refused. They also advised him on how to defraud the British welfare system to enhance his meagre earnings from them.

The revelations will deeply embarrass the security services and lead to further accusations of incompetence as yet another operative tells his story. It will also raise serious questions about the services' dealings with vulnerable groups like asylum-seekers.

'Any suggestion that asylum applications could be contingent on "co-operating" with the UK security services raises the most serious concerns,' a spokesman for Amnesty, the human rights group, said.

During two years as an informer, Hassaine was asked to steal scores of documents from senior preachers at mosques in north London. Some were communiqués from extremist groups overseas; others were seemingly innocuous.

Hassaine, 37, even told his handlers about a dirty tricks campaign against Muslim militants in London being run by the French intelligence service, the DGSE. Though it too involved burglaries of mosques and Islamic groups' premises as well as the funding of a newspaper supporting the terrorist Osama bin Laden, Hassaine was advised to help the French.

Though Hassaine has been badly beaten by Muslim hardliners and now faces almost daily death threats, the Home Office has refused his asylum application.

webTitle: Focus: Is the Celtic tiger losing its soul?

fields.headline: Romance dies as the Irish come of age
fields.standfirst: The nation is transformed by its soaring economy. But there are growing fears that the 'friendly country' could be losing its soul in the process.  Alan Ruddock reports from Dublin
fields.trailText: The nation is transformed by its soaring economy. But there are growing fears that the 'friendly country' could be losing its soul in the process.  Alan Ruddock reports from Dublin.
fields.body:
Charlie McCreevy sank back into his comfortable seat and watched the bright early evening lights of the airport flicker past the cabin window of the Brussels-Dublin shuttle as it taxied to the runway for take-off. In a few moments he would be bound for home and, he reflected, a hero's welcome.

It had been a gruelling day, but the Ireland's maverick Finance Minister knew the headlines in the country's press the next morning would be generous. McCreevy had been isolated and censured by his peers at last Monday's meeting of European Finance Ministers in Brussels, but he was not for turning.

He had defiantly told his EU colleagues he would not abandon Ireland's hugely successful policies of low taxation and economic expansion. Furthermore, he told the disbelieving gathering, the rest of Europe would be better off copying Ireland's success, not criticising it.

McCreevy had been summoned to Brussels to receive an unprecedented rebuke from his European partners for pursuing policies that they believe will overheat the already booming Irish economy. Europe's star pupil was being rapped across the knuckles.

His defiance last week would have been unimaginable in an Irish Finance Minister 10 years ago, but after a decade of stunning economic growth, Ireland is a country changing at bewildering speed.

Where once it tugged its forelock to Europe and held out the begging bowl for structural funds, now it struts with the brash self confidence of the nouveau riche. 'We have come of age,' said Jim O'Leary, chief economist of Davy Stockbrokers in Dublin.

Ireland's economic performance has been almost matched by its cultural success. Irish musicians regularly dominate the British charts, from the old hands of U2, to Westlife and The Corrs and emerging stars like 18-year-old R and B singer Samantha Mumba.

The country's writers, actors and playwrights have also enjoyed sustained success and international acclaim, while Irish designers such as Louise Kennedy and John Rocha have forced themselves to the forefront of the world fashion industry.

Gone are the days of the Clancy Brothers, woolly jumpers and old men sipping pints of the black stuff in quaint old bars: modern Ireland presents itself as young, cool, affluent, self-confident and proud. It can even boast VIP, its very own celebrity magazine, modelled on Hello! and OK!, so that Ireland's new élite can invite you into their homes and share their happiness with you. The irony that many of those featured have never been heard of sparks the odd snigger.

Throughout the country wealth is ostentatious where once it was hidden away. New car sales have quadrupled, with each year's new licence plate (designated by the year, as in 01, and not by a letter), a 'must have' accessory. Last week in Dublin, top-of-the-range Mercedes jostled with brand new Jaguars on the city's gridlocked streets.

House prices have soared by more than 70 per cent in seven years and dinner party conversations are reminiscent of London in the mid 1980s - money, money and more money. British cities such as Glasgow and Liverpool are now rich investment targets for Irish developers with money to spare. Jobs are also plentiful; technology companies advertising in the national press regularly offer salaries of up to IR£100,000.

'This place is awash with cash. People have developed the 'loadsamoney' culture that Britain experienced in the Eighties. Lunch is for wimps, greed is good and everybody wants a slice of the action,' wrote one commentator last month.

The benefits of growth have been very real: emigration, the scourge of Ireland for generations, has been replaced by immigration as the booming economy creates more jobs than the Irish can fill. The Ryanair generation, once made up of the young Irish leaving in search of work, has now been replaced by a wave of tourists.

Rural towns have been re-vitalised by commuters fleeing Dublin's high prices. Tumbling unemployment, low taxes and low interest rates have spread prosperity wider than ever before.

For the first time in their history, the Irish have money to burn and they are building a bonfire: successive Christ mases have seen record retail sales and consumer debt is running at a record high.

But success and wealth have not come free: within Ireland a debate has been rumbling about whether the country has lost its sense of identity, even its sense of humanity, in its fevered pursuit of riches. Some believe the country's proud greeting 'Cead Mile Failte' - a hundred thousand welcomes - is becoming an empty one.

Critics of modern Ireland have much to latch on to. Racism is now an ugly reality in the Emerald Isle. News of Ireland's economic boom has spread far and wide, and thousands of asylum seekers arrive each year hoping to get a fresh start, bringing the Irish face to face with the prospect of a multicultural society. In 1992, a total of 80 people applied for asylum in Ireland. The rate now runs at 8,000 a month.

It has not been a comfortable experience: rising reports of racial abuse on the streets have been matched by unexpected harshness and coldness in the official response to asylum seekers, which seems focused on ensuring that as few immigrants as possible actually succeed in setting foot on Irish soil.

Even immigrants with valid visas and work permits have felt the chill of Irish hospitality: recently a group of workers from eastern Europe arrived with valid permits and the promise of jobs. When immigration officials discovered that those jobs no longer existed, the men were dispatched to Dublin's Mountjoy jail for three days.

Wealth has also exacerbated a host of social problems. Last week the problem of teenage binge drinking knocked McCreevy off the front pages for a day: Irish teenagers are now the heaviest drinkers in Europe, but it is how they drink, rather than how much, which is causing concern.

Irish teenagers, wealthier than ever because of parental handouts and weekend and holiday jobs, drink themselves into oblivion and the consequences can be shocking. Last year, national outrage was sparked when a Dublin teenager was kicked to death outside a nightclub after a row between two groups of boys - allegedly from rival fee-paying schools.

Other manifestations of the boom have troubled observers. Irish theme bars, now littered across Britain, have replaced real Irish pubs, while super clubs, capable of hosting thousands of people, have mushroomed. In quiet country villages, typical of the fictional Ballykissangel, unsmiling doormen are becoming commonplace.

Another big disappointment has been the failure of the government to invest some of the country's new found riches in an ageing and over-burdened health system that is in dire need of investment. The transport infrastructure is also creaking under the strain.

'There is no doubt that Ireland, in some ways, is a harsher society than it used to be, but I don't think that's irreversible,' said Walton Empey, the Church of Ireland Archbishop of Dublin. 'It's also a much more open society than it used to be and that is healthy.'

The Irish economic miracle may have been primed by generous European structural funds in the late Eighties and early Nineties, but the real impetus for growth has been driven internally. Central to that growth has been a determination by successive Irish governments to cut taxes, both personal and corporate, and make Ireland the most attractive region in Europe for companies to move to. A determinedly consensual approach to economic planning that wrapped employers and unions into rolling wage agreements has helped.

Low taxes and a young, well-educated and English speaking workforce (40 per cent of the Irish population is under-25) have enticed the high-technology titans such as Intel, Apple and Microsoft.

The surge in employment has also created a labour shortage, with industry leaders predicting that Ireland will create more than 350,000 new jobs in the coming years and that about 200,000 of those will have to be filled by immigrants. Some will be Irish, lured by a government campaign to persuade Irish people abroad to come home.

The influx can only accelerate the changes that have swept through Irish society in the past decade as it has moved from being a controlled, monocultural society to a freer multicultural one. Side by side with the economic explosion has been an equally dramatic upheaval in the perception of the church and of politics.

A steady stream of sex abuse scandals throughout the Nineties stripped the Roman Catholic Church of its confidence and credibility. The effect on the morale of priests has been devastating and will take years to restore. Where once they were held in almost universal respect, now they come face to face with ridicule. 'I was on my way to the hospital when I met three young boys coming down the street towards me. "Buggered any boys today, father?" they shouted,' said one priest from a city parish.

While the church was battered by crisis, Irish politics was also being dragged through the mud. A number of tribunals of inquiry investigating the beef industry, payments to politicians and the distribution of contaminated blood supplies have uncovered startling levels of corruption at the very top of Irish politics.

Charles Haughey, the former Taoiseach, received millions of pounds from businessmen while in office and inexorably, other senior politicians are being drawn into the net as the tribunals continue their trawl. Last month Liam Lawlor, another Fianna Fail politician, was sent to jail for a week because he had not co-operated fully with a tribunal investigating payments to politicians. The investigations are far from complete: more political careers are expected to be ruined before the tribunals complete their work.

In an Ireland that is both cynical and obsessed by wealth, Charlie McCreevy has played a smart game. His Budget, so disliked by his European partners, went down exceptionally well at home. A government that should have been reeling from corruption scandals recently received 70 per cent approval ratings.

He is already planning his next Budget, which is certain to precede a general election, and it will not be a hairshirt one. As the price of euro membership, Europe wants McCreevy to rein in the economy, to raise or at least maintain tax rates and to curb public spending. It seems very unlikely that he will play ball.

At home his defiance has matched the public mood. 'The reaction has been tinged with xenophobia and old-fashioned raw nationalism,' said Jim O'Leary. 'There is a vein of Euroscepticism around.'

According to most economists, the changes that have swept Ireland will continue to gather pace: money will remain in plentiful supply and the Irish will continue to, as McCreevy himself once advised, 'enjoy the party'.

But the warning bells have been sounded. The question remains whether the Irish can balance their wealth and hang on to a society hailed as unique for its warmthand sense of community.

As one caller lamented on Irish radio: 'We are becoming obsessed with wealth creation. We used to care for old people, look after the sick, watch out for the underdog. It's not too late to turn back, to hang on to the things that made us who we are.'

webTitle: £1bn in cash taken out of UK for drugs

fields.headline: £1bn in cash taken out of UK for drugs
fields.standfirst: Special report: drugs in Britain
fields.trailText: Highly sophisticated criminal gangs are smuggling more than £1 billion in cash out of Britain each year to buy drugs,  The Observer can reveal.
fields.body:
Highly sophisticated criminal gangs are smuggling more than £1 billion in cash out of Britain each year to buy drugs, The Observer can reveal.

A crackdown by Customs officers, with sniffer dogs trained to detect currency stacks, means the gangs are resorting to the same techniques as cocaine and heroin smugglers to move money out of the country.

Huge sums of cash have been found concealed in hollowed out shoes, electrical goods, bicycle tyres, nappies and specially constructed body suits. A woman leaving Heathrow airport hid £418,000 in boxes of Persil washing powder.

Although there are no limits on what quantities of cash can be brought in or taken out of the country, Customs officers have the power to seize amounts greater than £10,000 if the owner cannot explain its origin and there are suspected drug trade links.

The amount seized this year has risen by more than 50 per cent but, at just £7 million, is only a tiny fraction of the sum believed to be leaving the country.

'We are seeing a complete reversal of what happens with drugs traffickers. They are often going to extreme lengths to smuggle something out of the country rather than bring something in,' says Customs officer Ian Watson. 'We are specifically targeting money and plan to greatly intensify our efforts because we find it a highly effective way of tackling the drug trade.

'A kilo of heroin will sell in the UK for £70,000. Take that sum abroad and you can buy up to four kilos of heroin. If a gang loses a kilo of drugs, they will just put another courier on the next plane, if they lose the profit from those drugs, that is much harder to replace.'

Cash is usually smuggled to such notorious 'drug' destinations as Amsterdam, southern Spain, South America and the Caribbean. At Heathrow, two specially trained teams of officers work exclusively on finding money couriers.

'If couriers are on their way to Holland, they say the money is to buy a car. If they are off to Spain, they claim they plan to buy a bar or a Jetski business. If it's the Caribbean, they inevitably say the money is to pay for home improvements or to buy a chunk of land. Everyone we stop has the option of staying and convincing us that the money is legitimate, or simply continuing on their way. More than 90 per cent leave the money. In many cases we never ever hear from them again,' says Watson.

As well as buying drugs, gangs are smuggling money abroad to have it laundered. Although transferring money through the banking system would be quicker and safer, smugglers know banks and other financial institutions are duty bound to report suspicious transactions to the National Criminal Intelligence Service. And travellers' cheques or bearer bonds leave a paper trail for police to follow.

When sniffer dogs detected money in the luggage of two women flying out of Heathrow, they denied they had any funds other than the cash in their purses. When one suitcase was opened, £680,000 was found hidden under towels. The money had been double-wrapped in clingfilm and then carbon paper in a failed effort to disguise its scent.

'Money couriers are usually hired specifically to carry the money,' says Watson, and are usually kept in the dark about exactly how much they are carrying, in case they choose to abscond with the cash. As money is seized under civil legislation, couriers do not face criminal charges, unless it can be proved they are directly involved in money laundering.

Legislation expected next year will give Customs officers the power to seize money linked to crimes other than drugs.

This is expected to have a massive impact on the burgeoning bootlegging industry which requires large amounts to be smuggled out of the country.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Kidnappers demand £1.2m ransom after engineer abducted in Bangladesh
fields.body:
Kidnappers demand £1.2m ransom after engineer abducted in Bangladesh

A British engineer and two Danish colleagues working in Bangladesh for an aid agency have been kidnapped by guerrillas who are said to be demanding a £1.2 million ransom.Tim Selby, from the Manchester area, was abducted with Torben Mikkelsen and Nils Hulgaard at gunpoint.

The group were driving between villages in the Chittagong Hill Tracts region in the south east. Another Briton, David Weston, and the group's Bangladeshi driver were also abducted but later released unharmed, spokesman Jon Geddes said. The unidentified gunmen have demanded a £1.2m ransom, he said.

The Foreign Office said: 'We are aware of the situation and we are in contact with the Bangladesh authorities and are providing consular assistance.'

Watch out for the weevils

The weevil Ixaion variegatum, a type which feeds on mistletoe and was until now found only on the Continent, has been discovered in England, in an orchard in a National Trust estate at Brockhampton, Herefordshire.

Sign of times

Vandals caused traffic chaos in Totland, Isle of Wight, after they left eight road signs pointing the wrong way.

Boy dies in fire

Police are regarding as suspicious the death of a boy aged 15 months in a fire at a house in Newport, South Wales. The toddler was rescued along with his mother and his brother aged nine but died in hospital.

Lawrence's Pillars of Wisdom is auctioned for £18,000

A 1926 subscription edition of T.E. Lawrence's Seven Pillars of Wisdom , one of only 120 copies produced and which was owned by the late Naomi Mitchison, fetched £18,000.

Lyon & Turnbull said the hammer was about to come down when an offer was received from a buyer in the South of England who had heard of the sale only that morning.

'The man rang the saleroom just at the moment that the book was being sold,' said spokesman Phillip Gregory.

'The person who took his call ran to the auction room to place his bid as the hammer was coming down.'

The book, which was lavishly illustrated by Augustus John and other artists, recounts Lawrence's experiences during the Arab Revolt in 1916 and was the inspiration for Lawrence of Arabia , directed by David Lean.

Millennium stained glass window in medieval church would look wrong, judge told

A stained glass window to celebrate the millennium would be out of place in a medieval church, Mr Justice Gage was told by the Council for the Care of Churches in a special ecclesiastical court hearing.

Parishioners thought the window at All Saints in Broughton, Cambridgeshire, costing £8,000 and depicting St Christopher carrying the infant Jesus, was an ideal way to mark 2,000 years of Christianity.

Parish council chairman John Ray said: 'Each generation has left its mark.' The court suspended judgment.

Detective constable charged with intent to supply drugs

A CID detective constable has been arrested in Norbury, south London, with three other men on suspicion of drug offences, including possession of class B drugs with intent to supply.

Six remanded in terror case

Six Algerian men were remanded in custody at London's Horseferry Road Magistrates' Court, charged with possessing computers, electronic equipment, false credit cards, false identity documents and money for terrorist use.

Runner's record hopes survive

Round-the-world runner Rob Garside may still gain a place in the Guinness Book of Records, despite admitting he bypassed sections of the route, and travelled hundreds of miles by plane.

Net clue as girl disappears

Police investigating the disappearance of Michaela Montague, 13, of Southampton, said she may have struck up a relationship with a man via an internet chatroom.

Lottery numbers

The winning numbers are 10 14 31 35 40 45, bonus 26. Thunderball numbers are 3 6 25 30 31, Thunderball 5. Lottery Extra numbers are 1 4 11 12 34 35.

New Damilola appeal

The father of murdered schoolboy Damilola Taylor yesterday appealed to a man who may have seen part of the fatal attack to come forward. Richard Taylor, 55, above, said he believed the potentially vital witness may feel guilty about not preventing the killing.

fields.headline: 'We'll quit' say RUC chiefs
fields.standfirst:
Sinn Fein demands for police board places met with resignation threat

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: Tony Blair risks provoking the resignation of the RUC's top commanders if he allows IRA prisoners to sit on Northern Ireland's new policing boards.
fields.body:
Tony Blair risks provoking the resignation of the RUC's top commanders if he allows IRA prisoners to sit on Northern Ireland's new policing boards.

Several senior officers, including an assistant chief constable, have told The Observer they will resign if the Prime Minister accepts Sinn Fein's demands for former republican prisoners to sit on the District Partnership Boards that will run the new police force at community level. Sinn Fein says it will only accept the police reform package if the ban on former paramilitary prisoners sitting on the boards is lifted.

The IRA's political allies have spent several days in secret negotiations with Jonathan Powell, Blair's chief of staff, at Downing Street. While Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness failed to reach a deal during talks at Downing Street last Thursday, discussions continue involving Powell, his Irish counterpart from Dublin's Department of Foreign Affairs, Dermot Gallagher, and republicans.

The republican movement has told Powell it will back the new policing service if its demands, which also include further powers for the policing board and a ban on plastic bullets, are met by the British Government. But the RUC's top personnel, who head a force already facing a severe loss of morale and rising sickness levels, has warned the Blair that ex-prisoners on police boards would mean the resignation of nearly all its senior commanders.

One of the most experienced officers told The Observer: 'This would be a bridge too far. For me this would be a resignation issue. The whole service, or those who remain in it, would say "that's it, that's the final finger in the eye". Making that move would produce a final collapse in the force, because we are damn near this point, in terms of morale and numbers, at present.'

Several of the officers claimed Sir Ronnie Flanagan, the RUC Chief Constable, would find it impossible to remain in charge of the force..

One officer said: 'Imagine if I went to speak to the District Policing Board on the Shankill Road in Belfast and there, sitting in front of me, was a former UDA prisoner. Given that the UDA is deeply involved in drugs, how could I start to brief the board about our drive against drug dealing with this man sitting there soaking up all the intelligence for his friends?'

Republicans argue that prisoners are often representative of the communities they live in. They claim that barring ex-prisoners from the policing boards would defeat the Patten Report's main objective - to make the police more accountable to local communities.

Meanwhile, the Adams-McGuinness leadership faces opposition to any radical move on arms from its membership in south Armagh, the most militant Provisional stronghold in Ireland. 'The Provos in south Armagh are going around saying that it doesn't matter if the British Army pulls down all its watchtowers along the border; they are not giving up a single bullet or gun in return,' one source said last night.

fields.headline: Beware bellicose Bush, Mr Blair
fields.standfirst:
His warmongering will not work
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: His warmongering will not work
fields.body:
America has just tested the limits of international law, killing and injuring a number of innocent civilians in a military adventure of dubious purpose. It has been assisted by another government, our own, which should have a much better sense of the dangerous ramifications of such an exercise of force. However, raids such as the bombing of Baghdad on Friday night have been carried out routinely for the past 10 years. What has changed is the decision of President Bush and his colleagues to court publicity for them. He is sending an early signal about how 'tough' he intends to be on rogue states like Iraq.

What this sea-change brings into sharp focus is the futility of an Anglo-American policy which has continued for a decade. Military pressure and sanctions have left Saddam Hussein more, rather than less, powerful, while seriously undermining the legitimacy of Western governments in the Middle East. We risk an Arab payback for what is seen as partisan highhandedness. We need a better policy than bombing.

President Bush sees it differently. He appears to believe that the US is encircled by danger that must be contested to the last, hence the signal to Saddam. It is part of a disturbingly unilateralist world view that extends beyond defence. This weekend, the new US Treasury Secretary, Paul O'Neill, will tell fellow finance ministers at the G7 meeting in Italy that he is unconvinced of the merits of intervention in financial crises, and of economic co-ordination generally.

In these circumstances, Tony Blair should treat Mr Bush's new administration with great caution. He wants to prove himself the loyal ally, winning the trust of the US and upstaging our own hawkish Conservative Party. But it is a dangerous policy. Bombing Iraq is purposeless. The new US National Missile Defence System, to which we fear the Government has already privately agreed, will be dangerously destabilising. And international response to financial crises is an imperative to limit the contagion of panic and financial losses.

This is not just The Observer 's view, but the view of all European governments, except our own. Mr Blair should now make common cause with the rest of Europe and assert his entitlement to shape American policy rather than be shaped by it.

fields.headline: Zimbabwe throws out journalists
fields.standfirst: Special report: Zimbabwe
fields.trailText: As part of an intensified wave of repression, Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe's government yesterday expelled two foreign journalists, giving them 24 hours to leave the country.
fields.body:
As part of an intensified wave of repression, Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe's government yesterday expelled two foreign journalists, giving them 24 hours to leave the country.

The action is the latest in a series of assaults on journalists, judges and opposition politicians.

The government yesterday revoked the work permits of Joseph Winter, correspondent for the BBC African Service, and Mercedes Sayagues, correspondent for the South African paper, the Weekly Mail and Guardian. No reason was given except that they were journalists. Immigration officials said other foreign journalists would also be kicked out of the country, but they did not give details.

Late yesterday, Zimbabwe's Information Minister Jonathan Moyo claimed that Winter's work permit was invalid because, he alleged, he had bribed an official to forge a letter on his behalf. Winter denies the allegation and those who know him dismiss the charge as absurd.

Sayagues was on business in South Africa and returned to Harare yesterday. Immigration officials initially refused to let her enter Zimbabwe but she pleaded to be allowed to be reunited with her nine-year-old daughter and so was given 24 hours to quit the country.

'As a journalist I have been reporting on human rights abuses and the general breakdown of the rule of law in Zimbabwe,' said a defiant Sayagues. 'The action taken against me is small compared to those Zimbabweans who have been murdered, tortured and beaten.'

Supporters of the Mugabe government have already beaten and threatened Zimbabwean journalists and earlier this month the printing press of the independent Daily News was destroyed in a massive bomb blast. The explosion came just hours after Moyo said the Daily News was a threat to national security and must be stopped.

In the past week the government has threatened Supreme Court judges, arrested opposition politicians on spurious charges and sent troops into Harare's townships to beat residents at random.

Confronted by widespread unpopularity and a rapidly declining economy, Mugabe and his Zanu-PF party are attacking all critics.

By threatening judges and encouraging them to resign, the Mugabe government has carried out what lawyers call 'a coup against the judiciary'. Three hundred of Mugabe's war veterans invaded the Supreme Court and forced the five judges to flee. The judges have received death threats and been excoriated in the state press by Mugabe and ministers.

Supreme Court Chief Justice Anthony Gubbay succumbed to the pressure and resigned. But the other Supreme Court judges are making a stand against the government. Justice Nick McNally refused to accept early retirement. Justices Wilson Sandura and Simbarashe Muchechetere refused to meet with Justice Minister Patrick Chinamasa.

Zimbabwe's Supreme Court has been admirably independent and in December issued carefully considered reversals to Mugabe's 'fast track' land seizures, ordering police to remove thousands of Mugabe's supporters from lands they were occupying illegally.

In January the Supreme Court ruled unconstitutional Mugabe's amendment to the Electoral Act which stated that no legal challenge could be made to the results of parliamentary elections. The Movement for Democratic Change (MDC) is pressing court cases against the results of 40 parliamentary seats with strong evidence of state-sponsored violence, intimidation and fraud.

The MDC's president, Morgan Tsvangirai, was on Thursday charged with inciting violence against the president, along with four MDC members of parliament. In September Tsvangirai said, 'We call on Mugabe to resign peacefully or he will risk being overthrown violently.' They all deny the charges.

Related story
'I've been caught up in a hurricane'

fields.headline: Bush signals a deadly intent
fields.standfirst:
Once again, Saddam may be the real victor of the latest Anglo-US air strikes that strain further the dwindling support of their allies

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: Once again, Saddam may be the real victor of the latest Anglo-US  air strikes that strain further the dwindling support of their allies.
fields.byline: Jason Burke and Ed Vulliamy in New York
fields.body:
Just before 9pm on Friday night the air raid sirens once again howled out over Baghdad. There were a few cars speeding on the empty roads, the cafés by the banks of the River Tigris were full but, on the whole, the city was quiet.

In fact, the sirens, and the streams of flaring tracer that the Iraqi air defences spat into the air, were too late. The 24 planes sent by Britain and the United States to teach Saddam Hussein yet another lesson were already screaming back to their bases in Saudi Arabia or lining up to land on the USS Harry S.Truman bobbing in the Gulf. Using high-tech 'stand-off' missiles the warplanes had not needed to approach the city to unleash their attack. Their missiles slammed into five command and control centres used, claim Washington and London, to co-ordinate Iraq's air defences.

The sky flaring against the black silhouettes of Baghdad's palm trees served as a giant noticeboard for America's new president. The message, to Saddam, to the Middle East, to the world, was plain to see.

But for the people of Baghdad the message is an old one. As the dull thump of the explosions shook the city, small crowds gathered in the streets. The impact of the strikes was discussed and analysed. Then, with the night growing chill, the groups broke up and went home to bed.

Washington and London has been predictably upbeat. Unmanned spotter planes sent up in the wake of the attack revealed that 'all weapons hit their targets successfully', the Ministry of Defence in London said.

Baghdad said two people were killed and 11, including several children, were injured. London briefed that they were more likely to have been hit by falling anti-aircraft ordnance than anything else. At first glance the damage, on both sides, seemed relatively slight.

But yesterday, as worldwide reaction to the strikes proved almost unanimously negative and there were demonstrations against America and in support of Saddam across the Arab world, the real impact of the strikes looked ominous.

In the last 36 hours Geoff Hoon, the Defence Secretary, and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook have rammed home the justification for the attacks in interviews.

The strikes were necessary to eliminate a threat to the planes patrolling the 'no-fly zones' in the north and south of Iraq, they said. The zones were imposed after the 1991 war to protect the Shi'ite Muslims and Marsh Arabs in the south, and the Kurds in the north, from repression by Saddam. The dictator has a history of appalling violence against both groups. When they rebelled against Baghdad after the Gulf War, having been promised support from the Americans, they were brutally crushed. The no-fly zones, which do not have a UN mandate, were imposed to help them.

Thus Hoon's oft-repeated claim that Friday's strikes were 'humanitarian'.

In the last 10 years US and UK planes have flown tens of thousands of sorties over Iraq. Their rules of engagement state that when they are 'locked on to' by anti-aircraft (AA) missiles, of which the Iraqis still have many, they can fight back. Though there has been significant degradation of Baghdad's AA defences, there has been 'collateral damage' as well. It is thought that more than 140 civilians have been killed by British and US missiles and hundreds more injured. Earlier this year, a missile hit a veterinarian clinic and killed, the Iraqis claimed, six people. Previous errors have included a sheep dip targeted after it was mistaken for a surface-to-air missile launch site.

The fault is not entirely with the pilots. The Iraqis routinely conceal their military hardware among civilians. Shortly after the last set of raids The Observer saw guns concealed in a university.

The plans for Friday's attack originated with officers in the US Central Command who patrol the no-fly zone. For them, Bush's election was welcome.

The past six months has seen intensified Iraqi activity. By one analysis, Saddam's forces have fired more missiles in the last year than in the previous nine. The missiles were also coming closer, with pilots reporting an increasing number of 'trips' - near-misses from AA missiles felt by those in the cockpit.

Intelligence revealed that the Iraqis had recently linked their missile batteries with fibre-optic cables greatly increasing their efficiency.

But the political tide seemed to be flowing in a different direction. Instead of escalation, Clinton's preferred tactic had been to scale back the patrols to avoid clashes.

But since Bush's inauguration on 20 January, the attacks on Iraqi anti-aircraft targets have been ramped up again. There had been nine attacks on Iraqi anti-aircraft targets south of the 33rd parallel, which had not needed presidential approval, before Friday's strike.

The recommendation to strike at the five command and communications centres above the 33rd parallel - the limit of the no-fly zones - originated with the commanders in the Gulf at the beginning of the week.

By Tuesday night, the Pentagon top strata were briefing the new Defence Secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, who then spoke to Vice-President Dick Cheney by telephone.

Cheney asked Bush about the strike during a meeting on Wednesday morning, and continued to talk with his friend and colleague Rumsfeld during the rest of the day.

Early on Thursday , Cheney received a second lengthy briefing during the drive from his suburban Virginia home into Washington.

That morning, the full facts and recommendations were laid out before the President. Bush, Cheney, Rumsfeld, Secretary of State Colin Powell and National Security Adviser Condoleeza Rice all discussed the proposals. The President retired for 20 minutes, and then gave his assent to the strike.

As Bush stepped off Air Force One at the airport in León, Mexico, for his first foreign trip at 9am on Friday, he knew the jets were fuelling up and ready to go.

Throughout his election campaign, Bush had sent out strong signals that he regarded the Clinton administration's policy towards Iraq as bankrupt.

'The strongest impression I have of Bush,' said Thomas Mann, analyst with the Brookings Institution, 'is that what he says before the election is very relevant to what he does after it.'

Significantly, Bush made no changes to his agenda and even sought to play down the attack on Iraq during his fleeting trip to Mexico. He stuck rigidly to the programme he had agreed with Mexican President Vicente Fox. It sent another clear signal. Concerned though he might be to tackle Saddam - and by implication the problems in distant parts - his priority was still closer to home: relations across the Americas.

Quite when the British became involved in the planning of the strikes is unclear. A Foreign Office source said yesterday that because British pilots fly alongside their American counterparts senior UK officers were on board from the start. But analysts say that London probably learnt of US intentions after Cheney's Thursday morning briefing.

Though Cook visited Washington last week and discussed Iraq at length with Powell, it is not thought that the plan was then on the table. Powell has spoken of his desire to 're-energise' the crumbling and deeply unpopular sanctions regime against Iraq and, sources say, much of the discussion between the two men centred on ways to bring global opinion round behind the UN embargo.

Powell clearly understood that, notwithstanding the ideological differences between Tony Blair and Bush, the commitment to a hard line on Iraq was unshaken. Cook is unlikely to have thought that his word would be tested quite so soon.

Hoon was contacted by the Americans on Thursday night. He spoke to the Prime Minister and consultations with the Americans and British defence staff continued through the night. By mid-afternoon in the UK, the planes were heading for their targets.

Next week Blair will visit Washington. The trip is designed to publicly announce that the 'special relationship' across the Atlantic is still very much alive.

This weekend Bush will be glad of it. Although the Americans could easily do without the British military input, London's involvment provides critical diplomatic support. Other than the UK, and Israel, even allies like Turkey - from whose airbases the jets that patrol the northern no-fly zone take off - have been critical of Friday's attacks. The continued threat of Saddam's non-conventional weapons programme or territorial ambitions is no longer enough to scare states into supporting Washington. The days of the Gulf War coalition are long gone.

Within Iraq, strikes only make Saddam stronger. There is now almost a generation of young people who have grown up with war. Many young adults can hardly remember the days when Britain and America were seen as friends of the Iraqi people. There is even, among older Iraqis, a residual respect for the British. But in the schools the children are taught a doctrine of hate. And every strike plays into Saddam's hands.

'We tell our pupils the truth,' one teacher in a Baghdad school told The Observer last month. 'We tell them that the British and the Americans are together in a Zionist-run plot to destroy our president because he is a leader of the Arab and Muslim people. And all the attacks are evidence of that truth.'

Given their own ruler's vicious nature, most Iraqis believe that the people of Britain do not share their leaders' hawkish views. But that may change. Saddam has embarked on a deliberate 'Islamisation' campaign aimed at boosting his credentials as a Muslim leader and radicalising youth. His calls for 'jihad' against Israel have increasing resonance both inside Iraq and in the region.

And his grasp on power seems as tight as ever. His hated intelligence services still operate with horrific efficiency. Mass executions have recently purged prisons. There have been a series of 'ethnic cleansing' operations to clear out potentially dissident Kurds and other minorities from several central cities.

'There won't be a coup,' one Iraqi dissident living in London said yesterday. 'Because you need at least two people for a coup. And in Iraq now one will always betray the other before he's betrayed himself.'

The new American administration has made it clear that it regards the Iraqi opposition - all, of course, in exile - as their best hope to depose Iraq.

But few analysts rate the chances of Washington's prefered successors very highly. In the last decade they have received millions of dollars in aid and achieved virtually nothing. The lavish headquarters they have maintained in London has been a focus of controversy and their recent plan, backed by the Clinton administration, for a leafletting campaign in the north of the country, was seen as risible. No one sees them as a serious threat.

Economically, Saddam's position is as good as it has been for years. He is now an extraordinarily rich man with a private fortune estimated at £4 billion, largely derived from oil smuggling. His power within Iraq is bolstered by a new stratum of rich middle-class businessmen, many of whom have made their money exploiting the sanctions regime. And his diplomatic standing is better than at any time before the invasion of Kuwait that sparked the Gulf War.

Every time Iraq is attacked, Saddam foresakes his palaces and heads for one of a number of nondescript private houses in suburban Baghdad. No one knows his exact location but, wherever he is, he will be smiling.

In the last 36 hours Geoff Hoon, the Defence Secretary, and Foreign Secretary Robin Cook have rammed home the justification for the attacks in interviews. The strikes were necessary to eliminate a threat to the planes patrolling the 'no-fly zones' in the north and south of Iraq, they said. The zones were imposed after the 1991 war to protect the Shi'ite Muslims and Marsh Arabs in the south, and the Kurds in the north, from repression by Saddam. The dictator has a history of appalling violence against both groups. When they rebelled against Baghdad after the Gulf War, having been promised support from the Americans, they were brutally crushed. The no-fly zones, which do not have a UN mandate, were imposed to help them. Thus Hoon's oft-repeated claim that Friday's strikes were 'humanitarian'. In the last 10 years US and UK planes have flown tens of thousands of sorties over Iraq. Their rules of engagement state that when they are 'locked on to' by anti-aircraft (AA) missiles, of which the Iraqis still have many, they can fight back. Though there has been significant degradation of Baghdad's AA defences, there has been 'collateral damage' as well. It is thought that more than 140 civilians have been killed by British and US missiles and hundreds more injured. Earlier this year, a missile hit a veterinarian clinic and killed, the Iraqis claimed, six people. Previous errors have included a sheep dip targeted after it was mistaken for a surface-to-air missile launch site. The fault is not entirely with the pilots. The Iraqis routinely conceal their military hardware among civilians. Shortly after the last set of raids The Observer saw guns concealed in a university. The plans for Friday's attack originated with officers in the US Central Command who patrol the no-fly zone. For them, Bush's election was welcome. The past six months has seen intensified Iraqi activity. By one analysis, Saddam's forces have fired more missiles in the last year than in the previous nine. The missiles were also coming closer, with pilots reporting an increasing number of 'trips' - near-misses from AA missiles felt by those in the cockpit. Intelligence revealed that the Iraqis had recently linked their missile batteries with fibre-optic cables greatly increasing their efficiency. But the political tide seemed to be flowing in a different direction. Instead of escalation, Clinton's preferred tactic had been to scale back the patrols to avoid clashes. But since Bush's inauguration on 20 January, the attacks on Iraqi anti-aircraft targets have been ramped up again. There had been nine attacks on Iraqi anti-aircraft targets south of the 33rd parallel, which had not needed presidential approval, before Friday's strike. The recommendation to strike at the five command and communications centres above the 33rd parallel - the limit of the no-fly zones - originated with the commanders in the Gulf at the beginning of the week. By Tuesday night, the Pentagon top strata were briefing the new Defence Secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, who then spoke to Vice-President Dick Cheney by telephone. Cheney asked Bush about the strike during a meeting on Wednesday morning, and continued to talk with his friend and colleague Rumsfeld during the rest of the day. Early on Thursday , Cheney received a second lengthy briefing during the drive from his suburban Virginia home into Washington. That morning, the full facts and recommendations were laid out before the President. Bush, Cheney, Rumsfeld, Secretary of State Colin Powell and National Security Adviser Condoleeza Rice all discussed the proposals. The President retired for 20 minutes, and then gave his assent to the strike. As Bush stepped off Air Force One at the airport in León, Mexico, for his first foreign trip at 9am on Friday, he knew the jets were fuelling up and ready to go. Throughout his election campaign, Bush had sent out strong signals that he regarded the Clinton administration's policy towards Iraq as bankrupt. 'The strongest impression I have of Bush,' said Thomas Mann, analyst with the Brookings Institution, 'is that what he says before the election is very relevant to what he does after it.' Significantly, Bush made no changes to his agenda and even sought to play down the attack on Iraq during his fleeting trip to Mexico. He stuck rigidly to the programme he had agreed with Mexican President Vicente Fox. It sent another clear signal. Concerned though he might be to tackle Saddam - and by implication the problems in distant parts - his priority was still closer to home: relations across the Americas. Quite when the British became involved in the planning of the strikes is unclear. A Foreign Office source said yesterday that because British pilots fly alongside their American counterparts senior UK officers were on board from the start. But analysts say that London probably learnt of US intentions after Cheney's Thursday morning briefing. Though Cook visited Washington last week and discussed Iraq at length with Powell, it is not thought that the plan was then on the table. Powell has spoken of his desire to 're-energise' the crumbling and deeply unpopular sanctions regime against Iraq and, sources say, much of the discussion between the two men centred on ways to bring global opinion round behind the UN embargo. Powell clearly understood that, notwithstanding the ideological differences between Tony Blair and Bush, the commitment to a hard line on Iraq was unshaken. Cook is unlikely to have thought that his word would be tested quite so soon. Hoon was contacted by the Americans on Thursday night. He spoke to the Prime Minister and consultations with the Americans and British defence staff continued through the night. By mid-afternoon in the UK, the planes were heading for their targets. Next week Blair will visit Washington. The trip is designed to publicly announce that the 'special relationship' across the Atlantic is still very much alive. This weekend Bush will be glad of it. Although the Americans could easily do without the British military input, London's involvment provides critical diplomatic support. Other than the UK, and Israel, even allies like Turkey - from whose airbases the jets that patrol the northern no-fly zone take off - have been critical of Friday's attacks. The continued threat of Saddam's non-conventional weapons programme or territorial ambitions is no longer enough to scare states into supporting Washington. The days of the Gulf War coalition are long gone. Within Iraq, strikes only make Saddam stronger. There is now almost a generation of young people who have grown up with war. Many young adults can hardly remember the days when Britain and America were seen as friends of the Iraqi people. There is even, among older Iraqis, a residual respect for the British. But in the schools the children are taught a doctrine of hate. And every strike plays into Saddam's hands. 'We tell our pupils the truth,' one teacher in a Baghdad school told The Observer last month. 'We tell them that the British and the Americans are together in a Zionist-run plot to destroy our president because he is a leader of the Arab and Muslim people. And all the attacks are evidence of that truth.' Given their own ruler's vicious nature, most Iraqis believe that the people of Britain do not share their leaders' hawkish views. But that may change. Saddam has embarked on a deliberate 'Islamisation' campaign aimed at boosting his credentials as a Muslim leader and radicalising youth. His calls for 'jihad' against Israel have increasing resonance both inside Iraq and in the region. And his grasp on power seems as tight as ever. His hated intelligence services still operate with horrific efficiency. Mass executions have recently purged prisons. There have been a series of 'ethnic cleansing' operations to clear out potentially dissident Kurds and other minorities from several central cities. 'There won't be a coup,' one Iraqi dissident living in London said yesterday. 'Because you need at least two people for a coup. And in Iraq now one will always betray the other before he's betrayed himself.' The new American administration has made it clear that it regards the Iraqi opposition - all, of course, in exile - as their best hope to depose Iraq. But few analysts rate the chances of Washington's prefered successors very highly. In the last decade they have received millions of dollars in aid and achieved virtually nothing. The lavish headquarters they have maintained in London has been a focus of controversy and their recent plan, backed by the Clinton administration, for a leafletting campaign in the north of the country, was seen as risible. No one sees them as a serious threat. Economically, Saddam's position is as good as it has been for years. He is now an extraordinarily rich man with a private fortune estimated at £4 billion, largely derived from oil smuggling. His power within Iraq is bolstered by a new stratum of rich middle-class businessmen, many of whom have made their money exploiting the sanctions regime. And his diplomatic standing is better than at any time before the invasion of Kuwait that sparked the Gulf War. Every time Iraq is attacked, Saddam foresakes his palaces and heads for one of a number of nondescript private houses in suburban Baghdad. No one knows his exact location but, wherever he is, he will be smiling.

webTitle: Will Hutton: We can love the euro - I proved it

fields.headline: We can love the euro - I proved it
fields.standfirst:
Will Hutton feared the worst when he was asked to campaign for a BBC mini-referendum in a London street. But after a weekend of knocking on doors...

The Euro debate - Observer special
fields.trailText: Will Hutton feared the worst when he was asked to campaign for a BBC mini-referendum in a London street. But after a weekend of knocking on doors...
fields.body:
It was when Tracey Tait waved to me to say she had not changed her mind - and yes she would still be voting in favour of the euro - that I first dared to hope that we could do better than achieving a pro-euro swing. We might even win the mini referendum.

I had been asked in November by the BBC to be team leader for the pro-euro case in a mini referendum campaign to be undertaken over a week-end in a street whose opinions and socio-economic characteristics more or less matched those of the country where support is consistently two to one against the euro.

We would canvass and leaflet just as in a national referendum. I had insisted that we construct a team that was evenly composed of men and women and as young as possible; as the pro-euro side is funkier, younger and more open than the antis, I thought we should try to look that way - although with me in the team we already had a serious deficiency in the age and looks department.

People were listening. They were hungry for information, especially the young - and even more especially young women. What was more extraordinary they were coming over to us because they didn't like the xenophobic cloud of union jackery and reverence to the ageing gods of Britishness from the antis that just hours earlier had seemed like an insuperable block to our case. I had underestimated the British.

It was one of our earlier converts - Andrew Dewsall - who put it best. Going in to the euro made more economic sense than staying out. As for Britishness, he didn't want to be part of a culture that defined his identity as putting on Union Jack boxer trunks on the beach in Corfu, harping on about the war and regarding the European Union as a foreign plot.

Austin Mitchell had just canvassed him wearing his Union Jack tie; the antis can't see it, but it is precisely because people's patriotism runs deep that they recoil from tasteless stage props such as Union Jack ties. Their patriotism is much more quiet, discrete and anchored.

In the event it was a 23 per cent swing; 58 per cent of Referendum Street voting for the euro and only 42 per cent against. The opposition to the euro might be extensive, but it's shallow.

But it didn't feel that way when we started last Saturday morning. Lembit Opik, the LibDem MP, was paired with Marcelle D'Argy Smith, the former editor of Cosmopolitan. Tony Banks would join us on Sunday to canvass with Sara Priem of the Young European Movement. And I paired up with Julia Gash, a thirtysomething lingerie designer whose business has been decimated by the high pound.

We sallied forth down Referendum Street - a street off Southgate high street in North London - to meet our first voter. The six antis were led by David Mellor and included the Daily Mail's Simon Heffer and a self-consciously political Tory MEP, Teresa Villiers. With Labour's Mitchell they were cross-party, and we thought (wrongly) that their Britain-should-not-give-up-what-works-for-an-eurofudge-and-lose-sovereignty line would play pretty well.

Julia and I found our first five or six encounters pretty depressing. Our argument was that the euro was good for manufacturing jobs, interest rates and investment; moreover it would strike a blow against rip-off Britain by promoting genuine price comparisons with mainland Europe.

Julia's own business experiences, increasingly having to invoice in euros, personally accepting an exchange rate risk even while her goods were being priced out of overseas markets, were pretty sobering. We said that although we could see it was a risk going in, staying out was also a risk. We accepted that sometimes one interest rate would not be suitable for every country, but that the gains for Britain and Europe as a whole would more than compensate for individual country's problems.

As for the sovereignty the sceptics said we were losing, it was illusory; Britain had no more control over the exchange rate in today's world of vast capital movements than Canute had over the tide. The choice was whether we wanted faceless foreign exchange speculators setting the value of the pound or the stability of the European Central Bank. Europe is no more than a club in which like-minded countries in a similar position get together to achieve common ends that can't be achieved alone - like having a stable currency and consistently low interest rates.

Unsurprisingly, I think these arguments - on balance - make the case for entry pretty overwhelming. But try them on a working-class couple like Rosalind and John Wheeler and you quickly get disabused. He's a Tottenham supporter, a Daily Mail reader and a warehouseman. For all the complaint about lack of debate etc. the Wheelers were really clued up, and they fired back replies for our every point.

I tried telling him that if Tottenham were successfully to compete in European football competitions it wouldn't make the club any less English, and the FA didn't think it was losing sovereignty by being part of UEFA - and for the first time his sceptic flow was checked. Not for long though; like others we canvassed earlier he was engulfed in suspicion of all things foreign. 1945 lives on.

Then we hit gold; Tracey Tait and Victoria Knight, two highly intelligent young working-class women, were soft antis - but they carried none of the baggage about the Union Jack, the war and even Elgar. They wanted information. Like a lot of those we canvassed, they felt they had never heard the pro argument. Within 15 minutes they had come over to us. It was common sense, they said.

Seeing people respond to your argument is a great feeling - and I saw the buzz that politicians must get. But it was when someone in the lunchtime crowd shouted at a heckler that it was time to put the war behind us, that I first began to feel opinion really changing. The roots of too much euroscepticism is sheer nastiness - and British tolerance runs deeper still.

In the aftermath of the vote a lot of blame was heaped on the hapless Mellor, and it is true that one of the reasons the sceptics lost is that they were not as personable as the pros. But this will reproduce itself in a real referendum; scepticism is a darker credo than the sunnier worldview of the pros - and this comes through in the style, culture and personality-type attracted to the twin camps.

Yes is more open than No. What was also impressive was the way young people would listen, and the way they soaked up information. And while the British are profoundly patriotic, they are not nationalist in the simple fashion portrayed by the sceptics. An electorate this small is hardly representative, but the result is an important pointer. With leadership and conviction the pros could win a referendum. Tony Blair and Gordon Brown please note.

Related story
How to make sense of the euro debate

webTitle: Comment: Sing if you're glad to be grey

fields.headline: Sing if you're glad to be grey
fields.standfirst: While the rich over-50s are getting richer, their poorer peers face a future of poverty and isolation
fields.trailText: While the rich over-50s are getting richer, their poorer peers face a future of poverty and isolation.
fields.body:
Baroness Jay is to stand down from the Cabinet to see more of her granddaughter and, as an incidental bonus, fewer of the irksome headlines that have dogged her during her time as Leader of the Lords. Not that snipers are likely to have deterred her. At 61, she simply wishes to achieve what an aide calls a 'better work/life balance'. What an emblem she will be at a time when the stereotypes of creeping age are dead. Whatever balance Lady Jay achieves, it is unlikely to feature midweek bingo and holidays in Frinton. She will not be expected to peruse, for as long as the cataracts hold off, adverts for Dr Werner's denture fixative, pre-arranged funerals, incontinence pads, stairlifts and sunshine homes for the terminally confused.

These days, the elderly call the shots. Shops and service providers target the grey pound. Politicians court the grey vote, and the discriminatory notion that employers must force people to leave when they become eligible for the state pension expired last week. From 2006, it will be illegal, under EU law, to stipulate a compulsory retirement date in an employment contract. This provision, hailed as upholding human rights, also gets the country out of a hole. There are now four workers for every pensioner. By 2050, without a rise in retirement age or an immigration total of one million a year, the ratio will be two to one.

By then, a quarter of Britons will be over 65. Already, the over-50s represent one third of the UK population, have a collective income of £166 billion, hold 80 per cent of Britain's wealth and 60 per cent of UK savings. In short, they are loaded. Retailers fawn on them, while failing to establish what this strange, new breed wants or needs. A contributor to a recent anthology called The Definitive Guide to Mature Advertising And Marketing solemnly advises that home-shopping catalogues targeted at oldies should offer dress sizes up to 34, footwear of an EEE fitting and expandable trousers. 'Today's 50 year olds have worn jeans for 30-plus years,' the author (clearly a student of the T. Blair informal dress code) writes. 'Consequently, success is gained by flattering youthful aspirations and offering jeans with discreet side elastication for extra comfort.'

How misunderstood the ageing are. For a start, 50 seems quite young to anyone but a creative director or a fruit fly. In addition, oldies do not, in general, have feet broader than telephone directories and bottoms resembling mattresses. They are, instead, skipping round like Baroness Jay and compiling a new lifestyle portfolio, or booking Saga cruises to the Galapagos, or brushing up on their golf swing or Mandarin. It is hard to see why this vibrant Sanatogen set should not carry on working, particularly since a retirement age of 65, or 60 for women, was established in Britain half a century ago to fit the narrow span between the gold watch and the grave.

Now, according to a report by the Centre for Policy Studies, the Government's promise to pay the basic state pension to future pensioners represents an unrecognised liability of £1,000bn. The longer people work, the less acute the pensions problem becomes. But the calculation also involves well-being. Last week, the Guardian held up Bobby Robson, 67, and John Mortimer, 77, as examples of contented older workers who, but for their choice of football and writing, would have been out on their ears long ago. Instead, Mr Mortimer's life seems a pleasant round of parties and book signings and languorous champagne lunches.

No doubt Lincolnshire beetroot-picklers or conductors on the Kilburn night bus or stressed-out teachers would also be delighted to put in a few extra years if the Krug and hours were right. Whether headteachers want to take up Margaret Hodge's kind suggestion of a classroom job after 65 'to lessen the pressure as they got older' seems quite another matter.

For now, sticking around is rarely encouraged. Unwanted executives step aside at 55 with a fat pension and a mutual sigh of relief. Good policemen rarely stay beyond 50 because, under existing pension rules, it would be financial suicide to do so. Whitehall despatches its employees at 60, while others simply get booted out when they are deemed to have reached their use-by date. Only 37 per cent of men still work by the age of 64, and the Louis MacNiece axiom - 'Sit on your arse for 40 years and hang your hat on a pension' - is for serious time-servers only.

Reversing the pattern will be hard, not least because many who can afford it quite like the idea of 30 years of indolence. Change may, despite pious talk of rights and choice, involve compulsion. For Britain to retain the same balance between workers and retired people over the next half century would mean raising the retirement age to 72. Already Iceland's threshold is 70, Norway's and Denmark's is 67, and in Italy, where the birth rate is dropping faster than anywhere in Europe, workers regularly slog on until 75. Whatever compact Britain eventually reaches - hopefully more immigration, a move towards funded pensions and encouraging, but not forcing, people to work longer - its success will depend on making the poorest better valued and rewarded.

The new spotlight on old people gleams on a supposedly homogeneous breed. They, increasingly, are the dominant workers, consumers and electors. An Age Concern survey last week showed that six million elderly voters have still not decided which party to support. In 1997, 38 per cent backed Labour and 29 per cent Tory. If that position were reversed - as it was in a Gallup poll last summer - Labour would have won 349 seats instead of 418. No wonder both Hague and Blair are full of blandishments for the elderly. Labour's deal, skewed longer-term towards helping the poorest, is brave considering what is at stake. It is also the only solution.

Old age is not synonymous with poverty any more. Over the past 20 years, pensioners have done twice as well as the general population. But while share-owning and occupational and personal pensions have underpinned a 60 per cent growth in income, the divide between rich and poor has widened dramatically. That gap must be narrowed now, not only for fairness but also, more expediently, because this is perhaps the last generation of pensioners that will vote for altruism.

Affluent older people are the volunteers - the cancer-shop workers or meals-on-wheels deliverers - who see the poverty among those of their peers who get the worst NHS treatments, a pitiful pension and a life of isolation imposed, in part, by an abysmal transport system. The next generation of wealthy pensioners will be a Peter Pan collection of gym-toned, cryogenically-preserved, smooth-browed Eminem fans whose long juggling of the 'work/life balance' may blind them to the fact that others have little life and less work to weigh.

The world grows older by the minute, The future is grey. There is nothing alarming in that evolution, beyond the fact that if the current gulf persists, a twenty-first century population composed of sprightly, globe-bestriding, vitamin-popping, nine-to-five-working octogenarians will only be camouflage for a society increasingly polarised between rich and poor.

For Britain to retain the same balance between workers and retired people over the next half century would mean raising the retirement age to 72. Already Iceland's threshold is 70, Norway's and Denmark's is 67, and in Italy, where the birth rate is dropping faster than anywhere in Europe, workers regularly slog on until 75. Whatever compact Britain eventually reaches - hopefully more immigration, a move towards funded pensions and encouraging, but not forcing, people to work longer - its success will depend on making the poorest better valued and rewarded. The new spotlight on old people gleams on a supposedly homogeneous breed. They, increasingly, are the dominant workers, consumers and electors. An Age Concern survey last week showed that six million elderly voters have still not decided which party to support. In 1997, 38 per cent backed Labour and 29 per cent Tory. If that position were reversed - as it was in a Gallup poll last summer - Labour would have won 349 seats instead of 418. No wonder both Hague and Blair are full of blandishments for the elderly. Labour's deal, skewed longer-term towards helping the poorest, is brave considering what is at stake. It is also the only solution. Old age is not synonymous with poverty any more. Over the past 20 years, pensioners have done twice as well as the general population. But while share-owning and occupational and personal pensions have underpinned a 60 per cent growth in income, the divide between rich and poor has widened dramatically. That gap must be narrowed now, not only for fairness but also, more expediently, because this is perhaps the last generation of pensioners that will vote for altruism. Affluent older people are the volunteers - the cancer-shop workers or meals-on-wheels deliverers - who see the poverty among those of their peers who get the worst NHS treatments, a pitiful pension and a life of isolation imposed, in part, by an abysmal transport system. The next generation of wealthy pensioners will be a Peter Pan collection of gym-toned, cryogenically-preserved, smooth-browed Eminem fans whose long juggling of the 'work/life balance' may blind them to the fact that others have little life and less work to weigh. The world grows older by the minute, The future is grey. There is nothing alarming in that evolution, beyond the fact that if the current gulf persists, a twenty-first century population composed of sprightly, globe-bestriding, vitamin-popping, nine-to-five-working octogenarians will only be camouflage for a society increasingly polarised between rich and poor.

fields.headline: Vale thwart rivals
fields.standfirst: Stoke City O'Connor 55   Port Vale Brammer 81 att: 22,133 :   1 1
fields.trailText: The passion-fuelled nature of derbies can often confound the form book, and so it proved in this meeting of the Potteries rivals. For much of the game it was difficult to gauge who was fifth from the top and who was five places from the bottom.
fields.byline: Mike Prestage at the Britannia Stadium
fields.body:
The passion-fuelled nature of derbies can often confound the form book, and so it proved in this meeting of the Potteries rivals. For much of the game it was difficult to gauge who was fifth from the top and who was five places from the bottom.

Certainly the recent fortunes of the sides should have ensured Port Vale were in for a difficult afternoon but David Brammer's goal nine minutes from time - equalising James O'Connor's strike on 55 minutes - was no more than Vale deserved in front of the biggest crowd in the Second Division this season.

Vale had made the livelier start. Tony Naylor had the two best chances of the first half but sadly for the visitors he squandered both.

The first came after Onandi Lowe put Naylor clear. He could have shot first time but instead he opted to beat Brynjar Gunnarsson before shooting and his effort was saved by Birkir Kristinsson at his right hand post.

It was Lowe who again put Naylor clear in the 45th minute and though he beat the keeper, his miscued shot was cleared by Graham Kavanagh.

But just as their fans appeared to have been silenced Stoke broke the deadlock 10 minutes after the break when O'Connor met a Tony Dorigo cross with a powerful header into the net.

Having conceded just one goal in more than 600 minutes of football at the Britannia, Stoke might have been forgiven for thinking that victory was in the bag. Vale had other ideas nine from time. Naylor was the provider and his inch-perfect crossfield pass found Brammer in acres of space and he advanced into the penalty box to score.
