fields.headline: Spurs stay on route one
fields.standfirst: Tottenham Hotspur King 5, Davies 30 50, Flynn 44og   Stockport County att: 36,040 :   4 0
fields.trailText: although the chant of 'Spurs are on the their way to Cardiff' had an unfamiliar ring to it, anyone with the slightest inkling about Tottenham's FA Cup history realises exactly why they cannot help singing new versions of old Wembley final favourites at White Hart Lane.
fields.byline: Amy Lawrence at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
although the chant of 'Spurs are on the their way to Cardiff' had an unfamiliar ring to it, anyone with the slightest inkling about Tottenham's FA Cup history realises exactly why they cannot help singing new versions of old Wembley final favourites at White Hart Lane.

George Graham may not be a man who believes in omens. But it is hard not to ponder portents considering what has happened to Spurs since encountering their favourite number. Now that the season has turned into 01 they have been unbeaten, have finally discovered how to win on their travels, and have fortune on their side. They do in the FA Cup anyway, given their unexpected recovery from a 2-0 deficit at Charlton in the last round, before enjoying the luck of the draw with a home tie against lower League opponents hit by an outbreak of flu. As a route into the last eight, this proved the easiest of passages.

So, there is plenty for Tottenham to cheer. Graham's men are playing with bountiful confidence, and the progress being made by a clutch of youngsters is particularly promising. While Gary Doherty and Ledley King are virtually established in the first team, yesterday the home crowd witnessed the coming of age of another stylish performer. Simon Davies crowned a composed performance with two outstanding goals.

The biggest upset was the fact that Tottenham had allowed access to a man from the Daily Mail .

The gulf in class told early - £11 million international Sergei Rebrov took on the 17-year-old County defender Rob Clare en route to the box. No contest. The consequent free-kick was floated in by Stephen Clemence and King applied the gentlest of glances to squeeze home the opening goal.

Did Stockport have a chance of getting backat Tottenham? The less savoury method was evident in Mike Flynn's violent dig at Oyvind Leonhardsen's shin (the Norwegian was soon forced to limp off). Otherwise, they managed a reasonable amount of possession and showed plenty of endeavour. They posed a threat in the air, but Tottenham possessed enough know-how to cope.

The contest was all but over by the half-hour mark when Rebrov scooped the ball towards Les Ferdinand, whose headed lob was finished with a flourish by the substitute Davies. The 21-year-old signed from Peterborough outmanoeuvred two defenders and created space for himself with a shrewd flick of the head, before driving low and and hard past Lee Jones.

County almost gave themselves a lifeline when Shefki Kuqi diverted a corner a fraction over the crossbar, but Stockport hopes were dashed once and for all a minute before half-time. Rebrov fed Luke Young down the right flank, whose whipped-in cross was prodded home by the only man lurking in the six-yard box: County captain Flynn, he of the horror tackle on Leonhardsen.

From hereon in it was merely a case of how much Tottenham wanted to enjoy their stroll into the quarter-finals. Davies took his second goal with aplomb, latching on to Tim Sherwood's lofted pass before finding the bottom corner with a sweet strike.

Stockport displayed sufficient battling qualities to keep the score respectable and their corner of supporters in good spirits. But it was the Tottenham masses who went home happiest.

There is, though, clearly more work to be done and lucky draws to be had. After all, Tottenham have never won anything when the year begins in two.

fields.headline: Saints kept at bay
fields.standfirst: Southampton  Tranmere Rovers att: 15,110 :   0 0
fields.trailText: Struggling Tranmere go into the draw for the quarter-finals of the FA Cup for the second successive season on a day when they also slipped to the bottom of the First Division. But this result against Premiership opposition should allow them to forget briefly about their First Division survival plight, at least until after Tuesday's replay at Prenton Park.
fields.body:
Struggling Tranmere go into the draw for the quarter-finals of the FA Cup for the second successive season on a day when they also slipped to the bottom of the First Division. But this result against Premiership opposition should allow them to forget briefly about their First Division survival plight, at least until after Tuesday's replay at Prenton Park.

Southampton manager Glenn Hoddle crowned Tranmere the cup kings before the game, mindful that they had collected six Premiership scalps in their past 16 months of cup football.

Tranmere are in serious danger of being relegated, but they play at a different level away from the grind of the League, and Hoddle had hoped to ensure his players were alert to the threat.

The message took a while to get through. Tranmere started the better team and former Southampton forward Paul Rideout missed an excellent chance to give them the lead after only two minutes.

Now the Southampton players knew Hoddle had not been exaggerating and they recovered from that early jolt to take some control of the game through sheer hard work. Hassan Kachloul was guilty of wasting two good chances in the air and he also finished one of Southampton's two disallowed efforts for offside in the opening 15 minutes.

Tranmere had lost Clint Hill to an injury by then and could have buckled, but they kept their cool and it took a superb save from Paul Jones to keep out an Andy Parkinson shot.

Southampton still looked the stronger side, but Tranmere gained further confi dence from a good start to the second half and there was little in the pattern of play to indicate at which end a goal would come, if at all.

There was no real rhythm to the game and the flow was further disrupted when Southampton's Matthew Oakley became the second player to leave the pitch on a stretcher, after a 64th-minute challenge on Sean Flynn.

Southampton's response was to create three of their best goalscoring chances in the next five minutes as Joe Tessem, Kachloul and substitute Tahar El Khalej all went close.

Tranmere were hanging on at times in the closing stages and John Achterberg made a stunning save from a Marian Pahars shot with ten minutes to go. They survived another scare when Uwe Rosler netted in time added on at the end only to be penalised for punching the ball in. And all the effort and anguish was ultimately worth it for the remarkable cup side from the Wirral.

fields.headline: Red roses all round
fields.standfirst: Bolton W Ricketts 62   Blackburn R Dunn 40 att: 22,048 :   1 1
fields.trailText: A tie that had everything lacked one ingredient vital to two teams keen for a positive outcome - a winner. But in every other facet, this fifth-round tie is one that will linger long in the memory.
fields.byline: Ian Whittell at the Reebok Stadium
fields.body:
A tie that had everything lacked one ingredient vital to two teams keen for a positive outcome - a winner. But in every other facet, this fifth-round tie is one that will linger long in the memory.

An intriguing encounter was made all the more so after just nine minutes, the length of time it took Blackburn's Bolton-born midfielder Garry Flitcroft to collect two yellow cards. Fouls on Gareth Farrelly and Kevin Nolan were not malicious but deserved the cautions that resulted in his dismissal.

Managers Sam Allardyce and Graeme Souness had admitted in the build-up to the meeting that Friday's league rematch between the pair at the Reebok Stadium is more important - that philosophy filtered down to their players in a free-flowing, adventurous game.

Unfortunately, Flitcroft's departure would mean the replacement of Berkovic on the half-hour for tactical reasons. Unfortunate because he had been the best player on the field, responsible for some breathtaking attacking contributions as Rovers' 10 men refused to concede self-belief.

All these factors affected an event-filled first half. Farrelly's long-distance effort was diverted by Brad Friedel on 11 minutes, Kevin Nolan's perfect cross found Ricardo Gardner, who headed wide, Marcus Bent's shot struck Matt Jansen who was denied by Jurgen Sommer before Michael Ricketts came agonisingly close with a shot that flew just wide of the Rovers goal. Riveting stuff.

Highly predictable, also, that the opening goal should come from the visitors, who collected a free-kick just outside the area following John O'Kane's 40th-minute challenge on Damien Duff. David Dunn calmly lifted a right-footed shot over the wall and Sommer and into the roof of the net. The goal was deserved, not only for Blackburn but for a pulsating tie.

It soon became clear that Sommer, brought in solely for this tie, was impeded by a thigh injury collected in the opening minute. Injury, suspension and ineligibility had already robbed Bolton of three keepers - they did not even have a substitute at their disposal.

Still, it was obvious there would be opportunities for at least an equaliser and Ricketts claimed it, in the 62nd minute, with his 19th goal of the season. Simon Charlton's low drive appeared to be going wide but Henning Berg blocked it - directly to Ricketts, who scrambled it over the line from point-blank range.

A sending-off, a passionate derby crowd and a colossal performance, from Bolton's former Blackburn idol Colin Hendry. This is what the FA Cup is about.

fields.headline: Pars' persistence pays off
fields.standfirst: Dunfermline Skerla 83, Nicholson 90   Celtic Larsson 66 88 att: 11,222 :   2 2
fields.trailText: These two will meet again at Celtic Park on Wednesday week as the result of a final few minutes that left all who saw this Tennents Scottish Cup fourth-round tie stupefied. Henrik Larsson's double had given Celtic the lead twice, the second of his goals seemingly decisive as it was scored so late.
fields.byline: Glenn Gibbons at East End Park
fields.body:
These two will meet again at Celtic Park on Wednesday week as the result of a final few minutes that left all who saw this Tennents Scottish Cup fourth-round tie stupefied. Henrik Larsson's double had given Celtic the lead twice, the second of his goals seemingly decisive as it was scored so late.

But Barry Nicholson's second equaliser, even more improbable than their first from Andrius Skerla, brought extraordinary excitement to a contest of different strategies.

The astute tactical deployment of Jimmy Calderwood, the Dunfermline manager, was the single most significant factor in Celtic's attacking difficulties until Larsson opened the scoring midway through the second half.

Andy Tod, the central defender who had not started a single game this season, was restored from the off for the specific purpose of putting the manacles on Chris Sutton; Youssef Rossi, who normally forms a central defensive partnership with Skerla, was put on the left to police Didier Agathe.

Calderwood clearly appreciated that keeping Sutton quiet had the twin advantages of diluting the big Englishman's own menace and, as a consequence, reducing the effectiveness of Larsson by blocking one of the Swede's main supply lines.

The plan was not only shrewd, but, more importantly, beautifully executed until the nature of the game changed. Rossi may be one of the quickest defenders in the country, judged by his duels with Agathe. The Frenchman appeared understandably shocked the first time he pushed the ball past Rossi and sprinted away, only to find the Moroccan beside him before he had the ball once again at his feet. The wing-back is not accustomed to such recovery speed in an opponent.

Calderwood's priority, to prevent his visitors from gaining an early fillip, was understandable, but it amounted to a virtual guarantee that, for much of the time, there would be few heart-stopping moments in the goal areas.

Indeed, it was not until almost 25 minutes had passed that there was an incident of note, a caution issued to Tod for what referee Willie Young considered to be one foul too many on Sutton. Dunfermline's most glaring weakness in their matches against the Old Firm this season has been a general lack of threat and, given their attention to putting a clamp on their opponents' flair here, it was hardly surprising that they should not produce a worthwhile scoring effort until the last minute of the first half.

It was Scott Thomson who caused the flutter, his well-struck left-foot shot from 25 yards forcing Robert Douglas to dive to his left to complete an important save.

Celtic deserve credit for their relentless probing during the second half, but, in their search for openings, they appeared to be assisted by the dangerous ambition that overcame the home side. As if realising that unrelieved containment of their visitors would gain them only a replay at best, they committed themselves more in forward areas. The resultant space they left behind them should have been exploited long before it was.

Larsson opened the scoring with what has become a kind of Celtic signature goal. Thompson took the free-kick on the left and the wickedly swerving delivery eluded all but the striker, who stooped to head the ball low to the left of Ruitenbeek.

But Dunfermline, having looked as though they could have played for a week without troubling Robert Douglas, found an equaliser from the tumult in Celtic's defence after a corner from the right, Skerla hooking the ball past Douglas from close range.

With characteristic refusal to settle for the draw, Larsson came back with a one-two with Sutton that allowed the Swede, from only six yards out, to dink the ball over Ruitenbeek for what looked like being the winner.

Not even the most optimistic home fan could have fantasised the 20-yard shot with which Nicholson would produce the second equaliser after two minutes of stoppage time. Dunfermline had worked hard enough to deserve it.

fields.headline: Old Dons earn draw
fields.standfirst: Wycombe W Simpson 72, Brown 80   Wimbledon Williams 32, Agyemang 44 att: 9,650 :   2 2
fields.trailText: Wycombe kept the romance of the cup alive with an unlikely but well-deserved draw against Wimbledon. Two goals down with 18 minutes remaining, Wycombe came back with two goals in the space of eight minutes to force a replay at Selhurst Park this Tuesday.
fields.body:
Wycombe kept the romance of the cup alive with an unlikely but well-deserved draw against Wimbledon. Two goals down with 18 minutes remaining, Wycombe came back with two goals in the space of eight minutes to force a replay at Selhurst Park this Tuesday.

Wimbledon used to thrive on their reputation as party-poopers when they were regularly bloodying noses at football's top table, but it hardly suits them to be the team to end Wycombe's cup hopes.

Lawrie Sanchez, who gave Wimbledon their greatest moment when he scored the winner in the 1988 FA Cup final against Liverpool, has fashioned a decent side at Wycombe who proved their cup pedigree with victories over Grimsby and Wolves in previous rounds.

But Terry Burton's Wimbledon are starting to look more formidable now that key players such as Kenny Cunningham and Gareth Ainsworth have returned from long-term injuries. Cunningham's experience in a relatively young side cannot be underestimated, and they have not lost since he returned from a nine-month lay-off four games ago.

But two new faces put Wimbledon in control with a two-goal lead by half-time. Mark Williams, the Northern Ireland defender signed from Watford last summer, put the Dons ahead in the 32nd minute when he thumped in a header from Neal Ardley's corner.

And Patrick Agyemang, the young striker who is keeping Jamaican international Marcus Gayle out of the side, effectively put the game beyond Wycombe's reach when he stabbed the ball home from close range two minutes before half-time after good work by Ainsworth and Jason Euell.

It was no more than the Dons deserved for their domination, although their goalkeeper, Kelvin Davis, made a superb save moments before Agyemang's goal to keep out a crisp half-volley from Wycombe's Dave Carroll.

But the cup is nothing if not unpredictable, and just as Wimbledon appeared to be cruising into the quarter-finals, Wycombe sprang a surprise.

Sam Parkin, the young forward on loan from Chelsea, was introduced as a second-half substitute and was instrumental in Wycombe's goal in the 72nd minute.

The burly striker, chasing what appeared a lost cause, forced a Dons defender into an error, and as the visitors failed to clear their lines, Michael Simpson fired in a low shot that took a deflection before going into the net off the inside of the far post.

The goal came just a minute after Euell had wasted a chance to put Wimbledon home and dry when he ran clear of the home defence but tried to square the ball, unsuccessfully, to Gayle, rather than go for goal himself.

It proved a costly miss when Wycombe equalised in the 80th minute - again Wimbledon were the architects of their own downfall. Young defender Peter Hawkins lobbed a backpass into the arms of his goalkeeper Davis, and a free-kick was given on the edge of the six-yard area.

Steve Brown's fierce free-kick rebounded off the defensive wall and was momentarily cleared. But when the ball was deflected back into the penalty area, Brown was the first of three Wycombe players to react and stab the ball triumphantly past Davis.

fields.headline: Freddie and Psycho show
fields.standfirst: Sunderland  West Ham Kanouté 76 att: 36,005 :   0 1
fields.trailText: Knowing West Ham's luck they will undoubtedly get Arsenal or Chelsea away in tomorrow's quarter-final draw, but even so it might be worth backing the Hammers to carry on all the way to Cardiff.
fields.byline: Paul Wilson at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Knowing West Ham's luck they will undoubtedly get Arsenal or Chelsea away in tomorrow's quarter-final draw, but even so it might be worth backing the Hammers to carry on all the way to Cardiff.

They have reached the last eight by virtue of three straight wins away from home, and the last two, against the teams placed first and second in the Premiership when the draws were made, have been achieved in identical fashion with a single goal 14 minutes from the end.

Paulo Di Canio, hero of Old Trafford, was almost anonymous here, it was Frédéric Kanouté's turn to take centre stage with his third goal of the FA Cup campaign. For over an hour the Frenchman toyed with the idea of being villain instead - he must have reached double figures for being caught offside and he missed two chances in the first half that were simpler than the one he eventually put away - but in the end the Sunderland defence was culpable for playing too far upfield and relying on an offside trap that invited trouble.

The Hammers had it figured out as early as the fifth minute, when Christian Dailly's perfectly judged ball forward put Kanouté behind a defence that was hugging the half-way line. It should have been an ideal start, but the weight on Dailly's pass meant Kanouté did not need to take a touch until he was bearing down on the goalkeeper, and - when he did - he succeeded only in nudging the ball tamely into Thomas Sorensen's arms.

Michael Carrick worked the same move five minutes later, for Kanouté this time to shoot narrowly wide. And after the former Lyon striker then left Stanislav Varga on his backside, Peter Reid withdrew his burly Slovakian defender. A groin strain was the reason given, though Varga's pride was probably hurting more.

Sunderland were short of ideas in attack. Niall Quinn rarely got the better of Igor Stimac and Kevin Phillips struggled to get a look-in, with the result that Shaka Hislop only had a single save to make in the first half. John Oster did well to create space for a shooting opportunity, but his eventual effort did not cause Hislop any problems.

Kanouté ended the half forcing a save from Sorensen, but when Di Canio opened the second by pinching a chance from Joe Cole's toes and firing wastefully into the side-netting, it began to look as if the Hammers might end up regretting their profligacy. With a midfield depleted by suspensions to Alex Rae and Don Hutchison, however, Sunderland were powerless to prevent their opponents coming through the centre. Nigel Winterburn split their defence again in the 71st minute for Frank Lampard to waste another chance by shooting straight at the goalkeeper, but it was only a matter of time before West Ham got their act together, and it was Lampard himself who made amends.

Running through the centre from his own half, Lampard waited until he was at Kanouté's shoulder before releasing his pass, ensuring the linesman's flag stayed down. Kanouté ran past Emerson Thome and, assisted by Sorensen's reckless sprint out of his area, slipped the ball coolly past the keeper.

Sunderland could hardly complain. They failed to extend Hislop until the closing seconds, although the West Ham goalkeeper was well protected by the outstanding Stuart Pearce, now 38. He cleared bravely under his own bar from Phillips, after Quinn had done well to get a cross in, and threw himself at Oster to block a goalbound shot.

Redknapp said. 'For a long time I thought Arséne Wenger had the easiest job in the world because he had Tony Adams in his dressing room. I tried to get Stuart before he went to Newcastle, and he phoned me when his contract ran out to ask if I was still interested. Of course I was. He was the best left-back in the world in his prime. I know there's Maldini but I know who I'd have. Your Stuart Pearces are just so special. If kids want to know about attitude, about workrate and will to win, all they have to do is look at him.'

fields.headline: Foxes march on
fields.standfirst: Leicester City Sturridge 10, Hill 15og, Izzet 83pen   Bristol City att: 20,905 :   3 0
fields.trailText: The result looks routine, but the reality was far less comfortable for Leicester City. Two goals in the first 15 minutes set them on the way to the FA Cup's last eight but between that flurry and a late penalty, Bristol City often looked the more sophisticated side.
fields.body:
The result looks routine, but the reality was far less comfortable for Leicester City. Two goals in the first 15 minutes set them on the way to the FA Cup's last eight but between that flurry and a late penalty, Bristol City often looked the more sophisticated side.

On paper, Leicester looked the sort of team who could win the competition; well placed in the Premiership and with a good defensive record. On grass, they look less convincing. Dean Sturridge, followed by an own goal, took Leicester clear, but Bristol City twice hit woodwork thereafter before Muzzy Izzet's penalty sealed the game.

The omens for an upset were promising. Leicester's form in the Premiership has been patchy of late, seeing them slip to eighth, while Bristol City went into the game unbeaten this year in nine matches, Danny Wilson's management beginning to bring results which have seen them move up to sixth in the Second Division. The first quarter of an hour ignored the omens, however.

Leicester's early lead came through a neatly worked move from a left-wing corner. Muzzy Izzet played it short to Robbie Savage, who let it run to Steve Guppy. His curling cross to the far post found Dean Sturridge unmarked for a simple header home from close range.

Then, exploiting space on the left again - where Scott Murray, the right wing-back, was leaving vast areas vacant behind him - Izzet curled in another cross that fizzed past Steve Phillips off his own defender Matthew Hill as he sought to deny Sturridge another free header.

The irony was that Bristol City, though clearly nervous, were scarcely being outclassed. Before the opening goal, their 18-goal striker Tony Thorpe had tested Simon Royce with a 25-yard shot. Then, between the goals, Brian Tinnion rattled the Leicester bar with a curling shot from a free kick at a similar distance.

After the goals, Murray, who had only Royce to beat, shot at him instead of lifting it over the diving goalkeeper. In addition, Lee Peacock, a muscular presence up front, had Royce scrambling with his header. The half-time score flattered Leicester, and insulted Bristol City.

City continued with neater approach play after the interval, with Tinnion at the hub. There was, however, little end product and they frequently looked likely to concede again to a home team content to watch them weave their patterns until they surrendered possession, before hitting them on the break.

Indeed but for Phillips, Second Division City might have quickly lost all hope of any late fightback. First he denied Ade Akinbiyi, playing against his former club, after Sturridge had found him in space. Then he blocked another of Akinbiyi's shots at the near post after Guppy had headed down Frank Sinclair's cross. Phillips also did well to turn aside a point-blank volley from Savage.

At the other end, when they did get close to goal, Bristol's luck was out - after Izzet had fowled Murray, Nicky Bell's swiftly-struck free-kick from 25-yards hit Royce's right post with the goalkeeper well beaten.

It was left to Izzet to put them out of their misery. From Sturridge's cross, Bell instinctively stuck out a hand and Izzet drove the penalty into the roof of the blameless Phillips's net.

webTitle: Sven's new script with old names

fields.headline: Sven's new script with old names
fields.trailText: That was quite a coup for the BBC on Thursday, hauling in Sven-Göran Eriksson to sit alongside Alan Hansen and Mark Lawrenson in the half-time interval of the Roma-Liverpool match.
fields.body:
ITV, who mostly make do with former England managers, must have been a bit miffed, though of course had they booked Eriksson they would still have had to fit him in around the adverts.

The novelty of having a foreign England coach has not yet worn off, even one who has nothing very much to say but is capable of being noncommittal in a disarmingly courteous manner. Eriksson has been paraded around like a prize exhibit this past month or so, but probably to his relief the phoney war ends on Friday when he names his first squad.

England play Spain in a friendly at Villa Park on Wednesday week, and, although the occasion might not be the most competitive event in the football calendar, an unusual combination of circumstances has lent the game a significance all of its own. Eriksson will be the fourth manager England have played under in their past four matches, Howard Wilkinson and Peter Taylor having supervised the trips to Finland and Italy since the fateful day in October when the Germans consigned Wembley and Kevin Keegan to history.

Wilkinson stuck with Keegan's team in Helsinki, Taylor picked a completely different one for the one-off friendly in Turin, so despite England being in the middle of qualifying for the 2002 World Cup it feels as though they have been treading water. Tony Adams took the opportunity to announce his retirement, further destroying any template Eriksson might have been hoping to use, though continuity of a sort was established with the news that Darren Anderton is injured again. The new man will soon get used to that.

Of course, if continuity was what England wanted they would never have gone to Italy looking for a coach. Eriksson's whole brief is to depart from the usual script, and although his first squad will be a list of familiar names, more importantly it will be regarded as a virtual audit of the country's available talent.

It is an almost unique situation, after all. Foreign man agers usually work in developing countries with a well-defined international elite. They do not normally get the chance to follow teams around Europe in the later stages of the Champions League, or consider possibilities theoretically suggested by 92 professional clubs.

The choices open to Eriksson must have seemed bewildering at times, but like any incoming manager he simply has to sort out what to change and what to leave alone. With maximum points now necessary from the World Cup qualifiers against Finland and Albania in March, he has little scope for experiment and has promised to name the strongest squad he can, featuring perhaps as many as 25 names.

What is left of it after the Worthington Cup final and FA Cup replays have taken their toll remains to be seen, but at least Manchester United are not doing anything that week. David Beck ham, Paul Scholes, Wes Brown, Gary Neville and possibly Teddy Sheringham can all expect to be involved, as they provide a solid bank of experience as well as ability. Eriksson has been unlucky so far in his attempts to watch Steven Gerrard, but it will be odd if the Liverpool midfielder is not included, along with all three of the club's English strikers. These are not startlingly new choices, but it is unrealistic to expect Eriksson to change too much before a ball has been kicked.

Surprises? Joe Cole hardly counts, but Arsenal's Ashley Cole could also get a look in. Eriksson and Tord Grip managed to convey their enthusiasm for the full-back even when Silvinho was keeping him out of the side. Ditto Paul Robinson, who could make the squad despite losing his Leeds place to Nigel Martyn. Most worried man might be David Seaman, who has rarely been seen at his best since Eriksson arrived in England.

And the shock? Rio Ferdinand might not be required as a sweeper.

webTitle: Hope restored as Rangers pursue Rix

fields.headline: Hope restored as Rangers pursue Rix
fields.trailText: Graham Rix's hopes of landing his first job as a manager, in succession to Gerry Francis at QPR, have been boosted by the club's insistence that his sex-offence conviction will not count against him.
fields.body:
Graham Rix's hopes of landing his first job as a manager, in succession to Gerry Francis at QPR, have been boosted by the club's insistence that his sex-offence conviction will not count against him.

Rix has been out of work since being sacked by Chelsea shortly after Claudio Ranieri's arrival at Stamford Bridge earlier this season. But he is known to be among those being considered for the QPR post and the club's vice-chairman, Nick Blackburn, said: 'We are more interested in his potential as a manager than anything he has done away from football, and he proved himself an outstanding coach at Chelsea.

'We are looking for someone young and hungry, who would be able to spot a bargain and bring in good young players.'

They will also be looking for the QPR players to maintain the sort of of form which enabled them to mark the end of Francis's managerial reign yesterday with a 2-0 win over Barnsley. Chris Kiwomya broke the deadlock with a far-post header just before half-time, and Peter Crouch added the other midway through the second half. Of the other struggling teams in action, Huddersfield, in the third-from-bottom spot, were sunk 3-2 at home to Gillingham, but Grimsby and Crewe both gained maximum points at the expense of Burnley and Watford respectively.

Whoever gets the QPR job will not have a tougher task than Oxford United's David Kemp.

It says much about Kemp's determination to make a success of it that, though Oxford are 10 points adrift at the bottom of the Second Division and he has recently been booed by a section of their fans, he has reiterated his commitment to the club by turning down an offer to follow Joe Kinnear - previously Oxford's director of football - to Luton. It seemed to rebound against him yesterday, when Luton beat Swansea 5-3 and Oxford, reduced to 10 men by Chris Hackett's dismissal, crashed 3-1 at Bury.

Still, it will clearly take more than that to undermine Kemp's faith in his ability. 'This club has had a lot of managers recently, and I think the message to the fans should be: "Let's really get behind someone." If things haven't got any better by this time next year, then I will hold my hand up. But in the meantime, people should appreciate that you do not go from being a bad team to a brilliant one overnight, and that I am not some guy Oxford have got from the JobCentre. I have vast experience in the game and I know what I am doing.'

On the premise that there is always someone worse off than yourself, the likes of Kemp can surely find some consolation in the case of Steve Archibald and Airdrie.

The removal of the former Tottenham and Scotland striker as Airdrie's manager (and potential buyer), and the decision by the club's liquidators not to select any of the players he has brought there for the Scottish Cup fourth round tie against Peterhead, led on Friday to the latter being given a bye to the next round. The contracts of all those Archibald signings - the vast majority of Airdrie's playing staff - expired last night, so one wonders where the club go from here.

The joint liquidator, Blair Nimmo, said: 'It's a pretty bleak picture but we are still hopeful that someone will come forward [to buy the club].' As for the need to get a new playing staff, he added: 'It's not too difficult to put together a pool of players in the short term. There are mechanisms available to get a squad together quickly.'

The removal of the former Tottenham and Scotland striker as Airdrie's manager (and potential buyer), and the decision by the club's liquidators not to select any of the players he has brought there for the Scottish Cup fourth round tie against Peterhead, led on Friday to the latter being given a bye to the next round. The contracts of all those Archibald signings - the vast majority of Airdrie's playing staff - expired last night, so one wonders where the club go from here. The joint liquidator, Blair Nimmo, said: 'It's a pretty bleak picture but we are still hopeful that someone will come forward [to buy the club].' As for the need to get a new playing staff, he added: 'It's not too difficult to put together a pool of players in the short term. There are mechanisms available to get a squad together quickly.'

webTitle: Alan Smith - New reds apply the Souness treatment

fields.headline: New Reds apply the Souness treatment
fields.standfirst:
Gerard Houllier's side are ready to overtake Arsenal

FA Cup final special
fields.trailText: Alan Smith says Gerard Houllier's side are ready to overtake Arsenal
fields.body:
Liverpool's win in Rome last week, one of their greatest results in recent years, has been hailed as a turning point in the club's fortunes - but I have to disagree.

From my point of view, the moment Gérard Houllier's side suggested that they were set to become Manchester United's biggest rivals in the domestic game and a major force in Europe once again was when they beat Arsenal 4-0 last month. Few would argue that Arsenal have been United's only serious challengers over the past five years or so. But the way Liverpool brushed them aside at Anfield - shortly before they beat us 5-0 in the same stadium - hinted at the arrogance of old. I'd say that they are the best side Liverpool have had for nine or 10 years - a view reinforced by one of my coaches, Ray Houghton, a key player in the last great Liverpool side of the late Eighties.

The changes in that time have been enormous. Ray says that there was no rocket science applied to their coaching a lot of five-a-sides and ballwork, but the fundamental principle was to put very good players together in a framework that suited them. Added to this, of course, was the Anfield aura, when simply pulling on the red shirt of Liverpool built you up in stature. It was true of players such as Ron Yeats and Ian St John, and you can see it today in the likes of Nick Barmby. So why did it go wrong for them for most of the Nineties? Liverpool's great strength - promoting from within - was also a weakness when the game started to change a decade ago. The managerial succession from Shankly to Bob Paisley, Joe Fagan to Kenny Dalglish was a smooth transition underpinned by the wisdom of their boot room. It started to go wrong when Graeme Souness arrived with ideas gleaned from his time in Italy and as manager of Rangers. One of the first things he tried to change was the drinking culture that was prevalent, not just at Liverpool but throughout British football. I know from experience that this doesn't always go down well, with players or fans. There is an old school of players who believe in working hard and drinking hard.

Souness wasn't the first manager to confront the issue - Alex Ferguson did it at Manchester United and years earlier Bobby Robson did something similar at Ipswich. It is no coincidence that both clubs had success with foreign players, and the influence of overseas players and coaches cannot be underestimated. Now the biggest single influence on Liverpool has been the arrival of Houllier, who has done exactly what Souness tried to do and was lambasted for. In the 100 or so games that he has had sole responsibility for the side, he has turned them into a very impressive outfit. His initial appointment alongside Roy Evans was not a great success, and I think joint managements are doomed to failure. I got to know Roy working with him at Fulham last season and I think the problem he and Houllier faced initially was rooting out players who were not totally committed.

Now Houllier has got the balance of his squad just right. He knows the importance of a youth system that has developed players such as Robbie Fowler, Michael Owen and Steven Gerrard, but has also made some very shrewd signings, both at home and abroad. Jari Litmanen and Gary McAllister are still hugely influential players. I think it was no coincidence that McAllister was not playing when we beat Liverpool 2-1 in the first leg of our Worthington Cup semi-final last month. He was back for the return leg and we all know what happened there. Litmanen's speed of thought and control means he can orchestrate quick counter-attacks.

What was striking about their performance in Rome was the quality of Liverpool's movement. They have quite a direct style in a fairly rigid 4-4-2 framework, and can keep their shape well while pulling opposing defences apart. They work the ball from front to back quickly and without fuss. They are not easy to play against because they can play at a high tempo, requiring supreme fitness, which makes it very hard to sit back against them. And if you go at them, they can punish you on the break.

I was in Lyon to watch Arsenal's win and I have to say the two best players by some distance were those old English lionhearts Tony Adams and David Seaman. But both are nearing retirement and Wenger has a real problem replacing them. That is why I can see Arsenal being overtaken by Liverpool, who have finally sorted out the defensive problems that let them down so often in the past.

webTitle: Gerard Houllier interview - French evolutionary who preaches patience

fields.headline: French evolutionary who preaches patience
fields.standfirst:
As Liverpool chase a cup treble, where did it all go right for Gerard Houllier?

FA Cup final special
fields.trailText: As Liverpool chase a cup treble, where did it all go right for Gerard Houllier?
fields.body:
Gerard who? That was the headline in one newspaper after Liverpool appointed a bespectacled French former schoolteacher to share managerial duties with, and ultimately to succeed, the popular Roy Evans two-and-a-half years ago. The insularity was nothing new, an identical headline having greeted his compatriot Arséne Wenger two years earlier. But, while Wenger quickly won favour with his early achievements at Arsenal, the process has taken a little longer on Merseyside.

The arrival of Gérard Houllier represented a radical deviation from Anfield's boot-room philosophy, an unsophisticated notion based on the twin foundations of industry and teamwork. An unashamed 'thinker' about the game and a devotee of a more scientific approach, the former coach of the French national team initially provoked widespread suspicion, among players and supporters.

Stories, not all of them apocryphal, abounded about bewildered looks among the senior players as he quoted Marcel Proust or Milan Kundera in team-talks. Houllier rubbed up supporters the wrong way by eulogising Manchester United, declaring that it would take years even to compete with them, while bookmakers, reacting to the acquisition of several faceless foreigners the summer before last, suggested he would be on the next boat back to France.

So where did it all go right? How did the Frenchman (as he is disparagingly labelled to this day by the club's former striker Ian St John, now an outspoken radio commentator), whose name was barely sung by the Kop in his first 12 months, suddenly find himself elevated to demi-god status on Merseyside. The stunning 2-0 victory away to AS Roma, the leaders of Serie A, in Thursday's Uefa Cup fourth round first leg was his finest hour yet, but he characteristically played it down: 'Another step towards where we want to be.'

Several more significant steps could be made over the next seven days, in three different cups. But, even were they to end this most promising of seasons without a trophy, Liverpool supporters can rest assured that Houllier has put them back on track for success.

'For me, it doesn't mean anything that I didn't know before,' he said. 'I maintain that Roma are an outstanding team and it doesn't mean that we are now on their level. All it is is another sign of the progress we're making. It's a means to an end. I said before the game that the media would see it as a test for us, because of the club's past, but I didn't. I saw it as a chance. It was a privilege and a step forward in the building process.'

Houllier referred to his team last season as embryonic. If this campaign, which has featured marked advances in all areas of the side's development, is the gestation period, then the birth, or rather the rebirth of Liverpool as a major footballing power, ought to take place within the next 18 months, in keeping with the timescale he set upon taking sole charge in November 1998.

'It took Manchester United four years under Alex Ferguson to win a trophy and another three to win a championship,' he often points out. While Houllier's inheritance at Anfield was hardly as meagre as Ferguson's at Old Trafford, the parallels are numerous. Both sought immediately to change the culture of the club, rooting out the boozers or those who had become too comfortable with second best.

Today's FA Cup rival manager Joe Royle says: 'They are a growing force. For those already looking for next season's challengers, although Arsenal haven't gone away, Liverpool could be the most serious challengers. They've got a strong squad and, in the three strikers plus Barmby, Gerrard and Carragher, they have the fullest hand of English players in the league.'

Houllier was castigated this time last year for spending a reported £11 million on Emile Heskey, an infrequent goalscorer with Leicester City and a player seemingly unable to punch his weight. Now Heskey is likely to be the focal point of Sven-Göran Eriksson's England attack. His chosen pairing of Sami Hyypia and Stephane Henchoz, two hitherto anonymous defenders, also raised eyebrows, but they have restricted opponents to just seven goals in the past 19 games. Henchoz, in particular, was majestic in Rome.

There was the recent 'crisis' surrounding Robbie Fowler after another late-night incident. Offers came in from Aston Villa and Chelsea, but Houllier ordered his board to turn them down. The forward appreciated that support and, after two years of trouble on and off the pitch, the question marks over his future have disappeared.

On Heskey, Houllier says. 'I said [to the media]: "Be patient because I think he will be a good player." Now I no longer hear people say he is not worth £11 million, which, by the way, is more than we paid for him. As for Robbie, I think he appreciated the support. If we had been forced to sell him, it would have been because we'd not been able to persuade Robbie to do the right thing, but I'd have regarded that as failure.'

Failure on the pitch would, in the manager's eyes, be failing to qualify, again, for the Champions League, currently the preserve of United, Arsenal and Leeds. Most important in the long term, though, is the continuation of the year-on-year progress that he feels will lead ultimately to the recapture of the league title that the club once regarded as their own.

The much-vaunted 'French revolution' has been anything but: Houllier has insisted on patience throughout the evolution of his team and that patience is now being rewarded. No longer do a blinkered minority of supporters react to every slip-up by calling for his head on phone-ins. No longer do the players raise eyebrows at his technical findings or literary references.

Whatever happens over the next week, nobody now needs to ask: 'Gerard Who?'

webTitle: Liverpool focus - Houllier's boys best since Kenny

fields.headline: Houllier's boys best since Kenny
fields.standfirst:
Ten years ago this week Kenny Dalglish quit Liverpool - since when they haven't won the title nor qualified for the Champions League and had mustered just two cup-final wins, against Sunderland and Bolton. Now, at last, they look like winners again

FA Cup final special
fields.trailText: The ten years since Kenny Dalglish quit Liverpool have been pretty barren for the reds. Now, at last, they look like winners again.
fields.body:
What a week for Liverpool to turn back the clock in Rome. Granted, the Uefa Cup is fairly small potatoes these days, and Roma did not appear to take the tie as seriously as they might, but comparing the exhilarating efficiency of Liverpool's win to their shambolic performances in Europe in Gérard Houllier's first season provided the best evidence yet that Anfield is emerging from a decade of anonymity.

Ten years ago this Thursday the football world was shocked, and the Gulf War briefly pushed out of the headlines, by the news that Kenny Dalglish had relinquished his position as Liverpool manager.

Shock, for once, was not too strong a word. Dalglish then had not fully developed the flinty exterior of today. He was a young, relatively inexperienced manager under enormous strain after Hillsborough. It was only his reluctance to acknowledge the pressure of the situation, because victims' families had had it much worse, which convinced everyone he was coping. With hindsight, we should not have been so surprised. But Dalglish himself would have been amazed, as would anyone in 1991, to be told that Liverpool would fail to qualify for Europe's premier competition for the next 10 years.

Liverpool dominated the Seventies and Eighties as comprehensively as Manchester United came to dominate the Nineties, and with four European Cups along the way they set a standard no British club and very few continentals could match. They seemed as invincible two decades ago as United appear now, but somehow more laudably so.

United fans, players even, don't mind admitting they worry about what will happen when Sir Alex Ferguson steps down, but for a while it appeared Liverpool had the continuity problem cracked. Without Manchester's merchandise millions or Read Madrid's insane overdraft, Liverpool quietly created a true footballing dynasty in which players and managers came and went but success remained a constant.

Until 1991. All Liverpool have won since then is one FA Cup (in 1992, against Sunderland) and one Coca-Cola Cup (in 1995, against Bolton). Another League Cup final awaits in Cardiff this Sunday, but with respect to Trevor Francis's side, when you have been brought up on victories over Roma and Real, and have just had to witness Manchester United carrying off the most glamorous of trebles, it is hard to get worked up about beating Birmingham City.

Not that Liverpool fans are ungrateful, for the past or the present. Tommy Smith, a link with Bill Shankly's Sixties side as well as a goalscorer in Rome in Liverpool's first European Cup final, has spent the past 10 years conducting one of football's liveliest letters columns in the Liverpool Echo 's Saturday Pink.

'On the whole the supporters have been patient and understanding,' Smith said. 'Well, they've had to be haven't they? Not even the most biased Liverpool fan could deny the last decade has belonged to Manchester United. Liverpool supporters appreciate that after dominating for so long it was bound to be someone else's turn soon.'

That does not mean they are happy about it. Now that three English clubs go forward each season the Champions League has become the place to play, and there is no excuse for a club of Liverpool's stature continuing to watch from the sidelines.

When the principle of non-champions entering the Champions League was first mooted, Liverpool were instinctively against it. 'Letting in more than one team per country dilutes the idea of a tournament for champions,' said Roy Evans, manager at the time. 'Keeping the European Cup exclusive also prevents it operating to the detriment of the domestic league.'

True enough, but the reality is that you can't win the domestic league these days without embracing the Champions League. Squads of the size and strength of Manchester United or Arsenal are not going to be overtaken by more parsimonious operations with a narrower outlook. Hence Houllier's insistence that you need four quality strikers to compete. Hence Sir Alan Sugar going to court over allegations of miserliness, or Aston Villa constantly being accused of lacking ambition. That option is not available to Liverpool.

'European qualification is a more or less constant aspiration at Liverpool,' Evans said. 'That's what the club is geared for, and that's what managers are expected to deliver.'

After finishing as far down as seventh and eighth in the past decade, the closest Liverpool have come to the Champions League was last season when they slipped out of the top three in the final week. That was the end of Houllier's first full season in sole charge, after the not-so-bright experiment of having the Frenchman and Evans working together. The more convincing manner in which Liverpool are pursuing a Champions League place this season suggests they have at least found the right manager.

'This one is in charge, and everybody knows that,' Smith said. 'Before he arrived I think the players were running the place. Houllier seems such a nice, polite chap on the surface, but he's got the hardness all managers need. One or two players tried to test him out and came off worse. He's not afraid to show people the door, and he's won the respect of the players and the fans.'

It is too simplistic to blame managers for football teams' failings, and while a degree of criticism can be levelled at every Anfield appointment since Liverpool last won the league, the same could be said of almost every under-achieving club in the country.

From this distance it is easy to conclude the intense, abrasive Graeme Souness was the wrong man for a situation made fraught by the manner of Dalglish's departure, and the popular view of Evans as an easygoing antidote who was promoted beyond his ability, tends to be backed by his record since leaving Liverpool.

Yet it should also be acknowledged that finding the right coach to take over a champion team is notoriously difficult, as some of the biggest names in sport can testify. This is precisely why Manchester United supporters are getting jittery, and why Houllier, in building up a side from a relatively low base, is performing a subtly different task to any of his immediate predecessors. The last Anfield manager to have to do that was Shankly, and by virtue of their clever policy of in-house appointments Liverpool managed to avoid the issue for the next 30 years until Dalglish's abdication left them with a succession crisis.

Evans, who ought to know after 35 years in and around it, reckons too much has been made of the cult of the boot room. 'It was only a cubby-hole under the stand. The strange thing about Bob Paisley and Joe Fagan, two of the greatest managers it produced, was that neither of them actually wanted the job. Not at the start, anyway. They both ended up taking it because they were worried we would all lose our jobs if a new man came in.'

Dalglish wanted it from the start, despite knowing it would shorten his playing career. Souness wanted it so badly he took it on even after presciently hoping he would not be remembered as a failed manager rather than a successful player. By 1994, Evans claimed he would have started to look elsewhere had he been passed over. The more people wanted the job, the harder it got. The more new faces who arrived, the less they looked like Liverpool players.

suddenly people were experiencing difficulty for the first time in putting names to the faces in the red shirts. Some of the ones they could name - Neil Ruddock, Paul Stewart, Julian Dicks and Jason McAteer spring to mind - never convinced. Dean Saunders, who at his best was of the required quality, found that no sooner had he achieved his lifetime ambition of joining Liverpool than he was on his travels again.

'I'll always be grateful for winning the FA Cup with Liverpool, but their expectations were so high you always had the sense that nothing short of winning the title was really good enough,' Saunders said. 'There was a slightly depressing atmosphere around the place, as if everyone knew they weren't quite matching up. Graeme called me in one day and told me he needed a centre-half [Torben Piechnik], and that he could raise the money by selling me to Aston Villa. I couldn't believe he was prepared to let me go, but he said he didn't think my partnership with Ian Rush had worked out, and Rushy wouldn't be the one going anywhere. That was it.' It happens in football, of course, but it never used to happen at Anfield.

'Things did get very intense under Graeme, but that was just a reflection of his personality,' Evans said. 'He always tried his hardest for the club. I'm a more laid-back type of person, the Liverpudlian in me likes to see people having a laugh at work. Football should be about enjoyment.'

Amen to that. It is often forgotten that when Shankly made his famous quip about football being more important than life and death, he was joking. Houllier shares a similar sense of humour and proportion, though Liverpool don't joke about life and death any more.

'The club could never be quite the same again after Heysel,' Smith said. 'The ban set the whole of English football back, and the repercussions lasted a lot longer than five years.

'Manchester United had so much ground to make up it took them nearly all the Nineties to win the European Cup. I wouldn't be surprised if they won it again this year, because it's the only cup they are still in. Fair play to them, they're a good side. But Liverpool are getting back there. And they are still in three cups.'

'On the whole the supporters have been patient and understanding,' Smith said. 'Well, they've had to be haven't they? Not even the most biased Liverpool fan could deny the last decade has belonged to Manchester United. Liverpool supporters appreciate that after dominating for so long it was bound to be someone else's turn soon.' That does not mean they are happy about it. Now that three English clubs go forward each season the Champions League has become the place to play, and there is no excuse for a club of Liverpool's stature continuing to watch from the sidelines. When the principle of non-champions entering the Champions League was first mooted, Liverpool were instinctively against it. 'Letting in more than one team per country dilutes the idea of a tournament for champions,' said Roy Evans, manager at the time. 'Keeping the European Cup exclusive also prevents it operating to the detriment of the domestic league.' True enough, but the reality is that you can't win the domestic league these days without embracing the Champions League. Squads of the size and strength of Manchester United or Arsenal are not going to be overtaken by more parsimonious operations with a narrower outlook. Hence Houllier's insistence that you need four quality strikers to compete. Hence Sir Alan Sugar going to court over allegations of miserliness, or Aston Villa constantly being accused of lacking ambition. That option is not available to Liverpool. 'European qualification is a more or less constant aspiration at Liverpool,' Evans said. 'That's what the club is geared for, and that's what managers are expected to deliver.' After finishing as far down as seventh and eighth in the past decade, the closest Liverpool have come to the Champions League was last season when they slipped out of the top three in the final week. That was the end of Houllier's first full season in sole charge, after the not-so-bright experiment of having the Frenchman and Evans working together. The more convincing manner in which Liverpool are pursuing a Champions League place this season suggests they have at least found the right manager. 'This one is in charge, and everybody knows that,' Smith said. 'Before he arrived I think the players were running the place. Houllier seems such a nice, polite chap on the surface, but he's got the hardness all managers need. One or two players tried to test him out and came off worse. He's not afraid to show people the door, and he's won the respect of the players and the fans.' It is too simplistic to blame managers for football teams' failings, and while a degree of criticism can be levelled at every Anfield appointment since Liverpool last won the league, the same could be said of almost every under-achieving club in the country. From this distance it is easy to conclude the intense, abrasive Graeme Souness was the wrong man for a situation made fraught by the manner of Dalglish's departure, and the popular view of Evans as an easygoing antidote who was promoted beyond his ability, tends to be backed by his record since leaving Liverpool. Yet it should also be acknowledged that finding the right coach to take over a champion team is notoriously difficult, as some of the biggest names in sport can testify. This is precisely why Manchester United supporters are getting jittery, and why Houllier, in building up a side from a relatively low base, is performing a subtly different task to any of his immediate predecessors. The last Anfield manager to have to do that was Shankly, and by virtue of their clever policy of in-house appointments Liverpool managed to avoid the issue for the next 30 years until Dalglish's abdication left them with a succession crisis. Evans, who ought to know after 35 years in and around it, reckons too much has been made of the cult of the boot room. 'It was only a cubby-hole under the stand. The strange thing about Bob Paisley and Joe Fagan, two of the greatest managers it produced, was that neither of them actually wanted the job. Not at the start, anyway. They both ended up taking it because they were worried we would all lose our jobs if a new man came in.' Dalglish wanted it from the start, despite knowing it would shorten his playing career. Souness wanted it so badly he took it on even after presciently hoping he would not be remembered as a failed manager rather than a successful player. By 1994, Evans claimed he would have started to look elsewhere had he been passed over. The more people wanted the job, the harder it got. The more new faces who arrived, the less they looked like Liverpool players. suddenly people were experiencing difficulty for the first time in putting names to the faces in the red shirts. Some of the ones they could name - Neil Ruddock, Paul Stewart, Julian Dicks and Jason McAteer spring to mind - never convinced. Dean Saunders, who at his best was of the required quality, found that no sooner had he achieved his lifetime ambition of joining Liverpool than he was on his travels again. 'I'll always be grateful for winning the FA Cup with Liverpool, but their expectations were so high you always had the sense that nothing short of winning the title was really good enough,' Saunders said. 'There was a slightly depressing atmosphere around the place, as if everyone knew they weren't quite matching up. Graeme called me in one day and told me he needed a centre-half [Torben Piechnik], and that he could raise the money by selling me to Aston Villa. I couldn't believe he was prepared to let me go, but he said he didn't think my partnership with Ian Rush had worked out, and Rushy wouldn't be the one going anywhere. That was it.' It happens in football, of course, but it never used to happen at Anfield. 'Things did get very intense under Graeme, but that was just a reflection of his personality,' Evans said. 'He always tried his hardest for the club. I'm a more laid-back type of person, the Liverpudlian in me likes to see people having a laugh at work. Football should be about enjoyment.' Amen to that. It is often forgotten that when Shankly made his famous quip about football being more important than life and death, he was joking. Houllier shares a similar sense of humour and proportion, though Liverpool don't joke about life and death any more. 'The club could never be quite the same again after Heysel,' Smith said. 'The ban set the whole of English football back, and the repercussions lasted a lot longer than five years. 'Manchester United had so much ground to make up it took them nearly all the Nineties to win the European Cup. I wouldn't be surprised if they won it again this year, because it's the only cup they are still in. Fair play to them, they're a good side. But Liverpool are getting back there. And they are still in three cups.'

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.trailText: Love in chains
fields.body:
Love in chains

Chained, the new 'shock' game show to be broadcast on E4 this spring, has brought love, however fleetingly, to two contestants.

The show, which involves five participants being chained together for a week for each episode, features gay, bisexual and heterosexual people. During a week which chronicled the clanking antics of five lesbians, the 'picker', named Rachel, had to eliminate a contestant each day. Getting rid of her competitors left her chained to her heart's desire - and the resultant affair lasted all of a month after filming. Ain't love grand?

Nike? No sweat

To the admen at Nike, it was a great idea. Let customers personalise their trainers by stitching their favourite word next to the trademark swoosh and watch sales soar.

'It's about freedom to choose,' the company said - unless, that is, you are a critic of Nike such as would-be customiser, Jonah Peretti, who chose the word 'sweatshop'. Funnily enough, Nike said no, arguing it was unacceptable because it was either another party's trademark, the name of an athlete or a profanity.

Peretti demurred. Nike then suggested the word was 'inappropriate slang'. Peretti begged to differ, citing Webster's dictionary. Finally, Nike admitted it rejected the word because it 'contains material we consider inappropriate or simply do not want to place on our products'.

Yentob drives on

Alan Yentob is still cruising the streets in his limo, despite Beeb director-general Greg Dyke scrapping such perks for execs. Insiders say the head of entertainment did a deal. But it costs: he's is paying for the wheels himself.

webTitle: Wide smiles mask a wider European gap

fields.headline: Wide smiles mask a wider European gap
fields.standfirst:
The Anglo-American air strikes put a further strain on the dwindling support of their allies

The Bush files - Observer special
Special report: Iraq
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The Anglo-US air strikes put a further strain on the dwindling support of their allies, report Kamal Ahmed and Ed Vulliamy
fields.byline: Kamal Ahmed, and Ed Vulliamy in New York
fields.body:
On Wednesday, Tony Blair will settle back in the private plane chartered for his trip to America. As it sits on the runway at Heathrow ready for the flight first to Canada and then Washington DC, he will have a series of red boxes bulging with 'issues to be raised'.

It is the Prime Minister's first trip to America since George Bush Jr took over the presidency. Both sides have tried to make out it will be a relaxed affair, the meetings and dinners between Blair and Bush being held in the rolling green surroundings of Camp David rather than the stiff confines of the White House. Wives have been invited to make this seem a very family affair.

The imagery is important. The Prime Minister is aware that every word and look will be pored over by the media and experts in trans-Atlantic politics, looking for signs that the Bush-Blair axis is nothing compared to the Clinton-Blair very special relationship. The British Government wants the summit to be covered in warm, uncontroversial words.

There is no reason why the personal chemistry between Blair and Bush need not be a smooth blend - both are skilled, tactile, chameleon politicians, often more at ease with adversaries than with their own allies.

But for all the surface warmth on either side - from a grinning Foreign Secretary Robin Cook on his recent US visit and his smiling hosts at the State Department - everyone knows that an underlying strain cuts beneath this latest incarnation of what Britain (though not America) still calls the 'special relationship' between London and Washington.

Reports in America yesterday revealed that Britain had threatened to pull out of further air strikes against Iraq because of increasing military concern that it was difficult to see what they were achieving.

'Frustration quickly set in as pilots understood they were taking risks over Iraq for no real military purpose,' the Washington Post said. 'Britain, the last ally willing to fly with the Americans over Iraq quietly passed the word to Washington that a more focused and effective strategy was needed to justify continued military action.'

The Ministry of Defence has denied that there is any difference in opinion between America and Britain over the air strike tactics. But the noise from America says something different. As it does on a number of other issues.

Three weeks after New Year, the flight from London to Washington DC contained two of the most powerful men in Britain. Jonathan Powell, the Prime Minister's chief of staff, and John Sawers, the Prime Minister's private secretary with responsibility for foreign affairs, were on an important mission. At a reception at the British Embassy the following day they would meet key players from the new Republican presidency of George Bush.

Powell met Andrew Card, Bush's new chief of staff at the White House. Sawers met Colin Powell, the new secretary of state, and Condaleeza Rice, Bush's security adviser. The two men wanted to make it clear that America would have few problems forging a relationship with Britain.

Sir Christopher Meyer, the British Ambassador to America, has spent the past two years building up relationships with those close to Bush and is known to have worked particularly hard on wooing Rice and Dick Cheney, Bush's No 2. To do anything else would have been foolhardy.

But for all these efforts, when Blair and Bush meet on Friday there will be key issues of tension.

On the National Missile Defence (NMD) project, Blair is playing a delicate game of realpolitik. Senior Government sources have told The Observer that Britain will push Bush to include Russia, China and continental Europe in any plans to strengthen nuclear security.

Blair will say that he is willing to consider co-operating in any new American-led construction of a nuclear umbrella against rogue states. But there are conditions.

'We are not simply an aircraft carrier for America,' said a source close to the delicate negotiations. 'We are in discussions with America because they are keen to go ahead. If you just said a blanket "no" then you would have no influence on what Bush did. That is the position France and Germany are in. We will be using that influence to argue for a multilateral approach.'

The Bush administration is driven by another machine, primarily under the direction of Cheney, whose priority remains the ascendancy of the US in the world, even more so after the Cold War than before. Cheney's White House is in no mood to negotiate over NMD, even if the scheme involves shattering the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty with Russia.

It is also ready to dictate terms, not negotiate, over Britain's obligations under the agreements that governed its predecessor, the Strategic Defence Initiative. 'NMD is not a talking point,' said an assistant to policy adviser Karl Rove, 'it's a given.'

Sources say the White House may try to placate European objections by offering to put Europe under a shield supposed to protect the US from 'rogue' states. But officials know Blair is stuck between the rock of its intentions, regardless, and the hard place of Europe's preference for the ABM treaty and friendly relations with Vladimir Putin, the Russian leader.

And then there is the euro. For America, Britain's importance is as a bridgehead into Europe. Stay outside the single currency, particularly if the euro keeps strengthening, and that importance diminishes. Britain is America's foremost ally. They need to be at the centre of things.

Here the 'special relationship' is not so much with London as with Brussels, and although the most part of US capital investment in Europe is in Britain, all sources in the White House and Department of Trade want to know from Blair whether or not the UK will join the euro.

'If it does, well and good,' an official at the State Department told The Observer . 'But if not, I think we will see a slow drift of investment from Britain to continental Europe.'

On the matter of EU defence, it is now a matter of concern in the British Embassy at Washington that the man at the apex of the Pentagon, Donald Rumsfeld, managed to last the duration of the recent security summit in Munich without once mentioning the words 'European Union'.

Other areas of conflict on the agenda, whatever the photo-opportunities at Camp David look like next Saturday afternoon, are rules on global warming, war crimes and the international criminal court - both of which fall firmly within Blair's and Europe's ambitions, and are an anathema to the Bush administration.

But these are likely to feature during the meetings surrounding the summit, not necessarily at Camp David.

'The best thing for Tony to do for Camp David,' says a long-standing US observer, 'is to spend some time on the plane mugging up on his baseball.'

webTitle: Even pro-US Arabs won't join this crusade

fields.headline: Even pro-US Arabs won't join this crusade
fields.standfirst:
Washington and London may have proved their might, but there will be a heavy diplomatic price to pay

The Bush Files - Observer special
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Washington and London may have proved their might, but there will be a heavy diplomatic price to pay.
fields.body:
The bombing of Iraq may have provided President George W. Bush with a splendid opportunity to project himself as a strong leader, and British Prime Minister Tony Blair with a fresh opportunity to underline the 'special relationship' between Washington and London, but the diplomatic price to pay will be heavy.

The grounds on which they ordered the air strikes are weak. The United Nations Security Council Resolution 688, under which the United States and the United Kingdom have declared and maintained air exclusion sectors for Baghdad, has no provision for such zones.

The timing of the bombing was disastrous: a week before the US Secretary of State Colin Powell starts his Middle East tour to shore up anti-Saddam resistance in the Arab world; and 10 days before Iraqi Foreign Minister Muhammadal Sahhaf meets the UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan to discuss revived UN inspections under the year-old Security Council Resolution 1284.

In briefings the defence ministries in Washington and London have accused Iraq of upgrading its air defence system to improve its chance of hitting an Anglo-American plane enforcing the no-fly zones in northern and southern Iraq.

But since December 1998, when Saddam ordered his forces to stop what he calls foreign violations of Iraqi airspace, his air defence personnel have failed to score a single hit, while Anglo-American aircraft have carried out 30,000 sorties into Iraq.

While the dispute between Saddam Hussein and the United Nations centred on UN inspectors disarming Iraq of its weapons of mass destruction, the issue was easily understood by the general public, and popular opinion could be mobilised against the Iraqi dictator.

But inspectors are no longer in the picture. Richard Butler, head of UN Special Commission (Unscom) for disarmament, withdrew them in 1998 so that the Pentagon, backed by Britain, could stage its four-day blitzkrieg against Iraq during which it fired 425 Cruise and Tomahawk missiles - 90 more than during the 43-day Gulf War.

More seriously, the Anglo-American imposition and maintenance of the air exclusion zones have no international legal basis. America and Britain refer to Security Council Resolution 688, passed on 5 April 1991 in the wake of the Kurdish refugee crisis created by Saddam Hussein after the Gulf War.

In fact, there is no provision for air exclusion zones in Resolution 688. At the Security Council, Russia and China have repeatedly pointed this out, adding that the US-UK action is a violation of international law.

France, which initially participated in the air policing, pulled out of the northern zone in September 1996 after the outbreak of intra-Kurdish fighting in which one faction involved Saddam Hussein's military to defeat the other.

Paris withdrew from the southern zone after the Anglo-Americans mounted Operation Desert Fox in December 1998 which resulted in a 100-hour non-stop bombing of Iraq.

During his forthcoming tour of the Middle East, Colin Powell will discover that Arab public opinion has been inflamed by images of dead and wounded Iraqis, brought into Arab homes by several Arabic-language satellite television channels.

Such images will make even the leaders of the pro-American regimes in Cairo and Amman unwilling to join a new crusade against Iraq. Even before the latest air strikes against Iraq, Arab states - except Kuwait and Saudi Arabia - were busy mending fences with Baghdad, and calling for the lifting of UN sanctions.

'We can't expect the people of Iraq to live under sanctions for ever,' Egyptian Foreign Minister Amr Moussa told the Davos economic conference last month. 'Since the Gulf War, public opinion in the Arab world has moved 180 degrees.'

The belief on the Arab street is that President Bush has used the pretext of Iraq upgrading its air defence to punish Saddam for the vocal and material support he is providing to the Palestinian intifada. The Iraqi leader has repeatedly declared that only 'jihad' will lead to the liberation of Palestine.

He has also dispatched convoys of food and medicine to the Palestinian territories via Jordan. His representatives have been handing out cheques of $10,000 each to the families of the martyred Palestinians - five times the sum the Palestinian Authority offers.

Inadvertently or otherwise, Bush and Blair have destroyed any chance Kofi Annan had of working out a plan for UN inspections when he meets the Iraqi Foreign Minister later this month.

In launching Operation Desert Fox, the American and British chief executives achieved the satisfaction of making full use of the intelligence that their administrations had gathered over several years, and inflicted a robust blow against Saddam's regime.

But what resulted was a full withdrawal of UN inspectors, thus providing the Iraqi leader with a strong diplomatic lever to renegotiate the con-ditions on which they would be allowed to return.

The 1998 American and British military action made the breach between them and Russia, France and China unbridgeable. It immobilised the Security Council.

And it took a whole year to draft a new resolution - 1284 - which lacks the authority of a unanimously passed document due to the abstention of Russia, France and China.

Once again, having had the satisfaction of teaching Saddam a military lesson, Washington and London will find it will cost them a hefty diplomatic price.

Dilip Hiro is the author of 'Desert Shield To Desert Storm' (HarperCollins). His forthcoming book is 'Neighbours, Not Friends: Iraq and Iran After The Gulf Wars' (Routledge)
