webTitle: Film censor to stop playing nanny

fields.headline: Film censor to stop playing nanny
fields.standfirst: The man who decides what's fit for us to see at the cinema is predicting an end to legally-enforced ratings
fields.trailText: The man who decides what's fit for us to see at the cinema is predicting an end to legally-enforced ratings.
fields.body:
Britain's most influential arbiter of public taste, the film censor, is predicting the end of legally enforced cinema ratings in the UK. In a speech on the future of censorship this week, Robin Duval will argue that greater freedom for film-makers and audiences is on its way.

'We are pretty much the only country left to enforce a film rating system by law,' he said. 'In most of northern Europe and the Americas, film regulation is advisory and not mandatory. How long will Britain keep this up? As the internet and new media become more available, everyone wonders why one medium is regulated by law and another isn't.'

Duval, director of the British Board of Film Classification (BBFC) for just over two years, does not expect all forms of film classification to disappear. He envisages a grading scheme in which parents would be able to take children to seefilms they deem suitable. Existing legislation covering obscenity and child abuse would then become the only statutory public protection. In contrast, when the late Princess Diana controversially took an under-age Prince Harry to see the 15-certificate film The Devil's Own , the London cinema involved was threatened with prosecution under the 1985 Cinemas Act.

'I suspect film producers will still want their product to be given some sort of bill of health,' said Duval, 'but I think the legal nature of it will change fairly soon. Television will have to have its own ratings system too.'

Duval will use his speech at the Royal Society of Arts on Wednesday to call on the Government to rethink its policy on monitoring broadcast standards. New Labour plans for one giant, over-arching watchdog to look after film, television and the internet are dangerous, he will argue, and are also based on false assumptions.

The Government's parliamentary consultation document on the communications industry, published at Christmas, outlined plans for a new body, dubbed OfCom, to take over the roles of the Independent Television Commission, the Broadcasting Standards Council, the Radio Authority, the Radio Communications Agency and Oftel.

Duval said: 'There would be too much power in one institution - a supreme cultural regulator. Video and film would be lost within the broadcast bias of this watchdog.'

OfCom has been billed by the Government as a simplification of conflicting standards as the worlds of new media and broadcasting converge. But Duval and his colleagues at the BBFC, including the president, Andreas Whittam Smith, are not convinced by the argument that filmed entertainment will all soon be delivered via the internet. 'There are a lot of assumptions being made that people will gravitate towards their homes,' said Duval. 'It is doubtful whether the expectation of this great convergence is justified.

'People want to have somewhere to go in the evening. There are actually now three times more people going to the cinema than in the middle of the 1980s.' Duval believes it will take a long time for the internet to become a central part of the film business. Sport is still the driving force behind home satellite and digital ownership and no film channel yet receives more than 1 per cent of viewing figures.

Attitudes to sex on screen have been deliberately relaxed since Duval and Whittam Smith have been in charge at the BBFC. 'We carried out research into public attitudes last year and there was a clear message,' said Duval. 'People believed the BBFC was being quite unnecessarily nannyish when it came to questions of sex, but attitudes to violence were less tolerant.' The BBFC's rating categories would continue to be rigorous over violence. Duval said that although the link between people seeing violence on screen and committing it was poor, the BBFC had to respond to public feeling.

Public acceptability is one of the BBFC's main criteria for rating films. 'The only statutory restriction we have is on violence towards animals under the 1937 Animals Act. We also have some restrictions under the Obscene Publications Act,' said Duval.

The BBFC ensures there is no mention of drugs in U-rated films. Even at PG level, however, there is more scope for referring to illicit substances, while at a 12-rating Duval says audiences are allowed to 'enter the real world', as long as there is no appearance of promoting drugs. 'Broadly, we have to steer away from "imitable techniques". And we will not allow any detail of a hanging in a 15-film,' he said.

Duval believes he has seen the end of the recent tide of violent horror films. However, he is concerned that the industry is about to erupt into a spate of brutal adventure movies.

In contrast to current British concerns, American censorship has been tougher on sex than violence. In 1929 the Hays Office Code ruled that married couples had to be shown in twin beds and that one foot must stay on the floor in love scenes, lest the nation's collective morals were damaged.

webTitle: How the mandarins squeezed Tony Blair

fields.headline: How the mandarins squeezed Tony Blair
fields.trailText: February 18 2001, comment: The Prime Minister privately believes he'll have a big win at the election, but until he masters Whitehall, he'll never be fully in power, writes Andrew Rawnsley.
fields.body:
When a virginal Prime Minister arrives at Number 10, the first thing the civil servants do is to relieve him of his passport. The next thing they try to take away is his gonads. This operation is conducted with such skill that many premiers barely feel the pain. Too late do they wake up from the anaesthetic to discover that their aspirations to achieve radical reform have been neutered by Whitehall's forces of conservatism. Before it is too late for Tony Blair, the Prime Minister should make a careful audit of the contents of his boxer shorts.

It is one of the least observed but most profound failures of his supposedly all-conquering regime that they have not mastered the civil service . The Cabinet is eviscerated as a forum for meaningful decision-making. The Commons is marginalised. But where it really matters, Mr Blair is not in command. The permanent government of Whitehall, control of which is critical to the delivery of New Labour's agenda, has not been mastered.

The machine has frustrated the Government over its first term. Unless Tony Blair takes a grip, many of the goals of his second term are at risk. The Prime Minister and a chorus line of backing vocalists from the Cabinet have spent this weekend in Glasgow lavishing the country with promises of sweeping change. And yet the levers of the machine that must fulfil those pledges are still not obedient to the will of the Prime Minister.

He came to office planning to blow a whirlwind of change through the musty corridors of power. Jonathan Powell, the Prime Minister's Chief of Staff, warned the civil service that his master intended to bend the 'feudal barons' to the will of a 'Napoleonic system' run from Number 10. Then, it alarmed the panjandrums of Whitehall now, it amuses them. Four years on, they quietly chuckle over dinner in St James's at the naivety of the Blairites who thought they were a match for the guile of the British civil service . Those reforms that have happened have been mainly presentational, not least because Mr Blair is a Prime Minister singularly uninterested - bored, in fact - by the nuts and bolts of administrative machinery.

It is time he got interested. Obstruction is never so much ideological as inertial. Whitehall is not riddled with Tory fifth columnists sabotaging a progressive government. Resistance to change is more sinuous and subtle. Like any institution of its venerable age and conservative character, the civil service is a vested interest naturally disposed to the maintenance of the status quo. The higher echelons believe themselves to be a 'Rolls-Royce' service, and the public will tend to esteem an 'independent' civil service higher than partisan politicians. Fearing to be accused of being bent on the politicisation of Whitehall, Ministers dare not voice aloud their discontent about the inadequacies of the bureaucracy. Privately, they seethe. The fuel blockades last autumn are seared into the souls of those Ministers involved. They were profoundly shocked to make the discovery that not one of the alpha minds of Whitehall had prepared any contingency plan to deal with such a grave emergency.

Efforts to make civil servants assume 'ownership' of government programmes - in other words, to take responsibility for failures - have come to little. Will a head roll for the latest costly computer fiasco at the Home Office? Will anyone be named and shamed for the hundreds of millions squandered on misdirected benefits and fraud by the Department of Social Security? Don't hold your breath unless you are looking forward to an early death.

Some Ministers have simply given up trying to control Whitehall. 'You can't beat them,' one Cabinet member lamented to me recently. He invoked the cautionary tale of Jack Cunningham. That accomplished operator set about trying to kick some life into the most backward department, Agriculture. His punishment was to be undermined by a drip of embarrassing leaks about his allegedly expensive tastes in office furnishings and foreign travel.

It is striking how many, and how easily, Labour Ministers have been captured by their civil servants. Under the tutelage of the eternally Europhiliac Foreign Office, Robin Cook, erstwhile scourge of Brussels, has become the most euro-enthused member of the Government. The civil service 's favourite member of the Cabinet is Jack Straw. He does as many red boxes as they give him, and a capacity to eat paper is always admired by officialdom. What they most love about the Home Secretary is the enthusiasm with which he has embraced the mind-set of the most secretive department in Whitehall. Measures that the Home Office bureaucracy could not get past previous Tory Home Secretaries, such as the curtailment of trial by jury and electronic snooping, have been willingly executed by Mr Straw.

Gordon Brown has imposed his tungsten will on the Treasury. Even this exception serves to prove the rule. His awful reputation among colleagues for meddling in everyone else's affairs is not all his own making. The Treasury bureaucracy, knowing the power of their chief, exploit it by dictating to other departments. Just one example: they are trying to force the Department of Education to reduce the levels of qualification required to be a child carer because the Treasury civil servants believe that setting too demanding a standard will make it harder to hit the target for child-care places.

The weapon at the disposal of the Prime Minister is the power of appointment over the heads of the Whitehall departments. Margaret Thatcher was a Prime Minister with balls of steel, metaphorically speaking. She records in her memoirs how she overcame the civil service 's aversion to change. 'It became clear to me that it was only by encouraging or appointing individuals, rather than changing attitudes en bloc , that progress would be made. That was to be the method I employed.' Spectacularly so. Two years in, she sacked the head of the home civil service , sending a signal which reverberated through the system.

Purges are not in the nature of the consensual Mr Blair. But an opportunity has just presented itself to demonstrate his determination to command a civil service focused on delivering results. Three vacancies have simultaneously arisen for new Permanent Secretaries at the Home Office, the Department for Educa tion and Employment, and the Department of Trade & Industry, key Ministries all. Number 10 is dismayed to lose Michael Bichard from Education. One of the most creative and modernising heads in Whitehall, it is surely no coincidence that he is also the only Permanent Secretary to have been recruited from outside the traditional civil service hierarchy. Barely more than a week ago, the Prime Minister announced that he wanted more civil service posts filled externally, forcing Whitehall to compete with talents from business and other professions. Sir Buggins would not automatically get his turn.

Yet Tony Blair has been stymied. Only one of those three vacancies - that at Trade & Industry, the least important - is to be open to competition. Achieving that much was only possible by overcoming resistance from the Cabinet Secretary, Sir Richard Wilson. A Prime Minister who cannot even get his way about how to appoint the most senior civil servants, never mind who are they, is not a Prime Minister in control of Whitehall.

There has been a swagger in New Labour's step at the pre-election rally in Scotland. Tony Blair, usually the least complacent of men, is presently of the private view that he will 'win big'. However large his triumph at the ballot box, victory will not be complete, and many of his ambitions to change Britain will be in jeopardy, until he masters the machinery of government. He will be in office - but not fully in power.

fields.headline: Learn to love Mondays
fields.standfirst: Thousands of us are sick to death of our jobs. But, says  Alexander Garrett, you can change careers if you plan carefully
fields.trailText: Thousands of us are sick to death of our jobs. But, says Alexander Garrett, you can change careers if you plan carefully
fields.body:
The seminal moment for Julia Brett happened after a lousy day at the office. 'I came home, went into the kitchen and started to cook, and after a while I realised that I'd forgotten about work completely, I was so happy,' she recalls.

That all-important revelation helped her finally to make the decision to change careers, giving up her lucrative job in corporate affairs with a multinational company to train as a chef.

Like many people, Julia, now 31, had found herself doing a job that she hadn't exactly planned and in which she felt unfulfilled. 'I had that Sunday evening feeling every week, and I dreaded Monday mornings,' she says. Unlike most people, she decided to do something about it, first seeing a careers counsellor, then seeking the help of a coach, who provided vital support to help her take the big step of switching to a new career.

Her coach, Veronica Lim, showed her how to 'deconstruct' the transition, so that it became less frightening, helped her to shed her fear of upsetting others' expectations and also to think through how she would feel about having less money to live on for the year she was training. 'I was determined I wouldn't get to the end of my life saying "what if"?' she says. 'Now it feels as if I've come home.'

Some people are forced to change career because of redundancy or other circumstances. There's not much call for athletes or footballers in their forties, after all. But to do so of your own volition can be a daunting affair; there's often the prospect of sacrificing salary, status and security. But thousands take the plunge every year, while friends and colleagues watch in envy.

Rachel Turner of the Lifecoaching Company, which helped Julia Brett, says: 'People dissatisfied with their careers often don't know what they want. Advisers might give them psychometric tests but we help them to ask their own questions, to look at where they are now, where they want to be, and to find a strategy to bridge that gap.'

Much dissatisfaction stems from the fact that people have to choose a career when they are very young, and ill-equipped to do so. In some cases, they have a calling they only discover later in life; in others, their needs change as they grow older. 'For example, it might be fine to work on a high-adrenaline trading floor when you are in your twenties, but when you want to have a better work-life balance it doesn't fit anymore - a bit like growing out of a suit of clothes.'

The decision to change careers is usually made over a period of time, she says: 'People don't just wake up one morning and decide they want to make leather belts in the Cotswolds.' The important thing is to work out a strategy, taking account of the practical issues, especially money. 'That may mean the transition takes six months, or even two years, but it's difficult to achieve your goals if you can't pay the bills.'

Margaret Stead, an occupational psychologist, whose company Career Design International provides counselling and coaching, believes that many people end up in the wrong job because they receive poor careers advice at school. 'They don't have time to sit down with a pupil to find out what that person is really good at and what they enjoy.' Many people are far too short-term in their outlook, she says, easily flattered by the offer of a job, and not thinking where they would like to be in five or 10 years' time.

She believes that helping people to find the right career is a question of identifying what is important to them, as well as their strengths and weaknesses. She cites the example of a quality manager in the food manufacturing industry who was 'bored out of his mind'. According to Stead: 'It was a question of looking at what he could be passionate about. He was very keen on travel, and he'd taught himself circus skills. We looked at travel firms with room for an entertainments manager, and he's now working for a company in the South of France.' In other cases, she says, a much less radical change may be needed. For example, somebody may find that working from home injects their career with a new lease of life.

Although men and women are equally likely to feel the urge to change career, women may have a better chance of doing so, since having children can become a natural break to reconsider their objectives, whereas for men children can mean heightened pressure to keep earning to support the family.

'Women returning to the workforce tend to look at what they really want to do, and how they can make it fit in with their home life,' says Stead. Those who do successfully switch careers find the benefits can be dramatic. Sarah Whittaker gave up a career as an account manager with an IT firm to set herself up as an image consultant, which involves helping people to devise their personal style and wardrobe. She had always had an interest in fashion and felt unfulfilled in IT. Now she says: 'I feel that I'm using far more of my natural skills than before. I can choose when I work and the people I work with, and a lot of the jobs are really rewarding, for instance, when I work on somebody's wedding.'

Careful planning, supported by Rachel Turner's coaching, has put Whittaker on track to achieving the income she had in her old job, thanks to contracts with clients such as lastminute.com and confetti.co.uk.

Like Julia Brett, she says she used to dread Mondays. 'Now it doesn't matter what day of the week it is - it's just another day.'

webTitle: Should my daughter work in a call centre?

fields.headline: Should my daughter work in a call centre?
fields.trailText: My daughter has recently graduated and has taken a job in a call centre so that she can be near her friends. Is she just wasting her time and putting up with unpleasant conditions?
fields.body:
My daughter has recently graduated and has taken a job in a call centre so that she can be near her friends. Is she just wasting her time and putting up with unpleasant conditions?

Many call centres are, indeed, dire places to work. Staff turnover points to how long people are prepared to put up with it. The Trades Union Congress, which has just started a campaign on call centres, believes that between 40 and 60 per cent leave each year. Salaries are, on average, 40 per cent below the national average: £11,100 in Wales, for instance, and £14,050 in London. The atmosphere can also be authoritarian, with supervisors listening in to calls, strict targets for length of call and monitoring how long people spend away from their desks.

But some employers are improving conditions. BT is moving from individual to team targets on call numbers and is reducing pressure on call times. Others have introduced training, flexible working and creche facilities. It is not an ideal environment for a new graduate to show her creativity or develop skills. But it will show future employers that she has worked in a disciplined workplace.

The TUC 'know your rights' line offers free leaflets and advice on 0870 600 4882. It is also asking workers to report horror stories on 0800 032 0033 before 23 February.

fields.headline: Tricks in clicks and mortar
fields.standfirst:
Internet entrepreneurs failed because they tried to defy age-old principles, writes Richard Scase

More net news
fields.trailText: Internet entrepreneurs failed because they tried to defy age-old principles, writes Richard Scase
fields.body:
Yahoo, the flagship company of internet trading, is laying off staff. So is Amazon. So is EToys. The share value of internet stocks has halved over the past three months. Is this the end, or does the internet still have a business future? Reflecting on the mania of the past two years, it is clear that the fault rests not with the technology but with management: the internet entrepreneurs and their venture capital allies who, in their impatience to become overnight millionaires, chose to ignore a number of age-old basic business principles.

One of their biggest mistakes was to expect clever software to change customers' lifetime shopping habits. The dotcom revolution was driven by the psychology and assumptions of internet service providers rather than knowledge of customer shopping patterns. A first-year university lecture in sociology would have told them that for most of the US and UK adult population shopping is not a chore but a shared family activity - as the outstanding success of giant out-of-town shopping centres amply testify.

Elementary market research would have told them that online shopping would never be anything more than a niche market. Certainly, there will be demand among high-earning, time-poor professionals who prefer to buy commodities such as holidays, travel tickets and financial services online. These, of course, are exactly the same people as the dotcom founders themselves. Erroneously, they assumed that all consumers would be like them.

Another elementary principle ignored was that even dotcom start-ups need basic management structures and procedures and business plans - boring things like future earnings projections, breakeven analyses and income and expenditure budgets. They also require salary structures which bear some relation to employees' value creation. It remains true that to make a success of the new conditions it helps to have solid business experience of the old. As every ex-employee of the late Boo.com now laments, 'It was such a great company to work for'. You bet. But setting up a viable business requires more of its leaders than good looks and a talent for poetry. Nightly champagne parties and weekly Concorde flights, although fun, unfortunately generate no revenue.

Has this neglect of basic business principles destroyed the credibility of all online business ventures? It will take the dotcoms some time before they regain investor confidence. It is not surprising that many online trading companies have re-invented themselves as 'clicks-and-mortar' ventures, or even as entirely offline high-street retailers. Where internet trading will continue to expand rapidly is in business-to-business transactions. Eighty per cent of internet use will probably be in B2B, which has the capacity to revolutionise global supply chains and inventory management, and rationalise relations between retailers and manufacturers.

In some sectors, B2B is putting smaller manufacturers on a more equal footing with larger businesses in their dealings with retailers. For instance, in the furniture industry, which consists of a great many small manufacturers and retailers, online platforms are emerging as the basis of much more efficient delivery systems.

Thus, Corridor, a platform recently launched by parent United Business Media, aims to give retailers (and customers) access to a far greater range of manufacturers' products which they will be able to view, compare and order online. Corridor's platform will allow retailers to inform their customers of precise delivery dates through online links to manufacturers and distributors.

For the time being the cost of investment in technologies and accompanying skills makes it unrealistic to expect small retailers and manufacturers in any economic sector to trade with each other directly online. Instead, online brokers will emerge as intermediaries. Opportunities exist in most areas of niche retailing, from childrens' toys to office stationery. These will be the real drivers of 'clicks and mortar'. In the near future it is not difficult to envisage online brokers such as Corridor giving small retailers access to manufactures on a global basis.

At the same time, the internet will allow companies to move many of their back-office activities to low-wage economies. In the near future UK financial institutions will outsource their data-processing functions to operations in India and other English-speaking parts of the world.

Many back-office activities that have been the drivers of job creation in the South East over the past 30 years could be eliminated over the next 10. The internet will let employees do more of their work from home, breaking away from the work patterns imposed by the requirements of the industrial economy. For large numbers of 'knowledge employees' the daily commute is redundant.

It is in the internal and external trading relations of companies that the internet will have its major impact. Reflecting on events of the past 12 months, it is unfortunate that those with neither business knowledge nor experience have undermined the credibility of a technology that is truly revolutionary in its impact. But as with the dotcom entrepreneurs of only last year, there is the risk that the advocates of B2B may promise too much too soon. There are still technological and organisational challenges to be overcome before we reach the promised land.

Richard Scase is a Professor at Kent University and author of Britain in 2010: the Changing Business Landscape (Capstone Publishing. £9-99)

webTitle: How to get the most outof your Jobcentre

fields.headline: How to get the most outof your Jobcentre
fields.trailText: 1 Understand that both employed and unemployed people can use Jobcentres - government-run recruitment agencies. Regular visits are compulsory for claimants of Jobseeker's Allowance - but other people can look at the job boards too and ask for help in finding work.
fields.body:
1 Understand that both employed and unemployed people can use Jobcentres - government-run recruitment agencies. Regular visits are compulsory for claimants of Jobseeker's Allowance - but other people can look at the job boards too and ask for help in finding work.

2 Recognise that Jobcentres have not built up a strong reputation with white collar employers who rarely advertise posts through them. Most of the jobs advertised will be hovering above the minimum wage and few will go above £20,000 per annum. Driving jobs are in abundance, as are posts in catering, cleaning, shop and bar work and labouring.

3 Make use of the better facilities they offer but do not always publicise well. Through Employment Services Direct (tel 0845 6060 234) you can find out about jobs in other parts of the country. There is also an overseas placement division which has advertised for karaoke callers in Ibiza and cattle slaughterers in mainland Spain - but which is still trying to build up its volume of posts.

4 Get on the right side of the staff if you are claiming benefits. 'If you are nice and well-meaning that will endear you to us immediately,' says Anne, a worker in a Jobcentre. Someone polite can make a refreshing change for them from the desperate, angry people who sometimes seem to fill their offices. In a bureaucratic environment, staff can make it far more likely that you will lose your Jobseeker's Allowance if they do not like you. And you can get into trouble quickly if you do not turn up for appointments with them or if you do not attend job interviews they have arranged.

5 Comply with their requirements to look for work under the terms of Jobseeker's Allowance. If you look like a hopeless case they may not bother to check on you - but other people should be sending off the number of job applications they promise to make each week and to make the set number of phone calls. Don't, however, let yourself be pushed into unsuitable work. People who want more stimulating jobs than those Jobcentres can offer need to make their own way - rather than letting the Jobcentre find something for them.

6 Keep looking at notice boards and asking questions of the staff. New local employers will sometimes advertise there; open days are sometimes held for driving jobs or other areas of skills shortages; local initiatives and crucial IT skills courses are sometimes publicised there.
